# 孙真人备急千金要方

**Preface to Sun Zhenren’s *Essential Emergency Prescriptions Worth a Thousand Gold***

Of old, the Divine Farmer tasted a hundred herbs to discern the five bitter and six pungent flavors. Then came Yi Yin, and the preparations of decoctions were complete. The Yellow Emperor, wishing to devise the nine needles to treat the illnesses of the three yin and three yang, obtained Qi Bo, and the methods of stone needling and moxibustion were refined. Though the great sages harbored the intent to relieve the people’s suffering, they necessarily awaited ministers of wisdom and broad learning—some to precede them, others to follow—before the sages’ works could endure for all time. The affairs of medicine, having passed through these two sages and two worthies, were thus brought to completion.

Those who later devoted themselves to the arts of healing, if they knew only medicines but not moxibustion, could not fully grasp the essence of treatment; if they knew moxibustion but not acupuncture, they could not exhaust the transformations of the exterior and interior. Only one who could comprehend the profound legacy of these sages and worthies might be deemed a truly excellent physician.

Such a one was the Tang Daoist Master Sun Simiao. Possessed of the highest wisdom and bearing the aspiration to bring peace to his age, during the reign of Taizong, he pondered how to assist his sovereign in sheltering the people. He held that the Dao of the supreme physician was the true governance of the sage and one of the duties of the royal office. Thus, he inherited the teachings of Shennong and the Yellow Emperor, elucidated the learning of Qi Bo and Yi Yin, collated Bian Que’s *Classic of Difficult Issues*, adopted Cang Gong’s *Prohibitions*, studied Zhang Zhongjing’s *Yellow and Plain Writings*, Hua Tuo’s *Green Restoration*, Ge Xianweng’s *Infallible Remedies*, Layman Hu’s *Tested Methods*, Zhang Miao’s *Drug Pairings*, Wang Shuhe’s *Pulse Canon*, Huangfu Mi’s *Three Sections*, Tao Hongjing’s *One Hundred and One Remedies*, and beyond these, from Guo Yu and Fan Wang to Sengyuan and Ruan Bing, from the earliest records to the end of the Sui dynasty, whether classics or formulas, none escaped his collection.

Gathering the secret essentials of all schools and discarding what was lacking in the theories of others, he compiled a work in thirty scrolls, with one scroll of contents. It encompassed discourses on the viscera and bowels, methods of acupuncture and moxibustion, differentiation of pulses and symptoms, and the suitability of dietary therapy. Beginning with women, then infants and children, proceeding from beriberi to wind-stroke, febrile diseases, carbuncles and ulcers, wasting-thirst, edema, disorders of the seven orifices, poisoning by the five minerals, emergency remedies, and arts of nurturing life—altogether two hundred thirty-two sections, comprising five thousand three hundred formulas and discussions. None failed to be perfectly efficacious, and all four methods were encompassed. His profound virtue surpassed a thousand gold, and his transmitted methods endured for a hundred generations, ensuring that the excellence of the two sages and two worthies did not fall to the ground. Through him, the people of the world could ascend from the near to the far, and those of superior understanding could fathom the mysteries of the Three Sovereigns—such was the merit of Master Sun’s transmission.

Yet as vulgar tastes favored the strange and perverse, his Dao remained pure and upright, and he did not record bizarre practices like splitting the abdomen or exchanging the heart. As worldly affairs demanded brevity and simplicity, his book was vast and comprehensive, not to be grasped by hearsay or casual talk. Thus, few studied it, and over time it fell into disarray. Worthy successors did not arise, and the bamboo slips decayed and scattered. The uninformed dismissed it as heterodoxy, while those who cherished it abandoned their efforts in the face of doubts.

Our august dynasty, valuing life as virtue and extending love as benevolence, has commanded its scholar-officials to rectify lost learning. We, though our skills are limited, have been entrusted with the task of collation. Thereupon, we sought the imperial archives’ secret texts, explored the *Daoist Canon’s* separate records, and gathered public and private editions far and wide. We corrected errors, supplemented omissions, excised redundancies, and arranged disordered passages. Through months of effort, we organized and classified the material.

Though an overarching structure was established, some passages remained obscure. Therefore, we began by rectifying the root to order the branches, consulting works such as the *Plain Questions*, *Nine Regions*, *Spiritual Pivot*, *A-B Canon*, *Grand Simplicity*, *Origins of Diseases*, various materia medica, ancient pulse texts, *Golden Casket and Jade Case*, *Handbook of Emergency Remedies*, Xie Shiqin’s *Condensed Formulas*, Liu Juanzi’s *Ghost-Bequeathed Treatise*, and the like. Every source was meticulously examined. Where gaps remained, we traced the streams back to their sources, consulting works such as the *Five Mirrors Classic*, *Supplement to the Thousand Gold*, Cui’s *Essentials*, *Secret Records for Extending Life*, *Broad Benefits of the Zhengyuan Era*, *Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library*, *Military Ministry’s Handbook*, and *Dream’s Verified Transmissions*. All distinctions were scrutinized, and every principle was investigated. Through mutual verification and repeated comparison, the obscure passages and doubtful meanings were at last clarified.

Though the book is old, its use is ever new. It can succor living beings and aid the sagely governance that cherishes life; it can be transmitted immortally, fulfilling the sovereign’s aspiration to extend boundless love. Not merely an ornament of a peaceful age, it truly assists the imperial bestowal of blessings.

Now that the collation is complete and the transcription begun, we respectfully present it for Your Majesty’s perusal.

Respectfully submitted by:
Minister Gao Baoheng, Right Advisor to the Crown Prince;
Minister Sun Qi, Attendant Gentleman of the Ministry of Justice;
Minister Lin Yi, Collator of the Secret Pavilion and Gentleman of the Ministry of Rites;
Minister Qian Xiangxian, Vice Minister of Works and Concurrent Lecturer to the Emperor.

**Original Preface**

When the clear and turbid were first separated and the above and below were distinguished, the Three Powers took form, and the Five Phases descended in order. All things were in pristine simplicity, beyond any designation.

When the Firesage emerged, he observed the Dipper and Pole to determine the cardinal directions and names, first bringing forth the transformations of fire. Fu Xi arose, and following this, drew the Eight Trigrams and established the kitchen. As flavors flourished, the art of healing began to sprout. The Great Sage Divine Farmer, moved by the multitude of ailments among the common people, tasted the hundred herbs to save and cure them—yet this was still not entirely perfected. When the Yellow Emperor received the Mandate, he devised the nine needles and, with the alchemist Qi Bo, Thunder Duke, and their peers, exhaustively discussed the channels and vessels. Through extensive inquiry and debate, they thoroughly explored the principles and established them as canonical treatises, so that later generations might rely upon and expound them.

During the Spring and Autumn period, the skilled physicians He and Huan flourished; in the time of the Six States, Bian Que appeared. The Han saw Zhang Zhongjing and Cang Gong, while the Wei had Hua Tuo—all of whom traced hidden patterns, plumbed the profound and subtle, using no more than two or three medicinals, and no more than seven or eight moxa cones, yet left no illness uncured. From the Jin and Song dynasties onward, though renowned physicians continued to emerge, they could cure no more than five or six out of ten cases. This is largely because people of today indulge their desires excessively, lack constancy of mind, and abandon themselves to dissipation, failing in the art of nurturing life.

I have long pondered the sagely teachings, which sought to enable every household to study and every person to understand: if one’s lord or parents fall ill and cannot be healed, this is no true loyalty or filial piety. Yet petty men of this degenerate age, practicing deceit and cunning, lean upon sagely teachings to perpetrate fraud. Thus, both court and common folk alike disdain the name of medicine and healing. They teach their sons and younger brothers to recite short texts and compose minor essays in pursuit of official advancement, while the art of healing is neglected and left undiscussed—how strange indeed!

Alas! This deeply betrays the original intent of the sages and worthies.

In my youth, I suffered from wind and chills, repeatedly seeking the doors of physicians, until the costs of decoctions and medicines exhausted my family’s wealth. Thus, from my green-tied years, I esteemed this canon; even in my hoary-headed age, I have never set aside its scrolls. As for pulse-taking and diagnosis, gathering herbs and compounding remedies, regulating ingestion and convalescence, and all matters of caution and care—wherever I found one thing in which another excelled, I would journey a thousand *li* to bow in reverence and seek resolution. By the time I reached my twentieth year, I began to perceive some understanding. Thereafter, among my kin and neighbors, near and far, those afflicted with illness or distress often found relief through my aid. As for my own ailments, I severed all reliance on physicians’ doors—thus I knew that formulas, remedies, and materia medica could not be left unstudied.

Yet I observed that the vast array of medical formulas was boundless and vast; when sudden illness struck, searching for the right prescription proved exceedingly difficult. By the time the formula was found, the disease had already become untreatable. Alas! Grieved by the unseen suffering of premature deaths, and lamenting the benighted folly of abandoned learning, I broadly gathered the many classics, pruning their redundancies, and striving for simplicity and ease, to compose the *Essential Formulas for Emergencies [Worth] a Thousand in Gold*, in over thirty scrolls. Though it cannot exhaustively probe the origins of all diseases, those who devote attention to it may yet grasp more than half.

I hold that human life is of utmost weight, more precious than a thousand in gold; a single formula that saves a life attains virtue surpassing this, and thus I have given it this name. It is not yet fit for transmission among the scholar-official class, but may perhaps be bequeathed to my own household.

Zhang Zhongjing said: “The scholars of this present age scarcely turn their minds to medicine and remedies, nor do they delve deeply into formulas and therapies. Above, they fail to heal the illnesses of their lords and parents; below, they fail to rescue the poor and humble from distress; and in their own persons, they fail to preserve their health and prolong their lives. Instead, they vie for glory and power, straining to stand among the mighty, ceaselessly striving, ever fixated on fame and profit. They adorn the branches while neglecting the root, seeking to embellish their outward appearance while withering within.”

When the skin no longer exists, where shall the hair adhere? Advancing, they cannot cherish others or understand things; retreating, they cannot cherish themselves or know their own nature. Suddenly encountering the qi of wind and pathogenic influences, they contract extraordinary illnesses. Once calamity and misfortune arrive, only then do they tremble in fear—standing upon the brink of death, muddled and confused, drifting like lost souls. They humble their aspirations and lower their pride, reverently gazing upon shamans and priests, confessing their helplessness and resigning to fate, submitting passively to defeat. Entrusting a lifespan of a hundred years and the most precious of vessels—the body—to mediocre physicians, they allow them free rein. Alas! Too late for regret! Lamenting as the body perishes, the spirit vanishes, transformed into something other, buried in the depths of the Yellow Springs, leaving only sorrow. How grievous! The whole world remains deluded, none awakening to the truth, abandoning themselves thus—what glory or power is there to speak of? This is what is meant.

**On the Study of Medicine**

**I. On the Great Physician’s Learning**

Those who aspire to become great physicians must be thoroughly versed in the *Plain Questions*, *A-B Classic*, *Yellow Emperor’s Needle Classic*, *Bright Hall Flowing Circulation*, the twelve meridians, the three regions and nine indicators, the five viscera and six bowels, exterior and interior points, the *Materia Medica*, and *Drug Pairings*, as well as the classical formulas of Zhang Zhongjing, Wang Shuhe, Ruan Henan, Fan Dongyang, Zhang Miao, Zhan Shao, and others.

They must also master the subtleties of yin-yang, fate and fortune, the physiognomic arts of various schools, divination by scorched tortoise shells and the five omens, and the *Book of Changes* and Six Ren methods—all must be studied with precision. Only then may one be called a great physician. Without such learning, one is like a blind man wandering at night, stumbling and falling at every step.

Next, one must study these formulas diligently, pondering their profound principles and devoting oneself to their exploration. Only then may one speak of the Dao of medicine.

Furthermore, one must peruse a wide range of books. Why? Without reading the Five Classics, one cannot know the Way of benevolence and righteousness. Without reading the Three Histories, one cannot understand the affairs of past and present. Without reading the various philosophers, one cannot silently comprehend matters as they arise. Without reading the *Inner Classic*, one cannot grasp the virtue of compassion, joy, and renunciation. Without reading the *Zhuangzi* and *Laozi*, one cannot embody spontaneity and natural movement—otherwise, good and ill fortune will be bound by taboos, arising at every turn.

As for the waxing and waning of the five phases and the celestial patterns of the seven luminaries, one must delve deeply into their mysteries. If one can study all these comprehensively, then in the Dao of medicine, nothing will obstruct or hinder, and one may achieve perfection.

**II. On the Great Physician’s Sincerity and Dedication**

Zhang Zhan said: The difficulty of mastering classical formulas has long been acknowledged. Now, diseases may appear similar externally yet differ internally, or differ internally yet appear similar externally. Thus, the fullness or emptiness of the five viscera and six bowels, the patency or blockage of the blood vessels and defensive qi, cannot be discerned by the eyes and ears alone—one must first examine and assess them through diagnosis.

Yet the pulses at the inch, bar, and cubit positions may be confused by floating, sinking, wiry, or tight qualities; the flow of qi through the transport points may vary in height, depth, shallowness, or profundity; the skin, flesh, sinews, and bones may differ in thickness, thinness, hardness, or softness. Only those who apply their minds with utmost precision may speak of these matters.

Now, to seek the most refined and subtle principles through the coarsest and shallowest thoughts—how perilous! If one supplements what is already full, depletes what is already empty, drains what is already unobstructed, or obstructs what is already blocked, cools what is already cold, or warms what is already hot, one only aggravates the illness and hopes for recovery—I foresee only death.

Thus, medicine, divination, and the arts are among the most difficult to master. Since they are not divinely bestowed, how can one grasp their hidden subtleties?

There are fools in the world who, after reading formulas for three years, claim there is no disease they cannot cure. Yet after treating diseases for three years, they realize there is no formula they can rely upon. Therefore, students must exhaustively explore the origins of medicine, diligently and tirelessly, without merely heeding hearsay and claiming to have mastered the Dao of medicine—how deeply they deceive themselves!

When a great physician treats illness, he must first calm his spirit and settle his mind, free from desires and demands. He must first arouse a heart of great compassion and empathy, vowing to universally relieve the suffering of all living beings.

When those afflicted by illness or misfortune come seeking help, he must not inquire into their status—whether noble or base, rich or poor, old or young, beautiful or ugly, friend or foe, Chinese or foreign, foolish or wise. He must regard them all equally, as if they were his closest kin.

He must not look ahead or behind, worrying about his own fortune or misfortune, or cherishing his own life. Seeing their suffering, he must feel as if it were his own, his heart filled with sorrow and distress. He must not avoid perilous paths, day or night, cold or heat, hunger or thirst, fatigue or exhaustion, but devote himself wholeheartedly to their rescue, without any thought of making a show of his efforts.

Only thus may one be called a great physician for the people. To act otherwise is to be a great bandit to all living beings.

Since ancient times, renowned physicians have often used living creatures to save those in critical condition. Though one may say that human life is more valuable than that of animals, when it comes to cherishing life, humans and animals are the same. To harm one to benefit another is a grievance shared by all beings—how much more so for humans!

To take life in pursuit of saving life only distances one further from life. This is why my formulas do not use living creatures as medicine. As for creatures like horseflies and leeches, if they are already dead when purchased from the market, they may be used—this is not the same.

Even something like a chicken egg, though it is in a state of undifferentiated chaos, must only be used in cases of great urgency and necessity, and even then with reluctance. Those who can avoid using it altogether are truly wise, though this may not always be possible.

When encountering patients with festering sores, dysentery, or foul and repulsive conditions that others find unbearable to look upon, one must only arouse feelings of shame, pity, and deep concern, without the slightest trace of aversion or disgust—this is my aspiration.

The demeanor of a great physician should be one of serene concentration and inward reflection, appearing solemn and dignified. His bearing should be expansive and magnanimous, neither ostentatious nor obscure.

When examining and diagnosing illness, he must apply his mind with utmost care and depth, scrutinizing the patient’s condition with meticulous attention, not missing even the slightest detail. When prescribing acupuncture or medicine, he must do so without the slightest error.

Though illness demands swift treatment, one must remain unconfused in the moment. One must carefully deliberate and ponder deeply, never rashly displaying cleverness or seeking fame at the expense of a patient’s life—this would be most unbenevolent.

When visiting a patient’s home, even if fine silks and brocades fill the eyes, one must not glance left or right. Though music may fill the ears, one must not appear to take pleasure in it. Though delicacies may be served, one must eat as if they had no taste. Though fine wines may be offered, one must regard them as if they were not there.

Thus it is that when one person grieves in a corner, the entire hall cannot rejoice—how much more so when a patient endures suffering without respite, while the physician remains at ease, indulging in merriment or complacency? Such conduct is a shared disgrace before both humanity and the divine, and the perfected would never act thus. This is the foundational intent of medicine.

The principles of being a physician forbid excessive speech, jesting, boisterous laughter, gossiping about right and wrong, judging others, flaunting one’s reputation, slandering fellow physicians, or boasting of one’s own virtue. Should one happen to cure a single ailment, one must not raise one’s head with an air of self-satisfaction, proclaiming oneself peerless in the world—this is the fatal flaw of the medical profession.

Lao Jun said: "One who performs yang virtue is repaid by others; one who performs yin virtue is repaid by spirits and gods. One who commits yang evil is repaid by others; one who commits yin evil is harmed by spirits and gods." Examining these two paths—yin and yang retribution—how could this be false?

Therefore, a physician must not rely on personal skill to scheme for wealth, but should act with a heart of relieving suffering. In the unseen workings of the Dao, such conduct naturally attracts abundant blessings. Nor should one, upon seeing a patient’s wealth and status, prescribe rare and costly medicines to make them difficult to obtain, merely to display one’s own abilities—this is hardly the way of loyalty and forbearance.

With the intent to save and aid, I have discussed these matters in such detail, though the words may seem coarse. Let the learner not disdain their plainness.

**On the General Principles of Treating Illness, Section Three**

Heaven spreads the five phases to nurture the ten thousand things; humans receive the five constants to form the five viscera. Through the channels, network vessels, and visceral conduits, yin and yang intermingle, their mysterious and subtle transformations boundless. As the *Yi* states: "Without the utmost profundity of the world, who could engage with this?"

Yet today’s physicians do not seek to study the classics’ essentials to expand their knowledge. Each relies on familial techniques, adhering rigidly to tradition. When examining and inquiring about illness, they focus on glib speech, facing the patient for but a moment before prescribing decoctions. They press the inch pulse but neglect the foot; they grasp the hand but ignore the foot vessels. The three positions—Renying, Fuyang, and the three divisions—are not cross-referenced. Breaths and beats do not reach fifty; short-term prognoses remain undetermined. The nine indicators are barely glimpsed, and the features of the Ming Tang and Que Ting are entirely unobserved. This is nothing more than "peering through a tube." How then can one distinguish life from death? This is the deepest caution for physicians. Patients must carefully examine such matters and guard against them.

Since ancient times, physicians have harbored mutual jealousy. Bian Que was murdered by Li Xi, the imperial physician of Qin—such is the evidence. When one physician prescribes a formula, another must not be allowed to compound it. If poison is secretly added, the patient’s condition may worsen, gradually leading to debilitation. Such cases are not rare; one must be especially vigilant. Better to forgo the medicine and rely on natural vitality than to let foolish physicians, consumed by envy, endanger a life—how lamentable this is.

The roots of the hundred diseases include wind-stroke, cold damage, alternating chills and fever, warm malaria, sudden affliction, cholera, abdominal distension, water swelling, intestinal obstruction, dysentery, urinary and fecal blockage, running piglet qi, counterflow qi, coughing, retching, vomiting, jaundice, wasting-thirst, retained fluids, food stagnation, hard accumulations, concretions and conglomerations, fright-induced epilepsy, ghost possession, throat impediment, toothache, deafness, blindness, metal wounds, fractures, abscesses, malignant sores, hemorrhoids, fistulas, tumors, and goiters. In men, the five taxations, seven injuries, deficiency, emaciation, and weakness; in women, vaginal discharge, flooding and spotting, blood block, and yin erosion. Injuries from insects, snakes, and gu poison—these are the general categories. Their variations and branches must be traced to their origins for treatment.

Additionally, there are cold, heat, taxation damage, overeating, sexual exhaustion, fright, palpitations, fear, sorrow, and anxiety. There are also childbirth, lactation, miscarriage, and stagnant blood from falls. Some seek pleasure in the bedchamber through the reckless consumption of the five minerals. These are the root sources of illness, from which countless branches and leaves of suffering arise. One cannot be ignorant of their beginnings and ends.

However, when a physician speaks of a patient’s condition—whether male or female, young or old—if half of it aligns with the disease’s origin, medicine may be administered.

Men, as the convergence of all yang, typically dwell in dryness. Their yang qi moves freely, and through strenuous exertion and ejaculation, they readily develop taxation and depletion disorders—such cases are numerous. Compared to women, their illnesses are ten times easier to treat.

Generally, once a girl reaches fourteen, she begins menstruation. If she encounters wind, cold, dampness, or heat during her menses, or if the four seasons’ illnesses coincide with it, she should disclose this. Otherwise, treatment may inadvertently clash with her condition, worsening her state. The prescriber should also inquire about this.

All medicines should be chosen according to the land’s suitability. In Jiangnan and the regions south of the Five Ridges, the climate is hot and humid, and the people have thin, delicate skin with loose interstices—medicines should be mild and minimal. In Guanzhong and Hebei, the land is hard and dry, and the people have tough skin with tight interstices—medicines should be stronger and more substantial.

Some in the prime of life, heedless of wind and dampness, violate prohibitions, and recklessly deplete their essence. Even with minor illnesses, they must not be lightly purged with potent medicines. A single excessive purge can exhaust their essence, leaving them bedridden for months or years.

For chronic illnesses, purgative decoctions may be used, but the full dose need not be taken. Once the purging is sufficient, stop. If the disease’s root remains, the formula may be repeated later. If the patient has some strength to endure the full dose, this need not be considered.

When the disease’s root requires purgative decoctions for removal, after purging, pills and powders should be administered periodically to assist. If a patient recovers after taking a purgative decoction, they must thereafter avoid tonic decoctions. If tonics are taken, the disease may return. Further purging would then inflict additional harm.

If the patient has just recovered but their qi and strength have not fully returned to balance, simply observe their condition carefully. Should medication be necessary, use mild remedies to harmonize them. For those with chronic ailments who are still able to walk and whose strength has not declined, if they wish to take restorative tonics—whether warming or cooling pills and powders—it is first proper to administer purgative decoctions to eliminate accumulations of phlegm and stagnation in the chest and abdomen. Only afterward may tonics be taken.

For those suffering from extreme depletion and taxation requiring restorative decoctions, no more than three doses should be given before stopping. If treating wind disorders with wind-dispelling decoctions, however, three or five doses are not sufficient to gauge their effect. Some cases involve persistent wind and profound deficiency, requiring ten or more doses, even extending to a hundred days or more before recovery is achieved. Thus it is said: for excess, purge; for deficiency, tonify.

Within the two modes of yin and yang, among all things, humans are most noble. Humans receive the harmonious qi of Heaven and Earth, and all laws, rituals, and music originate from them. At the beginning of life, essence is formed first, and once essence is complete, the brain and marrow come into being. The head is round, modeling Heaven; the feet are square, resembling Earth. The eyes correspond to the sun and moon; the five viscera align with the five stars; the six bowels follow the six pitch-pipes; and the heart serves as the central axis. The large intestine is twelve feet long, corresponding to the twelve hours; the small intestine is twenty-four feet long, corresponding to the twenty-four qi. The body has three hundred sixty-five collaterals, matching the days of the year. Humans possess nine orifices, corresponding to the nine provinces. Heaven has cold and heat; humans have deficiency and excess. Heaven has punishment and virtue; humans have love and aversion. Heaven has yin and yang; humans have male and female. The moon waxes and wanes; humans vary in height.

Thus, when the consumption of the five grains lacks moderation, cold and heat, saltiness and bitterness clash and collide, jointly assaulting the body to transform into illness. Generally, the art of medical diagnosis and examination is by no means easy. Yet one who, through inquiry, discerns the depth of an ailment is called a skillful physician.

Master Zhongjing said: Whenever preparing decoctions or compounding medicines, or applying the methods of acupuncture and moxibustion, one must reflect with utmost care. It is essential to thoroughly understand the twelve meridians, distinguish the three hundred sixty acupoints, and comprehend the circulation of *ying* and *wei* qi to identify the location of the disease and the appropriate method of treatment—this knowledge cannot be lacking.

In ancient times, superior physicians examined complexion: the color of the complexion and the pulse must not diverge from the physical form. If black overrides red, death follows; if red overrides green, life remains. Mediocre physicians listened to the voice: when the voice harmonized with the five notes, fire hearing the sound of water caused vexation and fright; wood hearing the sound of metal induced fear and mutual punishment.

The spleen corresponds to earth, nurturing the myriad things and aiding the four directions. When it is well, its presence is unseen; when it fails, all return to it. If it is in excess, the four limbs cannot be lifted; if it is deficient, the nine orifices become obstructed. The six senses grow blocked, leaving one as if intoxicated. The four seasons revolve, ending only to begin anew.

Inferior physicians diagnose by pulse, discerning the origin of disease, its flow and movement, the reversal or compliance of the four seasons, and the mutual harm or generation among the five phases. By carefully examining the subtleties of the viscera and bowels, they achieve mastery.

**On Diagnosis and Examination, Chapter Four**
To treat illness, one must first investigate its source and observe the mechanism of the disease. If the five viscera are not yet depleted, the six bowels not yet exhausted, the blood and vessels not yet disordered, and the spirit not yet scattered, then with medicinal treatment, life is surely preserved. If the disease has already taken form, only half may be cured. Once the momentum of the illness has passed, life becomes difficult to save.

The method of diagnosis is customarily performed at dawn, when *yin* qi has not yet stirred, *yang* qi has not yet dispersed, food has not been consumed, the meridians are not yet full, the network vessels are balanced, and the *qi* and blood are undisturbed. Only then may one take the pulse to discern its compliance or reversal. This is not to be done at other times—one must carefully examine the three positions and nine indicators before clearly declaring the condition.

The ancients skilled in medicine were thus: superior physicians healed the state, mediocre physicians healed people, and inferior physicians healed diseases. It is also said: superior physicians listen to the voice, mediocre physicians observe the complexion, and inferior physicians diagnose by pulse. Further, it is said: superior physicians treat the disease that has not yet arisen, mediocre physicians treat the disease that is about to arise, and inferior physicians treat the disease that has already arisen. If one does not apply the mind with care and intention, matters become confused, and the patient becomes difficult to save.

What are the three positions? They are the *cun*, *guan*, and *chi*. The upper position corresponds to heaven and the lungs; the middle position corresponds to humanity and the spleen; the lower position corresponds to earth and the kidneys.

What are the nine indicators? Each position has three, making nine in total. In the upper position (heaven): the arteries at the two temples govern the *qi* of the head and corners; in the upper position (earth): the arteries at the two cheeks govern the *qi* of the mouth and teeth; in the upper position (humanity): the arteries before the ears govern the *qi* of the ears and eyes. In the middle position (heaven): the hand *Taiyin* governs the *qi* of the lungs; in the middle position (earth): the hand *Yangming* governs the *qi* of the chest; in the middle position (humanity): the hand *Shaoyin* governs the *qi* of the heart. In the lower position (heaven): the foot *Jueyin* governs the *qi* of the liver; in the lower position (earth): the foot *Shaoyin* governs the *qi* of the kidneys; in the lower position (humanity): the foot *Taiyin* governs the *qi* of the spleen. Together, these form the nine indicators.

When the body is robust but the pulse is faint, and one is short of breath and unable to breathe, death follows. When the body is emaciated but the pulse is large, and the chest is full of *qi*, death follows. When form and *qi* are in harmony, life remains. When the three (positions) and five (phases) are disharmonious, illness arises. When the three positions and nine indicators all diverge, death follows.

Foolish physicians, ignorant of the three positions and nine indicators, as well as the meridians of the four seasons, may mistakenly administer decoctions or misapply acupuncture and moxibustion. Though they follow prescriptions to treat illness, they instead exacerbate other ailments, leading to ruin. Alas for the suffering people—half die wrongfully. How lamentable that the world lacks good physicians to explain these principles.

The classics state: Earth, water, fire, and wind combine to form a person. When the *qi* of fire is unregulated, the entire body steams with heat. When the *qi* of wind is unregulated, the whole body stiffens, and all the pores become blocked. When the *qi* of water is unregulated, the body swells, the *qi* becomes full, and breathing grows coarse. When the *qi* of earth is unregulated, the four limbs cannot be lifted, and speech loses its sound. When fire departs, the body grows cold; when wind ceases, the *qi* is cut off; when water is exhausted, there is no blood; when earth scatters, the body splits apart.

Yet foolish physicians, failing to consider the pathways of the pulse, treat the disease in reverse, causing the five phases within the viscera to mutually overcome one another. It is like adding oil to a raging fire—one cannot be too cautious. When the four *qi* harmonize in virtue and the four spirits are at peace, is there not tranquility? If even one *qi* is unregulated, one hundred and one diseases arise. When the four spirits stir, four hundred and four diseases erupt simultaneously.

It is also said: One hundred and one diseases heal on their own; one hundred and one diseases require treatment to heal; one hundred and one diseases are difficult to heal even with treatment; and one hundred and one diseases are truly incurable and fatal.

Master Zhang Zhongjing said: To treat various diseases, one should first use decoctions to purge the five viscera and six bowels, open the meridians, regulate *yin* and *yang*, disperse pathogenic *qi*, moisten what is withered, enliven the skin, and replenish the *qi* and blood. Water can cleanse all things, hence the use of decoctions. If the limbs have been afflicted for a long time and wind-cold stirs, next one should use powders, for powders can expel pathogenic *qi*. When wind, dampness, and impediment move between the exterior and interior without fixed location, powders are used to balance them. Next, one should use pills, for pills can dispel wind-cold, break up accumulations, dissolve hard masses, promote appetite, and harmonize *ying* and *wei*. One who can skillfully combine and apply these methods may be called a superior physician.

Thus it is said: Medicine is intention. It is also said: To force sweating when it is not needed depletes the fluids, leading to desiccation and death. To withhold sweating when it is needed causes the pores to close, leading to suffocation and death.

Moreover, to force purgation when it is not needed opens the intestines, causing uncontrollable diarrhea and death; to withhold purgation when it is needed causes internal vexation, distension, fullness, and restlessness, leading to swelling and death. To force moxibustion when it is not needed allows fire-pathogens to enter the abdomen, scorching and disrupting the five viscera, compounding vexation and leading to death; to withhold moxibustion when it is needed causes cold congealment to thicken, growing ever more stubborn, with *qi* surging upward to the heart, leaving no place for dissipation, and the illness becomes critical, leading to death.

The Yellow Emperor asked: What of excessive and wandering pathogenic *qi*?
Qibo replied: When proper pathogenic *qi* invades from without, it has no fixed abode, and when it overflows into the viscera, it finds no settled place. It moves together with *ying* and *wei*, and with the *hun* and *po* in flight, causing one to lie restless and dream excessively. When *qi* overflows into the bowels, it becomes excessive externally and insufficient internally; when *qi* overflows into the viscera, it becomes excessive internally and insufficient externally.

The Emperor asked: Do excess and insufficiency have physical manifestations?
Qibo replied: When *yin* is exuberant, one dreams of wading through great waters in fear; when *yang* is exuberant, one dreams of treading in great fires and being scorched. When both *yin* and *yang* are exuberant, one dreams of mutual killing and destruction. When the upper is exuberant, one dreams of flying; when the lower is exuberant, one dreams of falling. When overly sated, one dreams of giving; when overly hungry, one dreams of receiving. When liver *qi* is exuberant, one dreams of anger; when lung *qi* is exuberant, one dreams of fear, weeping, and wailing; when heart *qi* is exuberant, one dreams of joy, laughter, and terror; when spleen *qi* is exuberant, one dreams of singing, music, heaviness, and inability to lift the hands and feet; when kidney *qi* is exuberant, one dreams of the waist and spine separating and disconnecting. For these eleven cases of exuberance, promptly draining them brings immediate resolution.

When perverse *qi* lodges in the heart, one dreams of hills and mountains with smoke and fire; when it lodges in the lungs, one dreams of flying and seeing strange objects of metal and iron; when it lodges in the liver, one dreams of mountains, forests, and trees; when it lodges in the spleen, one dreams of hills, marshes, collapsing houses, and wind and rain; when it lodges in the kidneys, one dreams of standing at the edge of an abyss or being submerged in water; when it lodges in the bladder, one dreams of wandering; when it lodges in the stomach, one dreams of eating and drinking; when it lodges in the large intestine, one dreams of fields and wilds; when it lodges in the small intestine, one dreams of crowded towns and streets; when it lodges in the gallbladder, one dreams of fighting, litigation, and self-mutilation; when it lodges in the genitals, one dreams of intercourse and internal struggle; when it lodges in the nape, one dreams of decapitation; when it lodges in the hips, one dreams of walking without progress, or dwelling in ponds, ditches, wells, or pits; when it lodges in the thighs, one dreams of rituals, bowing, and kneeling; when it lodges in the bladder and rectum, one dreams of drowning or relieving oneself. For these fifteen cases of insufficiency, promptly supplementing them brings immediate resolution. The skilled diagnostician may deeply ponder this principle to achieve perfection.

The *Records of the Grand Historian* states: There are six conditions that render illness untreatable. First, arrogance and self-indulgence without regard for reason; second, valuing wealth over one’s own body; third, inability to properly regulate clothing and diet; fourth, *yin* and *yang* both in disorder with unsettled visceral *qi*; fifth, extreme emaciation preventing the taking of medicine; sixth, belief in shamans and not in physicians. While the signs of life remain, the complexion has not yet changed, and the illness has not yet penetrated the interstices, timely acupuncture and medicine, proper regulation, and entrusting oneself to a good physician ensure that no illness will not be cured.

**On Prescribing Formulas, Fifth Section**
To treat cold with hot medicines, to treat heat with cold medicines, to treat undigested food with emetic and purgative medicines, to treat *gu* toxins and demonic infestations with *gu* toxin medicines, to treat abscesses, swellings, sores, and tumors with medicines for sores and tumors, to treat wind-dampness with wind-dampness medicines—each is applied according to what is appropriate.

Leigong said: Medicines have three grades, and illnesses have three stages. Medicines vary in sweetness and bitterness, lightness and heaviness. Illnesses differ in being recent or long-standing, cold or warm. Heavy, hot, greasy, slippery, salty, intoxicating medicines, minerals, and foods are suitable for wind illnesses, but not for others. Light, cold, coarse, astringent, sweet, and bitter medicines, herbs, and foods are suitable for heat illnesses, but not for others. Light, hot, acrid, bitter, bland medicines and foods are suitable for cold illnesses, but not for others. These are the general principles, briefly revealing their origins. The rest may be discerned by observing the condition, and one should act appropriately according to the circumstances, keeping these essentials in mind.

The *Materia Medica Pairings* states: All accumulations and gatherings of illnesses arise from deficiency, and deficiency gives rise to the hundred illnesses. Accumulations are what the five viscera accumulate; gatherings are what the six bowels gather. For such illnesses, most follow established formulas without need for modification. For those deficient and taxed, the manifestations are myriad, and one should adjust according to the illness.

The good physicians of old all gathered their own medicines, examining their natures and what they governed, and selecting the proper time and season, early or late. If too early, the medicinal potency is not yet formed; if too late, the peak potency has already waned. Today’s physicians do not gather their own medicines, nor do they consider the timing of the seasons, merely collecting them together to use as medicine. Moreover, they do not understand the dynamics of cold and heat or the proper dosages, merely harboring the intention to treat illness without achieving certain cure—this is truly delusory. I have briefly examined their cold and heat properties and recorded their principal modifications.

For deficiency taxation with headache and recurrent heat, add *gouqi* and *wei rui*; for deficiency with vomiting, add ginseng; for deficiency with restlessness, also add ginseng; for deficiency with many confused dreams, add *longgu*; for deficiency with much heat, add *dihuang*, *muli*, *difuzi*, and licorice; for deficiency with cold, add *danggui*, *xiongqiong*, and dried ginger; for deficiency with depletion, add stalactite, *jici*, *roucongrong*, and *bajitian*.

For deficiency with high fever, add *huangqin* and *tianmendong*; for deficiency with forgetfulness, add *fushen* and *yuanzhi*; for deficiency with fright palpitations and restlessness, add *longchi*, *zishiying*, *shashen*, and *xiaocao*—if cold predominates, use *zishiying* and *xiaocao*; if external heat is present, use *shashen* and *longchi*; if neither cold nor heat is evident, omit them. For deficiency with dry mouth, add *maimendong* and *zhimu*; for deficiency with shortness of breath, add *huma*, *fupenzi*, and *baiziren*; for deficiency with excessive qi and slight cough, add *wuweizi* and *dazao*; for deficiency with bodily stiffness and lumbar discomfort, add *cishi* and *duzhong*; for deficiency with pronounced cold, add *guixin*, *wuzhuyu*, *fuzi*, and *wutou*; for deficiency with dark urine, add *huangqin*; for deficiency with external heat, add *digupi* and *baishuihuangqi*; for deficiency with cold, use *longxihuangqi*; for deficiency with phlegm and qi stagnation, add fresh ginger, *banxia*, and *zhishi*; for deficiency with frequent urination, add *sangpiaoxiao*, *longgu*, and *jijitun*; for deficiency with urinary difficulty, add *fuling* and *zexie*; for deficiency with white dysentery, add *houpo*.

None of these medicinals should be used exhaustively one by one; rather, one must assess the patient’s constitution and the dynamics of cold and heat, selecting those that directly address the condition. This brief account touches only on modifications at the margins—those who compose prescriptions should take this as their standard.

**On the Use of Medicinals, Sixth Section**
The 120 superior medicinals serve as sovereigns, governing the nourishment of life in accord with Heaven. They are non-toxic, and even prolonged or frequent use does no harm. Those who seek to lighten the body, augment qi, prevent aging, and prolong life should base their practice on the *Upper Canon*.

The 120 middle medicinals serve as ministers, governing the cultivation of nature in accord with humanity. Whether toxic or non-toxic, their use must be carefully weighed. Those who seek to suppress illness and replenish deficiency should base their practice on the *Middle Canon*.

The 125 inferior medicinals serve as assistants and envoys, governing the treatment of illness in accord with Earth. They are often toxic and should not be taken for long. Those who seek to dispel cold and heat pathogenic qi, break up accumulations, and cure disease should base their practice on the *Lower Canon*.

The three ranks together comprise 365 medicinals, corresponding to the 365 degrees of the celestial cycle, each degree aligning with a single day to complete a year. Doubling this number yields 730 names.

In all medicinals, there are sovereigns, ministers, assistants, and envoys, which interact through mutual enhancement and regulation when combined. A proper formula may consist of one sovereign, two ministers, three assistants, and five envoys—or alternatively, one sovereign, three ministers, and nine assistants and envoys.

Further, there are yin-yang pairings, mother-child and sibling relationships, roots and stems, flowers and fruits, herbs and stones, bones and flesh. Some act alone, while others require mutual reinforcement, mutual assistance, mutual restraint, mutual aversion, mutual opposition, or mutual detoxification. These seven interactions must be carefully considered when combining medicinals. Those that reinforce or assist each other are optimal; those that are mutually averse or opposed should not be used together. If toxicity must be moderated, one may employ those that restrain or detoxify each other—otherwise, they should not be combined.

Additionally, there are the five flavors—sour, salty, sweet, bitter, and acrid—and the four qi—cold, hot, warm, and cool—as well as distinctions between toxic and non-toxic, yin-dried and sun-dried, the timing of harvesting, raw and prepared states, the land of origin, and whether the medicinal is genuine or counterfeit, aged or fresh. Each of these follows its own principles.

The seven interactions of mutual assistance and mutual restraint are listed below. When composing prescriptions, one must study them deeply.
