Moxibustion methods:
For uncontrollable uterine bleeding, apply moxibustion to points three *cun* bilateral to *Guanyuan*.
For vaginal pain radiating to the heart and lower abdomen, colicky abdominal pain, and internal cold, apply one hundred moxa cones to *Guanyi*, located one *cun* above the lateral knee.
For red, white, or bloody uterine discharge, apply fifty moxa cones to the Foot Greater Yin meridian, three *cun* above the medial malleolus (*Sanyinjiao*).
For red and white uterine discharge and irregular menstruation, apply thirty moxa cones to *Jiaoyi*, five *cun* above the medial malleolus.
For red and white uterine discharge, apply thirty moxa cones to *Yingchi* (four points), located in the depressions anterior and posterior to the medial malleolus (*Yinyang*).
For red and white uterine discharge with emaciation and weakness, apply thirty moxa cones to *Louyin*, located five *fen* below the medial malleolus on the pulsating vessel.
For red and white uterine discharge with diarrhea, apply moxibustion to *Yinyang* according to age, repeated thrice, located at the white flesh border beneath the flexed big toe.
Formula Four for menstrual irregularities – Moxibustion

*Baie* pills for irregular menstruation (twice monthly, delayed, scanty, or profuse), persistent spotting, or accompanied by lumbar and abdominal pain, sighing, inability to eat, abdominal pain, or discharge of blue, yellow, black, or watery fluid, with generalized heaviness:
[Text incomplete]

**Baie Pills** for menstrual irregularities:
White chalk (*baie*), halloysite clay (*baishizhi*), oyster shell (*muli*), limonite (*yuyugen*), dragon bone (*longgu*), asarum (*xixin*), cuttlebone (*wuizeigu*)—one and a half *liang* each; Chinese angelica (*danggui*), peony (*shaoyao*), coptis (*huanglian*), poria (*fuling*), dried ginger (*ganjiang*), cinnamon bark (*guixin*), ginseng (*renshen*), fringed pink (*qumai*), pyrrosia leaf (*shiwei*), angelica root (*baizhi*), ampelopsis (*bailian*), aconite (*fuzi*), licorice (*gancao*)—one *liang* each; Sichuan pepper (*shujiao*)—half a *liang*. Grind the twenty-one ingredients into powder, mix with honey, and form pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take twenty pills on an empty stomach with wine, three times daily. When menstruation is due, take four or five doses daily for best results.

**Peach Kernel Decoction** for postpartum or miscarriage-related menstrual irregularities, persistent spotting, or sudden cessation followed by profuse flow resembling watery diarrhea, accompanied by sighing, inability to eat, abdominal hardness and pain preventing movement, irregular cycles (early, late, or absent for months), generalized heaviness, and constant desire to sleep or crave sour foods:
Fifty peach kernels (*taoren*), three *liang* each of *zelan*, licorice (*gancao*), chuanxiong (*xiongqiong*), ginseng (*renshen*), achyranthes (*niuxi*), cinnamon bark (*guixin*), moutan bark (*mudanpi*), and Chinese angelica (*danggui*); four *liang* each of peony (*shaoyao*), fresh ginger (*shengjiang*), and pinellia (*banxia*); eight *liang* of rehmannia (*dihuang*); seven *ge* of cattail pollen (*puhuang*). [Text incomplete] Decoct in two *dou* of water to yield six and a half *sheng*, divided into six doses.

**Apricot Kernel Decoction** for menstrual irregularities (twice monthly, every two or three months, early or late, or complete blockage):
Two *liang* of apricot kernels (*xingren*), one *liang* of peach kernels (*taoren*), three *liang* of rhubarb (*dahuang*), thirty each of leeches (*shuizhi*) and gadflies (*mengchong*). [Text incomplete] Decoct in six *sheng* of water to yield two *sheng*, divided into three doses. After the first dose, matter will descend with stool or urine; cease if excessive, but continue if scant, completing all three doses.

**Rhubarb and Mirabilite Decoction** for chronic menstrual blockage due to wind-cold in the uterus, requiring purgation:
Five *liang* each of rhubarb (*dahuang*) and achyranthes (*niuxi*); three *liang* each of mirabilite (*poxiao*), moutan (*mudan*), licorice (*gancao*), and aster (*ziwan*) (*Qianjin Yi* reads *zijue*); one *liang* of hematite (*daizhe*); two *liang* each of peach kernels (*taoren*), gadflies (*mengchong*), leeches (*shuizhi*), dried ginger (*ganjiang*), asarum (*xixin*), and sodium sulfate (*mangxiao*); five *ge* of hemp seeds (*maren*). [Text incomplete] Decoct in one *dou* and five *sheng* of water to yield five *sheng*, strain, and dissolve the mirabilite. Divide into five doses, beginning at dawn with intervals of one cooking time between each. Purgation will follow; rest afterward and avoid wind exposure.

**Evodia and Gadfly Decoction** for chronic cold-induced menstrual irregularities (excessive or scant flow):
Three *sheng* of evodia (*wuzhuyu*); one *liang* each of gadflies (*mengchong*), leeches (*shuizhi*), *qichong*, and moutan (*mudan*); one *jin* of fresh ginger (*shengjiang*); one *sheng* each of wheat (*xiaomai*) and pinellia (*banxia*); twenty jujubes (*dazao*); fifty peach kernels (*taoren*); three *liang* each of ginseng (*renshen*) and achyranthes (*niuxi*); six *liang* of cinnamon bark (*guixin*); one and a half *liang* of licorice (*gancao*); two *liang* of peony (*shaoyao*). [Text incomplete] Decoct in one *dou* of wine and two *dou* of water to yield one *dou*, strain, and adjust temperature. Take one *sheng* per dose, three times daily. For those intolerant to wine, substitute water. Add the insects when the decoction is nearly done. For those sensitive to the formula, reduce to seven *ge* per dose.

**Dihu Decoction** for menstrual blockage with abdominal fullness that occasionally subsides, or for men with bladder fullness and urgency:
Two *liang* each of *huzhang* (*Qianjin Yi* reads *huzhang* as *huzhang*) and rhubarb (*dahuang*); thirty-plus peach kernels (*taoren*); twenty-plus leeches (*shuizhi*). Decoct in three *sheng* of water to yield one *sheng*, and consume entirely. Purgation of stagnant blood will indicate efficacy.

**Seven-Fry Pills** for menstrual blockage with restless limbs, fever, abdominal fullness, lethargy, and irritability:
One and a half *liang* of rhubarb (*dahuang*); five *liang* each of *qianhu* (or *chaihu*), and fried mirabilite (*mangxiao*); six *zhu* each of tinglizi (*tingli*) and Sichuan pepper (*shujiao*), both fried; eighteen *zhu* each of fresh ginger (*shengjiang*) and chuanxiong (*xiongqiong*); fifteen *zhu* of poria (*fuling*); nine *zhu* of fried apricot kernels (*xingren*); twenty fried peach kernels (*taoren*); half a *ge* each of fried leeches (*shuizhi*) and fried gadflies (*mengchong*). Grind into powder, mix with honey, and form pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take seven pills on an empty stomach with water, three times daily. If ineffective, double the dose. (*Qianjin Yi* omits peony; another version includes two *liang* each of *guangchong* and moutan, totaling fourteen ingredients.)

**Peach Kernel Powder** for menstrual pain encircling the navel, rising to the chest and heart, with alternating chills and fever resembling malaria:
Fifty peach kernels (*taoren*), twenty-plus *qichong*, five *cun* of cinnamon bark (*guixin*), one *liang* of poria (*fuling*), two *liang* each of coix (*yiyiren*), achyranthes (*niuxi*), and hematite (*daizhe*); eight *liang* of rhubarb (*dahuang*). Grind into powder. On an empty stomach, take one *qianbi* with warm wine, three times daily.

**Formula for menstrual irregularities with abdominal swelling and lumbar pain:**
Four *qichong*, six *zhu* each of Sichuan pepper (*shujiao*) and dried ginger (*ganjiang*); half a *liang* each of rhubarb (*dahuang*), *nüqing*, cinnamon bark (*guixin*), and chuanxiong (*xiongqiong*). Grind into powder.

Take one *daogui* on an empty stomach, administered with wine, three times daily. After ten days, there will be slight purgation; tend to recovery carefully.

**Formula for menstrual irregularities—whether early, late, or resembling bean dregs—with lumbar pain as if broken, leg pain, and wind-cold in the uterus:**
Four *liang* each of rhubarb (*dahuang*) and mirabilite (*poxiao*); three *liang* of moutan (*mudan*); one *sheng* of peach kernels (*taoren*); two *liang* each of ginseng (*renshen*), actinolite (*yangqishi*), poria (*fuling*), licorice (*gancao*), leeches (*shuizhi*), and gadflies (*mengchong*). Chop the ten ingredients, decoct in nine *sheng* of water until reduced to three *sheng*, strain, and dissolve the mirabilite completely. Divide into three doses, spaced by the time it takes to eat a meal.

**Actinolite Decoction** for irregular menstruation—whether early, late, profuse, or scant, sometimes red, sometimes white:
Two *liang* each of actinolite (*yangqishi*), licorice (*gancao*), dipsacus (*xuduan*), dried ginger (*ganjiang*), ginseng (*renshen*), and cinnamon bark (*guixin*); one *liang* of aconite (*fuzi*); three *liang* of halloysite (*chishizhi*); five *liang* of oven earth (*fulonggan*); one *sheng* of fresh rehmannia (*shengdihuang*). Decoct in one *dou* of water until reduced to three *sheng* and two *ge*. Divide into four doses, taken thrice by day and once at night.

**Formula for women distressed by worry and resentment, with fullness beneath the heart, latent heat in the diaphragm, menstrual obstruction, blood and qi surging upward to the heart, nausea, poor appetite, and lethargy:**
Two *liang* each of rhubarb (*dahuang*), peony (*shaoyao*), and gadflies (*mengchong*); one *liang* each of trichosanthes root (*tuguagen*), Sichuan pepper (*shujiao*), scutellaria (*huangqin*), atractylodes (*baizhu*), dried ginger (*ganjiang*), and lycium bark (*digupi*, or *tanpi* if charred); one and a half *liang* each of cinnamon bark (*guixin*) and dried lacquer (*ganqi*). Grind into powder, form into honeyed pills the size of firmiana seeds. Take ten pills thrice daily; increase if no effect.

**Achyranthes Pill** for postpartum menstrual irregularities—sometimes profuse, sometimes scant, or even obstructed—with intermittent pain, lower abdominal tension, and dragging heaviness in the waist and body:
Three *liang* each of achyranthes (*niuxi*), peony (*shaoyao*), ginseng (*renshen*), and rhubarb (*dahuang*); two *liang* each of moutan bark (*mudanpi*), licorice (*gancao*), tangkuei (*danggui*), and chuanxiong (*xiongqiong*); one *liang* of cinnamon bark (*guixin*); forty each of *qichong*, *qicao*, and *feixian*; seventy each of gadflies (*mengchong*) and leeches (*shuizhi*). Grind into powder, form into honeyed pills the size of firmiana seeds. Take five pills with wine thrice daily; increase gradually if no effect.

**Additional Formulas:**
- Take deer antler powder; effective.
- Decoct three *sheng* of fresh rehmannia juice until reduced to two *sheng*; consume.
- Drink three *ge* of human breast milk; beneficial.
- Burn menstrual cloth, administer the ashes with well water.
- Char white dog feces, grind into powder, and take one *fangcunbi* with wine thrice daily.

Drink one *sheng* of white horse urine; effective.

**Formula for Unceasing Menstrual Flow:**
Boil one *jin* of *chuanru* (washed and rinsed) in four and a half *sheng* of river water until reduced to two *sheng*; divide into two doses.

**Additional Formulas:**
- Drink rehmannia wine; effective.
- Drink soybean wine; excellent.
- Burn *ji* (winnowing basket) tongue to ashes, administer with wine.
- Moxibustion at the blue vessel above the white flesh below the inner ankle, applying cones equal to the patient’s age.

**Formulas for Infants and Young Children, Part One**

**Preface to the First Section**

It is said: Among the principles of human life, none is more vital than nurturing the young. Without the small, the great cannot be achieved. Thus, the *Book of Changes* speaks of "accumulating the small to form the great," the *Book of Songs* recounts "the first birth of the people," and the *Commentaries* state that "Shengzi begot Duke Yin." This same principle—proceeding from the subtle to the manifest, from youth to maturity—is evident to all, requiring no appeal to classics or histories.

Therefore, in these formulas, we first address women and children, then men and the elderly, for this is the proper order of honoring the root. Yet infants, their *qi* and strength so delicate, present a challenge to physicians who would devote themselves to their care. Most scholars today pay them little heed, for babies lie swaddled in their cradles, their breath rank and restless, while physicians, proud in their skill, disdain to attend them. Reflecting on this, one can only sigh in lament.

The *Xiaopin Fang* states: From six years of age onward, one is called "small"; from sixteen onward, "young" (the *Chao Yuan* and *Waitai* texts read "eighteen onward" as "young"). From thirty onward, one is "strong" (the *Chao Yuan* and *Waitai* read "twenty onward" as "strong"). From fifty onward, one is "old." For those under six, the classics offer no guidance, and so illnesses in nursing infants are difficult to treat, for there is no foundation to rely upon.

In ancient times, there was a certain *Wu Fang* (the *Chao Yuan* reads *Wu Fang* as *Wu Mang*), who composed the *Luxiong Jing* on infants’ fontanelles, using it to divine longevity, diagnose illness, and predict life or death. Passed down through generations, this marked the beginning of pediatric formulas. By the Jin and Song dynasties, the southern lands esteemed the schools of the Su families, whose proven methods spread among the people. In the Qi dynasty, there was a certain Prince Xu, who compiled a *Formulary for Children* in three scrolls, and thus later scholars gained some access to transmission. Yet Prince Xu’s rank and renown were so exalted—how could he have found time to attend to the young? Examining his formulas, one finds them neither profound nor meticulous, with little worth adopting and nothing truly arcane.

Here, I have broadly gathered the effective methods from various schools, as well as those I have personally tested, to compose this section. Every household should master these arts of nurturing the young, that they may avoid the misfortune of untimely death.

It is further said: The illnesses of children differ little from those of adults; only the dosage of medicine varies. The conditions of fright epilepsy, *kewu* (visitation by malevolent spirits), *jielu* (unclosed fontanelle), and failure to walk—along with eight or nine other topics—are compiled in this volume. Formulas for conditions such as diarrhea are scattered throughout the other sections and may be consulted as needed.

In general: Sixty days after birth, the pupils form, and the child can laugh and respond to others. By one hundred days, the *ren* vessel is complete, and the child can roll over on its own.

One version states it occurs at one hundred fifty days. At one hundred eighty days, the coccyx forms, and the child can sit unsupported. At two hundred ten days, the metacarpals form, and the child can crawl. At three hundred days, the kneecaps form, and the child can stand alone. At three hundred sixty days, the knee bones form, and the child can walk. These are the established norms; if a child cannot meet these milestones, there must be some imbalance.

In general: A child undergoes its first *bian* (transformation) at thirty-two days after birth, and a second *bian* at sixty-four days, at which point *bian* is accompanied by *zheng* (steaming). At ninety-six days, the third *bian*; at one hundred twenty-eight days, the fourth *bian*, again accompanied by *zheng*. At one hundred sixty days, the fifth *bian*; at one hundred ninety-two days, the sixth *bian*, with *zheng*. At two hundred twenty-four days, the seventh *bian*; at two hundred fifty-six days, the eighth *bian*, with *zheng*. At two hundred eighty-eight days, the ninth *bian*; at three hundred twenty days, the tenth *bian*, with *zheng*. After the accumulation of three hundred twenty days, the minor *zheng* concludes. Sixty-four days later, the first major *zheng* occurs; another sixty-four days later, the second major *zheng*; and one hundred twenty-eight days after that, the third major *zheng*. In all, from birth, a child undergoes one *bian* every thirty-two days, with every second *bian* accompanied by a *zheng*. Ten *bian* result in five minor *zheng*, and three major *zheng* follow, totaling five hundred seventy-six days, after which all major and minor *zheng* conclude, and the child becomes fully formed.

The purpose of *bian* and *zheng* is to nourish the blood vessels and transform the five viscera. Thus, after each *bian* concludes, one can observe changes in the child’s temperament and disposition. During *bian* and *zheng*, the signs are as follows: *bian* manifests as rising qi, while *zheng* manifests as bodily heat. The severity of *bian* and *zheng* varies. In mild cases, the child has a slight fever and mild fright, with cold ears and coccyx, white blisters appearing on the upper lip like fish eyes, and slight sweating. In severe cases, the child has a strong fever with disordered pulse, either sweating or not, refuses food, vomits when fed, and the whites of the eyes may appear slightly red while the pupils may seem faintly white. It is also said: if the whites of the eyes are prominent, the condition is severe; if the red and black parts are affected, it is mild. After *bian* and *zheng* conclude, the eyes become clear again. These are the symptoms. A *bian* alone is mild, while *bian* combined with *zheng* is slightly more severe.

In normal cases, *zheng* subsides after five days; in prolonged cases, it may take up to ten days. The five days before and after the expected day—ten days in total—are when the fever dissipates. If a child undergoes its first *bian* at thirty-two days but develops a fever twenty-nine days early, treat it according to the proper method, and the *zheng* will conclude by thirty-six or thirty-seven days. To ensure clarity, this is reiterated.

During *bian* and *zheng*, avoid startling the child or allowing too many people near. The timing of *bian* and *zheng* may vary, and many children do not follow the expected pattern. If, during the initial *bian*, the fever is severe and does not abate after the expected number of days, carefully calculate the *bian* and *zheng* schedule. If the child has a slight fever and mild fright at the appropriate time, do not treat it with moxibustion or acupuncture; simply observe and harmonize. If the fever persists for a long time, administer a small dose of *Zi Wan* (Purple Pill) to induce a mild purgation, stopping once the fever subsides.

If, during *bian* and *zheng*, the child contracts a seasonal warm disease, or if such a disease occurs outside the *bian* and *zheng* period, the symptoms may appear similar. However, in such cases, the ears and coccyx will be uniformly hot, and no white blisters will appear on the lips. First administer *Hei San* (Black Powder) to induce sweating; after sweating, apply warm powder, and the fever should subside, leading to recovery. If the condition does not fully resolve, then administer *Zi Wan* to induce purgation.

If, during *bian* and *zheng*, the child is affected by cold, cold and heat will contend, causing twisting pain in the abdomen and waist, and incessant crying. In such cases, apply a warm compress to resolve it. The method for the warm compress is provided in the following section; it involves moxibustion, powder, and tight binding.

*Bian* and *zheng* resemble seasonal febrile illnesses and cold damage. If the condition is not *bian* and *zheng*, the body, ears, and coccyx will all be hot; this indicates another illness and should be treated accordingly. If it is indeed *bian* and *zheng*, do not treat it as another illness.

Another method states: A child begins its first *bian* at thirty-two days after birth, marked by bodily heat. At sixty-four days, the second *bian* occurs, accompanied by *zheng*, and the child’s appearance becomes well-proportioned. At ninety-six days, the third *bian* occurs, and the condition is confirmed by the emergence of sweat from the pores. At one hundred twenty-eight days, the fourth *bian* occurs, accompanied by *zheng*, and the child can laugh and respond. At one hundred sixty days, the fifth *bian* occurs, completing the joints and mechanisms. At one hundred ninety-two days, the sixth *bian* occurs, accompanied by *zheng*, and the five mechanisms are fully formed. At two hundred twenty-four days, the seventh *bian* occurs, and the child can crawl. At two hundred fifty-six days, the eighth *bian* occurs, accompanied by *zheng*, and the child begins to learn speech. At two hundred eighty-eight days, the ninth *bian* occurs, and the child stands upright.

From birth to two hundred eighty-eight days, a child undergoes nine *bian* and four *zheng*. On the day of *bian*, take care not to treat the child indiscriminately, as this may exacerbate the condition. *Bian* accompanied by *zheng* marks the child’s transition between months. *Zheng* is characterized by intense heat, disordered pulse, and sweating; it typically subsides in five days, or up to eight or nine days in prolonged cases. During *zheng*, do not apply moxibustion, acupuncture, or indiscriminate treatments.

**Purple Pill (*Zi Yuan*)**
For treating *bian* and *zheng* in children with persistent fever, as well as concurrent cold damage, seasonal febrile illnesses, fever persisting after sweating, phlegm accumulation in the abdomen, refusal to nurse, vomiting after feeding, and food epilepsy. The formula is as follows:

- *Chi Shi Zhi* (Halloysite) – 1 *liang*
- *Dai Zhe* (Hematite) – 1 *liang*
- *Ba Dou* (Croton seed) – 30 pieces
- *Xing Ren* (Apricot kernel) – 50 pieces

Grind the four ingredients into powder. Separately grind *Ba Dou* and *Xing Ren* into a paste, then combine and pound two thousand times until well-mixed. If the mixture is too hard, add a small amount of honey and continue pounding. Store in a sealed container. For a thirty-day-old child, administer a pill the size of a hemp seed with a small amount of breast milk to aid swallowing. After the time it takes to eat a meal, give a little more breast milk, but not too much. By midday, the child should experience a mild purgation, and the fever will subside. If the fever does not fully resolve, administer another pill the following morning.

For a hundred-day-old child, administer a pill the size of a small bean, adjusting the dosage accordingly. In summer, when heat is prevalent and rashes are prone to erupt, administering one pill every twenty or thirty days is beneficial.

The *Purple Pill* treats all ailments and, though purgative, does not weaken the patient.

**Black Powder**, a formula for treating childhood *bianzheng* (febrile episodes of growth), concurrent seasonal warm diseases, or seasonal illnesses occurring outside *bianzheng* periods:

- *Ma Huang* (Ephedra) – ½ *liang*
- *Xing Ren* (Apricot kernel) – ½ *liang*
- *Da Huang* (Rhubarb) – 6 *zhu*

First grind *Ma Huang* and *Da Huang* into powder, then separately grind *Xing Ren* into a paste. Gradually incorporate the paste into the powder, pounding until well-mixed. Store in a sealed container.

For a one-month-old child, administer a dose the size of a small bean, mixed with breast milk. Hold the child to induce sweating; once sweat appears, dust with warm powder and avoid exposure to wind. For a hundred-day-old child, administer a dose the size of a jujube pit, adjusting according to the child’s size.

**Method for Selecting a Wet Nurse:**
The blood and *qi* of a wet nurse transform into breast milk. All emotions, whether good or bad, arise from her blood and *qi*. Thus, a wet nurse must be cautious with joy and anger.

While the ideal physical and complexional traits of a wet nurse are numerous and unattainable in full, she should at least be free of foul body odor, goiter, fistula, chronic cough, scabies, paralysis, white scalp ringworm, festering sores, sunken lips, deafness, nasal congestion, epilepsy, or similar ailments before nursing a child. A skilled physician can discern the origins of past illnesses by examining old moxibustion scars.

**Prescriptions for Infants and Young Children**
**Second Discourse: On the Immediate Care After Birth**

When a child is first born, one must first wrap a finger in silk and wipe away the green mucus and foul blood from the mouth and tongue—this is called the *jade crosspiece* (or *bridle*). If not swiftly wiped away, the moment the child cries, these impurities will enter the abdomen and give rise to a hundred ailments.

If the child does not cry upon delivery, pour warm water over it in a vessel, and it will soon wail. If the child still does not cry, this is due to exhaustion from a difficult birth. One may take the umbilical cord and gently press it toward the child’s body to guide qi into the abdomen, then exhale warm breath upon it up to a hundred times, and the cry will naturally come. Alternatively, one may lightly strike the child with a scallion stalk to induce crying.

Once born, the child should be lifted immediately. Delay risks internal cold, causing rumbling in the abdomen. First bathe the child, then sever the umbilical cord—not with a knife, but by having someone bite through it while shielding the child with a single layer of clothing. Afterward, exhale warm breath upon it seven times before binding the cord, leaving the remaining stump long enough to reach the child’s instep. If too short, it may cause internal cold, leading to chronic dysentery. If the cord is cut before bathing, water may enter the navel, resulting in abdominal pain.

After severing the cord, inspect the stump carefully, for it often contains worms. Remove them promptly, lest they enter the child’s abdomen and cause illness. The umbilical stump should be left six *cun* in length—too long harms the flesh, too short harms the organs. If not cut in time or if residual fluids remain, the warmth will gradually dissipate, generating cold and causing *umbilical wind*.

For a male child, wrap him in his father’s old clothes; for a female, use her mother’s old garments. Avoid new silk, as it is best to use worn fabrics. Do not dress the child too warmly, for excessive heat damages the skin, harms the blood and vessels, and may lead to sores and jaundice. Infants’ clothing, whether silk or cotton, must never be overly thick or hot—take great care in this.

When a child is first born, its flesh is not yet fully formed, so do not bundle it in warm clothes, for this will weaken the sinews and bones. Instead, allow it to be exposed to wind and sunlight at appropriate times. If it never encounters wind, its skin and flesh will become fragile, easily susceptible to harm. Always clothe the child in old cotton padding, never new.

On warm, windless days, let the mother carry the child to play in the sun. Frequent exposure to wind and sunlight will congeal the blood, strengthen the qi, and firm the muscles, enabling the child to endure cold and avoid illness. Keeping the child constantly sheltered in curtains and wrapped in heavy, warm clothing is like growing plants in the shade—they will be soft and brittle, unable to withstand wind or cold.

**Method for Binding the Umbilicus:**
Pound white silk until soft, cut it into a four-*cun* square, and layer it with new cotton half a *cun* thick. Combine these with cloth of equal size, adjusting the tightness—if too tight, it will cause the child to vomit milk.

Twenty days after birth, unwrap the navel to inspect it. If around ten days the child cries angrily as if irritated by something in its clothes, this may be due to the dried navel stump pricking its abdomen. Unbind it, change the wrapping, and reapply. When binding the navel, close the door and curtains, light a fire to warm the room, and do the same when changing the wrapping. Dust the area with warm powder—this is for winter’s cold. If the navel does not heal, apply powdered burnt crimson silk. If after a month the navel still oozes fluid, apply powdered toad ash three or four times daily.

If water or cold enters the navel, the child will suffer from twisting abdominal pain, high-pitched wailing, and a bluish-black complexion. This is due to water intrusion. Warm powdered cotton and apply it as a compress. If untreated, the navel may swell—treat according to severity. For severe swelling, apply moxibustion up to eighty or ninety cones. For mild cases where the navel is not greatly swollen but merely oozes fluid and the child cries intermittently, pound *dang gui* into powder, mix it with lead powder, and apply it. Warm cotton compresses should be applied daily until the condition improves, with the cessation of crying as the sign of recovery. If the child’s stool is green, this indicates cold, akin to water in the navel.

After bathing, severing the cord, and swaddling the child, do not immediately give cinnabar honey. Instead, prepare a licorice decoction: take a segment of licorice the length of a finger joint, crush it, and boil it in two *ge* of water until reduced to one *ge*. Soak a piece of silk in the liquid and let the child suck it. Continue until about one *xian* shell’s worth of liquid has entered the abdomen, at which point the child should vomit, expelling the foul fluids from its chest and heart. If vomiting occurs, no further medicine is needed. If not, wait a while and administer more if the child seems hungry or thirsty. If the child still does not vomit after the initial and subsequent doses, give the remaining decoction gradually until the full *ge* is consumed.

If the foul fluids are expelled through vomiting, the child’s spirit and intelligence will be clear and free of illness. If the full *ge* is consumed without vomiting, it means the child did not ingest foul blood, and licorice decoction should not be given again. Instead, administer cinnabar honey to calm the spirit and settle the hun and po.

In the first three days after birth, do not give too much cinnabar honey, for excess will chill the spleen and stomach, causing abdominal distension, susceptibility to *yin* convulsions, rapid breathing, and potentially fatal lockjaw. **Method for Administering Cinnabar Honey to Newborns:**
Take refined cinnabar the size of a soybean, mix it with one *xian* shell of red honey, and use a chopstick wrapped in silk to dip and let the child suck it. Administer three dips, ensuring the full soybean-sized portion is consumed over one day. Continue for three days, using a total of three soybean-sized portions. Exceeding this amount will harm the child.

After administering cinnabar honey, give *niu huang* (cow bezoar) in the same quantity. *Niu huang* benefits the liver and gallbladder, clears heat, stabilizes the spirit, stops fright, repels malign qi, and prevents a hundred childhood illnesses.

Three days after birth, the child’s intestines and stomach should be opened to aid digestion.

**Method for Feeding Thick Rice Gruel to Newborns:**
Grind rice into a thick liquid, matching the consistency of yogurt or cream. Feed the child a portion the size of a soybean, allowing them to swallow it repeatedly until three soybean-sized portions are consumed. Administer this three times a day. After seven days, breastfeeding may commence.

**Breastfeeding Schedule:**
- Ten days after birth: feed portions the size of a jujube pit.
- Twenty days: double the amount.
- Fifty days: portions the size of a marble.
- One hundred days: portions the size of a jujube.

If the mother’s milk is insufficient, adjust the amounts slightly as needed. Breastfeeding at thirty days ensures the child remains free of illness. Early feeding overwhelms the child’s digestive *qi*, leading to sores on the head, face, and body that recur repeatedly, weakening the child and making them difficult to raise. Even after thirty days, do not overfeed; if the child shows no appetite, do not force-feed, as undigested food will cause illness.

If the child refuses milk, phlegm accumulations are likely present in the abdomen. Administer the *Four-Ingredient Purple Pill* to induce a mild purgation, then regulate breastfeeding. After a few days, the child will recover. For mild fever or chills, the same method should be used—purgation is essential for healing.

**Breastfeeding Precautions:**
- Avoid overfeeding, as it causes vomiting. If vomiting occurs, the child has been fed too much; offer empty breast (without milk) to settle the stomach, up to four times a day.
- If the umbilical stump has not healed, overfeeding may allow wind to enter through the navel.
- In summer, do not feed hot milk, as it causes vomiting and reflux.
- In winter, do not feed cold milk, as it leads to coughing and dysentery.
- If the mother has recently engaged in sexual activity, breastfeeding will cause the child to become emaciated, disrupting the menstrual cycle.
- If the mother has a fever, breastfeeding will turn the child yellow and impair their appetite.
- If the mother is angry while breastfeeding, the child may become easily startled, develop hernial *qi*, or suffer from upper-body *qi* disorders and mania.
- If the mother has recently vomited or had diarrhea, breastfeeding will weaken the child.
- If the mother is intoxicated, breastfeeding will cause the child to develop fever and abdominal distension.

**General Feeding Practices:**
- For newborns within the first month, feeding pig’s milk is highly beneficial.
- When breastfeeding, the mother should first thoroughly massage her breasts to disperse heat and prevent milk from spurting out, which could choke the child. Remove the breast to allow the child to breathe, then resume feeding. Repeat this five to ten times, adjusting based on the child’s hunger and satiety to determine the daily feeding frequency.
- Always express and discard the first milk before feeding.
- If the child is lying down, the mother should support them with her arm, keeping the breast level with the child’s head to prevent choking.
- If the mother wishes to sleep, she should remove the breast from the child’s mouth to avoid blocking their nose and mouth, and to prevent overfeeding.

**Bathing the Child:**
- The water temperature must be carefully balanced—too hot or cold will startle the child and harm the five viscera.
- In winter, avoid prolonged bathing to prevent cold injury; in summer, avoid prolonged bathing to prevent heat injury.
- Frequent cold baths on the back may induce convulsions, while insufficient bathing may cause hair loss.
- For newborns, mix the juice of one pig’s gallbladder into the bathwater to prevent sores and scabies for life. Do not use other water.
- Three days after birth, bathe the child with *Peach Root Decoction*: use two *liang* each of peach, plum, and apricot roots (or branches), chop them, boil in three *dou* of water for twenty simmers, strain, and use the liquid for bathing. This dispels inauspicious influences and prevents sores and scabies for life.
- To treat childhood fright and repel malign *qi*, bathe the child with *Gold-Tiger Decoction*: boil one *jin* of gold and one tiger skull in three *dou* of water, using the decoction for bathing as needed.

**Treating Oral Conditions in Newborns:**
- **Thrush (Goose Mouth):** Some newborns have white, rice-like patches on the tongue, and in severe cases, inside the nostrils. This results from excessive *qi* from grains in the womb or the mother’s craving for glutinous rice during pregnancy. Treatment: Wrap hair around a finger, dip it in well water (drawn at dawn), and gently wipe the patches for three days. If unresolved, boil chestnut husks to make a thick juice, wrap silk around a chopstick, dip it in the juice, and wipe the patches. In spring or summer, if chestnut husks are unavailable, boil chestnut bark and use it as with well water.
- **Tongue-Tie:** Some newborns have a membrane beneath the tongue resembling the partition in a pomegranate seed, restricting speech. Use a fingernail to snip it; slight bleeding is harmless. If bleeding persists, burn hair into ash and apply it to stop the bleeding.
- Six or seven days after birth, the child’s blood and *qi* consolidate into flesh, clearing the mouth, tongue, throat, and cheeks. If there are water-filled blister-like growths in the throat or tongue, or swollen, abscess-like protrusions, wrap silk around a long needle, leaving only a millet-sized tip exposed. Pierce the growth to release *qi*, draining green, yellow, or red fluid. Perform one puncture and observe for a day; if unresolved, repeat the next day. No more than three punctures are needed for complete resolution. Minor cases may require only three punctures.
  - Growths under the tongue are called *double tongue*.
  - Growths in the cheeks or upper palate are called *double palate*.
  - Growths on the gums are called *double gums*.
  All should be treated by draining the fluid.

**Treating Stillborn Newborns:**
If the child appears stillborn, check for a blister-like growth on the upper palate near the uvula. Use a finger to rupture it and drain the blood, ensuring it does not enter the throat—this would be fatal. Act swiftly and with caution.

**Blood Stagnation in Newborns:**
At birth, the child’s bones and flesh are not yet consolidated, and their muscles are still composed of blood. Only when blood coagulates does it form firm flesh. If the blood stagnates and fails to consolidate, the child’s face, particularly around the nose and mouth, will turn yellow, and they will cry with closed eyes, pursed lips, and a wrinkled face. Their mouth will be dry, and their limbs will be unable to stretch or flex. These symptoms indicate unconsolidated blood vessels, often leading to failure to thrive.

If such symptoms manifest, administer the *Longdan Decoction*. The formula is found in the section on fright epilepsy below.

**Methods for Assessing a Child’s Lifespan:**
When a child is first born, a cry that is prolonged and unbroken portends longevity. A cry that ceases abruptly and then rises sharply in pitch foretells a short life. A cry that is scattered and unfocused indicates the child will not survive to adulthood. A cry that is deep and guttural indicates the child will not survive to adulthood. If the navel contains no blood, this is auspicious. A small navel foretells a short life. If the body is limp and soft as though boneless, the child will not live long. A child who is fair-skinned, tall, and large in build will live long. A child who opens their eyes on their own will not survive to adulthood. Eyes that gaze unsteadily or dart about frequently are a grave omen. A child who sweats blood will endure many hardships and not live long. A child whose sweat does not flow will not survive to adulthood. Urine that congeals like grease indicates the child will not survive to adulthood. A skull with four unfused sutures indicates the child will not survive to adulthood. Constantly moving the hands and feet indicates the child will not survive to adulthood. Early sitting, early walking, early teething, or early speech are all signs of a perverse nature and an inauspicious constitution. Hair that does not grow in a complete ring around the head indicates the child will not survive to adulthood. Sparse hair indicates stubbornness and disobedience—or, in another version, dullness. A whorl of hair on the forehead portends early prominence but may bring misfortune to the parents. If the occipital bone is not fully formed at birth, the child will learn to speak before dying. If the bones of the corpse (cervical vertebrae) are not fully formed, the child will learn to sit upright before dying. If the bones of the palm are not fully formed, the child will learn to crawl before dying. If the heel bones are not fully formed, the child will learn to walk before dying. If the kneecaps are not fully formed, the child will learn to stand before dying. A body that does not contract (after birth) will die. A mouth shaped like a fish’s indicates death. Thighs lacking flesh will die. A cleft beneath the chin indicates death. Genitals that do not become erect indicate death. A scrotum that appears white indicates death; if it appears red, it also indicates death. If the scrotal seam is fully formed and dark, this portends longevity.

**Discourse:**
For children aged three to ten, observing the nature and disposition of their *qi* allows one to discern the general outline of their lifespan. Children who are precociously intelligent and quick-witted often die young—such as Xiang Tuo or Yan Hui. Children whose bone structure is well-formed, whose demeanor is dignified, and whose movements are deliberate and unhurried—requiring patient refinement—will live long. Those who anticipate others’ intentions and move with swift agility will also die young, like Yang Xiu or Kong Rong. From these observations, the general outline of a child’s lifespan can be known. It is like the early-blooming plum, which does not endure the cold of winter, while the late-blooming chrysanthemum thrives into old age. Thus, late maturation is a sign of longevity.

*The Ninth Scroll of Sun Zhenren’s* *Essential Emergency Prescriptions Worth a Thousand Gold Pieces* **concludes here.**
