Decoct *dongkuizi* (winter mallow seeds) and administer the juice.

**Alternative Formula:**
Burn *fengfang* (hornet’s nest) and *luanfa* (human hair) to ash, and administer one *qianbi* with water twice daily.

**Formula for Childhood Urinary Retention:**
One *sheng* of chopped *cheqiancao* (plantago herb) and one *sheng* of *xiaomai* (wheat).
The two ingredients are decocted in two *sheng* of water until one *sheng* and two *ge* remain. Strain and use the liquid to cook porridge, administering three to four times daily.

**Alternative Formula:**
One *sheng* of *dongkuizi* (winter mallow seeds) decocted in two *sheng* of water until one *sheng* remains; divide and administer, adding six *zhu* of *huashi* (talcum) powder.

**Formula for Childhood Hematemesis:**
Burn *shetui* (snake slough) to ash and administer with breast milk. Also treats *chongshe* (double tongue).

**Alternative Formula:**
Mix three parts oil with one part wine and administer in two divided doses.

**Formula for Childhood Nasal Obstruction with Nasal Polyps:**
One *liang* each of *tongcao* (tetrapanax pith) and *xixin* (asarum).
Grind the two ingredients into powder. Take a dose the size of a soybean, wrap it in silk, and insert into the nostril. Administer twice daily.

**Formula for Childhood Nasal Obstruction with Turbid Nasal Discharge:**
Half a *liang* of *xingren* (apricot kernel), six *zhu* each of *shujiao* (Sichuan pepper), *fuzi* (aconite), and *xixin* (asarum).
Crush the four ingredients, soak in five *ge* of vinegar overnight. The next day, decoct with five *ge* of lard until the *fuzi* turns yellow. Once the ointment is formed, strain and discard the residue. Apply the ointment to silk and insert into the nostrils. Administer twice daily, and also massage the crown of the head.

**Formula for Childhood Suppurative Ear Infection:**
Grind *liuhuang* (sulfur) into powder and apply inside the ear. Administer once in the morning and once at night.

**Formula for Childhood Ear Sores:**
Burn *maguhui* (horse bone ash) and apply to the affected area.
**Alternative Formula:**
Burn *jishibai* (white part of chicken droppings) and blow into the ear through a tube.

**Formula for Delayed Tooth Regrowth in Children:**
Take twenty-one large soybeans from cow dung. Make a small opening at the tip of each bean and apply to the tooth roots. Repeat several times to stimulate growth.
**Alternative Formula:**
Take twenty-one *xiongshushi* (pointed-end rat droppings). Use one dropping to wipe each tooth root, repeating until all are used. Teeth will grow within twenty-one days.
*(Note: Male rat droppings have pointed ends.)*

**Formula for Children Aged Four or Five Who Do Not Speak:**
Grind *chixiaodou* (red adzuki beans) into powder, mix with wine, and apply beneath the tongue.
**Alternative Formula:**

**Moxibustion Formula:**
Apply three cones of moxa to each ankle.

**Formula for Children Several Years Old Unable to Walk:**
Take food from an unopened tomb, feed it to the child three times daily, and the child will soon begin to walk.

**Formula for Children Unable to Nurse:**
Grind four sparrow droppings into powder and place on the nipple for the child to ingest. For older children, use ten droppings.

**Pu Huang Decoction: Formula for Children Who Fall from Beds or Heights, Suffering from Stagnant Blood in the Abdomen, Alternating Chills and Fever, Refusal to Nurse, and Continuous Crying:**
- *Pu huang* (cattail pollen) – 10 *zhu*
- *Mai men dong* (dwarf lilyturf root) – 10 *zhu*
- *Da huang* (rhubarb) – 10 *zhu*
- *Huang qin* (skullcap root) – 10 *zhu*
- *Gan cao* (licorice root) – 8 *zhu*
- *Mang xiao* (mirabilite) – 7 *zhu*
- *Huang lian* (coptis rhizome) – 12 *zhu*

Pound the seven ingredients, then decoct in two *sheng* of water until one *sheng* remains. Strain, add *mang xiao*, and divide into three doses. Adjust dosage according to the child’s condition; halve it for frail children. Recovery is marked by the passage of blood in urine or stool. Avoid cold foods.

**Formula for Children Who Eat Without Knowing Hunger or Fullness:**
Burn twenty-one rat droppings, grind into powder, and administer.

**Formula for Children Who Eat Dirt:**
Take one *jin* of meat, drag it along the ground for several *li* with a rope, then roast without washing and feed to the child.

**Formula for Children with Hiccups:**
- Fresh ginger juice – 5 *ge*
- Cow’s milk – 5 *ge*

Decoct the two ingredients until 5 *ge* remain, then divide into two doses.

**Alternative Formula:**
Decoct one *sheng* of cow’s milk until 5 *ge* remain, then divide into five doses.

**Formula for Children with *Zhu* (Infantile Malnutrition with Parasites):**
Mix equal parts stove ash and salt, then heat and apply as a compress.

**Formula for Children Who Accidentally Swallow a Needle:**
Take a lodestone the size of a jujube pit, either swallow or hold in the mouth, and the needle will emerge immediately.

**Formula for Children Who Accidentally Swallow Iron or Other Objects:**
Chop one handful of mugwort, decoct in five *sheng* of water until one and a half *sheng* remain, then administer to induce passage.

**Formula for Children Bitten by *Qusou* (Centipedes), Which If Encircling the Abdomen Leads to Death:**
Pound *ji li* (caltrop) leaves and apply as a poultice. If no leaves are available, use the seeds.

**Alternative Formula:**
Take soil from a swallow’s nest, mix with lard, and apply. Replace when dry.

*Sun Zhenren’s* *Beiji Qianjin Yaofang*, Volume Fourteen, Concludes

*Sun Zhenren’s* *Beiji Qianjin Yaofang*, Volume Fifteen
Collated and Corrected by Lin Yi, Gentleman for Court Service, Acting Vice Minister of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices, and Editor of the Imperial Library, et al., of the Song Dynasty

**Formulas for the Seven Orifices #1: Eye Diseases**

**Discourse, Symptoms, Formulas, Incantations, Moxibustion Methods**

It is said: Generally, after the age of forty-five, one’s eyesight gradually dims, but after sixty, it gradually becomes clear again. The method of treatment: before fifty, one may take *Draining the Liver Decoction*; after fifty, the liver must not be drained. If there is disease in the eyes, one may apply *Chalcanthite Powder* and the like. If there is no disease, one must not apply powders indiscriminately—simply tonify the liver. Naturally, if there is wind-heat in the liver causing dim or dark vision, one should apply moxibustion to the liver transport point and take several dozen doses of *Dispelling Wind Decoction*, pills, or powders, and the condition will resolve.

**Activities That Harm the Eyes:**
Consuming the five pungent vegetables raw
Eating or drinking while overheated
Consuming hot, fermented foods
Drinking alcohol without restraint
Indulging in the bedchamber without moderation
Straining the eyes to gaze into the distance
Frequently observing the sun and moon
Gazing at stars and firelight at night
Reading fine script at night
Reading under moonlight
Copying texts for many years
Engraving fine work
Gambling without cease
Remaining amid smoke and fire for long periods
Excessive weeping
Excessive blood loss from bloodletting during haircutting

These sixteen practices are all fundamental causes of vision loss. Those who cultivate their nature should be thoroughly cautious of them. Additionally, galloping during hunting, braving wind and frost, chasing beasts against the wind day and night without rest—these too are agents of eye injury. Indulging fleeting impulses may lead to lifelong chronic ailments; how can one not be vigilant?

When young, if one does not exercise self-restraint, by the age of forty, the eyes will gradually grow dim. If one can adhere to these precautions, one may preserve clear vision into old age. Thus, after the age of forty, one should often close the eyes and avoid gazing about. Unless there is urgent business, one should not open them lightly. This is the ultimate method of protection and caution.

Those who overstrain their eyes through excessive reading, gambling, and the like suffer from what is called "liver taxation." To cure this, one must close the eyes and refrain from looking for three years; otherwise, recovery is impossible. Merely draining the liver or applying various treatments will ultimately be ineffective.

When one suffers from wind rashes, dim vision often follows. First, dispel the wind, and the dimness will naturally resolve.

When the foot Taiyang, Yangming, or hand Shaoyang channels stir, eye diseases arise.

The Yellow Emperor asked: "Once, I ascended the Qingling Terrace. Midway up the steps, I turned to look back, crawling forward on my hands and knees. I privately found this strange and inwardly wondered at it. At times, I would close my eyes in darkness, calming my mind and regulating my qi. After a long while, the sensation did not dissipate. I loosened my hair, knelt upright, and looked downward, yet after some time, it persisted. Suddenly, it ceased on its own. What qi causes this?"

Qibo replied: "The essential qi of the five viscera and six bowels all ascend and infuse the eyes, forming the eyeballs. The essence of bone forms the pupil; the essence of sinews forms the dark of the eye; the essence of blood forms its network of vessels; the essence of qi forms the white of the eye; and the essence of flesh forms the eyelids and their binding. The essence of sinews, bones, blood, and qi, together with the vessels, form the ocular connections. These connections ascend to the brain and emerge at the nape.

Thus, when pathogenic qi invades the nape and encounters bodily deficiency, it penetrates deeply and follows the ocular connections into the brain. Once in the brain, it causes turning, which pulls on the ocular connections, making them tense. Tension leads to dizziness and vertigo.

If the pathogen strikes the eyeball directly, the affected part loses coordination, causing the eyeball to scatter. Scattering leads to double vision, so one sees two objects.

The eyes are the essence of the five viscera and six bowels, the domain where constructive and defensive qi, the ethereal and corporeal souls circulate, and where spirit and qi are generated. Thus, when the spirit is taxed, the ethereal and corporeal souls scatter, and the will and intent become disordered. For this reason, the pupil and dark of the eye correspond to yin, while the white of the eye and red vessels correspond to yang. When yin and yang unite and turn together, vision becomes clear.

The eyes are the messengers of the heart; the heart is the abode of the spirit. Thus, when the spirit scatters and the essence is disordered, sudden encounters with the extraordinary cause the spirit, ethereal soul, and corporeal soul to disperse and lose coherence, resulting in confusion."

The Emperor said: "Why does this happen? Whenever I go to the Eastern Garden, I invariably become disoriented, but upon leaving, I recover. Do I alone tax my spirit in the Eastern Garden? Why is it so peculiar?"

Qibo replied: "It is not so."

When the heart harbors joy while the spirit abhors it, their sudden clash disrupts essence and distorts vision, causing spiritual confusion. Only when the spirit shifts does clarity return—mild cases bring bewilderment, severe ones delusion.

The outer canthus where the eyes open onto the face is called the *dui-pi*; the inner corner near the nose, with its upper part as the *outer canthus* and lower as the *inner canthus*. Redness in the eyes signals heart disease; whiteness, lung disease; blueness, liver disease; yellowness, spleen disease; blackness, kidney disease. If the yellow hue defies description, the illness lies in the chest.

When diagnosing eye pain: if red vessels descend from above, it is *Taiyang* disease; if they ascend from below, *Yangming* disease; if they traverse from outer to inner, *Shaoyang* disease.

For chronic nasal discharge with unceasing turbid flow, leading to nasal congestion, blurred vision, and dizziness, this stems from *qi* counterflow. The *Foot Yangming* channel runs alongside the nose into the face, called *Xuanlu*, connecting to the mouth and linking to the root of the eyes. For visual distortions, reduce excess and supplement deficiency—reversing this worsens the condition.

The *Foot Taiyang* channel passes through the nape into the brain, directly connecting to the root of the eyes, called the *eye system*. For persistent headaches and eye pain, needle the space between the two tendons in the nape, where it enters the brain to branch into the *Yin Qiao* vessel. Yin and yang intersect here, with yang entering and yin exiting, and yang converging at the *dui-pi*. Excess yang *qi* causes squinting; depletion of yin *qi* induces deep sleep.

**Divine Leaven Pill** (for brightening vision, enabling lifelong reading):
Divine leaven (4 liang), magnetite (2 liang), luminous cinnabar (1 liang).
Grind into powder, mix with refined honey, and form pills the size of firmiana seeds. Take three pills with water, three times daily. No restrictions. Regular use enhances vision, surpassing all other formulas—scholars should take note. This divine remedy must be kept secret.

**Melon Seed Powder** (tonifies the liver, treats dim vision; also called *Ten-Seed Powder*):
Winter melon seeds, celosia seeds, motherwort seeds, wolfberry seeds, vitex seeds, tribulus seeds, dodder seeds, turnip seeds, cassia seeds, broom cypress seeds, arborvitae seeds (2 *ge* each); cinnamon bark, yingyu root (2 liang each); bush-cherry kernels (1 *ge*; one version says 2 *ge*); plantago seeds (1 liang); asarum (½ liang; one version says 1½ liang).
Grind and sift. Take one square-inch spoonful with wine after meals, twice daily. Divinely effective.

**Liver-Tonifying Pill** (for dim vision):
Celosia seeds, cinnamon bark, tingli seeds, apricot kernels, asarum, motherwort seeds, wolfberry seeds, schisandra berries (1 liang each); poria, scutellaria, saposhnikovia, broom cypress seeds, alisma, cassia seeds, ophiopogon, bush-cherry kernels (1 liang 6 *zhu* each); plantago seeds, dodder seeds (2 *ge* each); dried rehmannia (3 liang); rabbit liver (1 set).
Grind into powder, form honey pills. Take twenty pills the size of firmiana seeds with water, twice daily, increasing to thirty pills.

**Another Formula** (for dim vision with unclear sight, cold-induced tearing, or liver impediment damage):
Rabbit liver (2 sets); arborvitae seeds, dried rehmannia, poria, asarum, bush-cherry kernels, wolfberry seeds (1 liang 6 *zhu* each); saposhnikovia, chuanxiong, dioscorea (1 liang each); plantago seeds (1 *ge*); schisandra berries (18 *zhu*); licorice (½ liang); dodder seeds (1 *ge*).
Grind into powder, form honey pills. Take twenty pills the size of firmiana seeds with wine, twice daily, increasing to forty pills.

**Liver-Tonifying Powder** (for blindness with dim vision):
Cassia seeds (½ sheng); knotweed seeds (1 *ge*, stir-fried until fragrant); goat liver (1 set, remove membrane, slice thinly). Place the liver in a new, clean clay pot, roast over charcoal until thoroughly dry, and grind into powder.
Mix all ingredients, sift. Take one square-inch spoonful with porridge after meals, twice daily, gradually increasing to three spoonfuls. No more than two doses. One year of use enables night reading of fine print.

**Another Formula** (for thirty years of blindness):
Refined stalactite powder, refined mica powder, asarum, poria, polygala, schisandra berries (equal parts).
Grind and sift. Take 5 *fen* with wine, three times daily, increasing to 1 *qian*.

**Liver-Tonifying Turnip Seed Powder** (for regular use to brighten vision):
Turnip seeds (3 sheng, washed clean). Boil in 3 sheng of clear wine until done, dry in the sun, and sift. Take one square-inch spoonful with well water, gradually increasing to three spoonfuls. No restrictions; prepare in small batches. Benefits include plumpness, bright vision, and penetrating sight. May also be taken with wine-boiled water. *Qianjin Yi* uses water, changing it three times.

**Another Formula**:
Black sesame (1 *dou*), steamed thirty times, sifted. Take 1 sheng daily with wine.

**Another Formula**:
Swallow 14 small black soybeans on an empty stomach daily.

**Another Formula**:
Gather turnip flowers on the third day of the third month, dry in the shade, and sift. Take one square-inch spoonful with well water on an empty stomach. Prolonged use grants longevity, bright vision, and the ability to read fine print at night.

**Liver-Tonifying Powder** (for men’s five taxations and seven injuries, brightens vision):
Broom cypress seeds (1 *dou*, dried in the shade, ground into powder); fresh rehmannia (10 jin, juiced).
Mix the powder with rehmannia juice, dry in the sun, and regrind. Take one square-inch spoonful with wine, twice daily.

**Another Formula**:
White melon seeds (7 sheng), placed in a silk bag and dipped in boiling water three times, dried in the sun. Soak in 5 sheng of vinegar overnight, dry, and sift.

Take one square-inch spoonful with wine, three times daily. After one hundred days of use, one may write fine script at night.

**Gardenia Kernel Decoction**, for treating liver excess heat and stabbing pain in the eyes:
Gardenia kernels, cassia seeds, and *ruiren* kernels (1 *liang* each); plantain leaves and *qinpi* (1 *liang* 6 *zhu* each); gypsum (1 *liang* #5, crushed to the size of small beans); bitter bamboo leaves (2 *ge*); asarum (½ *liang*); red honey (3 *ge*).
The nine ingredients are cut, then boiled in 3 *sheng* of well water until reduced to 7 *ge*. Strain, add honey, and simmer further to 4 *ge*. Filter through silk, store in a dry vessel, and seal tightly to prevent debris from entering. Lie supine and apply the decoction drop by drop into the eyes.

**Liver-Purging Decoction**, for treating red eyes, blurred vision, and growth of fleshy obstructions:
Bupleurum, peony, and rhubarb (4 *liang* each); cassia seeds, alisma, scutellaria, and apricot kernels (3 *liang* each); cimicifuga, unripe bitter orange, gardenia kernels, and bamboo leaves (2 *liang* each).
The eleven ingredients are cut, then boiled in 9 *sheng* of water until reduced to 2 *sheng* 7 *ge*. Divide into three doses.
For those with abundant heat and robust constitution, add 1 *liang* of rhubarb. For the frail or elderly, omit rhubarb and add 5 *liang* of gardenia kernels.

**Another Formula**, for treating wind-induced redness and dimness of the eyes:
Peucedanum and peony (4 *liang* each); fresh rehmannia (10 *liang*); mirabilite, scutellaria, poria, angelica, unripe bitter orange (3 *liang* each); ginseng, atractylodes, gardenia kernels, alisma (2 *liang* each); licorice and asarum (1 *liang* each); bamboo leaves (5 *sheng*).
The fifteen ingredients are cut. First boil the bamboo leaves in 1 *dou* 2 *sheng* of water, reducing to 9 *sheng*. Strain, add the remaining ingredients, and simmer to 3 *sheng* ½ *ge*. Divide into three doses.

**Indigo Decoction for Washing the Liver**, for treating persistent liver heat flaring into the eyes, redness, pain, growth of fleshy obstructions, swelling, inability to open the eyes, and unrelenting heat, as well as yellowing of the eyes:
Dried indigo, plantain leaves, and bitter bamboo leaves (3 *sheng* each); asarum, *qinpi*, *ruiren* kernels, gardenia kernels, and peony (3 *liang* each); cassia seeds (4 *liang*); cimicifuga (2 *liang*).
The ten ingredients are cut, then boiled in 2 *dou* of water. First simmer the dried indigo, plantain, and bamboo leaves, reducing to 1 *dou*. Strain and clarify to 8 *sheng*, add the remaining ingredients, and simmer to 3 *sheng*. Divide into three doses. If a bowel movement is needed, add 2 *liang* of mirabilite.

**Jujube Decoction**, for treating heat in the eyes, redness at the canthi, growth of red veins encroaching on the pupils, fleshy obstructions, acute pain, inability to open the eyes, and grittiness as if sand were in the eyes:
Seven jujubes (peeled and pitted); 2 *liang* of coptis (crushed and wrapped in silk); 5 *ge* of sliced bamboo leaves.
Boil the bamboo leaves in 2 *sheng* of water, reducing to 1 *sheng*. Clarify to 8 *ge*, add the jujube pulp and coptis, and simmer to 4 *ge*. Strain thoroughly. Apply drop by drop to the canthi.

**Formula for Eye Growths**:
Donkey fat and powdered *shiguan* stone.
Mix evenly.

Apply to the canthi three times by day and once by night; the condition will resolve.

**Alternative Formula**:
Take the root of *wujiapi* (Acanthopanax) that has not been exposed to the sound of water, remove the soil and peel, then pound to obtain one *sheng* of powder. Mix with two *sheng* of fine wine and steep for seven days. Take twice daily at fixed hours. Avoid vinegar for fourteen days; sores will erupt over the entire body. If they do not appear, the medicinal potency has not yet taken effect. Bathe with a mixture of hot and cold water to draw out the toxic sores until the condition resolves.

**Eye-Washing Decoction**, for treating upward-rising heat attacking the eyes, causing nebulae, heat-pain, and tearing:
*Qinpi* (ash bark), *huangbo* (phellodendron), *juemingzi* (cassia seed), *huanglian* (coptis), *huangqin* (scutellaria), *ruiren* (bush-cherry kernel), each eighteen *zhu*; seven gardenia fruits; five jujubes.
The eight ingredients are cut and steeped in two *sheng* of water, then boiled to six *ge*. Clarify, and while lying supine, wash the eyes once daily.

**Formula for Eye Growths**:
Ten cowries, burned to ash and sifted.
Apply an amount the size of a soybean to the nebula twice daily. Lie supine while another applies it. After a long steaming, wipe it away. For fleshy growths, add genuine pearl in equal parts to the cowries.

**Formula for Red Eyes and Nebulae**:
Cuttlefish bone and *qiandan* (lead oxide) in equal amounts.
Grind finely together, mix with white honey to a paste, and steam for half a mealtime. When cool, apply to the four canthi.

**Alternative Formulas**:
- Apply sheep marrow; effective.
- Dry a mature sheep’s eyeballs in the sun, grind to powder, and apply to the canthi.
- Dry a newborn’s placenta in the sun, burn to ash, and apply to the canthi.
- One ancient coin and one *fangcunbi* of *guan* powder.
Grind together and sift, then apply to the canthi.

**Formula for Wind-Induced Tearing, Floating Nebulae, and Purulent Erosion of the Canthi**:
Dried ginger, *juemingzi*, *fanshi* (alum), *ruiren*, *xixin* (asarum), *huanglian*, *rongyan* (halite), each six *zhu*; three *zhu* of *tongqing* (verdigris).
Cut the ingredients, steep in a small amount of water overnight, then mix with eight *ge* of fine white honey in a bronze vessel. Cover the vessel with silk and place it in a steamer with three *dou* of wheat bran. Steam until the rice is cooked and the medicine is ready. Strain to remove the dregs, then mix in the gallbladders of two large male carp that have recently died. Place seven large coins at the bottom of the medicine and keep them in the bronze vessel. Wrap the head of a bamboo hairpin with silk and use it to apply the medicine to the canthi three or four times day and night, regardless of cold or heat. Reapply as the medicine dries, remixing with carp gallbladder as needed. Cover the medicine vessel to retain its potency; this is most effective.

**Formula for Heat-Induced Nebulae Obscuring the Eyes**:
Rinse the mouth with sheep tendon, chew thoroughly, and at night, with the eyes open, insert it. Close the eyes and sleep; the membrane will dissolve, and the condition will resolve by the next day. The *Qianjin Yi* states this also treats dim vision.

**Formula for Wind-Induced Nebulae**:
Burn a dead pig’s snout to ash and sift. Once daily, face the sun and take one *fangcunbi* with water.

**Formula for Heat-Induced Red or White Membranes in the Eyes**:
Take the straight, fine droppings of a male sparrow, mix with human milk, and grind thoroughly. Apply to gradually dissolve the membrane.

**Alternative Formula**:
Burn roundworms to ash and apply; effective.

**Formula for Human or Horse White Membranes Obscuring the Eyes**:
Cut a chicken feather and use it to gently brush near the black and white of the eye until the membrane gathers. Use a hooked needle to pull and excise it. Vision will be restored immediately. Apply silk to the eye to staunch the bleeding; the condition will resolve in three days.

**Dangfeng Powder**, for treating white membranes in the eyes and wind-induced tearing (from the *Shanfan Fang*, also called **True Pearl Powder**):
Half a *liang* of bright cinnabar; five cowries, roasted on charcoal until done and ground to powder; seven silverfish from clothing; three *zhu* of dried ginger (in one version, substitute fresh ginger juice, settled and powdered, for dried ginger).
Grind the four ingredients together in a new porcelain mortar. Sift through thick silk three times to obtain the powder.

Lie supine and have another person use their little fingernail to lift a small amount of the powder and apply it to the eye, continuing until the condition resolves. (The *Qianjin Yifang* calls this **True Pearl Powder**, for treating corneal opacity that obscures the pupil and impairs vision.)

**For fleshly growths in the eye, progressive membrane opacity threatening to cover the eye, closure of the pupil, and pearl-like tubes:**
Seven cowries, burned and ground to powder; an equal portion of true pearl.
Combine the two ingredients and process into a fine powder. Apply to the growth or opacity three times daily; highly effective. Also treats persistent discharge from the eye.

**For pearl-like tubes in the eye:**
Talc (or "cold stone"); burned fingernails; dragon bone; cowries; cinnabar, equal portions.
Grind the five ingredients and sift. Use a new brush to apply the powder to the pearl-like tube three times daily; highly effective.

**For red, painful eyes with opacity following toxic illness:**
Cover the eyes with a piece of blue cloth, then soak the cloth in cold water, changing it frequently.

**For opacity following febrile illness:**
Burn fourteen fermented soybeans into powder, place in a tube, and blow into the eye.

**For dimmed vision or blindness following febrile illness:**
Apply sheep’s gallbladder to the eyes, once at dawn and once at dusk.

**For wind-induced erosion at the canthi:**
Bamboo leaves, one *liang*; coptis, one *liang*; white mulberry bark, one and a half *liang*.
[Text missing] Chop the three ingredients, add two *sheng* of water, and boil down to five *ge*. Drip the decoction into the canthi three or four times daily.

**For neonatal red eyes:**
Take a branch of sophora wood, as thick as a riding crop and two *chi* long, with a flat end. Place one spoonful of sesame oil in a copper mortar, and have a child grind the wood in it daily until dusk. At bedtime, wash the eyes and apply the mixture to the canthi three times daily; highly effective.

**For erosive red eyes:**
Take three pinches of salt and place on an ancient coin. Heat the coin repeatedly over fire until red-hot, then immerse in a small amount of vinegar, enough to cover the coin. Use silk to absorb the liquid and apply to the canthi.

**Milk Decoction, for wind-cold overflow in the eyes, red and itchy canthi:**
Coptis, eighteen *zhu*; bush cherry kernel, half a *liang*; dried ginger, one *liang*.
[Text missing] Chop the three ingredients, soak in one *sheng* of human milk overnight, then gently simmer the next morning to yield three *ge*. Strain through silk. Apply a millet-sized amount to the inner canthus three times daily. (Zhang Wenzhong’s formula uses equal portions of the three ingredients.)

**For wind-induced swelling and pain in the eyes, to clear heat and soothe the eyes:**
Burn three *liang* of alum until its liquid is exhausted, then mix with jujube paste to form a pill the size of a bullet. Rub over the upper and lower eyelids for the duration of a meal, three times daily.

**Eye-Washing Decoction, for red and painful eyes:**
Seven sweet bamboo leaves; three smoked plums; three ancient coins.
Steep the three ingredients in two *sheng* of water for half a day. Boil over an east-facing stove, bringing to a boil three times and lowering the heat three times, to yield two *ge*. Apply to the canthi before sleep.

**For sudden eye swelling:**
Wash the eyes with a salt solution made from vinegar and water, four or five times daily.

**For sudden itching and pain in the eyes:**
Carve dried ginger into a smooth, round piece and insert into the canthus. When fluid appears, wipe it away and reinsert the ginger. Replace when the flavor is exhausted.

**For heat from the five viscera rising to the eyes, combined with external wind-cold, causing pain and dimmed vision:**
Earth skin seeds; melon seeds; feather cockscomb seeds; caltrop seeds; motherwort seeds; indigo seeds; dodder seeds; bush cherry kernels (in the *Qianjin Yifang*, substitute plantain seeds), two *ge* each; arborvitae seeds, one and a half *ge*; cassia tora seeds, five *ge*; asarum, one *liang* and six *zhu*; cinnamon bark, one *liang* and eighteen *zhu*; rhubarb, two *liang*; firefly, six *zhu*; coptis, one and a half *liang*.
Grind the fifteen ingredients into powder and form into honey pills the size of firmiana seeds. Take thirty pills after meals, three times daily. (The *Qianjin Yifang* omits arborvitae seeds.)

**For red and painful eyes:**
Realgar, one *zhu*; asarum; coptis; dried ginger, two *zhu* each.
Combine and process into a fine powder. Wrap in silk around a hairpin, moisten the tip with saliva, dip in the powder, and insert into the inner canthus. Close the eyes tightly until tears flow, then stop. Do not touch with the hands, wrap in cloth, or wash the eyes.

**Another formula:**

Realgar, six *zhu*; dried ginger, six *zhu*; coptis, six *zhu*; alum, six *zhu*.
Combine the four ingredients and process as in the previous formula. One variant adds six *zhu* of asarum.

**For red and dim eyes:**
Three ancient bronze coins; green salt, one *liang* and six *zhu*; apricot kernels (harvested before ripening, pounded to extract one *ge* of juice).
Combine the three ingredients in an earthenware vessel, seal the opening to prevent qi from escaping, and set aside for one hundred days before use. Apply to the four canthi of the eyes, two or three times daily. Avoid wind and cold.

**For dim, red, and cold-afflicted eyes:**
Bush-cherry kernels; Persian salt.
Grind the two ingredients in equal parts into a fine powder, then mix with fresh donkey fat. Each night, apply a millet-sized portion to the four corners of the eyes. Rest in a secluded chamber for one month to heal. Avoid the five pungent foods. For those who have lost their sight, apply for thirty days.

**For unceasing eye pain and protrusion:**
Carve aconite into pieces the size of silkworm droppings and place inside the eye before sleeping. Effective.

**For unclear vision and protrusion:**
Apply crow-gallbladder to the eyes before sleeping.

**For night blindness:**
Five *liang* of broom cypress fruit; one *sheng* of cassia tora seeds.
Grind the two ingredients into powder and form into pills with rice-water infusion. Take twenty to thirty pills after meals, twice daily. When the dose is finished, prepare another. Discontinue upon recovery.

**Method for night blindness:**
Have the afflicted person observe where sparrows roost at dusk, then startle them into flight. Recite the incantation: *"Purple Lord, Purple Lord, I return your blindness, you return my clarity."* Perform this at dusk daily for three repetitions; the eyes will brighten. This method has been tested and proven effective. (The *Zhouhou* states: The *Shanfan* records this as Physician Zhi’s method.)

**True Pearl Powder, for liver qi deficiency and cold, with greenish eyes and impaired vision:**
One *liang* of ground true pearl; two *ge* of white honey; one carp gallbladder; one carp brain.
Combine the four ingredients, gently heat until boiling twice, then wrap in silk and place inside the eye. When the fluid drains, reapply the remedy.

**For eyes that see nothing:**
Finely chop one green goat liver, place in a copper vessel with one *dou* of water, and cover with a fermented cake. Pierce two holes in the cake the size of human eyes, then position the eyes directly over the steam. Recovery occurs after no more than two applications. (The *Qianjin Yifang* omits the fermented cake for evening blindness.)

**For dim eyes:**
Fill a copper vessel with three to four *sheng* of strong vinegar and heat for seven to eight days. Place the vessel on damp earth, collect one *ge* of verdigris, and mix with the juice of one *sheng* of white apricot kernels harvested in the third month. Apply three or four times daily for excellent results.

**Another formula:**

**Another formula:**
Take seven ancient coins, verdigris, dried ginger, halite, lead powder, *pixie* seeds (each the size of a jujube pit), *wutou*, jujube kernels, *dahuang* (rhubarb) three *zhu*, *xixin* (asarum) five *zhu*, *ruiren* (bush cherry kernels) one hundred and thirty pieces, two *ge* of vinegar, five *ge* of clear wine, and a handful of catalpa leaves (extract the juice). Grind the first thirteen ingredients into a fine powder, combine, and decoct until reduced by one-third. Store in a porcelain vessel. If the mixture dries, blend with human milk and apply to the eyes. Avoid wind and cold.

**Another formula:**
Each morning, hold a piece of *huangbo* (phellodendron) the size of a fingernail in the mouth to generate saliva, then rub the eyes with the saliva from the palm. Rinse with water afterward. After one hundred days, the eyes will become clear. This method may be practiced for life to permanently eliminate eye ailments—highly effective.

**Another formula:**
Take six *zhu* of *chaihu* (bupleurum) and eighteen *zhu* of *juemingzi* (cassia seeds). Grind into a fine powder, mix with human milk, and apply to the eyes. This enables one to read at night and perceive the five colors.

**For dim eyes:**
Extract one *ge* of juice from the white part of a bitter bottle gourd harvested on the seventh day of the seventh month. Soak seven ancient inscribed coins in one *sheng* of vinegar, decoct over a low flame until reduced by half, then place a piece the size of a grain of rice into the eye.

**For eyes that see nothing:**
Take eighteen *zhu* each of *ruiren* (bush cherry kernels), *qinpi* (fraxinus bark), and *huanglian* (coptis), seven fireflies, and one *ge* of *juemingzi* (cassia seeds). Chop the ingredients, decoct in eight *ge* of water over a low flame, and reduce to three *ge*.

For cold conditions, rinse the eyes with cotton three times daily.

**Prescription for lightening the body, augmenting qi, and brightening the eyes by regular consumption of *wujingzi* (rape seeds):**
Take one *sheng* of *wujingzi*, boil in four *sheng* of water until the liquid is exhausted, remove and dry in the sun. Repeat the process with four *sheng* of water, boiling and drying three times in total. Grind into a fine powder. Take one *fangcunbi* (square-inch spoonful) with water.

*The Qianjin Yi* states: After one hundred days, the body will develop heat sores, which will soon resolve on their own.

**Prescription for brightening the eyes and preventing hair loss:**
On the *shangsi* day of the tenth month, gather pagoda tree seeds and place them in a clean new jar, sealing the mouth tightly with a basin. After twenty-one days, unseal, wash away the skins, and collect the seeds. Begin on the first day of the month by taking one seed, two seeds on the second day, increasing daily until ten days, totaling fifty-five seeds. In one month, take one hundred sixty-five seeds; in one year, one thousand nine hundred eighty seeds. In months with fewer days, reduce by sixty seeds. This medicine nourishes the brain; taken early, it prevents graying hair, enhances complexion, and prolongs life. Those with preexisting cold conditions should not take it.

*The Zhouhou [Beiji Fang]* attributes this to Bian Que’s formula.

**Alternative prescription:**
Steep pagoda tree seeds in ox bile and dry in the shade for one hundred days. Swallow one seed after meals. After ten days, the body will feel light; after thirty days, white hair will turn black again; after one hundred days, one will attain spiritual clarity.

**For objects lodged in the eye that cannot be expelled:**
Swallow one grain of silkworm excrement; the object will emerge immediately.

**For rice or wheat awns entering the eye:**
Take a live grub and cover the eye with a new cloth. Rub the grub over the cloth; the awn will adhere to the cloth. This method is highly effective.

**For sand, stones, grass, or wood entering the eye that cannot be removed:**
Apply chicken liver to the eye.

**Alternative prescription:**

**For objects lodged in the eye:**
Mix booklice with breast milk and apply to the eye.

**Method for treating objects in the eye:**
At dawn, kneel facing the doorway and recite: *"The doorway is narrow, unfit to lodge a guest."* The ailment will then be cured.

**For eye injuries with bruising (green-black discoloration):**
Boil mutton until hot and apply as a compress—avoid excessive heat. Pork liver may also be used.

**For eye pain preventing sleep:**
At dusk, warm a fresh piece of indigo-dyed cloth and apply as a compress. Steam soybeans, place them in a pouch, and use as a pillow, keeping it warm through the night.

**For red, painful eyes beginning at the inner canthus:**
Treat the Yin Qiao vessel.

**For eye pain with impaired vision:**
The *Shangxing* point governs this; first needle *Yixi*, then *Tianyou* and *Fengchi*.

**For green blindness (poor distant vision):**
The *Chengguang* point governs this.

**For blurred vision when looking afar:**
The *Muchuang* point governs this.

**For red, painful eyes with swelling:**
The *Tianzhu* point governs this.

**For dizziness with loss of sight, unilateral headache extending to the outer canthus with tension:**
The *Hanyan* point governs this.

**For poor distant vision, aversion to wind, tearing, chills, headache, dizziness, inner canthus redness and pain, blurred distant vision, canthus itching and pain, excessive eye discharge, white nebula, and clouded vision:**
The *Jingming* point governs this.

**For green blindness with no perception of light, blurred distant vision, excessive eye discharge, and white membrane covering the pupil:**
The *Jujiao* point governs this.

**For dim vision, exophthalmos, dizziness, pupil itching, blurred distant vision, night blindness, eye twitching, tension involving the neck, mouth, and jaw, facial distortion, and inability to speak:**
Needle *Chengqi*.

**For distorted, painful, and dim vision:**
The *Sibai* point governs this.

**For red or yellow eyes:**
The *Quanjiao* point governs this.

**For squinting eyes:**
The *Shuigou* point governs this.

**For painful, dim vision:**
The *Yinjiao* point governs this.

**For blurred vision with sweating:**
The *Chengjiang* point governs this.

**For green blindness with aversion to wind and cold:**
The *Shangguan* point governs this.

**For green blindness:**
The *Shangyang* point governs this.

**For eye pain:**
The *Xialian* point governs this.

**For white nebula in the eye:**
The *Qiangu* point governs this.

**For painful eyes with tearing, or severe pain as if the eye will detach:**
The *Qiangu* point governs this.

**For white membrane covering the pupil with total loss of sight:**
The *Jiexi* point governs this.

**For moxibustion of other points, see previous sections.**

**For dim vision and shortness of breath:**
Moxa the *Wuli* point—treat the right for the left, and the left for the right.

**For poor vision:**
Moxa below the *Dazhui* point, at the tenth vertebra along the spine. Apply two hundred cones; the more, the better. This method is highly effective.

**For liver strain with pathogenic qi causing red eyes:**
Moxa *Dangrong* with one hundred cones on each side. The point lies near the outer canthus, behind the eye, at the convergence of the three yang and three yin meridians before the ear. Pressing with both hands will reveal a horizontal pulse above and below—it aligns with *Ermen*.

**For acute eye pain with inability to see far:**
Moxa one *cun* above the pupil within the hairline, using cones equal to the patient’s age. The point is called *Dangyang*.

**For wind-induced nebula in the right eye:**
Moxa five cones the size of wheat grains on the head of the middle finger’s proximal joint of the right hand. The same applies to the left hand for the left eye.

**For wind-induced itching and redness:**
Moxa two cones near the base of the nose on *Renzhong*, with the patient lying supine.

**For sudden nebula formation:**
Moxa three cones on the transverse crease of the thumb’s joint—treat the left for the right, and the right for the left. This method is highly effective.

*Sun Zhenren’s* *Essential Emergency Prescriptions Worth a Thousand Gold Pieces*, Scroll Fifteen, concludes.
**Section on Seven Orifices’ Ailments** *(These four characters were originally missing and have been supplied in accordance with the text’s format.)*

**Section on Seven Orifices’ Ailments**
**Nasal Disorders, Second** *(Discourse, Prescriptions, and Moxibustion Methods)*

**For nasal congestion, cold brain, and clear snivel discharge:**
*Tongcao* (Rice-paper Plant Pith) and *Xinyin* (Magnolia Flower) – half a *liang* each
*Xixin* (Asarum), *Gansui* (alternatively *Gancao*, Licorice), *Guixin* (Cinnamon Heart), *Xiongqiong* (Ligusticum), and *Fuzi* (Aconite) – one *liang* each
Grind the seven ingredients into powder and form honeyed pills. Wrap in silk and insert into the nostrils, sealing tightly to prevent qi leakage. The pills should be the size of hemp seeds; slightly increase the size if mild pain is felt. Pounding ginger into the pills will cure the condition, and mixing with white dog’s gallbladder bile yields even better results.

**For nasal congestion with persistent clear snivel discharge:**
*Xixin* (Asarum), *Shujiao* (Sichuan Pepper), *Ganjiang* (Dried Ginger), *Xiongqiong* (Ligusticum), *Wuzhuyu* (Evodia), *Fuzi* (Aconite) – eighteen *zhu* each
*Guixin* (Cinnamon Heart) – one *liang*
*Zaojia* (Gleditsia) powder – half a *liang*
Lard – one *sheng*
Chop the nine ingredients, wrap in silk, and soak in bitter wine overnight. Fry in lard until the aconite turns yellow, then strain. Wrap in silk and insert into the nostrils, also applying to the bridge of the nose.

**For incessant snivel discharge:**
Moxa seven cones at the level of the nostrils and nasal bridge.

**Fragrant Ointment for Nasal Congestion and Obstruction:**
*Baizhi* (Angelica Dahurica) and *Xiongqiong* (Ligusticum) – eighteen *zhu* each
*Tongcao* (Rice-paper Plant Pith) – eighteen *zhu*
*Danggui* (Chinese Angelica), *Xixin* (Asarum), *Mangcao* (*Xiaopin* and *Qianjin Yifang* use *Xuncao*, Lemongrass) – thirteen *zhu* each
*Xinyin* (Magnolia Flower) – thirteen *zhu*
Chop the seven ingredients, soak in bitter wine overnight, then fry in one *sheng* of water-free lard with three rounds of heating and cooling until *Baizhi* turns yellow and the ointment forms. Strain. Dip silk in an amount the size of a jujube pit and insert into the nostrils, three times daily. *Xiaopin* adds eighteen *zhu* of *Guixin* (Cinnamon Heart).

**Fragrant Ointment for Nasal Obstruction:**
*Danggui* (Chinese Angelica), *Xuncao* (*Gujin Luyan* uses *Muxiang*, Costus Root) – eighteen *zhu* each
*Tongcao* (Rice-paper Plant Pith), *Xixin* (Asarum), *Ruiren* (Bush Cherry Kernel) – eighteen *zhu* each
*Xiongqiong* (Ligusticum), *Baizhi* (Angelica Dahurica) – half a *liang* each
Sheep marrow – four *liang* (pork lard may also be used)
Chop the eight ingredients and gently fry, heating and cooling three times until *Baizhi* turns yellow and the ointment forms. Strain. Take a piece the size of a small bean and insert into the nostrils twice daily. For those with prior heat conditions who later develop red, ulcerated sores in the nostrils, substitute *Huangqin* (Scutellaria) and *Zhizi* (Gardenia) for *Danggui* and *Xixin*.

**For nasal obstruction with blocked breathing:**
Boil one handful of *Xiaoji* (Field Thistle) in three *sheng* of water until one *sheng* remains. Divide into two doses.
**Alternative Prescription:**
Blow a small amount of *Guadi* (Melon Pedicel) powder into the nostrils, or wrap in silk and insert into the nose.
**Another Prescription:**
Five *sheng* of *Huaiye* (Sophora Leaves), one *sheng* of sliced *Congbai* (Spring Onion), and one *ge* of *Chi* (Fermented Soybeans)
Boil the three ingredients in five *sheng* of water until three *sheng* remain. Divide into three warm doses.

**For chronic nasal congestion lasting years, loss of smell, and incessant clear discharge:**
Take one handful of *Jili* (Caltrop) run over by a passing cart, pound, and boil in three *sheng* of water until cooked. Have the patient lie supine while another person fills their mouth with the decoction and pours one *ge* into the nostrils. After no more than two applications, the patient will sneeze, expelling one or two polyps resembling red maggots. One version includes equal parts *Huanglian* (Coptis) in the decoction.

**For nasal congestion with polyps (nasal *bao*):**
*Tongcao* (Rice-paper Plant Pith), *Xixin* (Asarum), and *Fuzi* (Aconite) – equal parts
Grind into powder, mix with honey, and wrap a small amount in silk to insert into the nostrils.
**Alternative Prescription:**
*Gansui* (Kansui Root), *Tongcao* (Rice-paper Plant Pith), *Xixin* (Asarum), and *Fuzi* (Aconite) – equal parts
Grind into powder, mix with white male dog’s gallbladder bile, and form pills the size of jujube pits. Wrap in silk and insert into the nostrils; a discharge of four to five *sheng* of pungent, hot snivel will follow, curing the condition. Also treats polyps.
**Another Prescription:**
Roast *Zaojia* (Gleditsia), grind into powder the size of small beans, and blow into the nostrils using a bamboo tube.
**Another Prescription:**
Grind *Ganjiang* (Dried Ginger) into powder, mix with honey, and insert into the nostrils. Blowing the powder in is also effective.
**Another Prescription:**
Grind an iron lock against stone to obtain powder, mix with lard, and wrap in silk to insert. After a day, the polyps will emerge and the condition will resolve.
**Another Prescription:**
Have the patient lie face down over a bed, fill their mouth with fresh horse urine, and pour it into the nostrils.
**Another Prescription:**
Have the patient face downward at the edge of a bed, pour newly drawn cold water over *Yuzhen* (Jade Pillow point), then wrap *Guadi* (Melon Pedicel) powder in silk and insert into the nostrils.

**For nasal congestion with polyps and loss of smell:**
*Guading* (Melon Pedicel) and *Xixin* (Asarum) – equal parts
Grind into powder, wrap a piece the size of a small bean in silk, and insert into the nostrils. The passage will clear momentarily.

**Powder of *Tongcao* for Nasal Polyps Causing Obstruction:**
*Tongcao* (Rice-paper Plant Pith) – half a *liang*
*Fanshi* (Alum) and *Zhenzhu* (Pearl) – one *liang* each
Grind the three ingredients into powder. Twist silk into the shape of a jujube pit, dip a small bean-sized amount of the powder onto the silk, and insert into the nostrils, changing it three times daily. One version adds one *liang* each of *Guixin* (Cinnamon Heart) and *Xixin* (Asarum), grinding and mixing them as above.

**For chronic rhinitis with nasal polyps obstructing breath:**
*Fanshi* (Alum) and *Lilu* (Black False Hellebore) – six *zhu* each
*Guadi* (Melon Pedicel) – fourteen pieces
*Fuzi* (Aconite) – twelve *zhu*
Grind each ingredient separately, then combine. Use a small bamboo tube to blow a small bean-sized amount of the powder into the nostrils, then plug with silk floss. Apply twice daily until cured.

*Sun Zhenren’s Essential Emergency Prescriptions Worth a Thousand Gold Pieces*, Scroll Sixteen
Collated and Corrected by Lin Yi, Gentleman for Court Service and Acting Vice Minister of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices, concurrently Proofreader of the Imperial Library, and others during the Song Dynasty.

From *Records of Ancient and Modern Verified Prescriptions*:

**Addendum:** *Caozheng* (Stemona) – half a *liang*.

**For nasal polyps:**
Char hedgehog skin into powder, wrap in silk floss, and insert into the nostrils for three days.

**Another formula:**
Sift soot from the bottom of a cauldron finely, and take with water for three to five days.

**For nasal polyps with loss of smell:**
Burn *fanshi* (alum) into powder and mix with facial grease. Wrap in silk floss and place inside the nostrils; after several days, the polyps will dissolve and fall away with the medicine.

**Another formula:**
Grind *guading* (melon pedicel) into a small bean-sized amount and blow into the nostrils—it will certainly dissolve the polyps. Repeat three or four times for efficacy.

**Another formula:**
*Xixin* (Asarum) and soot from the bottom of a cauldron.
Grind the two ingredients into powder, mix with water, and take a *fangcunbi*-sized spoonful.

**Another formula:**
Wrap *guadi* (melon pedicel) powder in silk floss and insert into the nostrils.

**Yangfei Powder, for protruding nasal polyps:**
One dried sheep lung
*Baizhu* (Atractylodes) – four *liang*
*Congrong* (Cistanche), *tongcao* (Rice Paper Plant Pith), *ganjiang* (Dried Ginger), and *xiongqiong* (Ligusticum) – two *liang* each
Grind the six ingredients into powder. After meals, take five *fen* with rice water, increasing to a *fangcunbi*-sized spoonful.

**Another formula:**
*Tongcao* (Rice Paper Plant Pith) – twelve *zhu*
*Zhenzhu* (Pearl) – six *zhu*
*Fanshi* (Alum) and *xixin* (Asarum) – one *liang* each
Grind the four ingredients into powder. Roll silk floss into a date-pit shape, dip in the powder to the size of a black soybean, and insert into the nostrils two or three times daily.

**For nasal polyps:**
Moxibustion at *Shangxing* (GV-23) – two hundred cones. The point is located one *cun* within the hairline directly above the nose.
**Another method:** Moxibustion at points three *cun* bilateral to *Shangxing*, one hundred cones each.

**For sores in the nostrils:**
Burn sacrificial rice into powder and apply inside the nostrils.

**Another formula:**
Burn an old horse tether into powder and apply inside the nostrils.

**Another formula:**
Wipe the nostrils with a mourning cap.

**Another formula:**
Apply earwax from a black ox.

**Another formula:**
Apply mucus from a cow’s nose.

**Another formula:**
Pound apricot kernels into milk and apply. Alternatively, burn the kernels, press to extract oil, and apply.

**Another formula:**
Burn bones of cows and dogs into ash, mix with lard from a twelfth-month pig, and apply.

**For gan-worms eroding the nose and causing sores:**
Heat the tip of a copper chopstick until red-hot, then quench it repeatedly in vinegar. Apply the vinegar to the sores. Alternatively, apply the ash of human feces to heal them.

**For nasal pain:**
Regularly apply oil inside and outside the nose. Ghee may also be used.

**For sudden blockage when food retracts into the brain through the nose, causing persistent pain and obstruction:**
Take a piece of cow or sheep fat the size of a fingertip and insert it into the nose. Inhale the fat through the nose; as it melts, the obstruction will follow the fat out.

**Discourse:**
A slightly pale nose indicates blood loss. If it is unusually flushed at an inopportune time, death will follow. A pallid complexion in a patient always signifies blood loss. During seasonal epidemics, nosebleeds should not be stopped immediately. If the bleeding exceeds one or two *sheng*, it may be stanched for fear of excessive loss. Use powdered dragon bone blown into the nose. For bleeding from any of the nine orifices, apply this method.

**For bloody stool, bleeding from the mouth and nose, blood ascending to the heart and chest, and labored breathing—all caused by consumptive heat:**
**Ingredients:**
- Fresh rehmannia (8 *liang*)
- Cattail pollen (1 *sheng*)
- Lycium root bark (5 *liang*)
- Scutellaria (3 *liang*)
- Peony (3 *liang*)
- Fresh bamboo shavings (3 *liang*)

Grind the six ingredients, then decoct in eight *sheng* of water until reduced to two *sheng* and seven *ge*. Divide into three warm doses.

**For hematemesis, epistaxis, and hematuria—all due to visceral qi deficiency, diaphragmatic injury, or arising from fright and palpitations:**
**Ingredients:**
- Fresh bamboo shavings (1 *sheng*)
- Peony (2 *liang*)
- Scutellaria (2 *liang*)
- Ligusticum (1 *liang*)
- Tangkuei (1 *liang*)
- Cinnamon bark (1 *liang*)
- Licorice (1 *liang*)

Grind the seven ingredients, then boil the bamboo shavings in one *dou* of water until reduced to three *sheng*. Add the remaining herbs and simmer to two *sheng*. Divide into three doses.

**For epistaxis:**
**Ingredients:**
- Fresh rehmannia (6 *liang*)
- Ligusticum (1 *liang*)
- Asarum (6 *zhu*)
- Hearth ashes (2 pieces, each the size of a chicken egg)
- Cinnamon bark (3 *liang*)
- Angelica (3 *liang*)
- Dried ginger (3 *liang*)
- Peony (3 *liang*)
- Licorice (3 *liang*)
- Evodia (3 *liang*)

Grind the ten ingredients, then decoct in three *sheng* of water and seven *sheng* of wine until reduced to three *sheng*. Divide into three doses.

**Fresh Rehmannia Decoction for epistaxis:**
**Ingredients:**
- Fresh rehmannia (8 *liang*)
- Scutellaria (1 *liang*)
- Ass-hide glue (2 *liang*)
- Licorice (2 *liang*)
- Biota leaves (1 handful)

Grind the five ingredients, then decoct in seven *sheng* of water until reduced to three *sheng*. Strain, add the glue, and simmer to two and a half *sheng*. Divide into three doses.

**Another formula:**
- Fresh rehmannia (3 *jin*, sliced)
- Ass-hide glue (2 *liang*)
- Cattail pollen (6 *ge*)

Decoct in five *sheng* of water until reduced to three *sheng*. Divide into three doses.

**Another formula:**
Simmer five *ge* of rehmannia juice until reduced to four *ge*. Take on an empty stomach. Avoid wine and roasted meat; consume rice broth instead.

**Another formula:**
Drink small thistle juice for good effect.

**Another formula:**
Rinse the mouth thoroughly with cold water, hold water in the mouth, and blow into the nostrils through a reed tube.

**Another formula:**
Burn five *liang* of human hair into ash. Blow a jujube-pit-sized amount into the nose; if bleeding persists, blow more until it stops. Take one *fangcunbi* with well water, three times daily. For severe cases, take twice at night. Even in critical cases where the patient is unconscious, this remedy is effective.

**Another formula:**
Burn the tip of human feces into ash. Take with water and blow a small amount into the nose to stop bleeding.

**Another formula:**
On the fifth day of the fifth month, burn human feces into ash. Take five *fenbi* with cold water for good effect.

**Another formula:**
Apply glue to the nose, extending upward to the hairline for a length of three *cun*.

**Another formula:**
Instill fresh horse dung juice into the nose and drink it for good effect.

**Another formula:**
Apply a damp cloth to the chest for relief.

**Another formula:**
Mix thick wine with soil and apply to the scrotum. Replace when dry.

**Another formula:**
Extract juice from leek and scallion roots. Insert a jujube-pit-sized amount into the nose; replace after a short while. Repeat two or three times to heal. Scallion-white juice may also be used.

**For unremitting epistaxis:**
**Ingredients:**
- Dried rehmannia
- Gardenia
- Licorice (equal parts)

Grind the three ingredients into a fine powder.

Take one *fangcunbi* of the powder with wine, three times daily. If the nose is painful, add one *ge* of fermented soybeans; for wind-heat in the nose, mix with nasal mucus and take five *wuzǐ*-sized pills.

**Another formula:**
Pound mulberry leaves to extract the juice and drink three *sheng*; highly effective.

**Another method:**
Draw a bow with the string facing upward, have the afflicted child lie supine with the string as a pillow, and position the limbs as in normal sleep.

When nosebleeds cause itching, immediately moxibust the transverse crease at the three hairs on the big toe’s joint—ten cones for mild cases, one hundred for severe. For unremitting epistaxis, apply moxibustion; this also treats swollen testicles.

**Further moxibustion points:**
- Moxibust *Fengfu* (GV 16) with four cones; repeat if bleeding persists.
- Moxibust *Yongquan* (KI 1) on both feet, one hundred cones each.

*The seventeenth volume of Sun Zhenren’s* *Essential Emergency Formulas Worth a Thousand in Gold*, collated and corrected by Lin Yi, Gentleman for Court Service and Acting Vice Minister of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices, concurrently Editorial Director of the Palace Library, of the Song Dynasty.

**Formulas for the Seven Orifices: Oral Diseases (Third Section)**

**Discourse on Formulas and Moxibustion Methods**
It is said: For all who suffer from mouth sores or tooth ailments, abstain from oily foods, fermented grains, wine, soy sauce, sour vinegar, salty and greasy foods, and dried jujubes. Even after recovery, one must remain cautious; if one does not exercise prolonged restraint, the condition will promptly recur, and once it does, it will be difficult to cure. The roots of *qiangwei* (Rosa multiflora) and *jiaohao* (Artemisia keiskeana) are divine remedies for mouth sores, yet few know of them.

**Formula for Fleshy Growths on the Face and in the Mouth That Gradually Enlarge:**
Lance with a knife to drain pus and blood; this will bring immediate healing.

**Formula for Chronic Mouth Sores That Fail to Heal, Spreading to the Chest and Persisting for Over Three Years:**
Boil *qiangwei* roots into a thick decoction, hold it in the mouth, and swallow it gradually—three times by day, once by night. In winter, use the roots; in summer, use the stems and leaves.

**Alternate Formula:**
Apply *jiaohao* ash as a poultice. Improvement will be evident after one night, and healing will occur after two. Spit out any fluid; do not swallow it.

**Formula for Persistent Mouth Sores:**
- *Niuxi* (Achyranthes bidentata) – 3 *liang*
- Fresh *suhe* (Mentha haplocalyx) roots – 3 *liang*
- *Huangbo* (Phellodendron amurense) – 1 *liang*

Grind the three ingredients, wrap them in silk, and steep in three *sheng* of wine overnight. Gently heat until the decoction lightly boils, then finely strain and hold in the mouth.

**Shengma Decoction for Unremitting Bladder Heat, Mouth and Tongue Sores, and Swollen Throat:**
- *Shengma* (Cimicifuga foetida) – 4 *liang*
- *Xuanshen* (Scrophularia ningpoensis) – 4 *liang*
- White bark of *qiangwei* roots – 4 *liang*
- *Shegan* (Belamcanda chinensis) – 4 *liang*
- *Daqing* (Isatis indigotica) – 3 *liang*
- *Huangbo* – 3 *liang*
- Honey – 7 *ge*

Grind the seven ingredients, boil in seven *sheng* of water, and reduce to one *sheng* and five *ge*. Strain, add honey, and simmer for two more boils. Hold the decoction in the mouth and swallow it slowly.

**Formula for Recurrent Mouth Sores Persisting for Years Without Healing:**
- *Qiangwei* roots – 1 *liang*
- *Huangqin* (Scutellaria baicalensis) – 1 *liang*
- *Danggui* (Angelica sinensis) – 1 *liang*
- *Jiegeng* (Platycodon grandiflorus) – 1 *liang*
- *Huangqi* (Astragalus membranaceus) – 1 *liang*
- *Bailian* (Ampelopsis japonica) – 1 *liang*
- *Dahuang* (Rheum palmatum) – 1 *liang*
- Bark of *shuli* (Rhamnus davurica) roots – 1 *liang*
- *Shaoyao* (Paeonia lactiflora) – 1 *liang*
- *Xuduan* (Dipsacus asperoides) – 1 *liang*
- *Huangbo* – 1 *liang*
- *Gegen* (Pueraria lobata) – 1 *liang*

Grind the twelve ingredients into powder. Take one *fangcunbi* with wine, twice daily. It may also be taken with fermented water.

**Formula for Guest Heat in the Stomach, Dry Lips and Mouth, and Sores:**
- *Fuling* (Poria cocos) – 30 *zhu*
- *Huangqin* – 30 *zhu*
- *Gancao* (Glycyrrhiza uralensis) – 30 *zhu*
- *Dahuang* – 30 *zhu*
- *Qiangwei* roots – 30 *zhu*
- *Zhishi* (Citrus aurantium) – 1 *liang*
- *Xingren* (Prunus armeniaca) – 1 *liang*
- *Huanglian* (Coptis chinensis) – 1 *liang*
- *Guixin* (Cinnamomum cassia) – ½ *liang*
- *Gualou* (Trichosanthes kirilowii) roots – 18 *zhu*

Grind the ten ingredients into powder. Take one *fangcunbi* with fermented water before meals, twice daily.

**Formula for Heat-Induced Mouth Sores:**
- *Shengma* – 30 *zhu*
- *Huanglian* – 18 *zhu* (alternatively, as in *Ancient and Modern Proven Formulas*)
- *Huangbo*

Grind the two ingredients into powder, wrap in silk, and hold in the mouth to swallow the juice. The residue may be discarded.

**Formula for Mouth Sores:**
- *Huangbo* – 2 *liang*
- *Shengma* – 3 *liang*
- Fresh *dihuang* (Rehmannia glutinosa) – 5 *liang*
- Bark of *qiangwei* roots – 4 *liang*

Grind the four ingredients, boil in seven *sheng* of water, and reduce to three *sheng*. Strain and hold the decoction in the mouth until healing occurs. When the mouth is fully saturated, spit it out and hold fresh decoction again.

**Formula for Ulcerated Mouth Sores with Pain Preventing Eating:**
- *Gancao* – 1 *cun*
- *Huanglian* – 6 *zhu*
- *Xingren* – 20 pieces

Grind the three ingredients into powder and blend. Wrap in silk to form a bolus the size of a *zaoren* (Ziziphus jujuba) pit, hold in the mouth, and do not swallow. Apply three times by day, once by night.

**Qiangwei Pill for Mouth Sores and Heat-Induced Rashes or Scrofula on the Body:**
- *Qiangwei* roots – 1 *liang*
- *Huangqin* – 1 *liang*
- *Shuli* roots – 1 *liang*
- *Danggui* – 1 *liang*
- *Gegen* – 1 *liang*
- *Bailian* – 1 *liang*
- *Huangbo* – 1 *liang*
- *Shilongrui* (Ranunculus sceleratus) – 1 *liang* (*Essential Emergency Formulas Supplement* uses *Huanglian*)
- *Shaoyao* – 1 *liang*
- *Xuduan* – 1 *liang*
- *Huangqi* – 1 *liang*
- *Gualou* roots – 2 *liang*

Grind the twelve ingredients into powder, mix with honey, and form pills the size of *wutong* (Firmiana simplex) seeds. Take ten pills, three times daily. (*Essential Emergency Formulas Supplement* includes 1 *liang* of *Huanglian*.)

**Formula for Sores on the Corners of the Mouth:**
Apply the inner white bark of *jiu* (Broussonetia papyrifera) while still damp. Healing will occur after three or four applications.

**Alternate Formula:**
Take aged *kuigen* (Malva verticillata) roots, preferably those beginning to rot, burn them to ash, and apply while still warm. This is highly effective.

**Alternate Formula:**
After cooking a fresh batch of rice, while the steamer is still hot, press the lips against its rim twenty to thirty times, two or three times daily. Discontinue once healed.

**Formula for Mouth Sores:**
*Gardenia* (栀子) and *licorice* (甘草), each eighteen *zhu*; *asarum* (细辛), thirty *zhu*; *cassia heart* (桂心), twelve *zhu*; *ligusticum* (芎藭), one *liang*. Grind the five ingredients into powder, mix with honey, and form pills. Take seven pills after meals, twice daily, until healed.

**Alternate Formula:**
*Ligusticum* (芎藭), *angelica* (白芷), *tangerine peel* (橘皮), *cassia heart* (桂心), and *jujube flesh* (枣肉), each one and a half *liang*. Grind the five ingredients into powder, mix with honey, and form pills. Take fifteen pills after meals, or hold them in the mouth, until healed. This formula is highly effective.

**Formula for Mouth Overgrowth Sores:**
Stir-fry leftover rice from the stove until charred, grind into powder, and apply.

**Formula for Swallowtail Sores (燕吻疮):**
Burn a withered branch of *white poplar* (白杨) on an iron surface, take the [residue], and apply while hot.

**Alternate Formula:**
Heat the heel of a wooden clog in hot ashes, then press it against both corners of the mouth twenty to thirty times each.

**Formula for Malignant Sores Beside the Mouth:**
*Human hair ash* (乱发灰), *old cotton ash* (故絮灰), *coptis powder* (黄连末), and *dried ginger powder* (乾姜末). Combine the four ingredients in equal parts to make a powder. Dust onto the sores; healing will occur after no more than three applications.

**Ointment Formula for Mouth Sores, Throat Obstruction, and Dry Mouth:**
*Lard* (猪膏) and *white honey* (白蜜), each one *jin*; *coptis* (黄连), one *liang*. Combine and decoct, strain, and stir until well blended. Hold a portion the size of half a jujube in the mouth, four to five times daily and twice at night.

**Ointment Formula for Heat Illness, Mouth Ulcers, and Throat Sores (Preventing Water or Broth Intake):**
*Chinese angelica* (当归), *belamcanda* (射干), and *cimicifuga* (升麻), each one *liang*; *aconite* (附子), half a *liang*; *white honey* (白蜜), four *liang*. Chop the ingredients, first decoct *lard* (猪脂), four *liang*, until it forms an ointment, then remove from heat to cool slightly. Add the herbs and simmer over low heat until the *aconite* turns yellow. Strain, add honey, and heat briefly until blended. Store in a container to solidify. Take a portion the size of an apricot kernel, hold in the mouth, and swallow four to five times daily.

**Formula for Dislocated Jaw from Yawning (Unable to Close Mouth):**
Have someone pull the jaw forward with their fingers and gradually push it back into place. Remove the fingers quickly to avoid being bitten.

**Alternate Formula:**
Apply melted wax mixed with water; this is effective.

**Alternate Formula:**
Moxibustion on the fifth thoracic vertebra, twice daily with fourteen cones. If not healed after three days, apply two hundred cones of moxibustion at *Qichong* (气冲), located at the hollow below the throat and above the collarbone (also called *Qitang*).

**Alternate Formula:**
Moxibustion at three *cun* above the inner ankle (or three and a half *cun*), one hundred cones, repeated three times. This is the *Sanyinjiao* (三阴交) point.

**Formula for Sudden Lockjaw:**
Grind *aconite* (附子) into powder, place it in a tube, force the mouth open, and blow the powder into it.

**Licorice Pill for Mouth Heat and Dryness:**
*Licorice* (甘草), *ginseng* (人参), *pinellia* (半夏), *fresh ginger* (生姜), and *dark plum flesh* (乌梅肉), each one and a half *liang*; *jujube paste* (枣膏), two and a half *liang*. Grind the six ingredients into powder, mix with honey, and form pills the size of a bullet. Hold in the mouth and swallow gradually, three times daily.

**Formula for Dry Mouth:**
Take *mutton fat* or *lard* the size of a chicken egg, break it apart, soak in half a *sheng* of vinegar overnight, then strain the liquid and hold it in the mouth.

**Formula for Dry Mouth, Heat Reduction, and Qi Descent:**
Five *ge* of crushed *gypsum* (石膏) and two *sheng* of *honey* (蜜). Boil the *gypsum* in three *sheng* of water, reduce to two *sheng*, add honey, and decoct to two *sheng*. Strain and hold a portion the size of a jujube pit in the mouth, swallowing the liquid before taking another.

**Formula for Deficiency Taxation and Dry Mouth:**
Two *liang* of *ophiopogon* (麦门冬), ground; thirty *jujubes* (大枣), flesh only. Mix with one *sheng* of honey, steam with five *sheng* of rice, and consume as desired.

**Alternate Formula:**
*Mutton fat* the size of a chicken egg, half a *sheng* of pure wine, and seven split *jujubes*. Soak together for seven days, then eat the jujubes; healing will be immediate.

**Alternate Formula:**
One *sheng* of *sour jujubes* (酸枣), five *ge* each of *pomegranate seeds* (酸石榴子) and *dark plums* (乌梅), three *liang* each of *trichosanthes fruit* (栝蒌实), *kudzu root* (葛根), and *licorice* (甘草), four *liang* of *ophiopogon* (麦门冬), and three *ge* of *raspberries* (覆盆子). Grind the eight ingredients into powder, mix with honey, and form pills. Hold a pill the size of a jujube in the mouth until moistened.

**Five Fragrances Pill for Foul Mouth and Body Odor, Calming Distress, and Dispersing Qi:**
*Cardamom* (豆蔻), *clove* (丁香), *agastache* (藿香), *lingling xiang* (零陵香), *costus root* (青木香), *angelica* (白芷), and *cassia heart* (桂心), each one *liang*; *cyperus* (香附子), two *liang*; *nardostachys* (甘松香) and *Chinese angelica* (当归), each half a *liang*; two *areca nuts* (槟榔). Grind the eleven ingredients into powder, mix with honey, and form pills. Regularly hold one pill the size of a soybean in the mouth, swallowing the liquid three times daily and once at night. Alternatively, hold and swallow continuously. After five days, the mouth will be fragrant; after ten days, the entire body will be fragrant; after fourteen days, clothing and bedding will be fragrant; after twenty-one days, the fragrance will be detectable downwind; after twenty-eight days, water from washing hands will leave a fragrance on the ground; after thirty-five days, shaking hands with others will transfer the fragrance. Avoid the five pungent foods to descend qi and eliminate odor.

**Fragrant Pill for Foul Breath (Suitable for Regular Use):**
Half a *liang* of *clove* (丁香), three *liang* of *licorice* (甘草), one *liang* of *ligusticum* (芎穷), one and a half *liang* each of *asarum* (细辛) and *cassia heart* (桂心). Grind the five ingredients into powder, mix with honey, and form pills the size of a bullet. Take two pills before going out.

**Alternate Formula:**
On the first day of the lunar month before sunrise, walk seven steps toward the eastern wall, turn around, face the wall, hold water in the mouth, and spray it against the wall seven times. The mouth will become fragrant.

**Alternate Formula:**
*Cassia heart* (桂心), *licorice* (甘草), *asarum* (细辛), and *tangerine peel* (橘皮).

The above four ingredients, in equal parts, grind and sift. Take one *qianbi* with wine; cease when cured.

**Alternate Formula:**
Eight *liang* of *jujube* pulp, four *liang* each of *ligusticum* (芎藭), *angelica* (白芷), *tangerine peel* (橘皮), and *cassia heart* (桂心).
Grind the five ingredients into powder, then mix with jujube pulp; if too dry, add honey. Form pills the size of a soybean. Take ten pills daily, either holding them in the mouth or swallowing, before or after meals. After seven days, great fragrance will result.

**Formula for Foul Breath:**
*Cassia heart* (《古今录验》 uses *asarum* and *licorice* in equal parts).
Grind the two ingredients into powder. Before retiring, take a pinch with wine; after twenty days, fragrance will manifest.

**Alternate Formula:**
*Asarum* and *cardamom*—holding them in the mouth is highly effective.

**Alternate Formula:**
*Chinese prickly ash* (蜀椒) and *cassia heart*, in equal parts.
Grind the two ingredients into powder. Take three pinches with wine.

**Formula to Perfume the Mouth and Eliminate Odor:**
Three *zhu* of *licorice*, eighteen *zhu* of *angelica*, and twenty-four *zhu* of *ligusticum*.
Grind the three ingredients and sift. Take one *fangcunbi* with wine, three times daily. After thirty days, the mouth will be fragrant.

**Alternate Formula:**
*Jujube*, *melon seeds*, and *white bark of pine root*.
Grind the three ingredients and sift. Take one *fangcunbi* with wine, twice daily. After one hundred days, clothing and bedding will be fragrant.

**Alternate Formula:**
Six *zhu* each of *melon seeds*, *ligusticum*, *ligusticum root* (稿本), *Chinese angelica* (当归), and *asarum leaf* (杜蘅); half a *liang* of *asarum*; two *liang* of *saposhnikovia* (防风).
Grind the seven ingredients and sift. Take one *fangcunbi* with water after meals, three times daily. After five days, the mouth will be fragrant; after ten days, the body; after twenty days, the flesh; after thirty days, clothing and bedding; after fifty days, fragrance will carry afar.
One version adds eighteen *zhu* of *angelica*.

**Alternate Formula:**

**Alternate Formula:**
Two *zhu* of *tangerine peel*, eighteen *zhu* of *cassia heart*, one *liang* of *magnolia bark*, and twenty *jujubes*.
Grind the four ingredients and sift. Take one *fangcunbi* with wine, three times daily. With prolonged use, the body will become fragrant.
Alternatively, form into pills with jujube pulp. Take twenty pills the size of *wutong* seeds, gradually increasing to thirty.
One version adds eighteen *zhu* of *ligusticum*.

**Alternate Formula:**
Boil *asarum* to a thick decoction, hold in the mouth, then spit out after a long while.

**Alternate Formula:**
Rinse the mouth with three *sheng* of well-flower water, then spit into the latrine. Effective.

**Alternate Formula:**
One handful of *elsholtzia*, one *dou* of water. Simmer to three *sheng*, then hold in the mouth in small amounts.

**Alternate Formula:**
Grind *sweet melon seeds* into powder, mix with honey, and form into pills the size of jujube pits.
Each morning after washing and rinsing, hold one pill in the mouth; may also be applied to the teeth.

**Alternate Formula:**
Roast soybeans until charred, then pour hot vinegar over them. Take the liquid and hold in the mouth.

**Formula for Fragrance in the Seven Orifices:**
Five *liang* of *aloeswood*, three *liang* of *ligusticum root* (稿本), half a *sheng* of *white melon seeds*, five *ge* of *clove*, two *liang* each of *licorice*, *Chinese angelica*, *ligusticum*, and *musk*.
Grind the eight ingredients into powder, form into honey pills the size of small beans. Take five pills after meals, three times daily. With prolonged use, the entire body will become fragrant.

**Formula for Body Odor to Induce Fragrance:**
One and a half *liang* each of *emblic myrobalan peel* and *angelica*, two *liang* of *melon seeds*, one *liang* each of *ligusticum root* (稿本), *Chinese angelica*, *asarum*, and *cassia heart*.
Grind the seven ingredients and sift.

Take one *fangcunbi* of the powder with wine, three times daily. After five days, the mouth will become fragrant; after twenty-one days, the entire body will become fragrant.

**Alternative Formula:**
Equal parts *licorice*, *pine root bark*, *jujube*, and *sweet melon seeds*.
Grind the four ingredients and sift. Take one *fangcunbi* after meals, three times daily. Effects will be felt in seven days; after one hundred days, the fragrance will be profound.

**Formula for Fumigating Clothes:**
Three *liang* each of *lingling fragrance*, *clove*, *green cassia bark*, *qingmuxiang*, *chicken-bone resin fragrance*, *turmeric fragrance*, and *maple resin*; two *liang* each of *frankincense*, *storax*, *gan song fragrance*, and *tortoiseshell fragrance*; five *liang* of *aloeswood*; one *liang* each of *sparrow-head fragrance*, *sandalwood*, *benzoin*, *ai na xiang*, and *patchouli*; half a *liang* of *musk*.
Grind the eighteen ingredients into powder. Boil forty plump jujubes in two and a half *sheng* of honey until thoroughly soft, then knead by hand until they form a porridge-like consistency. Strain through coarse cloth to remove residue, and mix with the powdered fragrance. Adjust moisture to the consistency of kneaded flour, then pound five hundred times to form pills. Seal tightly for seven days before use. When burning, place a basin of water beneath the censer to temper the heat; otherwise, the fragrance will acquire a scorched odor.

**Alternative Formula:**
Five *liang* each of *aloeswood* and *resin fragrance*; one *liang* each of *sparrow-head fragrance*, *clove*, and *patchouli*.
Grind the five ingredients and sift, then add half a *liang* of *musk* powder and sift again through a coarse sieve. Mix with honey just before fumigating clothes.

**Alternative Formula:**
One *liang* each of *frankincense*, *aloeswood*, *sandalwood*, *dou lou po fragrance*, *resin fragrance*, *gan song fragrance*, *lingling fragrance*, and *patchouli*; eighteen *zhu* of *clove*; eight *liang* of jujube pulp; two *liang* of *alfalfa fragrance*.
Grind the eleven ingredients coarsely and sift, then combine with jujube pulp and pound again. Adjust with honey as needed before use; this method is excellent.

**Formula for Moist Fragrance:**
Two *jin*, seven *liang*, and nine *zhu* of *aloeswood*; three *liang* and nine *zhu* each of *gan song*, *sandalwood*, *sparrow-head fragrance* (or *patchouli*), *chicken-bone fragrance*, *resin fragrance*, *tortoiseshell fragrance*, *lingling fragrance*, and *clove*; two *liang* and nine *zhu* of *musk*; three *liang* and six *zhu* of *black frankincense*.
Grind the ten ingredients into powder. Mix with honey just before use; if prepared in advance, the fragrance will dissipate and become ineffective.

**Additional Formula:**
Three *liang* of *aloeswood*; one and a half *liang* each of *lingling fragrance*, *resin fragrance*, and *musk*; half a *liang* each of *clove* and *alfalfa fragrance*; three *zhu* each of *tortoiseshell fragrance* and *sandalwood*; six *zhu* each of *black frankincense* and *gan song*.
Grind the ten ingredients coarsely and sift, then blend with honey. Store in a jar, bury it for long-term aging; the fragrance will be excellent when used to scent clothing.

**Hundred Harmonies Fragrance (Universal Formula for Daoist and Secular Use):**
Five *liang* of *aloeswood*; three *liang* each of *clove*, *chicken-bone fragrance*, *turmeric fragrance*, and *tortoiseshell fragrance*; two *liang* each of *black frankincense*, *white sandalwood*, *processed resin fragrance*, and charcoal powder; one *liang* each of *lingling fragrance*, *green cassia bark*, *costus root*, *gan song*, *white jiangxiang wood*, and *alfalfa fragrance*; half a *liang* each of *sparrow-head fragrance*, *storax*, *benzoin*, *musk*, and *swallow fragrance*.
Grind the twenty ingredients into powder, moisten with wine to soften, and let sit for two nights until the wine aroma dissipates. Mix with white honey and store in a ceramic vessel, sealing with wax paper to prevent the escape of fragrance. Open and use in winter for optimal results.

**Clothing-Scenting Fragrance Formula:**
One *liang* of *clove*; two *liang* of *alfalfa fragrance*; three *liang* each of *gan song* and *sweetgrass*; four *liang* each of *alfalfa fragrance* and *lingling fragrance*.
Grind each of the six ingredients separately, then add four *liang* of *ze lan* leaves. Sift coarsely for use; the fragrance will be exceptionally fine.

**Additional Formula:**
Two *liang* of *lingling fragrance*; one *liang* each of *alfalfa fragrance*, *gan song*, *alfalfa fragrance*, *resin fragrance*, *white sandalwood*, and *aloeswood*.
Combine and grind the seven ingredients, then add half a *liang* of *musk*. Sift coarsely and use as previously described; the results will be excellent.

**Another Formula:**
Four *liang* of *alfalfa fragrance*; seven *cloves*; one *liang* each of *gan song*, *musk*, *aloeswood*, and *resin fragrance*.
Grind the six ingredients coarsely and sift, then blend into a dry fragrance. Use to scent clothing; the results will be highly effective.
