**Formula for Initial Onset of Leg Qi**, where swelling and pain ascend from the foot to the knee along the meridians and bones:
Take *Ricinus* leaves, chop, steam, and apply thinly wrapped. Change two or three times daily to resolve. *Ricinus* seeds resemble the *cattle tick insect*, hence the name *tick hemp*. In winter when *tick hemp* is unavailable, take *Dipsacus* root, pound, and mix with three parts wine dregs and one part root. Steam until hot, then apply warm to the swelling as before, changing twice daily to resolve. This also treats numbness and stubborn impediment. Though not a decoction, this formula appears here as the preceding three were all recorded by Attendant Su.

**Formula for Swelling Ascending to the Thighs**, reaching the lower abdomen with distension and scant, dribbling urine:
Take one *sheng* of bull urine, divide into two doses, and consume twice daily until resolved. *Supplement to the Thousand Gold Prescriptions* states: for emaciated individuals, combine two parts urine with one part cow’s milk, boil until the milk forms a skin, then consume.

If the swelling has subsided yet these symptoms persist, administer this decoction urgently—a formula of Attendant Su, divinely efficacious:

Ephedra, *Belamcanda*, ginseng, *Poria*, *Stephania*, *Peucedanum*, and *Aurantii Fructus Immaturus* each two *liang*; *Pinellia*, rhinoceros horn, antelope horn, *Aristolochia*, tangerine peel, apricot kernel, and *Cimicifuga* each one *liang*; fresh ginger five *liang*; *Angelica pubescens* three *liang*; and *Evodia* one *sheng*. The seventeen ingredients are to be broken up, then decocted in twelve *sheng* of water until four *sheng* remain. Divide into five doses, spaced by the time it takes to walk twenty *li*, with a small serving of congee between to support stomach *qi*. This decoction is taken once every two days until the pathogenic *qi* retreats; adjust according to the condition.

If heat is severe with panting and vexation, add six *liang* of gypsum and one *sheng* of fresh *Ophiopogon*, omitting *Evodia*. If there is hardness below the heart, add one *liang* of turtle shell.

Now, *foot-qi* disease first arose in Lingnan and gradually spread to Jiangdong. Its onset may be sudden or insidious: slight pain and numbness, swelling along both channels, difficulty walking with weakness, or ascending to the abdomen with loss of sensation; alternating cold and heat, scant and difficult urination, panting, *qi* rushing to the throat, gasping as if near death, vomiting upon eating, or *qi* counterflow—all these are its signs.

At the first sign of these symptoms, administer the Rhinoceros Horn and *Inula* Decoction:

Rhinoceros horn and *Inula* each two *liang*; tangerine peel, *Poria*, and fresh ginger each three *liang*; seven *jujubes*; one *sheng* of fermented soybean; and a handful of perilla stems and leaves. The eight ingredients are to be broken up, then decocted in eight *sheng* of water until two *sheng* and seven *ge* remain. Divide into three doses, spaced by the time it takes to walk ten *li*, continuing until *qi* descends and urination flows freely. *Master Cui’s* version calls this the Minor Rhinoceros Horn Decoction. If *qi* does not descend, proceed to the Major Rhinoceros Horn Decoction.

The Major Rhinoceros Horn Decoction treats *foot-qi* where toxin ascends to the heart, transforming into water with generalized swelling, stupor, and near-death:

Rhinoceros horn, *Inula*, *Atractylodes*, cinnamon bark, *Stephania*, *Scutellaria*, fresh ginger, tangerine peel, and *Poria* each two *liang*; one *sheng* of fermented soybean; *Morus* bark and *Peucedanum* each four *liang*; ten *jujubes*; and a handful of perilla stems and leaves. The fourteen ingredients are to be broken up, then decocted in nine *sheng* of water until two *sheng* and seven *ge* remain. Divide into three doses, spaced by the time it takes to walk ten *li*, continuing until *qi* descends. If *qi* descends, urination flows, leg swelling subsides, and appetite returns. If the decoction fails to descend *qi* and panting persists, proceed to the Rhinoceros Horn and Ephedra Decoction.

*Master Cui’s* version substitutes *Cynanchum* for *Morus* bark, omitting *Stephania*, *Scutellaria*, and *Morus* bark, calling it the *Inula* Decoction.

The Rhinoceros Horn and Ephedra Decoction:

Rhinoceros horn, ephedra, *Saposhnikovia*, *Angelica pubescens* (*Master Cui* uses *Poria*), *Stephania*, *Ligusticum*, *Paeonia* (*Master Cui* uses asarum), *Angelica sinensis*, *Scutellaria*, antelope horn, gypsum four *liang*, fresh ginger, licorice, apricot kernel (*Master Cui* uses asarum), and cinnamon bark each three *liang*. The fifteen ingredients are to be broken up; decoct ephedra in two *dou* of water, skim the foam, reduce to eight *sheng*, then add the remaining ingredients and simmer until three *sheng* remain. Divide into three doses, spaced by the time it takes to walk ten *li*. After each dose, cover to induce sweating. If unresolved, repeat after five days, inducing sweat as before.

The *Evodia* Decoction treats *foot-qi* ascending to the abdomen with extreme distress, near-death, and abdominal distension—a formula of Attendant Su:

Six *sheng* of *Evodia* and two sliced *Chaenomeles* fruits. Decoct in thirteen *sheng* of water until three *sheng* remain. Divide into three doses, spaced by the time it takes to walk ten *li*. Relief may come through vomiting, sweating, diarrhea, or intense heat and distress. This is a formula to revive the dying.

The Minor Wind-Drawing Decoction treats wind stroke with lumbar and leg pain and weakness—*Hu Qia’s* version is called the Major Wind-Drawing Decoction:

*Angelica pubescens*, *Poria*, and ginseng each three *liang*; *Saposhnikovia*, *Angelica sinensis*, licorice, and dried ginger (*Hu Qia* uses cinnamon bark) each two *liang*; *Dendrobium* (*Hu Qia* uses *Astragalus*); one *Aconite* tuber; and two *sheng* of soybeans. The ten ingredients are to be broken up, then decocted in nine *sheng* of water and three *sheng* of wine until three *sheng* remain. Divide into four doses, spaced by the time it takes to walk ten *li*.

*Hu Qia* notes: Southern treatments for leg weakness differ, using one *liang* of *Cimicifuga*, two *liang* each of *Pinellia* and *Paeonia*, totaling thirteen ingredients. The original formula has ten, omitting *Angelica sinensis* and *Dendrobium*, and is called the Minor Wind-Drawing Decoction. *The Abridged Emergency Formulas* omits *Dendrobium*, using it to treat extreme cold in the flesh, muscle transformation, tongue atrophy, and conditions called malignant wind with lumbar pain and leg weakness.

The Four Agents with *Aconite* Decoction treats wind-damp confluence with painful, restless joints, limb spasms, inability to flex or extend, pain upon touch, spontaneous sweating with shortness of breath, scant urination, aversion to wind with reluctance to remove clothing, or intermittent facial, hand, and foot swelling:

Two *Aconite* tubers, four *liang* of cinnamon bark, three *liang* of *Atractylodes*, and two *liang* of licorice. The four ingredients are to be broken up, then decocted in six *sheng* of water until three *sheng* remain. Divide into three doses; mild sweating brings resolution, while profuse sweating with vexation warrants reducing to five *ge* per dose. For body swelling, add four *liang* of *Stephania*; for palpitations and scant urination, add three *liang* of *Poria*. Given the presence of *Aconite*, now add three *liang* of fresh ginger.

To treat excess *foot-qi* wind-toxin, Lingnan miasmic *qi* with facial swelling, alternating cold and heat resembling malaria, leg swelling, *qi* ascending to the heart with oppression, cough, flaccid paralysis, and stubborn impediment:

**Hemp Seed Decoction**
Hemp seeds, *Cimicifuga*, ephedra, *Belamcanda*, *Acorus*, mirabilite, licorice, and rhubarb—each half a *liang*; fermented soybeans, three *ge*. These nine ingredients are to be broken up, then decocted in six *sheng* of water until two and a half *sheng* remain. Add the mirabilite and boil three more times. Divide into three doses; mild diarrhea once or twice resolves toxic heat. For swelling, apply the dregs as a poultice. Whenever one feels *qi* fullness, taking a dose is beneficial.

**Master Shen’s Modified Kidney-Draining Decoction**
Daoist Master Shen’s modified *Kidney-Draining Decoction* treats wind-induced deficiency and consumptive depletion with toxin, *foot-qi* weakness, painful impediment or paralysis, lower burner deficiency-cold, slight guest heat in the chest, heart deficiency with fright palpitations and insomnia, poor appetite with loss of taste, frequent vexation day and night making rest impossible, scant urination, and occasional diarrhea. When the Prince of Xiangdong traveled to Jiangzhou, he fell ill with all these symptoms in Lingnan, becoming gravely debilitated. I prepared this decoction for him, and he soon recovered. For such conditions, this remedy is invariably effective; adjust the formula as needed:

Astragalus, licorice, peony, *Ophiopogon*, ginseng, *Cistanche*, dried rehmannia, red halloysite, *Poria* spirit, *Lycium* root bark, tangkuei, *Polygala*, magnetite, unripe bitter orange, *Saposhnikovia*, and dragon bone—each one *liang*; cinnamon bark and *Ligusticum*—each two *liang*; fresh ginger, four *liang*; schisandra, three *ge*; pinellia, one *sheng*; jujubes, thirty *enumerated*; one pair of white sheep kidneys.

These twenty-three ingredients are to be broken up, then the sheep kidneys decocted in two *dou* of water until one *dou* and two *sheng* of liquid remain. Add the remaining ingredients and decoct until four *sheng* remain. Divide into five doses. For those without diarrhea, omit dragon bone and red halloysite. For scant urination, substitute red *Poria* for *Poria* spirit and add three *liang* of *Atractylodes*. For pronounced heat, add one *liang* of scutellaria. For enuresis, add twenty *Mantis Egg-Cases*.

*Hu Qia’s Formula* omits astragalus, *Cistanche*, red halloysite, *Lycium* root bark, magnetite, unripe bitter orange, *Saposhnikovia*, dragon bone, and pinellia, but includes scutellaria, totaling fifteen ingredients.

**Gypsum Decoction**
*Gypsum Decoction* treats *foot-qi* wind-toxin with heat *qi* surging upward to the head and face, facial redness and tension, intermittent nasal congestion, mental confusion, chest disquiet, fright palpitations, bodily tremors, flaccid limbs, aching impediment, dizziness and heaviness in the head and eyes, eye inversion, nasal irritation, heat exhaled from the mouth, sweet taste in the mouth, and other indescribable afflictions:

Gypsum, gentian, *Cimicifuga*, peony, cowrie shells, licorice, turtle shell, scutellaria, and antelope horn—each one *liang*; tangerine peel and tangkuei—each two *liang*.

These eleven ingredients are to be broken up, then decocted in eight *sheng* of water until three *sheng* remain. Divide into three doses.

**Pinellia Decoction**
*Pinellia Decoction* treats *foot-qi* ascending into the abdomen, abdominal tension surging upward into the chest, and *qi* urgency verging on collapse:

Pinellia, one *sheng*; cinnamon bark, eight *liang*; dried ginger, five *liang*; licorice, ginseng, asarum, and *Aconite*—each two *liang*; Sichuan pepper, two *ge*.

These eight ingredients are to be broken up, then decocted in one *dou* of water until three *sheng* remain. Divide into three doses; initially administer small amounts to prevent *qi* surging upward and causing obstruction, allowing only slight passage of *qi*.

**Aconite Decoction**
*Aconite Decoction* treats wind-cold *foot* impediment with pain, spasms, and weakness preventing flexion and extension:

*Aconite*, asarum, and Sichuan pepper—each one *liang*; licorice, *Gentiana macrophylla*, *Aconite*, cinnamon bark, peony—each two *liang*; dried ginger, *Poria*, *Saposhnikovia*, tangkuei—each three *liang*; *Angelica pubescens*, four *liang*; jujubes, twenty *enumerated*.

These fourteen ingredients are to be broken up, then decocted in one *dou* and two *sheng* of water until four *sheng* remain. Divide into five doses. For heat toxin, frequent dosing is beneficial.

**Toxic-Constricting Decoction**
*Toxic-Constricting Decoction* treats *foot* weakness with wind-heat ascending into the heart and abdomen, causing vexation and oppression verging on collapse:

Pinellia and fresh ginger—each four *liang*; astragalus, licorice, tangkuei, ginseng, magnolia bark, *Angelica pubescens*, tangerine peel—each one *liang*; unripe bitter orange, ephedra, dried rehmannia, peony—each two *liang*; cinnamon bark, three *liang*; cowrie shells, seven *enumerated*; jujubes, twenty *enumerated*.

These sixteen ingredients are to be broken up, then decocted in one *dou* and two *sheng* of water until three *sheng* and six *ge* remain. Divide into four doses, three during the day and one at night.

**Wind-Flaccidity Decoction**
*Wind-Flaccidity Decoction* treats *foot* weakness, bodily numbness, and toxin *qi* ascending into the viscera, causing chest fullness and obstruction, vomiting after eating, and loss of taste:

*Angelica pubescens*, licorice, and gypsum—each three *liang*; antelope horn and rhinoceros horn—each half a *liang*; ephedra, *Saposhnikovia*, tangkuei, *Cimicifuga*, tangerine peel, evodia, cinnamon bark, pinellia, and turtle shell—each two *liang*; unripe bitter orange, one *liang*; fresh ginger, six *liang*; jujubes, twenty *enumerated*; cowrie shells, seven *enumerated*; *Aconite*, two *liang* (alternatively, seven *enumerated* smoked plums).

These nineteen ingredients are to be broken up, then decocted in one *dou* and four *sheng* of water until four *sheng* remain. Each dose is one *sheng*. For slight deficiency-heat, add two *liang* of dried rehmannia.

**Perilla Seed Decoction**
*Perilla Seed Decoction* treats *foot* weakness with *qi* ascent. Formerly, when the Prince of Xiangdong of the Song was in Nanzhou, he suffered gravely from *foot-qi* and greatly benefited from this decoction:

Perilla seeds and pinellia—each one *sheng*; *Peucedanum*, magnolia bark, licorice, and tangkuei—each one *liang*; tangerine peel, three *liang*; jujubes, twenty *enumerated*; fresh ginger, one *jin*; cinnamon bark, four *liang*.

These ten ingredients are to be broken up, then decocted in one *dou* and three *sheng* of water until three and a half *sheng* remain. Divide into five doses, three during the day and two at night.

**Aconite Decoction**
*Aconite Decoction* treats damp impediment and flaccid wind, with bodily pain as if broken, flesh as if pierced by awls or cut by knives.

**Aconite Decoction**
*Aconite Decoction* treats damp impediment, flaccid wind, bodily pain as if broken, and flesh as if pierced by awls or cut by knives. The formula is as follows:

Three *aconite* tubers; peony, cinnamon bark, licorice, poria, and ginseng—each three *liang*; white atractylodes, four *liang*.

These seven ingredients are to be broken up, then decocted in eight *sheng* of water until three *sheng* remain. Divide into three doses.

**Ledebouriella Decoction**
*Ledebouriella Decoction* treats vacuous wind with mild convulsions, fever, unresponsive limbs, disorientation, delirium, and intermittent episodes of unawareness. This formula, used by Zhi Facun of the South, proved highly effective—gentle yet potent, surpassing *Continuing Life Decoction*, *Maidservant Decoction*, and *Wind-Drawing Decoction*. The Lu family of Guangzhou and scholars of Nanzhou commonly employed it. It also excels in treating severe *foot* weakness. The formula is as follows:

Ledebouriella, ephedra, large gentian, pubescent angelica, fresh ginger, and pinellia—each two *liang*; tangkuei, polygala, licorice, stephania, ginseng, scutellaria, cimicifuga, and peony—each one *liang*; gypsum, half a *liang*; musk, six *zhu* (one version uses one *liang* of white atractylodes).

These sixteen ingredients are to be broken up, then decocted in one *dou* and three *sheng* of water until four *sheng* remain. Each dose is one *sheng*. For the first dose, cover the patient thickly to induce slight sweating, and expect two or three bouts of diarrhea. Administer subsequent doses at intervals equivalent to the time it takes a person to walk ten *li*. For fever, add two *liang* of rhubarb. For those with preexisting cold-induced heart pain, double the tangkuei and add three *liang* of cinnamon bark, omitting rhubarb.

**Licorice Decoction**
*Licorice Decoction* treats *foot* weakness with generalized swelling, stomach reflux, vomiting after eating, chest *qi* stagnation with restlessness, alternating chills and fever, unremitting diarrhea, and difficult urination. This decoction brings improvement. For urinary relief, also administer *Yeast Powder for Women* to reduce swelling. For further efficacy, use *Major Powder* and *Massage Ointment*. The formula is as follows:

Licorice and ginseng—each one *liang*; pinellia, one *sheng*; cinnamon bark and Sichuan pepper—each three *liang*; wheat, eight *ge*; jujubes, twenty *enumerated*; fresh ginger, eight *liang*; evodia fruit, two *sheng*.

These nine ingredients are to be broken up. First, decoct the wheat in one *dou* and three *sheng* of water until one *dou* remains, then remove the wheat and add the remaining ingredients. Decoct until three *sheng* remain. Divide into six doses.
*Yeast Powder for Women* is recorded in a separate volume.

**Dichroa Licorice Decoction**
For malarial fevers recurring two or three times daily, this formula may be administered:

Three *liang* of dichroa root; one and a half *liang* of licorice.

These two ingredients are to be crushed, then decocted in four *sheng* of water until one and a half *sheng* remain. Divide into three doses, administering each at intervals equivalent to the time it takes a person to walk five *li*.

**Salvia Milkvetch Steeped Powder**
*Salvia Milkvetch Steeped Powder* treats *foot* impediment with weakness, *qi* fullness, and mild generalized swelling. The formula is as follows:

Salvia, achyranthes, mulberry root bark, apricot kernel, cimicifuga, polyporus, and poria—each four *liang*; rhinoceros horn, scutellaria, tangerine peel, stephania, cynanchum, alisma, cinnamon bark, and large gentian—each three *liang*; plum root bark and

**Formulas for Wind-Toxin Foot *Qi* – Third of the Various Powder Formulas**

As a general principle, powders are most suitable for administration in spring and autumn.

**Eight-Wind Powder**
The *Eight-Wind Powder* treats wind deficiency with a dark, earthen complexion, inability to endure exposure to sunlight or moonlight, and foot *qi* with numbness and weakness. According to the classics, a dark complexion pertains to the kidneys, while inability to endure sunlight or moonlight pertains to the liver. Thus, this formula supplements the kidneys and treats the liver:

Three *liang* of chrysanthemum flower; one and a half *liang* each of dendrobium and aconite; one *liang* and six *zhu* each of ginseng, prepared aconite, and licorice; one *liang* each of stalactite, Chinese yam, dipsacus, astragalus, alisma, ophiopogon, polygala, asarum, gentian, pyrrosia, cuscuta, achyranthes, calamus, eucommia, poria, dried rehmannia, biota seed, cnidium, saposhnikovia, atractylodes, dried ginger, tokoro, and cornus; half a *liang* each of schisandra and aconite; two *liang* of cistanche.

The above thirty-three ingredients are to be ground and sifted. Take one square-inch spoonful with wine, three times daily. If ineffective, increase to two spoonfuls.

**Major Eight-Wind Powder**
The *Major Eight-Wind Powder* treats various types of flaccid wind-dampness impediment with weak feet. The formula is as follows:

Half a *liang* each of morinda root, astragalus, cinnamon bark, asarum, aconite, tokoro, cistanche, vitex seed, Chinese yam, chrysanthemum flower, Solomon’s seal, cornus, gentian, scutellaria, dendrobium, atractylodes, *yu* stone (also written as alum), magnolia bark, gentian, ginseng, and Sichuan pepper; eighteen *zhu* each of prepared aconite and schisandra; one *liang* each of calamus, poria, achyranthes (in the *Supplement to the Thousand Golden Remedies*, dried ginger), wolfsbane, and polygala; thirty *zhu* of platycodon; six *zhu* each of ligusticum, ampelopsis, and peony.

The above thirty-two ingredients are to be ground and sifted.

Take with wine half a *cun*-spoonful, three times daily; if ineffective, gradually increase the dose until a slight sensation is felt. The *Hu Qia* version omits platycodon.

**Internal-Tonifying Dendrobium and Gentian Powder**
This formula treats wind-induced vacuity with weak feet, clenched hands and feet, painful impediment preventing walking, swelling of the instep ascending to the knees, and a hard lower abdomen as if bound by rope. Patients experience constant sighing as if vexed and are unable to eat or drink. These symptoms arise from the five taxations and seven damages, kidney qi insufficiency, and contraction of wind-dampness. This formula governs all such cases:

One *liang* each of dendrobium, prepared aconite, aconite, cinnamon bark, *du huo*, and asparagus root; thirty *zhu* each of gentian, aconite, ginseng, dried ginger, tangkuei, *fangfeng*, and eucommia; eighteen *zhu* each of cornus, *mang cao*, platycodon, asarum, ephedra, and *qian hu*; half a *liang* each of Sichuan pepper, angelica, and atractylodes.

The above twenty-three ingredients are to be ground and sifted. Take one *cun*-spoonful with wine, twice daily; if ineffective, gradually increase to two spoonfuls. For those with vacuity, roast the three *aconites*; for those with repletion, they may also be used raw.

Wind qi fundamentally arises from kidney vacuity. After contracting the illness, if toxic qi fills the exterior, moxibustion may drain the qi; if it fills the interior, medicinals may hasten its resolution. Such measures are necessary for urgent relief. Once the wind recedes and the four limbs are weak, with residual toxins yet unexpelled, treatment must not cease. This powder should be taken to expel the old and usher in the new—it is most excellent. This is readily understood and leaves no room for doubt.

**Gentian Powder**
This formula treats wind, whether chronic or acute, sudden loss of consciousness, lack of sensation in the four limbs, generalized pain, hemiplegia with immobility, inability to flex or extend, alternating chills and fever, dizziness or fainting, or facial distortion:

One *liang* each of gentian, dried ginger, platycodon, and prepared aconite; ten *zhu* each of aconite, tangkuei, asparagus root, ginseng, atractylodes, and Sichuan pepper; eighteen *zhu* each of aconite and asarum; half a *liang* each of licorice, angelica, cornus, ephedra, *qian hu*, *fangfeng*, and schisandra.

The above nineteen ingredients are to be ground and sifted. Take one *cun*-spoonful with wine, three times daily; the elderly should take a smaller dose. The *Hu Qia* version omits asparagus root and *qian hu*, but includes *mang cao*, cinnamon bark, *fang ji*, tokoro, ampelopsis, and astragalus, totaling twenty-three ingredients.

**Single-Ingredient Pine Resin Formula**
This treats all wind conditions, including *great wind*, weak feet, and wind impediment. The method for *frankincense* is the same:

Take thirty *jin* of pine resin, place it in a bag made of palm fiber, and tie the opening. Arrange bamboo or wood at the bottom of a cauldron, place the bag on top, and weigh it down with three to five stones. Fill the cauldron with water and boil. Once the resin floats to the surface and is fully extracted, continue boiling for another twenty cycles. Remove and place in cold water, then replace the bag and wash the pot before boiling again. Repeat this process nine times. Once the medicine is prepared, pound and sift it, then pass it through a coarse sieve.

Take one *cun*-spoonful with wine, twice daily. Initially, mix the medicine with cold wine; after it enters the abdomen, drink warm wine to activate the medicine, adjusting the dose based on sensation. If heat is felt, reduce the amount; failure to do so may cause constipation or urinary difficulty. If blockage occurs, consume scallion broth. If still obstructed, take fresh rehmannia juice to induce mild diarrhea. Avoid only hemp seeds; no other restrictions apply.

To abstain from grains, add an equal part of poria to the pine resin and form into pills with honey. Consume only plain wheat noodles twice daily, one small bowl per meal—do not overeat.

**Method for Preparing Noodles:**
Knead the dough firmly while hot, boil for fifty cycles, then rinse in cold water. Return to boiling water for another ten cycles before removing and consuming.

After thirty days of taking pine resin, efficacy will be evident when a sensation akin to water flowing down the legs is felt. To prevent constipation, mix one *jin* of pine resin and poria with dates or chestnuts the size of a jujube, then fry in *su*—this will prevent blockage. After one hundred days, *leg qi* should resolve.

The *Immortal Classic* states: Taking pine resin for one year adds one year to one’s lifespan; two years adds two years. Taking it for ten years adds ten years to one’s lifespan.

**Huainan Eight Lords Dendrobium Powder for Myriad Diseases**
This formula treats wind-dampness pain and immobility of the lower back and feet:

One *liang* each of *fangfeng*, poria, chrysanthemum flower, asarum, Sichuan pepper, dried ginger, mica, cistanche, ginseng, dried rehmannia, prepared aconite, dendrobium, eucommia, polygala, cuscuta, aconite, tokoro, cinnamon bark, achyranthes, cnidium, atractylodes, Chinese yam, morinda root, calamus, dipsacus, and cornus; half a *liang* of schisandra.

The above twenty-seven ingredients are to be ground and sifted. Take one *cun*-spoonful with wine, twice daily.

**Cornus Powder**
This formula treats cold wind, lame feet, hemiplegia, half-body immobility, and incessant groaning—conditions deemed untreatable by physicians:

Half a *liang* each of evodia fruit, dried ginger, ampelopsis, *mu jing* (in the *Supplement to the Thousand Golden Remedies*, *mu gui*), prepared aconite, aconite, *gou ji*, dried lacquer, Chinese yam, gentian, and *fangfeng*.

The above eleven ingredients are to be ground and sifted. Take one *cun*-spoonful before meals, three times daily. A tingling sensation will spread through the skin and flesh within three days; recovery occurs within one month.

**Fourth Section: Wine and Elixir Formulas**

**General Principles**
When preparing medicinal wines, thinly slice the ingredients, place them in a silk bag, and steep in wine. Seal tightly. In spring and summer, steep for four to five days; in autumn and winter, seven to eight days—until the flavor is fully extracted. Remove the dregs and consume the wine. Once the wine is finished, pound the dregs.

Take one *cun*-spoonful with wine, three times daily. As a general rule, wines are best taken in winter; discontinue by the *Start of Spring*.

**Shihu Wine**
A formula for treating wind-induced deficiency, qi fullness, leg pain, numbness, and cramping weakness rendering one unable to walk:
*Shihu* (5 liang), *danshen* (5 liang), *wujia pi* (5 liang), *cezi* (4 liang), *qinjiao* (4 liang), *duzhong* (4 liang), *shanzhuyu* (4 liang), *niuxi* (4 liang), *guixin* (3 liang), *ganjiang* (3 liang), *qianghuo* (3 liang), *xiongqiong* (3 liang), *jupi* (3 liang), *huangqi* (3 liang), *baiqian* (3 liang), *shujiao* (3 liang), *yinyu* (3 liang), *danggui* (3 liang), *yiyiren* (1 sheng), *fangfeng* (2 liang), and *zhongru* (8 liang, crushed, placed in a separate silk bag within the main bag).

The above twenty-one ingredients are to be cut and steeped in four *dou* of clear wine for three days. Begin with three *ge* per dose, twice daily, gradually increasing until an effect is felt.

**Black Sesame Wine**
Five *sheng* of black sesame, lightly toasted and crushed, steeped in one *dou* of wine overnight. Drink as much as desired; when finished, prepare another batch. Highly effective.

**Zhongru Wine**
A formula for treating wind-induced deficiency, taxation damage, leg pain, cold numbness, emaciation, cramping weakness, and inability to walk:
*Zhongru* (8 liang), *danshen* (6 liang), *shihu* (5 liang), *duzhong* (5 liang), *tianmendong* (5 liang), *niuxi* (4 liang), *fangfeng* (4 liang), *huangqi* (4 liang), *xiongqiong* (4 liang), *danggui* (4 liang), *fuzi* (3 liang), *guixin* (3 liang), *qinjiao* (3 liang), *ganjiang* (3 liang), *shanzhuyu* (1 sheng), and *yiyiren* (1 sheng).

The above sixteen ingredients are to be cut and steeped in three *dou* of clear wine for three days. Begin with three *ge* per dose, twice daily, gradually increasing until an effect is felt.

**Gouqi and Changpu Wine**
A formula for treating flaccid and acute wind, uncoordinated limbs, unsteady gait, clenched jaw, and inability to flex or extend the limbs:
*Changpu* (5 jin) and *gouqi* root (100 jin).

The two ingredients are to be finely chopped, boiled in four *shi* of water to yield one *shi* and six *dou* of decoction, then used to brew two *hu* of rice wine. Drink gradually.

**Tiger Bone Wine**
A formula for treating bone marrow pain and wind afflicting the five viscera:
One set of tiger bones, roasted over charcoal until yellow, then pounded, scraped, and ground for several days. Steep in six *sheng* of clear wine for five nights. Drink gradually as desired.

The *Yi* states: "When the tiger roars, wind arises; when the dragon hums, clouds gather." This reflects the resonance between the sentient and insentient, ensuring the efficacy of wind treatments without doubt.

**Smartweed Wine**
A formula for treating cold in the stomach conduit, inability to eat, impaired hearing and vision, qi in the limbs, and cold feet in winter. After ten days of consumption, the eyes become clear and the body robust:
On the third day of the eighth month, gather smartweed, dry it in the sun, and bundle it into sixty bundles the size of five *sheng*. Boil in six *shi* of water to yield one *shi* of decoction, then brew wine as usual. Drink as desired; effects manifest swiftly.

**Minor Huangqi Wine**
A major formula for treating wind-induced deficiency, phlegm aggregation, hemilateral paralysis, weak legs, inability to raise the hands to the head, lower abdominal contraction and pain, rib-side cramping, hidden water beneath the heart, accumulated fluids beneath the ribs, nightmares, melancholy, forgetfulness, and disorientation—all caused by wind deficiency and visceral affliction. It also treats chronic lumbar pain from prolonged sitting, deafness, sudden dizziness and heaviness upon rising, generalized swelling, pain and numbness, aversion to cold food, chills, chest fullness with phlegm, cold mounting beneath the heart, and postpartum residual illnesses in women due to unrelieved wind deficiency and accumulated cold:
*Huangqi* (3 liang), *fuzi* (3 liang), *shujiao* (3 liang), *fangfeng* (3 liang), *niuxi* (3 liang), *xixin* (3 liang), *guixin* (3 liang), *duhuo* (3 liang), *baizhu* (3 liang), *xiongqiong* (3 liang), *gancao* (3 liang), *qinjiao* (3 liang), *wutou* (*Jiyan* uses *shuyu* 3 liang), *dahuang* (2 liang), *gegen* (2 liang), *ganjiang* (2 liang), *shanzhuyu* (2 liang), and *danggui* (2.5 liang).

The above eighteen ingredients are to be cut. For the robust, no toasting is needed; for the frail and elderly, lightly toast them. Place in a silk bag and steep in two *dou* of clear wine—five days in spring and summer, seven in autumn and winter. Take one *ge* before meals; if no effect, increase to four or five *ge*, three times daily. This formula excels at dispelling numbness and does not cause vomiting or discomfort.

For mild heat, consume cold food and drink. For severe deficiency, add *congrong* (2 liang). For diarrhea, add *nüwei* (3 liang). For forgetfulness, add *shihu*, *changpu*, and *zishi* (2 liang each). For excess water beneath the heart, add *fuling*, *renshen* (2 liang each), and *shuyu* (3 liang). When the wine is finished, steep the dregs again in two *dou* of wine. Alternatively, dry the dregs in the sun, grind them, and take one *cun*-spoonful with wine, gradually increasing if no effect is felt. One course strengthens resistance to cold, supplements deficiency, and treats all wind-cold conditions with divine efficacy.

**Huangqi Wine**
A formula for treating wind-induced deficiency, leg pain, flaccid weakness, qi oppression, and inability to control the limbs, with supplementing effects:
*Huangqi* (3 liang), *wutou* (3 liang), *fuzi* (3 liang), *ganjiang* (3 liang), *qinjiao* (3 liang), *shujiao* (3 liang), *xiongqiong* (3 liang), *duhuo* (3 liang), *baizhu* (3 liang), *niuxi* (3 liang), *congrong* (3 liang), *xixin* (3 liang), *gancao* (3 liang), *gegen* (2.5 liang), *danggui* (2.5 liang), *changpu* (2.5 liang), *shanzhuyu* (2 liang), *guixin*, *zhongru*, *baiziren*, *tianxiong*, *shihu*, and *fangfeng* (2 liang each), *dahuang* (1 liang), and *shannan* (1 liang).

The above twenty-five ingredients are to be cut without toasting and steeped in three *dou* of clear wine. Take one *ge* before meals; if no effect, increase to five *ge*, three times daily. Excellent for dispelling numbness.

For severe deficiency, add *congrong*; for diarrhea, add *nüwei*; for forgetfulness, add *changpu* (3 liang each).
*Huqia* includes *zexie* (3 liang), *fuling* (2 liang), *renshen*, *yinyu*, *banxia*, *gualou*, and *shaoyao* (1 liang each), omitting *qinjiao*, *xiongqiong*, *niuxi*, *congrong*, *gancao*, *gegen*, *danggui*, *changpu*, *zhongru*, and *dahuang*, totaling twenty-two ingredients, named *Major Huangqi Wine*.

**Yinyu Wine**, for treating severe wind afflictions, dizziness and heaviness of the head, blurred vision or total blindness, sudden collapse with loss of breath, reviving only after half a day, facial distortion with locked jaw, hemiplegia, stiffness and numbness with pain, inability to move, swollen and aching joints, deep bone soreness, inability to raise the hands to the head or bend and stretch the feet, difficulty walking with a limp, skin twitching as if insects were gnawing, itching rashes that fester when scratched, and in severe cases, manic running. For all these ailments, this formula governs:

*Yinyu*, *wutou*, *shinan*, *fangfeng*, *shujiao*, *nüwei*, *fuzi*, *xixin*, *duhuo*, *juanbai*, *guixin*, *tianxiong*, *qinjiao*, and *fangji* (1 *liang* each); *zhizhu* (2 *liang*).

The above fifteen ingredients are to be cut. For the young and robust, use without toasting; for the weak and elderly, lightly toast. Steep in two *dou* of clear wine—seven days in winter, three in summer, five in spring and autumn. Begin with one *ge*; if no effect, increase to two *ge*, starting with a smaller dose and taking twice daily, until mild numbness is felt. *Huqia* omits *shujiao*, *duhuo*, and *juanbai*, totaling twelve ingredients.

**Major Jinya Wine**, for treating miasmic poison, wind-cold-damp numbness, facial distortion, hemiplegia, cramped hands and feet, swollen and aching joints, and in severe cases, lower abdominal numbness known as "leg qi," governing all conditions:

*Jinya* (1 *jin*), *cezi*, *fuzi*, *tianxiong*, *renshen*, *congrong*, *fuling*, *danggui*, *fangfeng*, *huangqi*, *shuyu*, *xixin*, *guixin*, *bixie*, *weirui*, *baizhi*, *jiegeng*, *huangqin*, *yuanzhi*, *mujingzi*, *xiongqiong*, *digupi*, *wujia pi*, *duzhong*, *houpo*, *zhishi*, *baizhu*, *niuxi*, and *danshen* (3 *liang* each); *duhuo* (½ *jin*); *yinyu*, *shinan*, and *gouji* (2 *liang* each); *cishi* (10 *liang*); *yiyiren* and *maimendong* (1 *sheng* each); *sheng shihu* (8 *liang*); *shuodi* (4 *liang*); *sheng dihuang* (cut, 2 *sheng*).

The above thirty-nine ingredients are to be cut and steeped in eight *dou* of wine for seven days. Take one *ge* warm, four to five times daily and once at night. Grind the mineral ingredients finely, place in a silk bag, and steep with the other herbs. This formula is harmonious in potency and treats a wide range of conditions; for all wind-deficiency syndromes where the limbs show even slight signs of wind, it must be taken, governing all disorders. Those who prepare it must follow the formula precisely and not casually heed others’ exaggerated claims or make arbitrary additions or omissions.

**Zhongru Wine**, for treating deficiency and depletion, harmonizing the blood vessels, and strongly supplementing the lower *qi*:

*Zhongru*, *shihu* (5 *liang* each); *fuzi*, *ganju* (2 *liang* each).

The above five ingredients are to be cut and steeped in three *dou* of clear wine. Take two *ge* twice daily, gradually increasing to one *sheng*.

**Qinjiao Wine**, for treating wind in the four limbs, inability to control the arms, pain and weakness in the viscera and legs, or cramping, spasms, and curled fingers, hemiplegia, atrophy, and stubborn numbness:

*Qinjiao*, *tianmendong*, *wujia pi*, *niuxi*, *fuzi*, *guixin* (3 *liang* each); *bajitian*, *duzhong*, *shinan*, *xixin* (2 *liang* each); *duhuo* (1 *liang*); *yiyiren* (1 *liang*).

The above twelve ingredients are to be cut and steeped in two *dou* of wine until the flavor is extracted. Take three *ge*, gradually increasing to five or six *ge*, three times daily and once at night.

**Zhu Gao Wine**, for treating leg weakness, wind-deficiency, the five taxations and seven injuries, and all diseases:

Wash and pound one *shi* and five *dou* of fresh *baizhu* to extract three *dou* of juice, then reduce by half through simmering. Bundle twenty-five bundles of damp *jing* (each three *chi* in circumference, two *chi* and five *cun* long, two *cun* in diameter at the base), burn to collect three *dou* of drippings, then reduce by half. Bundle thirty bundles of green bamboo (each three *chi* in circumference, two *chi* and five *cun* long, one *cun* in diameter), burn to collect three *dou* of drippings, then reduce by half. Pound five large *dou* of fresh *dihuang* roots (thick and large) to extract three *dou* of juice, then reduce by half. Wash thirty-six *jin* of fresh *wujia* roots clean, chop, and boil in four *shi* of water in a large cauldron; strain, clarify, and collect seven *dou* of juice. Place in a copper vessel, simmer over water in a large cauldron to reduce to three *dou* and five *sheng*. The method for simmering all ingredients follows the *wujia* example.

The above five ingredients—*baizhu* and the rest—yield a total of nine *dou* and five *sheng* of juice. Take one *shi* and five *dou* of glutinous rice and eight *jin* of wheat *qu*, dry in the sun, and grind to powder. Soak the *qu* in six *dou* of the medicinal juice for five days until the *qu* ferments. For the first addition, wash and rinse seven *dou* of rice thirty times, place on a clean mat, and wipe with a raw cloth to ensure cleanliness. Steam the rice, then soak the cooked grains in the remaining medicinal juice, adjusting the consistency before steaming again. When a crust forms on the grains, spread them on a mat, adjusting the consistency, temperature, and moisture as in standard wine brewing. Ferment in a jar, sealing the lid tightly. After three days, make the second addition: wash and rinse four *dou* of rice as before, then add following the same method. After another three days, add the following ingredients:

*Guixin*, *gancao*, *baizhi*, *xixin*, *fangfeng*, *danggui*, *mahuang*, *xiongqiong* (6 *liang* each); *fuzi* (5 *liang*); *niuxi* (9 *liang*); *ganjiang*, *wujia pi* (1 *jin* each).

Cut the above twelve ingredients, then for the third addition, wash and rinse four *dou* of rice as before. Soak the cooked grains in the remaining juice, steam again until a crust forms, then spread on a mat, adjusting temperature and moisture as in standard brewing. Combine with the above ingredients, and after three more days, taste for a balanced sweetness and bitterness. Seal tightly for fourteen days, then press to obtain the clear wine.

Take four *ge* per dose, twice daily, gradually increasing until the desired effect is achieved. The wine should be warmed but not excessively hot. Avoid raw or cold foods, vinegar, slippery textures, pork, carp, garlic, beef, and the like.

**Pine Needle Wine**, which governs weakness of the legs, the twelve types of wind-induced paralysis rendering one unable to walk: After taking several doses of *Gengsheng San* and other treatments prove ineffective, a single dose of this formula enables long-distance walking. No more than two doses are required. **Method**:
Sixty *jin* of pine needles, cut and boiled in four *shi* of water to yield four *dou* and nine *sheng*. Use this to brew five *dou* of rice following standard methods. Separately boil the pine needle decoction to soak the rice and cook the grains. Seal the vessel with clay for fermentation. After seven days, the wine will activate; strain and drink to intoxication. Many have gained strength from this, and its efficacy is divine.

**Formula for Beriberi**:
Three *dou* of fine fermented soybeans, steamed with one *shi* of rice, then sun-dried. Repeat this process three times. Soak in five *dou* of wine for seven days, then strain and drink to intoxication. When the wine is finished, soak the residue again in two and a half *dou* of wine and drink as before.

**Aconite Wine**, a formula for wind-dampness paralysis, numbness, and leg weakness rendering one unable to walk:
*Aconitum lateralis* (4 *liang*), *niuxi* (4 *liang*), *danshen* (4 *liang*), *shanzhuyu* (4 *liang*), *shuodi* root (4 *liang*), *duzhong* (4 *liang*), *shihu* (4 *liang*), *fangfeng* (3 *liang*), *ganjiang* (3 *liang*), *shujiao* (3 *liang*), *xixin* (3 *liang*), *duhuo* (3 *liang*), *qinjiao* (3 *liang*), *guixin* (3 *liang*), *xiongqiong* (3 *liang*), *danggui* (3 *liang*), *baizhu* (3 *liang*), *yinyu* (3 *liang*), *wujia pi* (5 *liang*), *yiyiren* (1 *sheng*).
Cut the above twenty ingredients, place in a silk bag, and steep in four *dou* of clear wine for six days. Begin with three *ge* per dose, gradually increasing until the desired effect is achieved.

For those suffering from dim vision and dizziness, the condition will worsen with excessive essence depletion.

**Fifth Category: Medicinal Ointments**

**General Instructions for Preparing Ointments:**
When making ointments, always choose an auspicious day. Ensure that no one in mourning, those who are ritually impure, women who have recently given birth, lowly persons, chickens, dogs, or other animals witness the process.

For external ailments, apply the ointment with fire-warming and massage. For internal ailments, take a portion the size of a jujube kernel with warm wine.

**Divine Clarity Ointment**, a remedy for all diseases, including wind-stroke with malign qi, and various head and facial disorders—such as green blindness, wind-induced eye erosion, lacrimal duct obstruction, corneal opacity, deafness, nasal congestion, dental caries, tooth-root pain, abscesses, hemorrhoids, ringworm, and scabies:
*Wu zhuyu* (1 *sheng*), *shujiao* (1 *sheng*), *xiongqiong* (1 *sheng*), *baizhu* (1 *sheng*), *qianhu* (1 *sheng*; *Cui’s* version uses *baiqian*), *baizhi* (1 *sheng*), *fuzi* (30 pieces), *guixin* (2 *liang*), *danggui* (2 *liang*), *xixin* (2 *liang*).
Cut the above ten ingredients, steep them in pure bitter wine in a copper vessel overnight. Then, add ten *jin* of rendered lard and simmer over charcoal fire until it boils three times, lifting and lowering the mixture thrice. The process is complete when *baizhi* turns yellow.

For internal ailments, take a pill the size of a jujube kernel with warm wine, three times daily. For eye pain, apply a grain-sized amount to the inner corners of the eyes, then face the wind (or use a fan if there is no wind). For all sores, hemorrhoids, dental caries, ear and nasal disorders, apply the ointment topically. For skin ailments, warm the ointment with fire, massage onto the affected area, three times daily.
*Note: The* Zhouhou *version omits* guixin*.*

**Marquis Wei’s Green Ointment**, a remedy for all diseases, chronic wind-induced dizziness, nasal congestion with clear discharge, cholera with vomiting and retching, cold damage with sore throat, stiffness in the back, neck, and head, hemiplegia with spasms (either flaccid or rigid), long-standing cold in the heart and abdomen with accumulations and pain, cough with counterflow qi, alternating chills and fever, scrofula, swollen painful joints, total joint pain, the seven injuries in men, abdominal distension and fullness, emaciation with inability to eat, postpartum ailments in women, scabies, malign sores, abscesses, genital erosion, jaundice, carbuncles on the back, saddle sores, and neck sores:
*Danggui* (6 *liang*), *gualuo* root (6 *liang*), *gandihuang* (6 *liang*), *gancao* (6 *liang*), *shujiao* (6 *liang*), *banxia* (7 *ge*), *guixin* (4 *liang*), *xiongqiong* (4 *liang*), *xixin* (4 *liang*), *fuzi* (4 *liang*), *huangqin* (1.5 *liang*), *jiegeng* (1.5 *liang*), *tianxiong* (1.5 *liang*), *lilu* (1.5 *liang*), *zaojia* (1.5 *liang*), *houpo* (3 *liang*), *wutou* (3 *liang*), *mangcao* (3 *liang*), *ganjiang* (3 *liang*), *renshen* (3 *liang*), *huanglian* (3 *liang*), *jisheng* (3 *liang*), *xuduan* (3 *liang*), *rongyan* (3 *liang*), *huangyie* (2 *fen*), *shengzhuru* (6 *sheng*), *badou* (20 pieces), *shinan* (1 *liang*), *xingren* (1 *liang*), lard (3 *dou*), bitter wine (1 *dou* 6 *sheng*).
Cut the above thirty-one ingredients, steep them in bitter wine overnight, then simmer with lard over a gentle fire, lifting and lowering the mixture thrice until the ointment is ready.

For internal ailments, take a portion the size of half a jujube kernel with wine. For external ailments, massage the ointment onto the affected area, three times daily.

**Divine Brilliance Ointment**, a remedy for dryness in the nose, to be administered by instillation and massage:
*Shujiao* (5 *ge*), *zaojia* (3 *zhu*), *huangqin* (3 *zhu*), *shinan* (3 *zhu*), *huanglian* (3 *zhu*), *xionghuang* (3 *zhu*), *guixin* (3 *zhu*), *lilu* (3 *zhu*), *baizhu* (7 *zhu*), *xiongqiong* (7 *zhu*), *dahuang* (7 *zhu*), *zexie* (7 *zhu*), *wutou* (5 *zhu*), *mangcao* (5 *zhu*), *xuduan* (5 *zhu*), *renshen* (5 *zhu*), *banxia* (12 *zhu*), *danggui* (12 *zhu*), *gandihuang* (11 *zhu*), *weirui* (10 *zhu*), *xixin* (10 *zhu*), *fuzi* (2 *zhu*), *jiegeng* (2 *zhu*), *ganjiang* (6 *zhu*), *rongyan* (1 piece, the size of an apricot kernel).
Cut the above twenty-five ingredients, steep them in one *dou* of bitter wine, and add one *jin* of sheep marrow. Construct a stove in the southeast corner, place the ingredients inside, and heat with reed firewood. Arrange three mounds of fresh, clean soil. When the medicine boils, remove it and place it on the soil mounds. Repeat this process three times until the ointment is ready, then strain through new cloth to remove the dregs.

For external ailments, warm the ointment with fire and massage onto the affected area. For internal ailments, take a portion the size of a jujube kernel with warm wine, three times daily. Gradually increase the dosage until the desired effect is achieved.

**Grand Tutor’s White Ointment**, a remedy for all diseases, including cold damage with throat discomfort, stiffness and pain in the head, neck, waist, and spine, wind-dampness with swelling and difficulty in bending or walking, wind-induced dizziness, nasal congestion with nasal polyps or sores, body rashes with wind itching, scrofula, abscesses, malign sores, saddle and neck sores, long-standing cold accumulations in the heart, abdominal pain, chest impediment, vexation and fullness with insomnia, cough with counterflow qi, alternating chills and fever, and postpartum ailments in women. It also treats disorders of the ears, eyes, nose, and mouth. Also known as the *Supreme Unity Divine-Efficacy Ointment*:
*Shujiao* (1 *sheng*), *shengma* (cut, 1 *sheng*), *fuzi* (3 *liang*), *badou* (30 *zhu*), *xiongqiong* (30 *zhu*), *xingren* (5 *ge*), *li* bone (1.5 *liang*), *xixin* (1.5 *liang*), *baizhi* (0.5 *liang*), *gancao* (2 *liang*), *baizhu* (6 *liang*; one version uses *danggui* 3 *liang*).
Cut the above twelve ingredients, steep them in bitter wine overnight, then simmer with four *jin* of lard over a gentle fire. Peel one *fuzi* and tie it with a string, suspending it in the ointment. When the *fuzi* turns yellow, the ointment is ready. Remove the dregs.

For cold damage with abdominal accumulations, wind-induced swelling, stiffness in the neck, waist, and spine, and hemiplegia with numbness, massage the ointment onto the affected area once daily. For abscesses, malign sores, and scrofula, warm the ointment with fire and massage onto the affected area. For deafness, instill a soybean-sized amount into the ear. For eye pain with tearing, corneal opacity resembling a pearl over the pupil with loss of vision, apply a millet-sized amount to the white of the eye, have the patient cover it with their hand, and wait briefly for improvement. Then rinse with water, and vision will be restored as before. Avoid wind for thirty days thereafter.

For nasal pain, take a soybean-sized amount and insert it into the nostril, while also massaging the area. For toothache, wrap a soybean-sized amount in silk and place it on the aching tooth to bite down. For wind stroke with facial distortion—twisted mouth, nose, and eyes—massage the ointment onto the affected area. When traveling at dawn or night to ward off frost and mist, if eyebrows or eyelashes fall out, frequently wash with iron-infused water, then massage the ointment onto the area.

**Qu Yu Ointment**, a formula for wind-damp painful impediment, weakness in the limbs, hemiplegia with numbness, as well as abscesses and malign sores:
*Rhubarb, Scutellaria, Illicium leaf, Croton seed, Yellow jessamine, Tree peony bark, Yellow azalea, Genkwa flower, Sichuan pepper, Gleditsia pod, False hellebore, and Aconite root—one liang each.*
Grind the twelve ingredients, soak them in bitter wine overnight, then simmer in three jin of rendered lard over low heat. Bring to a boil three times, then add a slice of *Angelica dahurica*. Simmer until the *Angelica* turns yellow and the ointment is ready. Remove the dregs. Warm the ointment over low fire and massage onto the affected area three times daily.

**Ye Ge Ointment**, a formula for malign wind-toxin swelling, painful impediment with numbness, scrofula, malign sores, abscesses, swollen sores, leg weakness, hemiplegia, and all diseases:
*Yellow jessamine, Rhinoceros horn, *Saxifraga stolonifera*, Illicium leaf (substituted with *Skimmia* in *Waitai Miyao*), Aconite, Platycodon, Cimicifuga, Ledebouriella, Sichuan pepper, Dried ginger, Turtle shell, Realgar, Croton seed—one liang each; Salvia—three liang; Yellow azalea flowers—one sheng.*
Grind the fifteen ingredients, soak them in four sheng of bitter wine overnight, then simmer in five jin of rendered lard over low heat. Simmer three times up and down until the herbs turn slightly yellow. Remove the dregs and massage the ointment onto the affected area.
*This formula must not be applied to the unrefined; exercise caution.*
*Hu Qia’s version omits Salvia and Yellow azalea but includes Asarum. Su Gong substitutes Angelica, Stephania, Evodia, Aconite, and Chinese angelica for Croton seed, Realgar, *Saxifraga*, Ledebouriella, and Turtle shell.*

**Cangwu Daoist Chen Yuan’s Ointment**, a formula for all wind-damp painful impediment in bones and flesh:
*Chinese angelica, Asarum, Ligusticum—one liang each; Cinnamon bark—five cun; Aconite—three pieces; Fresh rehmannia—three jin; Angelica dahurica—one and a half liang; Cinnabar—two liang; Dried ginger—ten pieces; Aconite—three liang; Pine resin—eight liang; Lard—ten jin.*
Grind the twelve ingredients, soak them in rehmannia juice overnight, then simmer the lard. Remove the dregs, add the herbs, and simmer fifteen times. Remove the dregs, then add powdered cinnabar and stir thoroughly. Warm the ointment over fire and massage onto the affected area a thousand times daily until cured.
*Hu Qia’s version includes Ginseng and Ledebouriella—three liang each; Aconite—thirty pieces; Realgar—two liang (fifteen ingredients total). The *Zhouhou* and *Qianjin Yifang* versions include Aconite—twenty-two zhu; Realgar—two and a half liang; and three sheng of strong vinegar (fifteen ingredients total). Cui’s version matches the *Qianjin Yifang*.*

**Pei Gong’s Eight-Toxin Ointment**, a formula for sudden wind-toxin stroke, colicky abdominal pain, flying corpse entering the viscera, nightmare-induced unconsciousness, corpse-like syncope, sudden loss of awareness, undigested food, and cold damage:
Take a jujube-sized amount with warm wine; cease when purgation occurs. If the toxin is severe and the throat is obstructed, preventing swallowing, pry open the teeth, insert a scallion leaf into the mouth, and pour the ointment through it. For swellings, warm the ointment over fire and massage onto the affected area. To prevent seasonal warmth diseases or exposure to mist and dew, take it with wine or apply it inside the nostrils.
*Formulary: Sichuan pepper, Chinese angelica, Realgar, Cinnabar—two liang each; Aconite, Croton seed—one sheng each; Scallion—one jin; Illicium leaf—four liang.*
Grind the eight ingredients, soak them in three sheng of bitter wine overnight, then simmer in five jin of lard over a fire fueled by reeds in an east-facing stove. Simmer five times up and down until the scallion turns yellow. Strain out the dregs, grind Realgar and Cinnabar into powder, add to the ointment, and stir until congealed. Store in a non-porous vessel.
For centipede, snake, bee, and other venomous bites, apply the ointment to the wound. For external ailments, apply and massage the ointment, using the day of *Po Chu* for application.
*One version includes Arsenolite—one liang and Centipedes—two pieces, calling it Eight-Toxin Ointment. The *Zhouhou* omits Croton seed and Illicium leaf, naming it Five-Toxin Ointment.*
