Volume Thirty of *Sun Zhenren’s Essential Emergency Prescriptions Worth a Thousand in Gold*
Collated and Corrected by Lin Yi, Gentleman for Court Service and Vice Minister of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices, concurrently serving as Editorial Director of the Palace Library, and others, of the Song Dynasty.

**Prescriptions for Cold Damage**

**Third Prescription: Ointments for Cold Damage**

**Green Ointment** – Treats cold damage, headache, stiff neck, and generalized pain in the limbs:
*Danggui* (当归), *xiongqiong* (芎藭), *shujiao* (蜀椒), *baizhi* (白芷), *wuzhuyu* (吴茱萸), *fuzi* (附子), *wutou* (乌头), and *gancao* (甘草), each three *liang*.
The eight ingredients above are [cut], steeped in pure bitter wine for two nights, then fried in four *jin* of lard until the herbs turn yellow. Strain to remove the dregs.
Take three pieces the size of a jujube pit with warm wine, three times daily, to induce sweating. If no effect, slightly increase the dose.
May be taken orally or applied as a massage. For those who have contracted cold damage for a single day and suffer from severe headache and stiff back, massage is particularly effective.

**Yellow Ointment** – Treats cold damage with flushed complexion, headache, stiff neck, and pernicious or migratory wind:
*Dahuang* (大黄), *fuzi* (附子), *xixin* (细辛), *ganjiang* (乾姜), *shujiao* (蜀椒), and *guixin* (桂心), each half a *liang*; *badou* (巴豆), fifty pieces.
The seven ingredients above are [cut], steeped in pure bitter wine for one night, then fried in one *jin* of lard from a twelfth-month pig. Adjust the fire, frying the mixture three times up and three times down until the ointment is ready.
For cold damage with flushed complexion and fever, take one piece the size of a *wutong* seed with wine, and massage the body with fire several hundred times.
Also highly effective for pernicious wind, migratory wind in the skin, and wandering wind in any location. This is Zhao Quan’s prescription, never before transmitted in the *Thousand Gold*.

**White Ointment** – Treats cold damage with headache. Warm the ointment over fire and massage the body, then take a piece the size of an apricot pit with wine. Cover to induce sweating.
Massage the body a thousand times for the medicine’s power to take effect.
Also treats malignant sores, infantile head sores, and sores from ox collars or horse saddles. First wash the sore with salt water, wipe with cloth, then apply the ointment.
For abscesses and swellings, warm the ointment over fire and massage a thousand times, twice daily, until they resolve. Prescription:
*Tianxiong* (天雄), *wutou* (乌头), *mangcao* (莽草), and *yangzhizhu* (羊踯躅), each three *liang*.
The four ingredients above are [cut], steeped in three *sheng* of bitter wine for one night. Build an east-facing open-air stove and arrange twelve mounds of damp earth, each about one *sheng* in size.
Take three *jin* of rendered lard, place in a copper vessel, and heat over the stove with reed firewood until melted. Add the steeped herbs and boil. When it bubbles, transfer to the earth mounds, then return to the fire. Repeat twelve times until the earth is fully used and the ointment is ready. Strain to remove the dregs.
For sore throat from cold damage, hold one piece the size of a jujube pit in the mouth, three times daily.
When massaging, avoid proximity to the eyes.

**Fourth Prescription: Powders for Inducing Sweat**

**Powder for Dispelling Miasma and Inducing Sweat** – Treats cold damage with flushed complexion, aversion to cold, fever, headache, stiff neck, and generalized pain:
*Mahuang* (麻黄), three and a half *liang*; *jiegeng* (桔梗), *xixin* (细辛), *wuzhuyu* (吴茱萸), *fangfeng* (防风), and *baizhu* (白术), each one *liang*; *wutou* (乌头), *ganjiang* (乾姜), *shujiao* (蜀椒), and *guixin* (桂心), each one *liang* and six *zhu*.
The ten ingredients above are ground and sifted.
Take one *fangcunbi* with warm wine, cover to induce sweating, and stop once sweat appears. If sweating does not occur or is insufficient to resolve symptoms, take again as before. If sweating is adequate yet headache and fever persist, this indicates internal repletion, and one should take *chixi wan* or *Diaoshi wan*.
If heaviness in the head persists, insert a quantity the size of two large beans into the nostrils. When dryness is felt and nasal discharge occurs, repeat three to four times daily for certain resolution.
Also wards off seasonal epidemics.

**Five-Ingredient Poria Powder** – Treats seasonal febrile diseases with delirium, restlessness, and incoherent speech:
*Zhuling* (猪苓), *baizhu* (白术), and *fuling* (茯苓), each eighteen *zhu*; *guixin* (桂心), twelve *zhu*; *zexie* (泽泻), thirty *zhu*.
The five ingredients above are ground and sifted.
Take one *fangcunbi* with water, three times daily. Drink plenty of water, and recovery follows sweating.

**Cui Wenxing’s Dissolving Powder** – Treats seasonal disharmony and cold damage with fever:
*Jiegeng* (桔梗) and *xixin* (细辛), each four *liang*; *baizhu* (白术), eight *liang*; *wutou* (乌头), one *jin*.
The four ingredients above are ground and sifted.
For those afflicted with cold damage, take five *qianbi* with wine, cover to induce sweating and resolve symptoms. If no effect, slightly increase the dose until improvement is noted.
For seasonal disharmony, take five *qianbi* at dawn. To ward off malign qi and prevent illness, take one dose. All are taken with wine.

**Six-Ingredient Green Powder** – Treats cold damage with flushed complexion and aversion to cold:
*Fuzi* (附子) and *baizhu* (白术), each one *liang* and six *zhu*; *fangfeng* (防风) and *xixin* (细辛), each one *liang* and eighteen *zhu*; *jiegeng* (桔梗) and *wutou* (乌头), each three *liang* and eight *zhu*.
The six ingredients above are ground and sifted.
Take five *bi* with warm wine. If no effect, slightly increase the dose. If no sweating occurs within the time it takes to eat a meal, drink a cup of warm congee to promote sweating. Cover to induce sweat, which should be moderate—avoid profuse sweating or exposing the hands and feet. Stop once sweating occurs.
If sweating is profuse and unceasing, apply warm powder. For mild cases, powder is unnecessary. If no sweating occurs, take again. If sweating occurs but symptoms persist, take *Shendan Wan* (prescription found in the section on sweating pills below).

**Green Powder** – Treats spring cold damage with headache and fever:
*Kushen* (苦参), *houpo* (厚朴), and *shigao* (石膏), each thirty *zhu*; *dahuang* (大黄) and *xixin* (细辛), each two *liang*; *mahuang* (麻黄), five *liang*; *wutou* (乌头), five pieces.
The seven ingredients above are ground and sifted.
At the onset of cold damage with headache and fever, mix one *fangcunbi* of the powder with half a *sheng* of hot water, stir into the water, and boil thoroughly. Strain and consume the entire dose, then cover to induce sweating. Once sweating occurs, apply warm powder.
If symptoms persist after one dose, take again.

In some cases, mild diarrhea may occur due to the presence of *dahuang*.

**Imperial Decree White Aster Powder** – Treats cold damage persisting for three days:
*Baiwei* (白薇), twelve *zhu*; *xingren* (杏仁) and *beimu* (贝母), each eighteen *zhu*; *mahuang* (麻黄), one *liang* and eight *zhu*.
The four ingredients above are ground and sifted.
Take one *fangcunbi* with wine, then cover to induce sweating. Recovery follows sweating.

**Hua Tuo’s Red Powder** – Treats cold damage with headache, fever, stiff neck and back, wind-induced lockjaw, unrelenting malaria, and postpartum wind-cold in women with qi stagnation and abdominal distension:
*Dansha* (丹砂), twelve *zhu*; *shujiao* (蜀椒), *shuqi* (蜀漆), *ganjiang* (乾姜), *xixin* (细辛), *huangqin* (黄苓), *fangji* (防己), *guixin* (桂心), *fuling* (茯苓), *renshen* (人参), *shashen* (沙参), *jiegeng* (桔梗), *nüwei* (女萎), and *wutou* (乌头), each eighteen *zhu*; *xionghuang* (雄黄), twenty-four *zhu*; *wuzhuyu* (吴茱萸), thirty *zhu*; *mahuang* (麻黄) and *daizhe* (代赭), each two and a half *liang*.
The eighteen ingredients above are ground and sifted.
Take one *fangcunbi* with wine, three times daily. For those tolerant to the medicine, take two *fangcunbi*, then cover to induce sweating.
To treat malaria, take half a dose one hour before the expected onset, then adjust the dosage as needed.
Do not stir-fry *xixin*, *jiang*, *gui*, *dansha*, or *xionghuang*; stir-fry the remaining ingredients.

**Red Powder** – Treats cold damage with headache, stiff neck, fever, lumbar and spinal pain, and intermittent symptoms:
*Ganjiang* (乾姜), *fangfeng* (防风), *shashen* (沙参), *xixin* (细辛), *baizhu* (白术), *renshen* (人参), *shujiao* (蜀椒), *fuling* (茯苓), *mahuang* (麻黄), *huangqin* (黄苓), *daizhe* (代赭), *jiegeng* (桔梗), and *wuzhuyu* (吴茱萸), each one *liang*; *fuzi* (附子), two *liang*.
The fourteen ingredients above are ground and sifted.
Take one *qianbi* with wine before meals, three times daily.

**Aconite Red Powder** – Treats epidemic diseases:
*Wutou* (乌头), one and a half *liang*; *zaojia* (皂荚), half a *liang*; *xionghuang* (雄黄), *xixin* (细辛), *jiegeng* (桔梗), and *dahuang* (大黄), each one *liang*.
The six ingredients above are ground and sifted.
Take one *daogui* with clear wine or well water, twice daily. Increase the dosage gradually until the desired effect is achieved.
To prevent epidemic diseases or treat waterborne epidemics in cattle, horses, or livestock, administer one *fangcunbi*.
At the onset of illness (within one day), take one *daogui* and blow a pinch (about the size of two soybeans) into each nostril.

**Water-Dissolving Powder** – Treats seasonal illnesses with headache and high fever lasting one to two days:
*Guixin* (桂心), *gancao* (甘草), and *dahuang* (大黄), each two *liang*; *mahuang* (麻黄), four *liang*.
The four ingredients above are ground and sifted.
After the patient bathes in warm water, administer one *fangcunbi* with warm water, three times daily. Cover to induce sweating or diarrhea, leading to recovery. Robust individuals may take two *fangcunbi*.
*The Extensive Records of Longevity* includes *huangqin* (黄苓) and *shaoyao* (芍药), each two *liang*.
*The Ancient and Modern Records of Verification* omits *gancao* but includes *shaoyao*, treating epidemic febrile diseases with eruptive sores, pain, and promoting sweating to release muscle tension.

**Powder for Seasonal Illness with High Fever and Near-Death Symptoms**:
*Dahuang* (大黄), *hanshuishi* (寒水石), *mangxiao* (芒硝), *shigao* (石膏), *shengma* (升麻), *mahuang* (麻黄), *gegen* (葛根), and *zige* (紫葛), in equal parts, ground and sifted.
Take one *fangcunbi* with water, twice daily.

**Fifth Example of Sweating Decoctions: Cinnamon Twig Patterns**

General principles state: In spring and summer, sweating is generally appropriate. When inducing sweating, ensure it spreads evenly to the hands and feet, reaching a gentle, continuous state within about an hour—this is ideal. However, avoid excessive sweating like flowing water.
If the illness persists, induce sweating again.
Excessive sweating depletes yang; with yang deficiency, do not induce sweating repeatedly.
When taking decoctions to induce sweating, discontinue once the illness subsides; the full dose is unnecessary.
If sweating is recommended but no decoction is specified, pills or powders may also be used, as long as sweating occurs for resolution. However, decoctions tailored to the pattern are more effective.
If a patient sweats spontaneously without cause, inducing sweating again will lead to recovery, as it restores harmony to the defensive *qi*.
A floating pulse indicates an external illness; sweating is appropriate, and *Guizhi Tang* (Cinnamon Twig Decoction) is suitable.
A floating, large, and rapid pulse also indicates suitability for sweating, and *Guizhi Tang* is appropriate.
If a patient constantly sweats spontaneously, this indicates harmony of the nutritive *qi*. If the exterior remains unresolved despite harmonious nutritive *qi*, the defensive *qi* is disharmonious. The nutritive *qi* flows within the vessels, while the defensive *qi* flows outside them. Inducing sweating again will harmonize the defensive *qi* and lead to recovery; *Guizhi Tang* is suitable.
If a patient has no internal illness but frequently experiences fever and spontaneous sweating without recovery, this is due to disharmony of the defensive *qi*. Inducing sweating before the onset of symptoms will lead to recovery; *Guizhi Tang* is suitable.
In *Taiyang* disease with fever and sweating, the nutritive *qi* is weak and the defensive *qi* is strong, causing sweating. To expel pathogenic wind, *Guizhi Tang* is suitable.
In *Taiyang* disease with headache, fever, sweating, and aversion to wind and cold, *Guizhi Tang* is suitable.
In *Taiyang* disease with mild panting after purging, the exterior remains unresolved; *Guizhi Jia Houpo Xingren Tang* (Cinnamon Twig Decoction with Magnolia and Apricot Kernel) is suitable.
In *Taiyang* disease with unresolved exterior symptoms, purging is inappropriate; *Guizhi Tang* is suitable.
In *Taiyang* disease, if sweating is induced first but the illness persists and purging is then applied, a floating pulse indicates non-recovery. A floating pulse signifies an external illness, yet purging was applied—hence the lack of recovery. Since the pulse remains floating, the illness is still external, and resolving the exterior will lead to recovery; *Guizhi Tang* is suitable.
In *Taiyang* disease, if qi surges upward after purging, *Guizhi Tang* may be administered. If no upward surge occurs, it should not be given.
*Guizhi Tang* is fundamentally for resolving the muscles. If the pulse is floating and tight, with fever and no sweating, do not administer it. Remember this to avoid error.
For habitual drinkers, do not administer *Guizhi Tang*, as it will induce vomiting.
If vomiting occurs after taking *Guizhi Tang*, the patient will later vomit pus and blood.

**Cinnamon Twig Decoction** – Treats wind strike with a pulse that is floating in the yang and weak in the yin. A floating yang pulse indicates spontaneous heat, while a weak yin pulse indicates spontaneous sweating. There is aversion to wind with a rough sensation, aversion to cold with a chilly sensation, intermittent fever, nasal congestion, and dry heaves. The formula consists of:

**Cinnamon Twig (Guizhi), Peony (Shaoyao), and Fresh Ginger (Shengjiang)** – each three *liang*; **Licorice (Gancao)** – two *liang*; **Jujubes (Dazao)** – twelve pieces. Of these five ingredients, [missing character] chop the first three, slice the ginger, and split the jujubes. Boil the jujubes in seven *sheng* of water until soft, strain, then add the remaining ingredients. If the water is insufficient, add more, and simmer until gently boiling. Reduce to three *sheng*, then strain. Take one *sheng* three times daily; for children, adjust the dose as appropriate.

If slight sweating occurs soon after the first dose, slightly lengthen the interval between doses. If no sweating occurs, slightly shorten the interval to ensure the medicinal effect is continuous. Once sweating begins, protect the patient carefully as prescribed, taking special care to avoid wind. If the illness is severe, administer a dose at night. If one dose does not resolve the condition and the symptoms remain unchanged, repeat the dose as needed. Some patients may require two or three doses before sweating occurs and recovery follows. After taking the decoction, consume hot congee shortly thereafter to assist the medicinal effect.

**Ephedra Decoction (Mahuang Tang)** – Treats cold damage with headache, lumbar pain, generalized joint pain, fever, aversion to cold, absence of sweating, and panting. The formula consists of:
**Ephedra (Mahuang)** – three *liang*; **Cinnamon Heart (Guixin)** – two *liang*; **Licorice (Gancao)** – two *liang**; **Apricot Kernels (Xingren)** – seventy pieces (if panting is mild, use fifty). Of these four ingredients, [missing character] chop, then boil the ephedra in nine *sheng* of water, reducing by two *sheng*. Skim off the foam, add the remaining ingredients, and boil until two and a half *sheng* remain. Strain and take eight *ge*. Cover the patient to induce sweating.

**Major Blue Dragon Decoction (Da Qinglong Tang)** – Treats wind strike and cold damage with a floating, tight pulse, fever, aversion to cold, generalized pain, absence of sweating, and vexation. The formula consists of:
**Ephedra (Mahuang)** – six *liang*; **Cinnamon Heart (Guixin)** – two *liang*; **Licorice (Gancao)** – two *liang*; **Gypsum (Shigao)** – one piece the size of a chicken egg, crushed; **Fresh Ginger (Shengjiang)** – three *liang*; **Apricot Kernels (Xingren)** – forty pieces; **Jujubes (Dazao)** – twelve pieces. Of these seven ingredients, [missing character] chop, then boil the ephedra in nine *sheng* of water, skimming off the foam before adding the remaining ingredients. Boil until three *sheng* remain. Divide and take one *sheng* per dose, covering the patient thickly to induce profuse sweating. Apply warm powder to stop sweating; do not administer a second dose. If taken improperly, it may cause muscle twitching and jerking—this is a sign of reversal. If no sweating occurs, a second dose may be given.

**Yang Toxin Cimicifuga Decoction (Yangdu Shengma Tang)** – Treats cold damage that transforms into yang toxin within one or two days, or yang toxin arising after vomiting or purging from improper medication. Symptoms include heaviness of the body, lumbar and back pain, vexation and restlessness, delirious speech, or running about, seeing ghosts, vomiting blood, or diarrhea. The pulse is floating, large, and rapid; the face is red with a brocade-like rash; the throat is painful with expectoration of pus and blood. The condition is treatable within five days but becomes incurable by seven. The formula consists of:
**Cimicifuga (Shengma)** – half a *liang*; **Licorice (Gancao)** – half a *liang*; **Chinese Angelica (Danggui)** – six *zhu*; **Sichuan Pepper (Shujiao)** – six *zhu*; **Realgar (Xionghuang)** – six *zhu*; **Cinnamon Heart (Guixin)** – six *zhu*. Of these six ingredients, [missing character] chop, then boil in five *sheng* of water until two and a half *sheng* remain. Divide into three doses, taking one dose every time a person walks five *li*. Cover the hands and feet warmly; when the toxin is expelled, sweating will occur, and the condition will resolve. If unresolved, prepare and administer another dose; vomiting is also beneficial.

*Master Zhongjing’s* version omits **Cinnamon Heart** and includes **Turtle Shell (Biejia)** the size of a hand. The *Handbook of Prescriptions for Emergencies* and the *Thousand Golden Remedies* follow this version. The *Collection of Verified Remedies Ancient and Modern* includes **Gardenia (Zhizi)** – six *zhu* and **Turtle Shell (Biejia)** the size of a hand.

**Licorice Decoction for Yin Toxin** – treats cold damage that has just begun for one or two days and promptly congeals into yin toxin, or after taking medicine for six or seven days up to ten days, transforms into yin toxin. Symptoms include heaviness of the body, stiffness of the back, twisting pain in the abdomen, obstruction of the throat, toxin attacking the heart, hardness and tension below the heart, shortness of breath, counterflow retching, bluish lips and blackened face, reversal cold of the four limbs, and a pulse that is deep, fine, tight, and rapid. *Master Zhongjing* states this is the sign of yin toxin: the body feels as if beaten. It may be treated within five or six days, but by the seventh day, it cannot be cured.

**Ingredients:**
Licorice – half a *liang*
*Cimicifuga (Shengma)* – half a *liang*
*Chinese Angelica (Danggui)* – six *zhu*
*Sichuan Pepper (Shujiao)* – six *zhu*
*Turtle Shell (Biejia)* – one *liang*

Chop the five ingredients, then boil in five *sheng* of water until two and a half *sheng* remain. Divide into three doses, taking one dose every time a person walks five *li*. Cover warmly to induce sweating; the toxin should exit with the sweat, and recovery will follow. If no sweat appears, the condition will not resolve; prepare and administer another dose. *Master Zhongjing’s* version omits *Sichuan Pepper*.

---

**Yin Dawn Decoction** – treats cold damage with pain in the limbs and joints, internal cold with external heat, and deficiency vexation.

**Ingredients:**
*Peony (Shaoyao)* – two *liang*
Licorice – two *liang*
*Dried Ginger (Ganjiang)* – three *liang*
*Scutellaria (Huangqin)* – three *liang*
*Cinnamon Heart (Guixin)* – four *liang*
*Jujube (Dazao)* – fifteen pieces

Chop the six ingredients, then boil in one *dou* of water until five *sheng* remain. Strain and take one *sheng* warm, three times during the day and twice at night. Cover to induce slight sweating.

---

**Yang Dawn Decoction** – treats cold damage and wind strike with a floating pulse, alternating fever, sweating, aversion to wind, stiffness of the head and neck, nasal congestion, dry retching. *Cinnamon Twig Decoction (Guizhi Tang)* governs this; modifications for specific symptoms follow:

Boil in one *dou* of spring water until four *sheng* remain. Divide and take one *sheng* three times daily.

For spontaneous sweating, omit *Cinnamon Twig* and add one *Aconite (Fuzi)*.
For thirst, omit *Cinnamon* and add three *liang* of *Trichosanthes (Gualou)*.
For diarrhea, omit *Peony* and *Cinnamon*, and add three *lei* of *Dried Ginger* and one *Aconite*, blast-fried.
For palpitations below the heart, omit *Peony* and add four *liang* of *Poria (Fuling)*.
For deficiency taxation with abdominal urgency, use the standard *Yang Dawn Decoction*; when reduced to two *sheng*, add half a *jin* of *Maltose (Jiaoyi)* and divide into two doses.
If the pulse is floating and tight with fever, do not administer this formula.

---

**Six-Ingredient Decoction to Resolve the Muscles** – treats cold damage with fever and generalized pain.

**Ingredients:**
*Kudzu (Gegen)* – four *liang*
*Poria (Fuling)* – three *liang*
*Ephedra (Mahuang)*
*Oyster Shell (Muli)*
*Fresh Ginger (Shengjiang)* – each two *liang*
Licorice – one *liang*

Chop the six ingredients, then boil in eight *sheng* of water until two *sheng* remain. Divide into three doses; after the second dose, sweating will occur—once sweating is thorough, cease administration. The *Collection of Verified Remedies Ancient and Modern* omits *Fresh Ginger* and Licorice.

---

**Decoction to Resolve the Muscles** – treats cold damage and warm disease.

**Ingredients:**
*Kudzu* – four *liang*
*Ephedra* – three *liang*
*Scutellaria*
*Peony*
Licorice – each two *liang*
*Jujube* – twelve pieces

Chop the six ingredients, then boil in one *dou* of water until two *sheng* remain. Take one *sheng* three times daily. If unresolved after three or four days and the pulse remains floating, administer a double dose to induce sweating. If the pulse is deep and replete, administer *Fermented Soybean (Dandouchi) Pill* to precipitate.

The *Secret Records of Longevity* includes one *liang* of *Cinnamon Heart*.

---

**Formula for Cold Damage, Seasonal Qi, Warm Epidemic, Pain, High Fever, and Strong Pulse at the Onset (One or Two Days):**
*Cinnabar (Dansha)* – one *liang*, ground to powder, then boiled in one *dou* of water until one *sheng* remains. Take all at once and cover to induce sweating.

---

**Formula for Epidemic Qi with Cold Damage Unresolved Within Three Days:**
*Fermented Soybean (Haochi)* – one *sheng*, wrapped in silk
*Scallion (Congbai)*, chopped – one *sheng*
*Young Boy’s Urine* – three *sheng*

First stir-fry the *Fermented Soybean* and *Scallion* until well combined, then add the urine and boil until two *sheng* remain. Divide into two doses, taking slowly while covered to induce sweating. Divinely effective.

---

**Decoction with *Cimicifuga* to Resolve the Muscles** – treats seasonal qi unresolved after three or four days.

**Ingredients:**
*Cimicifuga*
*Peony*
*Gypsum (Shigao)*
*Ephedra*
Licorice – each one *liang*
*Apricot Kernel (Xingren)* – thirty pieces
*Cowrie Shell (Beichi)* – three pieces (one version uses *Fritillaria (Beimu)* – eighteen *zhu*)

Chop the seven ingredients, then boil in three *sheng* of water until one *sheng* remains. Take all at once, cover warmly to induce sweating, and recovery will follow.

---

**Kudzu and *Gentiana* Decoction** – treats cold damage unresolved after three or four days with generalized vexation and heat.

**Ingredients:**
*Kudzu* – eight *liang*
*Gentiana (Longdan)*
*Indigo (Daqing)* – each half a *liang*
*Cimicifuga*
*Gypsum*
*Solomon’s Seal (Weirui)* – each one *liang*
Licorice
*Cinnamon Heart*
*Peony*
*Scutellaria*
*Ephedra* – each two *liang*
*Fresh Ginger* – three *liang*

Chop the twelve ingredients, then boil *Kudzu* in one *dou* of water until eight *sheng* remain. Add the remaining ingredients and boil until three *sheng* remain. Divide into four doses, taking three during the day and one at night.

---

**Formula for Cold Damage After Four or Five Days with Headache, High Fever, Vexing Pain in the Four Limbs, and Inability to Eat:**
*Gardenia Seed (Zhiziren)*
*Coptis (Huanglian)*
*Phellodendron (Huangbo)* – each half a *liang*
*Fermented Soybean* – one *sheng*
*Scallion* – seven stalks

Chop the six ingredients, then boil the first four in eight *sheng* of water for six or seven boilings. Add *Scallion* and *Fermented Soybean*, and boil until three *sheng* remain. Take one *sheng* all at once, three times daily. After taking the decoction, cover warmly to induce sweating, then apply powder. Once sweating occurs, cease further doses; do not induce sweating again. If no sweat appears, administer another dose to induce sweating again. This formula has no contraindications and is especially suitable for the elderly and children. Divinely effective.

---

**Seven-Ingredient *Coptis* Decoction** – treats summer cold damage with vexing pain in the four limbs, fever, and a predilection for vexation, counterflow retching, propping fullness, and severe symptoms resembling demonic affliction. Cold and heat contend, causing the predilection for vexation.

**Ingredients:**
*Coptis*
*Poria*
*Scutellaria* – each eighteen *zhu*
*Peony*
*Kudzu* – each one *liang*
Licorice – one *liang* and six *zhu*
*Wheat (Xiaomai)* – three *ge*

Chop each ingredient, then boil in seven *sheng* of water until three *sheng* remain.

Serve cool, divided into three doses. If the patient cannot tolerate one *sheng*, administer gradually until the decoction’s effect settles, then allow rest. The medicinal power expels toxic *qi*; after taking the decoction, if there is heat in the chest or pain in the throat, all will resolve. The next day, boil another dose and administer as before. This decoction is non-toxic, merely clearing heat, descending *qi*, and calming the patient. For children, take one-third of the dose, boil in four *sheng* of water to yield two *sheng*, and administer gradually.

**Three-Spoonful Decoction** – treats cold damage and wind strike that remain unresolved from the third to the seventh or eighth day, with pain in the chest and rib-sides, counterflow cold in the four limbs, dry retching, inability to swallow even water or thin gruel, undigested food retained in the abdomen, and heavy discharge of blood in dozens of bowel movements.

**Ingredients:**
*Poria* – the size of a chicken egg
*Scutellaria* – three *liang*
*Ginseng* – three *liang*
*Trichosanthes root* – four *liang*
*Mirabilite*
*Dried rehmannia* – each one *sheng*
*Rhubarb*
*Ephedra*
*Calcitum* – each half a *jin*

Pound and sift the nine ingredients to blend evenly. Take three *fangcunbi* of the powder, boil in one *sheng* of water until it bubbles three times, then strain. Administer three times daily; cover to induce sweating, and recovery will follow. For severe cases, administer six or seven *bi*. **Five Fragrances Ephedra Decoction** – treats sudden swelling in cold damage, whether localized to the four limbs, chest, or back, presenting as vacuous swelling that appears inflated, or affecting the head, face, lips, mouth, and neck. In severe cases, swelling may concentrate on the outer calf, resembling an axle in size, yet without pain or redness. If the four limbs are affected, it may lead to impeded movement. This formula governs all such cases.

**Ingredients:**
*Musk* – half a *liang*
*Frankincense*
*Clove* – each one *liang*
*Aquilaria*
*Costus* – each two *liang*
*Ephedra*
*Saposhnikovia*
*Aralia*
*Large gentian*
*Solomon’s seal*
*Licorice* – each two *liang*
*Swallowwort*
*Immature bitter orange* – each two *liang*

Chop the thirteen ingredients, then boil in nine *sheng* of water until three *sheng* remain. Divide into three doses; after covering to induce sweating, apply *Stephania* ointment externally.

For cold damage persisting beyond three days, where previous formulas fail to resolve the condition and the pulse remains rapid, indicating that *yang qi* still lingers in the channels and network vessels without entering the viscera:

**Ingredients:**
*Cinnamon twig*
*Scutellaria*
*Licorice* – each two *liang*
*Cimicifuga*
*Kudzu*
*Fresh ginger* – each three *liang*
*Peony* – six *liang*
*Gypsum* – eight *liang*
*Gardenia* – fourteen pieces

Chop the nine ingredients, then boil in nine *sheng* of water until two *sheng* and seven *ge* remain. Divide into three doses, spaced at intervals of ten *li*. If sweating occurs after the first two doses, discontinue the third; if no sweat appears, take an additional dose, stopping once sweating begins. If still no sweat, the next day omit *gardenia*, add two *liang* of *ephedra*, increase water by two *sheng*, and proceed as before.

**Snow Decoction** – a formula for cold damage:

**Ingredients:**
*Ephedra* – ten *jin*
*Rhubarb* – one *jin* and twelve *liang* (golden-colored)
*Apricot kernel* – three *dou* and four *sheng*

Chop the three ingredients, then soak the *ephedra* in five *hu* and four *dou* of snow water in an east-facing cauldron for three nights. Add *rhubarb*, stir to blend, and boil with mulberry firewood until two *hu* of liquid remain. Strain, return the liquid to the cauldron, pound the *apricot kernels*, add to the liquid, and boil again until six or seven *dou* remain. Strain, place in a copper vessel, combine with three *dou* of snow water, and simmer while stirring until two *dou* and four *sheng* remain. When the decoction reaches a consistency suitable for forming pills, allow it to cool and congeal into pills the size of a bullet. For those afflicted, boil five *ge* of water until it bubbles three times, grind one pill into the water, and administer at an appropriate temperature to induce immediate sweating. If the condition persists, take another pill. Store the medicine tightly sealed to prevent leakage of *qi*.

*Sun Zhenren’s* *Essential Emergency Formulas from the Thousand Gold Pieces*, Volume Thirty, concludes here.

*Sun Zhenren’s* *Essential Emergency Formulas from the Thousand Gold Pieces*, Volume Thirty-One. Collated and corrected by Lin Yi, Gentleman for Court Service, Acting Vice Minister of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices, and Academician of the Imperial Archives, during the Song Dynasty.

**Cold Damage Remedies**

**Sixth Formula: Diaphoretic Pills**

**Divine Elixir Pill** – Treats cold damage with red, rough eyes, aversion to cold, fever, and body pain. Formula:
- *Aconite* (附子) 4 liang
- *Crow’s Head* (乌头) 4 liang
- *Ginseng* (人参) 5 liang
- *Poria* (茯苓) 5 liang
- *Pinellia* (半夏) 5 liang
- *Cinnabar* (朱砂) 1 liang

Grind the six ingredients into powder, form into honey pills, and color with true elixir. Take two pills the size of a soybean before meals, followed by fresh ginger decoction, three times daily. Shortly after, consume two *sheng* of hot congee, cover heavily, and cease when sweating occurs. If sweating does not occur or is insufficient to resolve the condition, repeat the dose as before. If sweating is adequate yet the condition persists, administer *Cassia Twig Decoction*. This medicine is highly toxic—those with heat should drink water, while those with cold should take warm fluids to counteract it.

For malaria, take two pills before the onset.

*The Essentials* uses *Asarum* (细辛) instead of *Ginseng* and includes one *Belamcanda* (射干) pill the size of a jujube, calling it *Red Pill*, which governs cold *qi* and counterflow reversal.

**Wheat Slave Pill** – Treats unresolved cold damage after five or six days, with heat in the chest, lockjaw, inability to speak, and desire for water, indicating deteriorated cold damage beyond medical aid, approaching death. If the patient’s heart remains slightly warm, use a stick to open the mouth and administer the medicine; recovery follows if the medicine is swallowed. Also called *Black Slave Pill* or *Water-Resolving Pill*. Formula:
- *Pot Soot* (釜底墨) 1 liang
- *Chimney Soot* (灶突墨) 1 liang
- *Beam Dust* (梁上墨) 1 liang
- *Wheat Slave* (麦奴) 1 liang
- *Scorch* (黄令) 1 liang
- *Rhubarb* (大黄) 1 liang
- *Mirabilite* (芒硝) 1 liang
- *Ephedra* (麻黄) 2 liang

Grind the eight ingredients into powder, form into honey pills the size of a bullet. Grind one pill in five *ge* of freshly drawn water, soak until dissolved, and administer. If the patient is thirsty, allow unrestricted water intake; if unwilling, compel them to drink. Shortly after taking the medicine, the patient will feel cold, followed by sweating and resolution. If no sweating occurs after the shadow moves five *chi*, repeat the dose as before, with no more than two or three administrations being optimal.

*Wheat Slave* refers to the black mold on wheat.

**Seventh Principle: Emetic Remedies**

**Guidelines** – The general rule states that in spring, emetics should be used sparingly; cease once the condition improves, without completing the full dose.

For conditions resembling *Cassia Twig Syndrome* but without headache or stiff neck, with a floating pulse at the inch position, fullness in the chest, and *qi* surging upward to the throat causing breathlessness—this indicates long-standing phlegm, suitable for emesis.

For various cold conditions in the chest, with oppression and pain, inability to eat, desire for pressure (which instead produces drool), and over ten bouts of diarrhea daily, if the patient’s pulse is slow and the inch pulse slightly slippery, emesis is appropriate; diarrhea will cease afterward.

For *Lesser Yin* disease where food is immediately vomited, with internal discomfort and inability to vomit despite the urge, emesis is suitable—undigested food in the upper passage should be expelled.

For cold counterflow in the hands and feet with intermittent pulse, guest *qi* in the chest causing fullness, vexation, and inability to eat due to chest congestion, emesis is appropriate.

**Melon Stalk Powder** – For conditions resembling *Cassia Twig Syndrome* but without headache or stiff neck, with a slightly floating inch pulse, chest fullness and hardness, and *qi* rushing upward to the throat causing breathlessness—this indicates cold in the chest, suitable for emesis. Formula:
- *Melon Stalk* (瓜蒂) 1 liang
- *Red Small Beans* (赤小豆) 1 liang

Grind the two ingredients and sift. Take one *qianbi* with one *ge* of fermented soybean, boil in seven *ge* of water to make a thin gruel, strain, and administer the liquid warm in one dose. If vomiting does not occur, gradually increase the dose until vomiting is induced.

*Zhang Wenzhong* administers it with three *ge* of plain hot water.

**Water-Inducing Powder** – Treats seasonal epidemic disease with burning heat, delirious speech, and erratic behavior. Formula:
- *Kansui* (甘遂) 0.5 liang
- *Angelica* (白芷) 2 liang

Grind the two ingredients and sift. Take one *fangcunbi* with water, then have the patient drink cold water until the abdomen is full, inducing vomiting; urine should turn red. Also called *Intestinal Flushing Decoction*, used for critical cases.

**False Hellebore Pill** – Treats cold damage where emesis is not induced. Formula:
- *False Hellebore* (藜芦) 1 liang
- *Aconite* (附子) 1 liang

Grind the two ingredients into powder, mix with honey into pills the size of lentils. For cold damage with loss of appetite, take two pills; increase if no effect is observed. Applicable from one to four days after onset. If no vomiting occurs after the shadow moves three *zhang*, consume hot congee to induce it.

**Wine and Gall Formula** – Treats warm disease or cold damage after three or four days, with chest discomfort and desire for emesis. Formula:
- *Pure Bitter Wine* (醇苦酒) 0.5 *sheng*
- *Pig’s Gallbladder* (猪胆) 1

Mix and drink fully; recovery follows vomiting.

**Alternative Formula** – Take 157 *Bi Lun* coins, boil in one *dou* of water until seven *sheng* remain, and administer in divided doses. Shortly after, boil the coins again in five *sheng* of water until one *sheng* remains, then add two *sheng* of water to make three *sheng*, remove the coins, and administer the liquid. The toxin will be expelled through vomiting, leading to recovery.

**Eighth Principle: Purgative Remedies**

**Guidelines and Formulas** – The general rule states that in autumn, purgatives should be used, with decoctions preferred over pills or powders; cease once the condition improves, without completing the full dose.

For cold damage with heat and lower abdominal fullness, where urination should be inhibited but is instead unobstructed, this indicates blood stasis—purgation is required, suitable for *Resistance-Current Pill*.

For *Greater Yang* disease with yellowing of the body, sunken and bound pulse, lower abdominal hardness and fullness, and inhibited urination—this indicates no blood stasis. If urination is unobstructed and the patient appears manic, this is a definitive blood condition, suitable for *Resistance-Awareness Decoction* for purgation.

For unresolved *Greater Yang* disease with heat binding in the bladder, where the patient appears manic, recovery follows spontaneous bleeding.

If the exterior syndrome remains unresolved, purgation should not yet be applied; first resolve the exterior. Once the exterior is resolved but the lower abdomen remains bound, purgation may then be applied.

In *Yang Brightness* disease with a slow pulse, though sweating occurs without aversion to cold, the body must feel heavy, with shortness of breath, abdominal fullness, panting, and tidal fever—this indicates the exterior is about to resolve, and purgation of the interior may proceed. If the hands and feet sweat profusely, the stool has already hardened, suitable for *Qi-Coordinating Decoction*. If sweating is copious with mild fever and aversion to cold, the exterior remains unresolved, and *Cinnamon Twig Decoction* governs it. If the fever is not tidal, *Qi-Coordinating Decoction* should not yet be given. If the abdomen is greatly distended and full without defecation, a small dose of *Qi-Coordinating Decoction* may be administered to gently harmonize the stomach qi, avoiding excessive purgation.

In *Yang Brightness* disease with tidal fever and slightly hardened stool, *Qi-Coordinating Decoction* may be given; if the stool is not hardened, it should not be administered. If there has been no defecation for six or seven days, fearing the presence of dry stool, the method to ascertain this is to administer a small dose of *Qi-Coordinating Decoction*. If there is passage of flatus, dry stool is present, and purgation may proceed; if no flatus is passed, this indicates hardness at the beginning and softness at the end, and purgation must not be applied—if forced, it will cause distension, fullness, and inability to eat. If the patient desires to drink water, this is a sign of recovery; if fever subsequently arises, the stool will surely harden again, and a small dose of *Qi-Coordinating Decoction* should be given to harmonize it. If no flatus is passed, purgation must be avoided.

In *Yang Brightness* syndrome where the patient is forgetful, there must be retained blood. The reason is that long-standing blood stasis causes forgetfulness. Though the stool may be hard, the stool will surely be black, suitable for *Resistance-Party Decoction* to purge it.

In *Yang Brightness* disease with fever and sweating, this is dispersion of heat, which cannot produce jaundice. But if only the head sweats while the body remains dry, the sweat stopping at the neck, with inhibited urination and thirst for fluids, this indicates stasis-heat in the interior, and the body will surely develop jaundice—purgation is suitable, with *Virgate Wormwood Decoction*. The formula appears in Scroll Ten.

In *Lesser Yin* disease of two or three days’ duration with dry mouth and throat, urgent purgation is required, suitable for *Qi-Coordinating Decoction*. In *Lesser Yin* disease of six or seven days’ duration with abdominal fullness and no defecation, urgent purgation is required, suitable for *Qi-Coordinating Decoction*.

Where there is repletion, there is delirious speech; where there is vacuity, there is *zheng*-voice. *Zheng*-voice is repetitive speech.

Fixed gaze, delirious speech, and panting with fullness indicate death; chronic diarrhea also indicates death.

In cold damage of four or five days’ duration with sunken pulse and panting fullness—sunken pulse indicates interior repletion—yet mistakenly inducing sweating causes fluids to escape, making defecation difficult. Exterior vacuity with interior repletion will eventually lead to delirious speech.

*Major Qi-Coordinating Decoction* governs intense heat with dry stool in the abdomen and delirious speech. The formula:
Four liang of rhubarb, eight liang of magnolia bark, five pieces of unripe bitter orange, three *ge* of mirabilite.

Grind the four ingredients, then decoct with one *dou* of water. First boil the magnolia bark and unripe bitter orange, reducing to five *sheng*; remove the dregs. Add the rhubarb and decoct to two *sheng*; remove the dregs. Add the mirabilite and boil briefly once or twice. Divide and administer in two doses; cease when rapid purgation occurs.

*Resistance-Subduing Pill* for blood descent. The formula:
Twenty leeches, twenty horseflies, twenty-two peach kernels, three liang of rhubarb.

Grind the four ingredients into powder, mix with honey, and form into four pills. Boil one pill in one *sheng* of water, reducing to seven *ge*, and administer in a single dose. Blood should descend within the time it takes for the pupils to move; if not, administer another dose.

*Resistance-Subduing Decoction* treats the same condition as above. The formula:
Thirty leeches, thirty horseflies, twenty-three peach kernels, three liang of rhubarb.

Grind the four ingredients, then decoct with five *sheng* of water, reducing to three *sheng*; remove the dregs. Administer one *sheng*; if no descent occurs, administer again.

**Decoction for Restoring Qi Formula:**
Five *zhi shi* (unripe bitter orange), half a *sheng* of *mang xiao* (mirabilite), four *liang* of rhubarb, two *liang* of licorice.

Crush the four ingredients, then decoct with five *sheng* of water, reducing to two *sheng*; remove the dregs. Adjust to a suitable temperature and divide into three doses. Administer one dose after the time it takes a person to walk five *li*; cease when purgation occurs. If no purgation occurs, administer the full dose.

**Fresh Rehmannia Decoction** treats febrile disease with heat, deficiency and emaciation, shortness of breath, fullness below the heart, retained food in the stomach, and constipation. The formula:
Three *jin* of fresh rehmannia, four *liang* of rhubarb, one *liang* of licorice, two *ge* of *mang xiao*, twenty jujubes.

Combine the five ingredients, pound thoroughly, and steam beneath five *sheng* of rice until done. Squeeze to extract the juice and divide into two doses.

**Major Bupleurum, Solomon’s Seal, and Anemarrhena Decoction** treats unresolved febrile disease after seven or eight days, taciturnity with vexation, dry stool in the abdomen, and delirious speech. The formula:
Half a *jin* of bupleurum, two *liang* each of Solomon’s seal, anemarrhena, rhubarb, and licorice, three *liang* each of ginseng, scutellaria, and peony, five *liang* of fresh ginger, half a *sheng* of pinellia.

Crush the ten ingredients, then decoct with one *dou* of water, reducing to three *sheng*; remove the dregs. Administer one *sheng* thrice daily; efficacy is achieved when purgation occurs. The *Collected Effective Remedies* version uses four *zhi shi* and omits peony.

**Formula for Febrile Disease with Headache, High Fever, and Pain in All Joints:**
Four *liang* each of bupleurum, gardenia seed, peony, and anemarrhena, three *liang* each of cimicifuga, scutellaria, *da qing* (isatis leaf), and apricot kernel, eight *liang* of gypsum, one *sheng* of fermented soybean.

Crush the ten ingredients, then decoct with nine *sheng* of water, reducing to two *sheng* and seven *ge*; divide and administer warm in three doses. If heat is severe, add four *liang* of rhubarb.

**Fermented Soybean Pill** treats febrile disease with retained fluids and undigested food. The formula:
One *sheng* of fermented soybean, three hundred *ba dou* (croton seed) with oil removed (now using two hundred), sixty-plus apricot kernels, four *liang* each of scutellaria, coptis, rhubarb, and ephedra, three *liang* each of *mang xiao* and *gan sui* (kansui root).

Grind the nine ingredients into powder, mix with honey, and form into pills the size of large soybeans. Administer two pills. If no purgation occurs, increase the dose.

**Cui's Yellow Plaintext Formula**

**Ninth Pulse and Symptom Pattern After Diaphoresis, Emesis, and Purgation**

**Moxibustion Method**
For *shanghan* that has resolved for half a day but recurs with vexing heat and a floating, rapid pulse, diaphoresis may again be applied; *Guizhi Decoction* is suitable. After diaphoresis, drinking water will invariably cause panting—this must be guarded against.

**Bamboo Leaf Decoction**
Treats vacuity vexation in the interior after diaphoresis, where purgation is contraindicated. The formula:
Two handfuls of bamboo leaf, half a *sheng* of pinellia, one *sheng* of ophiopogon, two *liang* each of ginseng and licorice, four *liang* of fresh ginger, one *jin* of gypsum.
Crush the seven ingredients, then decoct with one *dou* of water, reducing to six *sheng*; strain, add half a *sheng* of polished rice, and remove once the rice is cooked. Divide and administer one *sheng* thrice daily.
Zhang Wenzhong omits fresh ginger.

**Cinnamon Twice, Ephedra Once Decoction (#10)**
After profuse sweating from *Guizhi Decoction*, if the pulse is surging and large, administer *Guizhi Decoction* again. If the condition resembles malaria, recurring twice daily, and resolves with sweating, the formula is as follows:
One *liang* and seventeen *zhu* of cinnamon, sixteen *zhu* of ephedra, one *liang* and six *zhu* each of peony and fresh ginger, one *liang* and two *zhu* of licorice, sixteen apricot kernels, five jujubes.
Crush the seven ingredients, decoct ephedra in five *sheng* of water until it boils twice, skim off the foam, add the remaining ingredients, and reduce to two *sheng*. Adjust to a moderate temperature, divide, and administer in two doses to induce slight sweating.

**Minor Blue Dragon Decoction**
Treats *shanghan* with unresolved exterior and water-qi below the heart, causing dry retching, fever, cough, or thirst, diarrhea, hiccup, inhibited urination with lower abdominal fullness, or panting. The formula:
Three *liang* each of cinnamon twig, ephedra, licorice, dried ginger, peony, and asarum; half a *sheng* each of schisandra and pinellia.
Crush the eight ingredients, decoct ephedra in one *dou* of water, reducing by two *sheng*; skim off the foam, add the remaining ingredients, and reduce to three *sheng*. Divide into three doses, administering at intervals of approximately ten *li*.
If thirst is present, remove pinellia and add three *liang* of trichosanthes; if mild diarrhea occurs, remove ephedra and add *yuanhua* (the size of a chicken egg, stir-fried until red); if hiccup is present, add one piece of aconite; if urination is inhibited with lower abdominal fullness, remove ephedra and add four *liang* of poria; if panting is present, remove ephedra and add half a *sheng* of apricot kernels. Repeated use yields divine efficacy.

**Four Agents Licorice Decoction**
Treats *shanghan* with panting after diaphoresis and sweating, where no high fever is present. The formula:
Two *liang* of licorice, four *liang* of ephedra, half a *jin* of gypsum, fifty apricot kernels.
Crush the four ingredients, decoct ephedra in seven *sheng* of water, reducing by two *sheng*; add the remaining ingredients and reduce to three *sheng*. Divide and administer over three days.

**Gardenia Decoction**
Treats vexing heat with chest oppression and qi counterflow assailing the heart after diaphoresis or purgation. The formula:
Fourteen gardenia fruits, four *ge* of fermented soybean (wrapped in silk).
Decoct gardenia in four *sheng* of water, reducing to two and a half *sheng*; add fermented soybean and reduce to one and a half *sheng*. Divide into two doses, administering one warm. If vomiting occurs, discontinue the second dose.

**Magnolia Decoction**
Treats abdominal distention and fullness after diaphoresis. The formula:
Half a *liang* of magnolia bark, one *liang* of ginseng, two *liang* of licorice, eight *liang* of fresh ginger, half a *sheng* of pinellia.
Crush the five ingredients, decoct in one *dou* of water, reducing to three *sheng*. Divide into three doses.

**Black Warrior Decoction**
Treats *taiyang* disease with unresolved fever after diaphoresis, accompanied by palpitations below the heart, dizziness, generalized twitching, and a sensation of trembling as if about to collapse. The formula:
Three *liang* each of poria, peony, and fresh ginger; two *liang* of atractylodes; one piece of aconite.
Crush the five ingredients, decoct in eight *sheng* of water, reducing to three *sheng*. Administer seven *ge* warm.

**Pueraria and Coptis Decoction**
Treats *taiyang* disease improperly purged, leading to incessant diarrhea, a hasty pulse, unresolved exterior, panting, and sweating. The formula:
Half a *jin* of pueraria, three *liang* each of coptis and scutellaria, two *liang* of licorice.
Crush the four ingredients, decoct pueraria in eight *sheng* of water, reducing by two *sheng*; add the remaining ingredients and reduce to two *sheng*. Strain and divide into two doses.

**Poria Decoction**
Treats *shanghan* with counterflow fullness below the heart, qi surging into the chest, dizziness upon rising, a sunken and tight pulse, and trembling after diaphoresis. The formula:
Four *liang* of poria, three *liang* each of atractylodes and cinnamon twig, two *liang* of licorice.
Crush the four ingredients, decoct in six *sheng* of water, reducing to three *sheng*. Strain and divide into three doses.

When the *cunkou* pulse is floating but sunken at the *guan*, this indicates chest bind. (*Chao Yuanfang’s* *General Treatise on the Origins and Symptoms of Diseases* renders it "sunken and fine.")

When *shanghan* arises in yang but is improperly purged, heat enters and forms chest bind.

**Major Chest Bind Pill**
Treats chest bind with stiff nape resembling soft tetany; purgation brings resolution. The formula:
Eight *liang* of rhubarb, five *ge* each of *mang xiao*, apricot kernels, and *tingli* seed.
Pound and sift rhubarb and *tingli* seed; grind the remaining two ingredients separately into a paste. Combine the powders, form into a pill the size of a bullet, and take with one *qianbi* of kansui powder, two *ge* of white honey, and one *sheng* of water, reducing to eight *ge*. Administer warm in one dose; if no purgation occurs, repeat until efficacy is achieved.

For *shanghan* of six or seven days with chest bind, heat repletion, a sunken and tight pulse, pain below the heart, and hardness upon pressure, *Major Chest Bind Decoction* is suitable.

**Taiyang Disease with Repeated Sweating and Purging**
In *Taiyang* disease, where sweating is induced repeatedly followed by purgation, with no bowel movement for five or six days, dry tongue and thirst, slight tidal fever at dusk, and severe vexation in the chest—extending from below the heart to the lower abdomen with hardness, fullness, and pain so intense it cannot be touched—*Major Chest Bind Decoction* is suitable. The formula:
One *qianbi* of kansui powder, six *liang* of sliced rhubarb, one *sheng* of *mang xiao*.
Boil the three ingredients in six *sheng* of water; first decoct rhubarb to obtain two *sheng*, discard the dregs, then add *mang xiao* and bring to a single boil before adding kansui.
Divide and administer in two doses; if one dose induces prompt purgation, discontinue the second.

**Licorice Heart-Draining Decoction**
Treats *shanghan* or wind-strike where the physician erroneously purges, causing the patient to have diarrhea dozens of times daily with undigested food, abdominal thunderous rumbling, and hardness, fullness, and binding below the heart; dry retching, vexation, and inability to find ease.
If hardness below the heart is observed and the condition is mistakenly deemed unresolved, further purgation will exacerbate the binding. This is not due to bound heat but rather stomach vacuity with counterflow of guest qi. The formula:
Four *liang* of licorice, three *liang* each of scutellaria and dried ginger, one *liang* of coptis, half a *sheng* of pinellia, and twelve *da zao*.
Crush the six ingredients, decoct in one *dou* of water to obtain six *sheng*, and discard the dregs.
Divide and administer one *sheng* three times daily. Adding three *liang* of ginseng is also appropriate.

**Fresh Ginger Heart-Draining Decoction**
Treats *shanghan* after sweating where the stomach is disharmonious, with hardness and binding below the heart, dry belching with foul food odor, water qi beneath the rib-sides, abdominal thunderous rumbling, and diarrhea. The formula:
Four *liang* of fresh ginger, three *liang* each of licorice, ginseng, and scutellaria, one *liang* each of dried ginger and coptis, half a *sheng* of pinellia, and twelve *da zao*.
Crush the eight ingredients, decoct in one *dou* of water to obtain six *sheng*, and discard the dregs.
Divide and administer one *sheng* three times daily.

**White Tiger Decoction**
Treats *shanghan* after vomiting and purging that remains unresolved for seven or eight days, with bound heat in the interior, heat in both exterior and interior, intermittent aversion to wind, great thirst, dry tongue with vexation, and desire to drink several *sheng* of water. The formula:
One *sheng* of gypsum, six *liang* of anemarrhena, two *liang* of licorice, and six *ge* of non-glutinous rice.
Crush the four ingredients, decoct in one *dou* of water until the rice is cooked, and discard the dregs.
Divide and administer one *sheng* three times daily.
Those with blood loss or vacuity should not take *White Tiger Decoction*. From the start of summer until the start of autumn, it may be used; after the start of autumn, it should not be administered. In the third month of spring, when it is still cold, it should also not be given, as it may induce vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain.

For *shanghan* without great heat but with dry mouth, thirst, vexation, and slight aversion to cold in the back, *White Tiger Decoction* is suitable.
For *shanghan* with a floating pulse, fever, and absence of sweating where the exterior is unresolved, *White Tiger Decoction* should not be given.
For thirst with desire to drink water and absence of exterior signs, *White Tiger Decoction* is suitable.
For thirst with desire to drink water, dry mouth, and dry tongue, *White Tiger Decoction* is also suitable.

**Celosia Seed Pill**
Treats bound heat in the interior after *shanghan* with vexation and thirst. The formula:
Five *liang* of celosia seeds, one *liang* each of scutellaria, trichosanthes root, and sophora, two *liang* of phellodendron, and three *liang* each of gentian, gardenia seeds, and coptis.
Grind the eight ingredients into powder, form into honey pills the size of firmiana seeds.
Take seven pills after meals three times daily; if no effect, gradually increase the dose.
One version states to blend smoothly into pills.

**Indigo Decoction**
Treats *shanghan* or heat disease lasting ten days or more where sweating fails to resolve the condition, as well as after vomiting and purging where various heat signs persist, incessant diarrhea, or maculae. The formula:
Four *liang* of indigo, two *liang* each of licorice and donkey-hide gelatin, and one *sheng* of fermented soybean.
Crush the four ingredients, decoct in eight *sheng* of water to obtain three *sheng*, discard the dregs, boil three times, remove the fermented soybean, and add donkey-hide gelatin to melt.
Administer one *sheng* in a single dose three times daily. When the decoction is nearly finished, prepare more to ensure a continuous supply. Those with thirst should drink.
It solely clears heat, stops vomiting and diarrhea, and is non-toxic.
The *Shenshi* version treats taxation relapse; the *Zhouhou* includes three *liang* of halloysite, and the *Huqia* and *Jiyan* versions are the same.

**Post-*Shanghan* Remnant Heat Formula**
Treats unresolved *shanghan* with morning and evening fever resembling malaria. The formula:
Two *liang* of anemarrhena, one *liang* each of ephedra, licorice, peony, scutellaria, and cinnamon twig.
Crush the six ingredients, decoct in seven *sheng* of water to obtain two and a half *sheng*.
Administer five *ge* three times daily, cover warmly to induce slight sweating.
If vexation prevents sleep and the patient desires water, allow gradual sipping to harmonize the stomach, and recovery will follow.

The masters of Jiangnan secretly withhold the essential formulas of Zhongjing and do not transmit them.

**Moxibustion Method**
At the onset of illness, if there is initial headache, aversion to cold and heat, or a sensation of chilliness prompting the desire for fire, or stiffness in the waist and back with a flushed face resembling intoxication—this is the first or second day of *shanghan*. Apply strong fire moxibustion to three points below the heart:
First point: one *cun* below the heart, named *Juque*.
Second point: two *cun* below the heart, named *Shangguan*.
Third point: three *cun* below the heart, named *Weiguan*.
Moxa each point with fifty cones.
However, as people vary in size, the *cun* measurements may differ; using a string to measure according to individual length is best. Place the string at the tip of the xiphoid process (named *Jiuwei*), extend it to the navel, fold it in half, and the end marks *Weiguan*; fold it in half again, divide into two equal parts, and measure one part upward from *Weiguan* to locate *Shangguan*, then measure another part upward to locate *Juque*.
Adults may receive fifty cones; children may receive three, adjusted according to age.

The size of the moxa cones should be determined by discretion. If the patient has been ill for three or four days or more, first apply twenty cones of moxibustion to the chest.

Measure a string from the center of the nose straight up to the hairline, fold it in half, and cut off one portion. Then, starting from the hairline, enter into the hair and moxa the end of the string, naming this point *Tiancong*. Also moxa both temples (□), both *Fengchi* points, and the *Ganshu* point with one hundred cones. Apply twenty cones to the remaining points, and moxa *Taichong* with thirty cones—this is divinely effective.

**On Cold Damage Formulas**
**Miscellaneous Treatments for Cold Damage, Chapter One**
**Moxibustion Methods**

It is said: To eliminate heat and resolve toxins, nothing surpasses bitter and sour substances. Thus, one often employs *ku shen* (苦参), *qing xiang* (青葙), mugwort (*ai*, 艾), gardenia (*zhi zi*, 栀子), *ting li* (葶苈), bitter wine, and dark plum (*wu mei*, 乌梅)—these are the essentials. When heat is severe, it cannot be resolved without bitter and sour substances. If heat lingers within the body and is not treated in time, or if treatment employs no such bitter and sour medicines, this is like extinguishing fire without water—escape is impossible.

It is further said: Many current treatments rely on acrid and sweet ingredients, such as ginger, cinnamon, and ginseng, all of which are costly and difficult to obtain. Often, one must travel far to seek them, thus losing the opportunity for timely treatment. Yet *ku shen*, *qing xiang*, *ting li*, and mugwort are found everywhere, and their efficacy in eliminating heat and resolving toxins surpasses that of expensive medicines. These may be used repeatedly, before or after other treatments.

For internal heat disorders, one need not adhere strictly to the sequence of medicines. Simply administer *qing xiang*, *ku shen*, mugwort, and bitter wine, adjusting the intervals slightly—none will fail to resolve the condition.

Bian Que said: If the illness lies in the interstices (*cou li*, 腠理), it may be reached by decoctions and compresses; if in the blood vessels, by acupuncture and stone needles; if in the bone marrow, there is nothing to be done. Yet some physicians claim one should wait until the disease has fully developed before abruptly removing it—this is folly. One should instruct one’s household and retainers in advance, explaining this principle so that those who fall ill may understand its importance.

**Formula for Treating Warm-Qi Disease on the Verge of Death:**
One *liang* of *ku shen*, simmered in two *sheng* of wine until reduced to one *sheng*. Drink it all at once. Vomiting will expel all toxic illnesses. Cover the patient to induce sweating—all will be cured.

Zhang Wenzhong and *Zhouhou Fang* state: For death from heat-toxin qi, the "Breaking the Coffin Thousand-Gold Decoction" is used. The *Ku Shen Decoction* for treating heat illness of five or six days or more is as follows:
Three *liang* of *ku shen*
Two *liang* of *huang qin* (黄苓)
Eight *liang* of fresh *di huang* (生地黄)
Pound the three ingredients, then decoct in eight *sheng* of water until reduced to two *sheng*. Take one *sheng* at an appropriate temperature, twice daily.

**Frozen Snow Decoction** for treating epidemic toxic illness of seven or eight days, with heat accumulating in the chest, vexation, and near-death:
One *sheng* of *yuan hua* (芫花), decocted in three *sheng* of water until reduced to one and a half *sheng*. Soak an old cloth in the liquid and apply thinly to the chest. No more than three applications will eliminate the heat. Warm the limbs to prevent counterflow cold (*jue ni*, 厥逆).

**Gua Lou Decoction** for treating cold damage or wind strike of five or six days or more, with only chest vexation and dry retching:
One *gua lou* fruit (栝蒌实)
Three *liang* each of *huang qin* and licorice (*gan cao*, 甘草)
Four *liang* of fresh ginger
Twelve *da zao* (大枣)
Half a *jin* of *chai hu* (柴胡)
Pound the six ingredients, then decoct in one *dou* and two *sheng* of water until reduced to five *sheng*. Strain and discard the dregs. Take one *sheng* at an appropriate temperature, three times daily.

**Reed Root Drink** for treating post-cold damage retching, hiccups, counterflow stomach, and inability to eat:
One *sheng* each of sliced fresh reed root (*lu gen*, 芦根) and green bamboo shavings (*qing zhu ru*, 青竹茹)
Three *ge* of polished rice (*jing mi*, 粳米)
Three *liang* of fresh ginger
Decoct two *zhi* of *qian li xie di* (千里鞋底) in seven *sheng* of water until reduced to five *sheng*. Strain the liquid, add the remaining ingredients, and decoct until reduced to two and a half *sheng*. Drink as desired. If not cured, prepare again until recovery.

**Formula for Treating Post-Cold Damage Retching and Hiccups:**
Three *liang* of *tong cao* (通草)
One *sheng* of sliced fresh reed root
One *liang* of tangerine peel (*ju pi*, 橘皮)
Three *ge* of polished rice
Pound the four ingredients, then decoct in five *sheng* of water until reduced to two *sheng*. Drink gradually as desired. If not cured, prepare again until recovery ceases.

**Formula for Treating Post-Cold Damage Debility, Qi Deficiency, and Vomiting:**
One *sheng* each of gypsum (*shi gao*, 石膏), *mai men dong* (麦门冬), and *ban xia* (半夏)
Two handfuls of bamboo leaves (*zhu ye*, 竹叶)
Two *liang* of ginseng (*ren shen*, 人参)
Pound the five ingredients, then decoct in one *dou* of water until reduced to six *sheng*. Strain, add one *sheng* of polished rice, and cook until the rice is done. Take one *sheng* three times daily.
One variant adds five *liang* of fresh ginger. This is precisely Master Zhang Zhongjing’s *Zhu Ye Decoction*, which appears in the earlier chapter on post-sweating treatments, though it omits licorice and specifies no dosage.

**Formula for Treating Heat Toxin Attacking the Hands and Feet, with Redness, Swelling, Burning Heat, and Pain Threatening to Sever Them:**
Boil horse or sheep dung to make a juice, and soak the affected area three times daily.
**Alternate Formula:** Decoct *hu zhang* root (*hu zhang gen*, 虎杖根) to an appropriate temperature and soak the hands and feet, stopping one *chi* above the ankles.
**Alternate Formula:** Soak in thick rice-straw ash juice (*dao nong hui zhi*, 稻秾灰汁).
**Alternate Formula:** Decoct *ku shen* in good wine and soak the affected area.
**Alternate Formula:** Mix lard with sheep dung and apply—this is also effective.
**Alternate Formula:** Extract juice from *chang si cao* (常思草) and soak the affected area.

**Cang'er (also known as *Cang'er*).**

**Lou Lu Lian Qiao Decoction** for treating seasonal epidemic heat toxin transforming into red carbuncles and deep-rooted boils, as well as toxic heat rashes with redness, swelling, and pain, or for treating corneal opacity:
*Lou lu* (漏芦) 1 *liang*
*Lian qiao* (连翘) 1 *liang*
*Huang qin* (黄芩) 1 *liang*
*Ma huang* (麻黄) 1 *liang*
*Bai zhu* (白术) 1 *liang*
*Sheng ma* (升麻) 1 *liang*
*Gan cao* (甘草) 1 *liang*
*Zhi shi* (枳实) 3 *liang*
*Da huang* (大黄) 3 *liang*

Grind the nine ingredients, then decoct in nine *sheng* of water until reduced to three *sheng*. Divide into three doses, taking each after the time it takes a person to walk five *li* has passed. For severe heat, add two *liang* of *mang xiao*.

**Pig Bile Decoction** for treating cold damage with rashes appearing on the fifth or sixth day:
Pig bile 3 *ge*
Vinegar 3 *ge*
Chicken egg 1

Combine the three ingredients and boil three times to a boil. Robust patients should consume the entire dose; weaker patients should boil six or seven times to a boil and divide into two doses. Recovery follows sweating.

**Formula for Treating Seasonal Epidemic Heat Disease with Pox in Humans and Livestock:**
Boil *shu rang* (黍禳) to make a thick juice and wash the affected area. (Note: If only one stalk of *ji rang* (穄禳) is used, the condition will not resolve.) If the sores turn black, crush garlic and apply as a poultice.

**Alternate Formula:** Boil *yun tai* (芸薹) and wash the affected area.

**Formula for Treating Pox Following Heat Disease:**
Decoct three *liang* of *huang lian* in two *sheng* of water until reduced to eight *ge*, then consume in one dose.

**Alternate Formula:** Take a piece of genuine Persian *qing dai* the size of a jujube and administer with water to cure.

**Alternate Formula:** Decoct two *liang* of *qing mu xiang* in three *sheng* of water until reduced to one *sheng*, then consume in one dose to recover.

**Alternate Formula:** For red or black eruptions resembling scabies or "fire sores," decoct sheep fat and apply as a salve.

**Alternate Formula:** Mix powdered red beans with egg white and apply.

**Alternate Formula:** Wipe the sores with a cloth used during a woman’s menstruation.

**Alternate Formula:** For affected children, mix menstrual blood with water and bathe them.

**Alternate Formula:** Moxibustion: Apply three cones to the tip of the wrist bone (*yanzi gu*)—left for males, right for females.

**Mu Xiang Decoction** for treating restless pain from sores:
*Qing mu xiang* (青木香) 2 *liang*
*Xun lu xiang* (熏陆香) 1 *liang*
*Fan shi* (矾石) 1 *liang*
*Ding xiang* (丁香) 1 *liang*
*She xiang* (麝香) ½ *liang*

Grind the five ingredients, then decoct in four *sheng* of water until reduced to one and a half *sheng*. Divide into two doses. For severe heat toxin, add one *liang* of *xi jiao*; if unavailable, substitute with *sheng ma*. For milder cases, omit *fan shi*. Highly effective.

**Alternate Formula:** Mix *mang xiao* with pig bile and apply without disturbance. Scabs will fall off without scarring; afterward, lying on yellow earth powder is beneficial.

For this disease, if urination is difficult and bloody, internal damage is present; if sores are black and crusted without pus, the condition is fatal and untreatable.

**Formula for Treating Internal Outbreaks of Severe Sores:**
Vinegar 4 *ge*
Large pig bile 1

Combine and boil three times to a boil. Consume one *ge* five times daily. Effective.

**Formula for Treating Pox at the Onset of Symptoms:**
Decoct five *liang* of *da huang* and consume to cure.

**Formula for Treating Seasonal Epidemic Sores:**
Apply fine honey over the entire body on the sores. Alternatively, decoct *sheng ma* with honey and apply frequently, while also consuming it regularly.

**Formula for Treating Nosebleed from Cold Damage (due to residual heat in the lungs, causing unceasing upward flow of blood):**
*Mu li* (牡蛎) 2½ *liang*
*Shi gao* (石膏) 1 *liang* 6 *zhu*

Grind the two ingredients into a fine powder.

Take with wine, one *fangcun* spoonful, three to four times daily. Alternatively, form into honey pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Used to treat cases where, after recovery from a major illness, minor exertion causes nosebleed.

**Formula for Treating Sore Throat with Blockage in Cold Damage or Heat Disease:**
Fresh *wu shan* (乌扇, *Belamcanda chinensis*) 1 *jin*, sliced
Lard 1 *jin*

Combine the two ingredients and decoct. Once the medicine is prepared, remove the dregs and take a portion the size of half a chicken egg. Wrap it in thin silk, insert it into the throat, and gradually swallow it to cure.

**Alternative Formula:**
*Sheng ma* (升麻) 3 *liang*
*Shao yao* (芍药) 3 *liang*
*Ling yang jiao* (羚羊角) 3 *liang*
*Tong cao* (通草) 4 *liang*
*She gan* (射干) 2 *liang*
Fresh *lu gen* (芦根), sliced, 1 *sheng*

Chop the six ingredients, then decoct in seven *sheng* of water until two and a half *sheng* remain. Divide into two doses.

**Decoction for Heat Disease with Bitter Taste in the Mouth, Downward Qi Movement to Eliminate Heat, and Throat Wheezing:**
*Shi gao* (石膏) ½ *sheng*
Honey 1 *sheng*

First decoct the *shi gao* in three *sheng* of water until two *sheng* remain. Then add honey and decoct again until it reaches the consistency of malt sugar. Hold a portion the size of a jujube pit in the mouth, and continue doing so until finished. Highly effective.

**Formula for Dry Mouth with Frequent Spitting and Sore Throat Following Cold Damage or Heat Disease:**
Large jujubes 20 pieces
*Wu mei* (乌梅) 10 pieces

Pound the two ingredients together and mix with honey. Hold a portion the size of an apricot pit in the mouth, swallowing the juice. Highly effective.

**Yu Yu Gen Decoction:**
For cases of Cold Damage where, after taking decoctions, unceasing diarrhea occurs with hardness and fullness below the heart, and where administering *Xie Xin Tang* followed by other purgative medicines fails to stop the diarrhea, and where *Li Zhong* (理中) exacerbates the condition:

*Li Zhong* treats the middle burner, but this diarrhea originates in the lower burner. Treatment formula:
*Yu yu gen* (禹余根) 1 *jin*
*Chi shi zhi* (赤石脂) 1 *jin*, crushed

Decoct the two ingredients in six *sheng* of water until two *sheng* remain. Divide into three doses. If the condition persists, promote urination.

**Formula for Treating Post-Cold Damage Diarrhea with Pus and Blood:**
*E jiao* (阿胶) 1 *liang*
*Huang bo* (黄檗) 2 *liang*
*Huang lian* (黄连) 4 *liang*
*Zhi zi* (栀子) 14 pieces

Chop the four ingredients, then decoct in six *sheng* of water until one *sheng* remains. Remove the dregs, add *e jiao*, and decoct further until dissolved. Divide into three doses.
*Note: The* Jia Yi Fang *omits* huang bo *and includes* huang qin *(黄芩).*

**Formula for Treating Red and White Pus-like Diarrhea (in children, fatal within three days; caused by* gu *worms in the lower body):**
*She xiang* (麝香)
*Fan shi* (矾石)
*Ba dou* (巴豆)
*Fu zi* (附子)
*Zhen zhu* (真珠)
*Xiong huang* (雄黄), equal parts each

Grind the six ingredients together. Take a mulberry twig the length of an arrow shaft (three *cun*), wrap two *cun* of its tip with silk, moisten the silk with saliva, spread the medicine onto it, and insert it into the anus. Replace after half a day, twice daily. Divinely effective.

**Ma Huang Sheng Ma Decoction:**
For treating Cold Damage six or seven days after the patient has undergone major purgation, presenting with deep and slow pulse, cold extremities, absence of lower-body pulse, sore throat, spitting of pus and blood, and unceasing diarrhea—considered difficult to treat:

*Ma huang* (麻黄)
*Zhi mu* (知母)
*Wei rui* (also written as *chang pu*, 菖蒲)
*Huang qin* (黄芩) 3 *liang* each
*Sheng ma* (升麻)
*Shao yao* (芍药)
*Dang gui* (当归)
*Gan jiang* (乾姜)
*Shi gao* (石膏)
*Fu ling* (茯苓)
*Bai zhu* (白术)
*Gui xin* (桂心)
*Gan cao* (甘草)
*Mai men dong* (麦门冬) 2 *liang* each

Chop the fourteen ingredients, then decoct in one *dou* of water. First boil the *ma huang*, reducing the liquid by two *sheng* and skimming off the foam. Add the remaining ingredients and decoct until three *sheng* remain. Divide into three doses, consuming one *sheng* each time to induce mild sweating for recovery.

**Formula for Treating Warm Toxin and Cold Damage with Internal Deficiency, External Heat Attacking the Stomach, Discharge of Yellow-Red Fluid or Putrid Flesh, Red Dysentery, Abdominal Pain from Latent Qi, and Various Heat Toxins:**
*Zhi zi* (栀子) 14 pieces
*Chi* (豉) 1 *sheng*
*Xie bai* (薤白) 1 handful

Decoct the three ingredients in four *sheng* of water. First boil the *zhi zi* and *xie bai* until cooked, then add the *chi* and decoct until two and a half *sheng* remain. Divide into three doses, consuming frequently until cured.

**Formula for Treating Post-Illness Deficiency Swelling:**
*Chi* (豉) 5 *sheng*
Pure wine 1 *dou*

Boil three times to a boil, then consume while hot in one dose.

For those intolerant to wine, consume according to tolerance and cover to induce sweating.

**Formula for Treating Unremitting Sweating:**
Slice three *jin* of *di huang* (地黄), decoct in one *dou* of water until three *sheng* remain. Divide into three doses.

**Alternative Formula:**
Prepare a drink from *bai zhu* (白术) leaves and consume.

**Alternative Formula:**
Take one *fangcun bi* of *bai zhu* powder with water.

**Formula for Sudden Onset of Unremitting Sweating:**
Consume ox or sheep fat with warm wine to recover.

**Alternative Formula:**
Consuming *shi* (#10) also stops sweating.

**Formula for Treating Night Sweats and Spontaneous Sweating:**
Decoct forty-nine *jiu gen* (韭根) in two *sheng* of water until one *sheng* remains. Consume in one dose.

**Alternative Formula:**
Steep one *sheng* of *chi* (豉) in two *sheng* of wine for three days. If not cured, prepare and consume again; sweating will cease after no more than three doses.

**Alternative Formula:**
Burn the edge of a deceased person’s mat, boil the ashes to make a decoction, and bathe the body to cure.

**Formula to Stop Sweating:**
*Du zhong* (杜仲)
*Mu li* (牡蛎) equal parts

Grind the two ingredients into powder. Before retiring at night, take five *qian bi* with water.

**Alternative Formula:**
*Mu li* (牡蛎)
*Lei wan* (雷丸)
*Ma huang gen* (麻黄根) three *liang* each
*Gan jiang* (乾姜)
*Gan cao* (甘草) one *liang* each
Rice powder two *sheng*

Grind the six ingredients into powder and apply to sweating areas.

**Mu Li Powder for Treating Night Sweats and Wind-Deficiency Headache:**
*Mu li* (牡蛎)
*Bai zhu* (白术)
*Fang feng* (防风) three *liang* each

Grind the three ingredients into powder. Take one *fangcun bi* with wine, twice daily. This formula stops all types of sweating; consuming it for three days will cure all cases of excessive sweating.
