**Formulas for Cold Damage**
**Second Discourse on Taxation Relapse**
**Dietary Prohibitions**
**Formulas**

**Discourse on Dietary Prohibitions**

It is said: In all cases of febrile disease newly recovered or following major illness, consuming pork, sheep’s blood, fatty fish, greasy foods, or the like will invariably lead to severe diarrhea, which physicians cannot cure and will surely result in death. If one eats pastries, glutinous millet, maltose sweets, raw or roasted meats, jujubes, chestnuts, preserved fruits, dried meats, or other hard, indigestible foods, the stomach qi remains weak and unable to digest them, inevitably causing renewed heat bind. If purgatives are then administered, the stomach qi becomes cold and vacuous, and severe diarrhea will be uncontrollable. Not purging leads to death, while purging brings peril—both are difficult to remedy. Many die after febrile or major illness due to such causes; one cannot be too cautious.

After recent recovery from illness, one should only consume thin rice porridge, eating sparingly to maintain slight hunger and carefully avoiding fullness. No other foods should be taken, even if craved—do not yield to such desires. As days pass, one may gradually introduce white porridge with mutton, broths, pheasant, rabbit, or venison, but pork and dog meat must not be eaten.

After recent recovery, one should rest quietly and avoid rising early to wash the face or comb the hair. Not only does this strain the body, but excessive speech, mental exertion, or emotional agitation will also cause relapse. Thus, when Attendant Officer Gu Zi-xian had recovered from illness but remained weak, he visited Hua Fu for pulse diagnosis. Hua Fu said: “Though recovered, you are still vacuous and not fully restored. Your yang qi is insufficient—take care not to overexert. Ordinary labor is tolerable, but sexual activity will be fatal, causing the tongue to protrude several inches.” When his wife, having heard of his recovery, traveled over a hundred *li* to visit him and they engaged in intercourse after a night’s rest, he developed fever and lockjaw three days later, and died with his tongue protruding several inches.

If one engages in sexual activity before a hundred days have passed after recent recovery from illness, when qi and strength have not yet returned to normal, death will almost certainly follow. There was a scholar named Gai Zheng who, sixty days after recovering from illness, had regained enough strength to hunt, but died after intercourse, vomiting saliva. Engaging in sexual activity after febrile illness is called *yin-yang exchange disease*, which is difficult to treat and often fatal.

Recently, a certain official had a mild case of cold damage. Ten days after recovery, he was able to ride a horse, believing himself fully restored. After intercourse, he developed acute lower abdominal pain, limb spasms, and died.

If one eats any meat or wheat-based foods within five days of recovery from seasonal illness, the disease will relapse, causing severe distress. If one drinks wine or eats Chinese chives after recent recovery from seasonal illness, the disease will recur. If one eats raw fish with vinegar after recent recovery from seasonal illness, diarrhea will be unstoppable. If one eats raw vegetables after recent recovery from seasonal illness, the complexion will never fully return to normal. If one drinks cold water after recent resolution of illness through sweating, the pericardium will be harmed, causing vacuity that cannot be restored even with supplementation. If one eats raw jujubes or mutton after recent recovery from seasonal illness, heat will accumulate in the diaphragm. If one eats dog or sheep meat after recent recovery from malaria, heat will steam within the bones. If one eats fish, meat, melons, or raw vegetables after recent recovery from seasonal illness, the body will become feverish. (One version reads: “swollen.”) If one eats garlic with raw fish after recent recovery from seasonal illness, the disease will relapse, leading to severe distress.

**Yellow Dragon Decoction** treats headache, high fever, and vexation following recovery from cold damage.
*(Master Zhongjing’s formula, also called Minor Bupleurum Decoction.)*
Bupleurum: half a *jin* #1
Pinellia: half a *sheng*
Scutellaria: 3 *liang*
Ginseng: 2 *liang*
Licorice: 2 *liang*
Fresh ginger: 4 *liang*
Jujubes: 12 pieces
Grind the seven ingredients, decoct in one *dou* of water, and reduce to five *sheng*. Strain and take five *ge* three times daily. If there is no vomiting but thirst, remove Pinellia and add 4 *liang* of Trichosanthes root.

**Formula to Supplement Insufficiency and Vacuity-Labor After Major Illness** (also used for all vacuity-labor diseases):
Take one *sheng* of fresh milk from a yellow cow aged between five and seven years, decoct with four *sheng* of water, and reduce to one *sheng*. Drink warm in small sips, without exceeding the proper amount. Continuous consumption for ten days is optimal.

**Formula for Relapse Due to Labor, Food, Drink, or Activity After Cold Damage or Warm Disease:**
Gardenia seeds: 21
Gypsum: 5 *liang*
Fermented soybean: 1 *sheng*
Mouse droppings (large, pointed ends): 20 pieces
Grind the four ingredients, decoct in seven *sheng* of water, and reduce to three *sheng*. Divide into three doses.

**Formula for Relapse Due to Washing Hands and Feet, Combing Hair, Eating, or Other Labor After Illness:**
Drink one *ge* of the water used to wash hands and feet, and swallow one piece of scalp dirt the size of a jujube pit.

**Unripe Bitter Orange and Gardenia Decoction** treats relapse due to labor after major illness:
Unripe bitter orange: 3 pieces
Gardenia: 14 pieces
Fermented soybean: 1 *sheng* (wrapped in silk)
Grind the three ingredients, first decoct in seven *sheng* of vinegar-water, reducing by three *sheng*, then add unripe bitter orange and gardenia, decocting to two *sheng*. Finally, add fermented soybean, boil for five or six bubbles, and strain. Divide into two doses, cover to induce sweating. If there is retained food, add five or six pieces of rhubarb the size of *boqi* pieces.

**Formula for Relapse Due to Overeating After Recent Recovery from Illness:**
Burn the leftover food to ash, mix with water, and take two *qianbi* three times daily.

**Formula for Relapse Due to Rising Early or Overeating After Recent Recovery:**
Fermented soybean: 5 *ge*
Mouse droppings (pointed ends): 21 pieces
Decoct in two *sheng* of water, reduce to one *sheng*, and consume entirely. Rest warmly to induce slight sweating for recovery.
*(Master Cui’s version adds seven gardenia seeds, which is particularly effective. The *Handbook* version includes one *sheng* of hemp seeds, adding one *sheng* of water, and may also include three unripe bitter oranges and a handful of scallions.)*

**Formula for Relapse Leading to Near-Death Due to Rising Early, Overeating, or Labor After Recent Recovery from Severe Illness:**
Burn turtle shell to ash and take one *fangcunbi* with water.

**Formula for Indigestion Due to Overeating Leading to Relapse with Excessive Pulse:**
Fermented soybean: 1 *sheng*
Mouse droppings: 27 pieces
Gardenia: 7 pieces
Rhubarb: 3 *liang*
Pound the four ingredients, decoct in six *sheng* of water, and reduce to two *sheng*. Divide into three doses; induce slight sweating. If mild diarrhea occurs, discontinue; if not, repeat the formula.

**Formula for Near-Death Relapse Due to Overwork:**
Warm three *ge* of water, wash the genitals of a four- or five-year-old girl, and take the resulting liquid orally to recover. The same may be done with a young boy.

**Ophiopogon Decoction: Formula to Revive from Near-Death Relapse with Fading Qi:**
Ophiopogon: 1 *liang*
Licorice: 2 *liang*
Jujubes: 27 pieces
Bamboo leaves (chopped): 1 *sheng*
Pound the four ingredients, decoct one *sheng* of rice in seven *sheng* of water until cooked, remove the rice, add the herbs, and simmer to three *sheng*. Divide into three doses. If the patient cannot drink, drip the decoction into the mouth with silk floss; this method is effective.

**Formula for Relapse Due to Overeating and Overwork:**
Boil two *sheng* of wheat flour, take the liquid, and consume.

**Alternative Formula:**
Fifty apricot kernels, simmered in two *sheng* of vinegar until reduced to one *sheng*; consume to induce sweating.

**Alternative Formula:**
Burn human feces to ash and take one *fangcunbi* with water.

**Formula to Prevent Relapse:**
Burn scalp dirt the size of a *wutong* seed and swallow.

**Formula for Residual Water Retention in the Epigastrium One Year After Recovery from Cold Damage, Leading to Inability to Eat:**
Fresh rehmannia: 5 *jin*
White atractylodes: 1 *jin*
Fine wheat flour: 2 *jin*
Combine the three ingredients, pound thoroughly, dry in the sun, and sift. Take one *fangcunbi* with wine, three times daily, increasing to two *fangcunbi*.

**Discourse on Women’s Warm Disease and Relapse Through Intercourse:**
Though a woman’s warm disease may have abated, if she has not fully recovered, her blood and vessels remain unsettled, and residual heat-toxin persists. Should she engage in intercourse at this time, the resulting illness is termed *yin-yi* (relapsing through yin). The patient will experience bodily heaviness, heat surging into the chest, head too heavy to lift, and a film (or membrane) forming in the eyes. The limbs (or, in some versions, the sinews of the knees) become rigidly contracted, the lower abdomen twists with pain, and the hands and feet clench into fists—all signs portending immediate death. Some may not die at once but will suffer from urgent tension in the lower abdomen, heat rushing into the chest, a head too heavy to lift, joints loosening as if dislocated, meridians slackening, blood and qi depleted, marrow exhausted, breath shallow and labored, strength waning, and the body so enfeebled as to require assistance even to shift in bed. Such patients may linger for months or years before succumbing.

Physician Zhang Miao recounted a case: a maidservant, still weak days after recovery, was violated by six men—all of whom perished.

**Formula for Women Who Relapse Through Intercourse with a Recovering Man, or for Men Who Relapse Through Intercourse with a Recovering Woman:**
Take a woman’s undergarment string from near the private area, burn it, and administer one *fangcunbi* of the ash. After three days, if urination becomes smooth and the glans swells slightly, this signals recovery. For a woman’s relapse, use a man’s pubic hair in the same manner.

**Formula for Relapse Due to Intercourse (with Swollen, Retracted Testicles and Excruciating Abdominal Pain):**
Take the clothing worn by the woman during intercourse and cover the man with it—he will recover immediately.

**Formula to Prevent Relapse:**
Burn twenty of the woman’s fingernails and toenails, along with a one-*chi* length of her undergarment belt. Administer the ash with wine or rice-water decoction.

**Formula for Men Who Relapse After Resuming Intercourse Too Soon After Recovery:**
Burn a cloth stained with menstrual blood and take one *fangcunbi* of the ash. This also treats swollen, retracted testicles with agonizing abdominal pain.

**Method for Untangling Matted Hair After Illness:**
Take two *sheng* of raw sesame oil, loosen the patient’s hair, place it in a copper sieve, and soak it thoroughly with the oil. Gently comb through with a hairpin—soon the tangles will unravel of their own accord.

**Third Discourse on Lily Disease**
**Formulas and Discourse:**
Lily disease (*baihe bing*) arises when no single meridian is affected, but all the hundred vessels, originating from one source, become diseased. It typically follows unresolved *cold damage* or consumptive illness. Its manifestations vary by location:
- If the patient suffers aversion to cold and vomiting, the disease lies in the upper burner and will resolve in twenty-three days.
- If the patient has abdominal fullness, mild panting, hard stools passed every three or four days, or occasional loose stools, the disease lies in the middle burner and will resolve in sixty-three days.
- If the patient has difficult, dribbling urination, the disease lies in the lower burner and will resolve in thirty-three days.
Treatment must be tailored to the specific pattern.

The nature of lily disease is such that the patient may crave food yet be unable to eat, or may find food appealing at times and repulsive at others. Though they may feel chilled, there is no true cold; though they may feel feverish, there is no true heat. They remain silent, longing to lie down but unable to sleep. By morning, their mouth tastes bitter, their urine is dark and scant, and they may feel the urge to move yet lack the strength. No medicine can cure it; attempts at treatment only provoke severe vomiting and diarrhea, as if possessed by spirits.

In lily disease, the body appears harmonious, but the pulse is faint and rapid. If the patient’s head aches during urination, recovery will take sixty days. If, during urination, the head does not ache but the patient feels chilled, recovery will take forty days. If, during urination, the patient feels relief but experiences dizziness, recovery will take twenty days.

The signs of lily disease may appear before illness onset, within four or five days of falling ill, or even twenty days later. Misdiagnosis is common, so careful differentiation is essential.

**Discourse on Treatment Principles:**
If lily disease manifests in yin but is treated by attacking yang, the yin aspect will not resolve, and inducing sweating will be counterproductive. If it manifests in yang but is treated by attacking yin, the yang aspect will not resolve, and purging will fail to cure the disease. As the *Essentials* states: "For disease in yin, rescue with yang methods; for disease in yang, resolve with yin methods." Attacking yin when the disease is in yang, or inducing sweating after such an attack, is counterproductive and makes the disease difficult to cure. Attacking yang when the disease is in yin, or purging after such an attack, is equally counterproductive and renders the disease intractable.

**Lily and Anemarrhena Decoction (Baihe Zhimu Tang), for Lily Disease Relapsing After Sweating:**
- Lily bulb: 7 pieces, broken apart
- Anemarrhena rhizome: 3 *liang*

Soak the lily bulb in spring water overnight; the next morning, discard the water and any froth. Boil the lily bulb in 2 *sheng* of spring water until 1 *sheng* remains, then set aside. Slice the anemarrhena, boil in 2 *sheng* of spring water until 1 *sheng* remains, and combine with the lily decoction. Reboil until 1.5 *sheng* remain. Administer in two doses. If unresolved, prepare and administer again following the same method.

**Lily, Talc, and Hematite Decoction (Baihe Huashi Daizhe Tang), for Lily Disease Relapsing After Purging:**
- Lily bulb: 7 pieces, broken apart
- Talc: 3 *liang*
- Hematite: 1 *liang*

Soak the lily bulb in spring water overnight; the next morning, discard the water. Boil the lily bulb in 2 *sheng* of spring water until 1 *sheng* remains, then strain. Boil the remaining two ingredients in 2 *sheng* of water until 1 *sheng* remains, combine with the lily decoction, and reboil as before until 1.5 *sheng* remain. Divide into two doses.

**Lily and Egg Yolk Decoction (Baihe Jizi Tang), for Lily Disease Relapsing After Vomiting:**
Soak 7 pieces of lily bulb in spring water overnight, discard the water, then boil in 2 *sheng* of spring water until 1 *sheng* remains. Add one egg yolk, stir well, and administer in two doses.

**Lily and Rehmannia Decoction (Baihe Dihuang Tang), for Lily Disease Without Prior Sweating, Vomiting, or Purging, Presenting as in Its Initial Stage:**
Soak 7 pieces of lily bulb in spring water overnight, discard the water, then boil in 2 *sheng* of spring water until 1 *sheng* remains. Add 1 *sheng* of fresh rehmannia juice, reboil until 1.5 *sheng* remain, and divide into two doses. The passage of foul, frothy stool shall serve as the indicator.

**For Lily Disease Persisting for a Month Without Resolution, Developing into Thirst:**
Take 1 *sheng* of lily root, soak in 1 *dou* of water overnight, and use the liquid to bathe the patient’s body. After bathing, the patient should consume plain wheat noodles, avoiding salt and fermented soybeans. If thirst persists, grind equal parts of trichosanthes root and oyster shell into a powder, and administer one square-inch spoonful with water, three times daily.

**For Lily Disease Developing into Fever:**
- Lily root: 1 *liang*, dried
- Talc: 3 *liang*

Grind the two ingredients into a fine powder. Administer one square-inch spoonful with water, three times daily, until mild diarrhea occurs; discontinue upon onset of diarrhea, and the fever will resolve.
*Alternative text:* For Lily Disease with dark, scanty urine and hardness and tension below the navel.

**For Lily Disease Developing into Abdominal Fullness and Pain:**
Take an appropriate amount of lily root, stir-fry until yellow, then grind into a powder. Administer one square-inch spoonful with water, three times daily, until fullness and pain subside.

*Sun Zhenren’s* *Emergency Prescriptions Worth a Thousand Gold Pieces*, Scroll Thirty-Three, concludes.

### **Formulas for Cold Damage**
#### **Fox-Confusion Disease Developing from Failure to Induce Sweating (Fourth Discussion)**
**Discussion:**
Fox-Confusion Disease resembles Cold Damage. The patient becomes taciturn and drowsy, yet cannot close their eyes, and is restless whether lying or rising. If the toxin lodges in the throat, it is called *Confusion Disease*; if in the yin anus, it is called *Fox Disease*.

In Fox-Confusion Disease, the patient loathes food and drink, refusing to eat upon smelling food. Their complexion may flush red, pale white, or darken. If the toxin consumes the upper body, the voice becomes hoarse (hoarseness, variant: *gagging*); if it consumes the lower body, the throat becomes dry.

This arises from warm-toxin *qi*. For toxin in the upper body, *Drain the Heart Decoction* governs it; for toxin in the lower body, soak and wash with *Sophora Decoction*; for toxin at the external anus, fumigate it. Use three pieces of realgar, placed in an earthen jar over charcoal fire, and direct the fumes toward the anus, while also administering the decoction.

**Decoction for Fox-Confusion:**
- Coptis: 4 *liang*
- *Xun* grass: 4 *liang*

Bruise the two ingredients, steep in one *dou* of white vinegar water overnight, then boil to yield two *sheng*. Divide into three doses.

**Red Adzuki Bean and Chinese Angelica Powder:**
For patients with rapid pulse, no fever, mild vexation, taciturnity, desire to lie down, and sweating—if the eyes become red as a turtledove’s within the first three or four days, or if the four canthi turn yellow-black by seven or eight days, and the patient can eat, pus has already formed. The treatment formula:

Soak three *sheng* of red adzuki beans until they sprout sufficiently, then dry them. Add three *liang* of Chinese angelica, and grind into powder. Administer one square-inch spoonful with fermented water, three times daily, and recovery will follow.

**Drain the Heart Decoction:**
When the disease presentation forbids attack or moxibustion—if fire is used as a pathogenic factor, blood scatters within the vessels. Injury to the vessels is still manageable; injury to the viscera is severe. Well and stream points swell, yellow fluid oozes, channels and network vessels ulcerate externally, and flesh putrefies into abscesses and pus—this is *Fire Impetigo*, an injury caused by physicians.

Patients with rapid pulse must not undergo moxibustion. If fire is used as a pathogenic factor, vexation arises; if deficiency is pursued with excess, blood rushes within the vessels. Though fire’s *qi* is subtle, its internal attack is forceful, scorching bones and damaging sinews, making blood difficult to restore. Treatment should focus on draining the heart.

**Drain the Heart Decoction** also treats incessant diarrhea with abdominal hardness, vexation, vomiting, and borborygmus. (Master Jing calls it *Pinellia Drain the Heart Decoction*; the *Essentials* calls it *Licorice Drain the Heart*.)
- Pinellia: half *sheng*
- Scutellaria: 3 *liang*
- Ginseng: 3 *liang*
- Dried ginger: 3 *liang*
- Licorice: 3 *liang*
- Coptis: 1 *liang*
- Jujube: 12 pieces

Bruise the seven ingredients, boil in one *dou* of water to yield six *sheng*. Divide and administer one *sheng* three times daily.

### **Jaundice from Cold Damage (Fifth Discussion)**
**Symptoms and Formulas**
**Discussion:**
There are five types of jaundice: *Yellow Sweat*, *Yellow Jaundice*, *Grain Jaundice*, *Wine Jaundice*, and *Female Taxation Jaundice*.

**Yellow Sweat:**
The body and limbs are slightly swollen, the chest full without thirst, and sweat exudes like the juice of *Phellodendron*. This arises from profuse sweating followed by sudden immersion in water.

**Yellow Jaundice:**
The entire body and face turn yellow like an orange or pomelo. It arises from sudden heat followed by washing with cold water, causing heat to linger in the stomach, or from eating raw cucumbers or steaming. If it progresses to *Black Jaundice*, death is common.

**Grain Jaundice:**
After eating, the patient experiences dizziness, palpitations, and restlessness. The face turns yellow, caused by eating excessively while famished, with stomach *qi* surging upward.

**Wine Jaundice:**
The patient feels vexing pain in the heart, fullness in the feet and legs, yellow urine, and a face marked with red, yellow, and black macules. This arises from heavy intoxication followed by exposure to wind and water.

**Female Taxation Jaundice:**
The body and eyes turn yellow, with fever, aversion to cold, lower abdominal fullness and tension, and difficult urination. This arises from extreme fatigue and heat followed by intercourse and immersion in water.

Treat according to the following formulas.

**Yellow Sweat Disease:**
The body swells severely, with fever, sweating, and no thirst, resembling *Wind-Water*. Sweat stains clothes a true yellow, like *Phellodendron* juice. The pulse is inherently deep. How is this disease contracted? It arises from sweating followed by bathing in water, which enters through the sweat pores.

**Astragalus, Peony, and Cinnamon Wine Decoction** for Yellow Sweat:
- Astragalus: 5 *liang*
- Peony: 3 *liang*
- Cinnamon heart: 3 *liang*

Bruise the three ingredients, combine with one *sheng* of bitter wine and seven *sheng* of water, and boil to yield three *sheng*. Drink one *sheng*; by the sixth or seventh day, vexation will gradually resolve. Vexation arises from the obstruction of bitter wine.

**Yellow Jaundice Disease:**
If the patient is thirsty, the disease is difficult to treat; if not thirsty, it is treatable. If it arises in the yin aspect, the patient will vomit; if in the yang aspect, the patient will experience shivering and mild fever.

**Cinnamon and Astragalus Decoction** for all types of jaundice, suitable for promoting urination. If the pulse is floating, resolution should come through sweating:
- Cinnamon: 3 *liang*
- Peony: 3 *liang*
- Fresh ginger: 3 *liang*
- Licorice: 2 *liang*
- Astragalus: 5 *liang*
- Jujube: 12 pieces

Bruise the six ingredients, boil in eight *sheng* of water over a mild fire to yield three *sheng*, and remove the dregs. Administer one *sheng* warm to induce mild sweating.

If sweating does not occur shortly after administration, have the patient drink thin hot gruel to assist the decoction; if still no sweat, administer the decoction again.

**Ephedra and Pure Wine Decoction** for treating cold damage with heat effusing outward, causing jaundice:
- Ephedra: 3 *liang*
Boil in five *sheng* of pure wine to yield one and a half *sheng*, then consume entirely. Cover warmly to induce sweating, and recovery will follow. In winter or cold months, use clear wine; in spring, water is suitable.

**Jaundice Remedy:**
- Melon pedicel: 2 × 7 pieces
- Glutinous millet: 2 × 7 pieces
- Adzuki beans: 2 × 7 pieces
Grind the three ingredients into a fine powder. For severe cases, take an amount equivalent to two large soybeans and insert into the nostrils, causing nasal pain and contraction. Shortly after, yellow fluid will discharge—either from the nose or mouth—yielding one *sheng* or more, and the patient will recover. For mild cases, use one soybean’s worth; if unresolved, repeat after a day. In some regions, a tube is used to forcefully blow the powder into the nostrils, but this risks fatality—exercise extreme caution.

**From *Shanfan*:**
For epidemic toxic heat penetrating the viscera and marrow, manifesting as yellow jaundice, black jaundice, red jaundice, white jaundice, grain jaundice, or *mahuang* disease, with labored breathing that persists without cease:

**Rhubarb Pill**, for the same conditions as above:
- Rhubarb: 2 *liang*
- Tingli seed: 2 *liang*
Grind into powder, mix with honey, and form pills the size of firmiana seeds. Take ten pills before meals, three times daily; discontinue when the condition resolves.

**Alternative Formula:**
- Rhubarb: 2 *liang*
- Coptis: 3 *liang*
- Phellodendron: 1 *liang*
- Scutellaria: 1 *liang*
- Fermented leaven: 5 *ge*
Grind into powder, mix with honey, and form pills the size of firmiana seeds. Take three pills before meals, three times daily; if no effect, increase to five pills.

**Virgate Wormwood Decoction** for jaundice, where the body and eyes are entirely yellow:
- Virgate wormwood: 3 *liang*
- Coptis: 3 *liang*
- Scutellaria: 2 *liang*
- Rhubarb: 1 *liang*
- Licorice: 1 *liang*
- Ginseng: 1 *liang*
- Gardenia: 2 × 7 pieces
Bruise the seven ingredients, boil in one *dou* of water to yield three *sheng*, and divide into three doses, taken thrice daily. Also treats alcohol-induced jaundice and alcohol accumulation.

**Three Yellows Powder**, for the same conditions as above:
- Rhubarb: 4 *liang*
- Coptis: 4 *liang*
- Scutellaria: 4 *liang*
Grind into a fine powder. Take one square *cun* spoonful before meals, three times daily. Can also be formed into pills.

**Five Ling Powder** for jaundice, promoting urination:
- Polyporus: 3 *zhu*
- Poria: 3 *zhu*
- Alisma: 3 *zhu*
- Atractylodes: 3 *zhu*
- Cinnamon bark: 3 *zhu*
Pound and sift into a powder. When thirsty, take one square *cun* spoonful with water, drink copiously, and urination or sweating will resolve the condition. This formula is repeated from Volume Nine, with differing dosages.

**Prickly Ash Powder** for jaundice with scant drinking but copious urination:
- Prickly ash: 6 *zhu*
- Melon pedicel: ½ *liang*
Grind into a fine powder. Take one square *cun* spoonful with water, three times daily.

**Minor Pinellia Decoction** for jaundice where urine color is unchanged, with spontaneous diarrhea, abdominal fullness, and panting—heat should not be purged, as its removal will induce hiccups:
- Pinellia: ½ *jin*
- Fresh ginger: ½ *jin*
Bruise the two ingredients, boil in seven *sheng* of water to yield one *sheng* and five *ge*, and divide into two doses. There was a case of a person who died from chronic qi stagnation, their heart still warm; a small amount of this decoction’s liquid was dripped into their mouth, and they revived.

**Jaundice Remedy:**
Take fresh wheat seedlings, pound to extract the juice, and drink six to seven *ge*, three to four times day and night. Recovery occurs in three to four days. If wheat seedlings are unavailable, barley seedlings may be used.

**Remedy for Yellow Jaundice Turning into Black Jaundice, Untreatable by Physicians:**
Pound *tugua* root to extract one small *sheng* of juice and consume it all at once, once daily in the early morning. By mealtime, the disease will discharge through the urine. First assess the patient’s strength; do not administer excessively, as weakness may prevent them from rising.

**Remedy for Jaundice Where Body, Face, and Eyes Turn Golden, Urine Like Concentrated Phellodendron Decoction, Untreatable by Physicians:**
- Virgate wormwood: 4 *liang*
- Gardenia: 4 *liang*
- Scutellaria: 3 *liang*
- Rhubarb: 3 *liang*
- Bupleurum: 3 *liang*
- Cimicifuga: 3 *liang*
- Gentian: 2 *liang*
Bruise the seven ingredients, boil in eight *sheng* of water to yield two *sheng* and seven *ge*, and divide into three doses. If the body is emaciated, omit rhubarb and add five to six *liang* of gardenia and one *sheng* of fresh rehmannia.
*Yannian Milu* omits virgate wormwood and includes four *liang* of gardenia, three *liang* of trichosanthes, and two *liang* of mirabilite.
*Jinxiao Fang* adds two *liang* of unripe bitter orange.

If jaundice persists for a long time, turning peach-blossom colored, with hardness below the heart, retching, inability to eat, extremely scant dark urine, cold limbs, and a deep, faint, slow pulse, this formula is unsuitable—purging will induce *wan* disease. Instead, administer **Major Virgate Wormwood Decoction**, omitting rhubarb and adding five *liang* of fresh rehmannia. After consuming the decoction, observe the pulse: if it becomes slightly floating and the body shows minor signs, no longer deeply faint, treatment is possible. When the pulse becomes floating, the yellow hue will brighten, no longer peach-blossom colored, and the hardness below the heart will resolve. The formula for **Major Virgate Wormwood Decoction** follows the eleven-ingredient version below.

**Sophora Powder** for sudden onset of shivering and jaundice, with yellow dust-like skin, scant dark urine, occasional constipation, normal strength, and unaffected appetite—after other decoctions and powders fail to resolve residual heat in long-standing jaundice, inducing vomiting and purging:
- Sophora: 1 *liang*
- Coptis: 1 *liang*
- Melon pedicel: 1 *liang*
- Phellodendron: 1 *liang*
- Rhubarb: 1 *liang*
- Tingli seed: 2 *liang*
Grind into a fine powder. Take one square *cun* spoonful with water to induce severe vomiting. If vomiting occurs, take once daily; if not, take twice. Some relief should appear after five days; if not, continue administration and adjust as needed. Minor setbacks may require further adjustment.

**Formulas for Treating Jaundice**

**Decoction for Jaundice:**
- Virgate wormwood: 3 *liang*
- Phellodendron: 3 *liang*
- Gardenia: 3 *liang*
- Rhubarb: 3 *liang*
- Coptis: 2 *liang*
Chop the five ingredients, boil in nine *sheng* of water, reduce to three *sheng*, and divide into three doses.

**First administer the decoction, then the pills:**
- Rhubarb: 5 *liang*
- Virgate wormwood: 3 *liang*
- Gardenia: 3 *liang*
- Scutellaria: 2 *liang*
- Phellodendron: 2 *liang*
- Coptis: 2 *liang*
Grind into powder, form into honey pills the size of firmiana seeds. Take twenty pills with water, inducing mild purgation.

**Ephedra, Forsythia, and Adzuki Bean Decoction** for treating cold damage with stagnant heat in the interior, where the body must turn yellow:
- Ephedra: 2 *liang*
- Forsythia: 2 *liang*
- Licorice: 2 *liang*
- Fresh ginger: 3 *liang*
- Jujubes: 12 pieces
- Apricot kernels: 30+ pieces
- Adzuki beans: 2 *sheng*
- Fresh catalpa bark (chopped): 2 *sheng*
Chop the eight ingredients, boil in one *dou* of labored water. First boil ephedra, skim off foam, then add remaining ingredients, and reduce to three *sheng*. Divide into three doses.

**Virgate Wormwood Decoction** for treating cold damage of seven or eight days, with internal repletion and stagnant heat binding, where the body turns orange-yellow, urination is inhibited, and the abdomen is slightly distended and full—suitable for purgation:
- Virgate wormwood: 6 *liang*
- Rhubarb: 3 *liang*
- Gardenia: 40 pieces
Chop the three ingredients, boil virgate wormwood in one *dou* and two *sheng* of water, reduce to five *sheng*, strain, then add gardenia and rhubarb, and reduce to three *sheng*. Divide into three doses of one *sheng* each, taken thrice daily. Urine should flow like soapberry foam, deep red in color, with abdominal distension relieved and jaundice fully resolved through urination. Fan Wang used this to treat grain jaundice; *Minor Formulas* adds one *jin* of gypsum.

**Rhubarb and Phellodendron Decoction** for treating jaundice with abdominal fullness, inhibited and red urination, and spontaneous sweating—where the exterior is harmonized but the interior is replete, suitable for purgation:
- Rhubarb: 3 *liang*
- Phellodendron: 4 *liang*
- Mirabilite: 4 *liang*
- Gardenia: 15 pieces
Chop the four ingredients, boil in six *sheng* of water, reduce to two *sheng*, strain, add mirabilite, and reduce further to one *sheng*. Take on an empty stomach in one dose.

**Virgate Wormwood Pills** for treating seasonal epidemic acute jaundice, miasmic pestilential qi, and intermittent malarial disorders:
- Virgate wormwood: 3 *liang*
- Gardenia: 3 *liang*
- Mirabilite: 3 *liang*
- Apricot kernels: 3 *liang*
- Croton: 1 *liang*
- Dichroa root: 2 *liang*
- Turtle shell: 2 *liang*
- Fermented soybeans: 5 *liang*
- Rhubarb: 5 *liang*
Grind into powder, form into malt-sugar pills the size of firmiana seeds. Take three pills with water; vomiting and purgation indicate efficacy. If no effect, increase by one pill. At the first sign of bodily discomfort, administer immediately for rapid resolution—divinely effective.

**Formula for Acute Jaundice with Heat Qi and Steaming Bones, Red Veins in Both Eyes:**
- Mirabilite: 1 *liang*
- Rhubarb (powdered): 1.5 *liang*
- Fresh rehmannia juice: 8 *ge*
Combine. Take five *ge* per dose, twice daily, until purgation occurs; a second dose is unnecessary.

**Formula for Wind Jaundice, with Yellow or White Urine, Chills and Fever, Preference for Lying Down, and Aversion to Movement:**
- Fresh mugwort harvested in the third month: 1 bundle (pounded to extract juice)
- Simmer in a bronze vessel until lacquer-like, seal tightly.
- Rhubarb: 6 *zhu*
- Coptis: 6 *zhu*
- Calcitum: 6 *zhu*
- Trichosanthes root: 6 *zhu*
- Sophora: 6 *zhu*
- Tingli seed: 6 *zhu*
Grind the six ingredients into powder, mix with mugwort decoction, and form into pills the size of firmiana seeds. Take five pills before meals, twice daily, increasing to twenty pills as needed. For heat, add sophora; for thirst, add trichosanthes; for inhibited urination, add tingli seed; for copious urination, add calcitum; for white urine, add coptis; for difficult defecation, add rhubarb.

**Wet Jaundice** presents initially with generalized pain and fever, a dark yellow complexion, and after seven or eight days, vigorous heat in the interior with blood—requiring purgation to expel it like pig’s liver. If the lower abdomen is full, urgent purgation is needed.

**Formula for Generalized Jaundice, Yellow Eyes, Abdominal Fullness, and Inhibited Urination:**
- Alum: 5 *liang*
- Talc: 5 *liang*
Grind into powder. Take one square *cun* spoonful with barley porridge juice, thrice daily before meals. When stool resembles blood, sweating will resolve the condition.

When the *cunkou* pulse is floating and moderate: floating indicates wind, moderation indicates impediment. This impediment is not wind stroke but vexation in the four limbs. The spleen’s color must turn yellow, and stagnant heat will circulate.

When the *fuyang* pulse is tight and rapid: rapidity indicates heat, which consumes grain; tightness indicates cold, causing fullness after eating.

A floating *chi* pulse indicates kidney damage; a tight *fuyang* pulse indicates spleen damage. When wind and cold contend, eating grain induces dizziness. Grain qi fails to transform, the stomach suffers turbidity, turbid qi flows downward, urination is obstructed, and yin is encumbered by cold. Heat flows into the bladder, and the body turns entirely yellow—this is called grain jaundice.

**Pills for Taxation Jaundice and Grain Jaundice:**
- Sophora: 3 *liang*
- Gentian: 1 *liang*
Grind into powder, mix with ox bile, and form into pills the size of firmiana seeds. Take five pills before meals with barley porridge water, thrice daily. If no effect, gradually increase the dose. *Comprehensive Formulas* adds twenty-one gardenia kernels, forming pills with pig bile.

**For Wine Jaundice:** If the pulse is floating, first induce vomiting; if deep and wiry, first induce purgation.

For those with wine jaundice, some exhibit no heat, speak clearly, and experience abdominal fullness with nausea—suitable for vomiting. The seven-ingredient **Sophora Powder** (previously described) is appropriate.

Wine jaundice must involve inhibited urination, with signs including heat in the heart and heat in the soles of the feet.

If wine jaundice is purged over time, it may transform into black jaundice, with green eyes, a black complexion, a sensation of eating garlic mash in the heart, black stool, numbness in the skin and nails, and a floating, weak pulse. Though the color is black, a faint yellow hue confirms its nature.

**Unripe Bitter Orange and Rhubarb Decoction (#9):** Treats cold damage from wine, where food intake is scant but drinking abundant, phlegm binds and jaundice arises, with heart vexation yet no severe heat, or dry retching. Ingredients:
Five pieces of unripe bitter orange,
Three *liang* of rhubarb,
Half a *sheng* of fermented soybean,
Seven gardenia kernels.
Steep the four ingredients, then decoct in six *sheng* of water until two *sheng* remain. Divide into three doses. Governs heart heat, pain, and vexation.

**Frosted Sal Ammoniac Powder:** Treats flesh jaundice, with scant drinking, copious urination resembling rice-water, this condition arising from wine. Ingredients:
Frosted sal ammoniac,
White halloysite,
Trichosanthes root,
Cinnamon heart, each thirty *zhu*,
Cuscuta seeds,
Anemarrhena rhizome, each eighteen *zhu*.
Grind the six ingredients to powder. Take five *fen* with barley gruel, thrice daily. Effect known in five days, cure in ten.

**Poria Pill:** Treats horizontal and vertical hardness below the heart, with reddish urine, a condition of wine jaundice. Ingredients:
Poria,
Oriental wormwood,
Dried ginger, each one *liang*,
Stir-fried white atractylodes,
Unripe bitter orange, each thirty *zhu*,
Pinellia,
Apricot kernel, each eighteen *zhu*,
Kansui root, six *zhu*,
Sichuan pepper,
Chinese angelica, each twelve *zhu*.
Grind the ten ingredients to powder, form honey pills the size of firmiana seeds. Take three pills on an empty stomach, thrice daily, gradually increasing until urination flows freely.
*The Thousand Gold Wings* adds one *liang* of coptis and eighteen *zhu* of rhubarb, naming it **Oriental Wormwood Pill**, to treat black jaundice with darkening body, inhibited urination.

**Pinellia Decoction:** Treats wine accumulations shadowing the chest, heart distension and fullness, heaviness in bones and flesh, counterflow harming food intake, even to reddish-yellow urine, this rooted in vacuity taxation from wind-cold, food counterflowing to the heart, caused by internal phlegm in the spleen and stomach. Ingredients:
One *sheng* of pinellia,
One *liang* each of fresh ginger, scutellaria, oriental wormwood, Chinese angelica,
Two *liang* each of peucedanum, unripe bitter orange, licorice, euphorbia,
Three *liang* each of poria, white atractylodes.
Steep and decoct in one *dou* of water until three *sheng* remain. Divide into three doses.

**Ox Bile Pill:** Treats wine jaundice, with body yellow as dust rising. Ingredients:
One ox gallbladder,
One *sheng* of genkwa,
Half a *sheng* of *raohua*,
Three *liang* of melon pedicel,
Eight *liang* of rhubarb.
Steep the four ingredients in one *dou* of clear wine overnight, then decoct until half remains. Strain, add ox bile, simmer over low heat until pillable. Form pills the size of soybeans. Take one pill; if after moving six or seven *chi* there is no effect, take another, up to eight pills. Above the diaphragm, vomiting; below, purgation. Some recover without vomiting.

**Major Oriental Wormwood Decoction:** Treats internal repletion with exuberant heat and jaundice, yellow as gold, with floating, large, slippery, replete, tight, or rapid pulses. Jaundice often arises in wine drinkers with taxation heat, scant food, stomach heat, or warm toxin with internal heat, hence yellow as gold. Ingredients:
One and a half *liang* each of oriental wormwood, phellodendron,
Three *liang* each of rhubarb, white atractylodes,
Two *liang* each of scutellaria, licorice, poria, trichosanthes root, peucedanum, unripe bitter orange,
Twenty gardenia kernels.
Steep and decoct in nine *sheng* of water until three *sheng* remain. Divide into three doses. After rapid purgation, rest three or four days before further treatment.

**Oriental Wormwood Pill:** Treats qi strangury, drum distension with abdominal enlargement, body and face all yellow, and wine jaundice with shortness of breath. Ingredients:
Four *liang* each of oriental wormwood, asparagus root, gardenia,
Three *liang* each of rhubarb, cinnamon heart,
Two *liang* each of rice-paper plant pith, gypsum,
Half a *sheng* of pinellia.
Steam rhubarb, rice-paper plant pith, asparagus root, pinellia, and gardenia, then dry in the sun. Grind together, form honey pills the size of soybeans. Take three pills, thrice daily. Avoid raw fish; take with bean broth, not wine. One formula omits gypsum, adding two *liang* of talc. If no effect, increase to ten pills.

In yellowing households, heat arises at dusk with aversion to cold—this is female taxation. It arises when the bladder is tense, the lesser abdomen full, the entire body yellow, the forehead black, and the soles of the feet hot, leading to black jaundice. The abdomen is drum-distended and full, as if about to produce water, the stool necessarily black, sometimes sloppy diarrhea—this is female taxation jaundice, not water. Abdominal fullness makes it difficult to treat.

**Niter and Alum Powder:** Treats female taxation jaundice. Ingredients:
Half a *liang* each of niter, alum.
Grind to powder. Take one square *cun* spoonful with barley gruel, thrice daily. Cover with heavy clothing to induce sweating. The illness exits with the stool and urine—urine properly yellow, stool properly black.

Jaundice as a disease: heat arises at dusk with aversion to cold, the lesser abdomen tense, the body yellow, the forehead black, stool sloppy and black, the soles of the feet hot—this is female taxation. Abdominal fullness makes it difficult to treat. Treatment formula:
Equal parts talc and gypsum.

Grind the two ingredients to powder. Take one square *cun* spoonful with barley gruel thrice daily; when urination becomes copious, the illness resolves.

**Acupuncture and Moxibustion for Jaundice**

**Front View (Diagram 1)**
*Yinmen* | *Upper Gum* | *Upper Palate* | *Under the Tongue* | *Within the Lips* | *Xianru* | *Beside the Philtrum* | *Middle Beside* | *Chengjiang* | *Juque* | *Shangwan* | *Yinfeng*

*Yinmen* point: Measure from the tip of the nose straight to the hairline with a string, divide it into three equal parts, then take one part of the string from the hairline inward—needle at the string’s end. Treats acute jaundice and epidemic jaundice.

*Upper Gum* point: Located at the philtrum and lips; needle three *zhen*. Treats acute jaundice and epidemic jaundice.

*Upper Palate* point: Inside the mouth, along the upper seam where the red and white flesh meet; needle three *zhen*. Treats acute jaundice, epidemic jaundice, and seasonal illnesses.

*Under the Tongue* point: Beside both sides of the tongue; needle. Treats jaundice.

*Within the Lips* point: Directly beside *Chengjiang*, near the gums; needle three *zhen*. Treats acute jaundice, epidemic jaundice, cold-heat afflictions, and seasonal pestilences.

*Xianru* point: Between the tail of the eyebrow and the outer canthus, where visible coming-and-going collaterals are; needle or moxa. Treats seasonal cold-heat afflictions, jaundice *qi*, and warm diseases.

*Beside the Philtrum* point: Apply fire needling. Treats acute jaundice, epidemic jaundice, and cases where the entire body turns yellow and speech fails.

*Beside Chengjiang* point: One *cun* on either side of *Chengjiang*. Treats acute jaundice and severe epidemics.

*Juque* point: One *cun* below the heart; moxa seven cones. Treats acute jaundice, epidemic jaundice, and severe epidemics.

*Shangwan* point: Two *cun* below the heart; moxa seven cones. Treats acute jaundice and epidemic jaundice.

*Male Yinfeng* point: Lift the penis upward and moxa. Treats acute jaundice and epidemic jaundice.
For women, the *Yumen* point serves the same purpose. Needling and moxibustion apply equally to both sexes.

**Back View (Diagram 2)**
*Fengfu* | *Refu* | *Lung Shu* | *Heart Shu* | *Liver Shu* | *Spleen Shu* | *Kidney Shu* | *Heel*

*Fengfu* point: One *cun* into the hairline at the nape, one *cun* from the upper bone; needle. Treats all head diseases, acute jaundice, and epidemic jaundice.

*Refu* point: Below the second vertebra, one and a half *cun* on either side; needle or moxa without restriction. Treats acute jaundice and epidemic jaundice.

*Lung Shu* point: From *Dazhui*, count to the third vertebra, one and a half *cun* on either side; moxa. Treats jaundice and all toxic diseases.

*Heart Shu* point: From *Lung Shu*, count to the second vertebra, one and a half *cun* on either side.

*Liver Shu* point: From *Heart Shu*, count to the fourth vertebra, one and a half *cun* on either side.

*Spleen Shu* point: From *Liver Shu*, count to the second vertebra, one and a half *cun* on either side.

*Kidney Shu* point: From *Spleen Shu*, count to the third vertebra, one and a half *cun* on either side.

*Heel* point: At the white flesh’s posterior border; needle or moxa as desired. Treats acute jaundice, epidemic jaundice, cold-heat afflictions, and all toxins.

**Side View (Diagram 3)**
*Within the Ear* | *Within the Cheek* | *Hand Taiyang* | *Arm Shizitou* | *Qiankong* | *Taichong*

*Within the Ear* point: At the horizontal beam of the ear’s opening; needle or moxa. Treats acute jaundice, epidemic jaundice, cold-heat afflictions, and epidemic toxins.

*Within the Cheek* point: One *cun* from the corner of the mouth toward the opposite cheek; needle. Treats acute jaundice, epidemic jaundice, cold-heat afflictions, and seasonal pestilences. Apply the same method to both cheeks.

*Hand Taiyang* point: At the tip of the little finger; moxa according to the patient’s age. Treats jaundice.

*Arm Shizitou* point: Have the patient grasp their own arm; from the wrist’s *Taiyuan* point upward one *fu* to the white flesh’s border; moxa seven cones. Treats acute jaundice and epidemic jaundice.

*Qiankong* point: Measure from the nipple to the navel, then bend the rib’s end—this is the location; moxa one hundred cones. Treats jaundice.

*Taichong* point: Needle or moxa as desired. Treats acute jaundice and warm epidemics.

*Sun Simiao’s Essential Emergency Prescriptions, Volume Thirty-Four, concludes.* (Note: The Song Dynasty block-print edition reads "twenty-seven sections.")
