The root of this vessel lies behind the external malleolus, corresponding to three *cun* above the *Mingmen*. The *Mingmen* is located one *cun* above the heart. The vessel’s root is at *Shaoze*, which is at the tip of the little finger. Its sinews begin above the little finger, bind at the wrist, follow the inner arm’s edge, and bind at the posterior aspect of the elbow’s *dui* bone. When plucked, it resonates at the little finger’s tip, then enters and binds beneath the armpit. Its branch travels posteriorly along the armpit’s edge, ascends to encircle the scapula, follows the neck, emerges anterior to the foot *Taiyang* sinews, and binds at the *Wangu* behind the ear. Another branch enters the ear, emerges directly above it, descends to bind at the jaw, and connects to the outer canthus.

The vessel begins at the little finger’s tip, follows the hand’s outer edge to the wrist, emerges at the styloid process, ascends directly along the arm’s lower edge, exits between the two bones at the elbow’s inner side, follows the outer posterior edge of the upper arm, emerges at the shoulder joint, encircles the scapula, intersects above the shoulder, enters the supraclavicular fossa, and travels toward the armpit to network with the heart. It follows the throat, descends through the diaphragm, reaches the stomach, and pertains to the Small Intestine.

One branch ascends from the supraclavicular fossa along the neck to the cheek, reaches the outer canthus, and enters the ear. Another branch diverges from the cheek, ascends to the infraorbital region, reaches the nose, and extends to the inner canthus, obliquely networking at the zygomatic bone. It pairs with the hand *Shaoyin* as exterior and interior; the *Shaoyin*’s root is at the *dui* bone’s tip, corresponding to the back, and converges with the hand *Taiyin*.

The hand *Taiyang*’s divergence is called *Zhizheng*, which ascends five *cun* above the wrist and internally infuses into the *Shaoyin*. Its branch ascends to the elbow and networks at the shoulder’s *jie*, governing illnesses arising from the heart.

When replete, the Small Intestine suffers heat; heat causes joint laxity, laxity leads to *yang* illness, and the *yang* vessel becomes large. If it counterflows and doubles at the *cunkou*, illness manifests as throat pain, jaw swelling, deafness, yellowed eyes, an inability to lie down or speak, and oppression leading to sudden sitting. When vacuous, the Small Intestine suffers cold; cold generates warts, and warts lead to *yin* illness. If the *yin* vessel becomes smaller than the *cunkou* by more than one degree, illness manifests as shortness of breath, pain in all joints, sinew tension, neck pain, and an inability to turn the head.

All these are illnesses of the hand *Taiyang* Small Intestine’s sinews, vessels, branches, and divergences. Now, the heart’s governing pericardium and the *Shaoyin* heart channel are appended below.

The branch of the Hand *Pericardium Governor* is called *Neiguan*. Five *cun* above the wrist (the *Jiayi* states two *cun*), it emerges between the two sinews, follows the channel upward, strikes the pericardium, and networks the heart system. When *qi* is replete, there is heart pain; when vacuous, there is vexation of the heart. Treat it between the two sinews.

The channel of the Hand *Pericardium Governor* arises in the chest, emerges to belong to the pericardium, descends through the diaphragm, and passes through to network the Triple Burner. Its branch follows the chest, emerges at the flank, descends three *cun* below the axilla, ascends to the axilla, descends along the inner arm, travels between the *Taiyin* and *Shaoyin*, enters the elbow, descends the forearm between the two sinews, enters the center of the palm, and follows the middle finger to its tip. Another branch diverges from the center of the palm, follows the fourth finger to its tip.

When this channel moves, it causes illness: heat in the palm, spasm and tension in the elbow and arm, swelling in the axilla, and in severe cases, fullness and propping distension in the chest and flanks, great stirring in the heart, red face, yellowed eyes, and incessant laughter. The illnesses generated by this channel are vexation of the heart, heart pain, and heat in the center of the palm. For all these illnesses: when replete, drain; when vacuous, supplement; when hot, treat swiftly; when cold, retain the needle; when sunken and depleted, apply moxibustion. When neither replete nor vacuous, treat according to the channel. When replete, the *cunkou* pulse is twice as large as the *renying*; when vacuous, the *cunkou* is smaller than the *renying*.

The branch of the Hand *Shaoyin* is called *Tongli*. One *cun* behind the wrist, it diverges and ascends, follows the channel into the throat, connects to the root of the tongue, and belongs to the eye system. When replete, there is propping fullness in the diaphragm; when vacuous, there is an inability to speak. Treat it one *cun* behind the palm, where it diverges to the *Taiyang*.

The channel of the Hand *Shaoyin* arises in the heart, emerges to belong to the heart system, ascends through the diaphragm, and networks the Small Intestine. Its branch follows the heart system upward alongside the throat and connects to the eye system. (Another version states: follows the chest and emerges at the flank.) Its straight portion again follows the heart system upward to the lung, emerges below the axilla, descends along the posterior inner arm, travels behind the *Taiyin* and *Pericardium Governor*, descends to the inner elbow, follows the posterior inner forearm, reaches the styloid process at the back of the palm, enters the inner posterior palm, follows the inner side of the little finger to its tip.

When this channel moves, it causes illness: dry throat, heart pain, thirst with desire to drink—this is called *arm reversal*. The illnesses generated by the heart are yellowed eyes, fullness and pain in the flanks, pain and reversal in the posterior inner arm, and heat and pain in the center of the palm. For all these illnesses: when replete, drain; when vacuous, supplement. When replete, the *cunkou* pulse is twice as large as the *renying*; when vacuous, the *cunkou* is smaller than the *renying*.

Why does the Hand *Shaoyin* channel alone have no *shu*-points? It is said: The *Shaoyin* is the heart channel. The heart is the great ruler of the five viscera and six bowels, the emperor, the abode of spirit and essence. Its viscus is firm and secure; evil cannot lodge there. If evil lodges there, the heart is harmed; if the heart is harmed, spirit departs; if spirit departs, the body dies. Thus, all evils in the heart are in the heart’s pericardium. The pericardium is the channel of the *Pericardium Governor*. Therefore, the *Shaoyin* has no *shu*-points.

If the *Shaoyin* has no *shu*-points, does the heart not suffer illness? It is said: When the external channel or bowel is ill, the viscus is not ill. Thus, treat only its channel at the styloid process behind the palm.

In the third month of summer, the heart and Small Intestine govern. Red vessel illnesses arise when the *qi* of *Shaoyin* and *Taiyang* contend and stagnate, causing construction and defense to fail to flow, and pain to arise in the skin and flesh. When the *Taiyang* stirs and the *Shaoyin* moves, excessive evil *qi* arises, and the viscera and bowels receive seasonal epidemic illnesses accordingly, with their illnesses opposing one another. If the bowel is vacuous and harmed by *yin* evil *qi*, the body trembles and the pulse quivers, and one cannot grasp objects. If the viscus is replete and invaded by *yang* toxin, the flesh is hot, the mouth opens, the tongue splits, the throat is blocked, and the voice is hoarse—this is called *red vessel illness*. The formula is found in the *Cold Damage* scroll.

Bian Que said: Moxibustion on the *shu*-points of the kidney, liver, and heart governs the treatment of cinnabar toxin (or *bi* toxin). One should treat according to the source, regulate *yin* and *yang* at the exterior, harmonize the viscera and bowels, and illness will not arise.

**Heart Vacuity and Repletion, Second**
*Pulse, Formula, Moxibustion Method*

**Heart Repletion Heat**
When the *yin* pulse before the *renying* at the left *cunkou* is replete, it pertains to the Hand *Shaoyin* channel. The illness involves blockage, difficulty with defecation, abdominal fullness, heaviness in the four limbs, and generalized heat—this is called *heart repletion heat*.

*Gypsum Decoction* treats heart heat repletion, or when one desires to vomit but cannot, with vexation, oppression, panting, and headache:
Gypsum 1 *jin*, bland bamboo leaves 1 *sheng*, fermented soybean 1 *sheng*, wheat 3 *sheng*, lycium bark 5 *liang*, poria 3 *liang*, gardenia fruit 37 pieces.
Crush the seven ingredients, first boil the wheat and bamboo leaves in 1 *dou* 5 *sheng* of water to obtain 8 *sheng*, strain the liquid, then add the remaining ingredients and boil to obtain 2 *sheng*. Remove the dregs and divide into three doses. The *External Classic* calls this *Drain the Lung Decoction*.

*Drain the Heart Decoction* treats diarrhea in the elderly and children, undigested food and water, thunderous rumbling in the intestines, glomus and fullness below the heart, dry retching, and restlessness:
Ginseng, scutellaria, licorice 1 *liang* each; dried ginger 1.5 *liang*; coptis 2 *liang*; pinellia 3 *liang*; jujube 12 pieces.
Crush the seven ingredients, boil in 8 *sheng* of water to obtain 2.5 *sheng*, and divide into three doses. Also treats cholera.
If cold, add 1 piece of aconite; if thirsty, add 2 *liang* of trichosanthes root; if vomiting, add 1 *liang* of tangerine peel; if pain, add 1 *liang* of tangkuei; if guest heat, substitute fresh ginger for dried ginger.

**Heart and Small Intestine Both Replete**
When the *yin* and *yang* pulses before the *renying* at the left *cunkou* are both replete, the Hand *Shaoyin* and *Taiyang* channels are both replete. The illness involves headache, generalized heat, difficulty with defecation, vexation and fullness in the heart and abdomen, inability to lie down, and stagnation of stomach *qi* with repletion of water and grain—this is called *heart and Small Intestine both replete*.

**Bamboo Sap Decoction**
Treats repletion heat in the heart, fright dreams, excessive laughter, fear, palpitations, and restlessness. The formula:
- 1 *sheng* each of bland bamboo sap and fresh rehmannia juice
- 8 *liang* of gypsum
- 2 *liang* each of peony root, white atractylodes, ginseng, and gardenia seed
- 2 *liang* each of red halloysite, aster root, anemarrhena rhizome, and poria spirit

Eleven ingredients in total. Chop and boil the ten herbs in 9 *sheng* of water to obtain 2 *sheng* and 7 *ge*, then strain. Add the bamboo sap and simmer further to obtain 3 *sheng*. If purgation is required, add 2 *liang* of mirabilite and remove peony root. Divide into three doses.

**Poria Spirit Powder**
Treats repletion heat in the heart, dry mouth, vexing thirst, and restless sleep. The formula:
- 36 *zhu* each of poria spirit and ophiopogon root
- 30 *zhu* each of rice-paper plant pith and cimicifuga rhizome
- 18 *zhu* each of aster root and cinnamon bark
- 1 *liang* of anemarrhena rhizome
- 42 *zhu* of red halloysite
- 10 jujubes
- 1 piece of bland bamboo shavings (size of a chicken egg)

Ten ingredients in total. Grind, sift, and prepare as a coarse powder. Wrap a *fangcunbi* measure in silk and boil in 2.5 *sheng* of well-flower water to obtain 9 *ge*, occasionally stirring the pouch. One dose, taken twice daily.

**Drain the Heart Decoction**
Treats unsettled heart *qi*, vomiting of blood, and nosebleed. The formula:
- 2 *liang* of rhubarb
- 1 *liang* each of coptis rhizome and scutellaria root

Three ingredients in total. Chop and boil in 3 *sheng* of water to obtain 1 *sheng*, then take in one dose.

**Also treats cholera.**

**Calm the Heart Powder**
Treats heart heat with fullness, vexation, oppression, fright, and terror. The formula:
- 2 *liang* each of white peony root, polygala root, and dried ginger
- 42 *zhu* each of poria, red halloysite, ophiopogon root, anemarrhena rhizome, aster root, and gypsum
- 24 *zhu* of ginseng
- 30 *zhu* each of cinnamon bark, ephedra, and scutellaria root
- 36 *zhu* of Solomon’s seal rhizome
- 12 *zhu* of licorice root

Fifteen ingredients in total. Grind, sift, and prepare as a coarse powder. First boil 5 *sheng* of water with 1 *sheng* of bland bamboo leaves to obtain 3 *sheng*, then discard the dregs. Boil a *fangcunbi* measure of the powder, securely wrapped in silk, occasionally stirring the pouch. Decoct to obtain 8 *ge*. One dose, taken twice daily.

**Treats inability to eat, chest fullness, counterflow *qi* above the diaphragm, and oppression with heat.**
Moxibustion: apply 14 cones to the heart transport point. Reduce for children.

**Heart Vacuity Cold**
When the yin pulse at the *renying* position of the left *cunkou* is vacuous, it pertains to the hand lesser yin channel. The patient suffers from palpitations, terror, discontent, heart and abdominal pain, difficulty speaking, a sensation of cold in the heart, and absentmindedness. This is called heart vacuity cold.

**Poria Supplement the Heart Decoction**
Treats insufficiency of heart *qi*, frequent sorrow, anger, and resentment, nosebleed, yellow complexion, vexation and oppression, heat in the five centers, or unconscious muttering, sore throat, stiff tongue root, cold drool (or sweating), forgetfulness, terror, restlessness, and in women, flooding and spotting with a red facial complexion. The formula:
- 4 *liang* of poria
- 2 *liang* each of cinnamon bark and licorice root
- 1 *liang* each of fluorite and ginseng
- 20 jujubes
- 3 *liang* of ophiopogon root
- 24 red adzuki beans

Eight ingredients in total. Chop and boil in 7 *sheng* of water to obtain 2 *sheng*, then divide into three doses.

**Pinellia Supplement the Heart Decoction**
Treats heart vacuity cold with heart distention and fullness, sorrow, and grief, or dreams of mountains, hills, plains, and marshes. The formula:
- 6 *liang* of pinellia rhizome
- 5 *liang* of dried ginger
- 3 *liang* each of poria, cinnamon bark, unripe bitter orange, and tangerine peel
- 4 *liang* of white atractylodes rhizome
- 2 *liang* each of saposhnikovia root and polygala root

Nine ingredients in total. Chop and boil in 1 *dou* of water to obtain 3 *sheng*, then divide into three doses.

**Ox Marrow Pill**
A general remedy for all diseases, vacuity emaciation, and debility. The formula:
- 1 *sheng* each of ox marrow, sheep marrow, jujube paste, white honey, and *su* (refined butter)
- 30 *zhu* each of ophiopogon root, chuanxiong rhizome, cinnamon bark, Chinese angelica root, poria (or poria with hostwood), licorice root, and notopterygium root
- 36 *zhu* each of dried rehmannia root and dried ginger
- 1 *liang* each of schisandra fruit, ginseng, and saposhnikovia root
- 18 *zhu* of asarum herb
- 42 *zhu* of white atractylodes rhizome

Nineteen ingredients in total. Chop and pound the fourteen ingredients, sift, and separately grind the jujube paste to mix with the powder. Then blend with the various marrows and honey until well combined. Place in a bronze vessel and decoct in a steamer with boiling water until it can be formed into pills the size of firmiana seeds. Take 30 pills with wine, gradually increasing to 40 pills, twice daily.

**Heart and Small Intestine Both Vacuous**
When the yin and yang pulses at the *renying* position of the left *cunkou* are both vacuous, it pertains to the hand lesser yin and greater yang channels both being vacuous. The patient suffers from watery diarrhea, cold limbs, counterflow, and intestinal impediment. This is called heart and small intestine both vacuous.

**Major Supplement the Heart Decoction**
Treats vacuity detriment and insufficiency, weak heart *qi* with palpitations, or occasional delirium, emaciation of the four limbs, altered *qi* and strength, and a lackluster complexion. The formula:
- 1 *liang* each of scutellaria root and aconite
- 3 *liang* each of licorice root, poria, ophiopogon root, dried rehmannia root, cinnamon bark, and donkey-hide gelatin
- 4 *liang* each of pinellia rhizome, polygala root, and gypsum
- 6 *liang* of fresh ginger
- 1 *jin* of malt sugar
- 20 jujubes

Fourteen ingredients in total. Take thirteen ingredients, chop, and boil in 1 *dou* 5 *sheng* of water to obtain 5 *sheng*. When the decoction is ready, add the malt sugar and divide into four doses.

**Supplement the Heart Pill**
Treats visceral vacuity with frequent terror as if in a nightmare, and in women, postpartum residual illnesses and menstrual irregularities. The formula:
- 1 *liang* each of Chinese angelica root, saposhnikovia root, chuanxiong rhizome, aconite, peony root, licorice root, Sichuan pepper, dried ginger, asarum herb, cinnamon bark, pinellia rhizome, magnolia bark, rhubarb, and polyporus
- 2 *liang* each of poria (or poria with hostwood) and polygala root

Sixteen ingredients in total. Grind into powder and form into pills with honey the size of firmiana seeds. Take 5 pills with wine, three times daily, increasing to 10 pills if no effect is observed. For extreme cold, add heating medicinals.

---

**Discourse on Heart Taxation, Third**
**Formulas**

The discourse states: In heart taxation disease, supplement the spleen *qi* to benefit it. When the spleen is effulgent, it will resonate with the heart.

If one goes against summer *qi*, the hand greater yang will fail to grow, and heart *qi* will internally become hollow. Following it brings life; opposing it brings death. Following it brings order; opposing it brings chaos. Reversing compliance into opposition is called block and repulsion, and disease arises.

**Rhubarb Drain Heat Decoction**
Treats heart taxation heat, mouth sores, difficulty with defecation, constipation and blockage, heart fullness and pain, and small intestinal heat. The formula:
- 3 *liang* each of rhubarb, alisma rhizome, scutellaria root, mirabilite, and gardenia fruit
- 2 *liang* each of cinnamon bark and rice-paper plant pith
- 8 *liang* of gypsum
- 1 *liang* of licorice root
- 20 jujubes

Ten ingredients in total. Chop and soak the rhubarb in 1 *sheng* of water overnight. Boil the remaining eight ingredients in 8 *sheng* of water to obtain 2 *sheng* 5 *ge*, then discard the dregs. Add the rhubarb and boil for two more simmerings, discard the dregs, then add the mirabilite and dissolve. Divide into three doses.

**Sun Zhenren’s *Essential Prescriptions Worth a Thousand in Gold*, Scroll Forty, End**

**Sun Zhenren’s *Essential Prescriptions Worth a Thousand in Gold*, Scroll Forty-One**

---

**Pulse and Diagnosis:**
The pulse is *xian* (wiry) and *ku* (bitter). When examining, if the pulse is large and replete, it indicates the qi is not settled, and heat is present. The viscera and bowels, both internal and external, are affected. If the pulse at *mao* (5–7 a.m.) is victorious, it is like a game of *boqi* (a board game); if it follows the sequence, it is favorable. If the liver pulse is replete, the small intestine is affected; if the heart pulse is replete, the lung is affected.

**Formulas:**

1. **Powder for Harmonizing the Liver and Gallbladder**
   - 3 *liang* each of bupleurum root, scutellaria root, poria, and licorice root
   - 2 *liang* each of cinnamon bark and ginger
   - 10 jujubes

   Ten ingredients in total. Pound into powder, take 2 *qian* per dose with warm water, three times daily.

2. **Poria Spirit Decoction**
   - 3 *liang* each of poria, ginseng, atractylodes rhizome, and licorice root
   - 2 *liang* of ginger
   - 20 jujubes

   Eight ingredients in total. Pound into coarse powder, take 3 *qian* per dose, boil in 1 *sheng* of water to obtain 5 *ge*, discard the dregs, and consume warm.

3. **Powder for Nourishing the Liver and Gallbladder**
   - 3 *liang* each of bupleurum root, scutellaria root, poria, and licorice root
   - 2 *liang* each of cinnamon bark and ginger
   - 12 *zhu* of schisandra fruit
   - 1 *liang* of jujube kernels (roasted until firm)
   - 5 *liang* of rice-paper plant pith
   - 24 jujubes

   Eleven ingredients in total. Pound into powder, take 2 *qian* per dose with warm water, three times daily.

4. **Decoction for Liver Deficiency and Heat**
   - 3 *liang* each of bupleurum root, scutellaria root, and licorice root
   - 2 *liang* each of cinnamon bark, ginger, and rice-paper plant pith
   - 30 *zhu* each of jujube kernels (roasted) and schisandra fruit
   - 1 *sheng* of maltose
   - 14 jujubes

   Ten ingredients in total. Boil in 2 *sheng* of water to obtain 8 *ge*, discard the dregs, and divide into three doses.

**Sun Zhenren’s *Essential Prescriptions Worth a Thousand in Gold*, Scroll Forty-One, End**

**Heart Zang Prescriptions**
*Pulse Extremities, Fourth Discourse – Formulas and Moxibustion Methods*

The discourse states: All cases of pulse extremity pertain to the heart. The heart corresponds to the pulse, and pulse and heart are conjoined; thus, when the heart is afflicted, illness arises from the pulse.

It is further said: When illness is encountered in summer, it is termed *pulse impediment*. If pulse impediment persists and is again assailed by pathogenic influence, it lodges internally in the heart, resulting in food failing to nourish the muscles and skin, coughing with blood loss, a pallid and lustreless complexion, and a hollow, vacuous pulse. The lips manifest a reddish hue.

Whenever pulse qi declines, the blood desiccates and hair falls out. If contracted on a *bing* or *ding* day in summer due to wind damage to the pulse, it is termed *heart wind*. The symptoms of heart wind include profuse sweating and aversion to wind. If the pulse qi is replete, heat arises; heat injures the heart, causing irritability, a reddish facial hue, and in severe cases, sluggish speech. With blood depletion, the complexion becomes parched and lustreless, and food fails to nourish the muscles and skin. If the pulse qi is vacuous, cold arises; cold induces cough, cough induces heart pain, and the throat feels obstructed as if choked. In severe cases, the throat swells and becomes impeded. Thus, it is called heart wind—a condition of vacuity and repletion.

When the yang channel pulse is afflicted, treat the yin network vessels; when the yin network vessels are afflicted, treat the yang channel. Stabilize the blood and qi, each guarding its domain. For replete pulses, draining is appropriate; for qi vacuity, supplementation is suitable.

The skilled physician stabilizes vacuity and repletion and treats accordingly to achieve cure. If the illness resides in the skin, hair, muscles, flesh, sinews, or vessels, complete recovery is possible. If it reaches the six bowels or five viscera, half are doomed to die.

Bian Que stated: If the pulse is cut off, the patient will die within three days. How is this known? When pulse qi is hollow and vacuous, the complexion withers and hair falls out. The pulse corresponds to the hand *shaoyin*; when hand *shaoyin* qi is cut off, the pulse ceases to flow, and the blood dies first.

**Fresh Rehmannia Decoction**
*Treats pulse heat extremity with blood and qi depletion, a pallid and parched complexion lacking lustre, and food failing to nourish the muscles and skin. Clears heat, checks extremity, and fortifies stomach qi.*

- 1 *sheng* each of fresh rehmannia juice, fresh ophiopogon, and red honey
- 1 *sheng* of water shield (or fermented soybean, variant)
- 2 *sheng* of polygala root
- 2 *liang* of licorice root
- 3 *liang* each of ginseng, poria, dried rehmannia, peony, and atractylodes
- 6 *liang* of gypsum
- 4 *liang* of fresh Solomon’s seal

Eleven ingredients in total. Chop the eleven ingredients, boil in 1 *dou* 2 *sheng* of water to obtain 2 *sheng* 7 *ge*, discard the dregs, add rehmannia juice and honey, and decoct further to obtain 3 *sheng* 5 *ge*. Divide into four doses.

**Moxibustion Methods**
For chest pain radiating to the waist and back, with retching and counterflow, and a complexion lacking moisture, moxa *Shangmen* (Upper Gate) with cones corresponding to the patient’s age. The point lies beside *Juque* (Great Tower Gate), half a *cun* (or one *cun*, variant) on either side.

For a withered, parched complexion, taxation qi, and essence loss, with shoulder and arm pain preventing elevation to the head, moxa *Jianyu* (Shoulder Bone) with one hundred cones. The point lies at the outer head of the shoulder, near the rear; when pressed, a depression is felt.

---

**Pulse Vacuity and Repletion, Fifth Discourse – Formulas and Acupuncture-Moxibustion Methods**

The discourse states: All cases of pulse vacuity manifest as frequent startling and restlessness; pulse repletion manifests as surging fullness.

The correspondence of pulse vacuity and repletion pertains to the heart and small intestine. If the bowels or viscera are afflicted, heat generates illness corresponding to the viscera, while cold corresponds to the bowels.

**Ledebouriella Pill**
*Supplements vacuity, harmonizes the center, and treats pulse vacuity with startling and restlessness, sudden onset and departure, and cold in the small intestine bowel.*

- 3 *liang* each of ledebouriella root, cinnamon bark, rice-paper plant pith, poria spirit, polygala root, ophiopogon, licorice root, ginseng, and white quartz

Nine ingredients in total. Grind into powder, blend with white honey, and form pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take thirty pills with wine, twice daily, increasing to forty pills.

**Cimicifuga Decoction**
*Treats pulse repletion with surging fullness and heart heat illness.*

- 3 *liang* each of cimicifuga, scutellaria, alisma, gardenia seed, and bland bamboo leaf
- 1 *sheng* of fresh rehmannia (sliced)

Seven ingredients in total. Chop, boil in 9 *sheng* of water to obtain 3 *sheng*, discard the dregs, add 3 *liang* of mirabilite, and divide into three doses.

**Ephedra Decoction**
*Harmonizes the heart, drains heat, and treats heart pulse reversal with surging at the *cunkou*, small intestine heat, tooth decay, and throat pain.*

- 4 *liang* each of ephedra and fresh ginger
- 3 *liang* each of asarum, scutellaria, poria, and peony
- 2 *liang* of atractylodes
- 1 *liang* of cinnamon bark
- 1 *sheng* of fresh rehmannia (sliced)

Nine ingredients in total. Chop, boil in 9 *sheng* of water to obtain 3 *sheng*, discard the dregs, and divide into three doses. For urgent relief, add 3 *liang* of mirabilite; this is most effective.

**Acupuncture-Moxibustion Methods**
For pulse failure to emerge, needle *Burong* (Not Contained). The point lies 1.5 *cun* on either side of *Youmen* (Dark Gate).

For heart oppression and pain with counterflow qi pulling on the small intestine, moxa *Juque* (Great Tower Gate) with fourteen cones.

---

**Heart and Abdominal Pain, Sixth Discourse – Formulas, Steaming-Fomentation, and Moxibustion Methods**

The discourse states: When cold qi suddenly invades the five viscera and six bowels, it causes sudden heart pain and chest impediment. If the cold is mild, it induces cough; if severe, it causes pain and diarrhea.

*Reversal heart pain* drawing the back, with frequent convulsions, as if an object strikes the heart from behind, and the body stoops—this is *kidney heart pain*.

*Reversal heart pain* with abdominal distention and fullness, and severe heart pain—this is *stomach heart pain*.

*Reversal heart pain* as if a needle or awl pierces the heart, with severe heart pain—this is *spleen heart pain*.

*Reversal heart pain* with a pallid, ashen complexion like death, and inability to sigh deeply all day—this is *liver heart pain*.

*Reversal heart pain* where lying down causes pain from within the heart, and movement exacerbates the pain, with no change in complexion—this is *lung heart pain*.

*True heart pain* causes cold in the hands and feet extending to the joints, with severe heart pain. If it arises in the morning, death comes by evening; if it arises in the evening, death comes by morning.

*Roundworm heart pain* manifests as pain in the heart and abdomen, with intermittent swelling and gatherings that move up and down, pain with remissions, internal heat, and profuse drooling—this is roundworm biting.

Press firmly with the hand and hold steadfastly to prevent movement, then pierce with a large needle and hold it there for a long time. When the worm ceases to move, withdraw the needle.

The area beneath the heart must not be needled. Where there is a formed accumulation, the *shu*-points must not be selected.

For roundworms biting within the intestines, none may be treated with small needles.

**Formula for treating sudden heart pain caused by cold-heat qi invading the five viscera and six bowels:**

*Rhubarb (Dà Huáng)*, *Peony (Sháo Yào)*, and *Bupleurum (Chái Hú)*—four liǎng each;
*Cimicifuga (Shēng Má)*, *Scutellaria (Huáng Qín)*, *Platycodon (Jié Gěng)*, and *Cinnabar (Zhū Shā)*—three liǎng each;
*Ghost Arrow Feather (Guǐ Jiàn Yǔ)*, *Ghost Parsley (Guǐ Jiù)*, *Cinnamon Bark (Guì Xīn)*, and *Mirabilite (Pò Xiāo)*—two liǎng each.

The eleven ingredients above are cut and decocted in nine *shēng* of water until reduced to two *shēng* and seven *gé*. Divide into three doses. First, divide the *Cinnabar* into three portions, adding one portion to each dose and stirring well before administration.

If relief is obtained but the pain persists, the following formula is appropriate:

*Red Peony (Chì Sháo Yào)*—six liǎng;
*Platycodon (Jié Gěng)* and *Apricot Kernel (Xìng Rén)*—five liǎng each.

The three ingredients above are cut and decocted in six *shēng* of water until reduced to three *shēng*, then divided into three doses.

**Nine Pains Pill (Jiǔ Tòng Wán)**, for treating nine kinds of heart pain and also curing cold surging upward with qi, injuries from falls from horses or carriages, and blood disorders:

1. *Roundworm heart pain*
2. *Affliction heart pain*
3. *Wind heart pain*
4. *Palpitating heart pain*
5. *Food heart pain*
6. *Drink heart pain*
7. *Cold heart pain*
8. *Heat heart pain*
9. *Intermittent heart pain*

These are the nine pains.

*Aconite (Fù Zǐ)* and *Dried Ginger (Gān Jiāng)*—two liǎng each;
*Evodia (Wú Zhū Yú)*, *Ginseng (Rén Shēn)*, and *Croton (Bā Dòu)*—one liǎng each;
*Raw Wolfsbane (Shēng Láng Dú)*—four liǎng.

The six ingredients above are ground into powder and mixed with honey to form pills the size of *wu-tong* seeds.

Take one pill on an empty stomach. For sudden affliction with abdominal distension and pain, or inability to speak, take two pills once daily. For chronic cold accumulation flowing into the heart and chest over many years, take this remedy, rest well, and it will prove divinely effective.

**Remedy for Nine Kinds of Heart Pain:**
Take a handful of newly sprouted sophora branches from the direction of the Grand Year Star, remove both ends, break into pieces, and boil in three *shēng* of water until reduced to one *shēng*. Drink the decoction in one dose.

**Cinnamon Heart Three-Ingredient Decoction (Guì Xīn Sān Wù Tāng)**, for treating heart obstruction and various severe, suspended pains:
*Cinnamon (Guì Xīn)* and *Fresh Ginger (Shēng Jiāng)*—two liǎng each;
*Maltose (Jiāo Yí)*—half a jīn.
Of the three ingredients above, take two, break into pieces, and boil in six *shēng* of water until reduced to three *shēng*. Strain, add maltose, and divide into three doses.
*Master Zhāng* used five pieces of *Immature Bitter Orange (Zhǐ Shí)* instead of maltose; *Emergency Formulas to Keep Up One’s Sleeve* uses five pieces of *Immature Bitter Orange Root (Gēn Shí)* and two liǎng of *White Atractylodes (Bái Zhú)*, making five ingredients.

**Aconite Pill (Wū Tóu Yuán)**, for treating heart pain piercing to the back and back pain piercing to the heart:
*Monkshood (Wū Tóu)*—six *zhū*;
*Aconite (Fù Zǐ)*—half a liǎng;
*Sichuan Pepper (Shǔ Jiāo)*—half a liǎng;
*Dried Ginger (Gān Jiāng)* and *Halloysite (Chì Shí Zhī)*—one liǎng each.
Grind the five ingredients above into powder and form into pills the size of sesame seeds with honey. Take three pills before meals, three times daily. If no effect, gradually increase the dose.
*The Fan-Wang Collection* omits aconite, using three pills the size of *wu-tong* seeds; *Master Cuī’s* version adds half a liǎng of *Cinnamon (Guì Xīn)*, making six ingredients.

**Remedy for Heart Pain:**
Boil *White Peach Bark (Táo Bái Pí)* to make a decoction and drink on an empty stomach as desired. *Master Cuī’s* version uses it to treat *zhù* heart pain.

**Remedy for Sudden Heart Pain**, resembling demonic affliction with uncontrollable drooling and repeated vomiting:
*Lightyellow Sophora Root (Kǔ Shēn)*—ten jīn.
Break into pieces, boil in one *dàn* of water until reduced to two *dǒu*, strain, add two *dǒu* of bitter vinegar, and simmer until reduced to five *shēng*. Stir in roasted *Soybean (Dà Dòu)* powder and cook until the mixture can be formed into pills. Roll by hand into pills the size of *wu-tong* seeds. Take thirty to forty pills with one *shēng* of wine once daily. This should induce vomiting or diarrhea; if not, soak two jīn of *Lightyellow Sophora Root* in wine for an extended period—longer is better. This remedy not only treats sudden pain but also pains in the liver, bones, and *zhù*, as well as all abdominal disorders. It also cures chronic cold, blood stasis, and yin-type masses, proving highly effective with repeated use.

**Running Horse Decoction (Zǒu Mǎ Tāng)**, for treating demonic affliction with heart pain, abdominal distension, and constipation:
*Croton (Bā Dòu)*—two seeds;
*Apricot Kernel (Xìng Rén)*—two pieces.
Wrap the two ingredients above in silk, crush finely, and place in a small cup with two *gé* of hot water. Dip two fingers to extract the white juice until exhausted. Drink in one dose; relief will follow within the time it takes to eat a meal. Adjust dosage for the elderly and children. Also treats sudden *shàn* pain, flying corpse, and ghost strikes.

**Remedy for Sudden Demonic Affliction with Heart Pain:**
*Lightyellow Sophora Root (Kǔ Shēn)*—three liǎng.
Break into pieces and boil in one and a half *shēng* of good vinegar until reduced to eight *gé*. Strong individuals should drink in one dose; the elderly and children should divide into two doses.

**Alternative Remedy:**
*Cinnamon (Guì Xīn)*—one liǎng.
Break into pieces, boil in four *shēng* of water until reduced to one and a half *shēng*, and divide into three doses.

**Remedy for Worm-Induced Heart Pain:**
Grind *Carpesium Fruit (Hè Shī)* into powder and form into pills the size of *wu-tong* seeds with honey. Take forty pills with honey water once daily; the dose may be increased to fifty pills. Avoid wine and meat.

**Alternative Remedy:**
Grind one liǎng of *Carpesium Fruit* into powder, mix with one cup of warm vinegar, and take on an empty stomach to induce vomiting of worms.

**Alternative Remedy:**
Take one *gé* of *Lacquer (Qī)*.

For the remedies, refer to the *Nourishing Life and Ingesting Elixirs* section. All cases of worm-induced heart pain may be treated with *lacquer (qī)*.

**Five Pungents Decoction (Wǔ Xīn Tāng)**, a remedy for cold pain in the heart and abdomen:
*Asarum (Xì Xīn)*, *Sichuan Pepper (Shǔ Jiāo)*, *Cinnamon (Guì Xīn)*, *Dried Ginger (Gān Jiāng)*, *Evodia Fruit (Wú Zhū Yú)*, *Peony (Sháo Yào)*, *Saposhnikovia (Fáng Fēng)*, *Flavescent Sophora (Kǔ Shēn)*, *Licorice (Gān Cǎo)*, *Dried Rehmannia (Gān Dì Huáng)*, and *Chinese Angelica (Dāng Guī)*—one liǎng each; *Gardenia (Zhī Zǐ)*, *Mume Fruit (Wū Méi)*, and *Jujube (Dà Zǎo)*—fourteen pieces each.
Grind the fourteen ingredients, boil in nine *shēng* of water until reduced to three *shēng*, and divide into four doses.

**Rhinoceros Horn Pill (Xī Jiǎo Yuán)**, a remedy for chronic heart and abdominal pain persisting for years, recurring unpredictably—sometimes within hours, sometimes lasting days without the ability to eat. Even when passing dried blood, no remedy under heaven could cure it until Zhēn Lìyán devised this formula, which brings recovery within days:
*Rhinoceros Horn (Xī Jiǎo)*, *Musk (Shè Xiāng)*, *Realgar (Xióng Huáng)*, *Platycodon (Jié Gěng)*, *Falsehellebore (Mǎng Cǎo)*, *Ghost Umbrella (Guǐ Jiù)*, *Cinnamon (Guì Xīn)*, *Genkwa Flower (Yuán Huā)*—one and a half liǎng each; *Kansui Root (Gān Suì)*—one and a half liǎng; *Cinnabar (Guāng Míng Shā)* and *Aconite (Fù Zǐ)*—six *zhū* each; *Cowrie Shell (Bèi Chǐ)*—five pieces; *Croton Seed (Bā Dòu)*—twenty pieces; *Red-Legged Centipede (Chì Zú Wú Gōng)*—two pieces.
Grind the fourteen ingredients into powder, form into pills the size of *wu-tong* seeds with honey, and take one pill with water twice daily, gradually increasing to three pills until mild purgation is achieved.
*Note: The* Ancient and Modern Proven Formulas *(Gǔ Jīn Lù Yàn) omits* Realgar*.*

**Galangal Decoction (Gāo Liáng Jiāng Tāng)**, a remedy for sudden colicky pain in the heart and abdomen as if stabbed, with fullness in the flanks and unbearable vexation:
*Galangal (Gāo Liáng Jiāng)*—five liǎng; *Magnolia Bark (Hòu Pò)*—two liǎng; *Chinese Angelica (Dāng Guī)* and *Cinnamon (Guì Xīn)*—three liǎng each.
Grind the four ingredients, boil in eight *shēng* of water until reduced to one *shēng* and eight *gé*, and divide into three doses, taken twice daily. If the pain ceases after one dose, discontinue; do not take more. Strong individuals may take two doses; the weak may divide into three.

**Chinese Angelica Decoction (Dāng Guī Tāng)**, a remedy for colicky pain in the heart and abdomen, with various types of deficiency-cold *qi* causing fullness and pain:
*Chinese Angelica (Dāng Guī)*, *Peony (Sháo Yào)*, *Magnolia Bark (Hòu Pò)*, and *Pinellia (Bàn Xià)*—two liǎng each; *Cinnamon (Guì Xīn)*, *Licorice (Gān Cǎo)*, *Astragalus (Huáng Qí)*, and *Ginseng (Rén Shēn)*—three liǎng each; *Dried Ginger (Gān Jiāng)*—four liǎng; *Sichuan Pepper (Shǔ Jiāo)*—one liǎng.
Grind the ten ingredients, boil in one *dǒu* of water until reduced to three *shēng* and two *gé*, and divide into four doses. For the frail, divide into six doses.
*Note: The* Minor Formulas *(Xiǎo Pǐn Fāng) states: For severe cold, add one piece of* Aconite *(Fù Zǐ). This is effective.*

**Remedy for dull, lingering pain in the heart and abdomen:**
*Peony (Sháo Yào)*—six liǎng; *Scutellaria (Huáng Qín)*, *Mirabilite (Pò Xiāo)*, *Platycodon (Jié Gěng)*, and *Bupleurum (Chái Hú)*—four liǎng each; *Chinese Angelica (Dāng Guī)* and *Cimicifuga (Shēng Má)*—three liǎng each.
Grind the seven ingredients, boil in eight *shēng* of water until reduced to two and a half *shēng*, and divide into three doses.

**Alternative Remedy for deficiency-cold abdominal pain with inability to eat, indigestion, and bloating:**
*Chinese Angelica (Dāng Guī)* and *Poria (Fú Líng)*—five *fēn* each; *Astragalus (Huáng Qí)* and *Purple Aster (Zǐ Wǎn)*—four *fēn* each; *Galangal (Gāo Liáng Jiāng)* and *Dried Ginger (Gān Jiāng)*—six *fēn* each; *Deer Velvet (Lù Róng)*, *Cinnamon (Guì Xīn)*, *Kelp (Kūn Bù)*, *Cistanche (Ròu Cōng Róng)*, and *Tangerine Peel (Jú Pí)*—three *fēn* each; *Licorice (Gān Cǎo)*—two liǎng; *Aconite (Wū Tóu)*—one liǎng; *Jujube (Dà Zǎo)*—forty pieces; *Peach Kernel (Táo Rén)*—one hundred pieces; *Wolfberry Root Bark (Dì Gǔ Pí)*, *Fermented Leaven (Fǎ Qū)*, and *Malt (Dà Mài Niè)*—one *shēng* each.
Grind the eighteen ingredients, boil in one *dǒu* and five *shēng* of water until reduced to four *shēng* and two *gé*, and divide into five doses.
*For diarrhea, add* Halloysite *(Chì Shí Zhī)* and *Dragon Bone (Lóng Gǔ)*—three *fēn* each. *For thirst, add* Ophiopogon *(Mài Mén Dōng)*—one *shēng.*

**Alternative Remedy for cold abdominal pain (known in the *Minor Formulas* as *Evodia Decoction (Wú Zhū Yú Tāng)):**
*Chinese Angelica (Dāng Guī)*—two liǎng; *Cinnamon (Guì Xīn)*, *Licorice (Gān Cǎo)*, and *Ginseng (Rén Shēn)*—one liǎng each; *Fresh Ginger (Shēng Jiāng)*—five liǎng; *Pinellia (Bàn Xià)* and *Wheat (Xiǎo Mài)*—one *shēng* each; *Evodia Fruit (Wú Zhū Yú)*—two *shēng*.
Grind the eight ingredients, boil in one *dǒu* and five *shēng* of water until reduced to three *shēng*, and divide into three doses, taken thrice daily.
*Also treats deficiency-cold after childbirth.*

**Alternative Remedy for cold *qi* surging from the flanks into the chest and diaphragm, causing pain radiating to the flanks and back with oppression:**
*Chinese Angelica (Dāng Guī)*, *Cinnamon (Guì Xīn)*, *Ginseng (Rén Shēn)*, *Licorice (Gān Cǎo)*, *Evodia Fruit (Wú Zhū Yú)*, *Peony (Sháo Yào)*, and *Rhubarb (Dà Huáng)*—two liǎng each; *Poria (Fú Líng)* and *Immature Bitter Orange (Zhǐ Shí)*—one liǎng each; *Dried Ginger (Gān Jiāng)*—three liǎng.
Grind the ten ingredients, boil in eight *shēng* of water until reduced to two and a half *shēng*, and divide into three doses, taken thrice daily.
*Also effective for* corpse infection *(Shī Zhù).*
*Note: The* Outer Terrace *(Wài Tái) and* Zhongjing’s Formulas *omit* Poria *and* Immature Bitter Orange*.*

**Alternative Remedy for chronic cold conditions with pain in the chest and abdomen and intermittent diarrhea:**
*Chinese Angelica (Dāng Guī)*—three liǎng; *Licorice (Gān Cǎo)* and *Tangerine Peel (Jú Pí)*—two liǎng each; *Aconite (Fù Zǐ)*—one liǎng; *Dried Ginger (Gān Jiāng)*—four liǎng.
Grind the five ingredients, boil in eight *shēng* of water until reduced to two *shēng*, and divide into three doses, taken thrice daily.

**Alternative Remedy for chronic cold with pain in the chest and abdomen, shortness of breath, and intermittent diarrhea:**
*Chinese Angelica (Dāng Guī)* and *Cinnamon (Guì Xīn)*—three liǎng each; *Dried Ginger (Gān Jiāng)*—four liǎng; *Aconite (Fù Zǐ)*—one liǎng.
Grind the four ingredients, boil in eight *shēng* of water until reduced to two *shēng*, and divide into three doses, taken thrice daily.
*Note: The* Fan Wang *formula omits* Aconite *and uses* Licorice *—two liǎng. For severe cold pain, add* Astragalus *(Huáng Qí) and* Peony *(Sháo Yào)*—two liǎng each.*

**Warming the Center Chinese Angelica Decoction (Wēn Zhōng Dāng Guī Tāng)**, a remedy for pain in the heart and abdomen with intermittent swelling and masses that move up and down, accompanied by heat, excessive saliva, and *roundworm* bites:
After two or three doses, if ineffective or symptoms differ, adjust the formula accordingly.
*Chinese Angelica (Dāng Guī)*, *Ginseng (Rén Shēn)*, *Dried Ginger (Gān Jiāng)*, *Poria (Fú Líng)*, *Magnolia Bark (Hòu Pò)*, *Costus Root (Mù Xiāng)*, *Cinnamon (Guì Xīn)*, *Platycodon (Jié Gěng)*, *Peony (Sháo Yào)*, and *Licorice (Gān Cǎo)*—two liǎng each.
Grind the ten ingredients, boil in eight *shēng* of water until reduced to three *shēng*, and divide into five warm doses, taken thrice daily.
*For those intolerant to* Costus Root*, substitute with one liǎng of* Rhinoceros Horn *(Xī Jiǎo).*

**Modified Chinese Angelica Decoction (Zēng Sǔn Dāng Guī Tāng)**, a remedy for dull, lingering pain in the heart and abdomen:
*Chinese Angelica (Dāng Guī)* and *Cimicifuga (Shēng Má)*—three liǎng each; *Peony (Sháo Yào)*, *Scutellaria (Huáng Qín)*, *Mirabilite (Pò Xiāo)*, *Platycodon (Jié Gěng)*, and *Bupleurum (Chái Hú)*—four liǎng each.

Grind the seven ingredients, boil in eight *shēng* of water until reduced to two and a half *shēng*, and divide into three doses.

**Mutton and Chinese Angelica Decoction (Yáng Ròu Dāng Guī Tāng)**, a remedy for cold-induced gripping abdominal pain:
Half a *jīn* of mutton; four *fēn* of *Chinese Angelica (Dāng Guī)*; two *fēn* each of *Dried Ginger (Gān Jiāng)*, *Tangerine Peel (Jú Pí)*, *Astragalus (Huáng Qí)*, *Peony (Sháo Yào)*, *Chuanxiong (Xiōng Qióng)*, *Cinnamon (Guì Xīn)*, *Angelica Pubescens (Dú Huó)*, and *Saposhnikovia (Fáng Fēng)*; one *fēn* each of *Evodia Fruit (Wú Zhū Yú)*, *Ginseng (Rén Shēn)*, *Licorice (Gān Cǎo)*, *Rehmannia (Gān Dì Huáng)*, and *Poria (Fú Líng)*; six *fēn* of *Fresh Ginger (Shēng Jiāng)*; and over thirty *Chinese Dates (Dà Zǎo)*.
Grind the seventeen ingredients, first boil the mutton in one and a half *dǒu* of water until reduced to one *dǒu* and two *shēng*, remove the mutton, add the remaining ingredients, and boil until reduced to three *shēng*. Divide into three doses, taken thrice daily. Keep the patient warmly covered.

**Warming the Spleen Decoction (Wēn Pí Tāng)**, a remedy for abdominal pain, gripping pain below the navel, and persistent pain around the navel:
Two *liǎng* each of *Licorice (Gān Cǎo)*, *Aconite (Fù Zǐ)*, and *Ginseng (Rén Shēn)*; two *liǎng* of *Mirabilite (Máng Xiāo)*; three *liǎng* each of *Chinese Angelica (Dāng Guī)* and *Dried Ginger (Gān Jiāng)*; and five *liǎng* of *Rhubarb (Dà Huáng)*.
Grind the seven ingredients, boil in seven *shēng* of water until reduced to three *shēng*, and divide into doses, taken thrice daily.

**Fresh Ginger Decoction (Shēng Jiāng Tāng)**, a remedy for sudden pain in the chest and abdomen:
One *jīn* of fresh ginger (juiced); eight *liǎng* of *Honey (Shí Mì)*; and four *liǎng* of *Ghee (Tí Hú)*.
Simmer the three ingredients over low heat until well combined. Take three *gě* warm, thrice daily.

**Hot Compress and Steaming Method (Yùn Zhēng Fǎ)**, for cold-induced pain in the heart and abdomen:
Heat one *dǒu* of salt for a hot compress, or steam with heated silkworm sand or bricks. Wrap the compress to retain warmth. Steaming with earth is also highly effective.

**Acupuncture and Moxibustion Methods (Zhēn Jiǔ Fǎ)**:
When pathogenic qi lodges in the heart, it causes heart pain, frequent sorrow, and occasional dizziness or fainting. Assess excess or deficiency and regulate the corresponding *shū* points.
- For kidney-related heart pain, first needle *Jīnggǔ* and *Kūnlún*; if unresolved, needle *Rángǔ*.
- For stomach-related heart pain, needle *Dàdū* and *Tàibái*.
- For spleen-related heart pain, needle *Rángǔ* and *Tàixī*.
- For liver-related heart pain, needle *Xíngjiān* and *Tàichōng*.
- For lung-related heart pain, needle *Yújì* and *Tàiyuān*.
- For heart pain radiating to the lower back with nausea, needle the foot *Shàoyīn* meridian.
- For heart pain radiating to the back with breathlessness, needle the foot *Shàoyīn* meridian; if unresolved, needle the hand *Shàoyīn* meridian.
- For heart pain with abdominal distension, rough bowel movements, and constipation, needle the foot *Tàiyīn* meridian.
- For heart pain with lower abdominal fullness, wandering pain, and difficulty urinating, needle the foot *Juéyīn* meridian.
- For heart pain with shortness of breath, needle the hand *Tàiyīn* meridian.
- For unbearable heart pain with restlessness, *Jùquè* governs it.
- For heart pain with three worms, excessive salivation, and inability to turn over, *Shàngguǎn* governs it.
- For heart pain with cold body, difficulty bending, heart *shàn* pain with fainting, and loss of consciousness, *Zhōngguǎn* governs it.
- For piercing heart pain, *Rángǔ* and *Tàixī* govern it.
- For sudden heart and abdominal pain, *Shímén* governs it.
- For sudden heart *shàn* pain, needle the foot *Tàiyīn* meridian.
- For heart vexation, mild pain, and counterflow, moxa the heart *shū* point with one hundred cones.
- For stabbing heart pain with qi stagnation, moxa the diaphragm *shū* point with seven cones.
- For heart pain with cold qi cessation, moxa *Lónghàn* with one hundred cones, located one and a half *cùn* above the *Jiūwěi* point; do not needle.
- For heart pain with rising malign qi, hypochondriac tension, and pain, moxa *Tōnggǔ* with fifty cones, located two *cùn* below the nipple.
- For sudden, severe heart pain with impending death, moxa *Shénfǔ* with one hundred cones, located at the *Jiūwěi* point in the center of the heart; observe precautions.
- For sudden heart pain with aversion to wind, moxa *Jùquè* with one hundred cones.
- For heart pain with firm vexation and qi stagnation, moxa *Tàicāng* with one hundred cones.
- For heart pain, moxa the transverse crease of the wrist with twenty-one cones, and moxa the white flesh at the junction of both *hǔkǒu* with seven cones.

**Chapter Seven: Chest Impediment (Xiōng Bì) – Formulas and Moxibustion Methods**

The *Discourse* states: Chest impediment causes firm fullness and urgent pain in the heart, with numbness and gripping pain in the muscles like stabbing, preventing bending or stretching. The skin over the chest is painful to the touch, the chest feels oppressed and full, breath is short, coughing and spitting induce pain, the throat is obstructed and uncomfortable, with itching sensations, dryness in the throat, occasional nausea, vexation, and copious sweating. In some cases, pain radiates to the back. If left untreated, it may prove fatal within days.

The *Discourse* states: The pulse should be assessed for excess or deficiency. A faint *yáng* pulse and a wiry *yīn* pulse indicate chest impediment with pain. The cause lies in extreme deficiency. Now, *yáng* deficiency indicates the condition is in the upper burner, and chest impediment with heart pain arises because the patient’s pulse is wiry in *yīn*. In healthy individuals without chills or fever, shortness of breath indicates repletion.

**Immature Bitter Orange Decoction (Zhǐ Shí Tāng)**:
Four *Immature Bitter Oranges (Zhǐ Shí)*; one *jīn* of *Longstamen Onion Bulb (Xiè Bái)*; one *liǎng* of *Cinnamon Twig (Guì Zhī)*; three *liǎng* of *Magnolia Bark (Hòu Pò)*; and one *Trichosanthes Fruit (Guā Lóu Shí)*.
Grind the five ingredients, boil in seven *shēng* of water until reduced to two and a half *shēng*, and divide into two doses.
*Master Zhāng’s* formula uses four *liǎng* of *Magnolia Bark*, half a *jīn* of *Longstamen Onion Bulb*, and five *shēng* of water, boiling until reduced to one and a half *shēng* for consumption.

**Trichosanthes Decoction (Guā Lóu Tāng)**, a remedy for chest *wēn* disease with wheezing, coughing, spitting, chest and back pain, shortness of breath, a deep and slow *cùn* pulse, and a slightly tight and rapid *guān* pulse:
One *Trichosanthes Fruit (Guā Lóu Shí)*; half a *shēng* of *Pinellia (Bàn Xià)*; one *jīn* of *Longstamen Onion Bulb (Xiè Bái)*; two *liǎng* of *Immature Bitter Orange (Zhǐ Shí)*; and four *liǎng* of *Fresh Ginger (Shēng Jiāng)*.
Grind the five ingredients, boil in one *dǒu* of *fermented rice water (bái zāi jiāng)* until reduced to four *shēng*, and take one *shēng* thrice daily.
*Master Zhāng* and *Zhǒuhòu* omit *Fresh Ginger*, *Immature Bitter Orange*, and *Pinellia*.

**Tangerine Peel Decoction (Jú Pí Tāng)**, for chest impediment with oppressive fullness, choking obstruction, itching sensations, throat roughness, dryness, and spitting of foam:
One *jīn* of *Tangerine Peel (Jú Pí)*; half a *jīn* of *Fresh Ginger (Shēng Jiāng)*; and five *Immature Bitter Oranges (Zhǐ Shí)*.
Grind the three ingredients, boil in five *shēng* of water until reduced to two *shēng*, strain, and divide into two doses.

**Regulating the Center Decoction (Zhì Zhōng Tāng)**, a formula for chest impediment.
*See separate volume.*

**Poria Decoction (Fú Líng Tāng)**, a formula for chest qi obstruction and shortness of breath:
Three *liǎng* of *Poria (Fú Líng)*; one *liǎng* of *Licorice (Gān Cǎo)*; and fifty *Apricot Kernels (Xìng Rén)*.
Grind the three ingredients, boil in one *dǒu* and three *shēng* of water until reduced to six *shēng*, and strain. Divide into six doses, taking three daily. If unresolved, prepare and take again.

**Qi-Freeing Decoction (Tōng Qì Tāng)**, a formula for chest fullness, shortness of breath, and choking obstruction:
Eight *liǎng* of *Pinellia (Bàn Xià)*; six *liǎng* of *Fresh Ginger (Shēng Jiāng)*; three *liǎng* of *Tangerine Peel (Jú Pí)*; and forty *Evodia Fruits (Wú Zhū Yú)*.
Grind the four ingredients, boil in eight *shēng* of water until reduced to three *shēng*, and divide into three doses. One variant uses two *liǎng* of *Cinnamon Twig (Guì)* and omits *Tangerine Peel*.

**Asarum Powder (Xì Xīn Sǎn)**, a formula for chest impediment radiating to back pain and shortness of breath:
Two *liǎng* each of *Asarum (Xì Xīn)* and *Licorice (Gān Cǎo)*; three *liǎng* each of *Immature Bitter Orange (Zhǐ Shí)*, *Fresh Ginger (Shēng Jiāng)*, *Trichosanthes Fruit (Guā Lóu Shí)*, *Dried Rehmannia (Gān Dì Huáng)*, and *White Atractylodes (Bái Zhú)*; five *liǎng* each of *Cinnamon Heart (Guì Xīn)* and *Poria (Fú Líng)*.
Grind the nine ingredients into a fine powder. Take one square *cùn* spoonful with wine, thrice daily.

**Sichuan Pepper Powder (Shǔ Jiāo Sǎn)**, a formula for chest impediment radiating to the back:
One *liǎng* each of *Sichuan Pepper (Shǔ Jiāo)* and *Food Evodia (Shí Zhū Yú)*; three *liǎng* each of *Cinnamon Heart (Guì Xīn)* and *Platycodon (Jié Gěng)*; half a *liǎng* of *Aconite (Wū Tóu)*; and six *zhū* of *Fermented Soybeans (Chǐ)*.
Grind the six ingredients into a fine powder. Take one square *cùn* spoonful with wine after meals, thrice daily.

**Peucedanum Decoction (Qián Hú Tāng)**, a formula for counterflow qi in the chest, heart pain radiating to the back, shortness of breath, and loss of appetite:
Two *liǎng* each of *Peucedanum (Qián Hú)*, *Licorice (Gān Cǎo)*, *Pinellia (Bàn Xià)*, and *Peony (Sháo Yào)*; one *liǎng* each of *Scutellaria (Huáng Qín)*, *Chinese Angelica (Dāng Guī)*, *Ginseng (Rén Shēn)*, and *Cinnamon Heart (Guì Xīn)*; three *liǎng* of *Fresh Ginger (Shēng Jiāng)*; thirty *Jujubes (Dà Zǎo)*; and one *shēng* of *Bamboo Leaves (Zhú Yè)*.
Grind the eleven ingredients, boil in nine *shēng* of water until reduced to three *shēng*, and divide into four doses.

Another formula:
Three *liǎng* each of *Peucedanum (Qián Hú)*, *Ginseng (Rén Shēn)*, *Fresh Ginger (Shēng Jiāng)*, *Pinellia (Bàn Xià)*, *Ophiopogon (Mài Mén Dōng)*, *Licorice (Gān Cǎo)*, *Peony (Sháo Yào)*, *Poria (Fú Líng)*, and *Malt Sugar (Xíng)*; one *liǎng* each of *Cinnamon Heart (Guì Xīn)*, *Scutellaria (Huáng Qín)*, and *Chinese Angelica (Dāng Guī)*; and thirty *Jujubes (Dà Zǎo)*.
Grind the thirteen ingredients, boil in one *dǒu* and four *shēng* of water until reduced to three *shēng*, strain, and divide into three doses.

**Back-Warming Powder (Yùn Bèi Sǎn)**, a formula for chest and back pain with oppression:
Five *liǎng* each of *Aconite (Wū Tóu)*, *Asarum (Xì Xīn)*, *Prepared Aconite (Fù Zǐ)*, *Notopterygium (Qiāng Huó)*, *Sichuan Pepper (Shǔ Jiāo)*, and *Cinnamon Heart (Guì Xīn)*; one *liǎng* and six *zhū* of *Chuanxiong (Xiōng Qióng)*.
Grind the seven ingredients into a fine powder, wrap in silk, warm over a low fire, and apply as a compress to the back. Discontinue upon resolution. Avoid raw and cold foods as usual.

**Qi-Descending Decoction (Xià Qì Tāng)**, a formula for chest, abdominal, and back fullness with counterflow qi and panting:
Twenty-eight *Apricot Kernels (Xìng Rén)*; fourteen *Areca Nuts (Dà Fù Bīn Láng)*.
Grind the two ingredients, decoct in three *shēng* of boy’s urine until reduced to one and a half *shēng*, and divide into two doses. Prepare and take whenever qi disorders recur.

**Areca Decoction (Bīn Láng Tāng)**, a formula for breaking up malign qi in the chest and back with hoarseness:
Four large *Areca Nuts (Bīn Láng)*, or eight small ones.
Grind the ingredient(s), boil in two and a half *shēng* of boy’s urine until reduced by one *shēng*, strain, and divide into three doses. Administer five doses in succession for lasting resolution.

**Moxibustion Methods:**

For chest impediment radiating to the back with intermittent cold, apply moxibustion at *Jiānshǐ* (PC-5).

For chest impediment with heart pain, apply moxibustion at *Tiānjǐng* (SJ-10).

For chest impediment with heart pain, inability to breathe, and pain without fixed location, apply moxibustion at *Línqì* (GB-15).

For chest impediment with heart pain, apply one hundred cones of moxa at *Shànzhōng* (CV-17), located one *cùn* above *Jiūwěi* (CV-15). Avoid needling.

For fullness in the chest and rib-sides with heart pain, apply moxibustion at *Qīmén* (LR-14) according to the patient’s age in cones. The point is located one and a half *cùn* directly below the nipple, at the end of the second rib.

*Sun Zhenren’s Beiji Qianjin Yaofang*, Scroll Forty-One, concludes here.

**Xiongqiong Wine**
A remedy for brain wind with heavy-headedness, stiff neck, eyes protruding and crossing, frequent yawning, drowsiness, aversion to wind, and in severe cases, tinnitus with fullness, brow and eye pain with oppression, uncontrollable retching, vertigo, and fainting. When various winds exploit deficiency to invade the channels, all five viscera and six bowels may become afflicted with manic madness, and all pathogenic diseases are governed by this formula:

*Xiongqiong* (Chuanxiong) 3 *liang*
*Xinyin* (Magnolia Flower) 3 *liang*
*Tianxiong* (Aconite) 3 *liang*
*Renshen* (Ginseng) 3 *liang*
*Tianmendong* (Asparagus Root) 3 *liang*
*Baiziren* (Arborvitae Seed) 3 *liang*
*Cishi* (Magnetite) 3 *liang*
*Shigao* (Gypsum) 3 *liang*
*Yinyu* (Skimmia) 3 *liang*
*Shanzhuyu* (Cornus Fruit) 3 *liang*
*Baitouweng* (Pulsatilla) 3 *liang*
*Guixin* (Cinnamon Bark) 3 *liang*
*Qinjiao* (Gentian) 3 *liang*
*Songluo* (Usnea) 2 *liang*
*Lingyangjiao* (Antelope Horn) 2 *liang*
*Xixin* (Asarum) 2 *liang*
*Shuyu* (Dioscorea) 2 *liang*
*Changpu* (Acorus) 2 *liang*
*Gancao* (Licorice) 2 *liang*
*Yunmu* (Mica) 1 *liang* (calcined until red, ground to powder)
*Fangfeng* (Saposhnikovia) 4 *liang*

Grind the above twenty-one ingredients, steep in two *dou* of wine for seven days. Begin with a dose of two *ge*, gradually increasing to five *ge*, taken thrice daily.

There was a woman who suffered from wind vertigo since her youth, falling to the ground when it struck. After marriage, she remained childless for many years. Upon taking this wine along with the *Zishi Maimendong Pill*, her vertigo was cured, and she later gave birth to a child and fully recovered. The formula for *Zishi Maimendong Pill* is found in the *Formulas for Women*.

The following fifty-two characters were originally omitted and are restored here according to the Song edition: *"Of the fourteen ingredients above, twelve are to be coarsely cut and simmered with horse mane fat and twelfth-month lard over low heat."* The Song edition reads: *"Of the twelve ingredients above, coarsely cut them and simmer with five *ge* of horse mane fat and three *sheng* of twelfth-month lard over low heat."* Since "horse mane fat" and "lard" are not listed among the ingredients, this has been amended based on textual context and conventions.
11. "Alternative Formula": the Song edition reads *"Formula to Prevent Hair Regrowth."*
12. "White": the Song edition reads "hair."
13. "Two ingredients": the characters *"like powder"* following *"ingredients"* have been deleted according to the Song edition.
14. From *"ninth month"* to the end of this formula, fifty characters were misplaced beneath the fourteen-ingredient *"Formula for Eyebrow and Hair Loss to Regrow Hair"* (after *"three sheng of lard"*). This has been corrected according to the Song edition.
15. *"Formula for Yellowing Sideburns"*: these three characters were originally omitted and are restored here according to the Song edition.

Collated and Corrected by Lin Yi, Gentleman for Court Service and Acting Vice Minister of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices, concurrently serving as Editorial Director of the Secret Pavilion, and others, during the Song Dynasty.

**Formulas for the Small Intestine Repository**
**Discourse on the Small Intestine Repository’s Conduits (Chapter One)**

The discourse states: The small intestine repository governs the heart, and the tongue serves as its indicator. The heart is paired with the small intestine, which is the *receiving and containing* repository, known as the *supervisor of the granary*. It weighs two *jin* and fourteen *liang*, measures two *zhang* and four *chi* in length, and spans two *cun* and four *fen* in breadth. The *Classic of Difficult Issues* and *The Systematic Classic of Acupuncture and Moxibustion* record its length as three *zhang* and two *chi*, its breadth as two *cun* and a half, and its diameter as eight *fen* plus a minor third.

Attached to the spine posteriorly, it coils leftward in overlapping folds. Where it pours into the *returning intestine*, it adheres externally above the navel, revolving in sixteen convolutions. It typically retains two *dou* and four *sheng* of water and grain—one *dou* and two *sheng* being water, and one *dou* and two *sheng* being grain—corresponding to the twenty-four qi. The *Classic of Difficult Issues* states it has sixteen convolutions, holding two *dou* and four *sheng* of grain and six *sheng* plus three *ge* and a major half of water. *The Systematic Classic* records its capacity as three *dou* and three *ge* plus a major half.

The thickness of the lips and the length of the philtrum indicate the condition of the small intestine.

**Small Intestine Disorders**
When the small intestine is afflicted, there is pain in the lower abdomen, the lumbar spine and testicles ache, and one experiences urgency. Heat may also manifest before the ears. In cases of extreme cold, heat arises solely on the shoulders and between the little finger and its adjacent finger. If the pulse is slippery—*The Pulse Classic* renders this as "sunken," and *The Systematic Classic* concurs—this is its sign.

When the lower abdomen tugs at the testicles, drawing pain up the lumbar spine to the heart, and the pathogen resides in the small intestine, it connects to the spermatic cord, attaches to the spine, penetrates the liver and lungs, and binds the heart’s network. When qi flourishes, it surges upward in counterflow, disturbing the intestines and stomach, agitating the liver and lungs, dispersing into the *huang*, and congealing at the navel. Thus, one disperses it by needling the *huang* origin, harmonizes it by needling the *Greater Yin*, drains it by needling the *Terminal Yin*, and expels it by needling the *Lower Ridge of the Great Hollow*. Regulate it by pressing the conduits it traverses.

If the *yang* pulse at the *cun* position before the *guan* on the left hand is absent, the small intestine’s pulse is absent. The patient suffers from navel blockage, *shan* and *jia* masses in the lower abdomen, and in the *king month*, cold ascends to assail the heart. Needle the *Hand Reverting Yin* to treat the *yin*; the *Hand Reverting Yin* is located one *fen* deep in the transverse crease on the palm’s posterior side.

If the *yang* pulse at the *cun* position before the *guan* on the left hand is replete, the small intestine is replete. The patient suffers from urgency below the heart, heat blockage, internal heat in the small intestine, and reddish-yellow urine. Needle the *Hand Greater Yang* to treat the *yang*; the *Hand Greater Yang* is located in the depression at the base of the little finger’s outer side.

When the small intestine has cold, the patient experiences heaviness in the lower body and passes pus and blood in the stool. When it has heat, hemorrhoids necessarily arise. When the small intestine harbors retained food, fever regularly arises at dusk and subsides by dawn.

When the small intestine is distended, the lower abdomen swells and protrudes, drawing pain into the abdomen. When the heart first contracts an illness and transmits it to the small intestine, and the heart’s cough persists, qi and cough emerge together.

When counterflow qi lodges in the small intestine, one dreams of gathering in city streets and thoroughfares.

The heart corresponds to the skin. Where the skin is thick, the vessels are thick, and where the vessels are thick, the small intestine is thick. Where the skin is thin, the vessels are thin, and where the vessels are thin, the small intestine is thin. Where the skin is slack, the vessels are slack, and where the vessels are slack, the small intestine is large and long. Where the skin is thin and the vessels are faint and small, the small intestine is small and short. When all the *yang* conduits are excessively tortuous, the small intestine is knotted.

Bian Que stated: The *Hand Lesser Yin* and *Greater Yang* form an exterior-interior pair. Thus, the exterior is clear and the interior turbid; clarity is replete while turbidity is vacuous. Therefore, when food descends, the intestines are replete while the stomach is vacuous, making the repository replete yet not full. When replete, it is harmed by heat, and with heat, the mouth gapes and sores arise. When vacuous, it is harmed by cold, and with cold, one passes pus and blood in the stool or develops *wrapping water*, its root lying in the small intestine, first arising from the abdomen. The formula is found in the *Treatise on Water* section.

When the small intestine is cut off, it is incurable, and death follows in six days. How does one know this? The hair stands stiff as dry hemp, unable to bend or stretch, and incessant white sweating occurs.

**The Conduit of the Hand Greater Yang**
When it moves, there is pain in the throat, swelling in the jaw, and inability to turn the head. The shoulder feels as if pulled, and the upper arm feels as if broken. It governs the fluids and gives rise to diseases such as deafness, yellowed eyes, swollen cheeks and jaw, and pain along the posterior outer edge of the neck, shoulder, upper arm, elbow, and forearm. The branches and offshoots of the conduit are already recorded in the *Heart Viscus* section.

**Vacuity and Repletion of the Small Intestine (Chapter Two)**
**Pulse and Formulae / Moxibustion**

**Small Intestine Repletion Heat**
When the *yang* pulse before the *renying* at the *cun* position of the left hand is replete, it pertains to the *Hand Greater Yang* conduit. The patient suffers from body heat that comes and goes without sweating, vexation and fullness in the heart, heaviness in the body, and sores in the mouth. This is called *small intestine repletion heat*.

*Bupleurum and Alisma Decoction* treats small intestine heat distension and mouth sores:
Bupleurum, alisma, tangerine peel (substitute with platycodon), scutellaria, inula flower, unripe bitter orange, cimicifuga, and mirabilite—two *liang* each; fresh rehmannia (sliced)—one *sheng*.
Steep the nine ingredients, boil in one *dou* of water to yield three *sheng*, strain, add mirabilite, and divide into three doses.

*Rhubarb Pill* treats small intestine heat binding and fullness with obstruction:
Rhubarb, peony—two *liang* each; tingli seed, kansui—three *liang* each; apricot kernels—fifty pieces; croton seeds—seven pieces.
Grind the seven ingredients into powder, mix with honey, and form pills the size of parasol seeds. Adults take seven pills with water; children take two or three pills, twice daily. Once heat subsides, take once daily.

**Moxibustion**
For small intestine heat fullness, moxa the *Yin Metropolis* with cones corresponding to the patient’s age. The point lies one *cun* lateral to the midline beside the *Middle Conduit*.

For small intestine diarrhea with pus and blood, moxa the *Hun Meeting* with one hundred cones; reduce the number for children. The point lies one *cun* lateral to the navel on each side. *The Wings* states it is one *cun* distant. Alternatively, moxa the *Small Intestine Transport* with seven cones.

**Small Intestine Vacuity Cold**
When the *yang* pulse before the *renying* at the *cun* position of the left hand is vacuous, it pertains to the *Hand Greater Yang* conduit. The patient suffers from unilateral headache at the skull’s edge and pain in the ears and cheeks. This is called *small intestine vacuity cold*.

**Formula to Supplement Small Intestine Vacuity Cold**
For pain due to small intestine vacuity cold, passing red and white stool, intestinal slippage, and anguish in the intestines, use the following supplementing formula:

**Supplementing Formula for Small Intestine Vacuity Cold**
Dried ginger, three *liang*; Chinese angelica, *phellodendron*, and *diyu*, each four *liang*; coptis, ass-hide glue, each two *liang*; pomegranate rind, three pieces. The seven ingredients are cut and decocted in seven *sheng* of water until reduced to two *sheng* and five *ge*. Strain the dregs, add the glue, and simmer until fully dissolved. Divide into three doses for daily consumption.

**Chapter Three: On the Tongue**
The tongue serves as the indicator of the heart and small intestine. Weighing ten *liang*, it measures seven *cun* in length and two and a half *cun* in breadth. It excels in balancing flavors and regulating the five tastes.

When consuming foods:
- Excessive salt causes the tongue’s vessels to congeal and its color to alter.
- Excessive bitterness desiccates the tongue’s surface, causing the outer hairs to wither.
- Excessive acridity tightens the tongue and dries the nails.
- Excessive sourness fattens the tongue’s flesh and curls the lips.
- Excessive sweetness induces pain at the tongue’s root and hair loss.

It is further said: The heart desires bitterness, the lungs acridity, the liver sourness, the spleen sweetness, and the kidneys saltiness—these five flavors internally harmonize with the *qi* of the five viscera.

If the viscera are hot, the tongue develops sores, drawing the lips upward and reddening them. If the bowels are cold, the tongue’s root retracts, the mouth clenches, and the lips turn blue-green. Cold requires supplementation; heat requires drainage. When neither cold nor heat is present, regulate according to the viscera and bowels.

For retracted tongue, clenched mouth, and blue-green lips, the *Shengma Decoction* governs. The formula appears in another volume.

**Chapter Four: Wind Dizziness**
**Preface, Discussion, Formulas, and Moxibustion Prohibitions**
Since the previous volume already contains formulas for wind affecting the head and face, wind dizziness should not be separately categorized. However, Sun Simiao deemed these methods to be Xu Sibai’s formulas, which ought not be mingled with others. Thus, this section is established specifically for wind dizziness, exclusively presenting Xu’s formulas.

Xu Sibai states: From youth, I inherited my family’s medical tradition and became well-versed in classical formulas. I have studied the essential treatments of renowned physicians. While wind dizziness arises through many pathways, and no single method guarantees efficacy, this technique has been my particular focus. Since my early years, I have applied it without fail. Now, nearing old age, I fear my time is short, so I clearly expound these patterns and theories to bequeath them to later generations.

Wind dizziness arises from unsettled heart *qi* and stagnation in the chest, manifesting as high wind and flushed face. Phlegm-heat stirs wind, and wind disturbs the heart, causing confusion and dizziness—hence the name *wind dizziness*. In adults, it is called *epilepsy*; in children, *convulsions*—though the condition is fundamentally the same.

This formula cures without exception, provided the pattern is carefully assessed. Misjudgment may lead to errors. Generally, avoid the ten rich meats. If *running piglet* disorder arises, frequent attacks with rapid breathing may prove fatal and irreversible. Thus, this decoction balances severity and mildness—do not dismiss it as unsuitable for the condition.

Formulas for wind dizziness include decoctions, powders, pills, and syrups, totaling ten. At the onset, administer the *Continuing Life Decoction* immediately. In urgent cases, locate the moxibustion points and apply fire needling—none will fail to recover. Needling followed by moxibustion is most effective. The moxibustion method is listed below.

In over thirty years of practice, I have saved hundreds, all of whom recovered. May later practitioners master this formula and refrain from adulterating it with other methods.

**Continuing Life Decoction** (*Xuming Tang*), for wind dizziness with vexation, stupor, foaming at the mouth, opisthotonos, upward-staring eyes, and clenched jaw with inability to speak:
- Bamboo sap: 1 sheng and 2 ge
- Fresh rehmannia juice: 1 sheng
- Dragon’s tooth: 4 liang
- Fresh ginger: 4 liang
- Ledebouriella root: 4 liang
- Ephedra: 4 liang
- Stephania root: 3 liang
- Aconite: 3 fen
- Gypsum: 7 liang
- Cinnamon bark: 2 liang

Grind the ten ingredients, decoct in 1 *dou* of water, and reduce to 3 *sheng*. Divide into three doses.
*For cases with qi [deficiency], increase aconite to 1 liang, add perilla seed (5 *ge*) and tangerine peel (½ liang).*

After administering the *Continuing Life Decoction*, if the mouth opens but the limbs remain unsettled and the mind is still disturbed, the **Purple Stone Decoction** governs it. *(The formula is found later under* Purple Stone Boiled Umbrella*.)*

**Running Piglet Decoction**, for qi surging violently to the point of collapse:
- Evodia fruit: 1 sheng
- Gypsum: 4 fen
- Ginseng: 4 fen
- Pinellia: 4 fen
- Ligusticum: 4 fen
- Peony: 4 fen
- Fresh ginger: 4 fen
- Fresh kudzu root: 10 fen
- Poria: 10 fen
- Tangkuei: 4 liang
- Plum root bark: 1 *jin*

Grind the twelve ingredients, decoct in 7 *sheng* of water and 8 *sheng* of clear wine, and reduce to 3 *sheng*. Divide into three doses.

**Stephania-Rehmannia Decoction**, for incoherent speech, darting eyes, talk of seeing ghosts, or deranged spirit:
- Stephania root: 2 liang
- Licorice: 2 liang
- Cinnamon bark: 3 liang
- Ledebouriella root: 3 liang
- Fresh rehmannia: 5 *jin* (cut separately; do not soak with the other herbs; for mild cases, use 2 *jin*)

Grind the five ingredients, soak in 1 *sheng* of water overnight, then press to extract the juice. Place the dregs on a bamboo mat, layer the rehmannia over them, and steam beneath 5 *dou* of rice. Collect the liquid in a copper vessel. When the rice is cooked, combine it with the previously extracted juice, press again, and divide into two doses.

**Dioscorea Decoction**, for palpitations with flaccid limbs, heat in the head and face, phlegm-fullness in the chest, and dizziness as if the head and eyes are swaying:
- Dioscorea: 4 liang
- Ophiopogon: 4 liang
- Ginseng: 4 liang
- Fresh rehmannia: 8 fen
- Peucedanum: 8 fen
- Peony: 8 fen
- Unripe bitter orange: 3 fen
- Polygala: 3 fen
- Fresh ginger: 3 fen
- Poria: 6 fen
- Poria spirit: 6 fen
- Pinellia: 5 fen
- Licorice: 2 fen
- Scutellaria: 2 fen
- Bamboo leaf: 2 fen
- Glutinous rice: 3 *ge*

Grind the sixteen ingredients, take river water, and raise it high to agitate 390 times. Measure 3 *dou*, boil the rice, reduce by 1 *dou*, add pinellia, and reduce by another 9 *sheng*. Remove the dregs, add the remaining herbs, and decoct to 4 *sheng*. Divide into four doses.
*Where river water is unavailable, substitute water from a thousand *li* eastward. In Qin, Jing and Wei River water may be used. For* Zhuge’s Irrigation Channel*, take water from the upper reaches.*

**Ledebouriella Decoction**, for cases where, after the previous decoctions, the limbs remain uncooled and dizziness persists. This decoction is highly effective and may be taken long-term, with minor adjustments for cold or warmth. If the condition does not resolve, follow this formula:
- Ledebouriella root: 3 fen
- Gypsum: 3 fen
- Ginseng: 3 fen
- Red halloysite: 3 fen
- White halloysite: 3 fen
- Fresh ginger: 3 fen
- Dragon bone: 3 fen
- Calcite: 3 fen
- Poria: 3 fen
- Cinnamon bark: 2 fen
- Purple stone: 1 fen

Grind the eleven ingredients, decoct in 8 *sheng* of water, and reduce to 3 *sheng*. Divide into three doses.
*When using well-flower water, select the clearest portion.*

Here the Yangtze River water is used, for it carries no mud nor any grit or filth. The source springs travel far, following the current to the sea, never reversing upstream—thus when employed to treat the head, it must descend downward.

**Yam Decoction Formula:**
- Yam: 24 fen
- Licorice: 14 fen
- Alisma: 4 fen
- Ginseng: 4 fen
- Scutellaria: 4 fen
- Tangkuei: 3 fen
- Ampelopsis: 3 fen
- Cinnamon bark: 3 fen
- Ledebouriella: 3 fen
- Ophiopogon: 3 fen
- Cornus: 2 fen
- Platycodon: 2 fen
- Peony: 2 fen
- Aster: 2 fen
- Fermented soybean: 2 fen
- Rehmannia (dried): 2 fen
- Atractylodes: 2 fen
- Ligusticum: 2 fen
- Ginger (dried): 2 fen
- Sichuan pepper: 2 fen

Grind the above twenty ingredients and sift. Take 18 *jin* of fresh rehmannia, pound and press to obtain juice, then decoct until half remains. Also prepare:
- Mixed deer and stag marrow: 8 *liang*
- Deerhorn glue: 8 *liang*
- Jujubes: 80 pieces
- Hemp seeds (ground): 3 *sheng*
- Honey: 3 *sheng*
- Mulberry root bark: 5 *sheng* (avoid bark from trees growing on ridges, which is highly toxic; also avoid bark from near fences, walls, or ditches—none of these may be used)

Steep the twenty-seven ingredients in 2 *dou* 4 *sheng* of clear wine. Decoct the mulberry bark, hemp seeds, and jujubes until 1 *dou* remains, then strain. Add the rehmannia juice, glue, marrow, and honey, decocting until reduced by half. Incorporate the previously ground powders and continue decocting until the mixture can be formed into pills the size of a chicken’s egg yolk. Take one pill three times daily, gradually increasing to three pills.

**Yam Pill**, for treating dizziness, clouded vision, heart vexation, melancholy, fright palpitations, and manic epilepsy:
- Yam: 28 fen
- Licorice: 20 fen
- Deerhorn: 7 fen
- Fermented soybean: 7 fen
- Cinnamon bark: 7 fen
- Rehmannia (dried): 10 fen
- Medicated leaven: 10 fen
- Tangkuei: 10 fen
- Ginseng: 10 fen
- Ophiopogon: 6 fen
- Ledebouriella: 6 fen
- Scutellaria: 6 fen
- Peony: 6 fen
- Atractylodes: 6 fen
- Bupleurum: 5 fen
- Platycodon: 5 fen
- Poria: 5 fen
- Apricot kernel: 5 fen
- Ligusticum: 5 fen
- Ampelopsis: 3 fen
- Ginger (dried): 3 fen
- Jujubes: 100 pieces (extract the paste)

Grind the twenty-two ingredients into powder, combine with white honey and jujube paste, and form into pills the size of a bullet. Take one pill before meals, three times daily.

**Aconite Powder**, for treating dizziness where the room spins and tilts:
- Aconite: 3 fen
- Ledebouriella: 3 fen
- Ligusticum: 3 fen
- Ginseng: 3 fen
- Angelica: 3 fen

Grind the thirteen ingredients and sift. Take one square *cun* spoonful before meals with chrysanthemum wine, twice daily, gradually increasing to three spoonfuls until the desired effect is achieved.

**Chrysanthemum Wine Method:** On the ninth day of the ninth month, gather sweet chrysanthemum flowers from Dengzhou, dry them in the sun, and grind into powder. Steam with rice to make wine.

**Ginseng Pill**, for treating intermittent mental confusion:
- Shangdang ginseng: 1 *liang*
- *Podophyllum*: 1 *liang*
- Iron filings: 1 *liang*
- Bezoar: 1 *liang*
- Cinnabar: 1 *liang*
