Grind the eleven ingredients into powder and form into honey pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take seven pills with the aforementioned chrysanthemum wine, three times daily and once at night, gradually increasing the dose.

When compounding medicines, do not use blue paper. Avoid encounters with women, those in blue clothing, mourners, the incomplete, the unclean, or the impure, as well as livestock, chickens, rats, and the like.

**Moxibustion Method:**
Measure the width of the mouth with a string, then use the same string to measure the width of the nose between the nostrils. Fold the string in half at the midpoint of the nose measurement, then fold it again at the midpoint of the full mouth measurement. Locate the indentation in the hairline on the head and apply moxibustion there. Use the string to mark the four directions—left, right, front, and back—and apply moxibustion at the string’s endpoints, aligning the front with the face. The number of cones corresponds to the patient’s age, with three treatments per year. Each treatment should only proceed once the previous moxibustion sores have healed, using the same number of cones as before.

If consecutive moxibustion causes fire *qi* to rise upward, and the hairline indentations are multiple, apply moxibustion near the nose. If the indentation is closer to the forehead, moxibustion is also appropriate. If scarring the face is a concern, omit the facial points—though in severe cases, this consideration may be disregarded.

**Dietary Prohibitions:**
Avoid the meat of tigers, rabbits, dragons, snakes, oxen, horses, pigs, sheep, chickens, dogs, monkeys, and rats. The twelve zodiac-associated meats must not be consumed, nor used in medicinal preparations. However, bezoar and dragon bones/teeth may still be used.

*Master Sun’s* *Essential Emergency Prescriptions Worth a Thousand in Gold*, Scroll Forty-Three, concludes.

**Textual Variants:**
Variant characters from the Song Dynasty block-print edition are noted as follows: #2 "Wang" (王) appears as "Zhu" (主); #3 "person" (人) was originally "heart" (心); #4 "three liang each" (各三两) appears as "two liang each" (各二两); #5 "ten fen each" (各十分) appears as "six fen each" (各六分); #6 "two fen each" (各二分) appears as "one fen each" (各一分); #7 "thirteen ingredients" (右十三味) was originally "nineteen ingredients" (右十九味); #8 "one piece each" (各一枚) was omitted in the original and has been restored. #9 Below "must not be discarded" (用不可废), the Song edition includes the following passage:

*"Sibu Qi states: How could Sibu claim efficacy in prescriptions and techniques? Yet for wind-dizziness, which I hold most dear—even slight relief from suffering—I have long treasured and guarded these methods, vowing never to reveal them. When compelled to treat such cases, I do not disclose the full method. For all afflicted by this malady, none treated by Sibu have failed to recover. If one dies of this illness, it is only because they did not encounter Sibu. I humbly beseech inquiry among others to confirm this is no boast of mine. Since Your Highness requires this prescription, I respectfully seal and present it. Sibu’s humble resolve remains steadfast. Written in my own hand, though age has dimmed my eyes, and many characters are poorly formed—I beg your indulgence. Respectfully submitted."*

**Scroll Forty-Four: The Small Intestine Fu**
*Master Sun’s Essential Emergency Prescriptions Worth a Thousand in Gold*, Scroll Forty-Four
Collated and Corrected by Lin Yi, Gentleman for Court Service, Acting Vice Minister of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices, and Academician of the Secret Pavilion of the Song Dynasty

**Prescriptions for the Small Intestine Fu**
**Fifth Discourse on Wind-Epilepsy: Formulas and Acupuncture-Moxibustion Methods**

**Discourse on Wind-Epilepsy**

The Yellow Emperor asked: "When a person is born with epilepsy, how does this affliction arise?"
Qibo replied: "This arises when, while still in the womb, the mother experiences frequent great fright. The qi surges upward and fails to descend, causing essence and qi to congeal together, thus leading the child to develop epilepsy.

When the disease resides in the yang channels, the patient alternates between cold and heat. When all the interstices alternate between cold and heat, it is called *kuang* (mania). One should needle the deficient channels and observe the interstices until the heat abates before ceasing.

At the onset of epilepsy, if the disease strikes once a year and is left untreated, it will recur monthly. If still untreated, it will strike every four or five days—this is called *dianji* (epilepsy). Needle all the interstices; if the pulse is particularly cold, supplement with the needle until the disease subsides.

When epilepsy first arises, the patient initially feels dispirited, the head grows heavy, the gaze becomes fixed, and the eyes redden. Once the episode reaches its peak, the heart becomes vexed. Observe the complexion and treat by bleeding the hand Taiyang, Yangming, and Taiyin channels.

When epilepsy first arises and the patient instead stiffens, causing spinal pain, observe and bleed the foot Taiyang, Yangming, Taiyin, and hand Taiyang channels.

When epilepsy first manifests with drawn mouth, wailing, and panting (or palpitations as in *Jia Yi Jing*), observe the hand Yangming and Taiyang channels. If the right side is rigid, attack the left; if the left is rigid, attack the right. Cease once the blood changes.

In treating epilepsy, one should remain constantly with the patient, examining the appropriate points to needle. When the disease strikes, observe for any excess and immediately drain it, placing the blood in a gourd vessel. At the time of the next episode, if the blood stirs on its own, the disease is not yet cured; if it does not stir, apply twenty cones of moxa to *qionggu* (the coccyx).

*Qionggu* refers to the tailbone.

In *bone epilepsy*, the jaw, teeth, all transport points, and interstices become swollen, the bones stiffen and straighten, sweat breaks out, and the patient feels vexed and stifled, with frequent vomiting of drool and foam, and qi descending in leakage—this is incurable.

In *sinew epilepsy*, the body curls and contracts, the pulse is large. Needle the root of the *zhuyu* (the great channel of the nape). Frequent vomiting of drool and foam, with qi descending in leakage—this is incurable.

In *vessel epilepsy*, the patient suddenly collapses, the vessels of the four limbs all swell and follow the course of fullness. Bleed all the full vessels. If they are not full, apply moxa to the Taiyang channel beside the nape, and also to the *dai mai* (Belt Vessel) at the waist, three *cun* apart from the interstices, muscles, roots, and transport points. Frequent vomiting of drool and foam, with qi descending in leakage—this is incurable.

When treating epilepsy, if during an episode the patient raves like a madman and the facial skin appears thick and dull, this is fatal and incurable.

Generally, when epilepsy strikes, the patient falls to the ground, foams at the mouth, and loses awareness. If forcibly lifted, they may appear manic, and if they lose control of their bowels, the condition is difficult to cure.

If the pulse in epilepsy is bounding, large, and slippery, the disease will resolve on its own over time. If the pulse is deep, small, urgent, and replete, it is fatal and incurable. A pulse that is small, taut, and urgent is also untreatable. If deficient, it may be cured; if replete, it is fatal.

*Jue* (reversal) can develop into epilepsy. It arises from disharmony in the five *zang* and obstruction in the six *fu*.

*Jue* can become epilepsy, which is why *jue* is appended to this discourse.

When yang declines, heat *jue* arises; when yin declines, cold *jue* arises.

The Yellow Emperor asked: "What causes the cold and heat in *jue*?"
Qibo replied: "When yang qi declines below, it becomes cold *jue*; when yin qi declines below, it becomes heat *jue*."

The Emperor asked: "Why does heat *jue* invariably begin in the soles of the feet?"
Qibo replied: "Yang qi arises on the exterior of the five toes, gathers in the soles, and accumulates in the centers of the feet. Thus, when yang prevails, the soles become hot."

The Emperor asked: "Why does cold *jue* invariably begin in the five toes and ascend to the knees?"
Qibo replied: "Yin qi arises on the interior of the five toes, gathers at the knees, and accumulates above the knees. Thus, when yin qi prevails, cold ascends from the five toes to above the knees. This cold does not come from without but arises from within."

*Jue* may cause abdominal fullness, or it may cause sudden loss of awareness. Some patients remain unconscious for half a day, or even as long as a full day, before regaining awareness. Why is this?
When yin qi is exuberant above, the lower body becomes deficient. Lower deficiency leads to abdominal fullness, and fullness causes the lower qi to press upward, disrupting the proper flow of qi. When qi is disrupted, yang qi becomes chaotic, and chaos leads to loss of awareness.

In *Taiyang jue*, the head swells and feels heavy, and the feet cannot walk, leading to sudden collapse.

In *Yangming jue*, the patient raves, runs about, and shouts, the abdomen is full and prevents lying down, the face is red and hot, and they see and speak delusions.

In *Shaoyang jue*, there is sudden deafness, cheek swelling and heat, rib-side pain, and inability to move the thighs.

In *Taiyin jue*, the abdomen is full and distended, with constipation, loss of appetite, vomiting upon eating, and inability to lie down.

In *Shaoyin jue*, the tongue is dry, urine is red, the abdomen is full, and the heart aches.

In *Jueyin jue*, the lower abdomen swells and pains, the abdomen is distended, urination and defecation are obstructed, the patient prefers to lie with knees drawn up, the genitals retract and swell, and the inner thighs (or outer thighs) are hot.

When excess prevails, drain it; when deficiency prevails, supplement it. When neither excess nor deficiency prevails, treat according to the channel.

For upper cold and lower heat, first needle the Taiyang channel at the nape, retaining the needle for a long time. Then apply a heated iron to the nape and shoulder blades until the heat descends and the cold below ceases. This is called "pushing upward."

For upper heat and lower cold, observe the deficient channels where the vessels sink into the network vessels, and treat them until the qi descends. This is called "drawing downward."

When needling heat *jue*, retain the needle to induce cold; when needling cold *jue*, retain the needle to induce heat.

For heat *jue*, use two yin and one yang; for cold *jue*, use two yang and one yin.
"Two yin" means needling yin twice; "two yang" means needling yang twice.

Heat entering the kidneys in *wenbing* (warm disease) can also cause *jing* (convulsions). In children, epilepsy with exuberant heat can also cause *jing*.

All conditions such as wind-induced aphonia, sudden corpse-like *jue*, and ghostly nightmares that cause unconsciousness resemble one another. One must examine them carefully. Thus, the classics state that prolonged *jue* leads to epilepsy, which is how we know their similarity.

Epilepsy has five types:
The first is *yang epilepsy*. When it strikes, the patient appears dead, loses control of urination, and after a while recovers.

The second is *yin epilepsy*. It arises when, in early infancy, the umbilical wound has not yet healed, and frequent bathing leads to this condition.

The third is *wind epilepsy*. When it strikes, the patient’s eyes are drawn upward, the body convulses with spasms, and they emit a sheep-like cry. After about the time it takes to eat a meal, the episode subsides. It is caused by exertion while sweating in the wind, excessive sexual activity, or overindulgence in alcohol and food before intercourse, which forces the heart *qi* into distress, resulting in shortness of breath and palpitations.

The fourth is *damp epilepsy*. The patient suffers from pain at the brows and heaviness of the body. It is caused by washing the hair while overheated, allowing dampness to congeal in the brain before the sweat has ceased.

The fifth is *horse epilepsy*. When it strikes, the patient’s eyes roll back, the mouth clenches, the limbs contract, and the entire body becomes hot. It is caused by an imbalance of brain heat due to fatty *qi* in infancy.

**Formula for Treating the Five Epilepsies:**
*Verdigris, realgar, malachite, rooster’s head from the eastern gate, mercury—* each one *liang*;
*Poria, polyporus, ginseng, angelica, ampelopsis, cynanchum, selaginella—* each two *liang*;
*Selaginella tamariscina, belamcanda—* each half a *liang*;
*Sulfur—* one and a half *liang*.
Grind the fifteen ingredients into powder, mix with ox bile, and place in a copper vessel. Steam over five *dou* of soybeans in a steamer until the medicine is ready. Form into pills the size of sesame seeds. Take thirty pills before meals, twice during the day and once at night.

**Tiger’s Eye Pill** treats *wind epilepsy* with convulsions, wide-open eyes and mouth, foaming at the mouth, vocalizations, or loss of consciousness:
(From the *Qianjin Yifang*, named the *Great Heart-Settling Pill*, it governs all epilepsies that other formulas cannot cure.)
*Tiger’s eye—* one, soaked in wine overnight and then roasted;
*Ghost arrow feathers, wasp nest—* each two *fen*;
*Angelica, polygala, asarum, dryopteris, musk, ampelopsis (or cynanchum), cimicifuga, dictamnus—* each three *liang*;
*Bovine bezoar, saposhnikovia, gentiana, peucedanum, dragon’s teeth, scutellaria, realgar, cornus, rehmannia (or dried ginger in one version), stephania, poria, iron filings, hellebore, ginseng, rhubarb, silver filings—* each four *fen*;
*Spirit poria, gypsum, aconite—* each five *fen*;
*Calcite—* six *fen*;
*Snakeskin—* one *chi*.
Grind the thirty-two ingredients into powder, mix with honey, and form into pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take fifteen pills with wine, twice daily, gradually increasing to twenty-five pills. A divine formula.

**For the Signs of Epileptic Episodes** (which manifest in many ways, such as foaming at the mouth and erratic movements):
*Gentiana, ginseng, peucedanum (or saposhnikovia), spirit poria (or moutan), licorice—* each two *liang*;
*Lead oxide—* one *liang*;
*Dryopteris—* one piece.
Chop the seven ingredients, boil in nine *sheng* of water, reduce to three and a half *sheng*, and divide into three doses.

**Male-Female Pill** treats *wind epilepsy* with loss of consciousness, disorientation, and near-death states, as well as the five epilepsies and fright-induced convulsions:
*Realgar, orpiment, pearl—* each one *liang*;
*Lead—* two *liang*, heated into filings;
*Cinnabar—* two *fen*;
*Mercury—* eight *fen*.
Grind the six ingredients into powder, pound with honey thirty thousand times, and form into pills the size of *hudou* beans. Take two pills before meals, twice daily, gradually increasing until an effect is achieved.

From *Records of Ancient and Modern Verified Remedies*:
For the five epilepsies—ox epilepsy with bovine cries, horse epilepsy with equine neighs, dog epilepsy with canine barks, sheep epilepsy with ovine bleats, and fowl epilepsy with avian crows. When afflicted by the five epilepsies or manic disorders, the bowels and viscera interact, qi surges upward, cold reversal sets in, and the patient fails to recognize others. As qi contends and struggles, foam is expectorated, and only after a long while does consciousness return.

*Continuing Life Wind-Drawing Decoction* treats wind stroke with epilepsy, vertigo, loss of awareness, raving speech, and swollen protruding tongue:
Ephedra, chuanxiong, gypsum, ginseng, and ledebouriella—each three *liang*;
Cinnamon bark, licorice, and *duhuo*—each two *liang*;
Stephania root, aconite, and Chinese angelica—each one *liang*;
Apricot kernels—thirty pieces;
Dried ginger—five *liang* (one version omits "dried").
Chop the thirteen ingredients, combine with three *sheng* of wine and one *dou* of water, and boil down to four *sheng*. Divide into four doses, taking three during the day and one at night.

*Purple Stone Powder* treats adult wind-drawing and childhood fright epilepsy with convulsive spasms occurring dozens of times daily—conditions beyond the reach of physicians:
Purple fluorite, talc, kaolin, calcite, red kaolin, and gypsum—each six *liang*;
Licorice, cinnamon bark, and oyster shell—each five *liang*;
Rhubarb, dragon bone, and dried ginger—each four *liang*.
Grind the twelve ingredients, sift into coarse powder, and store in a leather pouch suspended in a cool, high place. To use, take a three-finger pinch, boil in three *sheng* of freshly drawn well water, and reduce to one *sheng* and two *ge*. Adults take the full dose at once; infants under one hundred days take one *ge*, and those unable to swallow may have it applied to the mouth with silk. For those with excessive heat, administer four to five doses daily, adjusting as needed.
*Master Shen’s Formula* uses only five ingredients: dragon bone, dried ginger, oyster shell, talc, and kaolin.

For the one hundred twenty types of wind, epilepsy, fright mania, and seizures with foaming at the mouth and loss of awareness, the following should be taken in the fourth or fifth month:
Purple fluorite, peony, dragon bone (one version substitutes scutellaria), green kaolin, dictamnus root, ephedra, Chinese angelica, licorice, trichosanthes root, cinnamon bark, and ginseng—each two *liang*;
Oyster shell—three *liang*;
Rhubarb—five *liang*.
Grind the thirteen ingredients, sift into coarse powder, and divide into seven portions. For each dose, boil ten jujubes in three *sheng* of water, reduce to two and a half *sheng*, discard the dregs, add one portion of the powder, and boil down to one *sheng*. Take the full dose at once, with seven days between doses; recovery follows completion of the course.

*Formula for Epilepsy and Reversal Seizures*:
*Fangji*, hematite, ginseng, lead oxide, white stiff silkworm, raw pig’s teeth, gambir vine, spirit poria, *leigong* fungus, tiger bone, *yuanzhi*, cinnamon bark, and ledebouriella—each six *fen*;
*Juanbai*, henbane seeds, cinnabar, cimicifuga, aconite, moutan, and dragon teeth—each one *fen*;
Ox gallstone—two *fen*;
*Ampelopsis*—four *fen*;
Cicada moltings—fourteen pieces;
Snake slough and white horse eyes—one set each.
Grind the twenty-five ingredients and sift.

Take with wine, one square-inch spoonful, twice daily. It may also be formed into pills, which are highly effective.

*Xiongqiong Decoction* for wind-induced epilepsy with pulling pain in the flanks, onset marked by vomiting and cicada-like ringing in the ears:
*Xiongqiong*, *gaoben*, and *louyu*—each five *liang*.
Chop the three ingredients, add to one *dou* of wine, and boil down to three *sheng*. Take the full dose at once; for the weak, divide into two doses, inducing profuse sweating.

*Formula for Wind-Induced Epilepsy* (from *Essential Records*, titled *Owl-Head Pills*):
Pepperweed seeds, lead oxide, *huzhang*, aconite, and *gualou* root—each three *fen*;
Kansui, *tianxiong*, Sichuan pepper, and *daji*—each two *fen*;
White atractylodes—one *fen*;
Iron filings and *louyu*—each one *liang*;
Owl’s head—one.
Grind the thirteen ingredients into powder and form into honey pills the size of parasol seeds. Take two pills with hot wine or water, three times daily.

*Alternative Formula*:
Rehmannia—thirty *jin*;
Asparagus—ten *jin*.
Pound to extract the juice and simmer into a thick paste; take to cure the condition.

*Alternative Formula*:
Pound and sift three *sheng* of henbane seeds, steep in one *dou* of wine for half a day, strain, and simmer the liquid until it can be formed into pills. Take two small bean-sized pills before meals, increasing to two parasol seed-sized pills, adjusting the dose until the desired effect is achieved. The sign of efficacy is redness rising along the lines of the palms and forehead. If this sign does not appear, continue taking the pills. For daily episodes, cure follows in three days; for alternate-day episodes, ten days; for five-day intervals, twenty days; for six-month intervals, one month.

*Formula for Epilepsy, Spasms, and Convulsions*:
Lead oxide—one *jin*;
Owl’s head—two (flying).
Grind into powder and form into honey pills. Take three pills before meals, three times daily; for severe cases, take one additional dose at night, gradually increasing the dose.

*Asparagus Wine*, universally effective for:
Great wind pervading the five viscera and six bowels, collapse and depletion, vacuity and weakness, the five taxations and seven damages, concretions and stagnation, qi blockages, cold and heat winds, epilepsy and malign illnesses, deafness and head wind, tetanic contraction of the limbs, wilting and migratory joint pain, and the myriad diseases. Long-term consumption extends years, rejuvenates the body, regrows fallen teeth, and restores white hair to black.

*Method*:
Asparagus resembles *baibu*; asparagus is sweet and square at both ends, while *baibu* is slender, long, and bitter, causing diarrhea.
Pound to extract two *dou* of juice, add two *sheng* of clear yeast, and ferment with two *dou* of glutinous rice, following standard household brewing methods. In spring and summer, serve the rice extremely cold; in autumn and winter, warm it to body temperature before eating. When the wine is ready, take one cup of the clear liquid, maintaining a continuous mild intoxication without reaching vomiting. Avoid raw, cold, sour, and slippery foods, as well as chicken, pork, fish, and garlic; especially avoid carp and greasy foods.

This is the method for one *dou* of juice; for larger quantities (one *shi* or two *shi*), scale proportionally. After ten days of consumption, the body may develop hidden rashes with intense itching; after twenty days, the itching worsens; by thirty days, it gradually subsides—all signs of wind qi being expelled. By forty days, the body and mind feel clear and greatly relieved, as if transformed; by fifty days, the relief is even greater. Sitting or lying in the wind, one feels it no longer affects the body, and all internal winds are entirely dispelled.

*Rice Preparation*:
Thoroughly wash the rice, dry it in the sun, and just before use, soak it in fresh asparagus juice. Dry and steam the rice, mixing the remaining juice into the cooked rice. Seal tightly.

*Extracting Asparagus Juice*:
Wash the asparagus clean, remove the heart and skin, dry, and cut into pieces. Pound and press three to four times until the dregs are as dry as grass.

When first ready, this wine tastes sour and emits a foul, watery odor, but with continued consumption as directed, it becomes fragrant and delicious—unmatched by other wines. Seal for twenty-eight days for best results. Prepare small batches in the eighth and ninth months, larger batches in the tenth month, and continue consumption until the thirtieth day of the fifth month of the following year. It may also be prepared in the third month of spring, but not after the fourth month.

When taking this wine, combining it with the powder form enhances its efficacy and speed. The powder formula follows.

*Powder Formula*:
Remove the heart and skin from asparagus, dry in the sun, and grind into powder. Take one square-inch spoonful with the wine, three times daily, increasing to three spoonfuls. Long-term consumption confers longevity; it may also be taken with other wines.

*Moxibustion Methods*:
For adult epilepsy and infantile fright epilepsy, moxa the second vertebra of the back and the lower end of the coccyx at two points. Measure the distance between these points with a string, fold it in half, and mark the midpoint on the spine. Moxa these three points. Then, cut the string into three equal lengths, arrange them in a triangle (△), and place one end at the central moxa point, with the other two ends flanking the spine. Moxa these five points, each with one hundred cones. Use bamboo strips as a measure, which is superior to string. Mark the five moxa points with cinnabar.

For sudden epilepsy, moxa the depression at the top of the penis with three cones until urination is unobstructed, achieving cure. *Supplement to the Thousand Gold Pieces* states this point is at the urethral orifice. Alternatively, moxa the glans penis with three cones; the big toe’s hairy region with seven cones; the scrotal raphe with fourteen cones; both nipples with three cones each; and the Governing Vessel with thirty cones, repeated three times (the point is on the midline of the nose, entering the hairline). Additionally, moxa *tianchuang* and *baihui*, gradually increasing to three hundred cones each, using small moxa. Also, moxa the hairline above both ears with fifty cones each.

*Discourse*:
The Yellow Emperor asked: "There is a disease of raging madness; how does it arise?"
Qibo replied: "It arises from yang."
The Emperor asked: "How does yang cause people to rage?"
Qibo replied: "When yang qi is violently obstructed and difficult to resolve, it leads to frequent anger; the disease is called yang reversal."
The Emperor asked: "How can one recognize it?"
Qibo replied: "The Yangming channel is normally active, while the Taiyang and Shaoyang are not. If the inactive channels become hyperactive, this is the sign."

The Emperor asked: "How is it treated?"
Qibo replied: "Reduce their food intake, and the disease will resolve. For food enters the yin to nourish the yang; thus, depriving them of food will cure it. Have them take *shengtieluo* as a post-meal remedy, for *shengtieluo* swiftly descends the qi."

*Discourse*:
Whenever madness erupts with a desire to flee, or when patients exalt themselves as supremely wise or claim divine sagacity, all such cases must be thoroughly treated with moxibustion to achieve lasting recovery. If, however, they weep sorrowfully or moan in distress, this is due to pathogenic influence rather than madness, and should be treated according to methods for pathogenic disorders.

When pathogenic influence enters the yang, it causes madness; when it enters the yin, it causes blood impediment.
When pathogenic influence enters the yang and transmits further, it becomes *dian* and convulsions; when it enters the yin and transmits further, it becomes pain and muteness.
When yang enters yin, the disease is tranquil; when yin enters yang, the disease is rage.

*Tuo Jia Decoction*:
Governs pathogenic qi manifesting as tears during dreams or wakefulness, aversion to human voices, bodily soreness and emaciation, alternating chills and fever, stiffness and pain in the lumbar spine, abdominal tension, loss of appetite, or conditions arising after illness, overwork, or exhaustion, or due to transgressing taboos and various forms of excess. For women after childbirth with menstrual irregularities, discharging blue, red, or white matter, bodily emaciation, muscle depletion, scanty urine, or alternating fever and chills over the head and body, or extreme fatigue lasting days after a single act of intercourse. The formula consists of:

Seven *tuo* shells
Two *liang* each of licorice, *baiwei* (or *baizhi*), fritillaria, and scutellaria
Two and a half *liang* each of ephedra, peony, and atractylodes
Three *liang* of saposhnikovia
Four *liang* each of *ningshuishi*, cinnamon bark, poria, and anemarrhena
Six *liang* of gypsum

Grind the fourteen ingredients, decoct in two *dou* of water, and reduce to four *sheng*. Take one *sheng* warm, three times during the day and once at night.

The Nine-Substance Ox Yellow Pill treats men afflicted by ghostly possession on the verge of death, manifesting as terrifying visions, an urge to flee, and intermittent respite—all caused by pathogenic qi, rendering the sufferer unable to break free. The formula consists of:

One *liang* each of:
- Ox yellow (Earth Essence, also called Fire Essence)
- Vitex fruit (Human Essence)
- Azurite (Azure Dragon Essence)
- Jade shavings (White Tiger Essence)
- Malachite (Heavenly Essence)
- Realgar (Earth Essence)
- Scrophularia (Black Warrior Essence)
- Dragon bone (Water Essence)
- Red halloysite (Vermilion Bird Essence)

These nine ingredients, known as the Nine Essences, connect above to the Nine Heavens and below to the Nine Earths. Grind them finely, sift, and blend with honey to form pills the size of small beans. Take one pill before meals, three times daily, gradually increasing the dose until an effect is achieved.

*The Supplement to the Thousand Golden Remedies* states: For all pathogenic illnesses, one should take the Five Pathogens Decoction and the Nine Essences Pill to achieve a cure.

The Ten Yellows Powder treats insufficiency of blood and qi in the five viscera and six bowels, loss of ethereal and corporeal souls, visceral unease, sudden melancholy or sorrow, frequent terror in the heart as if haunted by spirits—all arising from severe fright, exposure to wind, falls from heights, or near-drowning. The formula consists of:

- Realgar and ginseng, five *fen* each
- Scutellaria, rhubarb, phellodendron, astragalus, asarum, and cinnamon bark, three *fen* each
- Coptis, *huanghun* (possibly *Cortex Albiziae*), cattail pollen, and ephedra, one *fen* each
- Moonseed root and alisma, two *fen* each
- Cornus, two *fen*

Grind the fifteen ingredients finely and sift. Take one *fangcunbi* with warm wine before meals, three times daily. If no effect, increase to two *bi*. For the weak or debilitated, add five *fen* of ginseng, making a total of ten *fen*.

One variant includes two *fen* of raw yellow (possibly raw rehmannia).
*Master Cui’s* version adds five *fen* of Sichuan pepper and four *fen* of dried ginger.

**Separation Powder**, for treating wind-evil in men and women—where men dream of women and women dream of men, with sorrow, grief, worry, and vexation, or moods shifting between anger and joy without constancy, or episodes recurring every few months or half a year:

- Cinnamon bark, *yin yu* (*Skimmia reevesiana*), *tian xiong* (*Aconitum* root), calamus, asarum, madder root, aconite, and dried ginger, one *liang* each
- White atractylodes and mulberry mistletoe, three *liang* each

Grind the ten ingredients finely and sift. Take one *fangcunbi* with wine, three times daily.

When preparing this formula, ensure no women, chickens, dogs, or members of the patient’s household witness the process, lest the evil *qi* fail to depart—this prohibition ensures efficacy.

**Four-Ingredient Kite-Head Powder**, for treating demonic possession:

- *Donghai yuan tou* (kite’s head, i.e., *you ba* root), one *fen*
- *Huang ya shi* (yellow-tooth stone, also called *jin ya*), one *fen*
- *Chang dang* seeds, one *fen*
- *Fang kui*, one *fen*

Grind the four ingredients finely and sift. Take one *fangcunbi* with wine. To make the patient see ghosts, add one *fen* of *fang kui*; to reveal the ghost’s identity, add another *fen*—results appear immediately.

*Fang kui* and *chang dang* both induce confusion and disorientation akin to madness; they must not be taken in excess.

**Five-Evil Decoction**, for treating evil *qi* manifesting as weeping, singing, or wailing:

- Limonite, two *liang*
- *Fang feng*, cinnamon bark, peony, *yuan zhi*, *du huo*, licorice, white atractylodes, ginseng, gypsum, oyster shell, and *qin jiao*, two *liang* each
- *Fang ji*, calamus, *fu shen*, realgar (*Master Shen*’s version uses *huang dan*), and snake slough, one *liang* each

Chop the seventeen ingredients, boil in two *dou* of water, and reduce to four *sheng*. Divide into four doses. Alternatively, prepare as a boiled powder.

**Poria Spirit Decoction**, for treating five evil *qi* entering the body, causing visions of ghosts, delirious speech, sights and sounds, palpitations, and unsettledness:

- *Fu shen*, ginseng, calamus, and poria, three *liang* each
- Red adzuki beans, forty pieces

Chop the five ingredients, boil in one *dou* of water, and reduce to two and a half *sheng*. Divide into three doses.

**Ginseng Decoction**, for treating wind-evil and ghostly *qi* that come and go, sometimes with a pattern, sometimes without:

- Ginseng, *fang feng*, aconite, dried ginger, alisma, trichosanthes root (*Wings* version uses platycodon), *gou ji*, *yuan zhi*, aconite, scutellaria, *du huo*, five *fen* each
- *Qin jiao*, oyster shell, schisandra, cornus, *qian hu*, asarum, gypsum, *chuan xiong*, Sichuan pepper, *niu xi*, licorice, *shi nan*, mulberry root bark, cinnamon bark, ephedra, bamboo shavings, white atractylodes, and tangerine peel, eighteen *zhu* each
- *Gui jian* (*Thousand Gold Wings* version uses *ze lan*) and poria, twelve *zhu* each
- Jujubes, sixteen pieces

Chop the thirty-two ingredients, boil in six *sheng* of water and six *sheng* of wine, and reduce to four *sheng*. Divide into five doses, taking three during the day and two at night.

**Tiger’s Eye Decoction**, governing erratic manic possession, with disheveled hair, loud cries, and homicidal impulses, unafraid of water or fire. Formula:

- Tiger’s eye, wasp nest, owl’s head: one each
- Mistletoe on maple: five *fen*
- *Asplenium prolongatum*: ten *fen*
- Poria, cinnamon bark, *fang feng*: three *liang* each
- *Du huo*, licorice, ginseng, *tian xiong*: one *liang* each

Twelve ingredients in total. Chop, boil in twelve *sheng* of water, and reduce to three *sheng*. Divide into four doses, taking three during the day and one at night.

**Alternative formula**:
- *Fang kui*, ginseng, *guan zhong*: five *liang* each
- *Fang feng*, cinnamon bark: three *liang* each

Five ingredients in total. Chop, boil in ten *sheng* of water, and reduce to three *sheng*. Divide into four doses; gradual administration is also acceptable.

**Another formula**:
- Five *jin* of *ku shen*, mixed with honey into pills the size of sour jujubes. Take ten pills alone.

**For sudden manic onset**:
Have the patient lie supine on the ground and continuously pour cold water over their face throughout the day. Effective.

**For all manner of demonic possession**:
Take a head-dirt pellet the size of a small bean.

**For spectral hauntings**:
Take one *fang cun bi* of deer antler powder with water, three times daily.

**Another formula**:
Take otter liver powder with water, three times daily.

**For fox spirits and various malevolent entities causing terror, madness, and wind-like possession**:
- Six *jin* of realgar
- One *dou* and two *sheng* of oil

Break the realgar into pieces the size of chess pieces. Place in a cauldron covered with a basin to form a stove. Simmer over low heat for nine days and nights without interruption, ensuring the fire neither extinguishes nor cools. The flame must remain gently continuous. Divinely efficacious.

**For wind-like possession**:
- Thirty *jin* of *shang lu* root, peeled and finely chopped
- Eight *dou* of water

Boil in an east-facing stove until reduced by half. Strain, then continue boiling until the liquid thickens enough to form pills the size of *wu* seeds. Take one pill. During preparation, ensure no one witnesses the process. The *chang dang* formula and the Purple Decoction (see other scrolls) may also be taken; sweating is beneficial.

**Another formula**:
Burn toad ash, take one *fang cun bi* with water, three times daily.

**Another formula**:
Burn human feces to ash and take with wine.

Avoid raw, cold, sour, or slippery foods, as well as pork, chicken, fish, and garlic.

**Another formula**:
Take one *fang cun bi* of *fu long gan* with water, three times daily.

**Acupuncture and Moxibustion Diagrams and Techniques for Various Manic and Demonic Possessions**:

**Discourse**:
All manner of demonic afflictions arise from diverse origins, manifesting in varied forms that reveal the onset of manic possession. Symptoms may include silence, incessant babbling, singing, weeping, chanting, or laughter. Some may sleep or sit in ditches, consuming filth; others may strip naked, wander day and night, or hurl unrestrained curses. Still others may be possessed by flying insects, venomous creatures, or spirits, exhibiting erratic hand movements and darting eyes. For such manic and possessed individuals, acupuncture, moxibustion, and medicinal treatments are jointly administered.

Those who divine by wind also attribute such conditions to demonic influence. Bian Que stated: "For all afflictions caused by the hundred demons, there are thirteen acupuncture points. The procedure begins at *Ghost Palace*, then proceeds to *Ghost Faith*, followed by *Ghost Rampart*, and *Ghost Heart*. It is not necessary to needle all points; five or six will suffice to discern the truth. If the possessing entity is a spectral or venomous spirit, it will speak, revealing its origins. Once verified, the spirit may be compelled to depart without needing to exhaust its life force."

For men, begin needling on the left; for women, on the right. If the spirit remains silent after several points, needle all prescribed locations. Follow the techniques precisely, combining acupuncture and moxibustion as required. Additionally, employ the *Yellow Emperor’s Palm Technique* to manipulate the eyes for treatment—success is assured.

The *Yellow Emperor’s Palm Technique* is a secret art of exorcists, binding demons and restraining malevolent forces. It governs the Five Peaks, Four Waterways, mountain spirits, and spectral entities, all of which are subdued by the eyes located between the ten finger joints of the practitioner’s hands.

**First point**: *Renzhong* (Philtrum), called *Ghost Palace*. Insert the needle from the left, exiting on the right.

**Second point**: Beneath the thumbnail of the thumb, called *Ghost Faith*. Insert three *fen* into the flesh.

**Third point**: Beneath the big toenail, called *Ghost Rampart*. Insert two *fen* into the flesh.

**Fourth point**: The transverse crease on the back of the hand, called *Ghost Heart*. Insert half an *cun*. This is *Taiyuan* point.

**Fifth point**: Below the lateral malleolus at the white flesh border of the foot *Taiyang* meridian, called *Ghost Path*. Fire needle seven times, thrusting three times per insertion. This is *Shenmai* point.

**Sixth point**: One *cun* above *Dazhui* within the hairline, called *Ghost Pillow*. Fire needle seven times, thrusting three times per insertion.

**Seventh point**: In the depression of the hairline anterior to the ear, five *fen* below the earlobe, called *Ghost Bed*. Fire needle seven times, thrusting three times per insertion.

**Eighth point**: *Chengjiang* (below the lower lip), called *Ghost Market*. Insert from the left, exiting on the right.

**Ninth point**: Three *cun* above the transverse crease of the wrist between the two tendons, called *Ghost Path*. This is *Laogong* point.

**Tenth point**: One *cun* above the midpoint of the nose within the hairline, called *Ghost Hall*. Fire needle seven times, thrusting three times per insertion. This is *Shangxing* point.

**Eleventh point**: The perineal seam (for men) or the head of the vaginal orifice (for women), called *Ghost Storehouse*. Moxa three cones.

**Twelfth point**: At the lateral end of the transverse crease of *Chize*, where the white flesh begins, called *Ghost Minister*. Fire needle seven times, thrusting three times per insertion. This is *Quchi* point.

**Thirteenth point**: One *cun* from the tip of the tongue, along the midline of the tongue’s underside, piercing through to the upper surface, called *Ghost Seal*. Secure the needle with a board across the mouth to prevent tongue movement.

For the aforementioned points, if they are paired on both hands and feet, needle both sides. For solitary points, needle once.

For demonic ravings, moxa *Xuanming* fourteen times. The point lies at the central string-like ridge inside the lips.

**First point**: Called *Ghost Stipend*. Alternatively, use a sharp blade to sever the string-like ridge for best effect.

For demonic illness with stuporous unconsciousness, treat at *Fengfu*. Also called *Ghost Point*.

For demonic illness with loud shouting, cursing, and running, moxa the tips of all ten fingers, one *fen* from the nails. Also called *Ghost City*.

For demonic illness with loud shouting, cursing, and fleeing far, treat at *Sānlǐ*. Also called *Ghost Evil*.

For demonic illness with ghostly epilepsy, heaviness in the four limbs, treat at the fontanel. Also called *Ghost Gate*.

For demonic illness with heaviness and pain in the four limbs and various miscellaneous symptoms, treat at *Chǐzé*. The pulsating vessel at the elbow crease is also called *Ghost Receiver*.

For demonic illness with incessant speech and various miscellaneous symptoms, treat at *Rénzhōng*. Also called *Ghost Guest Hall*. For all cases of being struck by malevolent forces, first press beneath the nose.

**Cānggōng’s method**:
For manic epilepsy with inability to recognize people, or epileptic vertigo and confusion, moxa *Bǎihuì* nine cones.
For manic running with convulsions, moxa three *cun* above *Yùzhěn*, or alternatively one *cun* behind the vertex, one hundred cones.
For manic running and epileptic illness, moxa two *cun* behind the vertex twelve cones.
For manic demonic speech, moxa *Tiānchuāng* nine cones.
For manic running and epileptic illness, moxa *Dàyōu* one hundred cones.
For manic speech and disorientation, moxa *Tiānshū* one hundred cones.
For manic running and epilepsy, moxa the tip of the eleventh rib thirty cones.
For manic epilepsy with weeping, moxa *Shǒunìzhù* thirty cones. The point lies six *cun* behind the wrist on both left and right hands.
For manic running and fright epilepsy, moxa *Hékǒu* fifty cones. The point lies in the depression behind the wrist where the pulsating vessel is. This corresponds to the *Yángmíng* channel.
For manic epilepsy, wind epilepsy, and tongue protrusion, moxa *Wèiguǎn* one hundred cones; do not needle.
For manic demonic outbreaks without regularity, disheveled hair, loud shouting, desire to kill, no avoidance of water or fire, and manic speech or raving, moxa *Jiānshǐ* thirty cones. The point lies five *cun* behind the wrist, between the two bones of the forearm. Also moxa for fright, fear, singing, and weeping.
For manic running with joy, anger, sorrow, and weeping, moxa *Chénjué* (or *Jùjiǎo*) according to the patient’s age. The point lies on the back, inside the scapular border, where the hand cannot reach, above the bone’s edge—press to locate the tender spot.
For manic demonic speech, moxa *Fútù* one hundred cones. (Previously recorded as nine cones at *Tiānchuāng*.)
For sorrowful weeping and demonic speech, moxa *Tiānfǔ* fifty cones.
For sorrowful weeping, demonic speech, ghostly confusion, singing, and weeping, moxa *Címén* fifty cones.
For manic demonic fright epilepsy, moxa *Chéngmìng* thirty cones. The point lies three *cun* above the inner ankle on the pulsating vessel. Also moxa for fright mania and running.
For manic epilepsy, wind fright, counterflow, and heart vexation, moxa *Jùyáng* fifty cones.
For manic epilepsy and demonic speech, moxa the *Foot Tàiyáng* forty cones.
For manic running and disorientation, moxa the *Foot Yángmíng* thirty cones.
For manic epilepsy and *yì* illness, moxa the *Foot Shàoyáng* according to the patient’s age.
For manic running, epilepsy, and collapse resembling death, moxa the three hairs of the big toe nine cones. *Yì* states: moxa *Dàdūn*.
For manic running and cursing, moxa *Bāhuì* according to the patient’s age. The point lies five *fēn* below the *Yángmíng*.
For manic epilepsy, fright running, wind, disorientation, anger, joy, cursing, laughter, singing, weeping, and demonic speech, moxa *Nǎohù*, *Fēngchí*, *Hand Yángmíng*, *Tàiyáng*, *Tàiyīn*, *Foot Yángmíng*, *Yángqiāo*, *Shàoyáng*, *Tàiyīn*, *Yīnqiāo*, and the heel, all according to the patient’s age.
For fright, fear, heart palpitations, and lack of strength, moxa *Dàhéng* fifty cones.
For manic madness with cursing, striking, and attacking people—termed *Hot Yáng Wind*—moxa the red-white junction at the corners of the mouth (swallow’s beak) one cone on each side. Also moxa the scrotal seam thirty cones: have the patient stand, mark the center with a brush, then moxa while lying down on the raised part above the testicles, avoiding the front center of the scrotum to prevent harming the *yáng* qi.
For manic running, stabbing people, or desire for suicide, incessant cursing, invoking gods and ghosts, moxa the red-white junction at the corner of the mouth one cone, and moxa the inner crease of both elbows five cones. Also moxa the midpoint between the shoulder blades three cones, repeating the moxibustion. Cānggōng’s method, divinely effective.
For ghostly possession, moxa one *cun* into the hairline one hundred cones, and moxa *Jiānshǐ* and the palm of the hand fifty cones each.
For fox possession, bind the two thumbs together and moxa the crease between them twenty-one cones. When the fox cries out, the illness will resolve.
For sudden manic speech and demonic language, tightly bind the two thumbs together with a pot-string, then moxa both sides beneath the ribs, directly below the curved rib ends, with both fires lit simultaneously, seven cones each. After a moment, the ghost will state its name and beg to leave; then slowly question it and untie the hands.
For sudden possession by malevolent spirits with disorientation and clenched jaw, moxa *Rénzhōng* beneath the nose and the base of the thumbnail on both hands and feet, with the moxa cone half on the nail and half on the flesh, seven cones each. If unresolved, fourteen cones, with the cone size of a sparrow’s droppings.
For wind evil, moxa *Jiānshǐ* according to the patient’s age, *Chéngjiāng* seven cones, the heart *shū* seven cones, and *Sānlǐ* seven cones.
For sudden manic demonic speech, needle the underside of the big toe’s nail, inserting slightly to stop.
*Sun Zhenren’s* *Emergency Essential Prescriptions*, Scroll Forty-Four, concludes. (Originally written as "three"; amended according to the Song Dynasty block-printed edition.)

#2 "Wind": Originally written as "dampness"; amended according to the Song Dynasty block-printed edition. #3 "Each": Originally omitted; supplied according to the Song Dynasty block-printed edition. The same applies below. #4 "One liang": The Song Dynasty block-printed edition reads "two liang." #5 "Two fen": The Song Dynasty block-printed edition reads "one fen." #6 "Qi contention with speech formula": The Song Dynasty block-printed edition reads "qi settled with convulsive spasms." #7 "Purple Stone Powder": The Song Dynasty block-printed edition reads "Purple Stone Decocted Powder." #8 "Five liang each": The Song Dynasty block-printed edition reads "three liang each." #9 "Two dou": The Song Dynasty block-printed edition reads "one dou." #10 "Pound": Originally written as "remove"; amended according to the Song Dynasty block-printed edition. #11 "Note": The Song Dynasty block-printed edition reads "method." #12 "Emaciation": Originally written as "measure"; amended according to the Song Dynasty block-printed edition.

*Sun Zhenren’s Emergency Essential Prescriptions*, Scroll Forty-Five.
Collated and corrected by Lin Yi, Gentleman for Court Service and Acting Vice Minister of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices, concurrently serving as Editorial Director of the Palace Library, and others, during the Song Dynasty.

**Small Intestine Fu Prescriptions**
**Sixth Prescription for Wind-Vacuity Fright Palpitations**

**Polygala Decoction** – *Supplements the heart and treats heart qi vacuity, fright palpitations, forgetfulness, and loss of appetite:*
Polygala root, dried ginger, atractylodes (white) #1, cinnamon bark, astragalus, fluorite (each three *liang*), saposhnikovia, tangkuei, ginseng, poria, licorice, ligusticum, poria with hostwood, notopterygium (each two *liang*), ophiopogon, pinellia (each four *liang*), jujubes (twelve pieces), schisandra fruit (two *ge*).
Eighteen ingredients in all. [Crush], decoct in one *dou* three *sheng* of water to yield three and a half *sheng*. Divide into five doses; take thrice by day, once by night.

**Alternative Prescription** – *Treats wind-strike with heart qi insufficiency, fright palpitations, incoherent speech, absentmindedness, vexation, oppression, and tinnitus:*
Polygala root, astragalus, poria, licorice, peony, tangkuei, cinnamon bark (omitted in one version), ophiopogon, ginseng (each two *liang*), notopterygium (four *liang*), fresh ginger (five *liang*), aconite (one *liang*).
Twelve ingredients in all. [Crush], decoct in one *dou* two *sheng* of water to yield four *sheng*. Each dose is eight *ge*; for the debilitated, five *ge*. Take thrice by day, once by night.

**Poria with Hostwood Decoction** – *Treats wind traversing the five viscera, severe vacuity with fright palpitations, and quiets the spirit to settle the mind:*
Poria with hostwood, saposhnikovia (each three *liang*), ginseng, polygala root, licorice, dragon bone, cinnamon bark, notopterygium (each two *liang*), atractylodes (white, one *liang*), asarum, dried ginger (each six *liang*), wild jujubes (one *sheng*).
Twelve ingredients in all. [Crush], decoct in nine *sheng* of water to yield three *sheng*. Divide into three doses.

**Alternative Prescription** – *Treats wind vacuity with fullness, stiff nape and neck, unsettled heart qi, and inability to eat:*
Poria with hostwood (four *liang*), ophiopogon (four *liang*), ginseng, notopterygium, polygala root, tangkuei, licorice, fluorite, schisandra fruit (each two *liang*) #2, pinellia, saposhnikovia, astragalus (each three *liang*), fresh ginger (five *liang*), wild jujubes (three *sheng*).
Fourteen ingredients in all. [Crush], decoct wild jujubes in one *dou* three *sheng* of water to yield one *dou*, remove jujubes, add remaining ingredients, and simmer to three and a half *sheng*. Each dose is seven *ge*; take thrice by day, twice by night.

**Heart-Supplementing Decoction** – *Treats heart qi insufficiency with symptoms of fright palpitations, sweating, heart vexation and oppression, shortness of breath, unregulated joy, anger, sorrow, and worry, chronic sore throat, blackened lips, blood ejection, stiff tongue root, and inability to swallow fluids:*
Fluorite, poria, ginseng, polygala root, tangkuei, poria with hostwood (*Master Shen*’s version uses cinnamon bark), licorice, aster (each two *liang*), ophiopogon (one *sheng*), adzuki beans (three *ge*), jujubes (thirty pieces).
Eleven ingredients in all. [Crush], decoct in one *dou* two *sheng* of water to yield three *sheng*. Divide into three doses.

**Alternative Prescription** – *Treats heart qi insufficiency with profuse sweating, heart vexation, soliloquy, excessive dreaming without awareness, sore throat, periodic blood ejection, stiff tongue root, and inability to swallow fluids:*
Ground fluorite, poria, ginseng, cinnamon bark (each two *liang*), ophiopogon (three *liang*), aster, licorice (each one *liang*), jujubes (seven pieces), adzuki beans (twenty-four pieces).
Nine ingredients in all. [Crush], decoct in eight *sheng* of water to yield two and a half *sheng*. Divide into three doses; spring and summer are the best seasons for administration.

**Alternative Prescription** – *Treats sudden confusion, morning improvement and evening worsening, fright palpitations, mental agitation, chest fullness, loss of appetite, decline of yin and yang qi, spleen-stomach failure to grind, aversion to human voices, and settles the mind to downbear qi:*
Ginseng, poria, polygala root, licorice, unripe bitter orange, tangkuei, dragon’s teeth, platycodon (each three *liang*), pinellia, cinnamon bark (each five *liang*), astragalus (four *liang*), fresh ginger (six *liang*), poria with hostwood (two *liang*), jujubes (twenty-plus pieces).
Fourteen ingredients in all. [Crush], first boil five *ge* of non-glutinous rice until done, strain, then add the ingredients and decoct to yield four *sheng*. Each dose is eight *ge*; take thrice by day, twice by night.

**Alternative Prescription** – *Treats heart qi insufficiency with heart pain and fright:*
Polygala root, cattail pollen (one version uses calamus), ginseng, poria (each four *liang*).
Four ingredients in all. [Crush], decoct in one *dou* of water to yield three and a half *sheng*. Divide into three doses.

**Alternative Prescription** – *Treats heart qi insufficiency with pulling pain between abdomen and back, inability to bend or extend (also called Heart-Injury Decoction):*
Poria with hostwood, scutellaria, polygala root, dried rehmannia (each three *liang*), ophiopogon, gypsum (each four *liang*), pinellia, aconite, cinnamon bark, fresh ginger (each two *liang*), licorice, donkey-hide gelatin, malt sugar (each one *liang*), jujubes (thirty-plus pieces).
Fourteen ingredients in all. [Crush] twelve ingredients, decoct in one *dou* of water to yield three *sheng*, strain, add malt sugar and gelatin, and simmer to two *sheng* two *ge*. Divide into three doses.
*This prescription duplicates the Major Heart-Supplementing Decoction in the previous scroll on heart vacuity and repletion, differing only in dosages.*

**Minor Mind-Settling Decoction** – *Treats vacuity emaciation, weak heart qi with fright, and frequent nightmares:*
Poria (four *liang*), cinnamon bark (three *liang*), licorice, peony, dried ginger, polygala root, ginseng (each two *liang*), jujubes (fifteen pieces).
Eight ingredients in all. [Crush], decoct in eight *sheng* of water to yield three *sheng* #3. Divide into four doses; take thrice by day, once by night.

**Major Mind-Settling Decoction** – *Treats heart qi vacuity with palpitations, absentmindedness, forgetfulness, or dreaming and waking fright, and insufficient will #4:*
Ginseng, poria, poria with hostwood, polygala root, red halloysite, dragon bone, dried ginger, tangkuei, licorice, atractylodes (white), peony, cinnamon bark, aster, saposhnikovia (each two *liang*), jujubes (twenty pieces).

Fifteen ingredients in all. [Crush], decoct in one *dou* two *sheng* of water to yield three *sheng* and a half #5. Divide into five doses; take thrice by day, twice by night.

**Formula for Fright-Labor and Lost Will** – *Treats fright, taxation, and loss of will:*
Licorice, cinnamon bark (each two *liang*), dragon bone, saposhnikovia, ophiopogon root, oyster shell, polygala root (each one *liang*), poria with hostwood (five *liang*), jujubes (twenty pieces).
Nine ingredients in all. [Crush], decoct in eight *sheng* of water to yield two *sheng*. Divide into two doses; take at an interval of the time it takes a person to walk five *li*.

**Thin-Bamboo Decoction** – *Treats heart vacuity with unsteady fright palpitations and emaciation:*
Thin bamboo sap (two *sheng*), poria with hostwood, dictamnus root (each three *liang*), ginseng (two *liang*), silver (ten *liang*). Decoct the silver in one *dou* of water to yield three *sheng*.
Five ingredients in all. [Crush] the three medicinal ingredients, then decoct in the bamboo sap and silver decoction to yield one *sheng* four *ge*. Divide into three doses; take at an interval of the time it takes a person to walk ten *li*.

**Alternative Formula:**
Thin bamboo sap (two *sheng*). Simmer over a slow fire to yield one *sheng* six *ge*. Divide and take warm, four *ge* per dose, thrice by day, once by night.

**Mind-Settling Decoction** – *Treats wind vacuity, taxation cold, heart qi insufficiency, forgetfulness, fright, terror, and unsettled spirit and will:*
Saposhnikovia, tangkuei, rhubarb, ophiopogon root (each five *fen*—this ingredient also said to be five *liang*), alisma, fermented soybean, ampelopsis (each four *fen*—this ingredient also said to be three *liang*), acorus, ginseng, platycodon, cinnamon bark, polygala root, dioscorea, gypsum (each three *fen*), aster, dried ginger, poria (each two *fen*—also said to be three *liang*), atractylodes (white), licorice (each ten *fen*), polished rice (five *ge*), jujubes (five *liang*) #6, aconite, poria with hostwood (each two *liang*), gentian (six *fen*).
Twenty-four ingredients in all. [Crush], decoct in one *dou* two *sheng* of water. First boil the rice until done, remove the dregs, then add the other ingredients and decoct to yield four *sheng*. Divide into doses of eight *ge*; take thrice by day, once by night. *The Thousand Gold Wings* omits the polished rice and forms honeyed pills the size of firmiana seeds; take ten pills with wine, increasing to twenty pills.

**Major Mind-Settling Powder** – *Treats heart vacuity with fright palpitations, dreaming and waking terror:*
Fluorite, poria, saposhnikovia, ginseng, licorice, alisma (each eight *fen*), astragalus, gentian, atractylodes (white), dioscorea, ampelopsis (each six *fen*), ophiopogon root, tangkuei (each five *fen*), platycodon, fermented soybean, biota seed, cinnamon bark, polygala root, rhubarb, gypsum (each four *fen*), Sichuan pepper, peony, dried ginger, asarum (each three *fen*).
Twenty-four ingredients in all. Grind to powder and sift. Take two square *cun* spoons with wine, thrice daily.
One version omits fluorite, poria, alisma, and dried ginger, and includes jujubes (four *fen*); form honeyed pills the size of firmiana seeds and take fifteen pills with wine.

**Alternative Formula** – *Treats wind vacuity with heart qi fright-weakness, absentmindedness, sudden anger or sorrow, and discontented will:*
Fluorite, quartz, rehmannia (one version omits this), cinnabar, dragon’s teeth, ginseng, asarum, aconite (main root), aconite (accessory tuber), polygala root, poria, atractylodes (white), cinnamon bark, saposhnikovia (each two *liang*).
Fifteen ingredients in all. Grind to powder and sift. Take two square *cun* spoons with wine, thrice daily.

**Minor Mind-Settling Powder** – *Treats heart qi insufficiency with vacuity palpitations, terror, sorrow, absentmindedness, unsettled heart spirit, and constant fright:*
Ginseng, polygala root, atractylodes (white), aconite, rehmannia, adzuki bean, cinnamon bark, astragalus, asarum, dried ginger, dragon’s teeth, saposhnikovia, acorus (each two *liang*), poria (four *liang*).
Fourteen ingredients in all. Grind to powder and sift. Take two square *cun* spoons with wine, thrice daily.

**Mind-Settling Pill** – *Treats vacuity detriment in men and women, dreaming and waking fright palpitations, or loss of spirit; in women, red and white vaginal discharge or menstrual irregularities; wind evil and ghost possession; alternating chills and fever; abdominal accumulations and gatherings; and qi binding from sorrow and worry:*
Fluorite, poria, acorus, cistanche, polygala root, ophiopogon root, rhubarb, tangkuei, asarum, selaginella, fermented soybean, dried ginger (each five *fen*) #7, saposhnikovia, ginseng, alisma, gentian, salvia (each six *fen*), gypsum, peony, biota seed (each three *fen*), aconite, cinnamon bark, platycodon, licorice, dioscorea (each ten *fen*) #8, ampelopsis, iron filings, silver filings, peucedanum, bezoar (each two *fen*), rehmannia (twelve *fen*), atractylodes (white), pinellia (each eight *fen*), ground beetles (twelve pieces), jujubes (fifty pieces).
Thirty-five ingredients in all. Grind to powder, mix with honey and jujube pulp, and pound five thousand times. Form pills the size of firmiana seeds; take five pills with wine, thrice daily, increasing to twenty pills.
One version omits fermented soybean and jujubes.

**Major Mind-Settling Pill** – *Treats the same conditions as the previous formula; governs all heart diseases:*
Rehmannia (six *fen*), bezoar (five *fen*—one version uses achyranthes), notopterygium, cinnamon bark, ophiopogon root, gentian, ligusticum, ginseng, polygala root, fluorite, cinnabar, donkey-hide gelatin, licorice, rhubarb, silver filings, ampelopsis, tangkuei, dried ginger, saposhnikovia (each eight *fen*), apricot kernel, Sichuan pepper (each three *fen*) #9, alisma, astragalus, poria, fermented soybean, dioscorea, poria with hostwood, peucedanum, iron filings, biota seed (each five *fen*) #10, jujubes (forty pieces), mantis egg-cases (eleven pieces) #11.

The above thirty-two ingredients are ground into powder and mixed with white honey and jujubes to form pills. Take seven pills with wine, thrice daily, increasing to twenty pills.

**Minor Mind-Settling Pill** – *Treats insufficiency of heart qi, fright-induced deficiency, palpitations, counterflow qi in the chest, nightmares, confusion, forgetfulness, and disorientation:*
Fluorite, cinnabar, poria with hostwood, silver filings, realgar, acorus, ginseng, platycodon, dried ginger, polygala root, licorice, tangkuei, cinnamon bark (each two *fen*), saposhnikovia, asarum, iron filings, stephania (each one *liang*).
The above seventeen ingredients are ground into powder and mixed with honey to form pills the size of soybeans. Take ten pills with water, thrice daily, increasing to twenty pills. One version uses two *fen* of poria, making eighteen ingredients.

**Minor Mind-Stabilizing Pill** – *Treats unsettled heart qi, insufficiency of the five viscera, severe cases of sorrow, grief, melancholy, sudden forgetfulness, symptoms worsening at dawn or dusk, and manic vertigo:*
Acorus, polygala root (each two *liang*), poria, ginseng (each three *liang*).
The above four ingredients are ground into powder and mixed with honey to form pills the size of firmiana seeds. Take seven pills with water, thrice daily. Adding poria with hostwood makes the *Poria Spirit Pill*. Taking the powder directly is also effective.

**Fluorite Wine** – *Treats long-standing wind, deficiency cold, insufficiency of heart qi, or occasional fright and fear:*
Fluorite (one *jin*), stalactite, saposhnikovia, polygala root, cinnamon bark (each four *liang*), ephedra, poria, atractylodes, licorice (each three *liang*).
The above nine ingredients are cut and steeped in three *dou* of wine for five days during spring. Take four *ge* each time, thrice daily, or drink to intoxication, maintaining a constant presence of wine’s influence.

**Seventh Remedy for Forgetfulness – Pillow Formula**

**Pillow Formula – Powder of Tortoise Shell**

Tortoise shell, dragon bone, polygala root, and sweetflag—four ingredients in equal parts, ground and sifted. Take one square-inch spoonful with wine, thrice daily. Regular use sharpens the mind greatly. *The Thousand Gold Prescriptions* states: take with water after meals.

**Formula to Treat Forgetfulness and Prevent Memory Loss**

Sweetflag (two parts), poria, poria with hostwood, and ginseng (each five parts), polygala root (seven parts). The above five ingredients are ground and sifted. Take one square-inch spoonful with wine, thrice daily and once at night. Effects manifest after five days; the spirit is greatly enhanced.

**Alternative Formula**

Cistanche and dipsacus (each one part), polygala root, sweetflag, and poria (each three parts). The above five ingredients are ground and sifted. Take one square-inch spoonful with wine, thrice daily. Memory remains sharp even into old age.

**Powder to Open the Heart – Treats Forgetfulness**

Polygala root and ginseng (each one part), sweetflag (one *liang*), poria (two *liang*). The above

Take one square-inch spoonful after meals, twice daily.

**Alternative Formula**
On the seventh day of the seventh month, gather sweetflag and take three square-inch spoonfuls with wine, drinking to the point of mild intoxication.

**Alternative Formula**
On a *jiazi* day, gather a one-inch section of sweetflag with nine nodes from a stone surface, dry in the shade for one hundred days, grind and sift, then take one square-inch spoonful thrice daily. This sharpens hearing and vision and prevents forgetfulness. Found on the southern mountain of Quzhou Stone Bridge Temple.

**Alternative Formula**
On the seventh day of the seventh month, take one *sheng* of hemp seeds and two *liang* of ginseng, grind into powder, steam until thoroughly infused, and take one *daogui* measure before retiring at night. This enables knowledge of all matters in the four directions.

**Alternative Formula**
On a *wuzi* day, gather fourteen peach twigs from the east side, bind them, and place them beneath the pillow in your sleeping quarters to prevent forgetfulness.

**Alternative Formula**
On the fifth day of the fifth month, gather east-facing peach twigs before sunrise, carve them into a three-inch wooden figurine, and carry it in your clothing sash to prevent forgetfulness.

**Alternative Formula**
On a *dingyou* day, personally purchase polygala root from the market, wrap it in the corner of your clothing, return home, grind it into powder, and consume it to prevent forgetfulness.

**Formula to Treat Mental Dullness, Forgetfulness, and Frequent Errors**
On the seventh day of the seventh month, gather spiderwebs and place them in the collar of your clothing without others knowing. This prevents forgetfulness.

*Sun Zhenren’s* *Beiji Qianjin Yaofang*, Scroll Forty-Five, concludes.
