**Formulas for the Lung**

**Discourse on the Lung’s Pulse (First Section)**

The Discourse states: The lung governs the *po* (corporeal soul). The *po*-viscus is the essence that receives external things, serving as the "supreme general" stationed above to govern ascent. Thus, the lung is the canopy of the five viscera.

The entry and exit of essence are called *po*, and the *po* is the repository of the lung. The nose is the lung’s official; the lung’s *qi* communicates with the nose, and when the nose is harmonious, it can distinguish fragrance from foulness.

Its pathways circulate through the Purple Palace, ascend to the cheeks, manifest below the nose, return to the lung, flourish in the hair, externally govern *qi*, and internally govern the chest, corresponding to the breasts—left breast to *geng* (Metal-Yang), right breast to *xin* (Metal-Yin). The lung weighs three *jin* and three *liang*, with six lobes and two ears, totaling eight lobes. Fourteen boys and seven girls guard it, and its spirit is named *Honghong*.

It stores the *po*, hence called the *po*-viscus. Adapting to seasonal nodes, it is said: "The lung stores *qi*, and *qi* harbors the *po*." In *qi*, it manifests as cough; in fluids, as nasal mucus.

When lung-*qi* is deficient, the nasal passages are unobstructed yet breath is scant; when replete, there is panting, wheezing, and chest distension with labored breathing.

Deficient lung-*qi* causes dreams of white objects or scenes of slaughter with bloodshed; when aligned with its season, dreams of warfare arise. Exuberant *qi* induces dreams of terror, weeping, and lamentation.

If perverse *qi* invades the lung, one dreams of soaring, encountering metal implements or strange objects.

The lung corresponds to Metal and pairs with the large intestine as its *fu*-organ. Its channel is the Hand Greater Yin, externally-internally linked with the Yang Brightness. Its pulse is floating, associated with late summer, and flourishes in autumn.

Autumn is the season when all things conclude—withered leaves fall from branches, and bare twigs stand solitary. Its pulse is slightly floating: *wei*-*qi* slows, *ying*-*qi* quickens. Quickening resides above, slowing below, hence called "hair."

When Yang should descend but fails, or Yin should ascend but cannot, the two *qi* clash, allowing wind-cold to invade. If Yang is afflicted, the pulse curls; if Yin is afflicted, it tightens. Curling induces aversion to cold; tightening causes shivering. When cold and shivering contend, it is called malaria.

Weakness induces fever; floating indicates emergence. If onset occurs at dawn, it strikes at dawn; if at dusk, it strikes at dusk. Viscera have proximity and distance; pulses have slowness and rapidity. Cycles have measurements; movements have time divisions. Slowness above injures the exterior; rapidity below harms the lower burner.

If the middle burner harbors evil, it manifests; if benign, it conceals. When Yang-*qi* descends, Yin-*qi* warms. If Yang reverses below and Yin reverses above, it is called "prolonged and lingering."

The autumn pulse is floating—the lung’s pulse, corresponding to the West and Metal. All things gather and ripen, so its *qi* arrives light, vacuous, and floating, coming urgently and scattering swiftly—hence called "floating." Its contrary indicates illness.

What constitutes its contrary? If its *qi* arrives like hair but is firm in the center with vacuity at the sides, this is called "excess," and the illness lies externally. If its *qi* arrives faint like hair, this is called "insufficiency," and the illness lies internally.

Excess causes *qi* counterflow with back pain and vexing heat. Insufficiency induces panting, shortness of breath, coughing, counterflow *qi*, blood expectoration, and audible pathological sounds below.

A normal lung pulse arrives gently, like falling elm seeds—this is the lung’s harmony, with stomach-*qi* as its foundation.

A lung pulse arriving neither ascending nor descending, like stroking a chicken’s feather, indicates lung disease. (*Source of Pathogens* omits "not.")

A lung pulse arriving like a floating object or wind-blown hair indicates mortal lung disease.

When the true lung pulse arrives, it is large and vacuous, like feathers brushing the skin. The complexion is white-red without luster, and when body hair withers, death ensues.

In autumn, a pulse with slight hair-like quality and stomach-*qi* is normal. Predominantly hair-like with scant stomach-*qi* indicates lung disease. Hair-like without stomach-*qi* is fatal. Hair-like with string-like quality foretells spring illness; pronounced string-like quality indicates imminent illness.

The lung stores *qi* and harbors the *po*. Excessive joy and pleasure injure the *po*; when the *po* is injured, mania ensues. The manic disregard others, their skin withers, body hair wilts, and complexion fades—they die in summer.

When the Hand Greater Yin’s *qi* is severed, skin and body hair wither. The Greater Yin governs the circulation of *qi* to warm skin and body hair. If *qi* fails to nourish, skin and body hair wither; when they wither, fluids depart. Fluid loss injures skin and joints; when skin and joints are injured, nails (or skin) desiccate and body hair withers. When body hair withers, *qi* dies first—*bing* (third Heavenly Stem) hastens, *ding* (fourth Heavenly Stem) brings death, as Fire overcomes Metal.

When the lung is a dead viscus, its pulse is vacuous upon light touch and weak upon pressure, like an onion leaf without root—this is fatal.

In autumn, when Metal and the lung flourish, a slightly rough and short pulse is normal. If it is instead large and moderate, this is the spleen overacting on the lung, the mother returning to the child—a vacuous evil, though ill, easily treated.

If it is instead deep, soft, and slippery, this is the kidney overacting on the lung, the child overwhelming the mother—a replete evil, though ill, self-resolving.

If it is instead floating, large, and surging, this is the heart overacting on the lung, Fire overcoming Metal—a thieving evil, a grave reversal; ten deaths, no cure.

If it is instead string-like, fine, and long, this is the liver overacting on the lung, Wood encroaching on Metal—a minor evil, though ill, swiftly healing.

When the liver overacts on the lung, it must manifest as vacuity.

If the Yin pulse at the inch position before the right bar is severed, there is no lung pulse. If accompanied by shortness of breath, cough with counterflow, throat obstruction, and belching, needle the Hand Yang Brightness to treat Yang.

If the Yin pulse at the inch position before the right bar is replete, the lung is replete. One suffers from scant *qi*, fullness and distension in the chest, and tension extending to the shoulders—needle the Hand Greater Yin to treat Yin.

When the lung pulse arrives, it is light and floating, like a gentle breeze brushing the feathers on a crow’s back. Arriving twice is normal; thrice indicates channel disease; four times, essence depletion; five times, death; six times, life’s end—this is the Hand Greater Yin pulse.

An extremely tense lung pulse causes epilepsy; slight tension induces lung cold-heat, lassitude, coughing with blood, and pulling pain in the waist, back, and chest, or nasal polyps causing obstruction.

An excessively slack lung pulse causes profuse sweating; slight slackness induces atrophy, *loufeng* (or *pianfeng*), and uncontrollable sweating from the head downward. An extremely large pulse indicates channel swelling; slight largeness indicates lung impediment, with pulling pain in the chest and back extending to the inner waist. An extremely small pulse causes *sūnxiè*; slight smallness induces *xiāodàn*. An extremely slippery pulse causes *xīpèn* and counterflow *qi*; slight slipperiness induces bleeding from the upper and lower orifices. An extremely rough pulse causes blood vomiting; slight roughness induces *shǔlòu*, appearing between the neck, limbs, and armpits, where the lower cannot overcome the upper, and one craves sour flavors.

When the lung pulse is forceful, firm, and long, one will suffer from blood-spitting. If it is soft and scattered, one will suffer from *lòu* (or *guàn*) sweating, which will not disperse even now. When the white pulse arrives, it is panting and floating, with upper vacuity and lower repletion, causing fright and accumulation of *qi* in the chest. Panting with vacuity is called lung impediment, with alternating cold and heat, contracted from drunkenness followed by sexual activity.

The Yellow Emperor asked: Of the twelve channels, why does only the Hand Greater Yin pulse move without cease?
The Hand Greater Yin originates in the inch opening.
Qibo replied: The Foot Yang Brightness is the stomach channel. The stomach is the sea of the five viscera and six bowels. The stomach channel lies between the great toe and the instep, ascending three *cun* to the bone junction. Its essence-*qi* ascends and clears, pouring into the lung, and the lung *qi* follows the Greater Yin in its circulation. Its movement corresponds to the rhythm of breathing, so with each exhalation the pulse moves twice, and with each inhalation it also moves twice. As breathing does not cease, the pulse does not stop.

The Yellow Emperor asked: Why does the *qìkǒu* alone govern the five viscera?
Qibo said: The stomach is the sea of water and grain. Among the six bowels, the stomach is the largest. The five flavors enter the mouth and are stored in the stomach to nourish the *qi* of the five viscera. The *qìkǒu* is the Greater Yin; the *qi* and flavors of the viscera and bowels all issue from the stomach and manifest at the *qìkǒu*. The *qìkǒu* pertains to the bowels and governs the viscera—this is what is called the *cùnkǒu*.

Bian Que said: When the lung is diseased, the nose and mouth open wide; with repletion heat, there is panting counterflow and propped-up breathing. If its Yang *qi* is robust, one dreams of terror and fear. With vacuity cold, there is coughing, panting, diarrhea, and scant *qi*. If its Yin *qi* is robust, one dreams of wading through water.

The lung corresponds in sound to weeping, in movement to coughing, and in emotion to sorrow. Sorrow damages the lung; when essence-*qi* converges in the lung, one feels grief. Its flavor governs autumn. When binding fullness and blood are present, the disease lies in the chest, or it may arise from dietary irregularities—treat at the *hé* points, hence it is said that flavor governs the *hé*.

When disease first arises in the lung, there is panting and coughing. After three days, it reaches the liver, causing rib-side pain and propping fullness. After one day, it reaches the spleen, causing blockage and obstruction, bodily pain, and heavy limbs. After five days, it reaches the stomach, causing abdominal distension. If ten days pass without resolution, death ensues—at dusk in winter, at dawn in summer.

When disease is in the lung, clarity comes at late afternoon, severity at midday, and stillness at midnight. If lung disease is contracted from traveling south or eating horse or roebuck meat, or if not, it will erupt in summer, with onset on *bǐng-dīng* days—red medicinals are suitable.

In general, lung disease manifests as panting, coughing, counterflow *qi*, shoulder panting, back pain, sweating, cramping of the buttocks, private parts, thighs, knees, and calves, and pain in the hip joints, shanks, and feet. With vacuity, there is scant *qi* and inability to catch one’s breath, deafness, and dry throat—treat the Hand Greater Yin and Foot Greater Yang channels externally, and the Ceasing Yin and Lesser Yin channels internally, where the blood is.

When the lung pulse is deep and rapid, or floating and panting, one suffers from shivering cold and heat, abdominal fullness, heat in the intestines, red urine, shoulder and back pain, sweating from the waist upward, contracted from sexual activity followed by exposure to wind.

In lung disease, the complexion is white, the body is only cold without heat, and there is frequent coughing. If the pulse is slightly slow, it is treatable—suitable formulas include *Schisandra Great Supplementation Decoction* and *Drain the Lung Powder*. In spring, needle *Lesser Shang*; in summer, *Fish Border*—both to drain. In late summer, needle *Great Abyss*; in autumn, *Channel Ditch*; in winter, *Cubit Marsh*—all to supplement.

One should also apply moxibustion at *Shanzhong* (CV 17) with one hundred cones and at the third thoracic vertebra with twenty-five cones. When pathogenic qi resides in the lung, the skin aches, cold shivering arises, qi surges upward causing panting, sweating, and coughing that agitates the shoulders and back. Select the outer transport points on the chest and the points beside the third thoracic vertebra—when pressed with the hand, if the patient feels relief, then needle them. Also needle *Quepen* (ST 12) to disperse the pathogen.

Cold in form and cold drinks injure the lung, for the two colds interact, harming both interior and exterior, thus causing qi to rebel and ascend. When the lung is injured, exertion leads to coughing and spitting of blood. If the pulse is fine, tight, floating, or rapid, all indicate spitting of blood, resulting from restlessness, anger, or lung injury with qi obstruction.

When wind invades the lung, the mouth becomes dry and panting ensues, the body feels heavy and dizzy, and swelling occurs. When cold invades the lung, the person experiences abdominal rumbling. In lung water disease, the body swells and urination is difficult, sometimes with sudden urges, and the stool resembles duck droppings. In lung distension, there is emptiness and fullness, panting and coughing, with a sensation as if the moon were about to fall. The pulse is floating and large.

When the *Fuyang* pulse is floating and moderate, and the *Shaoyang* pulse is slightly tight, slight tightness indicates blood deficiency, while tightness suggests mild cold—this is *shuru* (nodular skin lesions). Upon diagnosis of lung accumulation, the pulse is floating and hair-like; when pressed, it scatters and evades. There is intermittent pain below the ribs, radiating to the back, shortness of breath, forgetfulness, blurred vision, abscess formation, cold skin, and improvement in autumn but worsening in summer. The skin intermittently aches, as if insects were crawling, or in severe cases, as if pricked by needles, sometimes itching, with a white complexion.

The lung accumulation is called *Xiben*, located beneath the right rib, covering an area as large as a cup. If unresolved for long, it causes alternating chills and fever, qi counterflow, panting, coughing, and lung abscess. It is contracted on *jia-yi* days of spring. Why? When heart disease transmits to the lung, the lung should transmit to the liver, but the liver is in its ascendant phase during spring. The ascendant organ does not receive pathogens, so the lung attempts to return the pathogen to the heart, which refuses it. Thus, the pathogen lingers and forms an accumulation—hence *Xiben* is contracted in spring.

In lung disease, the body should have heat, coughing, shortness of breath, and spitting of pus and blood, with a pulse that should be short and rough. If the pulse is instead floating and large, and the complexion should be white but is instead red, this indicates fire overwhelming metal—a grave reversal, with no chance of survival.

Those of the *Shang* tone belong to the lung’s sound, which is weeping. Its note is like a chime stone, its emotion is joy, and its channel is the Hand Greater Yin. When yang brightness is in counterflow, the constructive and defensive qi fail to circulate, yin and yang reverse their positions, yang qi strikes internally, and yin qi is injured externally. Injury leads to cold, cold to deficiency, and deficiency to vulnerability to severe wind, causing shivering, trembling, hoarse and scattered speech, short and exhausted breath, weakness in the limbs, a bluish-green complexion, and involuntary loss of stool and urine. In severe cases, it is incurable, but *Ephedra Continuing Life Decoction* governs it. The formula is found in the eighth scroll.

It is also said that when the voice is panting and urgent, with shortness of breath and frequent spitting, this indicates fire overwhelming metal, yang striking yin, yin qi sinking, and yang qi rising. Rising leads to repletion, repletion to heat, heat to madness, madness to closed eyes, palpitations, and incoherent speech. The mouth is red and gaping, with no regularity in drinking—this is heat injuring the lung, transforming it into blood, and is incurable. If the face is red but the nose is not crooked, it is treatable.

When lung disease manifests as malaria, it causes the person to feel cold in the heart. Severe cold gives way to heat, and during the heat phase, there is frequent fright, as if seeing something. *Dichroa Decoction* governs this. The formula is found in the tenth scroll.

If a person’s voice was originally strong and resonant but suddenly becomes faint, requiring effort to speak, differing from their usual state, and when called or spoken to, they stare blankly without responding—though not yet ill, their condition will not last long. This is the sign of lung disease in the voice. In examining illness, when the exterior and interior correspond, and one investigates the source to administer treatment, nothing is missed.

White corresponds to the lung, which governs the skin. A white complexion like lard is auspicious. The lung governs the nose, which is the lung’s surplus. Those of the metal constitution resemble the *Shang* tone above: white complexion, small head, square face, small shoulders and back, small abdomen, small hands and feet, light and agile body, keen and upright, quick-minded yet calm, and inclined toward officialdom. They endure autumn and winter but not spring and summer; if affected in spring and summer, they fall ill. They govern the Hand Greater Yin.

If the shoulders and chest are upright and balanced in thickness, the lung responds accordingly. A pure white complexion with fine texture indicates a small lung; small lungs drink little and do not suffer from panting or thirst. Coarse texture indicates a large lung; large lungs are deficient, deficient lungs are cold, causing panting, wheezing, excessive drinking, and susceptibility to chest and throat blockage with counterflow qi. If the shoulders are broad, the chest protrudes, and the throat is sunken, the lung is high; high lungs are replete, replete lungs are hot, causing upward qi, shoulder breathing, and cough with counterflow. If the armpits are closed and the ribs are flared, the lung is low; low lungs press upon the *ben* (stomach) and oppress the liver, causing frequent pain below the ribs, nasal congestion, or obstruction with snivel, and the growth of polyps. If the shoulders and back are thick, the lung is firm; firm lungs do not suffer from cough or upward qi. If the shoulders and back are thin, the lung is fragile; fragile lungs are easily injured by heat, causing panting and nosebleeds. If the shoulders and chest are well-formed, the lung is upright; upright lungs are harmonious, beneficial, and difficult to injure. If the chest is uneven, the lung is slanted; slanted lungs cause pain in one side of the chest, and the nose is also afflicted on one side.

All people have areas of depression and elevation in their bodily regions, which necessarily give rise to disease. The yang brightness of the large intestine is the lung’s domain, and the visceral qi communicate between interior and exterior, so the domain also responds accordingly. The deep and turbid pertain to the interior, the floating and clear to the exterior. If an external disease enters the interior, the domain becomes elevated; if an internal disease emerges outward, the domain becomes depressed. When an external disease enters, first treat the yang, then the yin; when an internal disease emerges, first treat the yin, then the yang—drain the replete and supplement the deficient.

The yang governs the exterior, the yin governs the interior. In all matters of life, death, fortune, or misfortune, the visceral spirits first manifest changes in form externally. When the lung is initially diseased, the nose becomes parched and dry with open pores. If the lung is on the verge of death, the nose’s bridge collapses, its pores close, and its color turns dark and black. Should the color of the celestial center and its corresponding regions match the hue of the tomb, death is certain and untreatable. Assess the depth of the color to gauge whether the condition is chronic or acute—if distant, death will not occur within a year; if acute, it will not extend beyond the month. How can one know if a lung ailment has slightly improved only to result in sudden death? It is said: if a blackish-red mark like a thumbprint appears on the cheek, sudden death is certain. The lung expires after three days—how can one know? The mouth gapes open, exhaling without inhalation, the face turns white, and the eyes green—this is called "disordered channels." Drinking wine while exposed to wind allows wind to enter the lung channel, causing reckless discharge of gallbladder qi, turning the eyes green. Even with heavenly intervention, life cannot be restored. A face yellow and eyes white as dry bone foretell death.

Fortune and misfortune are revealed in the divisions of the facial regions. If colors appear in proper sequence, red and white entering the nose foretell illness within the year. If no affliction arises in that time, calamity will strike within three years. In autumn, the lung’s qi is white, corresponding to the hand greater yin channel. In autumn, one selects the channel’s transport points. Autumn is when metal begins its governance, the lung prepares to gather and restrain, metal overcomes fire, yang qi resides in the uniting points, and yin qi begins its ascendancy. Damp qi assails the body, but yin qi is not yet dominant and cannot penetrate deeply. Thus, one selects the transport points to drain yin evil and the uniting points to deplete yang evil. As yang qi begins to wane, one selects the uniting points.

The root of this channel lies in the middle of the inch-opening, two inches between the two tendons behind the palm, corresponding to the pulsating artery beneath the armpit. Its root originates at the Great Granary, located three inches above the navel—one handbreadth. Its sinews begin above the thumb, ascend along the finger, bind behind the thenar eminence, run along the outer side of the inch-opening, ascend the arm, bind at the elbow, follow the inner upper arm, enter beneath the armpit, emerge above the supraclavicular fossa, bind in front of the shoulder joint, ascend to bind at the supraclavicular fossa, descend to bind within the chest, disperse and penetrate beneath the diaphragm, and reach the lower ribs.

The channel arises in the middle burner, descends to connect with the large intestine, circles back along the stomach’s opening, ascends through the diaphragm to connect with the lung. From the lung’s system, it extends horizontally beneath the armpit, descends along the inner upper arm, passes in front of the hand lesser yin and heart governor channels, descends to the elbow, follows the inner lower edge of the arm’s upper bone, enters the inch-opening, ascends to the thenar eminence, and emerges at the thumb’s tip. Its branch separates from the wrist’s posterior, runs directly to the index finger’s inner edge, and emerges at its tip. It pairs with the hand yang brightness as exterior and interior.

The root of the yang brightness lies in the elbow’s bone, converging with the hand greater yin. The greater yin’s divergence is called *Lieque*, arising in the space beneath the armpit, paralleling the greater yin’s channel to enter the palm, dispersing into the thenar eminence, and branching to the hand yang brightness. It governs lung-generated diseases. When the disease is replete, the large intestine becomes hot; heat causes the hand’s *Dui* and palm to rise, and rising causes yang disease. If the yang pulse is three times greater than the inch-opening’s pulse, the disease manifests as coughing, ascending qi, panting, thirst, vexation, fullness in the chest, pain along the inner front of the upper arm, and heat in the palm. When qi is abundant and excessive, the shoulders and back ache from wind, sweating, and wind strike. When deficient, the large intestine becomes cold; cold causes yawning and coughing. Frequent urination indicates yin disease. If the yin pulse is half the size of the inch-opening’s pulse, the disease manifests as cold pain in the shoulders and back, shortness of breath, insufficient qi for respiration, hollow pain in the lower ribs, altered urine color, and sudden involuntary loss of stool.

The three months of autumn govern the lung and large intestine, and the white qi *li* disease. Its origin lies in the greater yang striking the hand greater yin; when the greater yin receives the excess evil qi, the channels and network vessels become congested, and the skin and hair tighten. If the evil is discharged, the viscera and bowels are harmed by warmth, and as autumn receives the pestilence, the disease reverses. If the bowel is deficient, it is harmed by yin evil, causing alternating chills and fever, damaging the lung and injuring qi, leading to sudden coughing and retching. If the viscus is replete, it is harmed by yang toxin, generating heat and rashes, panting, and excessive thirst—this is called the white qi *li* disease. Bian Que said: moxibustion at the heart and lung transport points treats cinnabar toxin and white *li* disease. One should treat according to its origin, harmonizing the yang and regulating the yin, so that diseases of the viscera and bowels do not arise.

**Discourse on Lung Taxation, Third**
**Formulas**
**Moxibustion Methods**

It is said: For all lung taxation diseases, supplement kidney qi to benefit them, for when the kidney prevails, it responds to the lung. Those who go against autumn qi will find the hand taiyin failing to astringe, and lung qi scorched and full. Following it brings life; opposing it brings death. Following it brings order; opposing it brings chaos. Reversing the proper order is called *barrier and obstruction*, and disease arises.

Magnolia bark, ephedra, cinnamon bark, scutellaria, gypsum, *daji*, and tangerine peel—two *liang* each; unripe bitter orange, licorice, *qinjiao*, apricot kernel, and poria—three *liang* each; asarum—one *liang*; pinellia—one *sheng*; fresh ginger—one and a half *liang*; jujube—fifteen pieces. **Lung Viscera Remedies: Qi Exhaustion, Fourth Treatise**

**Remedies, Moxibustion Methods, and Discourse**

It is said: All cases of *qi* exhaustion are governed by the lungs. The lungs correspond to *qi*, and *qi* unites with the lungs. It is further said: When one encounters illness in autumn, it becomes *skin impediment* (皮痹). If *skin impediment* persists and one is again afflicted by pathogenic *qi*, it lodges internally in the lungs, allowing the cold-damp *qi* to invade the six *fu*-viscera.

If the lungs are diseased, the first sign is *qi* surging upward into the chest, with a constant urge to self-reproach. When, on *geng* or *xin* days in autumn, one is harmed by wind-evil *qi*, it becomes *lung wind*. The symptoms of *lung wind* include profuse sweating. If *yin* is damaged, cold arises; cold leads to vacuity, and vacuity causes *qi* counterflow and coughing. Coughing results in shortness of breath, which worsens at dusk when *yin qi* arrives and damp *qi* is generated—hence the severity. *Yin* fears *yang qi*, so symptoms abate during the day. If *yang* is damaged, heat arises; heat leads to repletion, and repletion causes *qi* to pant and rise into the chest and bosom. In severe cases, one spits blood.

Now, when *yang* is diseased, treat *yin*, for *yin* is its interior. When *yin* is diseased, treat *yang*, for *yang* is its exterior. Thus, *yin* and *yang*—exterior and interior—are the roots of decline and flourishing. Therefore, one must know to regulate *yin* with *yang* and *yang* with *yin*: when *yang qi* is replete, drain it; when *yin qi* is vacuous, supplement it.

The skilled physician treats illness at its onset, when it has only entered the skin, hair, flesh, sinews, or vessels. If it reaches the six *fu*-viscera or five *zang*-viscera, recovery is half impossible.

Bian Que said: When *qi* is cut off and untreatable, with panting (or *running*) and cold sweats, death occurs in two days. *Qi* corresponds to the hand *Taiyin*; when *Taiyin qi* is cut off, the skin and hair wither, and *qi* perishes first.

**Stalactite Powder**
Treats *qi* exhaustion with vacuity-cold, where *yin* fears *yang qi*, causing daytime aching and evening worsening, shortness of breath, and cold panting. Also cures all diseases, strengthens the body, enhances appetite, and dispels wind-cold.
*Stalactite* (separately ground), *dried ginger*, *platycodon*, *poria*, *asarum*, *cinnamon bark*, *aconite*, and *ginseng*—each one *liang* and six *zhu*; *white atractylodes*—one *liang*; *siler*, *trichosanthes root*, and *oyster shell*—each two and a half *liang*.
Grind the twelve ingredients into powder. Take one square *cun* spoonful with wine, three times daily, gradually increasing to two spoonfuls. Those over fifty may take it frequently until improvement is noted.
*The Thousand Gold Wings* states: For cold, add *zanthoxylum* (three *liang*); for heat, add *scutellaria* (three *liang*).

**Astragalus Decoction**
Treats *qi* exhaustion with vacuity-cold, withered skin and hair, obstructed fluids, consumptive diseases, and debilitated strength.
*Astragalus*—four *liang*; *ginseng*, *white atractylodes*, and *cinnamon bark*—each two *liang*; *fresh ginger*—eight *liang*; *jujubes*—ten pieces; *aconite*—thirty *zhu* (one version omits this).
Chop the seven ingredients, boil in eight *sheng* of water, reduce to three *sheng*, strain, and divide into four doses.

**Great Dew-Soaked Pill**
Treats *qi* exhaustion with vacuity-cold, persistent *skin impediment* lodging internally in the lungs, cold *qi* invading the six *fu*-viscera, abdominal distention, vacuous fullness, cold accumulations, and all diseases.
*Arsenolite* (*Elbow Rear* version: *alum*); *dried ginger*, *cinnamon bark*, * gleditsia*, *platycodon*, and *aconite*—each three *liang*.
Grind into powder, form into honey pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take ten pills with wine, three times daily, gradually increasing the dose.

**Cautions:** Avoid heat and proximity to fire.

**Sulfur Pill**
Treats *qi* exhaustion with vacuity-cold, *pi*-drink, phlegm-fullness in the chest, pain in the heart and abdomen, *qi* urgency, and inability to take food.
*Sulfur*, *arsenolite*, *dried ginger*, *aconite*, *monkshood*, *cinnamon bark*, *asarum*, *white atractylodes*, *platycodon*, and *poria*—each two *liang*.
Grind into powder, form into honey pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take ten pills with wine, three times daily, gradually increasing the dose until effective.
(*Elbow Rear* version omits *white atractylodes*, *platycodon*, and *poria*, using *evodia*, *Sichuan pepper*, *ginseng*, *gleditsia*, and *tangkuei* instead—twelve ingredients in total—for those with severe cold who wear winter clothing even in summer.)

**Major Bupleurum Decoction**
Treats *qi* exhaustion from heat damage, panting with *qi* surging into the chest, constant desire for self-reproach, fullness and pain in the heart and abdomen, internal and external heat, vexation, retching, and restlessness.
*Bupleurum*—eight *liang*; *pinellia*, *ephedra*, and *peony*—each four *liang*; *fresh ginger*—five *liang*; *scutellaria*—three *liang*; *unripe bitter orange*—four pieces; *jujubes*—twelve pieces.
Chop the eight ingredients, boil in nine *sheng* of water, reduce to three *sheng*, strain, and divide into three warm doses.

**Bamboo Leaf Decoction**
Treats *qi* exhaustion from heat damage, *qi* panting (in severe cases, spitting blood), shortness of breath, lack of desire for food, dry mouth, and parched throat.
*Bamboo leaves*—two *sheng*; *ophiopogon*, *wheat*, and *fresh rehmannia*—each one *sheng*; *fresh ginger* and *gypsum*—each six *liang*; *ephedra*—three *liang*; *licorice*—one *liang*; *jujubes*—ten pieces.
Chop the nine ingredients, boil in one *dou* of water, reduce to three *sheng*, strain, and divide into three doses.

**Moxibustion Methods:**
For retching, vomiting, and *qi* surging upward, apply moxa to *Chize* (LU 5), three to seven cones.
*Chize* is located in the transverse crease of the elbow, on the posterior aspect of the wrist.

For abdominal rumbling like thunder, undigested food, and counterflow *qi*, apply moxa to a point one *cun* below *Shangwan* (CV 13), called *Tai Cang*, seven cones.

---

**Fifth Discourse on Qi Accumulations**
**Formulas and Moxibustion**

It is said: The seven *qi* are cold *qi*, heat *qi*, anger *qi*, resentment *qi*, joy *qi*, sorrow *qi*, and grief *qi*—seven types in all.
When they form accumulations, these become hard masses the size of a cup or plate beneath the heart or in the abdomen, causing acute pain, inability to eat, and intermittent attacks that feel life-threatening, as if haunted by malevolent spirits. All arise from the seven *qi*.

- **Cold *qi*:** Retching, counterflow, and nausea.
- **Heat *qi*:** Incoherent speech, pressure to finish thoughts.
- **Anger *qi*:** Upward surging *qi* unbearable, heat and pain rushing into the heart, shortness of breath verging on death, inability to breathe.
- **Resentment *qi*:** Accumulations beneath the heart, inability to eat or drink.
- **Joy *qi*:** Inability to walk quickly or stand for long.
- **Sorrow *qi*:** Inability to engage in strenuous work, restless sleep at dusk.
- **Grief *qi*:** Forgetfulness, failure to recognize speech, misplacing objects in all directions yet unable to retrieve them; upon hearing urgent news, limbs swell, sinews contract, and hands and feet cannot be lifted.

When such diseases occur, they arise from the seven *qi*. In men, sudden onset stems from irregular eating; in women, they manifest as wind-stroke after childbirth or other illnesses.

**Seven Qi Pill**
*Monkshood* and *rhubarb*—each seven *fen*; *aster*, *pinellia*, *bupleurum*, *asarum*, *salvia*, *poria*, *ligusticum*, *peach kernel* (*Master Hu’s* version: *apricot kernel*), *acorus* (one version: *peony*), *gypsum*, *evodia*, *cinnamon bark*, and *platycodon*—each three *fen*; *ginseng*, *licorice*, and *prevention* (fang kui)—each one *liang*; *dried ginger* and *Sichuan pepper*—each half a *liang*.
Grind into powder, form into honey pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take three pills with wine, three times daily, increasing to ten pills.
(One version omits *pinellia* and adds *kan-sui* three *fen*. *Master Hu’s* version omits *salvia* and *licorice*.)

**Seven Qi Pill**
Governs the seven *qi*—cold *qi*, heat *qi*, anger *qi*, resentment *qi*, joy *qi*, sorrow *qi*, and grief *qi*.
These diseases all generate accumulations, hard as a cup, causing twisting pain in the heart and abdomen, inability to eat, intermittent attacks, and life-threatening episodes.

- **Cold *qi* symptoms:** Vomiting, counterflow, heart fullness.
- **Heat *qi* symptoms:** Confusion, dizziness, loss of essence.
- **Anger *qi* symptoms:** Unbearable heat, pain surging into the heart, shortness of breath verging on death, inability to breathe.
- **Resentment *qi* symptoms:** Accumulations with heart fullness, inability to eat or drink.
- **Joy *qi* symptoms:** Inability to walk quickly or stand for long.
- **Sorrow *qi* symptoms:** Inability to endure hard work, restless sleep.
- **Grief *qi* symptoms:** Outwardly resembling anger, forgetfulness, swelling of the limbs and elbows, inability to move.

Also treats residual illnesses from wind-stroke after childbirth.
*Rhubarb*—two and a half *liang*; *ginseng*, *pinellia*, *evodia*, *bupleurum*, *dried ginger*, *asarum*, *platycodon*, and *acorus*—each two *fen*; *poria*, *ligusticum*, *licorice*, *Sichuan pepper* (one version: *cinnamon bark*), *gypsum*, and *peach kernel*—each three *fen*.
Grind into powder, form into honey pills the size of *wutong* seeds. Take three pills with wine, three times daily, increasing to ten pills.
(*Supplement to the Thousand Gold* version uses ten ingredients, omitting *poria*, *ligusticum*, *licorice*, *gypsum*, and *peach kernel*.)

**Seven Qi Decoction**
Treats cold *qi*, heat *qi*, sorrow *qi*, taxation *qi*, grief *qi*, or *qi* from dietary obstructions, or internal damage from taxation *qi*, disharmony of the five *zang*-viscera, and *qi* debility with lack of strength.
*Dried ginger*, *scutellaria*, *magnolia bark* (*Master Shen’s* version: *cinnamon bark*), *pinellia*, *licorice*, *dried rehmannia*, *peony*, and *trichosanthes root*—each two *liang* (*Master Shen’s* version: *tangerine peel*); *Sichuan pepper*—three *liang* (*Master Shen’s* version: *platycodon*); *unripe bitter orange*—five pieces; *ginseng*—one *liang*; *evodia*—five *ge*.

The above twelve ingredients are cut into pieces, decocted in one *dou* of water, and reduced to three *sheng*. Divide into three doses, taken thrice daily.

**Alternative Formula**
Treats vacuity cold with counterflow *qi*, taxation *qi*, and similar conditions:
*Pinellia*—one *sheng*; *ginseng*, *fresh ginger*, *cinnamon bark*, *licorice*—each one *liang*.
The above five ingredients are cut into pieces, decocted in one *dou* of water, and reduced to three *sheng*. Divide into three doses, taken thrice daily.

**Five Obstructions Pill**
Treats sorrow obstruction, *qi* obstruction, food obstruction, and drink obstruction. All five conditions are treated with three doses. Caused by sorrow and frustration or dietary factors; triggered by cold foods or raw vegetables. Symptoms include heart fullness, inability to breathe, pain radiating to the back as if pierced, postprandial epigastric hardness resembling a mass of cotton, severe pain with desire to vomit (relieved upon vomiting), inability to swallow food or drink, and in severe cases, cold hands and feet, counterflow *qi*, cough, panting, and shortness of breath:
*Ophiopogon*—five *liang*; *licorice*—five *liang*; *Sichuan pepper*, *polygala*, *cinnamon bark*, *asarum*—each two *liang*; *aconite*—one and a half *liang*; *ginseng*—four *liang*; *dried ginger*—two *liang*.
The above nine ingredients are ground into powder and mixed with honey to form pills. Slightly softened, take one pill the size of a bullet on an empty stomach, swallowing slowly. The throat and chest will feel warm; when the effect wanes, take another pill. Three times daily and twice at night. Recovery occurs within seven days.
(*The Extending Life Formula* states: If unable to hold the pill in the mouth, divide one large pill into seven small ones and consume entirely. In summer, increase *ophiopogon*, *licorice*, and *ginseng*.)
(*Hu Qia’s* version: Alternatively, make ten pills the size of *wu* seeds and take with wine.)
(*Essentials of the Classics* uses *evodia* in place of *cinnamon bark*, taking five pills the size of *wu* seeds with wine on an empty stomach. Treats cold-induced heart pain with a sensation of an object in the throat that cannot be spit out or swallowed, and reduced food intake.)

**Decoction for Binding *Qi*, Cold Patterns, and Accumulations in the Hypochondrium**
Also treats *leg qi* ascending into the lower abdomen with abdominal distention and fullness, and various diseases:
Take three *sheng* of garlic (peeled), pound thoroughly, mix with three *sheng* of water, and strain to obtain the juice. Pound the remaining pulp again, mix with three *sheng* of water, and strain for juice. Repeat once more, combining all juice to make nine *sheng*. Discard the pulp (or shape into peach-sized balls). Simmer over low heat to reduce to three *sheng*, add three *sheng* of cow’s milk, and continue simmering to reduce to three *sheng*. Take the entire dose warm on an empty stomach at dawn, and eat at the *shen* hour. Take one dose every three days, for a total of ten doses over thirty days.

**Garlic Decoction**
Treats mounting conglomerations, cold accumulations, phlegm-rheum, abdominal distention and fullness, counterflow *qi*, cough, piercing wind, wind epilepsy, hemiplegia, lumbar pain, cold knees, *qi* blockage, and various diseases:
Six *jin* and four *liang* of garlic (peeled and sliced), decocted in four *dou* of water to obtain one *dou* of liquid (strained). Add one *sheng* of *su* butter to the garlic liquid, along with two *sheng* of cow’s milk, three *liang* each of *caltrop*, *pepper*, and *dried ginger*, two *liang* each of *rock honey*, *asafoetida*, and *halite*, and one *liang* each of *acorus* and *costus*. Four *liang* of dried grapes.
The above twelve ingredients are ground into powder and mixed into the garlic liquid, then simmered in a copper vessel over low heat to obtain one *dou*. Take one *liang* with wine on an empty stomach; after five days, gradually increase to three *liang*. After twenty days, with improved bodily harmony, increase to six *liang*. Highly effective for all cold *qi* patterns.

**Platycodon Qi-Breaking Pill**
Treats *qi* blockage above and below with inability to breathe:
*Platycodon*, *tangerine peel*, *dried ginger*, *magnolia bark*, *unripe bitter orange*, *asarum*—each three *fen*; *evodia*, *white atractylodes*—each six *fen*; *pepper*, *Sichuan pepper*, *aconite*—each seven *fen*; *long pepper*—ten *fen*; *ginseng*, *cinnamon bark*, *aconite*, *poria*, *peucedanum*, *saposhnikovia*, *ligusticum*—each five *fen*; *licorice*, *rhubarb*, *areca*, *tangkuei*—each eight *fen*.
The above twenty-four ingredients are ground into powder and mixed with honey to form pills the size of *wu* seeds. Take ten pills with wine thrice daily. For heat patterns, take on an empty stomach.

**Areca Decoction**
Treats replete *qi* with accumulations and inability to eat or breathe:
Thirty-seven *areca* nuts; one *aconite*; one *sheng* of *pinellia*; one *liang* of *asarum*; eight *liang* of *fresh ginger*; three *liang* each of *rhubarb*, *aster*, and *bupleurum*; two *liang* each of *tangerine peel*, *licorice*, *perilla* (use seeds in winter), and *poria*.
The above twelve ingredients are cut into pieces, decocted in one *dou* of water, and reduced to three *sheng*. Divide into three doses, spaced as long as it takes a person to walk ten *li*.
For hard accumulations like stone, add two *liang* each of *turtle shell* and *saposhnikovia*. For counterflow *qi*, add two *sheng* of *mulberry bark* (sliced) and two *liang* each of *unripe bitter orange* and *magnolia bark*. Adjust dosage based on *qi* strength; after two doses, wait ten days, then take the previous *Platycodon Qi-Breaking Pill*.

**Formula for Chronic *Qi* Disease**
Treats long-standing *qi* disease with periodic attacks, heart and abdominal colic, sudden *qi* collapse, abdominal hardness, and conditions deemed untreatable by physicians (also called *gu*):
Twenty-eight large *areca* nuts; one *aconite*; one *sheng* of *pinellia*; three *liang* of *bupleurum*; eight *liang* of *fresh ginger*; two *liang* each of *tangerine peel*, *licorice*, *cinnamon bark*, *tangkuei*, and *unripe bitter orange*.
The above ten ingredients are cut into pieces, decocted in one *dou* of water, and reduced to three *sheng*. Divide into three doses, taking one dose every five days. After three doses, the root cause is permanently eliminated.

**Pinellia Decoction**
Treats counterflow *qi* with heart and abdominal fullness, *qi* ascending to cause chest and hypochondriac pain, cold-induced heart and abdominal pain, retching, vomiting, inability to eat, and sorrow *qi* congealing into accumulations.

**Pinellia Decoction**
One *sheng* of *pinellia*; five *liang* each of *fresh ginger* and *cinnamon bark*; four *liang* of *tangerine peel*.
The above four ingredients are cut into pieces, decocted in seven *sheng* of water, and reduced to three *sheng*. Divide into four doses, taking three during the day and one at night. For those of strong constitution, divide into three doses. Also treats post-*huoluan* vomiting, retching, and abdominal pain.

Another formula treats counterflow *qi* with heart vexation and fullness, *qi* stagnation and disorder, and ascending *qi*. The four-ingredient formula is found in the sixteenth fascicle, under the "Vomiting" section.

**Fritillaria Decoction**
Treats ascending *qi* with throat obstruction, shortness of breath, inability to lie down, lumbar and back pain, chest fullness, inability to eat, and a withered-yellow complexion:
One *liang* of *fritillaria*; five *liang* of *fresh ginger*; two *liang* each of *cinnamon bark*, *ephedra*, *gypsum*, and *licorice*; thirty *apricot kernels*; five *ge* of *pinellia*.
The above eight ingredients are cut into pieces, decocted in one *dou* of water, and reduced to three *sheng*. Divide into three doses, taking one dose three times daily.

**Ephedra Decoction**
Treats ascending *qi* with floating pulse, cough and counterflow, frog-like sounds in the throat, labored breathing, and near-death dyspnea:
Eight *liang* of *ephedra*; four *liang* of *licorice*; thirty *jujubes*; two *shegan* (size of *boqi* pieces).
The above four ingredients are cut into pieces, decocted in one *dou* of well-drawn water. Boil the *ephedra* three times, skim off the foam, add the remaining ingredients, and reduce to four *sheng*. Divide into four doses, taking three during the day and one at night.

**Running Qi Decoction**
Treats major *qi* surging upward, causing chest and diaphragm distress, fullness and urgency, shortness of breath, inability to lie down, and in severe cases, near-death suffocation. Also treats cold-damp *qi* in the abdomen, borborygmus, and bound *qi*:
One *jin* of *fresh ginger*; one *sheng* each of *pinellia* and *evodia*; five *liang* of *cinnamon bark*; three *liang* each of *ginseng* and *licorice*.
The above six ingredients are cut into pieces, decocted in one *dou* of water, and reduced to three *sheng*. Divide into four doses.

**Unripe Bitter Orange Decoction**
Descends *qi* and treats chest fullness and oppression:
Three *unripe bitter oranges*; two *aconite*; fourteen *jujubes*; five *liang* of *pinellia*; two *liang* each of *ginseng*, *licorice*, *white atractylodes*, *dried ginger*, and *magnolia bark*.
The above nine ingredients are cut into pieces, decocted in seven *sheng* of water, and reduced to two and a half *sheng*. Take eight *ge* per dose, three times daily.

**Qi-Descending Decoction**
Treats *qi* fullness and abdominal distension:
One *sheng* of *pinellia*; one *jin* of *fresh ginger*; one and a half *liang* of *ginseng*; three *liang* of *tangerine peel*.
The above four ingredients are cut into pieces, decocted in seven *sheng* of water, and reduced to three *sheng*. Strain and divide into three doses, taking one dose three times daily. One variant omits *ginseng*, using only the three remaining ingredients.

**Wind-Cold Qi Formula**
Treats *qi* with fullness and urgency in both flanks:
Eight *fen* each of *apricot kernels*, *poria*, and *fangkui*; five *fen* each of *evodia*, *tangerine peel*, *cinnamon bark*, *saposhnikovia*, and *alisma*; six *fen* each of *white atractylodes*, *shegan*, *peony*, *perilla seeds*, *platycodon*, and *unripe bitter orange*.
The above fourteen ingredients are ground into powder and formed into pills the size of *wutong* seeds with honey. Take ten pills with wine, twice daily, increasing gradually to thirty pills.

**Qi Fullness and Obstruction Formula**
Treats *qi* fullness, blockage, inability to eat, and dyspnea:
Grind ten *haritaki* into powder and form into pills the size of *wutong* seeds with honey. Take three pills after meals. If no contraindications arise, continue until relief is obtained.

**Ascending Qi and Cough Formula**
Treats ascending *qi* and cough with counterflow:
One *sheng* of *perilla seeds*; five *ge* of *schisandra*; two *liang* each of *ephedra*, *asarum*, *aster*, *ginseng*, *scutellaria*, and *licorice*; one *liang* each of *cinnamon bark* and *tangkuei*; five *liang* of *fresh ginger*; three *liang* of *pinellia*.
The above twelve ingredients are cut into pieces, decocted in one *dou* of water, and reduced to three *sheng*. Divide into three doses.

**Qi Ascending and Insomnia Formula**
A secret formula for *qi* ascending and inability to lie down:
Five *liang* each of *tangerine peel*, *fresh ginger*, *perilla*, *ginseng*, and *schisandra* (one variant substitutes *platycodon*).
The above five ingredients are cut into pieces, decocted in seven *sheng* of water, and reduced to three *sheng*. Divide into three doses.

**Heat Effusion and Qi Ascending Formula**
Treats heat effusion with *qi* surging upward, inability to breathe, near-death distress, and inability to lie down:
Half a *liang* of *cinnamon bark*; two and a half *liang* each of *white quartz*, *ophiopogon*, *unripe bitter orange*, *dictamnus root*, *fritillaria*, *poria*, *areca nut kernels*, and *asparagus*; two *liang* of *plantago seeds*; one and a half *liang* each of *ginseng*, *peucedanum*, *tangerine peel*, *bistort*, and *apricot kernels*; three *liang* of *bush cherry kernels*; five *fen* of *peach kernels*.
The above seventeen ingredients are ground into powder and formed into pills the size of *wutong* seeds with honey. Take ten pills with *bamboo leaf decoction*, twice daily, increasing gradually to thirty pills.

**Bamboo Leaf Decoction**
One *sheng* each of *bamboo leaves* and *perilla seeds*; two *liang* each of *aster* and *cynanchum*; three *liang* each of *stemona* and *licorice*; three *liang* of *fresh ginger*.
The above seven ingredients are cut into pieces, decocted in eight *sheng* of water, and reduced to three *sheng*. Take warm to administer the pills above. When the decoction is finished, prepare another batch.

**Ginseng Decoction**
Calms the stomach, descends *qi*, regulates the chest and flanks, and treats visiting heat:
Two *liang* each of *ginseng*, *ophiopogon*, *dried ginger*, *tangkuei*, *poria*, *licorice*, *schisandra*, *astragalus*, and *peony*; three *liang* of *cinnamon bark*; one *sheng* of *pinellia*; fifteen *jujubes*.
The above thirteen ingredients are cut into pieces, decocted in nine *sheng* of water, and reduced to three *sheng*. Strain and take nine *ge* per dose, consuming all from dawn to dusk while warm. Avoid taking cold.

**Sargassum and Tangerine Peel Pill**
Descends *qi*, treats wind deficiency with branch fullness, bladder deficiency cold, *qi* surging upward to the lungs, and throat *qi* obstruction:
Three *fen* each of *sargassum* and *tangerine peel*; five *fen* each of *cynanchum*, *apricot kernels*, *poria*, *peony*, and *cinnamon bark*; five *ge* of *perilla seeds*; two *liang* each of *jujube flesh*, *mulberry root bark*, and *kelp*; one *liang* each of *evodia*, *ginseng*, *white atractylodes*, and *tingli seeds*.

The above fifteen ingredients are ground into powder and formed into honey pills the size of *wutu* seeds. Take ten pills with water, twice daily, increasing to fifteen pills until urine flows freely.

**Powder for Upward-Surging Qi**
Equal parts *sal ammoniac*, *asarum*, and *achyranthes*.
The above three ingredients are ground into powder. When *qi* surges upward, take one *fangcunbi* with wine; avoid wine for the next three days. Other prohibitions follow medicinal regulations.

**Remedy for Upward-Surging Qi**
One *sheng* of *refined butter* and five bulbs of *single-clove garlic*.
The above two ingredients are first fried in the butter until the garlic turns yellow, then mixed with one *ge* of fresh ginger juice and simmered until done. Take one *fangcunbi* warm on an empty stomach.

**Remedy for Upward-Surging Qi with Vomiting**
Two *sheng* of *mustard seeds*, ground into powder and formed into honey pills. At *yin* hour, take seven pills the size of *wutu* seeds with well-drawn morning water, twice daily. Alternatively, it may be taken as a powder on an empty stomach or steeped in wine. Also treats colicky pain below the navel.

**Remedy for Consumptive Qi**
Three *sheng* of *small mustard seeds*, pounded into powder and placed in a silk bag, steeped in three *dou* of wine, and sealed tightly for seven days. Strain and take half a *sheng* warm, gradually increasing to one and a half *sheng*. When the dose is found effective, prepare another batch. Prohibitions follow medicinal regulations.

**Remedy for Thirty Years of Uncured Upward-Surging Qi**
One hundred *jujubes*, one hundred *apricot kernels*, one hundred twenty *fermented soybeans*, and two hundred *Sichuan peppercorns*.
The above four ingredients are first pounded—*apricot kernels* and *fermented soybeans* until well-mixed—then *jujubes* and *peppercorns* are added and pounded further to form pills the size of jujube pits. Hold in the mouth and swallow gradually, three times by day and once by night.

**Remedy for Chronic Upward-Surging Qi on the Verge of Death**
*Henbane seeds*, stir-fried until their color changes, and *sheep’s liver*, thinly sliced and sun-dried.
The above two ingredients are pounded separately in equal parts and mixed with *divine vinegar* on the seventh day of the seventh month until well combined. On an empty stomach at night, take two *fangcunbi*; after a short while, take two spoonfuls of cold rice-water or congee between meals to settle it. Take every other day for a permanent cure. For forty days, consume only boiled rice-water or *turnip greens* stew; all other foods are prohibited thereafter.

**Remedy to Descend Qi**
Five *liang* of *fresh ginger* and one *sheng* of *wheat*.
The above two ingredients are boiled in seven *sheng* of water until reduced to one *sheng*; consume all at once.

**Alternative Remedy**
Twenty-seven *jujubes* and one *sheng* of *purple perilla stems and leaves*, cut.
The above two ingredients are boiled in three *sheng* of wine until reduced to one and a half *sheng*; divide and take twice. May also be boiled in water. One version adds half a *liang* of *tangerine peel*. The *Handbook of Emergency Remedies* omits *jujubes* and uses *tangerine peel* instead.

**Remedy for Qi**
Two *jin* of *peach bark*, discarding the yellow inner layer, cut into pieces, and boiled in five *sheng* of water until reduced to three *sheng*. Take one *sheng* per dose; discontinue when cured.

**Alternative Remedy**

Take two *ge* of *donkey fat* with wine, twice daily; discontinue when cured.

**Alternative Remedy**
Simmer two *sheng* of *yellow cow’s milk* until reduced to one *sheng*, then mix with one *sheng* of fresh milk. Consume on an empty stomach, twice daily.

**Alternative Remedy**
*Donkey’s milk*: begin with three *ge* per dose; after three days, increase to five *ge* daily; after seven days, increase to seven *ge*; then to one *sheng*. Avoid *mallow*, pork, fish, and oil.

**Alternative Remedy**
Consume *human urine* on an empty stomach for one hundred days to cure all diseases.

**Alternative Remedy**
Take *black ox urine* on an empty stomach, twice daily, up to three *sheng*.

**Remedy for Qi Deficiency and Counterflow**
Three *sheng* of *jujubes*; ten *licorice roots*, veins removed; two *liang* of *dried ginger*; eight *liang* of *dried rehmannia*.
The above four ingredients are processed and sifted. Steep the *jujubes* in four *sheng* of wine for three nights, then remove the *jujubes* and use the wine to steam them in a steamer until they become a paste. Return the paste to the pot with the wine and simmer until reduced to about two *sheng*. When only the skins and pits of the *jujubes* remain in the steamer, cease heating. Store in a vessel, then add the previously prepared powder while hot, stirring until well mixed—its consistency should resemble sugar. Take two *ge* with wine, twice daily. This remedy not only replenishes *qi* but also treats all forms of shortness of breath, emaciation, and debility with excellent efficacy.

**Major Qi-Replenishing Remedy**
Five *liang* of *dried rehmannia*; one *liang* each of *licorice* and *Sichuan pepper*; four *liang* each of *dried ginger*, *kelp*, and *wolfberry root bark*; three *liang* each of *white atractylodes*, *cassia heart*, *ginseng*, *magnolia bark*, and *seaweed*; one pair of *sheep kidneys*, fat removed; one *sheep stomach*, prepared as for consumption, fat and membranes removed.
The above thirteen ingredients are processed and sifted, then placed inside the *sheep stomach* along with the kidneys. The opening is sewn shut, and the stomach is steamed until thoroughly cooked. While still hot, pound in a wooden mortar until the stomach, kidneys, and herbs are fully combined. Dry in the sun, then pound again into a powder. Take one *square-inch spoonful* with wine, twice daily.

**White Quartz Powder**, brightens the eyes, promotes urination, treats *qi* disorders, and replenishes the five taxations and seven damages—efficacious for all ailments:
Refine ten *liang* of *white quartz* (quantity may vary). On an anvil, finely crush the quartz with a hammer, then examine it in bright light to remove any flawed, dark, black, yellow, or reddish pieces, retaining only the pure white fragments. Pound and sift through silk, then grind in a porcelain vessel until extremely fine. Place in a silk bag and levigate in a copper vessel with water, as in the preparation of powder, repeating this process three times. After grinding, allow the mixture to settle, gradually decanting the water until only the quartz remains. Dry in the sun, then inspect for any coarse or impure particles, discarding them. Retain the central, finest portion, and discard any inferior material at the bottom. Grind the selected quartz until smooth, then store in a silk bag within a porcelain bowl, covered with another bowl. Steam beneath three *dou* of rice until the rice is cooked, then remove and hang to dry. Grind again in a porcelain vessel seven times until fully refined.
Six *fen* each of *dendrobium* and *cistanche*; one *liang* each of *alisma*, *poria*, and *tangerine peel*; three *liang* of *cuscuta*.
The above seven ingredients are processed and sifted, then ground together in a porcelain vessel until well blended. Sift again. Take one *square-inch spoonful* with wine, twice daily; do not exceed this dosage. Avoid pork, fish, goose, duck, garlic, cold foods, vinegar, and slippery-textured foods.

**Powder for Supplementing Injury**
*Treats lung injury, frequent diarrhea, cough, susceptibility to fright, inability to move the sinews, inability to travel far, inability to stand long on the knees, sweating with dry nose, shortness of breath, tendency to sorrow, acute pain below the heart radiating to the chest, restless sleep, frequent dreaming, alternating chills and fever, dark yellow urine, inability to see far, and blood in the sputum.*

**Ingredients:**

**Moxibustion Methods**

For cold-induced counterflow qi with borborygmus, vomiting, and inability to eat: Moxa *Taichong* without limit, until pain ceases or until pain arises where there was none.

For counterflow qi with cold limbs: Moxa *Xiongtang* (mid-chest) one hundred cones, located between the two nipples.

For qi in the chest and diaphragm: Moxa *Que Shu* according to age, located 1½ *cun* bilateral to the fourth thoracic vertebra.

Bian Que states: *Que Shu* is 1½ *cun* bilateral to the fourth thoracic vertebra.

For all heart and abdominal diseases with hardness, fullness, vexation, pain, pent-up qi, cold-induced cholera, heart pain, vomiting, diarrhea, undigested food, borborygmus, and dysentery: Moxa *Tai Cang* one hundred cones. *Tai Cang* (also called *Wei Mu*) is one point located four *cun* below the heart, one *cun* below the stomach duct.

For pent-up qi in the scrotum beyond the reach of needles and medicine: Moxa *Huang Mu* according to age. *Huang Mu* (two points) is located by measuring from the nipple to the navel, halving the distance, and measuring downward from the nipple.

For descending qi: Moxa *Fei Shu* one hundred cones, and *Taichong* fifty cones.

For colicky pain below the navel radiating to the genitals with unpredictable onset (cold qi): Moxa *Guanyuan* one hundred cones, located three *cun* below the navel.

For shortness of breath with inability to speak: Moxa *Tianjing* one hundred cones, located in the depression posterior to the elbow between the two sinews. Alternatively, moxa *Dazhui* according to age, *Fei Shu* one hundred cones, *Gan Shu* one hundred cones, *Chize* one hundred cones, the intersecting vessel between the little finger and fourth finger seven cones, or the tips of all ten fingers, ten cones total.

For shortness of breath due to excessive sexual activity in youth: Moxa the tip of *Jiuwei* fifty cones, or salt-moxa the navel twenty-one cones.

For qi deficiency: Moxa below the fifth thoracic vertebra according to age.

---

**Discourse:**
For sudden cold-induced counterflow qi with qi attacking both flanks, pain and fullness below the heart, and near-collapse: Immediately prepare a decoction to soak the hands and feet, changing the liquid frequently.

For *running piglet* (qi rushing upward): Moxa *Qihai* one hundred cones, located 1½ *cun* below the navel. Alternatively, moxa *Guanyuan* one hundred cones, located three *cun* below the navel.

For *running piglet*: Moxa *Qimen* one hundred cones, located 1½ *cun* lateral to the second intercostal space below the nipple.

For *running piglet* with abdominal swelling: Moxa *Zhangmen* one hundred cones. *Zhangmen* (also called *Changping*) is two points located lateral to *Daheng*, at the free end of the eleventh rib.

For *running piglet* rushing to the heart with inability to breathe: Moxa *Zhongji* fifty cones. *Zhongji* (also called *Yuquan*) is located four *cun* below the navel.

For *running piglet* with pain radiating between the abdomen and lower back: Moxa *Zhongfu* one hundred cones, located in the third intercostal space above the nipple.

For *running piglet* with pain radiating up and down: Moxa *Siman* fourteen cones. The points are located three *cun* lateral to *Dantian*, eight *cun* below the heart, and level with the transverse crease below the navel.
