**Right (the above) seventeen herbs**, finely chopped, decocted in **1.5 *shēng* of water**. First boil the kidney, reducing to **1.2 *dòu* of liquid**, remove the kidney, add the remaining herbs, decoct to **3 *shēng***, discard dregs, and divide into three doses.

The *Xiǎopǐn Fāng* version omits **Dendrobium stem, Trichosanthes root, Rehmannia root, Mulberry bark, and Poria**, adding **Siler root** (芎藭) – 2 *liǎng*, **Coptis rhizome** (黄连) – 2 *liǎng*, and **Ostrea shell** (龙骨) – 2 *liǎng*; **Eupolyphaga** (螵蛸) – 20 pieces.

Another version treats **kidney-qi deficiency**, **thirst with excessive drinking**, **frequent urination**, and **lumbar and spinal pain**—omitting **Dendrobium stem, Trichosanthes root, Rehmannia root, Mulberry bark, and Glycyrrhiza**, adding **Siler root** (芎藭) – 2 *liǎng*, **Scutellaria root** (黄苓) – 1 *liǎng*, **Peony root** (芍药) – 1 *liǎng*, **Eupolyphaga** (桑螵蛸) – 20 pieces, and **Chicken gallbladder** (鸡脉胵) – 1 *liǎng*.

The *Cuīshì* version treats **organ injury and deficient labor**—omitting **Dendrobium stem, Trichosanthes root, Rehmannia root, and Mulberry bark**, adding **Astragalus** (黄耆) – 2 *liǎng*, **Scutellaria root** (黄苓) – 2 *liǎng*, **Peony root** (芍药) – 2 *liǎng*, and **Siler root** (防风) – 2 *liǎng*.

For treating **left flank breath-constriction**, **epigastric fullness**, **head wind like insects crawling**, **stiffness of the hands and feet**, **nasal congestion**, **leg cramps preventing extension and flexion**, and **occasional eye swelling and pain**—

---

**Zhūshèn Tāng** (Pig Kidney Decoction):
One **pig kidney** (猪肾), **Siler root** (防风), **Siler root** (芎藭), **Tangerine peel** (橘皮), **Alisma rhizome** (泽泻), **Cinnamon twig** (桂心), **Dendrobium stem** (石斛) – each 1 *liǎng* (两).
**Fresh ginger** (生姜), **Salvia miltiorrhiza** (丹参), **Poria** (茯苓), **Tetrapanax papyrifer** (通草), **Pinellia tuber** (半夏) – each 1 *liǎng* (两, #10).
**Rehmannia root** (乾地黄) – 3 *liǎng* (两).
The **right thirteen ingredients** (右十三味), finely chopped, are decocted with **1.5 *dòu* of water** (水一斗半). Boil the kidney first, then reduce the water by **3 *shēng*** (减三升). Remove the kidney and decoct the remaining herbs, yielding **2.7 *shēng*** (升合) of broth. Strain, discard dregs, and divide into three servings.

**Wǔ Bǔ Tāng** (Five Supplement Decoction), for treating **internal exhaustion of the Five *Zàng* Organs** (五脏内虚竭), **shortness of breath** (短气), **paroxysmal cough** (咳逆) and **organ injury** (伤损), **stagnant *qi* deficiency** (郁悒不足), and **sinking *qi* with fluid circulation** (下气通津液):
**Schisandra berry** (五味子), **Cinnamon twig** (桂心), **Glycyrrhiza** (甘草), **Ginseng** (人参) – each 1 *liǎng* (两, #11).
**Ophiopogon tuber** (麦门冬), **Wheat** (小麦) – each 1 *shēng* (升).
**Fresh ginger** (生姜) – 8 *liǎng* (两); omitted in *Qiānjīn Yì* (千金翼).
**Rice** (粳米) – 3 *hé* (合).
**Allium macrostemon** (薤白), **Lycium root bark** (枸杞根白皮) – each 1 *jīn* (斤).
The **right ten ingredients** (右十味), finely chopped, are decocted with **1.2 *dòu* of water** (水一斗二升), yielding **3 *shēng*** (升) of broth.
Take **1 *shēng*** (升) per dose, three times daily.
For **dry mouth** (口燥), first decoct **1 handful of bamboo leaves** (竹叶一把), reducing the water by **1 *shēng*** (减一升). Remove the leaves, then add all other herbs and decoct.

**Níngtuò Tāng** (Congealed Saliva Decoction), for treating **organ deficiency and shortness of breath** (虚损短气), **congealed saliva obstructing the throat** (咽喉凝唾不出), like **glue blocking the throat** (如胶塞喉) – also called **Poria Decoction** (一名茯苓汤):
**Ophiopogon tuber** (麦门冬) – 5 *liǎng* (两).
**Ginseng** (人参) – 2 *liǎng* (两, #12).
**Frontal lobe herb** (前胡) – 3 *liǎng* (两).
**Glycyrrhiza** (甘草), **Rehmannia root** (乾地黄), **Cinnamon twig** (桂心), **Peony root** (芍药) – each 1 *liǎng* (两, #13).
**Large dates** (大枣) – 3 pieces (+).
**Poria** (茯苓) – 2 *liǎng* (两).
The **right nine ingredients** (右九味), finely chopped, are decocted with **9 *shēng* of water** (水九升), yielding **3 *shēng* of broth**, to be taken warm in three divided doses.

**补汤方** (Tonifying Decoction):
**Plantago seed** (车前子) – 3 *liǎng* (#14).
**Siler root** (防风), **Cinnamon twig** (桂心) – each 2 *liǎng* (#15).
**Morinda root** (巴戟天), **Salvia miltiorrhiza** (丹参), **Rehmannia root** (乾地黄), **Deer antler velvet** (鹿茸), **Lycium bark** (枸杞皮), **Acanthopanax bark** (五加皮) – each 5 *liǎng*.
The **right nine ingredients** (右九味), finely chopped, are decocted with **8 *shēng* of water** (水八升), yielding **3 *shēng* of broth**, strained, and taken in three divided doses.

**Rénshēn Tāng** (Ginseng Decoction), for treating **male exhaustion from the Five Strains and Seven Injuries** (男子五劳七伤), **chest oppression and fullness** (胸中逆满), **aversion to food** (害食), **shortness of breath** (乏气), **nausea and retching** (呕逆), **distension and pain in the lower ribs** (两胁下胀), **sharp lower abdominal pain** (小腹急痛), **twisting agony as if dying** (宛转欲死) – a formula to **harmonize the center, balance the viscera, and restore extreme injury** (调中平脏、理绝伤):
**Ginseng** (人参), **Angelica root** (当归), **Peony root** (芍药), **Glycyrrhiza** (甘草), **Fresh ginger** (生姜), **Ophiopogon tuber** (麦门冬), **Rock sugar** (白糖), **Cinnamon twig** (桂心) – each 2 *liǎng*.
**Frontal lobe herb** (前胡), **Poria** (茯苓), **Schisandra berry** (五味子), **Sichuan peppercorn** (蜀椒), **Tangerine peel** (橘皮) – each 1 *liǎng*.
**Citrus fruit** (枳实) – 3 *liǎng*.
**Large dates** (大枣) – 15 pieces.
The **right fifteen ingredients** (右十五味), finely chopped, are steeped in **1.5 *dǒu* of fresh spring water** (东流水一斗半) for half a day, then simmered with **three-year-old old bamboo** (三年陈芦) to yield **4 *shēng* of decoction**. Rock sugar is added, and the mixture is boiled again until it rolls with **ten or more bubbles** (十数沸).

For those aged **20 to 60**, one dose is **1 *shēng***; for those **under 20 or over 60**, or those **chronically weakened despite youth**, one dose is **7–8 *gě*** (七八合), taken **three times daily and once at night**. If not, the **medicinal efficacy will falter**, and the illness cannot be cured. **Labor water and old bamboo must be used**; otherwise, the water’s **overpowering force and fierce heat** will **suppress the herbs’ potency**.

During the early **Zhēnguān era**, a man near death from chronic exhaustion was cured by this formula in a single dose—**like warm water melting snow**. Thus, it is recorded here. Other formulas of mine are likewise effective but cannot all be detailed.

**Nèi Bǔ Sǎn** (Internal Tonifying Powder), for treating **male exhaustion from the Five Strains and Six Extremes** (男子五劳六绝):
- If the **heart is injured**, the patient **startles easily, rages irrationally, and is unstable in mood** (令人善惊，妄怒无常).
- If the **spleen is injured**, the patient **has abdominal fullness, belches frequently, and desires sleep after eating, with a sallow, emaciated face** (令人腹满喜噫，食竟欲卧，面目痿黄).
- If the **lungs are injured**, the patient **lacks vitality, has a sore back and waist, and cold extremities** (令人少精，腰背痛，四肢厥逆).
- If the **liver is injured**, the patient **lacks blood and has a dark complexion** (令人少血面黑).
- If the **kidneys are injured**, the patient **has masses, lower abdominal and lumbar distension, coughs with sputum, and difficult urination** (有积聚，小腹腰背满痹，咳唾，小便难).

These **Six Extremes** arise from **excessive labor depleting the pulse**, **external wind pathogens**, and **internal cold-heat imbalances**, causing **hand and foot pain, coldness below the knees, abdominal rumbling, frequent diarrhea (or constipation), facial swelling, and a dull, speechless state with aversion to sound** (手足疼痛，膝以下冷，腹中雷鸣，时时泄痢，或闭或利，面目肿，心下愦愦不欲语，憎闻人声):
**Rehmannia root** (乾地黄), **Cuscuta seed** (菟丝子), **Cornus fruit** (山茱萸), **Barley** (地麦) – each 5 *fēn*.
**Polygala root** (远志), **Morinda root** (巴戟天) – each ½ *liǎng*.
**Ophiopogon tuber** (麦门冬), **Schisandra berry** (五味子), **Glycyrrhiza** (甘草), **Ginseng** (人参), **Asparagus tuber** (苁蓉), **Dendrobium stem** (石斛), **Cinnamon twig** (桂心), **Poria** (茯苓), **Aconite root** (附子) – each 1½ *liǎng*.
The **right fifteen ingredients** (右十五味) are ground into a powder, sifted, and taken with **wine in a square-inch spoonful** (酒服方寸匕), three times daily, increasing to **three spoonfuls** if needed. **No contraindications**.

**Shíhú Sǎn** (Dendrobium Powder), for treating **severe wind disorders**, where **limbs fail to flex, the patient cannot turn over, shoulders ache, the body feels heavy, sinews stiffen, movement is impossible, and there is alternating cold and heat with knife-like foot pain** (四肢不收，不能自反覆，两肩疼痛，身重经急筋肿，不能行，时寒时热，足端如似刀刺痛，身不能自任). These symptoms stem from **excessive alcohol, exposure to strong winds, sleeping on damp ground, or cold rising from below**, causing **lumbar coldness, leg weakness, qi deficiency, seminal exhaustion, cold in all vessels, dampness in the lower body, and genital atrophy** (腰以下冷，不足无气，子精虚，众脉寒，阴下湿，茎消), leading to **melancholy, disorientation, and occasional sorrow**. This formula **dispels wind, lightens the body, tonifies qi, brightens the eyes, strengthens the yin, promotes fertility, and restores deficiencies** (除风、轻身、益气、明目、强阴，令人有子，补不足):
**Dendrobium stem** (石斛) – 10 *fēn*.
**Achyranthes root** (牛膝), **Aconite root** (附子), **Eucommia bark** (杜仲) – each 4 *fēn*.
**Biota seed** (柏子仁), **Sargentodoxa vine** (石龙芮), **Peony root** (芍药), **Pine resin** (松脂), **Mica powder** (云母粉), **Cornus fruit** (山茱萸), **Alisma rhizome** (泽泻), **Coix seed** (萆薢), **Cuscuta seed** (菟丝子), **Siler root** (防风), **Asarum root** (细辛), **Cinnamon twig** (桂心) – each 3 *fēn*.
The **right sixteen ingredients** (右十六味) are ground into a powder, sifted, and taken with **wine in a square-inch spoonful**, twice daily. For **yin deficiency**, double the **Cuscuta and Eucommia**; for **abdominal pain**, double the **Peony**; for **knee pain**, double the **Achyranthes**; for **lumbar wind**, double the **Siler**; for **shortness of breath**, double the **Biota seed**; for **limping inability to walk**, double the **Alisma**. Alternatively, the powder may be made into **date-kernel-sized pills with jujube paste**, taken **seven pills at a time with wine**.

**Shènlì Sǎn** (Kidney Essence Powder), for treating **all manner of exhaustion-related illnesses** (虚劳百病):
**Ram’s kidney** (羖羊肾), dried in the shade – 1 pair.
**Poria** (茯苓) – 1½ *liǎng*.
**Schisandra berry** (五味子), **Glycyrrhiza** (甘草), **Morinda root** (巴戟天), **Cinnamon twig** (桂心), **Sargentodoxa vine** (石龙芮), **Achyranthes root** (牛膝), **Cornus fruit** (山茱萸), **Siler root** (防风), **Dried ginger** (乾姜), **Asarum root** (细辛) – each 1 *liǎng*.
**Rehmannia root** (乾地黄) – 2 *liǎng*.
**Ginseng** (人参), **Antelope horn powder** (锺乳粉), **Dendrobium stem** (石斛), **Cuscuta seed** (菟丝子), **Salvia miltiorrhiza** (丹参), **Asparagus tuber** (苁蓉), **Aconite root** (附子) – each 5 *fēn*.
The **right twenty ingredients** (右二十味) are ground into a powder, mixed with **antelope horn powder**, sifted until uniform, and taken with **morning clear wine in a square-inch spoonful**, gradually increasing to **two spoonfuls**, twice daily.

**Additional Formula**, for treating **male exhaustion from the Five Strains and Seven Injuries, the Eight Winds and Twelve Bi Syndromes**, regardless of season, with **prolonged sorrow, emaciation, and general debility** (八风十二痹，无有冬夏，悲忧憔悴，凡是病皆须服之):
**Ram’s kidney** (羊肾), dried in the shade – 1 pair.
**Magnolia bark** (厚朴), **Schisandra berry** (五味子), **Female ginseng** (女萎), **Asarum root** (细辛), **Cnidium fruit** (牡刑子), **Peony root** (芍药), **Morinda root** (巴戟天), **Dendrobium stem** (石斛), **White atractylodes** (白敛), **Sargentodoxa vine** (石龙芮), **Poria** (茯苓), **Cornus fruit** (山茱萸), **Toxicodendron resin** (乾漆), **Alum** (矾石), **Gentiana root** (龙胆), **Cinnamon twig** (桂心), **Ligusticum root** (芎藭), **Asparagus tuber** (苁蓉), **Sichuan peppercorn** (蜀椒), **Atractylodes macrocephala** (白朮), **Chrysanthemum flower** (菊花), **Continuous knotweed** (续断), **Polygala root** (远志), **Ginseng** (人参), **Astragalus root** (黄耆), **Alisma rhizome** (泽泻), **Coix seed** (萆薢), **Scutellaria root** (黄苓) – each 1 *liǎng*.
**Dried ginger** (乾姜), **Aconite root** (附子), **Siler root** (防风), **Acorus rhizome** (菖蒲), **Achyranthes root** (牛膝) – each 1 *liǎng*.
**Half-orange peel** (半桔梗) – 2 *liǎng*.
**Half-Chinese yam** (半薯蓣), **Siler root** (秦艽) – each 2 *liǎng*.

The following are the formulas for treating **lower back weakness (下节)** and **seven types of injury (七伤)**:

**Thirty-seven-herb formula (右三十七味)**:
To treat **lower back weakness (下节)**, take with wine, a **cubic-inch spoon (方寸匕)**, three times daily. Avoid sexual activity.
Another formula: **Sargentodoxa vine (石龙芮)**, **Continuous knotweed (续断)**, **Platycodon root (桔梗)**, **Dried ginger (乾姜)**, **Acorus rhizome (菖蒲)**, **Cornus fruit (山茱萸)**, **Poria (茯苓)** – each 2 *liǎng*.
**Chinese yam (薯蓣)**, **Sichuan peppercorn (蜀椒)**, **Paeonia root (芍药)**, **Dendrobium stem (巴戟天)**, **Ginseng (人参)**, **Gentiana root (龙胆)**, **Angelica root (女萎)**, **Magnolia bark (厚朴)**, **Asparagus tuber (肉苁蓉)**, **Asarum root (细辛)**, **Coix seed (萆薢)**, **Aconite root (附子)**, **Dendrobium stem (石斛)**, **Astragalus root (黄耆)**, **Ligusticum root (芎藭)**, **White atractylodes (白敛)**, **Aconitum root (乌头)**, **Aconite root (天雄)**, **Cinnamon twig (桂心)** – each half a *liǎng*.
**Siler root (秦艽)**, **Atractylodes macrocephala (白朮)**, **Cynanchum stem (誉石, also called 矾石)** – each 1 *liǎng*.
**Polygala root (远志)** – 2 *liǎng*.
**Half-Toxicodendron resin (半乾漆)** – 3 *liǎng*.
**Sheep kidney (羊肾)** – 1, dried in shade.

**Thirty-six-herb formula (右三十六味)**:
To treat **lower back weakness (下筛)**, take with wine, a **cubic-inch spoon (方寸匕)**, three times daily.
This formula differs from the previous one by omitting **Alisma rhizome (泽泻)**, **Scutellaria root (黄苓)**, and **Siler root (防风)**, while adding **Aconitum root (乌头)** and **Aconite root (天雄)**, each half a *liǎng*. The rest are the same.

**Chinese yam formula (薯蓣散)**:
To **tonify men (补丈夫)** and treat all ailments (though not all can be listed here):
**Chinese yam (薯蓣)**, **Vitex fruit (荆实)**, **Lycium fruit (枸杞子)**, **Continuous knotweed (续断)**, **Poria (茯苓)**, **Poria (茯神)**, **Achyranthes root (牛膝)**, **Cuscuta seed (菟丝子)**, **Dendrobium stem (巴戟天)**, **Eucommia bark (杜仲)** – each 1 *liǎng*.
**Asparagus tuber (两苁蓉)** – 2 *liǎng*.
**Five-flavor berry (五味子)**, **Cornus fruit (山茱萸)**, **Siler root (防风)**, **Gentiana root (蛇床子)** – each 2 *fen* (分).

Take with wine, a **cubic-inch spoon (方寸匕)**, twice daily and once at night to treat **lower back weakness (下筛)**. Avoid vinegar and garlic. No other dietary restrictions.
After five nights, vitality will improve; after ten nights, strength will return; after fifteen nights, strength will be robust like in youth; after twenty nights, strength will double.
If forgetfulness occurs, add **Polygala root (远志)** and **Poria (茯苓)**. If the body feels stiff, add **Ziziphus spinosa seed (柏子仁)**.
Three doses will benefit muscles. It can also be made into pills: take 30 pills per dose, twice daily and once at night. Warmth in the head, face, and body indicates proper dosage.
This formula is mild and not heating; it harmonizes the **five zang organs (五脏)**, and long-term use will enhance vitality beyond compare. Women who take it may develop a ruddy complexion.
**Formula for treating the five types of exhaustion (补五劳方)**:
Collect **Acanthopanax stem (五加茎)** on the fifth day of the fifth month, its leaves on the seventh day of the seventh month, and its roots on the ninth day of the ninth month to treat **lower back weakness (下筛)**. Take with wine, a **cubic-inch spoon (方寸匕)**, three times daily.
Long-term use will eliminate **wind exhaustion (风劳)** and **fatigue (劳)**, making it a marvelous remedy.

**Formula for treating five types of exhaustion, six types of extreme depletion, seven types of injury, and general weakness (治五劳六极七伤虚损方)**:
**Asparagus tuber (苁蓉)**, **White fossil bone (白龙骨)**, **Cordyceps militaris (阳起石)**, **Continuous knotweed (续断)**, **Aconite root (天雄)** – each 7 *fen*.
**Oyster shell (牡蛎)**, **Five-flavor berry (五味子)**, **Gentiana root (蛇床子)**, **Rehmannia root (乾地黄)**, **Mulberry mistletoe (桑寄生)**, **Asparagus tuber (天门冬)**, **White stone (白石英)** – each 1 *liǎng*.
**Plantago seed (车前子)**, **Allium tuberosum (韭子)**, **Cuscuta seed (菟丝子)** – each 5 *he* (合).
**Lycium root bark (地骨皮)** – 8 *fen*.

Take with wine, a **cubic-inch spoon (方寸匕)**, three times daily to treat **lower back weakness (下筛)**.

**Chongruo Milk formula (锺乳散)**:
To treat **five types of exhaustion and seven types of injury (五劳七伤)**, **general weakness and lack of vitality (虚赢无气力)**, and **extreme depletion (伤极)**:
**Chongruo Milk (锺乳)** – 6 *liǎng*, regardless of coarseness, taken as earth pure in white, which can hold 3-4 *dou* (斗). Add **millet husks (粟粗糠)** – 2 *he* (合), and boil in a copper pot until 5-6 times boiling. Add the milk and boil until the water reduces. Repeat adding water as before. After one *sháo* (晬) hour, strain with warm water, dry in the sun, and grind with a jade pestle until no sound is heard. Sift through fine silk with water, collect the sediment, and use it.
**White deer horn (鹿角白者)**, **Equisetum hyemale (白马茎)**, **Sulfur (硫黄)**, **Dendrobium stem (石斛)**, **Iron filings (铁精)**, **Ginseng (人参)**, **Magnetite (磁石)**, **Cinnamon twig (桂心)**, **Silkworm pupae (僵蚕)** – each 1 *liǎng*.
**Gentiana root (蛇床子)** – 3 *liǎng*.

Make into a powder, mix with **jujube paste (枣膏)**, and pound 3,000 times. Take with wine, 30 pills the size of **Ficus religiosa fruit (梧子)**, twice daily and once at night. Avoid sexual activity, raw and cold foods, **sour and slippery substances (酢滑)**, as well as chicken, pork, fish, and spoiled foods.

**Spring Festival Chongruo Milk formula (寒食锺乳散)**:
To treat **injury-induced weakness and lack of vitality (伤损乏少气力)**, **general exhaustion and all diseases (虚劳百病)**, and to **strengthen digestion and nourish appetite (令人嗜食)**, while eliminating **wind and cold (去风冷)**:
The formula is listed in the **Extreme Depletion (气极)** section.

**Rehmannia root formula (地黄散)**:
To **tonify qi (益气)**, **harmonize the middle (调中)**, **replenish absolute depletion (补绝)**, and **strengthen appetite (令人嗜食)**, while eliminating heat:
**Fresh Rehmannia root (生地黄)** – 30 *jīn* (斤), finely cut and dried in the sun. Take 30 *jīn* of fresh root, pound into juice, and steep the cut pieces. Repeat this process nine times, drying in the sun each time, then make into a powder.
Take after meals with wine, a **cubic-inch spoon (方寸匕)**, ensuring it is not taken to the point of exhaustion.

**Three Stone formula (三石散)**:
To treat **wind exhaustion, poisonous cold, and chronic ailments (风劳毒冷，百治不瘥)**, as well as **general depletion (补虚)**:
**Chongruo Milk (锺乳)**, **Purple stone (紫石英)**, **White stone (白石英)**, **Atractylodes macrocephala (白朮)**, **Platycodon root (桔梗)**, **Siler root (防风)** – each 5 *fen*.
**Trichosanthes root (栝蒌根)**, **Ginseng (人参)**, **Sichuan peppercorn (蜀椒)**, **Dried ginger (乾姜)**, **Aconite root (附子)**, **Oyster shell (牡蛎)**, **Cinnamon twig (桂心)**, **Eucommia bark (杜仲)**, **Asarum root (细辛)**, **Poria (茯苓)** – each 10 *fen*.

Take with wine, a **cubic-inch spoon (方寸匕)**, three times daily to treat **lower back weakness (下筛)**. Walking ten to fifty steps after taking this formula is highly beneficial, but young people should not use it. All other tonifying formulas are suitable for both old and young, especially recommended for winter use.

From the *Compendium of the Thousand Gold Pieces (千金翼)*, this formula is also called **Revitalizing formula (更生散)**, using **Cinnabar (赤石脂)** instead of **Purple stone (紫石英)**, and omitting **Sichuan peppercorn (蜀椒)**, **Eucommia bark (杜仲)**, and **Poria (茯苓)**, making it **thirteen herbs (十三味)**.

**Stone Achyranthes formula (石韦圆)**:
The Yellow Emperor asked about the **five types of exhaustion and seven types of injury (五劳七伤)** to **Gao Yang Fu (高阳负)**. Gao Yang Fu replied:
1. **Depleted yin (阴衰)**,
2. **Clear semen (精清)**,
3. **Sparse semen (精少)**,
4. **Consumed yin (阴消)**,
5. **Lower abdominal dampness (囊下湿)**,
6. **Lumbar or chest pain (腰一作胸胁苦痛)**,
7. **Knee cramps and coldness (膝厥痛冷不欲行)**, **bone heat (骨热)**, **blurred distant vision (远视沮出)**, **dry mouth (口乾)**, **abdominal rumbling (腹中鸣)**, **occasional heat (时有热)**, **frequent urination (小便淋沥)**, **penile pain (茎中痛)**, or **semen discharge without arousal (或精自出)**.

These are called **seven types of injury (七伤)**.
1. **Exhaustion from emotional distress (志劳)**,
2. **Exhaustion from overthinking (思劳)**,
3. **Exhaustion from overuse of the heart (心劳)**,
4. **Exhaustion from worry (忧劳)**,
5. **Exhaustion from fatigue (疲劳)**.

These are called **five types of exhaustion (五劳)**.

**Wu Bu Yuan (五补圆)**
Treats kidney *qi* depletion, five types of exhaustion, seven types of injury, lumbar and leg soreness, joint pain, dim vision, forgetfulness, disorientation, frequent nightmares, morning dry mouth, loss of taste, chronic discontent, frequent anger, impotence, abdominal distension, limb numbness, sour regurgitation, cold in the lower abdomen, dribbling urine, and constipation. This formula governs all such conditions.

**Prolonged use extends longevity, prevents aging, and eliminates a myriad of diseases within a year.**
**Formula:**
Du Zhong (杜仲) — *six fen*
Ba Ji Tian (巴戟天) — *six fen*

Gou Ji (狗脊) — *each four fen*
Gan Di Huang (乾地黄) — *twelve fen*
Rou Cong Rong (肉苁蓉) — *twelve fen*
Lu Rong (鹿茸) — *fifteen fen*
Tu Si Zi (菟丝子)
Fu Ling (茯苓) — *each five fen*
Fu Pen Zi (覆盆子)

Zi Xie (萆薢)
She Chao Zi (蛇床子)
Shi Nan (石南)
Bai Zhu (白朮) — *each three fen*
Tian Men Dong (天门冬) — *seven fen*

**Total: twenty-four herbs.** Ground into powder, formed into pills the size of *wu zi* with honey.
**Dosage:** Ten pills with wine, three times daily.

**Modifications:**
- *For wind-related symptoms*, add Tian Xiong (天雄), Chuan Xiong (芎藭), Dang Gui (当归), Huang Qi (黄耆), Wu Jia Pi (五加皮), Shi Nan (石南), Mai Dong (袂神), Du Huo (独活), Bai Zi Ren (柏子仁), Bai Zhu (白朮) — *each three fen*.
- *For stagnant qi*, add Hou Po (厚朴), Zhi Shi (枳实), Ju Pi (橘皮) — *each three fen*.
- *For cold symptoms*, add Gan Jiang (乾姜), Gui Xin (桂心), Wu Zhu Yu (吴茱萸), Fu Zi (附子), Xi Xin (细辛), Shuo Jiao (蜀椒) — *each three fen*.
- *For seminal emission*, add Jiu Zi (韭子), Bai Long Gu (白龙骨), Mu Li (牡蛎), Lu Rong (鹿茸) — *each three fen*.
- *For diarrhea*, add Chi Shi Zhi (赤石脂), Long Gu (龙骨), Huang Lian (黄连), Wu Mei Rou (乌梅肉) — *each three fen*.

**Seasonal Adjustments:**
- *Spring:* Follow the base formula.
- *Summer:* Add Sheng Di Huang (地黄) — *five fen*, Huang Qin (黄苓) — *three fen*, Mai Men Dong (麦门冬) — *four fen*.
- *If cold:* Remove the above and add Gan Jiang (乾姜), Gui Xin (桂心), Shuo Jiao (蜀椒) — *each three fen*.
- *If neither hot nor cold:* No additions or subtractions; take as is.

**Efficacy:** After three doses, all symptoms improve.
**Precautions:** Avoid alcohol, garlic, raw fish, spoiled or foul-smelling foods, extreme cold, and vomiting from intoxication. Otherwise, no external restrictions apply.
**Dosage Note:** Gradually increase to thirty pills, but do not exceed this limit.

**Deer Horn Pill:**
Use fresh antlers from the current year, including the brain cavity, as the finest. If the root shows signs of cutting, it is acceptable. Avoid flat-rooted antlers. Among the hundred and ten deer horn pill formulas, this one stands out—Chéngzǐ took it and transformed into a phoenix.

To prepare, take five (or four, three, two, or one) antlers. Cut off one *cùn* from the tip, leaving seven to eight *cùn* in length. Chop into pieces, pound into powder, and steep in flowing water in a bamboo container for ten nights.

If no flowing water is available, steep the mixture in a clean basin filled with water, changing it each night. Once the process is complete, scrape off the wrinkled skin, pound it finely to extract the white essence, and cease when done thoroughly. Then, with clean glutinous rice, steep the powder for two nights. After the first night, it will dry; squeeze out the old water, place it on fresh silk, and dry it in the sun. Purify and select the finest, discarding impurities, coarse bone skin, and unevenly pounded pieces.

Next, soak the mixture in fine, ash-free wine in a large white porcelain vessel for two nights. The wine and vessel should match the quantity of the drug. Transfer both the drug and the wine into a clean pot, and boil with strong fire for the duration of a meal. Then, reduce the flame and simmer gently, until the liquid bubbles like crab eyes. Use a willow-wood paddle, four *chǐ* long and three *fǎng* wide, to stir slowly—do not stop stirring. If tired, replace with another person. Add more fine wine as needed, until the decoction is complete. The decoction must begin at dawn and not last beyond two nights.

When the residue resembles thin glue, add the following ingredients in sequence:
- **Deer Horn (Lújiǎo)**, one *tiáo* (conditioned by roasting until yellow), made into powder, and prepared with the other drugs—
- **Betel Nut (Bīngláng)**, steeped in wine for two nights, then dried and pounded separately;
- **Halonium (Tōngcǎo)**, steeped in wine for two nights, then dried and pounded separately;
- **Sophora Root (Qínjiāo)**, steeped in wine for two nights, then dried and pounded separately;
- **Ginseng (Rénshēn)**, steeped in wine for two nights, then dried and pounded separately;
- **Licorice (Gāncǎo)**, steeped in wine for two nights, then dried and pounded separately;
- **Cuscuta Seed (Túsīzǐ)**, steeped in wine for two nights, then dried and pounded separately;
- **Meat of Cordyceps (Ròuzhīróng)**, one *liǎng* (20 pieces).

If no further supplementation is needed, these ingredients need not be decocted together. Alternatively, prepare the decoction for the duration of a meal, then let it cool slightly before adding the other powdered drugs, stirring until well combined. Wait until the mixture thickens enough to form pills, then store it in a clean vessel. With many hands rolling the pills simultaneously, shape them to the size of *wúzi* (willow seeds). If not enough hands are available, roll them one by one while keeping the mixture warm, and size them like *gǔshǒu* (ox-hoof pills). Apply a slight coating of ghee to the hands as needed.

**Method of Consumption:**
Take the pills on an empty stomach with three *guǒ* (fruits) of *jiāng* (juice), or with wine if no juice is available. Begin with thirty pills daily, increasing by one each day until reaching fifty pills as the standard dose, taken twice daily.

Within the first hundred days of consumption, abstain from sexual activity. After one month of taking the pills, internal ailments will begin to dissipate, and minor bowel movements should not be cause for alarm. Gradually, excessive flatulence will cease, appetite will improve, hearing and vision will sharpen, the spirit will be fortified, the organs will be steadied, bone marrow will be nourished, the waist and limbs will regain strength, allowing one to stand for long periods. Gray hair will turn black, and a youthful appearance will return even to the aged.

For those suffering from **qi** disorders, add **Rhizoma Pinelliae (Gēnshí)** and **Lignum Aquilariae (Qīngmùxiāng)**, each one *liǎng* (20 pieces), following the previous method.

If one has previously taken **elixirs of cinnabar or minerals (dànshí)**, consume **Three-Yellow Pill (Sānhuáng Wán)** with meals to induce mild bowel movements and purge the system.

If drinking wine or eating *qū* (fermented foods) causes dry mouth, coarse nasal breath, and dull eyes, take it with honey juice to alleviate the symptoms. If the symptoms persist, add **Three-Yellow Pill (Sānhuáng Wán)** to induce mild bowel movements.

In all cases, once the **Dao/Way** has been activated, regulate the diet accordingly.

After two hundred days of consumption, facial wrinkles will smooth out and a natural glow will appear. Within a year, teeth will fall out and regrow, memory will strengthen, the body will feel as light as wind, and one may walk several hundred *lǐ* (miles) daily. By the second year, the body will naturally become plump and well-fed, with reduced hunger, and those over seventy will appear as young adults. By the third year, the intestines will solidify like sinew and marrow, and one will foresee events before they occur. By the fourth year, one will be perpetually sated, no longer needing food, and may directly encounter **Daoist Immortals (xiān rén)**.

If taken continuously by those under thirty, the complexion will remain forever youthful and unchanging.

When preparing the medicine, do so in a **pure chamber (jìngshì)**, excluding the presence of **chickens, dogs, women, filial children (xiàozǐ)**, and others. Women may also take this medicine.

**For the Treatment of Organ Deficiency and Chronic Fatigue, as well as Tightness and Heat in the Lower Abdomen:**
Apply **moxibustion (jiǔ)** to the **Kidney Shu (Shènshū)** point twenty times (or adjust according to age and constitution). If the condition is marked by **cold deficiency (xuélěng)**, apply up to a hundred times. Moxibustion should be applied horizontally across three *cùn* (inches).

**Chapter 1: Treatise on the Bladder Vessel**
**Section #1: The Bladder Vessel (Pāngguāng Fǔ) Treatise**

The **Bladder Vessel** governs the **kidneys**, with its manifestations observed in the ears. The kidneys converge their *qi* into the bladder. The bladder, as a *fǔ* (visceral organ), is the repository of bodily fluids, known as the **"Water Clerk"** (*Shuǐ Cāochuàn*) or **"Jade Sea"** (*Yùhǎi*). It weighs **nine *liǎng* and two *chǔ*** (≈252g), coiled in a leftward spiral, extending vertically, nine *cùn* in breadth, and holds **nine *shēng* and nine *hé* (≈1.125L)** of fluids, balanced on both sides, corresponding to the **twenty-four solar terms**. Its orifice opens externally at the nose, while the bladder itself is prone to leakage.

The **Yellow Emperor** asked: *"Why do the five *zàng* (solid organs) each have one name and one form, while the kidneys alone are paired?"*

**Qíbó** replied: *"The bladder, as a *fǔ*, exists in two locations, and the kidneys likewise manifest in two forms, corresponding to the bladder’s duality. Though the *zàng* are singularly named, the *fǔ* are named in pairs—hence the five *zàng* and six *fǔ*."*

An alternative view holds that the kidneys are paired, while the bladder is singular. Now, we align the **left kidney** with the bladder and the **right kidney** with the **Triple Burner**.

If the **pulse at the *guān* (wrist crease) posterior to the *zhōngyáng* (middle finger line) on the left hand is absent**, it signifies the absence of the **Bladder Vessel**. Symptoms include:
- **Cold inversion** (*niùlěng*)
- **Irregular menstruation** in women, with **cessation during the *wángyuè* (winter solstice)**
- **Semen loss** in men
- **Dribbling urine**
Treatment: **Puncture the *shǎoyīn* (foot minor yin) meridian** at the **dorsal artery below the medial malleolus** (i.e., the *shǎoyīn* channel’s *yīn* point).

If the **pulse at the *guān* posterior to the *zhōngyáng* on the right hand is absent**, it signifies the absence of the **Child’s Gate Vessel** (*Zǐhù Mài*). Symptoms include:
- **Cold inversion in the feet**
- **Infertility**
- **Leucorrhea**
- **Sterility**
- **Cold in the genital region**
Treatment: **Puncture the *shǎoyīn* meridian** to regulate the *yīn*.

If the **pulse at the *guān* posterior to the *zhōngyáng* on the left hand is full**, it indicates **Bladder fullness**. Symptoms include:
- **Cold inversion**
- **Lateral pain from pathogenic *qi* drawing inward**
Treatment: **Puncture the *tàiyáng* (foot major yang) meridian** to regulate the *yáng*, targeting the **depression posterior to the proximal joint of the little toe** (i.e., the *tàiyáng* channel’s *yáng* point).

If the **pulse at the *guān* posterior to the *zhōngyáng* on the right hand is full**, it also indicates **Bladder fullness**. Symptoms include:
- **Distension of the lower abdomen**
- **Lumbar pain radiating upward**
Treatment: **Puncture the *tàiyáng* meridian** to regulate the *yáng*.

If disease **first manifests in the bladder**, the following patterns emerge:
- **Day 5 (associated with the kidneys)**: **Lumbar and sacral pain**, **urinary retention**, **acidic meridian sensations** in the lower abdomen and spine.
- **Day 1 (associated with the small intestine)**: **Abdominal distension**.
- **Day 1 (associated with the spleen)**: **Obstruction and stagnation**, **body heaviness and pain**.

If the condition persists for **two days**, death follows—**winter’s parrot-like cry**, **summer’s drooling**. *(Alternative: "at dusk.")*

For **Bladder disease**:
- **Unilateral distension and pain** in the lower abdomen, such that pressing it with the hand **triggers the urge to urinate without release**,
- **Heat in the shoulders**,
- If the **pulse is sunken**, **heat** also manifests at the **lateral side of the little toe** and **posterior to the ankle** on the *tàiyáng* channel.
  **Treatment**: **Needle *Wěizhōng*** (CV4).

For **Bladder distension**:
- **Fullness in the lower abdomen** with **difficult urination** (*qì liáo*).

When **disease first strikes the kidneys** and **transmits to the Bladder**:
- **Persistent kidney cough** leads to **involuntary urination** upon coughing.
- If **ulterior *jué* qi** lodges in the Bladder, **nocturnal somnambulism** ensues.

The **kidneys govern bone**; thus:
- **Dense, thick skin** indicates **thick *Sānjiāo* and Bladder**;
- **Coarse, thin skin** indicates **thin *Sānjiāo* and Bladder**;
- **Loose texture, sparse hair** indicates **lax *Sānjiāo* and Bladder**;
- **Taut skin with no hair** indicates **constricted *Sānjiāo* and Bladder**;
- **Coarse, lustrous hair** indicates **straight *Sānjiāo* and Bladder**;
- **Sparse hair** indicates **knotted *Sānjiāo* and Bladder**.

**Biānqué** said:
*"When the six *fǔ* are diseased, the face reflects it.
The **kidneys and Bladder**, along with the *shǎoyīn* and *tàiyáng* channels, form the **external enclosure**.
Since the **Bladder communicates with the five *zàng***, when the *zàng* are afflicted, the Bladder responds;
when the Bladder is afflicted, the **uterus (*bāo náng*)** responds.

**Heat injury** causes **urinary obstruction**, **Bladder urgency**, and **bitter, yellow-red urine**.
**Cold injury** causes **frequent, clear urination**, or **urinary stones**—
its root lies in the Bladder, with **small limbs** and **a disproportionately large abdomen**.
*(Treatment) **referenced in the *Water Treatment* chapter**.*

**Severed bone** is untreatable;
**yellow, falling teeth** portend death in **ten days.**

The **Foot Tàiyáng** channel originates at the inner canthus of the eye, ascends the forehead, and converges at the crown. Its branch extends from the crown to the upper angle of the ear. Its direct course descends from the crown, enters to network the brain, then emerges to descend behind the neck, follows the inner aspect of the shoulder and scapula, runs along the spine to the lumbar region, enters to network the kidneys, and connects with the Bladder.

Its branch descends from the lumbar region to meet at the perineum, then passes through the buttocks and enters the coccygeal region. Another branch descends from the inner scapula, bifurcates to pierce the hip (or *kuān*), passes the sacral pivot (*pí shū*), follows the posterior lateral aspect of the thigh, converges at the popliteal fossa, then descends to pierce the inner malleolus, emerges behind the lateral malleolus, follows the cuboid bone, and terminates at the lateral side of the little toe.

When this channel is disturbed, it causes **frontal headache**, the sensation of the eyes protruding, the neck feeling as if pulled taut, spinal pain, lumbar rigidity as if broken, inability to flex the hip, the popliteal fossa feeling knotted, and the heel as if split—this is known as **ankle reversal (*huái jié*)**. It governs diseases of the **sinews**, including hemorrhoids, malaria, mania, epilepsy, and convulsions; headaches, brain and neck pain; jaundiced eyes, excessive tearing, nasal and epistaxis bleeding; pain in the neck, back, lumbar region, popliteal fossa, heels, and feet; and dysfunction of the little toe. When excessive, the *rén yīng* pulse at the wrist is twice as large as the *cùn kǒu* pulse; when deficient, the *rén yīng* pulse is smaller than the *cùn kǒu* pulse.

**Discourse on the Bladder Sacculus (Bāonáng Lùn):**
The bladder sacculus is the diagnostic region of the kidneys and bladder, storing *jīnyè* (津液) and urine. If there is cold in the fǔ (腑), the sacculus becomes slippery, with frequent urination and white discharge. If urination is particularly frequent at night, it is due to the rise of *yīnyáng* (陰陽) *qi* at night.

Thus, heat is treated by purgation, cold by tonification, and when neither heat nor cold is present, regulation follows the *jing* (經). Then, the disease will not arise.

If urine does not reside in the sacculus, it is due to its contraction or deviation, obstructing *jīnyè*. Use leek leaves, remove the tip, and insert into the urethra to a depth of 3 *cùn*, gently blowing with the mouth. When the sacculus expands and *jīnyè* flows freely, the condition will be cured.

**Chapter Four: Treatise on the Three *Jiao* (Triple Burners)**

The Three *Jiao* are also called the Three Passes. The Upper *Jiao* is named *Sān Guǎn* (Three Passages) and *Fǎnshè* (Reflection), the Middle *Jiao* is named *Huòluàn* (Churning), and the Lower *Jiao* is named *Zǒubǔ* (Nursing). Together, they form an entity with a name but no tangible form. They govern the five *zàng* (solid organs) and six *fǔ* (hollow organs), serving as the divine pathways through which *qi* circulates, permeating the entire body—visible in its effects but not in its substance. They harmonize and facilitate the flow of refined *qi*, regulate the waterways, and restrain *qi* between the intestines and stomach. Their functions must not be overlooked.

The Three *Jiao* are also called the *Zhōngqīng* (Middle Clarity) *fǔ* (hollow organ), with the alternate name *Yùhǎi* (Jade Sea). The waterways emerge from here and converge with the bladder, though they remain distinct. The Upper, Middle, and Lower *Jiao* are collectively referred to as the *Gūfǔ* (Orphan Hollow Organ), with *yíng* (nutritive *qi*) emanating from the Middle *Jiao* and *wèi* (defensive *qi*) from the Upper *Jiao*.

*Nutritive qi* (*yíng*) is the pathway of the *luò* (collateral vessels), while *defensive qi* (*wèi*) is the pathway of the *jīng* (main channels). The Three *Jiao* vary in thickness, size, and form, yet share the same structure as the bladder.

**Diseases of the Three *Jiao*:**
When the Three *Jiao* are diseased, the abdomen becomes distended with *qi*, and the lower abdomen is particularly firm, preventing urination. Urgency and straining occur, with retention leading to distension and overflow resulting in urinary discharge. Observe the large collateral on the lateral side of the foot’s *Dàyáng* (Greater Yang) channel, located between the *Tàiyáng* (Greater Yang) and *Shàoyáng* (Lesser Yang) channels, also visible in the pulse. Treat at *Wěiyáng* (Bend Sun).

If the lower abdomen is swollen and painful with urinary retention, the pathology lies in the Three *Jiao*. Restrict treatment to the large collateral of the *Tàiyáng* channel. If the pulse is knotted at the junction of the *Juéyīn* (Supreme Yin) small collateral and blood is present, the swelling extends upward to the stomach tube—treat at *Sān Lǐ* (Three Miles).

When the Three *Jiao* are distended, *qi* fills the skin, causing a taut, non-painful sensation—some texts describe it as taut and firm. Chronic, unremitting coughing may spread to the Three *Jiao*, resulting in abdominal fullness and loss of appetite.

The channel of the hand’s *Shàoyáng* (Lesser Yang) begins at the lateral side of the second toe, ascends between the two toes, follows the outer wrist, passes between the two bones of the forearm, pierces the elbow, travels along the outer upper arm to the shoulder, and emerges behind the foot’s *Shàoyáng* channel, entering the *Quēpén* (Notched Basin) and intersecting *Tánzhōng* (Chest Center). It disperses into the collateral network of the pericardium, descends through the diaphragm, and spreads throughout the Three *Jiao*.

A branch ascends from *Tánzhōng* to the *Quēpén*, then to the nape, alongside the ear’s posterior, curving upward to the ear’s upper angle, and bending downward to the [missing character]. Another branch enters the ear from behind, emerges in front, passes the *Kèzhǔrén* (Guest and Host) points, crosses the cheek, and reaches the outer canthus of the eye.

When this channel is disturbed, it causes deafness with a ringing or buzzing sensation, throat swelling, and pharyngeal obstruction. The diseases it governs—induced by *qi* imbalance—include spontaneous sweating, pain at the outer canthus, swollen cheeks, and pain behind the ear, on the shoulder, upper arm, elbow, and outer forearm. The second toe and adjacent toe may also become dysfunctional.

For these conditions, apply reduction if excessive, tonification if deficient, rapid moxibustion if there is heat, and prolonged moxibustion if there is cold. If the pulse is sunken, use moxibustion. For neither excess nor deficiency, treat according to the channel. An excessive pulse at *Rényīng* (Human Welcome) is twice as strong as at *Cùnkǒu* (Cun Opening), while a deficient pulse is weaker at *Rényīng* than at *Cùnkǒu*.

**Chapter Five: The Vacancies and Plenitudes of the Three *Jiao* – Moxibustion Methods**

The Upper *Jiao* resembles mist rising upward—its *qi* originates from the upper orifice of the stomach (or mouth, as per *Nánjīng*, *Jiǎyǔ*, and *Cháoyuán*), passing through the throat and diaphragm, spreading across the chest, moving to the armpit, and following the division of the foot’s *Tàiyīn* (Greater Yin) channel. It returns to the hand’s *Yángmíng* (Yang Brightness) channel, ascending to the tongue and descending to the foot’s *Yángmíng* channel. It circulates with *yíng* and *wèi* *qi* for twenty-five degrees along the Yang pathways and twenty-five degrees along the Yin pathways, completing one full cycle every day and night—fifty cycles in total—before reuniting at the hand’s *Tàiyīn* channel.

It governs diseases of the hand’s *Shàoyáng* and the heart and lungs. When *qi* is internally trapped, heat in the body causes drinking and eating to descend into the stomach, but the *qi* is unsettled. Sweating ensues—sometimes on the face, sometimes on the back—with generalized body heat. Why does sweat emerge without following the *wèi* *qi*’s usual pathways? External wind invasion opens the pores, causing *wèi* *qi* to disperse and fail to follow its proper course. This *qi* is fierce, slippery, and swift; it escapes through any opening, hence the name *Lòuqì* (Leaky *Qi*).

The resulting ailments include elbow contracture and pain, vomiting before defecation (due to disrupted *qi* flow), and a sense of oppression in the diaphragm. This explains why vomiting precedes defecation. Cold induces spiritual disarray, leading to diarrhea, dysentery, and aphonia. If excessive, the condition ascends to the heart; if deficient, it draws *qi* into the lungs.

Treats Upper *Jiao* disorders where drinking and eating descend into the stomach, *qi* remains unsettled, and sweat emerges on the face and back with generalized body heat—known as *Lòuqì* (Leaky *Qi*).

**The twelve herbs above**, □-caul, use **one and a half *shēng* of water**, decoct to obtain **three *shēng***, and divide into **three doses**.

Treats **chest congestion** (*Jīqiè*) and **clustered pain** with a tendency to **vomit**—known as the **Mai Men Dong Regulates the Middle Jiao** decoction.

**For the following acupuncture treatment**: Moxa the **Lesser Yang (Juéyīn) Convergence Point** (*Shū*), located **one inch and five *fēn* away from the fourth vertebra on either side**, according to the patient’s age and constitution.

**Discourse on the Middle Jiao**:
The **Middle Jiao** is like **a stagnant pool** (*yòuyòu*), within the stomach as if **a pool were stagnating**. Its *qi* arises from the **stomach’s central pathway**—*Nánjīng* renders it as **Middle Mouth**, while *Jiǎyǐ* and *Cháoyuán* render it as **Stomach Mouth**—located **after the Upper Jiao**.

This is the **receptor of *qi*** (*Shòuqì*), responsible for **transforming water and grain into flavors**, **concealing糟粕 (*zāozāo* – dregs and impurities)**, **steaming essences and fluids**, and **refining them into vital subtleties** (*jīngwēi*), which **ascend to the lung’s channels** (*Fèimài*) and are then **converted into blood**. This blood **nourishes the body** (*shēngshēn*), and none is more precious than this. Thus, it **alone circulates through the meridians and collateral vessels**, known as **Nourishing *Qi*** (*Róngqì*), governing **Foot Yang Ming**.

The **alternate name of Foot Yang Ming** is **Feng Long** (*Fēnglóng*), located **eight *cùn* above the ankle** (*wàiguì*), **separating to course along Foot Tai Yin**, and **connecting with the pulses of all meridians**. It **ascends and descends to link with the Great Granary** (*Tàicāng*), governing **the fermentation and maturation of the five grains**—**neither vomiting nor descending occurs**.

If **excessive**, it **generates heat**; if **heat is present**, it **becomes obstructed and fails to pass through**, leading to **disconnection between upper and lower**.

If **deficient**, it **produces cold**; if **cold is present**, it causes **abdominal pain**, **leakage**, **diarrhea**, and **cholera-like disorders**, governing **spleen and stomach diseases**.

Now, **blood and *qi*** differ in form yet share the same essence (*lèi*). The **Defensive *Qi*** (*Wèiqì*) is the **vital essence** (*jīng*), and the **Nutritive *Qi*** (*Xuéqì*) is the **spirit** (*shén*). Thus, blood and *qi* share the same essence though they bear different names.

Where **blood is lost**, there is **no sweat**—this is the **spirit-*qi** (*shénqì*).
Where **sweat is depleted**, there is **no blood**—this is the **essence-*qi** (*jīngqì*).

Thus, **a person may have two deaths** (*liǎngsǐ*) but **no two lives** (*èrshēng*), akin to the **disconnection of spirit-*qi**.

If **deficient**, **supplement the stomach**; if **excessive**, **drain the spleen**. **Regulate the central harmony** and **balance the source**, and **not one among ten thousand will be neglected**.

**Shu Da Huang (Rhubarb) Drains Heat Decoction** – **Opens the Blocked Channels** and **Connects the Isolated**, treating **Middle Jiao excess-heat obstruction**, where **upper and lower fail to communicate**, **channels are blocked and disconnected**, **neither vomiting nor descending occurs**, **abdominal fullness and distension** (*Péngjiāo*), and **rapid, labored breathing**:
- Shu Da Huang (Rhubarb) – **cut**, soaked in **one *shēng* of water**
- Scutellaria Root (*Huángqín*) – 3 *liǎng*
- Alisma (*Zéxiè*) – 3 *liǎng*
- Cimicifuga Rhizome (*Shēngmá*) – 3 *liǎng*
- Mirabilite (*Mángxiāo*) – 3 *liǎng*
- Antelope Horn (*Língyángjiǎo*) – 4 *liǎng*

**The nine herbs above**, □-caul, use **seven *shēng* of water**, decoct to obtain **two *shēng* and three *gě***, then add the **pre-soaked rhubarb**, boil again for **two more cycles** (*liǎngfèi*), remove the dregs, add **mirabilite**, and divide into **three doses**.

Form into **pills the size of apricot kernels**; take **three pills** with water, **twice daily**. **On the seventh day of the seventh month**, combine all ingredients for a **greater efficacy**—this should be **made into a unified pill**.

**Huang Lian (Coptis) Decoction** – Treats **Middle Jiao cold**, **leakage**, and **diarrhea**, or **after cholera**, where **yellow-white discharges are uncontrollable** and **abdominal pain persists from deficiency**:
- Huang Lian (Coptis) – 4 *liǎng*

**The eight herbs above**, □-caul, use **nine *shēng* of water**; decoct to obtain **three *shēng***, remove dregs, add **donkey-hide gelatin**, and simmer again until dissolved (*yōng*), then divide into **three doses**.

Treats **four limbs being unable to lift or move**, with **excessive sweating** and **leakage-diarrhea**.

**For the following acupuncture treatment**: Moxa the **Great Horizontal (Dàhéng) Point** according to the patient’s age and constitution; the point is located **two inches and five *fēn* away from the navel on either side**.

**Discourse on the Lower Jiao**:
The **Lower Jiao** is like **a draining ditch** (*dúdú*), akin to **water flowing down a channel** (*yōngxiāo*), its *qi* arising from the **stomach’s lower pathway**, **separating to encircle the intestines**, and **descending into the bladder** (*Pángguāng*) to **percolate and drain**.

Thus, **water and grain** are always **conjointly stored in the stomach**, becoming **dregs and impurities** (*zāozāo*) and **together descending into the large intestine**.

It governs **Foot Tai Yang**, which **percolates and drains fluids**, **unites with the bladder**, **controls excretion but not intake**, and **discriminates between clear and turbid** (*Bìngqīngzhuó*), governing **the symptoms of liver and kidney diseases**.

**Discourse on the Lower Jiao’s Pathologies and Treatments:**

If **replete**, then **defecation and urination are obstructed**, *qi* **reverses and falters**, and **vomiting cannot be restrained**—thus it is called **"rushing suckling"** (*zǒubǔ*). If **vacant**, then **defecation and urination are uncontrollable**, and **fluids and *qi* are exhausted**.

When **a person drinks wine into the stomach**, yet **the grain is undigested while urine descends first**, why is this? Wine is the **refined essence of mature grain**, its *qi* **bold and slippery**, thus **later entering but earlier exiting**.

Hence, **heat drains into the liver**, while **cold and murkiness supplement the kidneys**.

- **Lower Extremity Confluence** (*Xiàjíshū*) is located five *cùn* away from **Lateral Curved Bone** (*Xiàqūgǔ*).

- **Water Channel** (*Shuǐdào*) is on both sides of **Lateral Curved Bone** (*Xiàqūgǔ*), two and a half *cùn* apart.

**Prescriptions for the Bladder Viscera**

**#1: Cholera (6th) – Theory, Symptoms, Prescriptions, and Moxibustion Method**

The Master says: *"Cholera, as a disease, arises solely from improper diet and has nothing to do with malevolent spirits. When one overeats rich meats and cold dairy, consumes an excess of seafood and land-based delicacies without restraint, sleeps on cold mats, and drinks chilled liquids, the stomach’s food stagnates and fails to digest. The interplay of yin and yang qi becomes disrupted—yang strives to ascend while yin seeks to descend, their disharmony giving rise to vomiting and dysentery. The patient suffers a splitting headache, joint dislocations, and convulsions throughout the limbs. Though the symptoms may seem minor at first, the disease’s progression is most perilous—even standing at the edge of a precipice cannot fully convey its danger. Those who cultivate life must grasp this truth to avoid untimely death.*

*In treating cholera, warmth and moderation are paramount. Exposure to cold will provoke convulsions throughout the body. Ideally, the patient should abstain from food for one day, then gradually reintroduce small portions of congee over three days. Only after this period may they resume normal eating, but for seven days, they should avoid mixed dishes to nourish the spleen’s qi.*

*Most cases of cholera stem from overindulgence in cold meats, dairy, or excessive, unregulated eating, followed by improper rest—such as sleeping without adequate covering. Many perish from this neglect.*

*The foundation of life lies in the five viscera, which correspond to the five phases (Wood, Fire, Earth, Metal, Water). Internally, they govern the five flavors; externally, they interact with them. Thus, seasonal adjustments in diet are essential. The *Classics* warn: ‘In spring, avoid excessive pungency; in summer, avoid saltiness; in late summer, avoid sourness; in autumn, avoid bitterness; in winter, avoid sweetness.’ These restrictions are not absolute prohibitions but cautions against excess. The proverb states, ‘A hundred diseases originate from the mouth’—a truth not without merit.*

*During the summer solstice to autumnal equinox, one must avoid greasy, rich foods. Yet in hot months, people naturally crave cold foods, compounding the harm by pairing them with heavy meals, unchecked consumption of fruits and vegetables, and excessive exposure to cold through sleep and bathing. Such imbalances in the five flavors inevitably lead to illness—even those who wish to remain healthy cannot escape it. As the *Book of Changes* states: ‘It is not Heaven that cuts short life; it is the person who brings ruin upon themselves.’*

*In cholera, rice water is strictly forbidden, as its ingestion provokes unrelenting vomiting. Instead, administer a decoction of *Houpu* (magnolia bark) and *Gegen* (kudzu root). Winter melon leaf tea may be sipped lightly to moisten the throat but must not be overconsumed. If vomiting persists during decoction intake, discontinue once the episode ceases.*

*If the pulse is imperceptible, prescribe a decoction of *Guizhi* (cinnamon twig) and *Gegen*. For persistent vomiting and diarrhea with restlessness, feverish flesh, and absent sweating—without convulsions and with a rapid, tense pulse—administer a decoction of *Xijiao* (rhinoceros horn) and *Gegen*.

*For unremitting vomiting and diarrhea with fever, restlessness, and thirst, offer small amounts of rice flour gruel. If symptoms persist, prescribe a decoction of *Gegen*, *Jie* (chickweed), and *Fu* (smilax).

*A student inquired: ‘What constitutes cholera?’ The Master replied: ‘Repeated vomiting and diarrhea.’*

*A student asked further: ‘A patient presents with fever, headache, body aches, aversion to cold, followed by vomiting and diarrhea—what ailment is this?’ The Master answered: ‘This is cholera. Cholera is characterized by alternating episodes of vomiting and diarrhea, interspersed with fever.’*

*If the pulse is faint and rough—indicating an underlying cholera—yet the patient exhibits signs of *Shanghan* (cold-induced febrile disease) and progresses to the yin channels within four or five days, convulsions and diarrhea will inevitably follow. Once diarrhea reverses to a downward flow, the condition is untreatable.*

*In cholera, excessive vomiting leads to convulsions without thirst, accompanied by umbilical distension. If the umbilicus distends in cholera, it signifies disturbed kidney qi, and *Zhongzi Tang* (Central Seed Decoction) must be administered first—omitting *Fuzi* (processed aconite) but adding *Guizhi* (cinnamon twig). The omission of Wood (aconite) is due to its depleting nature; cinnamon is added to prevent *Beitun* (abdominal distension with inability to lie flat).*

*For cholera with umbilical distension, excessive vomiting, or excessive diarrhea; for cholera with palpitations, thirst, or abdominal pain; for vomiting with diarrhea, or vomiting with diarrhea and a craving for water—all are treated with *Zhongzi Tang*.*

**Zhongzi Tang** – *For cholera with vomiting, diarrhea, distension, indigestion, and abdominal pain:*
- Ginseng (*Rénshēn*) – 3 *liang*
- Dried Ginger (*Gānjiāng*) – 3 *liang*
- White Atractylodes (*Báizhú*) – 3 *liang*
- Licorice (*Gāncǎo*) – 3 *liang*

*Decoct the four ingredients with 8 *sheng* of water, reducing to 3 *sheng*, and divide into three doses. If symptoms persist, administer three additional doses.*

*For preventive use during travel, prepare the decoction into pills the size of *wúzi* (schisandra berries), taking 30 pills. Alternatively, as a powder, take one *fangchén* dose with wine.*

*If convulsions occur, add 3 *liang* of gypsum.*

*Zhang Zhongjing states: ‘If the umbilicus distends, kidney qi is disturbed. Remove *Fuzi* and add 4 *liang* of *Guizhi*.’ For excessive vomiting, remove *Fuzi* and add 3 *liang* of fresh ginger. For excessive diarrhea, reintroduce *Fuzi*. For palpitations, add 2 *liang* of *Fuling* (poria). For thirst with a desire for water, add 4.5 *liang* of *Fuzi* combined with the original ingredients. For abdominal pain, add 4.5 *liang* of ginseng combined with the original ingredients. For coldness, add 4.5 *liang* of dried ginger combined with the original ingredients. For abdominal distension, remove *Fuzi* and add one piece of *Fuzi* (processed aconite).*

*After ingesting the decoction, consume a bowl of warm congee within an hour, ensuring the patient remains lightly covered and avoids sudden exposure to cold.*

**Guizhi Tang** – *For cholera with ceased vomiting and diarrhea but persistent body aches, this decoction gently harmonizes the exterior. The formula appears in the *Shanghan Lun* (Treatise on Cold-Induced Febrile Diseases).*

**Sisuo Tang** – *For cholera with convulsions, cold limbs, sweating, and hiccups:*

**Four-Inverse Decoction (Sì Nì Tāng)** – *For extreme cold with cold hands and feet, and a vanishing pulse:*
**Aconite (processed)** – 2 *liang*
**Ginseng** – 3 *liang*
**Dried ginger** – 3 *liang*
**Licorice** – 3 *liang*
**Right four herbs**, coarsely chopped. Decoct with 6 *sheng* of water, reduce to 2 *sheng*, and divide into three doses.
*The Range Wang [commentary] states:* For severe diarrhea, add 2 *liang* of dragon bone.

**Licorice** – 2 *liang*

*Right three herbs*, coarsely chopped. Decoct with 3 *sheng* of water, reduce to 1.2 *sheng*, and serve warm in two divided doses. For stronger cases, use 1 piece of **great aconite** and up to 3 *liang* of dried ginger.

**Treatment for Cholera with Food Stagnation and Cold Accumulation, Ghostly *Qi* Distress, and Abdominal Fullness:**
Use extremely salty warm water (3 *sheng*), drink 1 *sheng* hot, and induce vomiting to expel all stagnant food. If vomiting does not occur, repeat administration. Once vomiting ceases, drink again, repeating three times before resting.
*This method surpasses all others, yet common practitioners dismiss it as crude and rural, clinging to death instead. For such cases, this must be the first remedy applied.*

**General Treatment for Cholera:**

**Treatment for Cholera with Stagnant Food and Cold Accumulation, Ghostly *Qi* Distress, and Abdominal Fullness:**
*Flattened broad bean* and *common mugwort* each 1 *sheng*.
*Right two herbs*, coarsely chopped. Decoct with 6 *sheng* of water, reduce to 2 *sheng*, and take in divided doses. May also be used alone.

**Treatment for Cholera with Persistent Diarrhea:**
*Right* use 1 handful of *mugwort*, decoct with 3 *sheng* of water, reduce to 1 *sheng*, and take all at once. Excellent.

**Another Method:**
Use 1 handful of *sweet flag*, decoct with 4 *sheng* of water, reduce to 1 *sheng*, and take all at once. *Green wood aromatic* is also good.

**Treatment for Cholera with Vomiting, Diarrhea, and Abdominal Pain:**
*Right* decoct *peach leaves* into juice, take 1 *sheng* at once, and pain will cease. In winter, use the *peach bark*.

**Treatment for Cholera with Induced Vomiting, Where Vomiting Occurs Immediately After Drinking:**
*Right* use fresh ginger 5 *liang*, coarsely chopped. Decoct with 5 *sheng* of water, reduce to 2.5 *sheng*, and divide into two doses. *Galangal* is even better.

**Preventive Treatment for Cholera Before Long Journeys:**
*Duckweed*, *sweet flag*, *white atractylodes*, *tangerine peel*, *Evodia rutaecarpa*, *dried ginger*, *ginseng*, *thick-skinned magnolia bark*, *aucklandia costus*, *chicken tongue spikenard*, *dianthus superbus*, *cinnamon twig*, *thin mint*, *female Artemisia*, and *fennel* – *right* fifteen herbs, equally divided, ground into powder, formed into honey pills the size of *Chinese date seeds*. Take twenty pills with wine.

**Treatment for Cholera That Never Recurs:**
*Honeysuckle leaf* and *purslane* each 2 *liang*; *green tangerine fruit*, *aconite*, *ginseng*, *areca nut*, *dried ginger* each 3 *liang*; *thick-skinned magnolia bark* 6 *liang*; *soapberry* 3 *cun*; *white atractylodes* 5 *liang* – *right* ten herbs, ground into powder, formed into honey pills the size of *Chinese date seeds*. Take twenty pills with wine, three times daily.

During the *Wu De* era, there was a virtuous nun named *Pure Clarity* who had suffered from this ailment for a long time. Sometimes it flared once a month, sometimes twice. Each flare brought her near death. Even the *Chao Tai* physicians of the time, including those of the *Jiang Xu Gan Chao* school, could not recognize it. I treated her as cholera and administered this formula, and she recovered. Thus, I record it here.

**Treatment for Cholera Following Stone Consumption, Where Vomiting and Diarrhea Cease but Symptoms Persist:**
If one has first consumed *stone medicine* and then cholera induces vomiting and diarrhea, which stops after taking various hot drugs, but then transforms into *emptiness* (虚), restlessness, hot palms and soles, dry mouth, thirst, retching, confusion, and rapid, tense pulse – or if, after a febrile illness, residual *heat poison* remains and cholera again causes vomiting and diarrhea, followed by heat in the chest and heart as if tearing apart – use this to resolve it:

*Radicchio*, *ginseng*, *thick-skinned magnolia bark*, *anemarrhena asphodeloides*, *trichosanthes root*, *poria*, *rhinoceros horn*, *indigo naturalis*, *green tangerine fruit*, *platycodon grandiflorum*, *tangerine peel*, *pueraria root*, *scutellaria baicalensis*, and *licorice* – each 2 *liang*.
*Right* fourteen herbs, coarsely chopped. Decoct with 1 *dou* of water, reduce to 3 *sheng*, and divide into three doses.

**Treatment for Cholera with Internal Heat, Sudden Profuse Sweating, Restlessness, Rapid Pulse, and Desire for Cold Water:**
*Right* drink 1 *sheng* of freshly drawn well water at once, and it will cure immediately. Do not use this if one has previously suffered from *stomach coldness*.

**Secret Remedy for Cholera That Conventional Treatments Cannot Cure:**
*Right* use the menstrual cloth and blood of a virgin, burn to ash, make into powder, and take 1 *fen* (方寸匕) with wine. Use this if all other remedies fail.

**Treatment for Cholera with Spasmodic Twitching:**
*Right* use 1 handful of *knotweed*, remove both ends, decoct with 2 *sheng* of water, reduce to 1 *sheng*, and take all at once. Another method: decoct *pear leaves* instead.

**Another Method:**
Burn the ash of an old wooden comb, make into powder, and take with wine, 1 small dose. This will permanently cure it.

**Another Method:**
Apply the grease from the center of a *cart wheel hub* to the soles of the feet. This will cure it.

**Treatment for Cholera with Spasmodic Twitching Entering the Abdomen, Where All Else Fails:**
Prepare extremely salty brine, warm and soak the feet in a trough. Another method:

**Treatment for Persistent Spasms:**
If treating with fermented green cloth poultices, replace when cooled.

**For Unrelenting Spasms:**
If a man, pull his *yin* (阴) and stretch it; if a woman, pull near her breasts on either side.

**Moxibustion Methods (灸法):**
It is said: For cholera, though moxibustion may not cure it immediately, it will prevent death. Do not apply moxa prematurely. Some cases begin with abdominal pain, others with diarrhea followed by vomiting—treat according to symptoms.

If pain begins in the chest or vomiting first occurs, moxibustion at *Jiuque* (巨阙) seven times (one *zhàng*—壮—per application), located one *cun* below the heart. If ineffective, repeat as before.

If abdominal pain begins first, moxibustion at *Taicang* (太仓) twenty-one times (三七壮), located four *cun* below *Xinyan* (心厌) and one *cun* above the navel. If unresolved, repeat as before.

If vomiting and diarrhea are uncontrollable and both *yin* and *yang* pulses are rapid, moxibustion at *Xinbi* (心蔽骨) three *cun* below and at the navel three *cun* below, each forty-two to seventy times (六七十壮).

If dry retching occurs, moxibustion at *Jianshi* (间使) seven times, located three *cun* behind the wrist between two tendons. If unresolved, repeat as before.

If vomiting with phlegm occurs, moxibustion at *Xinzhu* (心主) seven times, located on the wrist crease. If vomiting persists, repeat as before.

If limbs are cold, moxibustion at *Sanyinjiao* (三阴交) seven times, located three *cun* above the medial malleolus at the *lián* bone (廉骨). If unresolved, repeat as before.

If diarrhea begins first, moxibustion at *Gumen* (谷门) fourteen times (二七壮), located two *cun* beside the navel—left for men, right for women—also called *Dachangmu* (大肠募). If unresolved, repeat as before.

If diarrhea persists, moxibustion at *Dadu* (大都) seven times, located at the inner side of the big toe’s base joint.

If dysentery is severe and the patient is near death, moxibustion at *Ciyun* (慈宫) fourteen times (二七壮), located two and a half *cun* beside the *henggu* (横骨)—the transverse bone below the navel.

If spasms occur in the arms or chest, moxibustion at the palm’s white flesh seven times, and also at *Dan Zhong* (亶中), *Zhongfu* (中府), *Jiuque* (巨阙), *Weiguan* (胃管), and *Chize* (尺泽)—all effective for muscle contractions, curing headaches and foot ailments alike.

For *walking-spasm* (走哺转筋), moxibustion at the heel’s white flesh three times seven, and at the lower abdomen’s central *henggu* (横骨) according to age.

For *fourfold spasms* (转筋四厥), moxibustion at the black-white junction of both breast roots, one *zhàng* each.

For spasms, moxibustion at *Yongquan* (涌泉) forty-two to seventy times (六七壮), located beneath the big toe’s large tendon, and once at the center of the big toe’s underside.

For unrelenting spasms, moxibustion at the heel’s tendon junction seven times—immediate cure.

If spasms enter the abdomen and pain is excruciating, four people hold the limbs while moxibustion is applied one *cun* above the navel fourteen times (十四壮). If the patient moves, stop holding.

Also, moxibustion at the *dàjīn* (大筋) of the thigh, one *cun* from the *yin* (阴).

For cholera spasms, have the patient lie face-up, arms extended. Measure the elbows with a cord, then mark points one and a half *cun* beside the spine at the cord’s level—moxibustion one hundred times (一百壮) ensures cure. *Zhǒuhòu* (《肘后》) states: This is Hua Tuo’s method.

If cholera patients appear dead but retain warmth, moxibustion at *Chengjin* (承筋) seven times: measure the foot’s circumference from toe to heel with a cord, fold it in half to find the midpoint—this is the point. Also, moxibustion at the navel’s center fourteen times (二七壮).

**Supplementary Prescriptions (杂补第七论):**

It is said: Pengzu (彭祖) declared that to maintain youthful vigor, prevent exhaustion from *fángshì* (房室—sexual activity), and preserve vitality and complexion, nothing surpasses *míjiǎo* (麋角—deer antler).

**Method:**
Scrape into powder (十两), mix with one fresh *fúzi* (附子—aconite), and take one *fāngcùn* (方寸匕) with wine, thrice daily—highly effective. Alternatively, parch the powder until slightly yellow and take alone, though less potent than with *fúzi*. Even better, mix with *quèdàn* (雀卵—sparrow eggs) into pills; twenty days of use yields great results.

**Húpò Sǎn (琥珀散):**
For *xūláo* (虚劳—debilitating exhaustion), impotence, seminal emission, weakness, urinary dysfunction resembling *lín* (淋—dysuria), cold-induced frontal headaches, *qi* congestion at *guānyuán* (关元), forced sexual activity, diminished semen, lumbar pain, heavy limbs, dry throat, loss of appetite, fatigue, blurred vision, palpitations, and *wǔzàng* (五脏) exhaustion—

**Ingredients:**
*Húpò* (琥珀—amber), *wújīngzǐ* (芜菁子—charlock seeds), *húmázi* (胡麻子—sesame seeds), *chēqiánzǐ* (车前子—plantain seeds), *shézhuāngzǐ* (蛇床子—Cnidium fruit), *túsīzǐ* (菟丝子—kudzu vine seeds), *gǒuqǐzǐ* (枸杞子—goji berries), *ānbèizi* (庵#10子—*possibly* *yùjīn* 裕金 or *wūwéizi* 乌蔹子—*uncertain*), *màimén’dōng* (麦门冬—Ophiopogon), *júpí* (橘皮—tangerine peel), *róusōngrǒng* (肉苁蓉—Cistanche), *sōngzhī* (松脂—pine resin), *mǔlì* (牡蛎—oyster shell), *sōngzǐ* (松子—pine nuts), *bǎizǐ* (柏子—*possibly* *bǎizhū* 柏子—*uncertain, likely* *bǎizhū* 柏实—*Chinese juniper fruit*), *rěnzǐ* (荏子—*possibly* *rúzhī* 荛花子—*uncertain, likely* *rúzhī* 荛花—*castor oil plant seeds*), *guìxīn* (桂心—cinnamon bark), *shíwéi* (石韦—*possibly* *shíwèi* 石韦—*polypody*), *shíhú* (石斛—Dendrobium), *huáshí* (滑石—talc), *fúlíng* (茯苓—Poria), *chóngwéi* (芎藭—*possibly* *xiōngwéi* 熊胆—*uncertain, likely* *chóngwéi* 虫藭—*maggot-infested herb, unclear*), *rénshēn* (人参—ginseng), *dùhuò* (杜荷—*possibly* *dùhuò* 杜荷—*uncertain, likely* *dùhuò* 杜衡—*Akebia*), *xùduàn* (续断—*Continuum* root), *yuǎnzhì* (远志—polygala), *dāngguī* (当归—angelica), *niúxī* (牛膝—achyranthes), *mǔdān* (牡丹—peony), and *tōngcǎo* (通草—*possibly* *tōngcǎo* 通草—*Arundo*)—*thirteen* *shēng* (升) each for the first ten, four *liǎng* (两) each for the next eight, three *shēng* each for the last three, and *tōngcǎo* fourteen *fēn* (分).

**Preparation:**
Grind all thirty ingredients through a sieve, mix into a paste, and store in a leather pouch. Take one *fāngcùn* before meals, thrice daily and once at night, decocted in cow or sheep milk until thick.

**Effects:**
Prolonged use strengthens vitality, lightens the body, augments *qi*, improves digestion, endures cold and heat, eliminates ailments, and—even with ten partners—prevents exhaustion. Semen becomes dense like fat; after seventy days, sexual function is restored. Long-term use reverses aging, turns white hair black, and regrows fallen teeth.

**Prescriptions from the *Thousand-Gold Canon* (太平部) – *Sun’s Emergency Formulas* (孙真人备急千金要方), Volume 63**

*Song Dynasty* **Ling Bì et al.** (林亿等) revised under **Lǎng Shǒu** (奉郎), **Guard of the Tai-Chang Office** (守太常少卿), and **Supervisor of the Secret Hall** (充秘一阁校理).

**#1 Prescriptions for *Xiao-Ke* (消渴, Diabetes)** – **First Discourse on *Xiao-Ke* (消渴第一论)**

**Prescriptions: Cauterization Method (灸法)**
The discourse states: *"In all cases where one has long indulged in alcohol, there is none who does not fall into *Xiao-Ke*. Yet, even in the depths of winter, when the sea congeals with cold, alcohol remains unfrozen—this demonstrates its nature of extreme heat, unmatched by any other substance. Salty meats and pickled delicacies are flavors alcoholics crave; without them, they cannot partake. After three cups, they lose control over their intake, consuming without measure. They chew fermented fish and sauces indiscriminately, whether sour or salty, year after year, night after night, their intoxication never ceasing. Thus, the *San-Jiao* (三焦, Triple Burner) becomes fiercely heated, and the *Wu-Zang* (五脏, Five Viscera) parched with drought. Even wood and stone wither and crack—how could a human not thirst?"*

The efficacy of treatment depends entirely on the patient’s compliance. If they adhere strictly to the prescriptions, recovery may be achieved within a decade; if they neglect self-care, death will follow swiftly. Medical texts abound with effective remedies, yet what benefit are they to those who do not exercise caution? There are three critical precautions: **1** abstaining from alcohol, **2** moderation in sexual activity, and **3** avoiding salty foods and fermented grains. Those who heed these may avoid illness even without medication; those who do not, though they possess *Jin-Dan* (金丹, Golden Elixir), cannot be saved. Reflect deeply and take heed.

Furthermore, it is said: *"Between those who recover from *Xiao-Ke* and those who do not, the decisive factor lies in whether they develop a great abscess (*Da-Yong*, 大痈). Why so? Those afflicted with *Xiao-Ke* will inevitably develop abscesses between the major joints, leading to their demise. Thus, the warning lies in the great abscess—prepare abscess remedies in advance to prevent it."*

There was a man whose *Xiao-Ke* and frequent urination began in spring, persisted through summer, and was treated with *Gua-Lou* (栝蒌) and *Fú* (豉, fermented soybean) juice, which gradually eased his thirst. Yet his urine remained excessive—over twenty times a day, often totaling three to four *sheng* (升), and even at remission, it did not drop below two *sheng*. Over time, urination ceased entirely, but he grew increasingly emaciated, his throat and lips parched, his breath shallow, unable to speak much, his heart restless with heat, and his legs aching. His appetite doubled, yet his strength did not improve—this condition was clearly caused by *Xu-Re* (虚热, False Heat). To treat it, he should take *Gua-Lou* juice long-term to dispel the heat; *Niu-Ru* (牛乳, cow’s milk) and *Xing-Li* (杏酪, apricot kernel paste) are excellent for nourishment. This method is particularly beneficial.

**Prescription to Eliminate False Heat in the Intestines and Stomach (消渴, 治除肠胃热实方):**
*Mai-Dong* (麦门冬, Ophiopogon japonicus) – **8 *fen*** (分)
*Fú-Ling* (茯苓, Poria) – **8 *fen***
*Huáng-Lián* (黄连, Coptis chinensis) – **8 *fen***
*Shí-Gāo* (石膏, Gypsum) – **8 *fen***
*Wěi-Ruì* (萎蕤, Asparagus cochinchinensis) – **8 *fen***
*Ren-Shēn* (人参, Ginseng) – **6 *fen***
*Lóng-Dǎn* (龙胆, Gentiana) – **6 *fen***

*Shí-Zhì* (枳实, Citrus aurantium) – **5 *fen***
*Shēng-Jiāng* (生姜, fresh Ginger) – **10 *fen***
*Gǒu-Qǐ* (枸杞子, Lycium fruit) – **10 *fen*** (replaced with *Dì-Gǔ-Pí* (地骨皮, Cinnamomum cassia) in *Wài-Tái* (外台))
*Gua-Lou* (栝蒌根, Trichosanthes root) – **10 *fen***

**Thirteen herbs above**, pulverized and formed into honey pills the size of *Wú-Zǐ* (梧子, Chinese date fruit). Take with *Máo-Gēn* (茆根, Imperata cylindrica) and *Sù-Mǐ* (粟米, Millet) juice, **10 pills twice daily** (日二). If thirst persists, take with the decoction until fully sated. *Da-Má* (大麻, Cannabis) may also be used. The decoction is prepared as follows:

*Máo-Gēn* (茆根, Imperata cylindrica), cut – **1 *sheng*** (升)
*Sù-Mǐ* (粟米, Millet) – **3 *he* (合, he)** (of volume)

**Two herbs above**, boiled in **6 *sheng*** of water until the millet is tender. Strain and add the preceding powdered mixture.

**Another Prescription:**
*Gua-Lou* (栝蒌根, Trichosanthes root) – **5 *liǎng* (两, liang)**
*Shēng-Jiāng* (生姜, fresh Ginger) – **5 *liǎng***
*Shēng-Mài-Dōng* (生麦门冬汁, fresh Ophiopogon juice) – **2 *sheng***

*Máo-Gēn* (茆根, Imperata cylindrica), cut – **3 *sheng***

**Fú-Shēn* (茯神) *Tang* (汤, Decoction)** – **Draining False Heat and Quenching Thirst** (泄热止渴), **for Stomach Heat with Persistent Thirst** (治胃腑实热, 引饮常渴方):
*Fú-Shēn* (茯神, Poria) – **2 *liǎng*** (replaced with *Fú-Ling* (茯苓, Poria) in *Wài-Tái*)

*Shēng-Mài-Dōng* (生麦门冬, fresh Ophiopogon) – **5 *liǎng***

*Zhī-Mǔ* (知母, Anemarrhena asphodeloides) – **4 *liǎng***
*Shēng-Dì-Huáng* (生地黄, fresh Rehmannia glutinosa) – **6 *liǎng***
*Xiǎo-Mài* (小麦, Wheat) – **2 *sheng***

*Dàn-Zhú-Yè* (淡竹叶, Phyllostachys edulis), cut – **3 *sheng***

**Nine herbs above**, coarsely chopped, boiled in **3 *dǒu*** of water. First, boil the *Xiǎo-Mài* and *Dàn-Zhú-Yè* until reduced to **9 *sheng***, strain, then add the remaining herbs. Simmer until reduced to **4 *sheng***, divided into four servings. Take without regard to time, but whenever thirst arises. This not only alleviates stomach thirst but universally treats heat-induced thirst.

**Prescription for *Zhū-Dù-Yuán* (猪肚圆, Pig Stomach Pills)** – **for *Xiao-Ke*** (治消渴方):

**Seven herbs above**, pulverized and stuffed into the sewn pig stomach, which is then steamed in a *Zèng* (甑, steaming pot) until thoroughly tender. While still hot, remove the stomach and pound the mixture with a wooden mortar until it can be formed into pills. If too hard, mix with honey. Form pills the size of *Wú-Zǐ* (梧子).

Take **20 pills daily** (日二), increasing to **50 pills** (随渴即服之). Another prescription:

*Gua-Lou* (栝蒌根, Trichosanthes root) – **8 *fen***
*Mài-Dōng* (麦门冬, Ophiopogon japonicus) – **8 *fen***
