*Fú-Ling* (茯苓, Poria) – **6 *fen*** (replaced with *Fú-Shēn* (茯神, Poria) in *Wài-Tái*)
*Gān-Cǎo* (甘草, Glycyrrhiza) – **6 *fen***

**Five herbs above**, sifted and prepared as a powder. Take with **mixed water** (浆水), **1 *fāng-cùn* (方寸, square-inch) spoonful daily**, **three times** (日三). *Wài-Tái* omits *Fú-Shēn* (茯神).

**Another Prescription:**
*Huáng-Qī* (黄耆, Astragalus membranaceus) – **3 *liǎng***
*Fú-Shēn* (茯神, Poria) – **3 *liǎng***
*Gua-Lou* (栝蒌根, Trichosanthes root) – **3 *liǎng***
*Gān-Cǎo* (甘草, Glycyrrhiza) – **3 *liǎng***
*Mài-Dōng* (麦门冬, Ophiopogon japonicus) – **3 *liǎng***
*Gān-Dì-Huáng* (乾地黄, dried Rehmannia glutinosa) – **5 *liǎng***

**Six herbs above**, coarsely chopped, boiled in **8 *sheng*** of water until reduced to **2.5 *sheng***, strained. Divide into three servings; take **one dose daily** (日进一剂), **ten doses ideal** (服十剂佳).

**Prescription for *Fú-Píng-Yuán* (浮萍圆, Floating Heartleaf Pills)** – **for *Xiao-Ke*** (治消渴方):
*Gān-Fú-Píng* (乾浮萍, dried Floating Heartleaf) – equal parts
*Gua-Lou* (栝蒌根, Trichosanthes root) – equal parts

**Two herbs above**, pulverized and mixed with **human breast milk** (人乳汁) to form pills the size of *Wú-Zǐ* (梧子). Take on an **empty stomach** (空腹), **20 pills daily**, **three times** (日三). For those who have suffered for **three years** (三年病者), **three days of treatment** (三日) may suffice. This is particularly effective for **False Heat** (虚热).

**Prescription for Those Who Drink a *Shí* (石, stone) of Water Daily (治消渴, 日饮水一石者方):**
*Qiān-Dān* (铅丹, Red Lead) – **2 *liǎng***
*Fù-Zǐ* (附子, Aconitum carmichaeli) – **1 *liǎng***
*Gě-Gēn* (葛根, Pueraria root) – **3 *liǎng***
*Gua-Lou* (栝蒌根, Trichosanthes root) – **3 *liǎng***

**Four herbs above**, pulverized and formed into honey pills the size of *Wú-Zǐ* (梧子). Take **10 pills daily**, **three times** (日三), whenever thirst arises. Reduce *Fù-Zǐ* (附子) in spring and summer.

**Prescription for *Huáng-Lián-Yuán* (黄连圆, Coptis Pills)** – **for Thirst** (治渴方):
*Huáng-Lián* (黄连, Coptis chinensis) – **1 *jīn* (斤, jin)**
*Shēng-Dì-Huáng* (生地黄, fresh Rehmannia glutinosa) – **1 *jīn* (加一斤, as per Zhāng Wén Zhòng’s note)**

**Two herbs above**, extract juice from *Dì-Huáng* (地黄), soak *Huáng-Lián* (黄连) in it, then dry in the sun. Return the soaked *Huáng-Lián* to the juice, allowing it to dry completely. Pound into a powder and form into honey pills the size of *Wú-Zǐ* (梧子).

Take **20 pills daily**, three times, either before or after meals without restriction.

It may also be prepared as a powder, to be taken with wine in a **one-cubic-inch spoonful** (*fāngcùn dāifǐ*).

**Secret Prescription for *Gua-Lou-Fěn* (栝蒌粉, Trichosanthes Powder) – for Severe Thirst** (*treat great thirst*):
Take the deep-dug *Gua-Lou* root (大栝蒌根), thickly peel its skin until the white core is revealed, then cut it into inch-long slices. Soak in water for one day and night, changing the water, and repeat this process for five days. Mash and pound it into a fine powder, filter it through a silk bag, and dry it as per the method for extracting powder (如出粉法). Take with water in a **one-cubic-inch spoonful**, three to four times daily.

It may also be mixed into powdered gruel, milk, or yogurt and consumed without limit until the ailment subsides.

Another prescription: Mix *Gua-Lou-Fěn* with beaten egg and dry it in the sun. Pound again into a powder and take with water in a **one-cubic-inch spoonful**, three times daily. It may also be taken in pill form.

Another prescription: Mix *Gua-Lou-Fěn* with water and take in a **one-cubic-inch spoonful**. It may also be formed into honey pills the size of *Wú-Zǐ* (梧子, large as a *Wú-Zǐ* seed), and **30 pills** may be taken.

Another prescription: Collect the knots formed near the rim of the bucket by the ropes of seven households’ wells, burn them into ash, and take with well-water. No more than three doses are required for recovery.

Another prescription: Boil *Zhú-Gēn* (竹根, bamboo root) into a concentrated decoction and drink it until the ailment subsides.

Another prescription: Drink fermented soybean paste juice (*Zì* or *Zǐ* juice) in any quantity until recovery.

Another prescription: Cook *Qīng-Liáng-Mǐ* (青粱米, green broomcorn millet) and drink its juice until the ailment subsides.

**Commentary** (*Lùn Yuē*):
The disease of **internal consumption** (*nèi xiāo*) arises from excessive internal heat. If urination exceeds intake, it drains one’s vitality, causing shortness of breath and extreme exhaustion.

In **internal consumption** (*nèi xiāo*), all ingested food is converted into urine, yet the patient feels no thirst. Over a span of ten years, the governor of Zìzhōu (梓州), **Lǐ Wén Bó** (李文博), had long consumed *Bái-Shí-Yīng* (白石英, white quartz). Suddenly, his sexual vitality surged, but after a month, he began to suffer from thirst. Over several days, his urination became excessive—up to a hundred times a day—despite all treatments worsening his condition. His body grew weak, unable to rise or rest; his spirit became confused, and his mouth and tongue parched until his death.

Though rare, this disease is indeed fearsome. When symptoms appear, the pulse is **deep, fine, and weak** (*chén-xì-wēi*). A decoction of **goji berry** (*Gǒu-Qǐ-Tāng*) proves effective, yet it cannot ensure lasting cure.

Taking **Lead-Elixir Powder** also reduces symptoms, and in between, one may administer **Propagating-Supplement Pills**.

**Goji Berry Decoction** (for treating thirst and excessive urination):
- Goji berry branches and leaves: 1 *jin*
- Coptis rhizome (*Huáng Lián*), Trichosanthes root (*Guā Luó Gen*), Glycyrrhiza (*Gān Cǎo*), Gypsum (*Shí Gāo*): each 3 *liǎng*

**Total five flavors**, finely chopped. Boil with 1 *dòu* of water, reducing to 3 *shāng*. Divide into five doses—three during the day, two at night. For severe cases, increase the dosage; drink immediately upon thirst.

**Lead-Elixir Powder** (for treating *xiao-ke* diabetes, stopping frequent urination, and resolving *zhong-xiao* internal consumption):
- Lead elixir (*Qiān Dān*), barite (*Hú Fěn*): each 2 *fèn*
- Glycyrrhiza (*Gān Cǎo*), Trichosanthes root (*Guā Luó Gen*): each 10 *fèn*
- White pitchstone (*Bái Shí Zhī*—*Zhǒu Hòu* text reads *Bèi Mǔ*, Fritillaria), Alisma (*Zé Xiè*), Gypsum (*Shí Gāo*), Red pitchstone (*Chì Shí Zhī*): each 5 *fèn*

**Total eight flavors**, sifted and ground. Take with water, 1 *fāng cùn* spoonful, three times daily; robust individuals may take 1.5 *fāng cùn* spoonfuls. Patients with one year of illness recover in one day; those with two years recover in two days. For extreme thirst, take two doses at night; reduce if abdominal pain occurs.

Pills are also effective—ten pills per dose.

Excessive use causes abdominal pain. **Zhang Wén Zhòng** states: If abdominal pain occurs, administer rice gruel to induce defecation. The *Bèi Jí Fāng* states: Alcohol should not be used for induction; instead, use barley gruel. The *Gǔ Jīn Lù Yàn Fāng* states: After taking this medicine, within three days, boil and mash sheep liver and stomach, taken on an empty stomach, or made into a soup. One should habitually consume bland foods until urination becomes frequent and salty-bitter, then take **Cistanche Pills** alongside the decoction for recovery. The formula for **Cistanche Pills** and the decoction appears in *Wài Tái* Volume 11.

**Poria-Supplement Pill** (*Xuān Bǔ Wán*—*Jí Yàn* names it **Propagating-Supplement Pills**), for treating kidney-related *xiao-ke* diabetes and frequent urination:
- Poria (*Fú Shén*), Astragalus (*Huáng Qí*), Ginseng (*Rén Shēn*), Ophiopogon (*Mài Mén Dōng*), Glycyrrhiza (*Gān Cǎo*), Coptis (*Huáng Lián*), Anemarrhena (*Zhī Mǔ*), Trichosanthes root (*Guā Luó Gen*): each 3 *liǎng*
- Cuscuta seed (*Tú Sī Zǐ*): 3 *hé*
- Cistanche (*Bó Róng*): 4 *liǎng*
- Gypsum (*Shí Gāo*), Prepared Rehmannia (*Gān Dì Huáng*): each 6 *liǎng*

**Total twelve flavors**, ground into powder. Mix with 3 *hé* of cow bile, kneaded with honey into pills the size of *wú zǐ* (schisandra berries). Take with *máo gēn* (imperata root) decoction, 30 pills per dose, twice daily, gradually increasing to 50 pills.

**Sour Jujube Pill** (for treating dry mouth and internal consumption):
- Sour jujubes: 1.5 *shāng*
- Dried pomegranate seeds (pickled): 5 *hé*
- Wolfberry fruit (*Fú Pén Zǐ*), Pueraria root (*Gē Gēn*): each 3 *liǎng*
- Trichosanthes root (*Guā Luó Gen*), Poria (*Fú Líng*): each 3.5 *liǎng*
- Ophiopogon (*Mài Mén Dōng*): 4 *liǎng*
- Honey (*Shí Mì*): 4.5 *liǎng*
- Cinnamon bark (*Guì Xīn*): 1.6 *zhū*
- Prunes (*Wū Méi*): 10 pieces

**Total ten flavors**, ground into powder, kneaded with honey into pills. Dissolve in the mouth as needed, day or night, until saliva returns—repeat until fully restored. No dietary restrictions.

**Treatment for internal consumption with day-and-night urination of 7–8 *shāng***:
Roast deer antlers until charred, grind into powder, and take with wine, 5 *fāng cùn* spoonfuls daily, three times, gradually increasing to 1 *fāng cùn* spoonful.

Drink 1 *shāng* of fermented hemp seed juice.

**Discourse on the Causes of Thirst and Polyuria**:

The *Way* states: Among the many ways in which people exhaust themselves, those in their prime of vigor and strength do not guard against excess, indulging their passions and unrestrained desires, overindulging in *chamber arts* (房中). As they grow older, their *kidney-qi* (肾气) becomes depleted and exhausted, giving rise to myriad ailments.

Again, those who in their youth fear their inability to perform in *chamber arts* (房中) often consume *stone elixirs* (石散), thereby depleting their *true-qi* (真气). The *stone-qi* (石气) then stands alone, unbalanced—leading to mere *emptiness and dissipation* (虚耗), dry and parched lips, and spontaneous emission of *essence-fluid* (精液); or to *urine that is red and turbid* (小便赤黄), with *hard and dry feces* (大便乾实); or to *excessive thirst and frequent urination, up to ten shāng per day* (渴而且利，日夜一石); or to *thirst without frequent urination, or frequent urination without thirst*, where all consumed food transforms into *urine* (小便). These conditions are all caused by *excessive indulgence in chamber arts* (房室不节).

For ordinary individuals who experience *thirst in summer* (夏月喜渴), it stems from the *heart* (心王). When the *heart* (心王) induces *sweating* (便汗), the *kidney* (肾) becomes *dry and emaciated* (虚燥), hence the *thirst with scant urination* (渴而小便少). In winter, when there is no *sweating* (不汗), the *urine becomes abundant and frequent* (小便多而数). These are the signs of an ordinary person, known as *xiao-ke* (消渴).

However, if there is *frequent urination without drinking water* (小便利而不饮水), it indicates *kidney fullness* (肾实). The *Classics* state: *When the kidney is full, it consumes* (肾实则消). *Consumption* (消) refers to *frequent urination without thirst* (不渴而利). Therefore, those who take *stone elixirs* (石之人) and suffer from *frequent urination* (小便利), the *stone* (石) being of a nature that pertains to the *kidney* (归肾), the *kidney* (肾) receiving the *stone* (得石) becomes *full* (实), and *fullness* (实) can *consume water and fluids* (能消水浆), hence the *frequent urination* (故利). Excessive *urination* (利多) prevents the *kidney* from *nourishing the five zàng* (五脏), and when the *zàng* (脏) weaken, all manner of diseases arise.

Zhang Zhongjing (仲景) says: *When heat congeals in the middle burner* (热结中焦), it results in *hardness* (坚); *when heat congeals in the lower burner* (热结下焦), it causes *dysuria with blood* (溺血), also leading to *strangury* (淋闭不通). Though it is not necessary to enumerate all cases, one must recognize that *frequent urination* (小便利) is indeed a sign. Those with internal *heat* (内有热) will experience *thirst* (则喜渴); removing the *heat* (除热) will halt it. If *thirst is accompanied by emptiness* (渴兼虚), one must *remove heat and supplement emptiness* (须除热补虚) to achieve recovery.

**Atractylodes macrocephala** (白朮) **3 liǎng**

**Cinnamomum bark** (桂心) **3 liǎng**
**Licorice root** (甘草) **1 liǎng**

The **six herbs** (右六味), finely chopped, are decocted in **10 shāng of water**, with **small millet** (小麦) **3 shāng**. Reduce to **3 shāng of juice**, remove the millet, and add the herbs again. Simmer until **2.5 shāng** remain. Take **8 ge** per dose, **twice daily**.

**Another recipe** (又方):
Take **aged roof tiles** (屋上瓦, **30 years old**), crushed like **sparrow brains** (雀脑) **3 shāng**, and **water from the East Flow River** (东流水) **2 shí**. Decoct until **2 dòu** remain, then add the following herbs as in the previous recipe (**如左方**):
**Fresh Atractylodes macrocephala** (生白朮) **8 liǎng**
**Prepared Rehmannia root** (乾地黄) **8 liǎng**
**Fresh ginger** (生姜) **8 liǎng**
**Tangerine peel** (橘皮) **3 liǎng**
**Ginseng root** (人参) **3 liǎng**
**Licorice root** (甘草) **3 liǎng**
**Astragalus root** (黄耆) **3 liǎng**
**Polygala root** (远志) **3 liǎng**
**Cinnamomum bark** (桂心) **2 liǎng**
**Angelica root** (当归) **2 liǎng**
**Paeonia root** (芍药) **2 liǎng**
**Large jujube** (大枣) **30+ pieces**

The **twelve herbs** (右十二味), finely chopped, are added to the tile decoction, simmered until **3 shāng** remain, and taken in **four divided doses**. Alternatively, drinking the **tile decoction alone** is also beneficial (**或单饮瓦汁亦佳**).

**Recipe for post-febrile *yuhu* (虚热渴)**—**when **four limbs are restless and painful** (四肢烦疼)—
**Pueraria root** (葛根) **1 jīn**
**Ginseng root** (人参) **1 liǎng**
**Licorice root** (甘草) **1 liǎng**
**Bamboo leaves** (竹叶) **1 put**

The **four herbs** (右四味), finely chopped, are decocted in **15 shāng of water**, reducing to **5 shāng**. Drink whenever thirsty (**渴即饮之**), **three times daily and twice at night**.

**Bone-Filling Congee** (骨填煎), a **universally effective remedy** for **emptiness and fatigue with thirst** (虚劳渴):
**Poria** (茯苓) **3 liǎng**
**Cuscuta seed** (菟丝子) **3 liǎng**
**Angelica root** (当归) **3 liǎng**
**Cornus fruit** (山茱萸) **3 liǎng**
**Achyranthes root** (牛膝) **3 liǎng**
**Schisandra fruit** (五味子) **3 liǎng**
**Aconite root** (附子) **3 liǎng**
**Morinda root** (巴戟天) **3 liǎng**
**Gypsum** (石膏) **3 liǎng**
**Ophiopogon root** (麦门冬) **3 liǎng**
**Dioscorea bulbifera** (石韦) **3 liǎng**
**Ginseng root** (人参) **3 liǎng**
**Cistanche root** (苁蓉, *External Canon*作远志) **3 liǎng**
**Cinnamomum bark** (桂心) **4 liǎng**
**Soybean curd** (大豆卷) **1 shāng**
**Asparagus root** (天门冬) **5 liǎng**

The **sixteen herbs** (右十六味), ground into powder, are taken with **10 jīn each of fresh Rehmannia root and Trichosanthes root** (生地黄、栝蒌根), pounded and strained for their juice. Simmer the powdered herbs in the juice over **gentle fire**, reducing by half. Divide into several portions, add **3 jīn of white honey** (白蜜) and **1 jīn of bone marrow** (牛髓). Simmer further until the mixture thickens like **gruel** (糜), forming pills the size of **chicken yolk** (鸡子黄大). Take **three times daily**. Alternatively, the mixture may be consumed as a drink (**亦可饮服之**).

**Poria Powder** (茯神散), for treating **emptiness with heat** (虚热), **weakness and fatigue of the four limbs** (四肢羸乏), **persistent thirst and heat** (渴热不止), **Xiaoke (消渴)**, and **tonifying emptiness** (补虚):
**Poria** (茯神) **4 liǎng**
**Cistanche root** (苁蓉) **4 liǎng**
**Dioscorea bulbifera** (萎蕤) **4 liǎng**
**Fresh Dendrobium** (生石斛) **8 liǎng**
**Coptis rhizome** (黄连) **8 liǎng**
**Trichosanthes root** (栝蒌根) **5 liǎng**
**Salvia root** (丹参) **5 liǎng**
**Licorice root** (甘草) **3 liǎng**
**Schisandra fruit** (五味子) **3 liǎng**
**Anemarrhena rhizome** (知母) **3 liǎng**
**Angelica root** (当归) **3 liǎng**
**Ginseng root** (人参) **3 liǎng**
**Young wheat** (麦蘖, *External Canon*作小麦) **3 shāng**

The **thirteen herbs** (右十三味), wrapped in a **silk pouch** (绢袋) of **3 fāngcùn dāizǐ** (方寸匕), are decocted in **3 shāng of water**, reducing to **1 shāng**. Take **twice daily**, with one decoction constituting one dose (**一煮为一服**).

**Lycium Root Decoction** (枸杞汤), for treating **emptiness and fatigue** (虚劳), **bitter and thirsty mouth** (口中苦渴), and **restless or cold joints** (骨节烦热或寒):
**Lycium root** (枸杞根) **5 shāng**, **peeled** (白皮切)
**Ophiopogon root** (麦门冬) **3 shāng**
**Young wheat** (小麦) **2 shāng**

The **three herbs** (右三味) are decocted in **2 dòu of water**, until the wheat is cooked and the herbs are ready. Strain and take **1 shāng per dose**, **twice daily**.

**Ba Province Governor’s Three-Huang Round Pills** (巴郡太守奏三黄圆), for treating **male Five Fatigues and Seven Injuries** (男子五劳七伤), **Xiaoke (消渴)**, **failure to develop muscle** (不生肌肉), **female leukorrhea** (妇人带下), and **alternating hot and cold hands and feet** (手足寒热):
**Spring (三月), Poria** (茯苓) **4 liǎng**, **large** (大)
**Rhubarb root** (大黄) **3 liǎng**
**Coptis rhizome** (黄连) **4 liǎng**

**Summer (三月), Poria** (茯苓) **6 liǎng**
**Rhubarb root** (大黄) **1 liǎng**
**Coptis rhizome** (黄连) **7 liǎng** (*One version states summer three months do not use this remedy*)

**Autumn (三月), Poria** (茯苓) **6 liǎng**
**Rhubarb root** (大黄) **2 liǎng**
**Coptis rhizome** (黄连) **3 liǎng**

**Winter (三月), Poria** (茯苓) **3 liǎng**
**Rhubarb root** (大黄) **5 liǎng**
**Coptis rhizome** (黄连) **2 liǎng**

The **three herbs** (右三味) are adjusted seasonally, ground, and mixed with honey to form pills the size of **large soybeans** (大豆). Take **five pills** with water, **three times daily**, gradually increasing to **seven pills** until symptoms subside (**取下而已**). After **one month of treatment**, the illness should be cured (**病愈**). Prolonged use may cause **exhaustion resembling a galloping horse** (走逐奔马), but testing confirms its efficacy (**常试有验**).

**Recipe for heat and thirst** (治热渴), **headache and severe heat** (头痛壮热), and **when women’s blood and vital energy surge upward** (血气上冲), causing **oppressive discomfort** (闷不堪):
Use **3 shāng of cut Imperata grass** (茅根切), pounded three times. Strain and drink the juice whenever thirsty (**渴即饮之**).

**Recipe for Lingnan Mountain Miasma** (治岭南山瘴), when **wind-heat toxic energy enters the kidneys** (风热毒气入肾中), causing **alternating cold and heat, weak legs, emptiness, fullness, and thirst** (变寒热脚弱，虚满而渴):
**Coptis rhizome** (黄连) **unlimited quantity** (不限多少)
**Fresh Trichosanthes root juice** (生栝蒌根汁)
**Fresh Rehmannia root juice** (生地黄汁)
**Sheep milk** (羊乳汁)

The **four substances** (右四味), mixed with the **three juices** (三汁) and **Coptis powder** (黄连末), are formed into pills the size of **Firmiana seeds** (梧子大). Take **thirty pills on an empty stomach**, gradually increasing to **forty pills**, **three times daily**. For severe cases, symptoms improve after **five days**; for mild cases, after **three days**. If **sheep milk is unavailable**, **cow milk or human milk** may be substituted. If the remedy is too bitter to take, **cook small wheat porridge** and drink it with the medicine (**煮小麦粥饮服之**), which is effective for **emptiness with heat** (主虚热). Zhang Wenzhong notes that this is also called **Sheep Milk Coptis Pills** (黄连丸, 一名羊乳丸).

**Donkey-Hide Gelatin Decoction** (阿胶汤), for treating **emptiness with heat** (虚热), **frequent and excessive urination** (小便利而多), **post-stone powder consumption leading to emptiness with heat** (服石散人虚热), **catching cold in the wind** (当风取冷), **leg edema** (患脚气), **preference for movement** (喜发动), and **Xiaoke with weak kidney meridians** (兼消渴肾脉细弱):

**Donkey-Hide Gelatin Decoction** (Donkey-Hide Gelatin Decoction: *Ājiāo Tāng*)

For treating **Xiaoke** (消渴, *Xiaoke*):

**Donkey-Hide Gelatin** (阿胶, *Ājiāo*) – 2 *tǐng*
**Sesame Seeds** (麻子, *Mázǐ*) – 1 *shēng*
**Prepared Aconite** (附子, *Fùzǐ*) – 1 piece
**Dried Ginger** (乾姜, *Gānjiāng*) – 2 *liǎng*
**Reishi Mushroom (or Far-Fetched Thought)** (远志, *Yuǎnzhì*) – 4 *liǎng*

Take the above five ingredients, **roughly chop** them, and decoct with **7 *shāng* of water**, reducing to **2.5 *shāng***. Remove the dregs, add the gelatin, and dissolve it. Divide into three doses for ingestion.

**Moxibustion Method for Xiaoke (消渴, *Xiaoke*)**:

The text states: **"In cases where urination is frequent and copious, with the patient passing tens of times daily up to a *dàn* (石, ~100 *shāng*) of urine, repeated moxibustion over five days is beneficial."**

**Caution on Moxibustion for Chronic Xiaoke**:
"For those afflicted with **Xiaoke** for over **one hundred days**, moxibustion is forbidden. If applied, **pus will continuously drain from the wound**, leading to **abscesses and emaciation**, ultimately resulting in death. **Misapplication or injury is also taboo**; even if only a needle-sized wound is made, the urine consumed will **transform into pus within the wound** and drain out. If the **pus does not cease**, death is certain. **Exercise extreme caution.**"

For **newly diagnosed cases**, moxibustion may be applied as per the following prescriptions:

If **throat dryness** (咽喉乾) is the primary symptom of **Xiaoke**, moxibustion is applied to **Stomach Meridian Convergence Point** (胃管下输, *Wèiguǎn Xiàshū*), **three acupuncture points** (三穴, *Sānxué*) each for **100 *zhuàng*** (壮), located **three *cùn* below the 8th vertebra**, horizontally spaced **three *cùn* apart**, with moxibustion applied at **one *cùn* intervals**.

Alternatively, **moxibustion may be applied to the Chest Center** (胸堂, *Xiōngtáng*) for **50 *zhuàng***, and to **Foot Taiyang** (足太阳, *Zú Tàiyáng*) for **50 *zhuàng*** (as noted in *Huángdì Jīng*).

If **mouth dryness is unbearable** (口乾不可忍), apply moxibustion to **Small Intestine Convergence Point** (小肠输, *Xiǎocháng Xiàshū*) for **100 *zhuàng***, horizontally spaced **three *cùn* apart**, at **one *cùn* intervals**.

If **mouth dryness causes irritability and suffocation** (口乾烦闷), apply moxibustion to **Foot Jueyin** (足厥阴, *Zú Juéyīn*) for **100 *zhuàng***, and to **Yang Pool** (阳池, *Yángchí*) for **50 *zhuàng***.

If **Xiaoke presents with coughing and retching** (咳逆), apply moxibustion to **Hand Jueyin** (手厥阴, *Shǒu Juéyīn*) for **100 *zhuàng*** (adjusted by age).

If **urination is frequent** (小便数), apply moxibustion to **both hands’ little fingers** (两手小指头) and **both feet’s little toes** (足两小趾头), as well as the **nape of the neck and cervical vertebrae** (并灸项椎, *Bìng jiū yǐngzhuī*). **Moxibustion at the central spine** (当脊梁中央解间一处) and **two points on the waist** (腰目上两处) is also recommended—**three points in total**.

Additionally, apply moxibustion to **Spleen Convergence Point** (脾输, *Pí Xiàshū*), **four *cùn* below the back**, near the **lumbar vertebrae** (侠脊梁, *Xià jǐliáng*), **two points total**.

All moxibustion treatments should be **adjusted according to the patient’s age** (随年壮).

Further, apply moxibustion to **two points on Kidney Convergence** (肾输, *Shèn Xiàshū*), and to **Waist Mark** (腰目, *Yāomiù*), located **three *cùn* below Kidney Convergence**, **one *cùn* and a half** on either side of the **lumbar spine** (侠脊骨两傍各一寸半). These points are **located by pressing with the fingers**.

Apply moxibustion to **one point at Guanyuan** (关元, *Guānyuán*), and **two points** on either side, **two *cùn* apart**.

Apply moxibustion to **two points at Yin Market** (阴市, *Yīnshì*), located **three *cùn* above the kneecap** (膝上当伏兔上行三寸), near the knee.

Alternatively, **arrange three or two points in a row**, spaced **one *cùn* apart**, known as **Kidney System** (肾系, *Shènxì*).

The **Taixi** (太溪, *Tàixī*), **Zhongfeng** (中封, *Zhōngfēng*), **Ranggu** (然谷, *Rángǔ*), **Tai Bai** (太白, *Tàibái*), **Dadu** (大都, *Dàdōu*), **Fuyang** (趺阳, *Fùyáng*), **Xingjian** (行间, *Xíngjiān*), **Dadun** (大敦, *Dàdūn*), **Yinbai** (隐白, *Yǐnbái*), and **Yongquan** (涌泉, *Yǒngquán*) acupuncture points are **all effective for stopping urination** (断小便最佳), without **depleting Yang Qi** (不损阳气), and also **for treating urinary incontinence** (亦云止遗溺也). Apply **100 *zhuàng*** to each of these points.

**Total of 47 points** (腹背两脚凡四十七处) on the **abdomen, back, and both legs**—specifically, **Kidney Convergence** (肾输), **Waist Mark** (腰目), **Guanyuan** (关元), and **Water Channel** (水道)—may receive **moxibustion of 30 *zhuàng*** each, **once every five days**, totaling **150 *zhuàng*** per point.

**Yongquan** (涌泉) may be treated with **10 *zhuàng***.

**Dadun** (大敦), **Yinbai** (隐白), and **Xingjian** (行间) may be treated with **3 *zhuàng*** each.

All remaining points should receive **7 *zhuàng*** each, applied **once every five days**. **Three sessions suffice** (满三灸可止也).

If **symptoms worsen** (若发), and moxibustion on **Yin points** (诸阴) fails to improve the condition, apply moxibustion to **Yang points** (诸阳) instead. **Yang points are located on the outer surfaces of the legs**; apply moxibustion to **Lung Convergence** (肺输, *Fèi Xiàshū*) and **Lung Mu** (募, *Mù*), following the **acupuncture points along the Lung Meridian’s flow** (按流注孔穴), with **moxibustion intensity adjusted as per Yin points** (壮数如灸阴家法).

For **frequent but scanty and difficult urination**, where **straining causes seminal leakage** (用力辄失精), instruct the patient to **extend both hands**, **clasp them together**, and **align the thumbs**. Forcefully press until the **nails of both thumbs nearly touch**, then apply **moxibustion at the junction of the nail beds and flesh** (两爪甲本肉际), where a natural **ridge** (角) forms. Position the **moxa cone at the ridge**, allowing it to **slightly penetrate the nail surface**. **One cone is used for both thumbs**.

Alternatively, apply **moxibustion to the big toe** (脚大指) using the same method, **three cones total**. Repeat the treatment **after three days**.

*(From *Sun Zhēnrén Bèijí Qiān Jīn Yào Fāng*, Volume 63, Prescription #1 for Xiaoke; Volume 64, as cross-referenced by the Song-era officials Lin Yì et al.)*

**Prescriptions for Dysuria and Retention of Urine (Línbì Fāng) – Second Treatise on Dysuria**
**Symptoms, Prescriptions, and Moxibustion Methods**

The Treatise states:
When **heat** (熱) accumulates in the **middle burner** (中焦), it causes **hardness** (堅); when **heat** accumulates in the **lower burner** (下焦), it causes **dysuria with blood** (溺血), leading to **dysuria and retention** (淋閉不通). This often occurs in **depleted** (虛损) individuals who consume **large doses of medicinal decoctions** (大散), resulting in **extraneous heat** (客熱) in the lower burner.

There are also cases where the lower burner naturally harbors **heat** (熱), though it is usually mild and can be discerned through careful observation.

**Dysuria due to stagnant *qi*** (氣淋) manifests as **difficult and scanty urination** (溺難涩), with lingering drips (余沥).
**Dysuria from urinary stones** (石淋) presents with **pain in the urethra** (茎中痛), unable to fully void urine (溺不得卒出).
**Dysuria with sticky urine** (膏淋) shows urine resembling **pitch or resin** (膏), which passes spontaneously (自出).
**Dysuria from exertion** (勞淋) arises upon **fatigue or strain** (勞倦), with **pain radiating to the perineum** (氣冲下).
**Dysuria from heat** (熱淋) occurs with **heat** (熱), and in severe cases, **hematuria** (尿血) ensues. All such cases are treated similarly to **dysuria from stagnant *qi*** (氣淋).

If one observes **yellowish nasal tip** (鼻頭色黃), it indicates **difficult urination** (小便難).

**Dìfūzǐ Decoction** (地肤子汤) treats **lower burner heat accumulation** (下焦結熱), manifesting as **reddish-yellow, obstructed urine** (小便赤黃不利), **frequent but scanty urination** (数起出少), **urethral pain** (茎痛), or **blood in urine** (或血出). It is also used for **residual heat after febrile illness** (温病后余热), **post-dysentery heat retention** (霍乱后当风取热), **excessive alcohol consumption or sexual overindulgence** (过度饮酒房劳), **exposure to heat while walking** (行步冒热), or **dysuria from heat accumulation** (以饮逐热). This decoction also resolves **lower burner heat obstruction** (熱結下焦), **stone-induced urinary stasis** (散石熱動關格), **lower abdominal hardness** (小腹堅), and **distended bladder resembling a bowl** (胞胀如斗). For all types of dysuria listed, the following **reliable prescription** (立验方) is given:

**Dìfūzǐ** (地肤子) – 3 oz
**Zhīmǔ** (知母) – 3 oz
**Huángqín** (黄苓) – 3 oz
**Fúlíng** (茯苓) – 3 oz
**Qúmài** (瞿麦) – 3 oz
**Jīshí** (枳实, *alternatively* **Sōngshí** – 松实) – 3 oz
**Shēngmá** (升麻) – 3 oz
**Tōngcǎo** (通草) – 3 oz
**Kuízi** (葵子) – 3 oz
**Hǎizǎo** (海藻) – 3 oz

Total: **ten herbs** (十味). **Crude-cut** (□咀), decoct with **water, 1 *dòu*** (斗, ~16 cups), and reduce to **3 *shēng*** (升, ~3 cups). Divide into **three doses** (分三服).

If both **urination and defecation are obstructed** (大小便皆閉), add **Dàyuán** (大黄) – 3 oz.
For women suffering from **sexual overindulgence** (房劳) with **kidney heat** (肾中有热), **difficult and obstructed urination** (小便难不利), **lower abdominal distension and pain** (小腹满痛), and **deep, fine pulse** (脉沉细), add **one pig kidney** (猪肾一具).
*The Chuài Shì* (崔氏) states: If adding kidney, use **1.5 *dòu* of water** (水一斗半). First decoct the kidney, extract **1 *dòu* of juice** (取一斗汁), then add the remaining herbs and decoct.
*The Xiǎopǐn Fāng* (小品方) omits **Jīshí** (枳实).

To treat **all types of dysuria** (百种淋), including **cold dysuria** (寒淋), **heat dysuria** (热淋), **exertional dysuria** (劳淋), **difficult urination** (小便涩), **bladder distension** (胞中满), and **lower abdominal urgency and pain** (腹急痛), use:

**Tōngcǎo** (通草) – 3 oz
**Shíwéi** (石韦) – 3 oz
**Gāncǎo** (甘草) – 3 oz
**Wángbùliúxíng** (王不留行) – 3 oz
**Dōngkuízi** (冬葵子) – 3 oz
**Huáshí** (滑石) – 3 oz
**Qúmài** (瞿麦) – 3 oz
**Báizhǔ** (白朮) – 3 oz
**Sháo yào** (芍药) – 3 oz

Total: **nine herbs** (九味). **Crude-cut**, decoct with **1 *dòu* of water** (~16 cups), reduce to **3 *shēng*** (~3 cups), and divide into **three doses** (分三服).

*The Gǔjīn Lùyàn* (古今录验) includes **Dāngguī** (当归) – 2 oz, for **lower burner heat** (下筛), taken with **wheat gruel** (麦粥) as a **cleansing dose** (清服), **1 *fāngcùn* spoonful** (方寸匕) daily, **three times** (日三).

Another prescription:
**Huáshí** (滑石) – 3 oz
**Shíwéi** (石韦) – 3 oz
**Guólóu root** (栝蒌根) – 3 oz

Total: **three herbs**. Treat **lower burner heat** (下筛) by taking with **barley water** (大麦饮), **1 *fāngcùn* spoonful** (方寸匕) daily, **three times** (日三).

To treat **all types of dysuria** (诸种淋), use:

**Kuí root** (葵根) – 8 oz
**Máo root** (茆根) – 3 oz
**Shíshǒu yú headstone** (石首鱼头石) – 3 oz
**Gāncǎo** (甘草) – 1 oz
**Tōngcǎo** (通草) – 2 oz
**Bèizi** (贝子) – 5 *hé* (合, ~5 oz)
**Tiān má root** (天麻根) – 5 oz

Total: **seven herbs**. **Crude-cut**, decoct with **1.2 *dòu* of water** (~19.2 cups), reduce to **5 *shēng*** (~5 cups), and divide into **five daytime doses** (分五服) and **two nighttime doses** (日三夜二). This also treats **stone dysuria** (石淋).

Another prescription:
**Yú pí** (榆皮) – 1 lb
**Chēqiánzǐ** (车前子) – 1 *shēng* (~1 cup)
**Dōngguāzǐ** (冬瓜子) – 1 *shēng*
**Lǐyú chǐ** (鲤鱼齿) – 2 oz
**Táojiāo** (桃胶) – 2 oz
**Tōngcǎo** (通草) – 2 oz
**Dìmài** (地脉) – 2 oz
**Qúmài** (瞿麦) – 4 oz

Total: **eight herbs**. **Crude-cut**, decoct with **1 *dòu* of water** (~16 cups), reduce to **3 *shēng*** (~3 cups), and divide into **three doses** (分三服) daily, **three times** (日三).

Another prescription:
**Fine white sand** (细白沙) – 3 *shēng* (~3 cups), parched until **intensely hot** (极热), then strained with **3 *shēng* of wine** (酒三升), taking **1 *hé* spoonful** (一合) per dose.

To treat **dysuria pain** (淋痛), use:
**Huáshí** (滑石) – 4 oz
**Bèizi** (贝子) – 7 *mǔ* (牧, ~7 oz), **burnt and pulverized** (烧碎)
**Fúlíng** (茯苓) – 2 oz
**Báizhǔ** (白朮) – 2 oz
**Tōngcǎo** (通草) – 2 oz
**Sháo yào** (芍药) – 2 oz

Total: **six herbs**. Treat **lower burner heat** (下筛) by taking with **wine** (酒), **1 *fāngcùn* spoonful** (方寸匕) per dose, **twice daily** (日二服). Recovery occurs within **ten days** (十日瘥).

Another prescription:
**Kuízi** (葵子) – 5 *hé* (~5 oz)
**Fúlíng** (茯苓) – 2 oz
**Bái mù** (白木, *likely* **Bái zhú** – 白术) – 2 oz
**Dāngguī** (当归) – 2 oz

Total: **four herbs**. **Crude-cut**, decoct with **7 *shēng* of water** (~7 cups), reduce to **2 *shēng*** (~2 cups), and divide into **three doses** (分三服) daily, **three times** (日三).

Another prescription:
**Pig fat** (猪脂) taken with **3 *hé* spoonfuls of wine** (酒服三合) daily, **three times** (日三). For children, **1 *hé* spoonful** (一合) per dose, preferably in **the twelfth lunar month** (腊月者).

To treat **obstructed urination** (小便不利), **urethral pain** (茎中疼痛), and **lower abdominal urgency and pain** (小腹急痛), use:
**Tōngcǎo** (通草) – 3 oz
**Fúlíng** (茯苓) – 3 oz
**Tínglì** (葶苈) – 2 oz

Total: **three herbs**. Treat **lower burner heat** (下筛) by taking with **water** (水), **1 *fāngcùn* spoonful** (方寸匕) per dose, **three times daily** (日三).

Another prescription:
**Púhuáng** (蒲黄) – equal parts
**Huáshí** (滑石) – equal parts

Total: **two herbs**. Treat **lower burner heat** (下筛) by taking with **wine** (酒), **1 *fāngcùn* spoonful** (方寸匕) per dose, **three times daily** (日三).

To treat **obstructed urination** (小便不通), use:
**Water chestnut leaves** (水上浮萍) dried under sun, **ground into powder** (为末), taking **1 *fāngcùn* spoonful** (方寸匕) per dose, **three times daily** (日三).

To treat **obstructed urination** (小便不利), **bladder distension** (膀胱胀), and **water-*qi* edema** (水气流肿), use:
**Hézi** (葵子) – 1 oz
**Yú bái pí** (榆白皮) – 1 oz
**Huáshí** (滑石) – 3 oz

Total: **three herbs**. Treat **lower burner heat** (下筛) by decocting **sesame seed juice** (麻子汁) to **1.5 *shēng*** (~1.5 cups), reducing to **1 *shēng*** (~1 cup), and mixing with **2 *fāngcùn* spoonfuls of powder** (散二方寸匕), divided into **three doses** (分三服). Urination will **immediately pass** (即通).

Another prescription:
**4 *shēng* of water** (~4 cups) used to wash **rice** (洗饭), extract the **rice water** (带取汁), then decoct **Hézi** (葵子) to obtain **2.5 *shēng*** (~2.5 cups), divided into **three doses** (分三服).

Another prescription:
**Húyàn shǐ** (胡燕屎) and **chǐ** (豉) – each **1 *hé* spoonful** (~1 oz), **pounded and mixed** (和捣), formed into **pills the size of *wú* seeds** (丸如梧子), taking **three pills** (三丸) per dose, **three times daily** (日三).

Another prescription:
**Hair ashes** (发去垢烧末) and **Hézi** (葵子) – each **1 *shēng*** (~1 cup), taken with **wine** (饮), **1 *fāngcùn* spoonful** (方寸匕) per dose, **three times daily** (日三).

Another prescription:
**Shíshǒu yú headstone** (石首鱼头石), **ground into powder** (为末), taken with **water** (水), **1 *fāngcùn* spoonful** (方寸匕) per dose, **three times daily** (日三).

Another prescription:
**Stone pit ashes** (石槽塞灰土), taken with **water from a well’s surface scum** (井华水), **1 *fāngcùn* spoonful** (服) per dose, **three times daily** (日三).

Another prescription:
**Lǐyú chǐ ashes** (鲤鱼齿烧灰末), taken with **wine** (酒), **1 *fāngcùn* spoonful** (方寸匕) per dose, **three times daily** (日三).

Another prescription:
**Chēqiánzǐ powder** (车前子末), **1 *fāngcùn* spoonful** (方寸匕) per dose, **three times daily** (日三), taken for **a hundred days** (服百日止).

To treat **sudden urinary obstruction** (卒不得小便), swallow **raw chicken egg whites** (吞鸡子白) until relief is achieved (取瘥).

「Ge Shi further states: Swallow **yellow** (黄).

Another prescription:
**One handful of *chēqiáncǎo* (车前草)**, **half *liǎng* of *sāngbáipí* (桑白皮)**. These two ingredients, **coarsely chopped** (□咀), are decocted with **three *shāng* of water** (水三升), reduced to **one *shāng***, and taken all at once (顿服之).
To treat **sudden urinary obstruction in women** (治妇人卒不得小便):
**Forty-nine *xiàngrén* (杏仁)**, roasted and ground into powder (熬末), taken to induce immediate urination (服之立下).

Another prescription:
**Powdered *zǐwǎn* (紫菀)**, taken with **well-surface scum water** (井华水) in a **three-finger pinch** (三指撮), to induce immediate relief (立通). If **blood appears** (血出者), take it **four or five times** (四五度服之).

To treat **post-jaundice urinary dribbling** (治黄疸后小便淋沥):
**One pig kidney** (猪肾一具), sliced
**One *jīn* of *fúlíng* (茯苓)**
**Six *liǎng* of *qúmài* (瞿麦)**
**Chopped *chēqián* roots** (车前根切), **two *dòu*#7
**Three *liǎng* of *huángqín* (黄苓)**
**Three *hé* of *jiāomù* (椒目)**, wrapped in cloth (绵裹)
**Four *liǎng* each of *zéxiè* (泽泻) and *dìfūzǐ* (地肤子)**
These eight ingredients, **coarsely chopped** (□咀), are decocted with **two *dòu* of water** (水二斗). First, boil the *chēqián*, reducing to **one *dòu* six *shāng* (一斗六升)**, then remove the dregs (去滓) and add the pig kidney (下猪肾), decocting to **one *dòu* three *shāng* (一斗三升)**. Remove the kidney (去肾), add the remaining herbs (下药), and reduce to **three *shāng* (三升)**, to be taken in **three divided doses** (分三服).

To treat **qi-related urinary difficulty** (治气淋):
Decoct **three *shāng* of water** (水三升) with **ship-bottom algae** (船底苔) the size of a **duck’s egg** (如鸭子大), reducing to **two *shāng***, and taken all at once (顿服).

Another prescription:
Decoct **one *shāng* of *dòu* (豉)** in **three *shāng* of water** (水三升). After boiling once, remove the dregs (一沸去滓), and add **one *hé* of *língzhī* (灵芝)**, taken all at once (内灵一合，顿服). Alternatively, **soup of *dòu* alone** (亦可单煮豉汁服之) may be taken.

Another prescription:
Decoct **three *bǎi* of *bǐlúnqián* (比轮钱)** in **one *dòu* of water** (水一斗), reducing to **three *shāng***, and taken warm (温服之).

Another prescription:
**Powdered *kuízi* (葵子)**, taken with **hot water** (汤服) in a **one-*fāngcùn* spoonful** (方寸匕).

Another prescription:
**Eat an empty stomachful of *shùkuí* (蜀葵)** (空腹单茹蜀葵一满口).

Another prescription:
**Roast and apply warm *guàn* (盥)** to the lower abdomen (熬盥热熨小腹), replacing when cooled (冷复易). This also treats **urinary blood** (亦治小便血).
*—From *Zhǒuhòu Fāng* (《肘后方》), treating urinary obstruction (治小便不通).*
**Moxibustion method (灸法):**
Apply **moxa to the navel** (脐中着盥), **three *zhuàng*** (灸三壮).
Ge Shi states: To treat urinary obstruction (治小便不通), **moxibustion at *guānyuán* (关元)** for **fifty *zhuàng*** (灸五十壮). Also, **moxibustion at points one-and-a-half *cùn* apart from *yùyuán* (玉泉)** for **thirty *zhuàng*** (灸侠玉泉相去一寸半三十壮).

To treat **stone-related urinary difficulty** (治石淋):
Use **two *shāng* of *chēqiánzǐ* (车前子)**, wrapped in silk (绢袋盛), decocted in **nine *shāng* of water** (水九升), reduced to **three *shāng***. The patient must **fast overnight** (先经宿不得食) and take it **on an empty stomach at dawn** (平旦空腹顿服之), and the stone will pass. *—*The *Bèijí Fāng* (《备急方》) states this treats **heat-related urinary difficulty** (治热淋).

Another prescription:
Take **floating stone** (浮石) to fill **one hand’s measure** (满一手许), **sift through a sieve** (治下筛), decoct with **three *shāng* of water** (水三升) and **one *shāng* of vinegar** (酢一升), reducing to **two *shāng***. After straining (澄清), take **one *shāng***, and the stone will pass within **no more than three doses** (不过三服). It also treats **cough** (亦治嗽) if decocted in **undiluted alcohol** (淳酒煮之).

Another prescription:
**A piece of *táojiāo* (桃胶)** the size of a **date** (枣许大), mixed with **three *hé* of cold water in summer** (夏以冷水三合) or **three *hé* of hot water in winter** (冬以汤三合), taken three times daily (和服，日三). The stones will pass like **beans or eggs** (当下石子如豆卵), and treatment stops once they are fully expelled (石尽止).

Also treats **urinary bleeding** (亦治小便出血).

**Moxibustion method:**
For **stone-related urinary difficulty** (石淋) and **36 ailments below the navel** (脐下三十六种病), where **urination is obstructed** (不得小便), moxibustion at **Guān Yuán** (关元) for **30 sessions** (三十壮).

Another method: Moxibustion at **Qì Mén** (气门) for **30 sessions** (三十壮).
Another method: Moxibustion at **Shuǐ Quán** (水泉) for **30 sessions** (三十壮)—this is the **Great Toe’s Mound** (足大敦).

**Prescription for greasy urinary difficulty** (治膏淋方):
Take **Lǚ Grass** (律草) juice **three *shāng*** (二升), mix with **two *hé* of vinegar** (酢二合), and take on an empty stomach (空腹顿服之). Urine will appear like **mung bean juice** (当尿如小豆汁也).

Alternatively, take the **concentrated decoction** (浓煮汁) as a drink—this also treats **urinary dribbling** (亦治淋沥).
**Sū Chéng** (苏澄) uses this to cure **urinary bleeding** (疗尿血).

**Prescription for Five Fatigues and Seven Injuries** (治五劳七伤), **Eight Winds and Twelve Bi Syndromes** (八风十二痹), where **Fatigue congeals into blood-related urinary difficulty** (劳结为血淋) and **Heat congeals into flesh-related urinary difficulty** (热结为肉淋), with **urinary obstruction** (小便不通), **pain in the urethra and lower abdomen** (茎中及小腹痛), and **intolerable suffering** (不可忍):
**Slippery Stone** (滑石) **Cinnamon Twig** (桂心) **Winter Hollyhock Flower** (冬葵子) **Morning Glory Seed** (王不留行) **Common Reed** (通草) **Plantain Seed** (车前子) each **two *fèn*** (二分)
**Sweet Canonical Atractylodes** (甘遂) **one *fèn*** (一分)
**Rocky Pteris** (石韦) **four *fèn*** (四分)
Take these **eight herbs** (右八味), sift through a sieve (治下筛), and mix with **five *hé* of sesame seed tea** (麻子饮五合). Take **one *fāngcùn* spoonful** (方寸匕) three times daily (日三). **Sand and stones will be expelled in urine** (尿沙石出).

One variation adds **Pale Poplar Bark** (榆白皮) **three *fèn*** (三分).

**Moxibustion method:**
For **Fatigue-related urinary difficulty** (劳淋), apply moxibustion at **Foot Taiyin** (足太阴) for **100 sessions** (百壮)—located **three *cùn* above the inner ankle** (内踝上三寸), repeated **three times** (三报之).

**Prescription for heat-related urinary difficulty** (治热淋方):
**Large Dates** (大枣) **27 pieces** (二七枚)
**Hollyhock Root** (葵根) cut, **one *shāng*** (一升)—use **seeds in winter** (冬用子), **sprouts in summer** (夏用苗)
Take these **two herbs** (右二味), decoct with **three *shāng* of water** (以水三升), reducing to **one *shāng* and two *hé*** (煮取一升二合), and divide into **two doses** (分二服).

For **heat**, add **Scutellaria Root** (黄苓) **one *liǎng*** (一两).
For **difficulty in urination**, add **Slippery Stone** (滑石) **two *liǎng* powdered** (二两末).
For **blood in urine**, add **Madder Root** (茜根) **three *liǎng***.
For **pain**, add **White Peony Root** (芍药) **two *liǎng***.
When adding herbs, also add **water accordingly** (加药，亦加水也).

Another prescription:
Take **White Grass Root** (白茆根) cut, **four *jīn*** (四斤), decoct with **one *dòu* and five *shāng* of water** (以水一斗五升), reducing to **five *shāng*** (煮取五升). Take **one *shāng*** (一升) three times daily (日三) and twice at night (夜二).

Another prescription:
Habitually decoct **Winter Hollyhock Root** (冬葵根) and take as a drink (常煮冬葵根作饮服之).

**Prescription for blood-related urinary difficulty** (治血淋), where **urine is scanty and painful** (小便碜痛):
**Perilla Stem** (鸡苏二两) **Common Reed** (通草) **Slippery Stone** (滑石) each **five *liǎng*** (五两)
**Bamboo Leaf** (竹叶) **one handful** (一把)
**Fresh Rehmannia Root** (生地黄) **half *jīn*** (半斤)
**Small Burnet Root** (小蓟根) **one *liǎng*** (一两)
Take these **six herbs** (右六味), **□** (caustic-fried), decoct with **nine *shāng* of water** (以水九升), reducing to **three *shāng*** (煎取三升), strain, and divide into **three doses** (去滓, 分三服), taken warm (温服).

**Rocky Pteris Powder** (石韦散), **prescription for blood-related urinary difficulty** (治血淋方):
**Rocky Pteris** (石韦) **Chinese Angelica Root** (当归) **Catkin** (蒲黄) **White Peony Root** (芍药)
Take these **four herbs** (右四味) in **equal portions** (各等分), sift through a sieve (治下筛).
Take with **alcohol** (酒服), **one *fāngcùn* spoonful** (方寸匕), three times daily (日三).

Another prescription:
Decoct **ten fresh hemp roots** (生大麻根十枚) with **five *shāng* of water** (以水五升), reducing to **two *shāng*** (取二升), and take all at once (顿服).

**Also for treating urinary bleeding:**

Another prescription: Decoct **one handful of broad bean leaves** (大豆叶一把) with **four *shāng* of water** (以水四升), reducing to **two *shāng*** (取二升), and take all at once (顿服).

Another prescription: Decoct **one *shāng* of hydrangea seeds** (葵子一升), extracting the juice (取汁), and take **three times daily** (日三服).

**Also for treating hematuria due to exhaustion (虚劳尿血):**
**Moxibustion method (灸法):**
For **blood-related urinary difficulty (血淋)**, apply moxibustion to **Dan Tian** (丹田) according to age and vitality (随年壮).

For **retained urinary difficulty (伏留#8)**, apply moxibustion **fifty times** (五十壮), or as per age and vitality (一云随年壮).

For **five types of urinary difficulty (五淋)** where urination is impossible, apply moxibustion to **Suspended Spring (悬泉)** **fourteen times** (十四壮). The acupoint lies **one *cùn* forward from the inner ankle**, along the small vein, also known as **Middle Seal (中封)**.

For **five types of urinary difficulty (五淋)**, apply moxibustion to **Great Metropolis (大敦)** **thirty times** (三十壮).

For **sudden urinary difficulty (卒淋)**, apply moxibustion to the **tip of the outer ankle** (外踝尖) **seven times** (七壮).

For **urinary difficulty (淋病)** and its **nine categories of ailments (九部诸疾)**, apply moxibustion to **Foot Taiyang** (足太阳) **fifty times** (五十壮).

For **urinary difficulty (淋病)** where urination is impossible and there is **pain above the genitals (阴上#9)**, apply moxibustion to **Foot Taichong** (足太冲) **fifty times** (五十壮).

For **abdominal fullness** and **frequent urges to urinate**, apply moxibustion to the point **one *cùn* below Jade Spring (玉泉)**, named **Urinary Bladder (尿胞)** or **Flexed Bone End (屈骨端)**, **forty-nine times** (二七壮). For children, reduce accordingly (小儿以意减之).

**Prescription for enuresis and urinary difficulty (治遗尿，小便涩方):**
**Oyster Shell (牡蛎)** **Deer Antler Velvet (鹿茸)** each **four *liǎng*** (各四两)
**Mulberry Ear Fungus (桑耳)** **three *liǎng*** (三两) [*Note: Some omit this in *Ancient and Modern Records of Verified Prescriptions (古今录验)***]
**Donkey-Hide Gelatin (阿胶)** **two *liǎng*** (二两)

Take these **four herbs** (右四味), **□** (caustic-fried), decoct with **seven *shāng* of water** (以水七升), reducing to **two *shāng*** (取二升). Divide into **two doses** (分二服), taken **twice daily** (日二).

Another prescription:
**Stephania Root (防己)** **Hydrangea Seed (葵子)** **Silkworm Chaff (防风)** each **two *liǎng*** (各二两)

Take these **three herbs** (右三味), **□** (caustic-fried), decoct with **five *shāng* of water** (以水五升), reducing to **two and a half *shāng*** (取二升半), and divide into **three doses** (分三服). Powdered form is also effective (散服亦佳).

**Prescription for urinary incontinence (治小便失禁方):**
Decoct **chicken intestines** (鸡肠) with **three *shāng* of water** (以水三升), reducing to **one *shāng*** (取一升), and divide into **three doses** (分三服).

**Prescription for incontinence without awareness (治失禁出不自觉方):**
Mix **soybean paste juice (豆酱汁)** with **stove ash (灶突墨)** into a bean-sized pellet (如豆大), and insert into the **urinary orifice (尿孔中)**. [*Note: *Fan Wang’s text (范汪)* states this also treats **uterine inversion (胞转)** and is suitable for children (亦治小儿)***].

---
**Prescription for bedwetting (治尿床方):**
Fill a **sheep’s stomach (羊肚)** with water until full, tie the ends with string (线缚两头), boil until cooked (熟煮), then open and consume the water all at once (顿服), with immediate cure (立瘥).

Another prescription:
Burn **one chicken’s gizzard and intestines (鸡肶胵一具并肠)** to ash (烧末), and take with **alcohol** (酒服), distinguishing male from female (男雌女雄).

Another prescription:
Fill a **sheep’s bladder (羊胞)** with water until full, then burn it completely over **charcoal fire (炭火)**. Consume the **flesh (肉)** on an empty stomach (空腹食), with cure achieved in **four or five doses** (不过四五度瘥).

Another prescription:
Mix **one bowl of freshly cooked hot rice (新炊热饭一盏)** with the **bedwetting area (泻尿床处)**, and feed it to the patient without their knowledge (拌与食之，勿令知). This is effective (良).

---
**Moxibustion method (灸法):**
For **enuresis and incontinence without awareness (遗尿失禁，出不自知)**, apply moxibustion to **Yin Lingquan (阴陵泉)** according to age and vitality (随年壮).

For **enuresis (遗尿)**, apply moxibustion to **遗道** (located **five *cùn* beside Jade Spring (侠玉泉)**), and also to **Yang Lingquan (阳陵泉)** and **Foot Yangming (足阳明)**, each according to age and vitality (各随年壮).

For **urinary incontinence (小便失禁)**, apply moxibustion to **Great Metropolis (大敦)** **seven times** (七壮), and also to **Xingjian (行间)** **seven times** (七壮).

For **bedwetting (尿床)**, hang the patient’s **two hands** over their **two flanks (两脏上)**, and apply moxibustion to the **depressed points on the fingertips (尽指头上有陷处)** **seven times** (七壮).

Another method: Apply moxibustion to the **horizontal line below the navel (脐下横纹)** **seven times** (七壮).

**Third prescription for hematuria (尿血第三方):**

**Prescription for urinary bleeding due to sexual exhaustion (治房劳伤中尿血方):**
**Oyster Shell (牡蛎)** **Cinnamon Heart (桂心)** **Scutellaria Root (黄苓)** **Plantain Seed (车前子)** each in **equal portions** (各等分)

Take these **four herbs** (右四味), sift through a sieve (治下筛), and take with **drink** (以饮服), starting with **one *fāngcùn* spoonful** (方寸匕), gradually increasing to **two spoonfuls** (稍加至二匕), **three times daily** (日三服).

**Prescription for urinary blood (治小便血方):**
**Fresh Rehmannia Root (生地黄)** **eight *liǎng*** (八两)
**Cypress Leaf (柏叶)** **one handful** (一把)
**Scutellaria Root (黄苓)** **two *liǎng*** (二两)
**Donkey-Hide Gelatin (阿胶)** **two *liǎng*** (二两)

Take these **four herbs** (右四味), **□** (caustic-fried), decoct with **eight *shāng* of water** (以水八升), reducing to **three *shāng*** (取三升), strain, and dissolve **gelatin** (去滓下胶), dividing into **three doses** (分三服). One variation adds **two *liǎng* of Licorice Root (甘草)**.

Another prescription:
**Cuscuta Seed (菟丝子)** **Catkin (蒲黄)** **Angelica Dahurica Root (白芷)** **Coptis Root (刑实)** **Dried Rehmannia Root (乾地黄)** **Sour Jujube (酸枣)** [*Note: *Small Classics (小品)* writes **fermented soybean paste (败酱)***] **Ligusticum Root (芎藭)** **Hydrangea Seed (葵子)** **Chinese Angelica Root (当归)** **Poria (茯苓)** each in **equal portions** (各等分)

Grind into powder (为末), form into **mung bean-sized pills with honey (蜜丸如梧子)**, and take **five pills** (五丸) with **drink**, **three times daily** (日三), gradually increasing to **ten pills** (稍加至十丸).

Another prescription:
**Military Salt (戎盐)** **six *fēn*** (六分)
**Licorice Root (甘草)** **two *liǎng*** (二两)
**Catkin (蒲黄)** **two *liǎng*** (二两)
**Deer Antler Glue (鹿角胶)** **two *liǎng*** (二两)
**White Peony Root (芍药)** **two *liǎng*** (二两)
**Alum (矾石)** **three *liǎng*** (三两)
**Jujube (大枣)** **ten pieces** (十枚)

Take these **seven herbs** (右七味), **□** (caustic-fried), decoct with **nine *shāng* of water** (以水九升), reducing to **two *shāng*** (取二升), and divide into **three doses** (分三服).

Another prescription:
Grind **sesame seeds (胡麻)** into **three *shāng* of fine powder** (三升，捣细末), soak overnight in **two *shāng* of east-flowing water (东流水)** (渍一宿), strain after squeezing (绞去滓), and boil **twice** (煮两沸), taking all at once (顿服).

Another prescription:
Grind **Dragon Bone (龙骨)** into fine powder (为细末), and take with **warm water** (温水服) **one *fāngcùn* spoonful** (方寸匕), **five or six times daily** (日五六服). [*Note: Zhang Wenzhong recommends taking with **alcohol (酒服)***].

Another prescription:
Decoct **four *liǎng* of Sichuan Angelica Root (蜀当归)** with **three *shāng* of alcohol** (酒三升), reducing to **one *shāng*** (取一升), and take all at once (顿服).

Another prescription:
Extract juice from **pounded Chinese Wisteria Leaf (荆叶)**, and take with **alcohol** (酒服) **two *hé* measures** (二合).

Another prescription:
Decoct **Plantain Root, Leaf, and Seed (车前根、叶、子)**, and drink liberally (多饮佳).

Another prescription:
Take **burnt human hair ash (乱发灰)** with **alcohol** (酒服). [*Note: Su Cheng recommends taking with **water (水服)***].

Another prescription:
Take **hydrangea stem ash (葵茎灰)** with **alcohol** (酒服) **one *fāngcùn* spoonful** (方寸匕), **three times daily** (日三).

Another prescription:
Scrape **soapstone (滑石)** into powder (刮末), mix with **water (水和)**, and apply around the **lower abdomen and genital area (绕小腹及阴际)**. [*Note: Ge Shi states this also treats **urinary retention (小便不通)***].

Another prescription:
Decoct **two *shāng* of fermented soybean paste (豉)** with **four *shāng* of alcohol** (酒四升), reducing to **one *shāng*** (取一升), and take all at once (顿服).

**Discourse on Water Edema (Fourth Treatise) – Symptoms, Prescriptions, and Moxibustion**

**On the Condition:**
Water disease is difficult to treat. After recovery, one must be especially cautious with diet. Moreover, those afflicted with water often indulge excessively in food without restraint, which is why this illness is hard to cure.

Many physicians, following the trends of their time, prioritize profit over life, neglecting the fundamental nature of the disease. When patients desire meat, these doctors urge them to consume the most luxurious cuts—such as lamb’s head and shanks—yet none who follow this method have ever seen a cure.

In water edema, both *qi* and water are excessive across all vessels. Treatments universally seek to purge them, yet lamb’s head and shanks are profoundly nourishing—how could such a contradiction ever effect a cure?

Thus, most water treatments employ **Gua Lou (Trichosanthes) seeds** and similar herbs. The *Pen Ts’ao* (Materia Medica) states: *"Prolonged use of Gua Lou renders one severely debilitated."* Therefore, water edema cannot be cured unless the root cause is addressed through prolonged depletion.

There are two types: **snakebite edema (蛊胀)**, where only the abdomen is distended without swelling, and **water edema (水胀)**, where the abdomen swells and the limbs and face become grossly enlarged. Some physicians fail to distinguish properly—treating snakebite edema with water-purging drugs and water edema with snakebite remedies, or simply prescribing water-purging drugs for any distension. Such errors align with Zhang Zhongjing’s warning: *"Foolish physicians kill their patients."*

Now, the following are prohibited:

- **Forbidden Foods & Actions:**
  Mourning rituals
  Postpartum lactation
  Music
  Sexual activity
  Loud laughter and merrymaking
  All fish
  All meat
  All raw or cold foods
  Vinegar, slippery foods
  Garlic
  Sticky foods (rice, beans, oil, grease)

**All the above must be strictly avoided**, both in consumption and in mental indulgence. What is not prohibited will be detailed under each prescription.

Regarding sexual activity and similar matters, caution must be observed for **three years**, lest the condition recur permanently.

「If not treated properly, even after remission, the condition will relapse, and relapses cannot be cured further.

The ancient prescriptions include the *Ten-Water Pill* (十水丸), but most cases result in loose stools rather than improved urination, which is why it is not recorded here.

The Yellow Emperor asked Qibo: *"How can one distinguish between water edema (水), skin distension (肤胀), drum distension (鼓胀), intestinal obstruction (肠覃), and stone-like concretion (石瘕)?"*

Qibo replied: *"When water edema first appears, the eyes are slightly swollen—like the state after waking from a nap—(《灵枢》、《太素》 describe this as slight abscesses), the neck pulse is active, coughing occurs intermittently, the groin and inner thighs feel cold, the legs swell, and the abdomen remains enlarged. Once the water has fully formed, pressing the abdomen causes the skin to rise with the hand, like wrapping around water. This is its characteristic sign.

How does one diagnose skin distension (肤胀)?*
Skin distension occurs when cold *qi* (寒气) lodges between the skin and muscles, causing a firm, taut swelling (《太素》、《外台》 describe it as not firm). The abdomen is enlarged, the entire body swells, the skin thickens, and pressing the abdomen leaves a depression (《太素》 describes this as a sunken back that does not rebound), with no color change in the abdomen. These are its signs.

What about drum distension (鼓胀)?
Drum distension presents as an enlarged, swollen abdomen, similar in size to skin distension, but with a grayish-yellow hue. The abdominal pulse is prominent—this is its characteristic sign.

How does one recognize intestinal obstruction (肠覃)?
Intestinal obstruction arises when cold *qi* (寒气) lodges outside the intestines, clashing with the *Wei* *qi* (卫气) and impeding the flow of *Zheng* *qi* (正气). If there is an obstruction caused by some binding force, stagnant *qi* (恶气) will emerge, leading to polyp formation. Initially, these polyps resemble chicken eggs, gradually growing larger until they resemble a fetus in the womb. In chronic cases, they exceed a year in duration. When pressed, they feel firm, and when pushed, they shift. Menstrual flow may still occur, but irregularly—these are its signs.

What about stone-like concretion (石瘕)?
Stone-like concretion forms within the uterus, where cold *qi* (寒气) lodges at the *zi men* (子门, uterine opening), obstructing the flow of *qi* (气) and preventing stagnant blood from discharging. Instead, it accumulates, growing larger day by day until it resembles a fetus in the womb. Menstrual flow becomes irregular, and this condition occurs only in women. It can be induced to discharge through treatment.

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"Can skin distension (肤胀) and drum distension (鼓胀) be treated with acupuncture?"*
Qibo replied: *"First, drain the blood vessels in the abdomen, then regulate the meridians, and finally puncture the blood vessels to remove the obstruction."*

The Master said: *"There are also five types of water edema: wind water (风水), skin water (皮水), true water (正水), stone water (石水), and yellow sweating (黄汗).*
Wind water is characterized by a floating pulse, joint pain, and aversion to wind.

Skin water also presents with a floating pulse, but its external signs are superficial swelling. Pressing leaves a depression where the fingers sink in, and there is no aversion to wind. The abdomen remains unchanged (《要略》、《巢源》 describe it as neither full nor empty), and the patient should be induced to sweat.

True water is marked by a deep, slow pulse and spontaneous dyspnea.

Stone water has a deep pulse and abdominal fullness (《脉经》 describes this as pain), without dyspnea.

Yellow sweating exhibits a deep, rapid pulse, feverish body, chest fullness, and swelling of the limbs, face, and head. If untreated for long, it will inevitably lead to abscesses and pus formation. The patient feels heavy and swollen (some texts describe it as generalized edema with shortness of breath), unable to lie down, restless and irritable, with severe swelling in the groin.

Liver water manifests as a greatly distended abdomen, preventing the patient from turning or rolling. The lower abdomen and sides are painful, and saliva occasionally forms. Urination remains continuous, though scanty.

Spleen water presents as an enlarged abdomen with heavy limbs, no saliva formation, but persistent shortness of breath and difficulty in urination.

Lung water causes the body to swell with difficulty in urination, and intermittent frothy urine resembling duck droppings (鸭溏).

Kidney water results in an enlarged abdomen, umbilical swelling, and lumbar pain. The patient cannot urinate, with dampness in the groin like a cow’s nose, excessive sweating, and cold extremities. The face paradoxically becomes emaciated.

The Master said: *"In treating water edema, if swelling occurs below the waist, induce urination; if above the waist, induce sweating—this will restore the patient to health."*

The questioner asked: *"Why does a patient have diarrhea followed by excessive thirst, difficulty in urination, abdominal fullness, and swelling?"*

The Master replied: *"This indicates a water edema condition. If urination improves naturally or sweating occurs, the patient will recover (some texts say the condition will resolve by the end of the month).*

In general, the early signs of water edema include slight swelling above both eyes, resembling the color of an old silkworm, with neck pulse activity and coldness in the groin. The legs feel full, pressing leaves a depression, and the abdomen emits sounds when turned or rolled. These are its initial signs.

If not treated promptly, the body will soon swell slightly, and the abdomen will become uniformly distended. Pressing it causes the skin to rise with the hand, confirming the water has fully formed—but it can still be treated. Such conditions all stem from constitutional weakness.

There are ten types of water edema, but five are incurable:
1. Blackened lips (唇黑) harm the liver;
2. Flatness at the clavicle (缺盆平) harms the heart;
3. Umbilical protrusion (脐出) harms the spleen;
4. Flatness of the back (背平) harms the lungs;
5. Fullness below the feet (足下平满) harms the kidneys.

These five conditions are fatal and cannot be treated. In all cases of water edema, avoid abdominal swelling with external fluid discharge, as this is a grave sign—such patients will die within a month.

For *Black Round* (黑圆) edema of the gallbladder (胆玄水), swelling begins from the head and face down to the feet. The patient experiences dizziness and headache, general weakness, and fever. This is called *Black Water* (玄水), characterized by body swelling, constipation in both urination and defecation—this prescription is suitable. The formula appears in the fifth + eight volume.

For small intestine water edema, the lower abdomen is full, with sudden swelling and a bitter, dry mouth—use the following prescription:
Take 30 *Ba Dou* (巴豆, croton seeds), scrape off their skin, and crush them. Boil in five *sheng* (升) of water until reduced to three *sheng*, soak a cloth in the liquid, and wipe the swollen areas. The swelling will reduce with each application. Repeat five or six times daily, but avoid the eyes and genitals.

The *Ji Yan* (集验) text describes a remedy for sudden body swelling like being inflated: (formula omitted).

**Treatment for Large Intestine Water (alternating constipation and diarrhea):**
*Red Adzuki Beans (赤小豆), five sheng*
*Sang White Bark (桑白皮), sliced, two sheng*
*Crucian Carp (鲤鱼), four jin*
*White Atractylodes (白朮), eight liang*

Take the four ingredients, coarsely chop, and boil in three *dou* of water until the fish is thoroughly cooked. Do not add salt. Remove the fish and consume it entirely, then strain the broth to obtain about four *sheng*. Drink the decoction slowly.

**Alternative Prescription:**
*Mutton (羊肉), one jin, sliced*
*Dang Gui (当归), one sheng*

Take the two ingredients, boil in two *dou* of water. First, cook the *Dang Gui* until tender, then remove the dregs. Add the mutton along with scallions, fermented soybean paste, and vinegar, following the same method as the *Black Water* prescription.

*The [Zhouhou] [Canon] states:* Treatment for sudden swelling and distension, with the body and face appearing bloated.

**Treatment for Bladder Stone Water (emaciated limbs, abdominal swelling):**
*Sang White Bark (桑白皮), three sheng*
*Foxtail Millet Husks (谷白皮), three sheng*
*Dewberry Leaf (泽漆叶), three sheng*
*Yellow Soybeans (大豆), five sheng*
*Stephania (防己), four liang*
*Belamcanda (射干), four liang*
*White Atractylodes (白朮), four liang*

Take the seven ingredients, coarsely chop, and boil in one *dou* and five *sheng* of water, reducing to six *sheng*. Remove the dregs, then add three *sheng* of good wine, and boil again to five *sheng*. Take twice daily and once at night. Any remaining decoction should be consumed the following day.

*The [Collected Verified Prescriptions] omits Dewberry Leaf, Stephania, and Belamcanda, using only four ingredients.*

**Another prescription:**
*Sang White Bark (桑白皮), six liang*
*Belamcanda (射干), four liang*
*Scutellaria (黄苓), four liang*
*Poria (茯苓), four liang*
*White Atractylodes (白朮), four liang*
*Alisma (泽泻), three liang*
*Stephania (防己), two liang*
*Yellow Soybeans (大豆), three sheng*
*Dewberry Leaf (泽漆, cut), one sheng*

Take the nine ingredients, coarsely chop, and boil in five *dou* of water. First boil the Yellow Soybeans, reducing to three *dou*, then strain and clarify, taking one *dou* to decoct the remaining herbs, reducing to three *sheng*. Take on an empty stomach, divided into three doses.

**Treatment for Stomach Water (edema of the limbs, abdominal distension):**
*Pig Kidney (猪肾), one pair*
*Poria (茯苓), four liang*
*Stephania (防己), two liang*
*Tangerine Peel (橘皮), two liang*
*Scrophularia (玄参), two liang*
*Scutellaria (黄苓), two liang*
*Apricot Kernel (杏仁), two liang*
*Alisma (泽泻, or Dewberry Leaf 泽漆), two liang*
*Sang White Bark (桑白皮), two liang*
*Poria (猪苓), three liang*
*White Atractylodes (白术), three liang*
*Yellow Soybeans (大豆), three sheng*

Take the twelve ingredients, coarsely chop, and boil in one *dou* and eight *sheng* of water. First decoct the Pig Kidney, Yellow Soybeans, Alisma, and Sang White Bark, reducing to one *dou*, then clarify and remove dregs before adding the remaining herbs, reducing to three *sheng*. Take in three divided doses.

If coughing occurs, add *Schisandra (五味子), three liang*. Generally, take three doses, then one dose every five days. This prescription is consistently effective.

Many suffer from chronic dyspnea and persistent edema, with water accumulating beneath the skin, attacking the face and upper body from the waist up. All such cases can be treated with this decoction to induce sweating, ensuring complete recovery:

*Ephedra (麻黄), four liang*
*Licorice (甘草), two liang*

Take the two ingredients, coarsely chop, and boil in five *sheng* of water. First boil the Ephedra until it boils again, then skim off the foam, add Licorice, and reduce to three *sheng*. Take in three divided doses to induce sweating until cured. Be cautious of wind and cold.

**Treatment for Facial Swelling, Difficult Urination, and Abdominal Distension:**
*Poria (茯苓), eight fen*
*Apricot Kernel (杏仁), eight fen*

Grind the six ingredients into a powder, mix with honey to form pills the size of small beans. Take ten pills with Sang White Bark decoction, twice daily, increasing to thirty pills.

Cut two *sheng* of *Broussonetia Leaf (楮叶)*, boil in four *sheng* of water, reducing to three *sheng*. Strain and add rice to cook into porridge, eating as usual without interruption. In winter, dry the leaves in advance and prepare the porridge accordingly. This method ensures lasting relief, but avoid all raw and cold foods.

**Treatment for Severe Abdominal Ascites, Dyspnea, and Imminent Death:**

In the ninth year of Zhenguan (正观), the Prince of Hanyang suffered from water disease, which conventional medicine could not cure. I administered this prescription, and he urinated one to two *dou* daily, recovering within five to six days. After recovery, he occasionally relapsed but was otherwise cured. This is truly a divine prescription.

**Prescriptions from the *Chuai Shi* (崔氏)**

It says: *"Mix with honey and form into pills; serve with honey decoction."* For cases where a person suffers from **water edema** (水肿), with a distended abdomen as hard as stone, slender limbs, and where even slight exertion causes swelling of the feet and ankles, and where drinking or eating provokes **shortness of breath** (气急), this being a lifelong ailment—when conventional **diuretic and purgative** (利下) medicines fail to cure—this prescription should be administered. It will gradually eliminate **wind-dampness** (风湿), facilitate **urination** (小便), and disperse **water and grain dampness** (水谷). Taken over time, its efficacy will manifest. After recovery, one may take it regularly as a preventive measure:

**Ghost Arrow Herb** (鬼箭羽) **5 liang**
**Salvia Root** (丹参) **5 liang**
**Atractylodes** (白朮) **5 liang**
**Angelica Root** (独活) **5 liang**
**Sophora Root** (秦艽) **3 liang**
**Porcini Sclerotium** (猪苓) **3 liang**

**Kelp** (海藻) **2 liang**
**Poria** (茯苓) **2 liang**
**Cinnamon** (桂心) **2 liang**

Grind the above ten ingredients into a coarse powder. Soak in **3 dou of wine** (酒) for five days. Take **5 ge of the decoction** (五合), three times daily, gradually increasing the dosage according to one’s tolerance and strength.

For **water edema** (水肿), **urinary difficulty** (小便不利), **alcohol-induced heat** (酒客虚热), **wind-dampness consumption** (当风饮玲水), **abdominal distension** (腹肿), and **scrotal swelling** (阴胀满), the following prescription is effective:

**Daphne Genkwa** (芫花) **2 liang**
**Evodia Fruit** (吴茱萸) **2 liang**

Grind the above five ingredients into a powder, mix with honey to form pills the size of **Firmiana seeds** (梧子), and take three pills with water, three times daily.

Another variation includes:
**Rhubarb** (大黄) **2 liang**
**Daphne Genkwa** (荛花) **2 liang**
(omitting Evodia Fruit)

**Porcini Sclerotium** (猪苓) **1 liang**

For **persistent water edema** (久水), where the abdomen swells like a drum, use the **Black Soybean Powder** (大豆散):

**Black Soybeans** (乌豆) **1 dou**
Roast until fragrant, but do not overcook. Remove the skins and grind into a fine powder. Sift, and take with **congee or gruel** (粥). Begin with **1 ge** (一合), gradually increasing the dose. If the odor becomes unbearable after initial use, continue until the prescription is finished, then prepare a fresh batch. Stop when symptoms abate. Avoid **rich, greasy foods** (肥腻); if thirsty, drink **soup broth** (羹汁). Strictly abstain from **alcohol, meat, pork, chicken, fish, raw cold foods, slippery or glutinous substances, and sexual activity** (房室). Consume only **porridge, milk, or lean meats such as beef, mutton, rabbit, and venison** (浆粥、牛羊兔鹿肉). Even if one can tolerate these foods during times of great hunger or thirst, one should still avoid them.

This ailment is difficult to treat. Though many powerful **pills, powders, decoctions, and plasters** (丸散汤膏) may temporarily alleviate symptoms, they often recur later. Only this powder ensures lasting relief—taking it regularly prevents recurrence for life. Its restricted diet must be adhered to in moderation; do not indulge in **salty or miscellaneous foods** (咸物诸杂食) at will.

Another prescription:
**Balloonflower Root** (葶苈), ground into powder **2 + 1 spoonfuls** (二＋匕)
**Xanthium Fruit** (苍耳子), burned into ash **2 + 1 spoonfuls** (二＋匕)

Mix the above two ingredients with water and take twice daily.

Another prescription:
Take **ardamom** (椒目) that has settled in water, roast until fragrant, pound into a paste, and serve with wine in **1 fen of a spoonful** (方寸匕), once daily.

Another prescription:
Boil **horse manure** (马篼) in water and drink the strained liquid.

For **water-qi edema** (水气肿), **abdominal distension** (鼓胀), and **urinary difficulty** (小便不利), the following is effective:

Wash the sheep lung, then simmer it in a shallow decoction. Slice thinly and dry in the sun. Grind into a powder. Soak **Desmodium Stem** in **three-year-old vinegar** (三年大酢) for **one shao** (晬时), then remove and roast until its color changes. Pound until it becomes like mud. Mix with the sheep lung powder, knead with honey, and pound **3,000 times** (三千杵) to form pills the size of **Firmiana seeds** (梧子). Take four pills with **Ophiopogon Drink** (麦门冬饮) after a meal, three times daily. Observe the symptoms of **dry throat, sticky mouth, and incoherent speech** (浪语) as indicators. **Mountain Cnidium** (山连) cured **Wei Siyu** (韦司业), whose nephew said it was a prescription sent by **Emperor Taizong** (表), and that it had proven miraculously effective in multiple uses.

Use **1 sheng and 5 ge of water** (一升五合), simmer for **three fen of a spoonful** (三寸匕), then take **1 sheng of the decoction** (一升) at once, twice daily. If unable to tolerate, take once daily. This should be administered within the first two to three months, particularly for those with **excessive urination but difficulty in passing urine** (小便涩). It is highly effective.

**Chu Zhen’s Han Stephania Powder** (褚澄汉防己散), for **water edema** (水肿) and **upper respiratory distress** (上气):
