**Pyrrosia Leaf** (石韦) **5 liang**
**Alisma Rhizome** (泽泻) **5 liang**
**Mulberry Bark** (桑根白皮) **3 liang**
**Atractylodes** (白朮) **3 liang**
**Salvia Root** (丹参) **3 liang**
**Red Poria** (赤茯苓) **3 liang**
**Tangerine Peel** (橘皮) **3 liang**
**Halostachys Stem** (通草) **3 liang**
**Fresh Ginger** (生姜) **10 liang**
**Prunus Mume Kernels** (郁李仁) **5 ge** (五合)

Boil the above twelve ingredients in a sieve. Use **1 sheng and 5 ge of water** (一升半), simmer for **three fen of a spoonful** (三方寸匕), then take **8 ge of the decoction** (八合), strained. Consume at once, three times daily, until urination improves.

**Poria Pill** (茯苓圆), for **water edema** (水肿), prescribed by **Zhen Quan** (甄权) for **Ankang Gong** (安康公):
**Poria** (茯苓) **4 fen** (四分)
**Atractylodes** (白朮) **4 fen** (四分)
**Ardamom** (椒目) **4 fen** (四分)
**Stephania Root** (木防己) **5 fen** (五分)
**Balloonflower Root** (葶苈) **5 fen** (五分)
**Alisma Rhizome** (泽泻) **5 fen** (五分)
**Sweet Cane** (甘遂) **12 fen** (十二分)
**Red Adzuki Beans** (赤小豆) **2 fen** (二分)
**Peucedan Root** (前胡) **2 fen** (二分)
**Daphne Genkwa** (芫花) **2 fen** (二分)
**Cinnamon** (桂心) **2 fen** (二分)
**Mirabilite** (芒硝) **7 fen** (七分), separately ground

Grind the above twelve ingredients into a powder, mix with honey to form pills the size of **Firmiana seeds** (梧子). Take five pills with honey decoction, once daily, gradually increasing the dose until symptoms abate.

For **water edema** (水肿) and **urinary difficulty** (小便不利):
**Rhubarb** (大黄) **equal parts**
**Atractylodes** (白朮), or **Balloonflower Root** (葶苈) **equal parts**

Grind the above three ingredients into a powder, mix with honey to form pills the size of **Firmiana seeds** (梧子). Take ten pills with water, until urination improves; if symptoms persist, increase the dose.

Another prescription:
**Radish Seed** (牵牛子), ground into powder, take **1 fen of a spoonful** (方寸匕) with water, once daily, until urination improves.

Another prescription:
**Balloonflower Root** (葶苈) **4 liang**, used fresh
**Cinnamon** (桂心) **1 liang**

For the first prescription:
Take the two ingredients, grind into a powder, and form honey-coated pills the size of **Firmiana seeds**. Swallow seven pills with water, twice daily, until symptoms abate.

Another prescription:
**Ju-jube Seed** (郁李仁) powder and **fermented barley** (曲), each one *sheng*.
Mix the two ingredients into seven cakes, roast until done.
Take four cakes on an empty stomach while hot, increasing by one each time until all seven are consumed.

Another prescription:
**Mercury** (水银), cooked for three days and nights, **Balloonflower Seed** (葶苈子), **Sichuan Peppercorn** (椒目), each one *sheng*;
**Clothes Moth** (衣鱼) twenty-seven specimens;
**Duckweed** (水萍), **Trichosanthes Fruit** (瓜蒂), **Talc** (滑石), each two *liang*;
**Mirabilite** (芒硝), five *liang*.

Grind the **Balloonflower Seed** finely, then add the mercury and pound until no mercury is visible. Separately grind the **Sichuan Peppercorn** finely, then pound the **Trichosanthes Fruit** and **Duckweed**, sift, and mix with the remaining ingredients. Combine with honey and pound into pills with thirty thousand strokes.

Begin with one pill the size of a **Firmiana seed**, then two, three, four, five, and six. By the seventh day, restart with one pill, then two, and so on, resuming the sequence each time until six pills are reached.

When first taking the medicine, a **goiter-like swelling** (喉上有𠀤子肿起) will appear in the throat, the **jaw joint** (颊车) will swell and distend, the gums will all swell, and spitting will produce blood. Do not be alarmed—this will subside within three to five days, and all suffering will be relieved. If diarrhea occurs after taking the medicine, stop until it ceases; the medicine should be taken no more than five times.

If the illness persists, continue; if cured, stop. This treats cases where the body is abnormally fleshy and thick, pressing down without indentation, with severe cases having thick arms that cannot fit into sleeves, as well as ten types of **untreatable edema** (大水). It is infallibly effective.
(*Sources: 深师, 集验, 陶氏, 古今录验*—omitting **Clothes Moth, Duckweed, Trichosanthes Fruit,** and **Talc**.)

---
**Ze-lac Decoction** (泽漆汤):
For **water-qi** (水气) causing generalized floating edema, weakness in the limbs, or arising from **diabetes** (消渴), **jaundice** (黄疸), or **lung congestion** (支饮), with internal deficiency, stagnant **honor-qi** (荣) and **defense-qi** (卫), undigested **qi**, and skin congestion—producing shortness of breath, abdominal resonance and distension, and blurred vision:

**Ze-lac Root** (泽漆根), ten *liang*;
**Crucian Carp** (鲤鱼), five *jin*;
**Fresh Ginger** (生姜), eight *liang*;
**Adzuki Bean** (赤小豆), two *sheng*;
**Poria** (茯苓), three *liang*;
**Ginseng** (人参), **Licorice** (甘草), **Ophiopogon** (麦门冬), each two *liang*.

Cut and decoct with seventeen *sheng* of water. First boil the fish and beans, reducing to seven *sheng*, then remove and add the remaining herbs. Simmer to four and a half *sheng*. Take three *ge* per dose, three times daily; the weak may take three *ge* total.

After the second dose, if **qi descends** (气下), shortness of breath will cease, and the dose may increase to four *ge*. Urination will improve, edema will lessen, or loose stools may occur. If urination is excessive, restart with one *ge* until it normalizes. If no fish is available, substitute another fish. For severe edema preventing sleep or turning, add one *jin* of **Ze-lac Root**; for thirst, add two *liang* of **Trichosanthes Root** (栝蒌根); for coughing, add two *liang* of **Aster** (紫菀), one *liang* of **Asarum** (细辛), one *ge* of **Balloonflower Flower** (款冬花), and three *liang* of **Cinnamon Bark** (桂心), increasing fish broth to two *sheng*.
(*胡洽* omits **Adzuki Bean** and **Ophiopogon**, adding **Alisma** (泽泻), five *liang*, and **Apricot Kernel** (杏仁), one *liang. Ancient and Modern Verified Records* omits **Adzuki Bean**, treating **water in the five viscera**, causing coughing, wheezing, shortness of breath, abdominal distension with resonance, swollen legs, **thread-like veins under the eyes** (目下有卧蚕状), slight thirst, inability to lie still, **rapid shallow breathing** (气奔短气), and frequent, scanty urination. It also addresses **lung disease** (肺病) with chest fullness and hidden pain, **water-qi pressing the lungs** (水气迫肺), and alternating chills and fever.)

---
**Hog Fungus Powder** (猪苓散):
For **hollow fullness** (虚满), generalized edema, and promoting **Triple Burner** (三焦) and **water pathways** (水道):

**Hog Fungus** (猪苓), **Balloonflower Root** (葶苈), **Ginseng** (人参), **Scrophularia** (玄参), **Schisandra** (五味子), **Siler** (防风), **Alisma** (泽泻), **Cinnamon Bark** (桂心), **Wolfsbane** (狼毒), **Sichuan Peppercorn** (椒目), **Atractylodes** (白朮), **Dried Ginger** (乾姜), **Cantharis** (大戟), **Licorice** (甘草), each two *liang*;
**Cistanche** (苁蓉), two and a half *liang*;
**Fermented Wheat Gluten** (女曲), three *ge*;
**Adzuki Bean** (赤小豆), two *ge*.

Grind and sift. Take one *fen* of a spoonful with wine, three times daily and once at night. The elderly and young may take one *qian* of a spoonful, until urination improves.

---
For **water-qi edema** causing severe generalized swelling, unresponsive to other treatments, and nearing death:

**Fresh Hemp Seeds** (大麻子), thoroughly selected, one *dan*;
**Adzuki Beans** (赤小豆), pure and unadulterated, one *dan*.

Both must be freshly harvested and refined. Wash and dry in the sun, then steam the hemp seeds until cooked, dry again, and store in a clean container.

To prepare, take five *sheng* of hemp seeds, roast until golden and fragrant (using slow fire to prevent burning), then grind into an extremely fine powder. Extract the juice with five *sheng* of water, strain, and store in a clean, sealed vessel.

The night before taking, soak one *sheng* of **Adzuki Beans** in clean water until morning, then drain and dry. Boil the beans in fresh water until nearly cooked, drain, and mix with the hemp juice. Simmer until thoroughly softened. Take on an empty stomach, three times daily. Initially, a **stifling sensation** (小心闷) may occur but will soon pass.

After five days, urination will increase, possibly with red urine, sticky saliva, and dry mouth—do not be alarmed. After completing the treatment, engage in **gentle movement** (微行); if unable, lie down. On the tenth day, **acupuncture** (针) and **moxibustion** (灸) the **Stomach 36** (三里) and **Stomach 37** (绝骨) points to release **qi**; otherwise, **qi** will not disperse, and the medicine will be ineffective.

Five days later, if **counterflow** (逆) prevents further doses, take a **dead crucian carp** (大鲤鱼), remove scales and tail, boil to remove slime, clean, open, and remove entrails. Mix the remaining hemp juice and **Adzuki Beans**, then cook into a porridge with **garlic** (葱), **fermented soybean** (豉), **tangerine peel** (橘皮), **fresh ginger** (生姜), and **perilla** (紫苏). Consume throughout the treatment, strictly avoiding bathing.

When thirsty, drink **hemp juice**—warm in autumn and winter, cold in spring and summer. Always eat until just sated, no more than to stave off hunger. Avoid **sexual activity**, anger, loud speech, high-pitched voices, alcohol, oil, vinegar, raw or cold foods, vegetables, all fish and meat, pickled dishes, and the five pungent spices.

This cures ten out of ten cases, with divine efficacy. It also treats all **qi-related ailments**; those who take it recover fully within a month of daily administration. Collect **hemp seeds** when ripe, store in fresh jars, and distribute to others.

**Formula #22:**
**Evodia (吴茱萸)**, **Ligusticum (华拨)**, **Kombu (昆布)**, **Apricot Kernel (杏仁)**, **Lappula (葶苈)**—equal parts.
Powder and form into honey pills the size of *wuzi* seeds. For **breathlessness**, take five pills on an empty stomach, ensuring no overeating. If **counterflow** or **breathlessness** occurs after eating, take them immediately to disperse the **qi**.

**Bitter Gourd (苦瓠) Pills** for **edema (大水)**, where the head, face, and body swell severely, and the abdomen is distended:
Take **bitter gourd** and **white **Akebia (白禳) fruit**, knead into the size of large beans, wrap in dough, boil until just simmered, and swallow seven pieces on an empty stomach. By noon, one *sheng* of urine should pass. Over three to four days, urine will continue to flow without stopping, and the patient will grow significantly thinner before recovery. For three years afterward, be cautious with dietary flavors.

Use only the finest **bitter gourd**, free of blemishes, with fine texture, and thoroughly cleaned—otherwise, it is toxic and unusable. *Chui Shi’s method* uses the seeds to make dumplings, taking fourteen pieces. If fearing **emptiness (虚)**, take with cow’s milk. Administer alternately each day, gradually increasing to twenty-one pieces, stopping when urination improves. If urination is excessive, pause for one to two days.

**Formula for whole-body edema:**
Decoct **Sichuan peppercorn (猪椒) branches and leaves** like intestines. Take one spoonful on an empty stomach, three times daily. For itching, wash with the decoction.

**Another formula:**
**Bitter gourd membrane (苦瓠膜)**—2 *fen*, **Lappula (葶苈子)**—5 *fen*.
Combine and knead into pills the size of small beans. Take five pills daily, three times.

**Another formula:**
Decoct human urine until it can be formed into pills. Take pills the size of small beans, three times daily.

**Formula #23:**
**Lappula (葶苈)**, **Peach Kernel (桃仁)**—equal parts.
Toast both, knead into pills, and take to promote urination. Some versions use **Apricot Kernel (杏仁)** instead.

**Another formula:**
Seven **jujubes (大枣)**, **bitter gourd membrane** the size of jujube pits.
Knead into pills. Take three pills at a time, then after walking fifteen *li*, take another three. If urination occurs, take one more to stop.

**Another formula:**
Knead raw **Lappula (葶苈子)** and take with alcohol, adjusting dosage by the frequency of urination.

**Another formula:**
Burn **ginger stone (姜石)** until red, immerse in black cow’s urine until heated, and drink one *sheng* daily.

**Another formula:**
Drinking cow’s urine alone is highly effective.

For all **water-related illnesses**, begin with small doses and stop once urination improves.

**Another formula:**
Moxibustion at the second toe, one *cun* upward, adjusted by age and strength. Also, moxibustion at the junction of both thumbs, seven times.

**Ephedra Decoction** for **wind edema (风水)**, where the body swells to the point of rupture and urination is obstructed:
**Ephedra (麻黄)**, **Poria (茯苓)**, **Alisma (泽泻)**—4 *liang* each;
**Saposhnikovia (防风)**, **Toxicodendron (泽漆)**, **Atractylodes (白朮)**—5 *liang* each;
**Apricot Kernel (杏仁)**, **Cantharis (大戟)**, **Clear Alcohol (清酒)**—1 *sheng* each;
**Astragalus (黄耆)**, **Tuckahoe (猪苓)**—3 *liang* each;
**Siler (独活)**—8 *liang*;
**Soybeans (大豆)**—2 *sheng*, water—7 *sheng*.
Decoct, taking one *sheng*. Combine thirteen herbs, chop finely, and decoct with soybean juice, alcohol, and water (totaling one *dou*), reducing to six *sheng*. Divide into six or seven doses, finishing within one day and night. Urination should become extremely frequent as the measure of efficacy.

**Soybean Decoction #24** for **wind edema**, where the body swells severely, the eyes cannot open, and breathing is shallow to the point of near-death:
**Soybeans (大豆)**, **Apricot Kernel (杏仁)**, **Clear Alcohol (清酒)**—1 *sheng* each;
**Ephedra (麻黄)**, **Cocculus (木防己)**, **Saposhnikovia (防风)**, **Tuckahoe (猪苓)**—4 *liang* each;
**Alisma (泽泻)**, **Astragalus (黄耆)**, **Aconite (乌头)**—3 *liang* each;
**Fresh Ginger (生姜)**—7 *liang*;
**Pinellia (半夏)**—6 *liang*;
**Poria (茯苓)**, **Atractylodes (白朮)**—5 *liang* each;
**Euphorbia (甘遂)**, **Licorice (甘草)**—2 *liang* each.
Chop finely, decoct soybeans in 14 *sheng* of water, reducing to 10 *sheng*, then add the remaining herbs and alcohol, decocting to 7 *sheng*. Divide into seven doses, four times daily and three times at night. Stop when urination is frequent and smooth, and swelling subsides—do not finish the entire decoction. If urination remains obstructed, add **raw Cantharis (生大戟)**—1 *sheng*, and **Lappula (葶苈)**—2 *liang*. This will ensure prompt urination without failure.

*Shen Shi’s method* omits **Tuckahoe (猪苓)**, **Alisma (泽泻)**, **Aconite (乌头)**, **Pinellia (半夏)**, and **Euphorbia (甘遂)**.

**Formula for wind edema:**
**Soybeans (大豆)**—3 *sheng*;
**Poria (茯苓)**, **Atractylodes (白朮)**, **Saposhnikovia (防风)**, **Tangerine Peel (橘皮)**, **Pinellia (半夏)**, **Fresh Ginger (生姜)**—5 *liang* each;
**Tortoise Shell (鳖甲)**, **Angelica (当归)**, **Cocculus (防己)**, **Ephedra (麻黄)**, **Tuckahoe (猪苓)**—3 *liang* each;
**Cantharis (大戟)**—1 *liang*;
**Prickly Ash Fruit (葵子)**—1 *sheng*;
**Mulberry Bark (桑白皮)**—5 *sheng*.
Decoct in 20 *sheng* of water, reducing to 10 *sheng*, then add the remaining herbs, decocting to 5 *sheng*. Take eight *ge* per dose, three times daily, with intervals equivalent to walking ten *li*. Stop when urination improves.

**Hemp Seed Decoction** for **generalized fluid retention (遍身流肿):**
**Hemp Seeds (麻子)**—5 *sheng*;
**Red Adzuki Beans (赤小豆)**—3 *sheng*;
**Solanum nigrum (当陆)**—1 *jin*;
**Saposhnikovia (防风)**—3 *liang*;
**Aconite (附子)**—1 *liang*.
Chop finely, first pounding the hemp seeds until ripe. Decoct in 30 *sheng* of water, reducing to 13 *sheng*, then add the remaining herbs and beans, decocting to 4 *sheng*. Strain and drink with the beans.

**Soybean Decoction** for **new or chronic edema in men and women**, sudden exposure to **malignant wind (暴恶风)** entering the abdomen, or postpartum women where **wind enters the viscera**, causing abdominal distension like a **horsewhip**, with labored breathing and coughing:
Use **soybeans (大豆)**—10 *sheng*, cleaned. Decoct in 50 *sheng* of water, reducing to 15 *sheng*, then strain and return to the pot. Add 15 *sheng* of wine, decocting to 9 *sheng*. Avoid food the night before. At dawn, take 3 *sheng* warm, cover to induce sweating. Within two meals, **wind will be expelled**, edema will subside, and caution against **wind and cold** is advised for ten days to ensure full recovery.

On the day of cessation, take it together for optimal effect. If the urgency is severe and cannot be endured, administer it to expel the urgency. If the edema does not fully subside, repeat the dose; if it is mostly resolved, take three *sheng* more. If it is entirely resolved, do not take it again. During the illness, one may also drink freely as desired, ensuring the **qi** of the wine harmonizes with the body’s state.

The *Zhǒuhòu* [《肘后》] states: If the edema is mostly resolved but thirst persists, be cautious not to drink excessively.

Another prescription: Bundle **ramie bark and leaves (chǔpí zhīyè)**—one large handful, cut, and decoct to obtain the juice. Ferment it into wine according to the quantity needed, and drink until intoxication. Within three to four days, the edema will significantly subside, and afterward, it may be taken regularly.

One alternative uses **pork pepper bark and leaves (zhūjiāo pí zhīyè)**.

Another prescription: A **crucian carp (lǐyú)** of fifteen *cùn* in length. Soak it in urine overnight. At dawn, pierce it from mouth to tail with a wooden skewer and roast it over gentle fire until just cooked. Remove the skin. Avoid food the night before and take it on an empty stomach in one dose. If unable to consume all at once, divide it into two servings. Do not add salt. Apply the fish paste externally to treat the surface. For any edema, one must employ a hundred methods—both internal and external—to attack it; no single remedy suffices universally.

**Recipe for External Application:**
Take **fresh dodder (shēngdàng)**—one *jīn* (斤), and **pork fat (zhūgāo)**—one *jīn*. Decoct together until the mixture turns yellow. Strain and apply to the edema. Alternatively, take a small amount internally as well, and spread it on the affected area. Cover with paper, and reapply when dry. The edema will resolve within three days.

**Musk Powder (Shèxiāng sǎn)** for **women with shortness of breath and emaciation from deficiency (虚羸)**, whose entire body is **floatingly swollen (fúzhǒng)**, with taut skin—an uncommon condition:
**Musk (shèxiāng)**—3 *zhǔ* (铢)
**Realgar (xiónghuáng)**—6 *zhǔ*
**Daphne genkwa (yuánhuā)**—2 *liǎng* (两)
**Sweet Sophora (gānsuì)**—2 *liǎng*

Combine these four ingredients and sift. Take with wine—5 *chǐ* (匕) of powder, adjusting the dose for the elderly or young as needed. Alternatively, make into pills the size of small beans. The strong may take seven pills.

From *Xiǎopǐn* [《小品》], omit **realgar (xiónghuáng)**.
From *Shēnshī* [《深师》], make into honey pills the size of large beans. Take two pills, three times daily.

To treat **dysfunction of the Triple Burner (Sānjiāo)**, with water lodged externally in the chest—**Water Disease (shuǐbìng)**—where the abdomen is **cloudy#26 and enlarged**, use **Large Galingale Pill (Dàkāngxiāng wán)** externally. The *Huàtá Prescriptions* [《华佗方》] and *Zhǒuhòu* [《肘后》] include **ginseng (rénshēn)**—2 *liǎng*, made into pills for oral use.

For **emaciation from deficiency (虚láo)** and **floating edema (fúzhǒng)**:
Moxibustion at **Great Rushing (Tàichōng)**—100 *zhuàng* (壮), and again at **Kidney Confluence (Shènshǔ)**.

End of *Sun Zhēnrén’s Thousand-Gold Emergency Prescriptions*, Volume 65.
Corrected by *Song Cháo Fèngláng Shǒutàicháng Shàoxīng Lín Yì* [宋朝奉郎守太常少卿充秘阁校理林亿等] and others.

**Prescriptions for *Dīngzhǒng*#1: First Treatise on *Dīngzhǒng*
**Symptoms | Prescriptions | Acupuncture & Moxibustion Methods**

The treatise states:
The human body, in its formation, must be preserved and nourished; if one fails to regulate rest and activity, diseases will arise. Thus, the four seasons transform, and *yin* and *yang* alternate in their flourishing. When these two *qi* forces clash violently, it is inevitable that **pathogenic#4 *fùqi*#5** will emerge. Such **pathogenic *fùqi*** occurs every month. Sudden exposure to **great wind (dàfēng)**, **great mist (dàwù)**, **great cold (dàhán)**, or **great heat (dàrè)**—if not avoided in due time—will strike the body, impairing the skin, flooding the meridians, and causing **residual *lì*#6** to stagnate, while **nutritive and defensive *qi*#7** congeal. This obstruction prevents *yin* and *yang* from venting properly, leading to **boils and carbuncles (yōngjū)**, ***Dīngdú*#8**, and **malignant sores (èchuāng)****, all of which manifest as swellings.

As for ***Dīngzhǒng*#9**, if not recognized beforehand, it will kill a person before noon. If one waits until it has fully developed before seeking treatment, the patient is already beyond recovery. Therefore, those who cultivate longevity must study this prescription early. No matter the type of **ulcerous swelling (chuāngyí)**, none can escape its effects.

In treating ***Dīngzhǒng*#9**, one must **prick the center until bleeding**, and also **prick the edges ten or more times** to induce bleeding. After removing the blood, apply the medicine—this allows the **drug’s *qi*** to penetrate the needle holes most effectively. If the treatment does not reach the **sore’s core**, it will lack efficacy.

The **swelling** of *Dīngzhǒng* often appears on the inner cheeks or tongue, **reddish-black like pearls**, and causes **aching pain that resonates in the heart**. This is a **chronic accumulation of autumn-winter cold toxins** within the skin, transforming into this ailment. If left untreated, the **root of the disease** will grow by day and night, spreading through multiple meridians, **fixing the body like an arrow lodged deep**, rendering it immobile. If one does not **heed dietary and sexual precautions**, death will follow swiftly.

If the swelling does not subside after five or six days, symptoms such as **flickering lights in the eyes (yǎnzhōng jiàn huǒguāng)**, **aversion to light (shénzèng)**, **dry mouth (kǒugān)**, and **restlessness of the heart (xīnfán)** appear—**death is imminent**.

1. **Hemp-seed *Dīng* (Mázǐ Dīng)**: The swelling **begins as a nodule on the flesh**, the size of **millet grains**, slightly black with **edges faintly red**, and often **itchy**. Avoid consuming **hemp seeds** or wearing **hemp cloths**, and **do not enter hemp fields**.

2. **Stone *Dīng* (Shídīng)**: The swelling **connects skin and flesh**, appearing **jet-black like black beans**, **extremely hard**, and **unpenetrable by pricking**. The **inner flesh** feels **dullly painful**. Avoid **tiles, rubble, and stones**.

3. **Male *Dīng* (Xióngdīng)**: The swelling **forms a black, raised pustule**, with **edges upturned**, **pus-filled blisters**, and **yellowish fluid discharge** like **water**, **the size of a coin’s hole**, and **elevated in shape**. Avoid **sexual activity**.

4. **Female *Dīng* (Cídīng)**: The swelling **appears as a yellowish pustule**, with **edges depressed**, also resembling **a moxibustion burn**, **blisters forming at the edges**, and **a sunken center with red hue**, **the size of a coin’s hole**. Avoid **sexual activity**.

5. **Fire *Dīng* (Huǒdīng)**: The swelling **resembles a scald from hot water or fire**, with **a blackened pustule**, **blisters at the edges**, and **a raised form like red millet grains**. Avoid **exposure to flames, scorching heat, or burning objects**.

6. **Rotten *Dīng* (Làndīng)**: The swelling **has a slightly blackened appearance with white scars**, **the sore breaks open**, and **pus discharges**. The **size varies like a spoon’s face**. Avoid **boiling-hot foods or rotting fabrics**.

7. **Thirty-six *Dīng* (Sānshíliù Dīng)**: The swelling **appears as black, raised nodules**, **the size of black beans**, with **large red rims**. It **emerges one per day**, then **two the next**, then **three**, and so on, up to **ten**. If **thirty-six swellings** fully develop, **no medicine can cure it**. If fewer than **thirty-six swellings** appear, it **may still be treated**.

---

**8. Black *Dīng* (Hēi Dīng)**: Commonly known as *Hēi Dīng*. Avoid **anger and repressed sorrow**.

**8. Snake-Eye *Dīng* (Shéyǎn Dīng)**: The swelling **has a blackened pustule**, **raised upon the skin**, **the size of small beans**, **resembling a snake’s eye**, and **is generally hard**. Avoid **being looked upon by an evil eye**, **envy or jealousy from others**, and **poisonous medicines**.

**9. Salt-Skin *Dīng* (Yánfū Dīng)**: The swelling **is as large as a spoon’s face**, **with red rims all around**, and **has black millet-grain-like nodules rising**. Avoid **salty foods**.

**10. Water-Washed *Dīng* (Shuǐxǐ Dīng)**: The swelling **is as large as a coin**, **or as large as a coin’s hole**, with **a white pustule**, **surrounded by blackened edges**, and **a fluid discharge that is slightly hard**. Avoid **drinking whey**, **washing with water**, or **crossing rivers**.

**11. Sickle *Dīng* (Dāolián Dīng)**: The swelling **is broad or narrow like a lotus leaf**, **one inch long**, with **blackened flesh on the left side resembling burns**. Avoid **pricks or cuts from sickles or knives**, and **injuries from iron blades**. These **can be treated with medicine**.

**12. Floating *Dīng* (Fú’ào Dīng)**: The swelling **is curved and rounded**, **slightly unclosed**, **long and narrow like a lotus leaf**, with **yellow interior and black exterior**. **Pricking the blackened area causes no pain**, but **pricking the yellow interior causes pain**.

**13. Ox-Restraint *Dīng* (Niújū Dīng)**: The swelling **has raised flesh that cannot be broken by pinching**.

---
For the **thirteen types of *Dīng*** mentioned above, **the initial symptoms are always itching followed by pain**, **cold followed by heat**, and **heat subsiding into cold**. They often cause **heaviness in the limbs**, **headaches**, **fright**, and **blurred vision**. If **the condition is severe**, **vomiting may occur**, and **vomiting cases are difficult to treat**.

The **Itch *Dīng* (Mázǐ Dīng)** is **the only type where itching persists from start to finish**. The **precautions listed** must **not be violated**; if they are, **treatment becomes difficult**.

The **Floating *Dīng* (Fú’ào Dīng)** and **Ox-Restraint *Dīng* (Niújū Dīng)** have **no specific prohibitions**. Even if **untreated**, they **cannot kill a person**. Their **symptoms of cold and heat align with those of other *Dīng*** types, and **all can be treated with this formula**, with **a success rate of ten thousand out of ten thousand**.

To **recognize the danger of violating precautions**, observe **a stiffened spine** and **unbearable pustule pain**.

**Treatment for the thirteen types of *Dīng* (Shísān Zhǒng Dīng Fāng)**:
Use **Gǒuqǐ** (Lycium fruit).

The **medicine** has **four names**: in **Spring** it is called **Celestial Essence** (Tiān Jīng), in **Summer** **Lycium Fruit** (Gǒuqǐ), in **Autumn** **Turn Back Aging** (Què Lǎo), and in **Winter** **Earth Bone** (Dì Gǔ).

In the **first three days of the third month of Spring**, gather the leaves on **auspicious days**; in the **first three days of the third month of Summer**, gather the branches on **auspicious even-numbered days**; in the **first three days of the third month of Autumn**, gather the seeds on **auspicious days**; in the **first three days of the third month of Winter**, gather the roots on **auspicious days**. Whenever the **auspicious days** first appear in any of the four seasons, collect the **branches, leaves, seeds, and roots**—all four—and dry them in the sun. If obtained on the **fifth day of the fifth month at noon**, it is even more potent.

If one cannot gather according to the proper method, even a single type suffices. Wrap the medicine in **a crimson silk cloth**, using just enough to cover it, in a size comparable to **a fistful of disordered hair** or **a cow’s gallbladder and Chinese wolfberry seed**. Mix **twenty-seven needles of Reverse Hook Thorn Acupuncture** (Fǎn Gōu Jié Zhēn), **seven red adzuki beans**, and apply them thinly atop the crimson silk. Then roll the cloth into a bundle, binding it with **ten cross-ties of disordered hair**, and parch it over **rapid central fire** until the steam rises. Once the steam subsides, let it dry naturally. Grind the dried bundle into powder, sift through silk, and measure with **a one-cubic-inch spoon**. Combine the **four types of Lycium**, grind them, sift through silk, and take **two spoonfuls** of the powder. Mix it with the earlier **one spoonful**, making a total of **three spoonfuls**, ensuring the properties harmonize. Divide into two portions: **one to be taken in the morning on an empty stomach with wine**, twice daily.

**The Honorable Old Lady Róng’s Formula from Qí Prefecture**—for all **types of *Dīng* (Dīng Zhǒng)**—uses:
- **Oyster shell (Mǔlì)**, nine *liǎng* (3.6 *catty*), if rotten, use **Chóngrú** instead
- **Lycium root and bark (Gǒuqǐ Gēn Pí)**, two *liǎng* each
- **White stone (Bái Shíyīng)**, one *liǎng*
- **Platycodon root (Jiégěng)**, one and a half *liǎng*
- **White ginger (Bái Jiāngshí)**, one *jīn* (16 *liǎng*), if soft and yellow

Grind these **six ingredients** into powder, sift through silk, and blend thoroughly. First, take **Fùlóng Gān** (Scolopendra), nine *shēng* (3 *liǎng*), and make into powder. Mix with **one *dòu* (10 *shāng*) of clear wine**, stir until uniform, and strain off the clear liquid. Take **two *shēng*** of the strained liquid, blend with the medicine, and knead into **a pill six divisions large and two divisions thick**. The remaining dregs are placed back in the basin. The pill is then steamed in a **bamboo basket** over the basin, covered with **a sheet of paper**, and sealed with mud for **three times seven days**. Once dry, store in **a paper bag** in a dry place.

**Method of use**: Acupuncture the **center of the pustule** with a needle, piercing to its root and also around its **four sides** to draw blood. Then scrape and apply **a dose of medicine the size of a large soybean** onto the pustule. For severe cases, apply **three to four times daily**; for mild cases, **once to twice**. In severe cases, the root will rot and appear within **two days**; in mild cases, within **half a day to one day**. When the pustule **floats up**, it is a sign the root has emerged. If the root has already rotted upon emergence, **do not cease applying the medicine**.

This medicine is **exceptionally stable**, promoting **fresh tissue growth** and quick healing. If the **pustule lies within the throat, mouth, chest, or abdomen**, it will **manifest externally as abnormal swelling**. When **cold and heat symptoms persist**, suspect this disease. Mix **a dose of medicine the size of five Chinese dates** with **wine or plain water**, and administer **three to four times daily**. The swelling will **naturally dissolve and rot**. If vomiting occurs due to external manipulation, the root will emerge with the vomit. If the root does not emerge, the condition will still resolve. Observe the patient’s **vitality and self-awareness** for signs of improvement.

The **fifth day of the fifth month** is the **optimal time** for combining the medicine, followed by the **seventh day of the seventh month**, then the **ninth day of the ninth month** and the **twelfth month’s *Là* day**. If the medicine is urgently needed on other days, it may still be used, though it will **not be as effective**.

When preparing the medicine, **keep the environment pure** and **burn incense**. **Do not allow it to be touched by impurities**, nor **seen by filial children, incomplete initiates, postpartum women, or livestock such as chickens and dogs**. Those afflicted with this disease must **avoid sexual activity, pork, beef, chicken, fish, raw chives, leeks, garlic, Chinese cabbage, coriander, hemp sesbania, vinegar, fermented grains, or Lycium root**. If **precautions are violated** and symptoms worsen, use **Lycium root decoction** mixed with the medicine and taken as directed, along with the **following formula**.

The **second formula** is **of the same lineage**, but **wise practitioners** consider the **first formula** the **true original**.

**Zhào Ráo’s Formula**:
- **White ginger (Bái Jiāngshí)**, two and five *liǎng* (2.5 *catty*)
- **Oyster shell (Mǔlì)**, ten *liǎng* (4 *catty*), though **Chuī Shì’s text** lists seven *liǎng* (2.8 *catty*)
- **Poria (Fúlíng)**, three *liǎng*
- **Lycium root and bark (Gǒuqǐ Gēn Pí)**, four *liǎng*

Grind these **four ingredients** and sift through silk. First, take **fresh Lycium root and bark**, cut into **six *shēng* (1.8 *catty*)**, and decoct with **one and a half *dòu* (15 *catty*) of water**, reducing to **five *shēng*** of liquid. Remove the dregs and add **two *shēng* of fresh dog dung** (or **urine**, as **Chuī Shì’s text** states). Stir until blended, strain off the clear liquid, and mix it with the earlier medicine. Knead into **a pill**, dry in the shade.

For the patient, **acupuncture the pustule directly on the head** with a **two-edged needle**, ensuring the pain is piercing before withdrawing the needle. Scrape and apply the **medicine powder into the pustule’s hole**, **without allowing the breath to touch it**, and cover the entire pustule. It will **swell immediately**, and **pricking the root will cause it to emerge**.

In severe cases, the root may appear within **half a day** or have already dissolved. If pricking fails to extract the root, the condition will still **resolve naturally**; **do not worry**. If the pustule lies **internally**, it will **manifest externally as swelling**, accompanied by **persistent cold and heat symptoms**.

If one suspects a **pustule** but it remains unseen, mix **five doses of medicine the size of *tóng* seeds** with **half a bowl of water** and administer **three times daily**. The swelling will **dissolve on its own**. If the root must emerge, take the medicine for **one day**, then **use a chicken feather to induce vomiting**, and the root will come out with the vomit. If the root does not emerge, the medicine will still **dissolve the swelling**.

For **external pustules**, apply the medicine **three times daily**. Once the root emerges, **continue applying the medicine regularly** until **fresh tissue forms** and the condition heals. If **precautions are violated** and symptoms worsen, decoct **three *shēng* of Lycium root and bark** with **five *shēng* of water**, reducing to **two *shēng* of liquid**. Remove the dregs, grind **one *qiǎn* spoonful of medicine** into powder, and mix with **one bowl of Lycium juice**. Take **two to three times daily**, or **preferably drink only Lycium juice** for even better results.

Alternatively, mix **Lycium juice with fresh white dog dung**, and take the liquid—**this is even more effective**.

「Mix thoroughly and apply immediately, without waiting for it to dry.

The **white dog dung** mentioned refers to the dung of dogs that eat bones—its color resembles **quicklime**, hence it is simply called *white dog dung*. If preparing in advance, collect it on the **5th day of the 5th month, 7th day of the 7th month, 9th day of the 9th month, or the 12th month’s *là* day** (i.e., the winter solstice), as these are particularly potent and efficacious.

If someone suddenly experiences **throat pain**, alternating between **chills and heat**, this is the disease, and the remedy should be applied **urgently**. If throat pain arises **without apparent cause**, accompanied by **aversion to cold and fever**, it is also this disease—simply follow the previous method, and recovery will be swift.

Both the earlier and current prescriptions employ the same principle, with identical application, and are **highly effective** for **boils and abscesses**.

For **Ding’s swelling** (a severe throat abscess), **avoid exposure to hemp plants or *má bó* (Cannabis sativa)**, as seeing them may prove fatal. The formula:
**Sesame (胡麻), candle wick residue (烛烬), and sand spicules (针沙), each in equal parts.**
Take the three ingredients, grind into powder, mix with **vinegar**, and apply.

Alternatively:
**Quicklime (石灰) three parts, and horse-hoof tea (马齿菜) two parts.**
Pound the two ingredients, mix with **raw egg white**, and apply.

Another method:
**Pierce the four sides and center of the swelling**, then **dust with male sulfur (雄黄) powder**, and it will **heal immediately**—this is miraculously effective.
One account suggests **dusting with yellow soil (黄土)** instead.

Yet another method:」

「For **Ding’s swelling** (a severe throat abscess), another method:
Take **freshly dug earth from a new mouse burrow** (鼠新室土), mix with **child’s urine** (小儿尿), and apply.

Another method:
Grind **iron rust** (铁衣) into powder, mix with **human breast milk** (人乳汁), and apply—it will heal immediately.

Another method:
Grind **mung bean flowers** (小豆花) into powder and apply—it will heal.

Another method:
Apply **the tip of human feces** (人屎尖)—it will heal immediately.

Another method:
Place **one pill of Sìshén Dān** (四神丹) on the patient’s forehead; after a night, the root will emerge.

For **all cases of Ding’s swelling**:
Take **Xīnglǎo (Xanthium)** (苍耳) root, stem, sprouts, and seeds, burn them to ash until they turn a single color, mix with **vinegar dregs and fermented soybean residue** (醋泔淀) into a paste, and apply. Once dry, reapply. The root will be extracted within ten days—this method is highly effective.

During my four years of **orthodox Daoist practice** (正观), I suddenly developed **Ding’s swelling** on my cheek. I sought **Gānzǐ Zhèn’s** (甘子振) mother for a poultice, but after ten days it did not heal. I then applied this formula and recovered. Later, I often used this remedy to treat others, and none failed to heal. Thus, I record it specially to pass it down.

There are **thousands of formulas for Ding’s swelling**, but none surpass this one. Even the **Qízhōu Rónglǎo’s formula** (齐州荣姥方) cannot rival it. This remedy is simple and easily obtained.

Another method:
Drink **iron vinegar** (铁浆) in a measure of **one *dǒu* (≈10 liters)** (一斗)—it will heal immediately.

Another method:
Mix **fermented grain** (曲) with **pork fat from the 12th lunar month (Làyuè)** (腊月堵脂), seal it over the swelling—it will heal.

Another method:
Burn **one *shēng* (≈100 ml)** (一升) of **cocklebur seeds** (蒺藜子), grind to ash, mix with **strong vinegar** (酽醋), and seal it over the swelling. After a night, it will heal. If the swelling is pierced first, the effect is even better.

Another method:
Grind **soapberry seeds** (皂荚子) to extract the kernel, apply as powder—it will heal within five days.

**Han Guang’s formula from Yùshān** (玉山韩光方): Han Guang treated cases of **Ding’s swelling**. During my **orthodox Daoist practice** (正观), **Xú Shǐjūn from Qúzhōu** (衢州徐使君) found this formula for me:
Take **one担 (≈50 kg)** of **mugwort and artemisia** (艾蒿), burn to ash, and extract the juice in a bamboo tube. Mix with **stone lime** (石灰) like iron vinegar in a ratio of **1:2** (一二合). Pierce the swelling with a needle until it hurts, then apply the mixture three times. The root will emerge on its own—this is a miraculously effective method. I have used this formula to treat over thirty people with success, hence I record it.

**Yúqǐ Ding’s swelling** (鱼脐丁疮) resembles a **fresh needle prick** (似新火针疮), with its edges red and center black. It can be pierced with a needle. If it does not cause severe pain upon piercing, it is fatal to treat. The remedy:
Take **ash from fish heads in the 12th lunar month** (腊月鱼头灰) and **human hair ash** (发灰), each in equal parts, mix with **fermented egg yolk and human feces** (鸡溏屎), and apply. This swelling is highly lethal upon sight.

The *Wàitái* (外台) text omits **human hair ash** (发灰), using **egg white** (鸡子清) instead for mixing and application.

Another method:
Apply **sweetened glutinous rice balls from the Cold Food Festival** (寒食饧)—this is highly effective.

For **hardened swellings**, burn to ash and apply as a poultice—it will heal.

For **Yúqǐ Ding’s swelling** (鱼脐丁疮), where the head is white and swollen, causing unbearable pain:
First, pierce the swelling’s four sides to create holes. Pound **white celery root** (白苣) to extract its juice, and drip it into the needle holes.

Another method:
Apply **feces of the water otter** (水獭屎)—this is highly effective.

For **Ding’s swelling with red roots** (赤根丁):
Take **white powder** (白粉), char it until blackened, mix with **honey** (蜜), and transmit it (as an oral remedy)—this is effective.

Another method:
Take **freshly dug earth from a mouse burrow** (新坌鼠壤), mix with water, and apply. Reapply when it cools.

Another method:
Pound **horse teeth** (马牙齿) into powder, mix with **pork fat from the 12th lunar month** (腊月猪脂), and apply—it will extract the root. Burning to ash and applying is also effective.

For **Ding’s swelling that has turned malignant** (犯丁疮):
**Turnip root** (芜菁根) and **iron rust** (铁生衣), each in equal parts.
Take the two ingredients, mix and pound them. Pierce the swelling with a large needle to create holes. Then, cut **turnip root** into needle-sized strips, apply **iron rust** to them, and insert into the needle holes. Next, apply the previously pounded mixture and seal it. Finally, use a **small square of red cloth** (方寸匕绯帛) to cover and bind it. If pus emerges, reapply. In moments, the root will be extracted, and the swelling will heal immediately.
**Avoid oily, greasy, raw cold, vinegary, spicy, or foul-smelling foods.**

Another method:
Pierce the swelling’s head and four sides, allowing the juice to flow freely. Pound **raw chestnut** (生栗) into powder, apply it, and surround with **fermented grain** (曲), ensuring the chestnut does not spill out. By midday, the root will be extracted.

Another method:
Surround the swelling with **fermented grain** (曲) as in the previous method. Pierce the swelling chaotically with a needle. Boil **vinegar in a copper vessel** until it reaches a rolling boil, and pour it into the fermented grain surrounding the swelling, filling it to **one *shǎo* (≈100 ml)** (一盏). Reapply when it cools. After three applications, the root will emerge.

Another method:
Take **a snake’s shed skin** (蛇蜕皮) the size of an **egg** (如鸡子大), boil in **four *shēng* (≈1.6 liters)** (四升) of water for **three to four boils** (三四沸), strain, and drink the decoction immediately—it will heal immediately.

Another method:
Burn **snake’s shed skin** (蛇蜕皮) to ash, mix with **egg white** (鸡子清), and apply—it will heal.

Another method:
Take **Xīnglǎo (Xanthium) sprouts** (苍耳苗), pound to extract the juice—**one to two *shēng* (≈100-200 ml)** (一二升)—and drink it. Apply the residue to the swelling—it will heal immediately.

Another method:
**Moxibustion** (灸) the **horizontal crease on the back of the hand** (掌后横纹) behind the **five fingers** (五指), **left hand for men, right hand for women** (男左女右), with **seven sessions** (七壮)—it will heal. This method has proven effective.

Though there are many **moxibustion methods for Ding’s swelling**, this one is particularly effective and surpasses expectations.

From *Sūn Zhēnrén’s* (孙真人) *Bèijí Qiānjīn Yàofāng* (备急千金要方), **Volume 65** concludes.
