**Prescriptions for Carbuncles and Abscesses (痈疽方)**

**Section on Pulses (第二脉)**
**Discussion (论)**
**Prescriptions (方)**
**Prohibitions (禁法)**
**Moxibustion Methods (灸法)**

**Pulse Diagnostics:**
If the pulse is **floating and rapid** (浮数脉) but the body shows no heat, it indicates an **internal carbuncle** (痈). All floating and rapid pulses should cause fever, yet if the patient instead feels **chilly and aversion to cold** (洗洗恶寒) and complains of localized pain, it will soon **congeal into a carbuncle** (结为痈).

If the pulse is **weak and slow** (微而迟), fever will develop. If it is **weak and rapid** (弱而数), it signifies **shivering** (振寒) and will lead to **carbuncle and swelling** (痈肿).

If the pulse is **floating and rapid** (浮而数) with no bodily heat, the patient’s demeanor grows **listless** (默默), the stomach feels **slightly parched** (微燥), and they may not yet feel pain—yet they will soon develop **carbuncle and swelling**.

If the pulse is **slippery and rapid** (滑而数), slipperiness indicates **repletion** (实), rapidity indicates **heat** (热). Slipperiness corresponds to the **Nutritive Qi** (荣), rapidity to the **Defensive Qi** (卫). When Nutritive and Defensive Qi converge, it **congeals into a carbuncle** (结为痈). Wherever heat passes, **pus forms** (痈脓).

If the body has a **painful area** (痛处) and **ulcers recur** (苦有疮), it is a sign of impending carbuncle.

**Q:** *If the pulse at the **Cun position** (寸口) is **weak and rough** (微而涩), the standard prognosis is blood loss or sweating. What if sweating does not occur?*
**A:** *If the body has ulcers or wounds from blades or tools, it is due to **blood loss** (亡血).*

If the **Yin Spring pulse** (趺阳脉) is **slippery and rapid**, it indicates **diarrhea** (下重).

If the **Minor Yin pulse** (少阴脉) is **slippery and rapid**, a woman will develop **ulcers in the genital region** (阴中生疮).

**Discussion:**
When a carbuncle or abscess first appears, its onset is often **subtle**, and people rarely regard it as urgent. Yet this is a **grave affliction**; swift treatment is essential. Delay leads to **established disease**, and many disasters arise from hesitation.

If the carbuncle appears on the **back** (发背), if the skin is **thin**, it is called **carbuncle** (痈); if the skin is **thick**, it is called **abscess** (疽). **Urgent treatment is required.**

When a carbuncle or abscess first emerges, it may resemble a **small mole** (小廊), or cause **severe pain** (大痛) or **mild pain** (小痛). Sometimes it appears as a **white pus-filled grain** (米粒大白脓子)—these are **early signs** (微候). If even slight changes occur, **immediate alarm is needed**. Attack with **therapeutics and dietary restrictions**, administer **decoctions to purge heat-toxins** (下去热毒). If no medicine is available, **moxibustion at the crown** (当头百壮) is required.

For severe cases, moxibustion should be applied to **all four sides and the center** (四面及中央), **200–300 moxa cones** (二三百壮). Frequent moxibustion is unnecessary—**apply thin layers of cooling herbs** (薄以冷药) afterward.

**All救疗 methods must be swift to achieve cure** (必速瘥).

When applying **medicated plasters** (药帖), place them over the **carbuncle’s head** (疮头). The plaster should have **ventilation holes** (开孔) to **release heat** (泄热气).

Alternatively, **pierce the carbuncle with a fire-needle** (火针) to a depth of **four fen** (四分)—this ensures cure.

**Never** use acupuncture or **bloodletting** (针角) on **carbuncles, abscesses, tumors, calcified carbuncles, tendon knots, or scrofula** (痈、疽、瘤、石痈、结筋、瘰疬)—**even slight misapplication risks disaster** (少有不及祸).

For **any carbuncle**, regardless of size, once detected, **cut a piece of glue** (胶) the size of a **palm**, soften it in **warm water** (暖水), and mold it into a thin sheet. Punch a **coin-sized hole** (如钱孔大) over the carbuncle’s center. Apply it to the swelling—it will **dry quickly**. If no pus has formed, the carbuncle **will not worsen**. If pus has formed, it **will drain naturally**. If a **sharp needle** (锋针) is inserted through the hole to **draw pus**, it is ideal. Remove the glue once the carbuncle heals.

**Swelling classifications:**
- If the **base is less than one inch wide**, it is a **furuncle** (疖).
- If the **base is over one inch**, it is a **small carbuncle** (小痈).
- If it resembles a **pea-sized blister** (豆粒大), it is a **vesicle** (疱子).

**Immediate treatment:** Administer **Five-Spice Forsythia Decoction** (五香连翘汤) to purge heat-toxins. Use **multiple doses until cured**.

For carbuncles that are **elevated, smooth, and large** (高而光大) with **no excessive heat**, if the flesh is **level and purple** (正平无尖而紫), **do not lance them**—instead, prescribe **Bamboo Leaf Astragalus Decoction** (竹叶黄耆汤) to **regulate the Qi** (申其气). A **flat, purple surface indicates no pus** (无脓).

If a carbuncle **suddenly becomes painful**, apply **Eight-Flavor Astragalus Powder** (八味黄耆散). For **large carbuncles**, apply for **seven days**; for **small ones**, **five days**. If the carbuncle is **firm and resistant**, it **must rupture naturally** (宁生破).

If **milk-like discharge or heat** appears and the hand **cannot approach**, first administer **King-of-the-Vines Powder** (王不留行散) internally and **apply Breaking-the-Back Ointment** (发背膏) externally.

If the **back ulcer ruptures without pain**, and the carbuncle is on the **breast**, ensure it is **fully mature** (极熟). When pressing it **follows the hand’s movement** (随手即起), the ulcer is **ready for lancing** (疮熟). **Needle swiftly**, aiming for pus—**adjust depth intuitively** (以意消息). The needle should not penetrate **more than one inch** into the chest or back.

If **no pus is found**, apply **Meat-Eating Ointment** (食肉膏散) to the **carbuncle’s opening** (着兑头) and insert it into the **carbuncle’s cavity** (内痈口中). If the **body’s heat subsides**, administer **Mulberry Leaf Powder** (木占斯散).

After **five days**, if the carbuncle is **forming a scab** (欲着痂), prescribe **Pus-Draining Internal Plug Powder** (排脓内塞散).

After a carbuncle **ruptures**, the patient may feel **weak and near death**, with **internal cold and external heat** (内寒外热). Some swellings **resemble carbuncles but are not**—press the swelling: if it **does not connect to deeper tissues**, it is **wind-toxin** (风毒). **Do not lance it**; instead, administer **Cangzhu Decoction** (升麻汤) and apply **Cangzhu Ointment** (摩升麻膏). When lancing, leave **three fen at the top** and **one fen at the bottom**—ensure the area is **extremely hot** (极热), which **relieves pain**.

If the carbuncle **decays without healing**, wash it with **Pig’s Hoof Decoction** (猪蹄汤), **twice daily**. In summer, **two days** suffice; in winter, **six or seven days**. Even **half a dose** may help.

If **necrotic flesh** remains after decay, wash with **Pig’s Hoof Decoction** to remove impurities, then apply **Meat-Eating Ointment** (食肉膏散). Once all **necrotic tissue is gone**, apply **Fresh Meat Ointment** (生肉膏散) and **rub the edges** (摩四边) to **promote healthy tissue growth**.

**Avoid sexual activity**, **guard against wind and cold**, and **prevent overexertion**. Only when **tendons and vessels recover** may normal activities resume.

**New flesh is fragile**—if injured, it **may ulcerate again**, leading to **recurrence**, which is **difficult to treat**. **Exercise utmost caution**, especially with **white scabs** (白痂).

For **all sudden swellings**, regardless of location, administer **Five-Spice Forsythia Decoction** (五香连翘汤), **lance to bleed**, and apply **mung bean powder** (小豆末). **Frequently lance to bleed** between doses.

If treatment is **delayed and ulceration occurs**, continue with **Five-Spice Decoction** and **Drainage Decoction** (漏芦汤), adjusting the dose based on **heat severity**. Externally, apply **Cangzhu Decoction** (升麻汤) to **wash and warm** the area. *(See section on **Danpox** (丹毒) for **Cangzhu Ointment** (摩升麻膏).)*

If **fleshy polyps** arise, apply **White Simplified Poria Powder** (白简茹散) until all **greenish-black necrotic flesh** is gone, then cease. Once **healthy flesh regenerates**, apply **Cangzhu Ointment** (升麻膏). If **no new flesh forms**, apply **One-Ingredient Astragalus Powder** (一物黄耆散). Should **White Simplified Poria Powder** fail to remove all **greenish-black malignant flesh**, mix **half a *cash* of Lacquered Poria Powder** (漆头茹散) with **three *cash* of White Simplified Poria Powder**, applying gradually. Each powder must be **ground separately by color**, sifted, and used as-is.

These methods are recorded in *Ji Yan* (《集验》) for treating **slow abscesses**.

Sometimes, **sudden localized pain** occurs—like after a blow—known as **Qi Pain** (气痛). The pain is **unbearable**, **wandering and relentless**, flaring at intervals. When it strikes, **mild fever** follows; when it subsides, **chill** ensues. This stems from **winter exposure to warm *qi*** (温气), followed by **spring’s sudden cold**, where **wind disrupts** it, preventing **warm disease** and instead causing **Qi Pain**. Treat first with **Five-Spice Forsythia Decoction** (五香连翘汤), apply **Dan Shēn Ointment** (摩丹参膏), and **warm-compress with wine-cooked willow bark**. If **red *qi* spots** appear, **lance to bleed**.

Continue with **Five-Spice Forsythia Decoction** and **Small Bamboo Juice Decoction** (小竹沥汤) for **multiple doses**—do not cease after one dose if no immediate relief, lest disaster follow. **White Wei Powder** (白薇散) is also beneficial mid-treatment.

For **Qi-induced swelling and pain**, resembling **abscesses but without a head**, **hollow swelling with unchanged skin color**, yet **tight skin and unbearable pain preventing touch**, again administer **Five-Spice Decoction**, followed by **White Needle Drainage** (白针泻), then apply **Spiny Cocklebur Powder** (蒺藜散).

If **chest pain** accompanies **shortness of breath**, enter a **dark room**, press your fingers on the **left eye**—if light appears, a **hidden abscess** lurks in the chest; if no light, the **disease has erupted internally as a carbuncle**. The *Classics* state:
*"When *qi* stagnates in the meridians, both *qi* and blood congeal, clotting into abscesses and carbuncles."* It does not specify **heat’s role**, yet later, **heat forms abscesses**. Further, **yang *qi* gathering** turns **cold into heat**, and **excessive heat rots flesh into pus**. When **body heat clashes with cold**, **pulse congeals and stagnates**, with **heat *qi* clotting into abscesses and carbuncles**.

Treatment may involve **moxibustion** or **warming therapy** for **early cold stages**, or **cooling herbs** for **established heat** to prevent suppuration. For **red, pointed swellings**, apply **Prickly Ash Ointment** (藜芦膏). Alternatively, **mix vinegar with crushed clam-shell ash**, reapplying when dry.

From my own experience, **abscesses and carbuncles** often stem from **medicinal *qi*** or **ancestral ingestion of minerals**, passing to descendants. **Dietarily**, avoid **fermented grains, alcohol, garlic**, and **overly warm beds or thick blankets**. Those who heed these precautions may **avoid such ailments lifelong**. These insights come from **personal verification**, hence their inclusion.

---
**Five-Spice Forsythia Decoction** (五香连翘汤)
*For all malignant nodules, scrofula, abscesses, and toxic swellings:*
**Green Wood Aromatic** (青木香) – 2 *liang*
**Deposited Aromatic** (沉香) – 2 *liang*
**Cinnamon Flower** (丁香) – 2 *liang*
**Aloeswood** (熏陆香) – 2 *liang*
**Musk** (麝香) – 2 *liang*
**Puncturevine** (射干) – 2 *liang*
**Cangzhu** (升麻) – 2 *liang*
**Solitary Activity** (独活) – 2 *liang*
**Dodder Seed** (寄生) – 2 *liang*
**Forsythia Fruit** (连翘) – 2 *liang*
**Medullary Bamboo** (通草) – 2 *liang*
**Rhubarb** (大黄) – 3 *liang*

*Decoction:* Chop all ingredients. Simmer in **9 *sheng* of water** until reduced to **4 *sheng***, then add **2 *sheng* of bamboo juice**, reducing further to **3 *sheng***. Divide into **three doses**, taken until **bowel movement is smooth**.

*The *Zhǒu Hòu* (《肘后》) version* includes **Purple Geum** (紫葛) and **Licorice** (甘草), omitting **Medullary Bamboo**, treating **malignant flesh, toxic vessels, nodules, and wind-induced swelling/pain**.

*The *Yào Jí Yù Yì* (《要籍喻义》) version* adds **Astragalus** (黄耆), **Licorice** (甘草), and **Mirabilite** (芒硝), each **6 *fēn***.

*The *Qiān Jīn Yì* (《千金翼》) states:* **"Continue dosing until recovery."** This overlaps with the **Pediatric Formulas**, with minor variations.

---
**Astragalus-Bamboo Leaf Decoction** (黄耆竹叶汤)
*For abscesses and carbuncles:*
**Astragalus** (黄耆) – 3 *liang*
**Licorice** (甘草) – 3 *liang*
**Scutellaria** (黄苓) – 3 *liang*
**Peony** (芍药) – 3 *liang*
**Twelve-Leaf Gentian** (麦门冬) – 3 *liang*
**Chinese Angelica** (当归) – 2 *liang*
**Ginseng** (人参) – 2 *liang*
**Gypsum** (石膏) – 2 *liang*
**Ligusticum** (芎藭) – 2 *liang*
**Pinellia** (半夏) – 2 *liang*
**Fresh Ginger** (生姜) – 5 *liang*
**Rehmannia Root** (生地黄) – 8 *liang*
**Jujube** (大枣) – 30 pieces
**Bamboo Leaves** (淡竹叶) – 1 handful

*Decoction:* Chop all. Simmer **12 *sheng* of water** after first boiling **bamboo leaves** to **10 *sheng***, then add remaining herbs, reducing to **3 *sheng***. Divide into **four doses**, taken every **20 *li* of travel time** (approx. 6–8 hours), **three times daily, once at night**.

---
**Eight-Flavor Astragalus Powder** (八味黄耆散)
*For external application:*
**Astragalus** (黄耆) – equal parts
**Ligusticum** (芎藭) – equal parts
**Rhubarb** (大黄) – equal parts
**Coptis** (黄连) – equal parts
**Peony** (芍药) – equal parts
**Imperata** (莽草) – equal parts
**Scutellaria** (黄苓) – equal parts
**Gardenia Fruit** (栀子仁) – equal parts

*Preparation:* Grind into powder, mix with **egg white** into a paste, spread on **clean cloth**, and apply based on swelling size. Replace when dry. If the abscess **opens**, seal the wound until the **head fully forms**.

---
**Vincetoxicum Powder** (王不留行散)
*For stubborn, non-draining abscesses:*
**Vincetoxicum Seed** (王不留行子) – 3 *ge* (*Qiān Jīn Yì* uses 1 *sheng*)
**Dragon Bone** (龙骨) – 2 *liang*
**Chinese Angelica** (当归) – 2 *liang*
**Wild Pueraria Root** (野葛皮) – 0.5 *liang*
**Dried Ginger** (乾姜) – 1 *liang*
**Cinnamon Bark** (桂心) – 1 *liang*
**Trichosanthes Root** (栝蒌根) – 0.6 *liang*

*Preparation:* Grind and sift. Take **1 *cùn* spoonful** in **warm wine after meals**, **three times daily**, until **limbs feel comfortably warm**. Gradually increase if needed—**pus will drain naturally**, the wound will heal, and recovery is swift. This is **Hào Zhòng Kān’s** formula. *Sù Jì Zé Lí* (隋济阇黎) called it the **"Divine Powder"**, dissolving abscesses entirely. *Qiān Jīn Yì* states it treats **all suppurating abscesses and mixed swellings**.

---
**Internal Supplement Powder** (内补散)
*For abscesses, carbuncles, breast abscesses in women, and unruptured boils:*
**Wood Occupy** (木占斯) – 1 *liang*
**Ginseng** (人参) – 1 *liang*
**Dried Ginger** (*or* **Rehmannia Root**) (乾姜/乾地黄) – 1 *liang*
**Cinnamon Bark** (桂心) – 1 *liang*
**Asarum** (细辛) – 1 *liang*
**Thick-Shell Bitter Orange** (厚朴) – 1 *liang*
**Fermented Safflower** (败酱防风) – 1 *liang*
**Trichosanthes Root** (栝蒌根) – 1 *liang*
**Platycodon Root** (桔梗) – 1 *liang*
**Licorice** (甘草) – 1 *liang*

「The following eleven ingredients treat **lower sores** (下筛): **Wood Occupy** (木占斯), **Ginseng** (人参), **Dried Ginger** (乾姜), **Cinnamon Bark** (桂心), **Asarum** (细辛), **Thick-Shell Bitter Orange** (厚朴), **Fermented Safflower** (败酱防风), **Trichosanthes Root** (栝蒌根), **Platycodon Root** (桔梗), **Licorice** (甘草), each 1 *liang*.
Take with wine, one **square-cubed spoonful** (方寸匕), until the medicine flows into the sore. For **carbuncles and abscesses** (痈疽) where moxibustion fails to rupture them, this remedy may be taken. If the abscess is unruptured, omit **Fermented Safflower**; if pus has already formed, include it. Take the medicine seven or eight times daily and two or three times at night—more frequent use is preferable. If the illness is in the lower body and **pus and blood** (脓血) are expected, this is **intestinal carbuncle** (肠痈). For all diseases affecting the lower region, take this medicine alone, and its efficacy will be felt: pain will cease, and prolonged use will harmonize all sores and **abscesses, hemorrhoids, and fistulas** (疽痔). If the wound has already ruptured, healing will be swift. Physicians unaware of this remedy have no cure for **unruptured abscesses** (发背). If a patient feels discomfort on the back and **thirst** (渴), it indicates the abscess is not yet resolved—take the medicine diligently. Once the medicine takes effect, the thirst will subside, and the swelling will dissipate. Even if the abscess has already ruptured, continue taking the medicine without interruption; the swelling will gradually vanish without notice. For long-term use, **Fermented Safflower** should be omitted. Women with **breast abscesses** (乳痈) should take it promptly.

Another formula, lacking **Cinnamon Bark**, is called **Wood Occupy Powder** (木占斯散), which treats **hard, stubborn abscesses and swellings** (痈肿坚结). If the abscess has already ruptured, healing will be rapid; if unruptured, it will prevent formation and dissolve the swelling. **Zhang Wenzhong** omitted **Cinnamon Bark**, while **Liu Xunzi** stated this is **Hua Tuo’s** formula.

**Pus-Draining Internal Plug Powder** (排脓内塞散), for **large sores** (大疮) where fever has subsided but **pus and blood** (脓血) persist, and where the wound is hollow with lingering pain:
**Siler** (防风), **Poria** (茯苓), **Angelica Root** (白芷), **Platycodon Root** (桔梗), **Schisandra Berry** (远志), **Licorice** (甘草), **Ginseng** (人参), **Peony Root** (芍药), **Angelica** (当归), **Astragalus Root** (黄耆), each 1 *liang*; **Thick-Shell Bitter Orange** (厚朴) 2 *liang*; **Cinnamon Bark** (桂心) 2 *fen*; **Aconite** (附子) 2 pieces; **Red Adzuki Beans** (赤小豆) 5 *he*, soaked in wine and simmered.
These fourteen ingredients treat **lower sores** (下筛); take with wine, one **square-cubed spoonful** (方寸匕), three times daily and once at night.

**Pig’s Hoof Soup** (猪蹄汤), for **carbuncles, abscesses, and unruptured abscesses** (痈疽发背):
One **pig’s hoof** (猪蹄), prepared as food; **Astragalus Root** (黄耆), **Coptis Rhizome** (黄连), **Peony Root** (芍药), each 3 *liang*; **Rose Root** (蔷薇根), **Lycium Root** (狼牙根), each 8 *liang*.
These seven ingredients, chopped, are simmered in 3 *dou* of water until the hoof is cooked. Strain and take 2 *dou*, then add the medicines and reduce to 1 *dou*. Discard the dregs, and wash the wound for about half an hour. Dry with cloth, then apply **fresh meat paste** (生肉膏) once daily. If pain persists, add **Angelica** (当归) and **Licorice** (甘草), each 2 *liang*.

Another formula treats **carbuncles and abscesses** (痈疽) spreading to all ten fingers, or rising from the **bladder** (膀胱), or generating **malignant flesh** (恶肉) after **unruptured abscesses** (发背):
One **pig’s hoof** (猪蹄), prepared as food; **Angelica** (当归), **Rhubarb** (大黄), **Ligusticum Root** (芎藭), **Peony Root** (芍药), **Scutellaria Root** (黄苓), **Corydalis Rhizome** (独活), **Imperata Rhizome** (莽草), each 1 *liang*.
These eight ingredients, chopped, are simmered in 3 *dou* of water until the hoof is cooked. Take 8 *sheng*, strain, then add the medicines and reduce to 4 *sheng*. Discard the dregs, and soak the wound for two meals’ duration. Wash it, dry thoroughly, and apply **Musk Paste** (麝香膏).

**Musk Paste** (麝香膏), for **all malignant sores** (痈疽及发背诸恶疮) and **removing malignant flesh** (去恶肉):
**Musk** (麝香), **Margarita Pearl** (真珠), **Realgar** (雄黄), **Alum** (矾石), each 1 *liang*.
These four ingredients are ground into powder, mixed with **pork fat** (猜膏) into a paste, and applied to the wound. The **malignant flesh** (恶肉) will cease, and **fresh meat paste** (生肉膏) may then be reapplied.

**Paste for Malignant Flesh** (食恶肉膏):
**Rhubarb** (大黄), **Ligusticum Root** (芎藭), **Imperata Rhizome** (莽草), **Margarita Pearl** (真珠), **Orpiment** (雌黄), **Aconite** (附子, raw), each 1 *liang*; **White Lead** (白敛), **Alum** (矾石), **Scutellaria Root** (黄苓), **Margarita Pearl** (真珠), **Realgar** (雄黄), each 2 *liang*.
These eleven ingredients, chopped, are simmered in 1 *shang* and 4 *liang* of **pork fat** (猪脂) until it boils five or six times. Discard the dregs, then mix in **Margarita Pearl** (真珠) and **Alum** (矾石) powder, stirring well before applying to the wound. The **malignant flesh** (恶肉) will cease entirely.

For **abscesses and swellings** (痈肿) where **malignant flesh** (恶肉) persists:
**Caltrop Fruit** (蒴藋灰) or **Caltrop Ash** (藋灰), **Lime Ash** (石灰, or **white charcoal ash** (白炭灰) in *Zhǒuhòu* [肘后]).
Take the juice from each, combine, and simmer into a paste. Apply to the wound; the **malignant flesh** (恶肉) will stop, and **black moles** (黑子) will also be removed.
This remedy loses efficacy after ten days.

Another formula: Simmer **raw Rehmannia Root juice** (生地黄汁) into a **glue-like consistency** (如胶), shape into **pills** (饼子), and apply four or five times daily.

**Powder for Malignant Flesh** (食恶肉散):
**Sulfur** (硫黄), **Cinnabar** (丹砂), **Musk** (麝香), **Mollified Margarita Pearl** (漆头真珠), **Alum** (马齿矾), **Realgar** (雄黄), **Orpiment** (雌黄), **White Alum** (白矾), each 2 *fen*.
These eight ingredients are ground into powder and applied to **malignant flesh** (恶肉) for it to be sucked away. The *Qian Jin Yi* (《千金翼》) section on **thin applications** (薄帖篇) omits **White Alum** (白矾) and **Orpiment** (雌黄), instead including **Puncturevine** (藜芦), stating it may also be mixed into a paste and applied. The *Qian Jin Yi* section on **treating carbuncles and abscesses** (处疗痈疽篇) omits **Cinnabar** (丹砂). The *Guang Ji Fang* (《广济方》) states that for **abscesses and swellings** (痈肿) where pus has ruptured and **purple flesh** (紫肉) remains in the wound, this powder may be mixed with water or applied internally.

Another formula:
**Mollified Margarita Pearl** (简茹), **Alum** (矾石), **Realgar** (雄黄), **Sulfur** (硫黄), each 2 *fen*.
These four ingredients are applied to the wound; the **malignant flesh** (恶肉) will cease entirely without harming **healthy flesh** (好肉).

**Fresh Meat Paste** (生肉膏), for **carbuncles and abscesses** (痈疽) and **unruptured abscesses** (发背) after rupture, when new flesh forms:
**Raw Rehmannia Root** (生地黄) 1 *jin*; **Magnolia Flower Bud** (辛夷) 2 *liang*; **Corydalis Rhizome** (独活), **Angelica** (当归), **Rhubarb** (大黄), **Astragalus Root** (黄耆), **Ligusticum Root** (芎藭), **Angelica Root** (白芷), **Peony Root** (芍药), **Scutellaria Root** (黄苓), **Euryale Seed** (续断), each 1 *liang*; **Lotus Leaf** (莲白) 5 *liang*.
These twelve ingredients, chopped, are simmered in **pork fat** (猪脂) collected in the twelfth lunar month (腊月), 4 *sheng*, until it boils. Remove the **Angelica Root** (白芷) and **Scutellaria Root** (黄苓) before discarding the dregs, then apply the paste—healing will occur immediately.

Another formula:
**Licorice** (甘草), **Angelica** (当归), **Angelica Root** (白芷), **Cistanche** (苁蓉), **Sichuan Peppercorn** (蜀椒), **Asarum** (细辛), each 2 *liang*; **Crow’s Beak** (乌啄) 6 *fen*, raw; **Snake’s Tongue** (蛇衔) 1 *liang*; **Belamcanda Rhizome** (薤白) 20 stalks; **Rehmannia Root** (乾地黄) 3 *liang*.
These ten ingredients, chopped, are steeped in vinegar overnight. The next day, simmer in 3 *jin* of **pork fat** (猪膏) until boiling, repeating the process of adding and removing the fat three times. Once the paste is ready, apply it—healing will occur immediately.

**Snake’s Tongue Fresh Meat Paste** (蛇衔生肉膏), for **carbuncles and abscesses** (痈疽) and **golden sores** (金疮) that have deteriorated:

**Snake’s Tongue and Angelica Root Paste**
**Angelica Root** (当归) and **Snake’s Tongue** (蛇衔), each 6 *fen*;
**Rehmannia Root** (乾地黄) 3 *liang*;
**Coptis** (黄连), **Astragalus** (黄耆), **Scutellaria** (黄苓), **Rhubarb** (大黄), **Continuing Cynanchum** (续断), **Sichuan Peppercorn** (蜀椒), **Peony Root** (芍药), **Bulbine** (白芨), **Ligusticum** (芎藭), **Imperata** (莽草), **Angelica Root** (白芷), **Aconite** (附子), **Licorice** (甘草), **Asarum** (细辛), each 1 *liang*;
**Belamcanda Rhizome** (薤白) 1 stalk.
These eighteen ingredients, chopped, are steeped in vinegar for two nights. In the twelfth month, simmer in 7 *sheng* of **pork fat** (猪脂), repeating the process of adding and removing the fat three times. Once the vinegar is exhausted, discard the dregs and apply the paste. Use twice daily and once at night.

*Chuai’s Formula* omits **Rehmannia Root**, **Coptis**, **Astragalus**, **Continuing Cynanchum**, **Bulbine**, **Ligusticum**, **Angelica Root**, and **Licorice**, but includes **Cantharis** (大戟) and **Siler** (独活), each 1 *liang*.

---
**Five-Aroma Decoction** (五香汤), for **heat-toxin** (热毒气), sudden swelling and pain, nodular formations, or conditions resembling **carbuncles and abscesses** (痈疖) but not so—causing headache, chills, fever, and breathlessness, persisting for days and proving fatal:
**Aquilaria** (青木香), **Patchouli** (藿香), **Aloeswood** (熏陆香), **Sandalwood** (沉香), **Clove** (丁香), each 1 *liang*.
These five ingredients, chopped, are boiled in 5 *sheng* of water, reduced to 2 *sheng*, and taken in three divided doses. If no improvement, repeat, and apply the dregs to the swelling. *The Thousand-Gold Prescriptions* substitutes **Musk** (麝香) for **Patchouli**.

**Drainage Decoction** (漏芦汤) for urgent purgation:
**Drainage Reed** (漏芦), **Bulbine** (白芨), **Scutellaria** (黄苓), **Ephedra** (麻黄), **White Honeysuckle** (白薇), **Immature Bitter Orange** (枳实), **Cimicifuga** (升麻), **Peony Root** (芍药), **Licorice** (甘草), each 2 *liang*;
**Rhubarb** (大黄) 3 *liang*.
These ten ingredients, chopped, are boiled in 1 *dou* of water, reduced to 3 *sheng*, and taken in three divided doses, with urgent purgation. In the absence of other herbs, **Rhubarb** alone suffices. *The Emergency Formulas* states it treats **carbuncles and abscesses**, **measles**, **toxic swellings**, and **malignant flesh**. *The Thousand-Gold Prescriptions* omits **White Honeysuckle**. *Liu’s Formulas* omits **Peony Root**, substituting **Forsythia** (连翘), for **seasonal heat-toxin**, transforming into red **carbuncles and abscesses**, **measles**, **toxic swellings**, and **eye inflammation with pain and visual obstruction**. If heat is severe, add **Mirabilite** (芒硝) 2 *liang*. *The Record of the Heart* omits **White Honeysuckle**, adding **Anemarrhena** (知母), **Rhinoceros Horn** (犀角), and **Mirabilite**, each 2 *liang*. This decoction overlaps with the pediatric section but differs in dosage.

---
**Salvia Miltiorrhiza Paste** (丹参膏):
**Salvia Miltiorrhiza** (丹参), **Cnidium Fruit** (蒴藋), **Imperata** (莽草), **Sichuan Peppercorn** (蜀椒), **Candelabra Cactus** (踯烛), each 2 *liang*;
**Siler** (独活), **Bulbine** (白芨), **Cynanchum** (牛膝), **Chrysanthemum** (菊花), **Aconite** (乌头), **Tripterygium** (防己), each 1 *liang*.
These twelve ingredients, chopped, are steeped in 2 *sheng* of vinegar overnight (or half a day in summer; if urgent, proceed immediately). Simmer in 4 *sheng* of **pork fat** until the vinegar scent dissipates, then reduce with gentle heat, discard the dregs, and apply to the affected area five or six times daily. *The Emergency Formulas* uses **Saposhnikovia** (防风) instead of **Tripterygium**, treating **malignant flesh**, **malignant nodules**, **scrofula**, and **wind-induced swellings**, noting the paste may also be ingested.

---
**Bamboo Sap Decoction** (小竹沥汤), for **gas-related pain** (气痛):
**Bamboo Sap** (淡竹沥) 2 *sheng*;
**Belamcanda Rhizome** (射干), **Apricot Kernel** (杏仁), **Siler** (独活), **Immature Bitter Orange** (枳实), **Atractylodes** (白朮), **Tripterygium** (防己), **Saposhnikovia** (防风), **Siler** (秦艽), **Peony Root** (芍药), **Licorice** (甘草), **Colocasia** (茵芋), **Poria** (茯苓), **Scutellaria** (黄苓), **Ephedra** (麻黄), each 2 *liang*.
These fifteen ingredients, chopped, are boiled in 9 *sheng* of water, reduced to half, then the sap is added and boiled again to 3 *sheng*, divided into four doses.

---
**White Honeysuckle Powder** (白薇散):
**White Honeysuckle** (白薇), **Saposhnikovia** (防风), **Belamcanda Rhizome** (射干), **Atractylodes** (白朮), each 6 *fen*;
**Ephedra** (麻黄), **Siler** (秦艽), each 5 *fen*;
**Angelica Root** (当归), **Tripterygium** (防己), **Aconite** (乌头), **Aquilaria** (青木香), **Asparagus Tubers** (天门冬), **Immature Bitter Orange** (枳实), **Siler** (独活), **Hemiphragmium** (萎蕤), **Cornus** (山茱萸), each 4 *fen*;
**Bupleurum** (柴胡), **Angelica Root** (白芷), each 3 *fen*;
**Imperata** (莽草), **Sichuan Peppercorn** (蜀椒), each 2 *fen*.
These nineteen ingredients treat **diarrhea with straining** (下筛), taken in a *fangcun* spoonful with gruel, three times daily, increasing to two spoonfuls.

---
**Spiny Cocklebur Powder** (蒺藜散), for **gas-induced swelling and pain** (气肿痛):
**Spiny Cocklebur Seed** (蒺藜子) 1 *sheng*, roasted until yellow, ground into powder, mixed with **sesame oil** (麻油) into a paste, fried until blackened, and applied to a warm cloth cut to the swelling’s size—do not puncture. If **Spiny Cocklebur** is unavailable, substitute **mung bean** (小豆) powder mixed with **egg** (鸡子) as above, drying and replacing as needed.

---
**Bitter Apricot Kernel Paste** (藜芦膏), for **red swellings with pointed tips** (赤色肿有尖头者):
**Bitter Apricot Kernel** (藜芦) 2 *fen*;
**Coptis** (黄连), **Alum** (矾石), **Realgar** (雄黄), **Pine Resin** (松脂), **Scutellaria** (黄苓), each 8 *fen*.
These six ingredients, ground into powder, are simmered in 2 *sheng* 2 *ge* of **pork fat** until melted, mixed, and applied. Effective for **eczema** (瘑癣), **head sores**, and **chronic scratched ulcers** that have formed open wounds.

---
**Dianthus Powder** (瞿麦散), for **carbuncles and abscesses**, to **drain pus**, **alleviate pain**, and **promote urination**:
**Dianthus** (瞿麦) 1 *liang*;
**Peony Root** (芍药), **Cinnamon Bark** (桂心), **Red Adzuki Bean** (赤小豆, soaked in alcohol and roasted), **Ophiopogon** (麦门冬), **Ligusticum** (芎藭), **Astragalus** (黄耆), **Angelica Root** (当归), **White Atractylodes** (白敛), each 2 *liang*.
These nine ingredients treat **diarrhea with straining**, taken on an empty stomach with a *fangcun* spoonful in alcohol, three times daily. *The Thousand-Gold Prescriptions* substitutes **Asarum** (细辛), **Coix Seed** (薏苡仁), and **Angelica Root** (白芷), omitting **Cinnamon Bark**, **Ophiopogon**, and **White Atractylodes**, for **various carbuncles** (whether ulcerated or not), **painful sores with unremitting pus and blood**, and unbearable agony.

---
**Coix Seed Powder** (薏苡仁散), for **carbuncles and abscesses** to **induce ulceration and promote flesh regeneration**:
**Coix Seed** (薏苡仁), **Cinnamon Bark** (桂心), **White Atractylodes** (白敛), **Angelica Root** (当归), **Corydalis Tuber** (茯蓉), **Dried Ginger** (乾姜), each 2 *liang*.
These six ingredients treat **diarrhea with straining**, taken on an empty stomach with warm alcohol in a *fangcun* spoonful, three times daily and twice at night.

---
**Astragalus and Poria Decoction** (黄耆茯苓汤), for **carbuncles and abscesses** with **excessive pus post-ulceration** and **constitutional heat**:
**Astragalus** (黄耆), **Ophiopogon** (麦门冬), each 3 *liang*;
**Fresh Ginger** (生姜) 4 *liang*;
**Schisandra Berry** (五味子) 4 *ge*;
**Ligusticum** (芎藭), **Poria** (茯苓), **Cinnamon Bark** (桂心), each 2 *liang*;
**Jujube** (大枣) 20 pieces.
These eight ingredients, chopped, are boiled in 1.5 *dou* of water, reduced to 4 *sheng*, and taken in six divided doses.

**Astragalus and Rehmannia Decoction** (黄耆地黄圆) from *The Thousand-Gold Supplement* (《千金翼》):
For **carbuncles and abscesses** (痈疽) with **internal heat** (宿热), **Rehmannia Root** (地黄) 2 *liang*;
**Angelica Root** (当归), **Ginseng** (人参), each 2 *liang*;
**Licorice Root** (甘草) 6 *liang*.
This decoction treats **all types of carbuncles and abscesses** (痈疽) and is suitable for long-term use.

**Mung Bean Decoction** (赤小豆醋), for **carbuncles and abscesses** (痈疽):
**Mung Beans** (赤小豆) 1 *sheng* soaked in vinegar and roasted#11;
**Ginseng** (人参), **Licorice Root** (甘草), **Dianthus Root** (瞿麦), **Angelica Root** (当归), **Hoelen** (猪苓), **Scutellaria Root** (黄苓), each 2 *liang*;
**White Atractylodes** (白敛), **Coix Seed** (薏苡仁), **Astragalus** (黄耆), each 3 *liang*;
**Siler Root** (防风) 1 *liang*;
**Cimicifuga Root** (升麻) 4 *liang*.
These twelve ingredients, chopped, are taken with a *fangcun* spoonful of warm alcohol, three times daily and twice at night. Long-term use leads to **cure** (瘥).

**Hedgehog Skin Powder** (猬皮散), for **carbuncles and abscesses** (痈疽) with **pus and blood leakage** (脓血内漏), **various types of internal discharge** (诸漏壤败), **back abscesses in men** (男发背) and **breast abscesses in women** (女乳房), as well as **five types of hemorrhoids** (及五痔):
**Hedgehog Skin** (猬皮) 1 piece;
**Bee Hives** (蜂房) 1 piece;
**Potentilla Root** (地榆), **Aconite Root** (附子), **Cinnamon Bark** (桂心), **Angelica Root** (当归), **Siebold’s Continuous Sedge Root** (续断), each 5 *fen*;
**Dried Ginger** (乾姜), **Sichuan Peppercorn** (蜀椒), **Cnidium Rhizome** (稿本), each 4 *fen*;
**Magnolia Bark** (厚朴) 6 *fen*.
These eleven ingredients, chopped, are taken with a *fangcun* spoonful of warm alcohol on an empty stomach, three times daily, until **cure** (瘥). Adding **leopard cat** (斑猫) 7 pieces enhances efficacy.

For those suffering from **carbuncles and abscesses** (肿) due to **constitutional heat** (虚热), if **diarrhea with cold** (冷利) persists after recovery, use:
**Ginseng** (人参), **Dragon Bone** (龙骨), **Red Sappanwood** (赤石脂)#12, **Licorice Root** (甘草), **Dried Ginger** (乾姜), each 2 *liang*;
**Aconite Root** (附子) 1 piece.
These six ingredients, chopped, are boiled in 8 *sheng* of water, reduced to 2.5 *sheng*, and taken in three divided doses, each 8 *ge*.

**Gardenia Rhizome Decoction** (栀子汤), for **both external and internal heat** (表裹俱热), **empty three *jiao*** (三焦不实), **bodily sores** (身体生疮), as well as **carbuncles and abscesses** (发痈廊) with **constipation** (大小便不利):
**Gardenia Fruit** (栀子仁) 27 pieces;
**Mirabilite** (芒硝) 2 *liang*;
**Scutellaria Root** (黄苓), **Licorice Root** (甘草), **Anemarrhena Rhizome** (知母), each 3 *liang*;
**Rhubarb Root** (大黄) 4 *liang*.
These six ingredients, chopped, are boiled in 5 *sheng* of water, reduced to half, and **Rhubarb Root** (大黄) is added. The decoction is strained to take 1.8 *sheng*, then **Mirabilite** (芒硝) is added, and taken in three divided doses.

**Five-Power Decoction** (五利汤), for **strong individuals aged forty or older** who often suffer from **excessive heat** (强壮常大患热) and **carbuncles and abscesses** (痈疽) with **no fixed location** (无定处), as well as **constipation** (大小便不通):
Named **Rhubarb Decoction** (大黄汤) in *Liu Xuanzi’s Treatise* (《刘涓子》).
**Mirabilite** (芒硝) 1 *liang*;
**Cimicifuga Root** (升麻), **Scutellaria Root** (黄苓), each 2 *liang*;
**Rhubarb Root** (大黄) 3 *liang*;
**Gardenia Fruit** (栀子仁) 5 *liang*.
These five ingredients, chopped, are boiled in 5 *sheng* of water, reduced to 2.4 *sheng*, strained, and **Mirabilite** (芒硝) is added. Taken in four divided doses, stop when **bowel movement is smooth** (快利).

**Rehmannia Pills** (乾地黄圆), for **strong individuals with excessive heat** (壮热人) who can take them long-term:
**Rehmannia Root** (乾地黄) 5 *liang*;
**Peony Root** (芍药), **Licorice Root** (甘草), **Cinnamon Bark** (桂心), **Astragalus** (黄耆), **Scutellaria Root** (黄苓), **Polygala Root** (远志), each 2 *liang*;
**Dendrobium Stem** (石斛), **Angelica Root** (当归), **Rhubarb Root** (大黄), each 3 *liang*;
**Morinda Root** (巴戟天), **Trichosanthes Root** (栝蒌根), **Ginseng** (人参), each 1 *liang*;
**Ophiopogon Tuber** (天门冬), **Cistanche Stem** (苁蓉), each 4 *liang*.
These fifteen ingredients are ground into powder, formed into honey pills the size of **walnut kernels** (梧子). Taken with alcohol, 10 pills daily, three times, increasing to 20 pills.

Another formula, for **constitutional heat** (虚热) and **dissolving boils and carbuncles** (消疮疖):
**Rehmannia Root** (乾地黄) 4 *liang*;
**Rhubarb Root** (大黄) 6 *fen*;
**Peony Root** (芍药), **Violet Herb** (王不留行), **Poria** (茯苓), **Licorice Root** (甘草), **Polygala Root** (远志), **Ophiopogon Tuber** (麦门冬), **Ginseng** (人参), **Cimicifuga Root** (升麻), **Scutellaria Root** (黄苓), each 3 *liang*;
**Cinnamon Bark** (桂心) 6 *liang*.
These twelve ingredients are ground into powder, formed into honey pills the size of **walnut kernels** (梧子大). Taken with alcohol, 10 pills daily, three times, increasing to 20 pills. Long-term use promotes **fatness and health** (肥健).

One variation includes **Citrus Aurantium Fruit** (枳实) 3 *liang*. The *Essentials of External Medicine* (《外台》) omits **Licorice Root** (甘草), **Polygala Root** (远志), **Ophiopogon Tuber** (麦门冬), **Ginseng** (人参), **Cimicifuga Root** (升麻), and **Scutellaria Root** (黄苓).

Another formula, for **constitutional heat** (虚劳客热) and **frequent carbuncles and abscesses** (数发痈肿疮疖) that persist for years:
**Rehmannia Root** (乾地黄) 4 *liang*;
**Astragalus** (黄耆), **Scutellaria Root** (黄苓), **Rhubarb Root** (大黄), **Coptis Rhizome** (黄连), **Alisma Rhizome** (泽泻), **Asarum Rhizome** (细辛), each 3 *liang*;
**Licorice Root** (甘草), **Cinnamon Bark** (桂心), **Peony Root** (芍药), **Poria** (茯苓), **Dried Lacquer** (乾漆), each 2 *liang*;
**Ginseng** (人参) 1 *liang*;
**Ophiopogon Tuber** (天门冬) 5 *liang*.
These fourteen ingredients are ground into powder, formed into honey pills the size of **walnut kernels** (梧子大). Taken with alcohol, 10 pills daily, three times and once at night, increasing to 20 pills. Long-term use extends **longevity** (延年) and prevents **carbuncles and abscesses** (痈疽) for life.

**Note on preparation of Rhubarb Root** (大黄):
Thinly sliced, steamed with 5 *sheng* of rice until cooked, dried, and used. If **heat is excessive** (热多), double the amount of **Rhubarb Root** (大黄). The *Key Texts with Explanations* (《要籍喻义》) omits **Alisma Rhizome** (泽泻).

**Rehmannia Decoction** (地黄煎), for **tonifying deficiency and clearing heat** (补虚除热), **dispersing milk stones** (散乳石), and **treating carbuncles, abscesses, and hemorrhoids** (去痈疖痔疾):
**Fresh Rehmannia Root** (生地黄) in varying amounts, pounded and pressed three times, with the juice extracted. Boiled in a copper vessel with water, uncovered to allow **qi** (气) to disperse, reduced to half. Strained through cloth to remove coarse, clotted, and turbid residues, then decocted again until it thickens like **molasses** (饧). Formed into pills the size of **small shot** (弹丸许), taken with alcohol, three times daily, without increasing the dose. After 100 days, **carbuncles and abscesses** (痈疽) will never recur.

**Goji Berry Decoction** (枸杞煎), for **constitutional heat** (虚劳) and **lightening the body while nourishing *qi*** (轻身益气):
**Goji Berry** (枸杞) 30 *jin*, chopped. If leaves are fresh but not yet fallen, use the **stem** (茎); if leaves have fallen but not yet regrown, use the **root** (根). Boiled in 1 *dan* of water, reduced to 5 *dou*, strained to remove residues. The residues are reboiled in the same amount of water, reduced to another 5 *dou*, combined with the first decoction to make 1 *hu* (斛). The mixture is clarified, strained again, and decocted until 2 *dou* remain. Further decocted in a small copper pot until it thickens like **molasses** (饧), or simmered in a vessel with water until the same consistency is achieved. Taken daily, 1.5 *ge* in the morning and another 1.5 *ge* in the afternoon. Start with 1 *ge*, gradually increasing. This also treats **wind-dampness bodily pain** (风湿体痛) and **inability to eat**, as well as **replenishing deficiency post-carbuncle** (痈疽后补虚赢).

For **wind-dampness bodily pain** (风湿体痛), **inability to eat**, and **post-carbuncle deficiency** (痈疽后补虚赢):
**Rose Root** (蔷薇根) 100 *jin*;
**Goji Root** (枸杞根) 100 *jin*;
**Honey** (食蜜) 10 *jin*;
**Fresh Rehmannia Root** (生地黄) 10 *jin*.

The four ingredients above, coarsely chopped, are first decocted with water to concentrate the two roots, reducing to two *hu*. The dregs are removed, then Rehmannia is added and simmered until soft. Strain and decoct gently over low heat until it thickens like gruel. Honey is then added, stirring until well incorporated. Take after meals, a quantity roughly the size of a *dàn* (弹丸).

**Treatment for Edema (扬肿方):**
Rhubarb (*Dàhuáng* 大黄) 3 *fèn* (分);
Scutellaria (*Huángqín* 黄苓) 3 *fèn*;
White Lead (*Báiliàn* 白敛) 3 *fèn*;
Mirabilite (*Mángxiāo* 芒硝) 3 *fèn*.

The four ingredients, coarsely chopped, are decocted with six *shēng* (升) of water, reducing to three *shēng*. A four-layered silk cloth is dipped in the strained liquid and applied to the swollen area. Replace when dry, without limit, day and night.

**Another Prescription for Early Carbuncle (痈疽始作), with Rapid Swelling, Redness, and Heat:**
Green Wood Aromatic (*Qīngmùxiāng* 青木香) 2 *fèn*;
Rhinoceros Horn (*Xījiǎo* 犀角) 2 *fèn*;
Rhubarb (*Dàhuáng* 大黄) 2 *fèn*;
Gardenia Fruit (*Zhīzǐ* 栀子仁) 2 *fèn*;
Sandalwood (*Zǐtánxiāng* 紫檀香) 2 *fèn*;
Cimicifuga (*Shēngmá* 升麻) 2 *fèn*;
Scutellaria (*Huángqín* 黄苓) 2 *fèn*;
Antelope Horn (*Língyángjiǎo* 羚羊角) 2 *fèn*;
Coptis (*Huánglián* 黄连) 2 *fèn*;
Licorice (*Gāncǎo* 甘草) 2 *fèn*;
Mirabilite (*Mángxiāo* 芒硝) 2 *fèn*;
Belamcanda (*Shègān* 射干) 2 *fèn*;
Berberine (*Huángbài* 黄檗) 2 *fèn*;
White Lead (*Báiliàn* 白敛) 2 *fèn*;
Rehmannia Juice (*Dìhuáng zhī* 地黄汁) 5 *hé* (合);
Musk (*Shèxiāng* 麝香) 1 *fèn*.

All sixteen ingredients, coarsely chopped, are decocted with five *shēng* of water, reducing to two *shēng*. When slightly cooled, a two-layered silk cloth is dipped in the broth and applied to the swollen area. Replace when dry, applying repeatedly day and night.

**Prescription for Swelling on Neck, Shoulders, Chest, or Back, Preventing Abscess Formation:**
Pericarpium Citri Reticulatae (*Pòxiāo*朴消) 5 *liǎng* (两);
Fermented Soybeans (*Xiāngchǐ* 香豉) ½ *jīn* (斤);
Rehmannia Juice (*Shēngdìhuáng zhī* 生地黄汁) ½ *jīn*.

The three ingredients are pounded together and cooked until the Rehmannia is thoroughly softened. Apply thickly (about 2 *fèn*) to the swollen area, replacing three to four times daily until cured. This treats all types of swelling.

**Prescription for Carbuncle Pain and Restlessness:**
Fresh *Jiūlěi* (*Shēngjiūlěi yè* 生揪叶) is layered ten times and applied, wrapped with cloth to allow for expansion and contraction. Replace twice daily. It effectively stops pain, reduces swelling, and drains pus—superior to other methods. If dried in winter, moisten before use or thinly scrape the bark for application.

**Prescription for Adult and Child Paralytic Swelling (瘫肿):**
Fresh pig brain is applied to paper and affixed to the swelling. Replace when dry, three to four times daily.

**Another Prescription:**
Mustard seeds (*Jièzǐ* 芥子) are ground into powder, mixed with hot water, and applied to paper before affixing. *Qīanjīnyì* (*千金翼*) suggests mixing with pig bile for application.

**Another Prescription:**
Powdered *Báijiāngshí* (白姜石) is mixed with minced garlic and applied.

**Another Prescription:**
Crushed *Mǎbiāncǎo* (马鞭草) is applied until the head of the carbuncle emerges.

**Another Prescription:**
Moxibustion at the *Qízhōng* (奇中) point on both big toes immediately cures the condition, following the affected side.

**Prescription to Dissolve Early Carbuncle Swelling:**
Rhubarb (*Dàhuáng* 大黄) 1 part;
Medulla Tetrapanacis (*Tōngcǎo* 通草) 1 part;
Balloonflower Root (*Yòujī* 葶苈) 1 part;
Desert Ephedra (*Mángcǎo* 莽草) 1 part.

All four are ground into powder, mixed with water, and applied. Replace when dry.

**Another Prescription:**
Powdered *Qíngèruò* (茛若) is taken with water, three times daily—a divine remedy.

**Prescription for Carbuncle:**
Powdered *Yúhuā* (芫花) is mixed with glue into a gruel-like paste and applied.

**Prescription for Multiple Carbuncles on the Abdomen, Back, or Hidden Areas, or Numerous Carbuncles Across the Body:**
Dried cow dung is burned to ash, sifted, and mixed with egg white for application. Replace when dry.

**Prescription for Consolidated Pus (to Promote Drainage):**
Powdered *Guāluó* (栝蒌) root is mixed with sour wine and applied. Replace when dry. Red Bean (*Chìdòu* 赤小豆) is also effective.

**Prescription to Induce Pus Drainage in Abscesses:**
Thirty-seven chicken feathers are burned to ash and taken orally to induce drainage.

**Another Prescription:**
Fermented paste (*Pú* 曲) mixed with human milk is applied. By dawn, all pus and blood will have drained without needing to touch the wound.

**Another Prescription:**
Burned tinfoil (*Bó* 箔) is ground into powder and mixed with lard from December pigs. Applied to the edge of the swelling, it induces drainage without need for acupuncture or moxibustion.

**Prescription for Severe Carbuncle on the Back, with Swelling, Redness, Heat, and Toxic Qi, Causing Day-and-Night Pain Resistant to All Other Treatments:**
Fresh *Dǒujīzǐ* (赌鸡子) egg, newly laid;
Dog feces, the size of a chicken egg.

The two are mixed and simmered gently until the consistency is just right, formed into cakes. Apply to the firmest part of the swelling, covering with paper and securing with cloth. Observe frequently—when the cake grows warm, replace it immediately. Do not allow it to cool or lose contact. After one night, the condition will stabilize. For long-standing cases, apply for three days, replacing once daily until cured. Though foul and unrefined, this prescription surpasses all others in efficacy. It should not be used on nobles, but its curative power is unmatched. Scholars must master this remedy for emergencies.

**Wu Má Gāo (乌麻膏) for All Ulcers, Malignant Sores, Thirteen Types of Edema, Multicolored Wandering Swellings, Carbuncle Toxic Heat, Fox/Weasel Bites, Snakebites, Rabies, and Injuries from Livestock—Even Undiagnosable Wounds, Chronic Ulcers of Twenty Years, and Wind in Wounds—Apply This Salve:**
Sesame Oil (*Shēngwūmá yóu* 生乌麻油) 1 *jīn*;
Litharge (*Huángdān* 黄丹) 4 *liǎng*;
Beeswax (*Là* 蜡) 4 *fèn* (all measured in *dàliǎng* 大两).

The three ingredients are simmered in a copper vessel from noon on the day before the winter solstice, with low heat until dawn. When the oil reduces by one *fèn*, add litharge until dissolved, then add wax until frothy. The salve is complete by noon. **Men only may prepare it; exclude children, women, and livestock.**

**Prescription for All Swellings (治诸肿帖方):**
Knotweed (*Zǐgē* 紫葛) 10 *fèn*;
Rhubarb (*Dàhuáng* 大黄) 5 *fèn*;
Green Wood Aromatic (*Qīngmùxiāng* 青木香) 1 *fèn*;
Scrophularia (*Xuánshēn* 玄参) 3 *fèn*;
White Lead (*Báiliàn* 白敛) 3 *fèn*;
Scutellaria (*Huángqín* 黄苓) 3 *fèn*;
Coptis (*Huánglián* 黄连) 3 *fèn*;
White Mulberry Bark (*Yúbáipí* 榆白皮) 3 *fèn*;
Cimicifuga (*Shēngmá* 升麻) 3 *fèn*;
Dioscorea (*Yóubá* 由跋) 3 *fèn*;
Red Bean (*Chìdòu* 赤小豆) 1 *hé*.

All eleven ingredients are ground and sifted, mixed with Rehmannia juice into a paste, and applied to the swelling. Replace when dry. If Rehmannia juice is unavailable, substitute with rice vinegar.

**Prescription for Pine Resin Salve (治痈肿松脂膏方):**
Pine resin (*Sōngzhī* 松脂) 1½ *catty*;
Hog fat (*Zhūzhī* 猪脂) 1½ *hé*.

**Scutellaria (*Huángqín* 黄苓), Astragalus (*Huángqí* 黄耆), Coptis (*Huánglián* 黄连), Angelica (*Dāngguī* 当归), Rhubarb (*Dàhuáng* 大黄), Peony (*Sháo yào* 芍药), Atractylodes (*Sháo wú* 芍蓊), and Wax (*Là* 蜡) each 1 *liǎng*.

All thirteen ingredients are coarsely ground. First, the pine resin and hog fat are simmered over gentle fire, three times up and three times down. Strain through silk and cloth to remove dregs. Toast and apply to paper, then affix to the swelling according to its size. Replace three times daily until cured.

**Alternative Prescription:**
Pine resin (*Sōngzhī* 松脂) 1 *catty*;
Hog fat (*Zhūzhī* 猪脂) ½ *catty*;
Rhubarb (*Dàhuáng* 大黄) 1 *liǎng*;
White wax (*Bái là* 白蜡) 4 *liǎng*;
Asarum (*Xìxīn* 细辛), Notopterygium (*Fángfēng* 防风), Scutellaria (*Huángqín* 黄苓), Ligusticum (*Chuángxī* 芎藭), White lead (*Bái liàn* 白敛), Angelica (*Dāngguī* 当归), Peony (*Sháo yào* 芍药), Imperata (*Mǎngcǎo* 莽草), Coptis (*Huánglián* 黄连), and Notopterygium (*Huángbò* 黄檗) each ½ *liǎng*.

All fifteen ingredients are coarsely ground. First, simmer the hog fat and white wax over gentle fire until melted. Then add the remaining herbs, three times up and three times down. Strain through silk and cloth, form into cakes in water, and take a small portion to toast. Apply onto oil paper and affix to the wound. The *Qiánjīn Yì* (千金翼) includes Astragalus (*Huángqí* 黄耆) 1 *liǎng*.

**Prescription for All Wound-Related Swellings (治痈疽痔漏恶疮、妬乳、漆疮方):**
Wild knotweed (*Yěgě* 野葛), Peony (*Sháo yào* 芍药), Allium (*Xièbái* 薤白), Angelica (*Dāngguī* 当归), and Phragmites (*Tōngcǎo* 通草) each 2 *fèn*;
Aconite (*Fùzǐ* 附子) 1 *fèn*.

All six ingredients are coarsely ground. Soak in vinegar for half a day. First, simmer hog fat (*Zhūzhī* 猪脂) 8 *hé*, until smoke rises. Add 2 *fèn* of disordered hair (*luàn fà* 乱发), stir until fully dissolved, then set aside to cool.

Next, add pine resin (*Sōngzhī* 松脂) 8 *fèn* and wax (*là* 蜡) 2 *fèn*, and mix again over fire until well combined. Then add the remaining herbs, simmer until boiling, three times up and three times down, and strain to remove dregs.

Apply to the swelling with clean silk. Replace when dry. If used in spring, omit Aconite (*Fùzǐ* 附子). The hair must be thoroughly washed and cleaned; otherwise, it will cause pain in the wound.

**Prescription for Green Dragon Five-Layered Salve (青龙五生膏, 导脓血方):**
White skin of living *Fùshān* (*Wú tóng* 梧桐) 5 *liǎng*;
White skin of living mulberry (*Sāng* 桑) 5 *liǎng*;
Green bamboo shoots (*Qīngzhú* 青竹茹) 5 *liǎng*;
White skin of living cypress (*Bǎi* 柏) 5 *liǎng*;
Living gentian (*Lóngdǎn* 龙胆) 5 *liǎng*;
Beehives (*Fēngfáng* 蜂房) 1 set;
*Bì* skin (*Bìpí* 谓皮) 1 set;
Snake shed skin (*Shé tuìpí* 蛇蜕皮) 1 set;
Realgar (*Xiónghuáng* 雄黄) 1 *liǎng*;
Orpiment (*Cíhuáng* 雌黄) 1 *liǎng*;
Sichuan pepper (*Shǔ jiāo* 蜀椒) 5 *fèn*;
Aconite (*Fùzǐ* 附子) 5 *fèn*;
Ligusticum (*Chuángxī* 芎藭) 5 *fèn*.

All thirteen ingredients are coarsely ground. Soak in three-year-old *kǔ* (苦, bitter) wine 2 *dòu* for one night. Toast over charcoal fire until dry, then pound and sift through fine mesh. Simmer with hog fat (*Zhūzhī* 猪脂) 2½ *shēng*, stirring gently until the mixture thickens like syrup. Add the powdered herbs and water, and store in a new white porcelain container.

Apply gradually according to the depth of the wound. Take with clean wine, the size of a date pit, once daily.

**Prescription for Scar-Removal Salve (灭瘢膏, 治诸色痈肿恶疮瘥后有瘢痕方):**
Benzoin (*Ānxī xiāng* 安息香, also called *Nǚwěi* 女萎) 1 *liǎng*;
Alum (*Fánshí* 矾石) 1 *liǎng* (*Qiánjīn Yì* includes 1 *liǎng* here);
Euphorbia (*Lángdú* 狼毒) 1 *liǎng*;
Epimedium (*Yángzhízhú* 羊踯躅) 1 *liǎng*;
Aconite (*Wūtóu* 乌头) 1 *liǎng*;
Aconite (*Fùzǐ* 附子) 1 *liǎng*;
Wild knotweed (*Yěgě* 野葛) 1 *liǎng*;
Notopterygium (*Bái zhì* 白芷) 1 *liǎng*;
Cuttlefish bone (*Wūzéi gǔ* 乌贼骨) 1 *liǎng*;
Sapindus (*Zàojiá* 皂荚) 1 *liǎng*;
Chuanxiong (*Tiānxiōng* 天雄) 1 *liǎng*;
Peony (*Sháo yào* 芍药) 1 *liǎng*;
Ligusticum (*Chuángxī* 芎藭) 1 *liǎng*;
Red pitchstone (*Chìshí zhī* 赤石脂) 1 *liǎng*;
Rhubarb (*Dàhuáng* 大黄) 1 *liǎng*;
Angelica (*Dāngguī* 当归) 1 *liǎng*;
Imperata (*Mǎngcǎo* 莽草) 1 *liǎng*;
Gypsum (*Shí gāo* 石膏) 1 *liǎng*;
Rehmannia (*Gāndìhuáng* 乾地黄) 1 *liǎng*;
Potentilla (*Dìyú* 地榆) 1 *liǎng*;
Atractylodes (*Bái zhú* 白朮) 1 *liǎng*;
Dipsacus (*Xùduàn* 续断) 1 *liǎng*;
Caulophyllum (*Guǐjiù* 鬼臼) 1 *liǎng*;
Sichuan pepper (*Shǔ jiāo* 蜀椒) 1 *liǎng*;
Croton (*Bādòu* 巴豆) 1 *liǎng*;
Asarum (*Xìxīn* 细辛) 1 *liǎng*.

All twenty-six ingredients are ground into a powder. Mix with previously prepared simmered hog fat (*Zhūzhī* 猪脂) 4 *catty*, following the given proportions. Simmer three times up and three times down, then add 1 large spoonful of good salt. When the salve is complete, apply as needed—either internally or externally. When applying externally, avoid near the eyes. When used internally, avoid by pregnant women.

For scar removal, rub onto the affected area with clean cloth until it breaks the skin. For nasal polyps, insert the size of a large soybean. For bruised blood, take with wine the size of a date pit. For hemorrhoids, wrap in silk the size of a plum and insert into the affected area. For wind-stroke (*zhòngfēng* 中风), rub onto the affected area until cured. For uterine bleeding (*bēngzhòng* 崩中), also administer internally.

For scar removal, mix a small amount with hawk dung (*yīngshǐ* 鹰屎) and white lead (*Bái liàn* 白敛). Best prepared on the winter solstice (*làrì* 腊日).

**Prescription for Post-Purulent Wound Non-Healing (治脓溃后疮不合方):**
Burn mouse skin (*shǔpí* 鼠皮) into ash, apply to the wound opening.

**Alternative Prescription:**
Chew large soybeans until warm, then apply to the wound.

**Alternative Prescriptions:**

For post-purulent wounds, roast black sesame (*wūmá* 乌麻) until fully blackened, then pound and apply.

Another prescription: Apply cow dung (*niúshǐ* 牛屎), replacing when dry.

Another prescription: Burn broken reed mats (*pòpúxí* 破蒲席) into ash, mix with pig fat (*zhūzhī* 猪脂) in December, and apply to the wound opening.

**Prescription for Chronic Non-Healing Abscesses (*zhì yōng jiǔ bù yào fāng* 治痈久不疟方):**
Pound *mǎchǐcài* (马齿菜) into juice, decoct, and apply.

**Prescription for Persistent Post-Abscess Discharge or Injuries from Foreign Objects, Where Wounds Fail to Heal:**
Powdered *shílíuhuáng* (石硫黄) – 2 *fēn* (分)
Take a chopstick, break off a small piece, slightly moisten it, and dip into the sulfur powder. Use to prick the wound opening until healed.

**Prescription for Deep-Seated Abscesses Resistant to All Medicines (*zhì yōng ròu zhōng rú yǎn, zhū yào suǒ bù xiào fāng* 治痈肉中如眼，诸药所不效者方):**
Slice *fùzǐ* (附子) into pieces the size of chess pieces, place on the swelling, secure with saliva, and cauterize with fire until the *fùzǐ* nearly chars. Moisten again with saliva and cauterize three times, allowing its heat to penetrate deeply. The swelling will then subside. This method is most efficacious.

**Refined Stone Powder (*Liànshí Sàn* 练石散) – For Abscesses with Hard, Stone-Like Nodules That Do Not Soften or Change Color, or for *Shíyōng* (石痈):**
Coarse-grained yellow stone (*huángshí* 黄石) – 1 *jīn* (斤)
Deer antler (*lùjiǎo* 鹿角) – 8 *liǎng* (两), burned
White lead (*báilian* 白敛) – 3 *liǎng* (两)
Combine the three ingredients. Use 5 *shēng* (升) of vinegar (*cù* 醋), first roasting the stone until red-hot, then immersing it in the vinegar without limit. Stop when the vinegar reduces by half. Grind all into powder, mix with the remaining vinegar into a paste, and apply thickly. Replace when dry, until the lesion softens and heals. This prescription is also effective for all types of *lòu* (漏) and *yīngliú* (瘰疬).

Additionally, pierce the lesion with a fire needle (*huǒzhēn* 火针), then apply the medicine.

Alternatively, grind deer antler and *bànxià* (半夏) into powder and apply—though this is less effective than the previous method.

**Prescription for Hard, Stone-Like Abscesses That Do Not Form Pus:**
Use fresh *shānglù* (商陆) root, pound while warm, and apply. Replace when dry, until softened.

**Additional Prescriptions for Wet *Lòu* (漏) and Various Abscesses:**

Another prescription: Dry the white bark of *shùsāng* (蜀桑) root in shade, grind into powder, melt *jiāo* (胶), mix with wine, and apply to the swelling. The root will then be drawn out.

Another prescription: Powder *qíngruòzǐ* (茛若子), mix with vinegar, and apply to the wound head. The root will then be drawn out.

Another prescription: Apply shed snake skin (*shétuīpí* 蛇蜕皮). The swelling will heal within a night.

Another prescription: Grind one *liángzǐ* (栎子) with vinegar on a green stone, and apply to the swelling. Replace when dry—no more than ten applications will be needed.

Another prescription:
Dust from beams (*liángshàngchén* 梁上尘)
*Kuí* (葵) root and stem ash – equal parts.

「The two substances above, mixed with vinegar and applied, will immediately heal.

**Another Prescription:**
When the swelling is firm and rooted, cauterize the area above with **100 applications of *jiāo*** (壮). The stone will then shatter and emerge.
If it does not emerge, increase the applications—this is most effective.
All swellings that reach hardness with a root are called *shíyīng* (石痈, lit. "stone abscess").

**Method to Prevent Swellings:**
At the beginning of spring, when the first thunder sounds, quickly press two fingers to the thunder’s source. Cease when the sound stops. For the next seven days, do not wash your hands. Thereafter, if you encounter any swelling—whether from *yìshuì* (蜴螫, lit. "lizard bites") or malignant abscesses—rubbing them with your fingers will cause them to dissolve instantly.

**Prescription for Marking Swellings:**
*Tiān* (天) **#17** *Yǐ* (乙) *Jiǎ* (甲) **#1** (一) *bùshēng* (不生) **#2** *Yǐ* (乙) *bùchéng* (不成), *Rén* (壬) *Guǐ* (癸) *sǐ* (死) **#3** (右)
Use cinnabar to mark the swelling, then hold your breath and mark it again—it will immediately heal.

**Prescription for Malignant Toxic Swellings:**
If the swelling is excruciating, drawing inward to the lower abdomen, or if it appears on the scrotum or one side, causing unbearable pain and cramping—this will kill a person within one night:
Take **fennel (*huíxiāng* 茴香) grass**, crush it into juice, and drink **one *shēng* (升)** daily, three or four times. Apply the residue to the swelling.
In winter months, if it is not yet alive, the root can also be used.
This is a divine foreign prescription, first employed in the last year of **Yǒngjiā** (永嘉) era. It has miraculous efficacy in reviving the dead.

**Prescription for Wind-Labor Toxic Swellings:**
If the swelling causes excruciating pain, cramping, or draws inward to the lower abdomen and waist, causing spleen pain:
Use **one *shēng* (升) of *peach kernels (*táorén* 桃仁)***, processed as usual, mixed with **three *shēng* (升) of wine, and taken in one dose. Wrap yourself in thick clothing and induce sweating—no more than three doses will heal.

**Prescription for Leg Swellings Rising to the Abdomen (Fatal):**
Use **one *dǒu* (斗) of *red adzuki beans (*chìxiǎodòu* 赤小豆)***, boiled in **three *dǒu* (斗) of water until soft. Drain the beans and soak the legs in the broth up to the knees daily—once, until healed.
If the swelling has already entered the abdomen, do not soak—simply boil and eat the beans.
Avoid **salt, vegetables, rice, and *qū* (曲, malt/fermented grains)***.
Drink the broth when thirsty—cease when healed.

**Fennel and Adzuki Broth:**
For **poisonous swellings** with no fixed location, or those with **redness and malignant cold**, or those causing **piercing abdominal pain and restlessness**—this is due to deep-seated **poisonous *qi* (*dúqì* 毒气)**:
**Fennel (*huíxiāng* 茴香) – five *shēng* (升)**
**Red adzuki beans (*chìxiǎodòu* 赤小豆) – five *shēng* (升)**
**Fresh *shànglù* (*shānglù* 商陆, lit. "common plantain") – two *shēng* (升)**
**Prepared *fùzǐ* (*fùzǐ* 附子, lit. "aconite") – two *liǎng* (两)**
**Prepared *shègān* (*shègān* 射干, lit. "belamcanda") – three *liǎng* (两)**
**Prepared *shēngmá* (*shēngmá* 升麻, lit. "stemona") – four *liǎng* (两)**
The six substances above, **#4** (□) chopped, are boiled in **four *dǒu* (斗) of water. First, boil the first four ingredients, reducing to **two and a half *dǒu* (斗)**, then discard the dregs. Next, crush the **fennel seeds (*mázi* 麻子)** into fragments, mix with the broth, and boil once more. Strain and discard the residue. Use the broth to cook the **adzuki beans** until soft.
Take **five *hé* (合)** of the broth per dose, **two times daily and once at night**.
The treatment should be administered until **urination improves**—when the swelling recedes, it will heal. Also eat the beans.

**Prescription for All Unbearable Swellings and Toxins:**
Take **ripe *bìmázi* (*bìmázi* 萆麻子, lit. "lappula seeds)***, crush and apply—the swelling will immediately heal.

**Prescription for Boils with White Crusts That Recur:**
**Garlic (*dàsuàn* 大蒜) – equal parts**
**Mouse dung (*shǔshǐ* 鼠屎) – equal parts**
**Ink (*shūmò* 书墨) – equal parts**
The three substances above, ground into powder and applied, **three times daily**.

**Prescription for Carbuncles (*jiēzi* 疖子):**
For **carbuncles without a head**, swallow **one *kuízi* (*kuízi* 葵子)**—do not take more than this.
**Another Prescription:**
**Powdered fresh chili pepper (*shēngjiāo* 生椒) – equal parts**
**Ash from beneath the pot (*fǔxià tǔ* 釜下土) – equal parts**
The two substances above, mixed with vinegar and applied.
The *Wing of the Thousand Gold* (《千金翼》) includes **fermented grain powder (*qǔmò* 曲末)**, making it three substances.

**Another Prescription:**
**Dog skull (*gǒutóugǔ* 狗头骨) – equal parts**
**Turnip seeds (*yóusùzi* 芸薹子) – equal parts**
The two substances above, ground into powder, mixed with vinegar, and applied.

**Another Prescription:**
Burn **kudzu vine (*gémàn* 葛蔓)** to ash and seal the swelling—it will dissolve on its own. Sealing with **cow dung ash** is also effective.

**Another Prescription:**
Apply **kudzu root (*niújiān* 鼠粘) leaves** as a poultice.

**Another Prescription:**
Apply **sparrow dung (*quèshǐ* 雀屎)**, mixed with water.

**End of Prescriptions from *Sūn Zhēnrén*’s *Essential Prescriptions for Emergency Use* (《孙真人备急千金要方》), Volume **66**.

**Prescription #1: *Fàbèi* (发背) – Third Theory on *Fàbèi***

**Theory:**
All cases of *fàbèi* arise from ingesting the Five Stones (五石), cold foods, or *Gēngshēngsǎn* (更生散). Some occur from consuming *zhōngrǔ* (钟乳, stalactite) alone, while others manifest spontaneously in those who have never ingested such substances—these are remnants of past consumption. Typically, the condition first appears between the shoulder blades as a grain-sized lump, either painful or itchy, with a reddish hue. Patients often dismiss it initially, but within ten days, it grows to three *cùn* wide and one *cùn* high, forming dozens of pus-filled orifices. Pressing it causes pus to discharge, and soon the patient loses their voice. Those who practice *yǎngshēng* (养生, life-nurturing) must act swiftly: upon sensing unusual itching or pain on the back, they should immediately prepare clean soil mixed with water into a paste, shaping it into a plaque—two *fèn* thick and one-and-a-half *cùn* wide. Using coarse mugwort (*ài* 艾) as an incense stick, they cauterize the plaque placed over the sore, replacing it after each stick. If the lump is grain-sized, seven plaques suffice for recovery; if the size of an elm fruit (*yújiá* 榆荚), seventy-seven plaques are needed; if coin-sized, cauterize continuously day and night without limit. Concurrently, administer *Wǔxiāng Liánqiáo Tāng* (五香连翘汤) and *tiějiāng* (铁浆, iron decoction) to purge the condition, ensuring full recovery.

**Alternative Method:**
Before *fàbèi* develops into a large abscess, repeatedly drench it with cold water and apply cold compresses of soaked stones day and night until recovery. Patients must avoid wheat flour, alcohol, and the Five Pungent Aromatics (五辛).

Some cases manifest on the shoulders. Those who ingest stones must engage in vigorous physical labor, avoiding comfort. Failure to do so often triggers the condition. They must also resist excessive warmth, denying personal comfort to endure cold—though initially uncomfortable, this prevents future outbreaks.

When a swelling arises between the shoulder blades, white like millet or sorghum, spreading with red-black edges and causing dizziness, it is *fàbèi*. Abstain from sexual activity, alcohol, meat, and garlic-flour mixtures. If untreated, it invades internally and proves fatal. Cauterization requires seven to eight hundred applications over the sore. Many misdiagnose it as a general swelling and die as a result.

---
**Prescription for Treating *Fàbèi* and Abscesses (Whether Ruptured or Not):**
Take *xiāngchǐ* (香豉, fragrant fermented soybeans), three *shēng*, mix with minimal water, and pound into a thick paste. Shape into plaques (three *fèn* thick or more) over the swelling, avoiding existing orifices. Place the soybean paste plaque and arrange mugwort above for cauterization, ensuring warmth without burning the flesh. If pain or heat arises, replace immediately. The condition should improve. Once stable, cauterize twice daily. If pus drains from existing orifices, recovery follows.

---
**Prescription for Treating Ruptured or Unruptured *Fàbèi*, Abscesses, and Toxic Swellings:**
**Gūlǔ gēn** (枯篓根, dried *Luffa* root)
**Yúbáipí** (榆白皮, elm bark)
**Húyànkē** (胡燕窠, swallow’s nest)
**Shǔshìtǔ** (鼠室土, rat’s nest soil)

Equal parts. Grind into a powder. Use a woman’s menstrual cloth, washed to extract its juice, and mix with the powder into a paste. Apply over the swelling; replace upon drying. For ruptured cases, seal the edges. Apply daily for one to five days until recovery.

---
**Prescription for Early *Fàbèi* Swelling on the Back:**
**Dàhuáng** (大黄, rhubarb) – 3 *liǎng*
**Shēngmá** (升麻, *Cimicifuga*) – 3 *liǎng*
**Huángqín** (黄苓, scutellaria) – 3 *liǎng*
**Gāncǎo** (甘草, licorice) – 3 *liǎng*
**Zhīzǐ** (栀子, gardenia) – 37 pieces

[Missing character] cut, decoct with nine *shēng* of water, reduce to three *shēng*, and divide into three doses.

**Prescription for Early *Fàbèi* Swelling on the Back:**

---

**General Treatment Principle:**
When bowel movements are smooth and easy, stop [taking the medicine]. If not, continue.

**Internal Supplementing Powder, for Treating Boils, Carbuncles, and *Fàbèi* Swellings (whether ruptured or not):**
**Dāngguī** (当归, angelica) – 2 *liǎng*
**Guìxīn** (桂心, cassia bark) – 2 *liǎng*
**Rénshēn** (人参, ginseng) – 1 *liǎng*
**Xiōngwú** (芎藭, chuanxiong) – 1 *liǎng*
**Hòupò** (厚朴, thick-skinned magnolia bark) – 1 *liǎng*
**Fángfēng** (防风, saposhnikovia) – 1 *liǎng*
**Gāncǎo** (甘草, licorice) – 1 *liǎng*
**Báizhì** (白芷, angelica dahurica) – 1 *liǎng*
**Jiégēng** (桔梗, platycodon) – 1 *liǎng*

Right: nine herbs. Sifted and processed, taken with wine in a *fāngcùn* dose, three times daily and twice at night. If not yet recovered, continue taking; do not discontinue. **Fourth Discussion on *Dāndú* [Erythema]:**
*Dāndú* is also called **Tiān Huǒ** (天火, Heavenly Fire). Suddenly, red patches like vermilion appear in the flesh, large ones resembling a hand’s palm, severe cases covering the entire body with itching and swelling, and no fixed color.

There is **Báidān** (白丹, white *dāndú*): red patches rise in the flesh, itching followed by pain, with slight hollow swelling like blown-up skin, and hidden **zhěn** (轸, *dú*-like eruptions).

There is **Jīguān Dān** (鸡冠丹, *dāndú* resembling a rooster’s comb): red patches rise in the flesh, large ones like linked coins, small ones like sesame seeds, with rough texture resembling a rooster’s comb. Also called **Zhūyú Dān** (茱萸丹, cornelian cherry *dāndú*).

There is **Shuǐdān** (水丹, water *dāndú*): caused by whole-body heat, which, when exposed to water or moisture, forms red-yellow patches resembling water trapped in the skin, often appearing on the thighs or groin. Though seemingly minor, if untreated, it can be fatal.

**Treatment:**
All cases use the **Shēngmá Gāo** (升麻膏, *Cimicifuga* plaster) prescription:

**Shēngmá** (升麻, *Cimicifuga*) – 2 *liǎng*
**Báiwěi** (白薇, *Oldenlandia diffusa*) – 2 *liǎng* (*Zhǒuhòu* [Prescriptions from the Armchair] uses **Báiliàn** (白敛, angelica dahurica))
**Lòulú** (漏芦, *Veratrum nigrum*) – 2 *liǎng*
**Liánqiào** (连翘, forsythia) – 2 *liǎng*
**Mángxiāo** (芒硝, mirabilite) – 2 *liǎng*
**Huángqín** (黄苓, scutellaria) – 2 *liǎng*
**Shéxián** (蛇衔, *Achyranthes bidentata*) – 3 *liǎng*
**Zhǐshí** (枳实, immature tangerine) – 3 *liǎng*
**Shuāilǜ** (蒴藋, *Achyranthes aspera*) – 4 *liǎng*
**Zhīzǐ** (栀子, gardenia) – 40 pieces

Right: ten herbs. Lightly crushed, steeped in three *shēng* of water for half a day, then simmered with five *shēng* of pig fat until the water evaporates. Strain, and apply the fat plaster to the swelling. All types of *dāndú* use this, as well as for heat-induced sores and swellings, three times daily.

The *Jīngxīn Lù* (经心录) omits **zhǐshí** (枳实, immature tangerine), using it instead only for Toxic Swellings.

**Shēngmá Tāng** (升麻汤, *Cimicifuga* Decoction), for Treating *Dāndú*:

After defecation, take **Yīnzǐ Tāng** (饮子, decoction) along with **Lòulú Tāng** (漏芦汤, *Veratrum nigrum* Decoction). This prescription is also found in the earlier section on carbuncles. **On the Coldest Herbs in the World:**
No herb is colder than aquatic greens. For those afflicted with heat-toxins, eruptions, or *dān* (pox), take the aquatic greens from the water, finely chop, and mash while warm to apply. Apply thickly—three *fēn* (分)—and replace once dry.

**Divine-Efficacy Prescription for All Eruptions:**
Take *yúnwēi cài* (芸薹菜, Chinese cabbage) and mash while warm, sealing thickly. It dissolves upon application. If residual heat-qi persists, seal it for three days to fully resolve—even if dry, do not remove, to cut off the root.

In the third month of the seventh year of *Zhèngguān* (正观), on the eighth day, I drank excessively in Nèijiāng County (内江县). By night, I awoke in pain throughout my bones and flesh. By dawn, my head ached, my vision blurred, and a swelling the size of a marble formed at the left corner of my brow—too painful to touch. By noon, it shifted to the right corner, and by night, it spread everywhere, sealing my eyes shut so I could not open them. I nearly perished. The county magistrate, Master Zhōu (周公), treated me with various medicines, but none took effect. After seven days, I applied this prescription myself, and its efficacy was divine. Thus, I record it to pass down to future generations.

**Prescription for Five-Colored Oil Pox (*yóudān*, 油丹):**
Commonly called "oil swelling," this affliction often proves fatal—do not treat it lightly.

**Method:** Bind a sow and sleep with its head as a pillow—most effective.

**Alternative Prescription:**

「Apply cow dung to the affliction, and it will ease upon drying.

**Prescription for Sudden Red-Black Pox (*dān*, 丹) and Toxic Swelling (*dú*, 毒):**
Take the white bark of elm (*yú*, 榆) roots, ground into powder, and mix with egg white (*jīzǐbái*, 鸡子白) to apply. The *Qiánjīn Yì* (千金翼) also prescribes mixing egg white with *púshèyī* (蒲席衣#7) and applying it.

**Alternative Prescriptions:**
Pound hemp seeds (*dàmázhǐ*, 大麻子) into a paste, mix with water, and apply. Another method: Rub with cooked sheep fat (*yángzhǐ*, 羊脂), with the finest quality being that of the green sheep (*qīngyángzhǐ*, 青羊脂). The *Jíyàn Fāng* (集验方) states: For sudden red-black pox affecting the face, eyes, or body—erupting like scabies (*jiè*, 疥) and worsening daily without treatment, spreading across the body and proving fatal—

**Prescription for Infant Toxic Pox (*dán dú*, 丹毒):**
Pound one handful of *mǎchǐdiàn* (马齿苋) into a paste, consume its juice, and apply the residue to the affected area. Another method: Pound five *hē* (合) of red adzuki beans (*chìdòu*, 赤小豆), mix with water, and drink one *hē* of the juice—this is effective. Apply the residue to the five *xīn* (心) [palms, soles, and three other vital points]. Another method: Apply thickly boiled soybean juice (*dàdòu*, 大豆) to the affliction—this is effective, and no scars remain after recovery. Another method: Mix pig fat (*zhūzhǐ*, 豬脂) from the twelfth lunar month (*làyuè*, 腊月) with soil from beneath the cooking pot (*fǔxià tǔ*, 釜下土) and apply; it will ease upon drying.

**Prescription for Infant Five-Colored Pox (*wǔsè dān*, 五色丹):**
Use rotted mud from beneath a pig trough (*zhūcáo xià lànní*, 豬槽下烂泥) and apply; it will ease upon drying. The *Jíyàn Fāng* also prescribes this for sudden red-black pox.

**Alternative Prescriptions:**
Pound the leaves of *chuòliè* (蒴藋) and apply. Another method: Consume two *hē* of *Huánglóng tāng* (黄龙汤) and apply it to the affected area—this is excellent.

**Prescription for Infant White Pox (*báidān*, 白丹):**

**Prescription for Infant Red Pox (*chìdān*, 赤丹):**
Pound the leaves of *yóunái* (芸薹) into juice and drink three *hē*—this is effective. Apply the residue to the affected area. The *Qiánjīn Yì* states: Grind *yóunái* (芸薹) into powder, mix with egg white, and apply. Another prescription for infant red pox with scattered patches (*bānbó*, 斑驳者):

Use saliva mixed with *húfěn* (胡粉) and apply from the outside inward. Another method: Pound roasted iron filings (*duàn tiě*, 锻铁) into a paste, mix with pig fat, and apply. Another method: Mix house dust (*wūchén*, 屋尘) with pig fat from the twelfth lunar month and apply.

**Prescription for Infant Fire Pox (*huǒdān*, 火丹)—red as cinnabar and spreading beneath the skin:**
Pound fermented soybeans (*zhǐ*, 豉) with vinegar (*cù*, 醋) and apply. Another method:」

**Prescriptions for Infant Red Pox (continued):**
Use carp blood (*lǐyú xuè*, 鲤鱼血) applied—excellent.
Another method: Pound *rěnzi* (荏子) and apply—excellent.
Another method: Mix pig dung water (*zhūshǐ shuǐ*, 猪屎水) and strain to extract the juice; take a small amount orally—excellent.

**Prescription for Infant Heavenly Fire Toxin (*tiān huǒdú*, 天火毒)#8—when flesh bears red cinnabar-like patches, some as large as a hand, or spreading across the body, with pain, itching, or swelling:**
Take *chìxiǎodòu* (赤小豆), two *shēng*, and grind into powder. Mix with egg white to form a thin paste and apply. Once dry, change it—this will cure. This prescription works for all types of *dān* (丹).

Another method: Apply raw sesame oil (*shēng máyóu*, 生麻油).

**Prescription for Infant Bone Fire Pox (*gǔ huǒdān*, 骨火丹)—when the sores expose the bone:**
Pound garlic (*suàn*, 蒜), thickly apply, and seal. If applied to the ankle (*zhuó zúhuái*, 著足踝), it is effective.

**Prescription for Infant Calamity Fire Pox (*yāng huǒdān*, 殃火丹)—when toxin affects the ribs and armpits:**
Grind *fúlóng gān* (伏龙肝) into powder, mix with oil, and apply. Once dry, change it. If the toxin enters the abdomen or genitals, extract the juice of *shèn huǒ cǎo* (慎火草) and take orally.

**Prescription for Infant Urine Furnace Pox (*niào zào dān*, 尿灶丹)—when the rash begins at the thighs, spreads to the navel, and enters the genitals, all in red:**
Slice *sāngbáipí* (桑白皮), two *shēng*, with two *shēng* of water, boil to extract the juice, and bathe with it—excellent.
Another method: Burn *lǐ gēn* (李根) to ash, mix with water from a field (*tiánzhōng liúshuǐ*, 田中流水), and apply—excellent.

**Prescription for Infant Vermilion Field Fire Pox (*zhū tián huǒdān*, 朱田火丹)—when the disease forms sores within a day and night, beginning at the back and spreading across the body, resembling dates in size, and bright red:**
Wash with concentrated boiled juice of *jí gēn* (棘根). If sores have already formed, apply powdered *chìxiǎodòu* (赤小豆). If no sores have formed, mix egg white with powdered *xiǎodòu* (小豆) and apply.
*Note:* In all prescriptions using eggs (*jīzǐ*, 鸡子), only broken eggs should be used—intact eggs lack efficacy.

Pound *fúlóng gān* (伏龙肝) into powder, mix with egg white, and apply three times daily—excellent.

**Hidden Itch (隐翰) – Fifth Discussion on Moxibustion Methods**
The *Suwen* (《素问》) states:
*"When wind evil invades the muscles, the muscles become depleted, and true *qi* scatters. If further struck by cold, it seizes the skin, opens the pores, and disrupts the hair follicles, allowing errant *qi* to wander—this gives rise to itch. Thus, wind-induced itching and hidden itch all stem from this."*

There are also cases of *chì hàn* (赤翰), which suddenly appear like mosquito bites, causing intense itching—when scratched, new welts rise in their place.
Similarly, there is *bái zhěn* (白轸), which behaves likewise.
*Chì hàn* erupts when hot and subsides when cool;
*Bái zhěn* appears when the weather is cold and damp.

For *bái zhěn*, boil *fánshí* (矾石) into a decoction and wipe the affected area, or boil *chuìlì* (蒴藋) with a small amount of wine for bathing—excellent, as used by Master Yao (姚氏) for treating *chìzhěn* (赤疹).
Alternatively, boil *shínán* (石南) into a decoction and wipe the area—excellent.
Or boil *jīshǐ* (鸡屎) into a decoction, or boil *jīshí* (枳实) into a decoction and wipe—excellent.

All other cases follow the methods for treating *dān* (丹).
Commonly called *fēngshǐ* (风屎) or *fēngshī* (风尸).

**Stone South Decoction (石南汤)** treats sixty-four kinds of wind disorders:
When *yín yè* (淫液) invades the skin like crawling insects, causing stiffness in the waist and spine, alternating flaccidity and rigidity in the limbs, cramping hands and feet, hidden itch that worsens when scratched into sores, or *fēngshī* (风尸) itch—suddenly swelling of the face, inability to raise the hands to the head, or locked jaw preventing speech—
This decoction should be taken internally for relief.
