**Remedies for Broken Needles Lodged in the Flesh:**
Scrape *Elephas maximus* (Xiang) ivory into powder, mix with water, and gather it onto the broken needle’s site—it will immediately expel.

**Another remedy:** Apply mouse brain to the site.

**Another remedy:** Use a lodestone (which attracts iron) to draw the needle out.

**On Dietary Therapy (Introduction to the First Chapter):**

Zhang Jing (仲景) said:
*"When the human body is in harmony, one need only cultivate good habits of nourishment and avoid reckless medication. Though medicines may offer some aid, they disrupt the balance of the organs’ **qi** (脏气), making one vulnerable to external afflictions. All beings that draw breath depend on food to sustain life, yet few understand how dietary choices determine success or failure. Common people consume it daily without discernment, while the vital principles of water and fire remain obscure. I lament this state and, in the leisure of my brush and ink, have composed this *Five Flavors: Dietary Harm and Benefit* (五味损益食治) chapter to enlighten the unlearned. If diligently followed, its wisdom will endure like an echo."*

The *River East* (Huang Dong) record of Wei Xuan (卫汛) notes:
*"Bi Que (扁鹊) taught that the foundation of human life is **form** (形); disruption of harmonious **qi** (和气) brings disease; regulation of toxins is the role of medicine; and saving lives and supporting the perilous is the physician’s duty. Food is essential for sustaining the body, while medicine is indispensable for swiftly curing illness. Without understanding proper foods, one cannot preserve life; without knowing medicinal taboos, one cannot eradicate disease. These two matters are vital to the living—if neglected without study, it is truly lamentable.

Thus, food can expel evil **qi** (邪) and stabilize the organs, delight the spirit, and invigorate the mind—thereby nourishing **blood** and **qi** (血气). If one can use diet to balance chronic ailments and release emotional distress, they may be called a master of their craft. The extraordinary methods of prolonging life and supporting old age are the pinnacle of **Dao** (道) of nurturing vitality.

The physician must first comprehend the origins of disease, identify its cause, and treat it with diet. Only when dietary therapy fails should they resort to medicine. Medicinal properties are fierce and potent, like wielding an army. Can one recklessly deploy soldiers without consequence? Improper use harms many; likewise, ill-advised medication spreads harm indiscriminately.

The High Prince of Gao Ping (高平王熙) remarked that food should not be mixed indiscriminately—for mixing may invite affliction. Where affliction arises, injury follows. Even if no immediate harm occurs, over time, such imbalances will plague the body. Moreover, one should avoid excessive consumption of fish and rich meats; instead, let food be simple and beneficial. In daily meals, moderation is key—greed for flavor and gluttonous feasts lead to distended stomachs, shortness of breath, and sudden violent illnesses, even cholera.

After the summer solstice, until the autumn equinox, one must be cautious with fatty, greasy, or overly sweet foods, as well as pastries and dairy products. These items clash with the **virtue/power** (德) of wine, grains, melons, and fruits. The body’s susceptibility to disease stems from overindulging in coldness during spring and summer, as well as irregular eating habits. Furthermore, fish and strong-smelling, cold foods often harm the body—abandoning them is beneficial.

Consuming dairy products like cheese and butter strengthens tendons and sinews, fortifies the gallbladder, and keeps the skin supple. If eaten excessively, they may cause diarrhea and gradual self-correction.

The Yellow Emperor (黄帝) said:
*'The five flavors enter the mouth, each with its own path and potential harm. Sour affects the sinews—excessive sourness causes urinary retention (癃). Why?*

*Min Yu (少俞) replied:*
*'Sour enters the stomach, where its **qi** (气) is astringent and contracting. It ascends to the two upper **jiao** (焦), but the **qi** of the upper **jiao** (焦), being astringent, cannot freely circulate. If it cannot ascend, it flows downward into the stomach, where warmth harmonizes it before it descends into the bladder. The bladder’s **qi** (气) is thin and soft—when exposed to sourness, it contracts and tightens, blocking the flow of water. Thus, urinary retention (癃) occurs. The sinews are where yin **qi** (阴者) accumulates—hence, sour enters the stomach and travels to the sinews.*

*‘Salty affects the blood—excessive saltiness causes thirst. Why?’*

*‘Because salty **qi** (气) enters the stomach and descends into the middle **jiao** (焦), where it permeates the vessels. The vessels are the pathways of blood, and when salty **qi** (气) interacts with them, the blood congeals. Congealed blood drains the stomach’s fluids, leaving it parched and thirsty. The *Jia Yi* (甲乙) text states: *‘Congealed blood causes the stomach’s fluids to drain, and drained fluids lead to extreme thirst.’* Thirst dries the throat, making the tongue rough and craving more drink. The vessels are the **Dao** (道) of the middle **jiao** (焦)—thus, salty **qi** (气) enters the stomach and travels to the blood. Huangfu Shian (皇甫士安) notes that the kidneys regulate the three **jiao**’s vessels, though they belong to the liver and heart, they are still the **Dao** (道) of the middle **jiao**—hence, salt enters and affects the blood.’*

*‘Pungent affects the **qi** (气)—excessive pungent flavors cause irritability and heartache (愠心). Why?’*

*‘Because pungent **qi** (气) enters the stomach and ascends to the upper **jiao** (焦), where it governs and harmonizes all **qi** (气) and nourishes the yang pathways. The **qi** of ginger and scallions permeates the **honor** (荣) and **defense** (卫) systems—if they do not receive pungent **qi** (气) in due measure, it lingers beneath the heart, causing #1 irritability (愠). Irritability is akin to pain. Pungent flavors move alongside **qi** (气), thus when they enter the stomach, they follow the **qi** (气) and exit with it, leading to excess **qi** (气).’*

*‘Bitter affects the bones—excessive bitter flavors cause nausea and vomiting (变呕). Why?’*

*‘Because bitter **qi** (气) enters the stomach and, being dry and dispersive, overwhelms the **virtue/power** (德) of the five grains. It descends into the lower **jiao** (管), where the three **jiao**’s pathways converge—if they close, **qi** (气) cannot flow, and stagnation leads to vomiting. The teeth are where yin **qi** (气) terminates—thus, bitter **qi** (气) enters the stomach, travels downward, and exits again, causing the teeth to darken and weaken. Huangfu Shian (皇甫士安) notes that water and fire support each other, so the bones’ **qi** (气) connects to the heart.’*

*‘Sweet affects the flesh—excessive sweetness causes nausea. Why?’*

*‘Because sweet **qi** (气) enters the stomach but, being weak and deficient, cannot ascend to the upper **jiao** (焦), instead lingering with the grains in the stomach. Sweetness softens and relaxes—when the stomach is relaxed, the roundworms (蛔) stir, leading to nausea. Sweet **qi** (气) externally permeates the flesh, thus when sweet enters the stomach and travels to the flesh, it causes the flesh to become coarse and develop goosebumps (粟起而胝). Huangfu Shian (皇甫士安) notes that its **qi** (气) externally permeates the skin...’*

Thus it is said: when sweet **qi** (气) enters, it travels to the skin. The skin is the covering of the flesh, though it belongs to the lungs, yet it is connected to the flesh as one entity, so sweet **qi** (气) moistens both the flesh and the skin.

The Yellow Emperor asked: *"Can I hear the principles of the five flavors of grains?"*
Bo Gao replied: *"To eat wind is to gain agility and lightness of movement; to eat **qi** (气) is to achieve harmony and longevity; to eat grains is to gain wisdom but exhaust the mind; to eat grass is to become foolish yet strong; to eat meat is to become courageous yet prone to anger."*

Therefore:
- The liver (肝), of wood (木) and green (青), suits sour (酸);
- The heart (心), of fire (火) and red (赤), suits bitter (苦);
- The spleen (脾), of earth (土) and yellow (黄), suits sweet (甘);
- The lungs (肺), of metal (金) and white (白), suit spicy (辛);
- The kidneys (肾), of water (水) and black (黑), suit salty (咸).

Internally, they govern the five **zàng** organs (脏); externally, they correspond to the five phases (行); and their colors align with the five directions (方).

The five **zàng** organs’ harmonizing principles:
- The liver (肝) harmonizes with sinews (筋), its **róng** (荣) being the nails (爪);
- The heart (心) harmonizes with vessels (脉), its **róng** (荣) being complexion (色);
- The spleen (脾) harmonizes with flesh (肉), its **róng** (荣) being the lips (唇);
- The lungs (肺) harmonize with skin (皮), its **róng** (荣) being hair (毛);
- The kidneys (肾) harmonize with bones (骨), its **róng** (荣) being the hair (发).

The five **zàng** organs’ dietary prohibitions:
- Excessive sour (酸) causes the skin to dry and hair to wither;
- Excessive bitter (苦) causes the sinews to contract and nails to brittle;
- Excessive sweet (甘) causes the bones to ache and hair to fall;
- Excessive spicy (辛) causes the flesh to become coarse and lips to crack;
- Excessive salty (咸) causes the vessels to congeal, tears to flow, and complexion to alter.

The five **zàng** organs’ suitable foods:
- For liver (肝) ailments: hemp (麻), dog meat (犬肉), plums (李), garlic chives (韭);
- For heart (心) ailments: wheat (麦), mutton (羊肉), apricots (杏), lovage (薤);
- For spleen (脾) ailments: glutinous rice (脾米), beef (牛肉), dates (枣), castor bean (葵);
- For lung (肺) ailments: yellow millet (黄黍), pigeon meat (鹦肉), peaches (桃), scallions (葱);
- For kidney (肾) ailments: soybeans and yellow rolls (大豆黄卷), pork (豕肉), chestnuts (栗), dodder (藿).

*The *Suwen* (《素问》) states:
- The liver (肝) is green (青), favoring sweet (甘): glutinous rice (秔米), beef (牛肉), dates (枣), and castor bean (葵) are all sweet;
- The heart (心) is red (赤), favoring sour (酸): small beans (小豆), dog meat (犬肉), plums (李), and garlic chives (韭) are all sour;
- The lungs (肺) are white (白), favoring bitter (苦): wheat (麦), mutton (羊肉), apricots (杏), and lovage (薤) are all bitter;
- The spleen (脾) is yellow (黄), favoring salty (咸): soybeans (大豆), pork (豕肉), chestnuts (栗), and dodder (藿) are all salty;
- The kidneys (肾) are black (黑), favoring spicy (辛): yellow millet (黄黍), chicken meat (鸡肉), peaches (桃), and scallions (葱) are all spicy.

The five flavors’ influence on disease:
- Sour affects the sinews (筋): when sinews are diseased, avoid sour;
- Bitter affects the bones (骨): when bones are diseased, avoid bitter;
- Sweet affects the flesh (肉): when flesh is diseased, avoid sweet;
- Spicy affects the **qi** (气): when **qi** is diseased, avoid spicy;
- Salty affects the blood (血): when blood is diseased, avoid salty.

The five flavors’ correspondences:
- Rice (米) and congee (饭) are sweet;
- Hemp (麻) is sour;
- Soybeans (大豆) are salty;
- Wheat (麦) is bitter;
- Dates (枣) are sweet;
- Plums (李) are sour;
- Chestnuts (栗) are salty;
- Apricots (杏) are bitter;
- Peaches (桃) are spicy;
- Yellow millet (黄黍) is spicy;
- Castor bean (葵) is sweet;
- Garlic chives (韭) are sour;
- Dodder (藿) is salty;
- Lovage (薤) is bitter;
- Scallions (葱) are spicy;
- Beef (牛) is sweet;
- Dog meat (犬) is sour;
- Pork (豕) is salty;
- Mutton (羊) is bitter;
- Chicken meat (鸡) is spicy.

The five **zàng** organs’ therapeutic dietary principles:
- If the liver (肝) is bitter and tense, eat sweet to relax it;
- If the liver (肝) seeks to disperse, eat spicy to disperse it;
- Use sour to purge it, but avoid exposure to wind.

- If the heart (心) is bitter and slack, eat sour to constrict it;
- If the heart (心) seeks softness, eat salty to soften it;
- Use sweet to purge it, but avoid warm food and thick clothing.

- If the spleen (脾) is bitter and damp, eat bitter to dry it;
- If the spleen (脾) seeks relaxation, eat sweet to relax it;
- Use bitter to purge it, but avoid warm food, overeating, dampness, or damp clothing.

- If the lungs (肺) are bitter and **qi** rises in reverse, causing breathlessness, eat bitter to vent it;
- If the lungs (肺) seek constriction, eat sour to constrict it;
- Use spicy to purge it, but avoid cold drinks or cold clothing.

- If the kidneys (肾) are bitter and dry, eat spicy to moisten them, opening the **tánglǐ** (腠理) and ensuring **qi** and fluids circulate;
- If the kidneys (肾) seek firmness, eat bitter to bind them;
- Use salty to purge them, but avoid scorching dust or heat—avoid warm food and hot clothing.

Thus, poisonous medicines attack evil, the five grains nourish, the five meats benefit, the five fruits assist, and the five vegetables fill. **Jīng** (精) is nourished by **qi** (气), and **qi** nourishes **jīng** to manifest complexion (色); the body is sustained by flavors, and flavors sustain the body to generate strength (力). This is the principle.

The **shén** (神) is stored in five ways, with five times five making twenty-five varieties; the body is stored in four directions, four seasons, four times, and four limbs—altogether, five nines, forty-five in total. By this means, one may assist the **shén** (神) to achieve longevity and enduring vision.

**Jīng** (精) follows the five **qì** (气) to become agile; if one’s **qì** (气) and food are incompatible, it harms **jīng**.
The body depends on flavors to form; if flavors are not balanced, it injures the body. Therefore, the sage first employs dietary regulation to preserve life essence (性), then uses medicine to safeguard vitality (命). Thus, when the body is deficient, warm it with **qì** (气); when **jīng** (精) is deficient, supplement it with flavors; and warm and supplement **qì** (气) and flavors to preserve **jīng** (精) and body.

Bo Gao said:
- **Yáng** (阳) is **qì** (气), **yīn** (阴) is flavor;
- Flavor nourishes the body, and the body nourishes **qì** (气);
- **Qì** (气) nourishes **jīn** (精), and **jīng** (精) refines into transformation (化);
- **Jīng** (精) consumes **qì** (气), the body consumes flavor;
- Transformation (化) generates **jīng** (精), and **qì** (气) generates the body;
- Rich flavors injure the body, and **qì** (气) deficiency harms **jīng** (精);
- **Jīng** (精) transforms into **qì** (气), and **qì** (气) is harmed by flavors;
- **Yīn** (阴) flavors exit through the lower orifices, while **yáng** (阳) **qì** (气) exits through the upper orifices.

- Rich flavors are **yīn** (阴), light flavors are **yīn**’s **yáng** (阴之阳);
- Rich **qì** (气) is **yáng** (阳), light **qì** (气) is **yáng**’s **yīn** (阳之阴).
- Rich flavors cause depletion, light flavors cause circulation;
- Light **qì** (气) causes emission, rich **qì** (气) causes stagnation.

- The **zhuànghuǒ** (壮火) **qì** (气) is weak, while the **shàohuǒ** (少火) **qì** (气) is strong;
- **Zhuànghuǒ** (壮火) consumes **qì** (气), and **qì** (气) nourishes **shàohuǒ** (少火);
- **Zhuànghuǒ** (壮火) disperses **qì** (气), while **shàohuǒ** (少火) generates **qì** (气).

- Spicy and sweet flavors disperse and emit as **yáng** (阳), while sour and bitter flavors surge and drain as **yīn** (阴);
- When **yīn** prevails, **yáng** becomes diseased; when **yáng** prevails, **yīn** becomes diseased;
- When **yīn** and **yáng** are balanced, one remains at peace.

- In spring (七十二日): reduce bitter and increase sweet to nourish spleen **qì** (气);
- In summer (七十二日): reduce sour and increase spicy to nourish lung **qì** (气);

「Autumn (七十二日): reduce spicy and increase sour to nourish liver **qi** (气);
Winter (七十二日): reduce salty and increase bitter to nourish heart **qi** (气);
Each of the four seasons' transitional months (季月), eighteen days each: reduce sweet and increase salty to nourish kidney **qi** (气).

Fruits and seeds (果实), categorized by their properties (第二二＋九条):
**Binglang** (槟榔): flavor spicy (辛), warm (温), astringent (濇), non-toxic (无毒).
Dissolves accumulated food, expels water, removes phlegm and dampness (痰癖);
Kills parasitic worms (三虫), dispels lingering pathogenic factors (伏尸), treats leukorrhea (寸白).

**Doukou** (豆蔻): flavor spicy (辛), warm (温), astringent (濇), non-toxic (无毒).
Warms the middle (温中), treats heart and abdominal pain (主心腹痛);
Stops vomiting (止吐呕), removes foul breath (去口气臭).

**Putao** (蒲萄): flavor sweet (甘) and spicy (辛), neutral (平), non-toxic (无毒).
Treats dampness in sinews and bones (筋骨湿痹);
Augments **qi** (气), doubles strength (倍力), fortifies willpower (强志), promotes health and plumpness (令人肥健), enhances endurance to hunger (耐饥) and cold/wind (忍风寒);
Prolonged consumption lightens the body and prevents aging (延年), extending life.
Treats water in the intestines (肠间水), harmonizes the middle (调中).
Can be made into wine; regular drinking benefits one.
Expels water, promotes urination (利小便).

**Fupenzi** (覆盆子): flavor sweet (甘) and spicy (辛), neutral (平), non-toxic (无毒).
Augments **qi** (气) and lightens the body (轻身), prevents hair from turning white (令发不白).

**Dazao** (大枣): flavor sweet (甘) and spicy (辛), hot (热), slippery (滑), non-toxic (无毒).
Treats pathogenic **qi** (邪气) in the heart and abdomen (主心腹邪气), calms the middle and nourishes spleen **qi** (安中养脾气), assists the twelve meridians (助十二经), balances stomach **qi** (平胃气);
Opens the nine orifices (通九窍).」

「**Qi** foulness (气臭).
---
**Pupao** (蒲萄): flavor sweet (甘) and spicy (辛), neutral (平), non-toxic (无毒).
Augments **qi** (益气), strengthens willpower (强志), and enhances vigor (倍力);
Treats dampness in joints and muscles (主筋骨湿痹), harmonizes the middle (调中);
Prolonged consumption lightens the body (轻身), prevents aging (耐老), and extends life (延年).
Can be made into wine; regular drinking benefits one (常饮益人).
Expels water, promotes urination (逐水利小便).

**Fupenzi** (覆盆子): flavor sweet (甘) and spicy (辛), neutral (平), non-toxic (无毒).
Augments **qi** (气) and lightens the body (轻身), prevents hair from turning white (令发不白).

**Dazao** (大枣): flavor sweet (甘) and spicy (辛), hot (热), slippery (滑), non-toxic (无毒).
Treats pathogenic **qi** (邪气) in the heart and abdomen (主心腹邪气), calms the middle and nourishes spleen **qi** (安中养脾气), assists the twelve meridians (助十二经), balances stomach **qi** (平胃气);
Opens the nine orifices (通九窍).

---
**Supplementing deficient vital breath (气), body fluids (津液), and middle insufficiency (身中不足),**
**after great shock (大惊) or heaviness in the limbs (四肢重);**
Can be combined with a hundred remedies (可和百药),
Supplementing the middle and augmenting **qi** (补中益气), strengthening willpower (强志);
Relieves vexation and oppression (除烦闷),
**Suspended heart** (心下悬);
Treats **intestinal dampness** (肠澼).
Prolonged consumption lightens the body (轻身), extends life without hunger (长年不饥), and achieves transcendence (神仙).

**Shengzao** (生枣): flavor sweet (甘) and spicy (辛).
Excessive consumption causes heat, thirst, and **qi** distension (令人热渴气胀).
**For those suffering from cold-heat imbalance (寒热赢瘦), it is especially contraindicated and harmful (弥不可食, 伤人).**

**Oushi** (藕实): flavor bitter (苦) and sweet (甘), cold (寒), non-toxic (无毒).
Consumption brings joy to the heart (食之令人心欢).
Stops thirst and removes heat (止渴去热),
Supplements the middle and nourishes spirit (补中养神),
Augments **qi** and strengthens vitality (益气力),
Expels a hundred ailments (除百病).
Prolonged consumption lightens the body and prevents aging (轻身耐老),
Extends life without hunger (不饥延年).
Also known as **Shuizi** (水芝).
**Raw root is cold (生根寒), stops heat and thirst (止热渴), and breaks retained blood (破留血).**

**Jitou Shi** (鸡头实): flavor sweet (甘), neutral (平), non-toxic (无毒).
Treats dampness in joints and muscles (主湿痹),
Pain in the waist, spine, and knees (腰脊膝痛);
Supplements the middle (补中),
Expels sudden violent diseases (除暴疾),
Augments **jing-qi** (精气) and strengthens willpower (强志意),
Sharpens hearing and vision (耳目聪明).
Prolonged consumption lightens the body (轻身),
Prevents aging (耐老),
Extends life without hunger (不饥),
And achieves transcendence (神仙).

**Jishi** (芰实): flavor sweet (甘) and spicy (辛), neutral (平), non-toxic (无毒).
Calms the middle (安中),
Supplements the five zang organs (补五脏),
Prevents hunger (不饥),
And lightens the body (轻身).
Also known as **Ling** (菱).
**Emperor Huangdi** (黄帝) said: *"In the seventh month, do not eat raw **ling** or **jishi**; they breed worms (作烧虫)."*

**Lizi** (栗子): flavor salty (咸), warm (温), non-toxic (无毒).
Augments **qi** (益气),
Strengthens the intestines and stomach (厚肠胃),
Supplements kidney **qi** (补肾气),
And enhances endurance to hunger (令人耐饥).
**Raw consumption is especially effective for treating weakness in the waist and legs (甚治腰脚不遂).**

**Yingtao** (樱桃): flavor sweet (甘), neutral (平), astringent (濇).
Harmonizes the middle and augments **qi** (调中益气),
Can be consumed in abundance (可多食),
And brings good complexion and refined temperament (令人好颜色, 美志性).

**Juju** (橘柚): flavor spicy (辛), warm (温), non-toxic (无毒).
Treats **chest stagnation-heat** (胸中瘕热) and **reversed vital breath** (逆气),
Promotes digestion and assimilation (利水谷),
Expels **qi** and stops vomiting and coughing (下气止呕咳),
Removes lingering heat in the bladder and stagnant water (除膀胱留热停水),
Breaks **five types of dysuria** (破五淋),
Promotes urination (利小便),
Treats **spleen inability to digest food** (治脾不能消谷),
**Stops chest inversion-vomiting and cholera** (却胸中吐逆霍乱),
Stops diarrhea and dysentery (止泻利),
Removes **white spots on teeth** (去寸白),
Prolonged consumption eliminates foul breath (久服去口臭),
Expels **qi** and opens the spirit (下气通神),
Lightens the body and extends life (轻身长年).
Also known as **Jupi** (橘皮); aged specimens are superior (陈久者良).

**Jinfuzi** (津符子): flavor bitter (苦), neutral (平), slippery (滑).
Excessive consumption refreshes the mouth (令人口爽),
Causing loss of taste perception (不知五味).

**Meishi** (梅实): flavor sour (酸), neutral (平), astringent (濇), non-toxic (无毒).
Expels **qi** and removes heat and fullness (下气除热烦满),
Calms the heart (安心);
Stops limb pain, **hemiplegia with numbness** (偏枯不仁), and **dead flesh** (死肌),
Removes **blue-black moles and malignant moles** (去青黑痣、恶痣);
Stops diarrhea and dysentery (止下利),
**Cures excessive salivation and dry mouth** (好唾口乾),
And benefits tendons and vessels (利筋脉).
Excessive consumption harms the teeth (多食坏人齿).

**Shizi** (柿): flavor sweet (甘), cold (寒), astringent (濇), non-toxic (无毒).
**Harmonizes the five types of vital breath** (通和五气),
Treats **intestinal dampness insufficiency** (主肠澼不足) and **fire sores** (火疮),
**Golden wounds** (金疮);
Stops pain (止痛).

**Mugua Shi** (木瓜实): flavor sour (酸) and salty (咸), warm (温), astringent (濇), non-toxic (无毒).
Treats **dampness in joints and muscles** (主湿痹气) and **chronic vomiting/diarrhea** (霍乱),
**Severe post-emetic leg cramps** (大吐下后脚转筋不止).
Its **raw bark is non-toxic** (生树皮无毒) and can also be cooked (亦可煮用).

**Jishi** (极实): flavor sweet (甘), neutral (平), astringent (濇), non-toxic (无毒).
Treats **five types of hemorrhoids** (主五痔),
Expels **three types of parasitic worms** (去三虫),
Kills **poisonous toxins, ghostly diseases, and malignant poisons** (杀蛊毒、鬼疰、恶毒).

**Ganzhe** (甘蔗): flavor sweet (甘), neutral (平), astringent (濇), non-toxic (无毒).
Expels **qi** and harmonizes the middle (下气和中),
Supplements spleen **qi** (补脾气),
Benefits the large intestine (利大肠),
Stops thirst and relieves vexation (止渴去烦),
Detoxifies alcohol (解酒毒).

**Ruanzao** (软枣): flavor bitter (苦), cold (冷), astringent (濇), non-toxic (无毒).
Excessive consumption reactivates chronic illnesses (多食动宿病),
Augments cold **qi** (益冷气),
And induces coughing (发咳嗽).
**Yu** (芋): flavor spicy (辛), neutral (平), slippery (滑), toxic (有毒).
Relaxes the intestines and stomach (宽肠胃),
Fills the flesh and skin (充肌肤),
And smooths the middle (滑中).
Also known as **Tuzhi** (土芝); **excessive consumption is contraindicated** (不可多食),
And it **stirs cold stagnation** (动宿冷).
**Wu Yu** (乌芋): flavor bitter (苦) and sweet (甘), slightly cold (微寒), slippery (滑), non-toxic (无毒).
Treats **diabetes and stagnation-heat** (主消渴瘅热);
Augments **qi** (益气).
Also known as **Jiegu** (藉姑) and **Shuiping** (水萍).
**Harvest in the third month** (三月采).

**Xinghe Ren** (杏核仁): flavor sweet (甘) and bitter (苦), warm (温), cold yet **promoting** (冷而利), toxic (有毒).
Treats **coughing, reversed vital breath, and upward-rising **qi**** (主咳逆上气),
**Intestinal thunder** (肠中雷鸣), and **throat obstruction** (喉痹);
Expels **qi** (下气);
Induces lactation and treats **golden wounds** (产乳金疮),
**Cold in the heart, palpitations, and epigastric oppression** (寒心贲豚),
**Convulsions and shock** (惊痫), and **epigastric heat and vexation** (心下烦热);
**Expels wind and pathogenic **qi**** (风气去来),
**Seasonal epidemic headaches** (时行头痛),
And **disperses muscles and dissolves epigastric urgency** (解肌消心下急).
Kills **dog poison** (杀狗毒).
**Harvest in the fifth month** (五月采之).
**Its kernel with two seeds is harmful** (其一核两仁者害人),
And should be discarded (宜去之).
**Its raw fruit, still sour in taste, with the stone not yet hardened,**
**when dried and consumed, is especially effective in stopping thirst (甚止渴)**
And removing cold-heat poisons (去冷热毒).
**Bian Que** (扁鹊) said: *"Apricot kernels should not be consumed for long, as they cause blindness (令人目盲), falling of eyebrows and hair, and reactivate all chronic illnesses (动一切宿病)."*

**Taohu Ren** (桃核仁): flavor bitter (苦), sweet (甘), and spicy (辛), neutral (平), non-toxic (无毒).
Breaks **stagnant blood** (破瘀血),
**Blood clots and bruises** (血闭痕),
**Pathogenic **qi**** (邪气),
And kills small parasites (杀小虫).
Treats **coughing, reversed vital breath, and upward-rising **qi**** (治咳逆上气),
Dissolves **epigastric hardness** (消心下硬),
And removes **sudden violent blood strikes** (除卒暴击血).
Breaks **syndrome masses** (破症瘕),
Promotes **menstrual flow** (通月水),
And stops **heart pain** (止心痛).
**Harvest in the seventh month** (七月采).
**In general, all fruits with kernels containing two seeds are harmful** (凡一切果核中有两仁者并害人),
And should not be used (不在用).
**Its raw fruit is sour in flavor and non-toxic** (其实味酸, 无毒),
But excessive consumption causes heat (多食令人有热).
**Emperor Huangdi** (黄帝) said: *"After eating peaches to fullness and taking a water bath, one may develop dysuria (成淋病)."*

**Lihe Ren** (李核仁): flavor bitter (苦), neutral (平), non-toxic (无毒).
Treats **stiffness, collapse, and sudden paralysis** (主僵仆跻),
**Stagnant blood and bone pain** (瘀血骨痛).
**Lishi** (李实): flavor bitter (苦) and sour (酸), slightly warm (微温), astringent (涩), non-toxic (无毒).
Removes **fixed heat** (除固热),
Harmonizes the middle (调中),
And benefits the heart (宜心).
**Excessive consumption causes emptiness** (不可多食, 令人虚).
**Emperor Huangdi** (黄帝) said: *"Plums should not be eaten with white honey, as they corrode the five internal organs (蚀人五内)."*

**Ling** (梨): flavor sweet (甘) and slightly sour (微酸), cold (寒), astringent (濇), toxic (有毒).
Expels **foreign heat and pathogenic **qi**** (除客热气),
And stops **heart vexation** (止心烦).
**Excessive consumption causes cold in the middle** (不可多食, 令人寒中).
**Contraindicated for those with golden wounds or postpartum women** (金疮、产妇勿食),
As it causes **prostration and cold in the middle** (令人萎困、寒中).

**Linzhen** (林擒): flavor sour (酸) and bitter (苦), neutral (平), astringent (濇), non-toxic (无毒).
**Induces thirst and excessive salivation** (渴、好唾).
**Excessive consumption weakens the hundred vessels** (不可多食, 令人百脉弱).

**Nai Zi** (奈子): flavor sour (酸) and bitter (苦), cold (寒), astringent (濇), non-toxic (无毒).
**Induces hunger** (饥),
And benefits **heart **qi**** (益心气).

「Excessive consumption causes **abdominal distension** (胪胀).
For those with chronic illness, consumption worsens their condition (久病人食之，其病尤甚).

**Pomegranate (安石榴):** flavor sweet (甘) and sour (酸), astringent (濇), non-toxic (无毒).
**Stops throat dryness and thirst** (止咽燥渴).
Excessive consumption harms the lungs (不可多食，损人肺).

**Loquat Leaf (枇杷叶):** flavor bitter (苦), neutral (平), non-toxic (无毒).
**Stops incessant hiccups** (主啘不止) and **settles rebellious **qi**** (下气).
*[Method:]* Scrape fresh bark from the tree, chew it, and swallow the juice in small amounts. Alternatively, boil the juice and consume it cold—both methods are highly effective (正尔削取生树皮嚼之，少少咽汁，亦可煮汁冷服，大佳).

**Walnut (胡桃):** flavor sweet (甘), cold (冷), slippery (滑), non-toxic (无).
Excessive consumption **stirs phlegm and fluids** (动痰饮), causing nausea (恶心), vomiting of water (吐水), and vomiting of food (吐食).

---
**Section 58: Vegetables (菜蔬第三五十八条)**

**Goji Leaf (枸杞叶):** flavor bitter (苦), neutral (平), astringent (濇), non-toxic (无毒).
**Tonifies deficiency and weakness** (补虚赢), **benefits essence and marrow** (益精髓).
*A proverb states:* "When away from home for a thousand *li*, do not eat *luólu* or goji (枸杞)."
This refers to those with **excessive yang** (强阳道) and those who **nourish yin **qi** to hasten recovery** (资阴气速疾).

**Luólu (萝藦):** flavor sweet (甘), neutral (平), non-toxic (无毒).
*Also called:* **bitter pill** (苦丸).
Its leaves are thick and large, growing as vines. When freshly picked, they exude white juice.
Commonly cultivated at homes; can be eaten raw or steamed/boiled.
Its **tonifying benefits are the same as goji leaf** (补益与枸杞叶同).

**Pumpkin Seeds (瓜子):** flavor sweet (甘), neutral (平) to cold (寒), non-toxic (无毒).
**Imparts luster and improves complexion** (令人光泽，好颜色), **benefits **qi**** (益气), **suppresses hunger** (不饥), and with prolonged use **lightens the body and prolongs life** (轻身耐老).
Also **relieves chest fullness and heart discontent** (除胸满心不乐).
Prolonged consumption causes **cold in the middle** (久食寒中).
Can be made into **face cream** (可作面脂).
*Also called:* **water zhi** (水芝), **white pumpkin seeds** (白瓜子)—these are **winter melon seeds** (冬瓜仁).
*Harvest in the 8th month (August).*

**White Winter Melon (白冬瓜):** flavor sweet (甘), mild (微), non-toxic (无毒).
**Relieves lower abdominal distension and water retention** (除小腹水胀), **promotes urination** (利小便), and **stops diabetes** (止消渴).

**General Melon (凡瓜):** flavor sweet (甘), cold (寒), slippery (滑), non-toxic (无毒).
**Quenches thirst** (去渴), but excessive consumption causes **vulvar itching, dampness, and sores** (阴下痒湿生疮), as well as **jaundice** (发黄疸).
*The Yellow Emperor said:* "Do not eat frost-bitten melons in the 9th month (September)."
This may lead to **fever and chills, or warm diseases** (向冬发寒热及温病).
Even the first bite may induce vomiting (初食时即令人欲吐).
After eating, **stagnant water forms in the chest** (心内作停水), unable to dissipate on its own, potentially causing **reverse peristalsis** (或为反胃).
If melons sink in water, consuming them may cause **ling disease** (得玲病), an incurable lifelong condition (终身不瘥).

**Cucumber (越瓜):** flavor sweet (甘), neutral (平), non-toxic (无毒).
Should not be eaten for prolonged periods (不可久食).
**Benefits the intestines and stomach** (益肠胃).

**Bitter Gourd (胡瓜):** flavor sweet (甘), cold (寒), **toxic** (有毒).
Excessive consumption **stirs cold and heat** (动寒热), leading to **frequent malaria** (多疟病) and **stagnant heat with blood stasis** (积瘀血热).

**Early Green Gourd (早青瓜):** flavor sweet (甘), cold (寒), non-toxic (无毒).
**Dissipates heat and vexation** (去热烦).
Prolonged consumption causes **excessive forgetfulness** (多忘).

**Winter Mallow Seeds (冬葵子):** flavor sweet (甘), cold (寒), non-toxic (无毒).
**Regulates cold and heat in the five **zàng** organs and six **fǔ** organs** (主五脏六腑寒热赢瘦), **dissolves five types of **lin** syndrome** (破五淋), and **promotes urination** (利小便).
For women: **relieves difficult lactation** (妇人乳难) and **blood stagnation** (血闭).
Prolonged use **strengthens bones** (坚骨), **lengthens muscles** (长肌肉), **lightens the body and extends life** (轻身延年).
*Harvest in the 12th month (December).*
**Leaves:** flavor sweet (甘), cold (寒), slippery (滑), non-toxic (无毒).
**Harmonizes the spleen** (宜脾); prolonged use **benefits stomach **qi**** (利胃气).
*The heart of the plant is toxic—avoid consuming it with any medicine (其心伤人，百药忌食心，心有毒).*
*The Yellow Emperor said:* "Eating frost-bitten winter mallow raw **stirs five types of **liúyǐn** fluids** (动五种流饮)."
Excessive fluid intake may cause vomiting (饮盛则吐水).
Consuming **fresh winter mallow with fresh carp** (凡葵菜和鲤鱼鲜食之) is harmful.
Avoid eating raw winter mallow during the **soil-dominant months** (四季之月土王时), as it may cause **indigestion and trigger latent illnesses** (令人饮食不化，发宿病).

**Amaranth Seeds (苋菜实):** flavor sweet (甘), cold (寒), astringent (濇), non-toxic (无毒).
**Treats glaucoma and cataracts** (主青盲、白翳), **brightens the eyes** (明目), **expels pathogenic **qi**** (除邪气), **promotes urination** (利大小便), **regulates cold and heat** (去寒热), and **kills roundworms** (杀蛔虫).
Prolonged use **strengthens **qi** and vitality** (益气力), **suppresses hunger** (不饥), and **lightens the body** (轻身).
*Also called:* **horse amaranth** (马苋), **mo shí** (莫实)—this is **amaranth** (马齿苋菜).
**Treats eczema** (治反花疮).

**Small Amaranth (小苋菜):** flavor sweet (甘), **greatly cold** (大寒), slippery (滑), non-toxic (无毒).
Can be eaten for prolonged periods; **strengthens **qi** and vitality** (益气力) and **expels heat** (除热).
*Avoid consuming with turtle meat*—this combination causes **turtle-related stagnation** (不可共鳖肉食，成鳖瘕).
Consuming with **fern** (蕨菜) also causes **turtle-related stagnation**.

**Common Lamb’s Quarters (邪蒿):** flavor spicy (辛), warm (温), astringent (濇), non-toxic (无毒).
**Expels foul odors in the chest and diaphragm** (主胸膈中臭恶气) and **benefits the intestines and stomach** (利肠胃).

**Dandelion (苦菜):** flavor bitter (苦), **greatly cold** (大寒), slippery (滑), non-toxic (无毒).
**Expels pathogenic **qi** from the five **zàng** organs** (主五脏邪气), **relieves stomach atrophy and stagnation** (厌谷胃痹), **clears the intestines** (肠澼), **quells excessive thirst and internal heat** (大渴热中), and **treats acute illnesses and malignant sores** (暴疾，恶疮).
Prolonged use **calms the mind and benefits **qi**** (安心益气), **sharpening perception and reducing sleep** (聪察少卧), **lightening the body and enduring old age, hunger, and cold** (轻身耐老，耐饥寒).
*Also called:* **tea#7 grass** (茶#7草), **xuǎn** (选), **yóudōng** (游冬).
*Survives winter without dying* (冬不死).
*Harvest every month in the 4th month (April).*

**Jìcài (Shepherd’s Purse):** flavor sweet (甘), warm (温), astringent (濇), non-toxic (无毒).
**Benefits liver **qi**, harmonizes the middle (and), kills all poisons (杀诸毒).
Its seeds **treat blurred vision, eye pain, and excessive tearing** (主明目、目痛、泪出);
its roots **treat dry, painful eyes** (主目濇痛).

**Wújīng (Chinese Cabbage) and Lǘbó (Turnip Greens):** flavor bitter (苦), cold (冷), astringent (濇), non-toxic (无毒).
**Benefits the five **zàng** organs, lightens the body and benefits **qi**; suitable for prolonged consumption (利五脏，轻身益气，宜久食).
**Wújīng seeds:** **clears the eyes** (朋目); after nine steaming and drying cycles, **treats jaundice, promotes urination, and, when taken long-term, grants divine immortality** (九蒸曝，疗黄疸，利小便，久服神仙).
Its roots: **treat #8 wind-heat toxin-induced swelling** (主#8消风热毒肿).
**Excessive consumption causes abdominal distension** (不可多食，令人气胀).

**Sōngcài (Potherb Mustard):** flavor sweet (甘), warm (温), astringent (濇), non-toxic (无毒).
**Prolonged consumption smooths and benefits the intestines and stomach, relieves chest congestion, and resolves excessive thirst** (久食通利肠胃，除胸中烦，解消渴).
Originally a variant of **turnip (蔓菁)**, but when cultivated in the south, it transforms into **Sōngcài**, much like how **citron (枳) and orange (橘)** adapt to their soil (本是蔓菁也，种之江南即化为嵩，亦如枳橘，所生土地随变).

**Jiècài (Mustard Greens):** flavor pungent (辛), warm (温), non-toxic (无毒).
**Directs **qi** to the nose, dispels kidney **pathogens**, **severely breaks coughing and reverse breathing** (大破咳逆#9), **descends **qi**, benefits the nine orifices, sharpens vision and hearing, and harmonizes the middle. Prolonged consumption **warms the middle** (久食温中); some say it **cools the middle** (又云寒中).
Its seeds: flavor pungent (辛); also **direct **qi** to the nose**, toxic (有毒).
**Treat throat obstruction, remove all wind-toxin-induced swellings** (主喉痹，去一切风毒肿).
**The Yellow Emperor said:** Mustard greens **must not be eaten with rabbit meat**, as it causes malignant disorders (黄帝云：芥菜不可共兔肉食，成恶邪病).

**Mùxu (Alfalfa):** flavor bitter (苦), neutral (平), astringent (濇), non-toxic (无毒).
**Harmonizes the middle, benefits the four limbs; suitable for prolonged consumption** (安中，利人四体，可久食).

**Róngzǐ (Lotus Seeds):** flavor pungent (辛), warm (温), non-toxic (无毒).
**Treat coughing and reverse breathing, descend **qi**, warm the middle, and nourish the marrow** (主咳逆，下气，温中，补髓).
Its leaves: **regulate the middle and remove foul odors** (主调中，去嗅气).
**Harvest in the 9th month (October), dry in shade for use. Its oil can also be used as a protective coating** (九月采，阴乾用之。油亦可作油衣).

**Mèngshí (Job’s Tears):** flavor pungent (辛), warm (温), non-toxic (无毒).
**Sharpen vision, warm the middle, resolve the muscles, endure wind and cold, descend water **qi**, treat facial and bodily edema, and prevent carbuncles and abscesses** (明目，温中，解肌，耐风寒，下水气，面目浮肿，却痈疽).
Its leaves: pungent (辛), **direct **qi** to the tongue** (归舌).
**Treat pathogenic **qi** in the large and small intestines; benefit the middle and enhance willpower** (治大小肠邪气；利中，益志).
**The Yellow Emperor said:** Excessive consumption of **lǚ (Polygonum) is toxic**, causing heart pain. Eating it raw with fish **depletes **qi** and causes testicular pain leading to death. Women during menstruation **must not eat lǚ or garlic**, as it causes blood clots and vaginal discharge. Avoid lǚ in the 2nd month (March), as it harms the kidneys. **Bian Que said:** Prolonged consumption of lǚ causes alternating cold and heat, damages the marrow, **depletes male **yin** energy, and reduces semen** (蓼食过多有毒，发心痛。和生鱼食之，令人脱气，阴核疼痛求死。妇人月事来，不用食蓼及蒜，喜为血琳、带下。二月勿食蓼，伤人肾。扁鹊云：蓼，久食令人寒热，损骨髓，杀丈夫阴气，少精).

**Cōngshí (Onion Seeds):** flavor pungent (辛), warm (温), non-toxic (无毒).
**Benefits the lungs** (宜肺). **Directs pungent **qi** to the head, sharpens vision, and supplements middle deficiencies** (辛归头，明目，补中不足).
Its white stems: neutral (平), slippery (滑), can be used in soups (可作汤).
**Treat injury from cold with alternating cold and heat, bone and muscle pain, and induce sweating; treat windstroke, facial and bodily edema, and throat obstruction. Stabilizes pregnancy. Counteracts cinnamon. (主伤寒寒热，骨肉碎痛，能出汗；治中风，面目浮肿，喉痹不通。安胎。杀桂).
Its green leaves: warm (温), pungent (辛), **direct **qi** to the eyes** (归目).
**Remove liver **pathogens**, harmonize the middle, benefit the five **zàng** organs; enhance eye clarity; induce jaundice, and counteract all poisons** (除肝中邪气，安中，利五脏；益目精；发黄疸，杀百药毒).
Its roots and stalks: neutral (平).
**Treat cold-induced headaches** (主伤寒头痛).
**Onion tears and raw onion juice:** neutral (平), slippery (滑).
**Stop urinary bleeding and resolve **lǚ (Polygonum) and cinnamon toxicity** (止尿血，解藜芦及桂毒).
**The Yellow Emperor said:** Eating raw onion immediately followed by honey **causes diarrhea**; eating scorched onion with honey **causes fatal abdominal distension** (黄帝云：食生葱即啖蜜，变作下利；食烧葱并啖蜜，拥气而死). **Do not eat raw onion in the 1st month (February)**, as it causes facial wind rashes (正月不得食生葱，令人面上起游风).

**Gécōng (Chive):** flavor pungent (辛), slightly warm (微温), non-toxic (无毒).
**Remove pestilential **qi** and malignant toxins** (除瘴气恶毒).
**Prolonged consumption benefits gallbladder **qi** and strengthens willpower** (久食益胆气，强志).

**Onion seeds:** Treat seminal emission (主泄精).

**Scallion (薤):** Flavor bitter, pungent (苦、辛), warm (温), slippery (滑), non-toxic (无毒).
**Nourishes the heart**, pungent nature enters the bones (宜心，辛归骨).
**Treats traumatic wounds, ulcers, and sores**; promotes flesh regeneration (主金疮疮败，能生肌肉).
**Lightens the body, suppresses hunger**, and prolongs life (轻身不饥，耐老).
Also called *càizhī* (菜芝).
**Eliminates cold and heat**, dispels dampness, warms the middle, and scatters stagnant *qi*; benefits postpartum ailments (除寒热，去水气，温中，散结气；利产妇病人).
For wind-cold-induced rashes, edema, and sores, crush fresh and apply (诸疮中风寒水肿，生捣傅之).
If the *lèigǔ* (鲠骨, lodged bone fragment) is stuck in the throat and cannot be swallowed, consuming it will remove it (鲠骨在咽不下者，食之则去).
**The Yellow Emperor said:** Scallion should not be cooked with beef in a stew, as it causes *jū* (瘕, abdominal masses) (黄帝云：薤不可共牛肉作羹食之，成瘕疾). Leek (*jiǔ*) is likewise (韭亦然).
In the **10th, 11th, and 12th months (November–January)**, do not eat raw scallion, as it causes excessive nasal discharge and spitting (十月、十一月、十二月，勿食生薤，令人多涕唾).

**Leek (韭):** Flavor pungent, sour (辛、酸), warm (温), dry (濇), non-toxic (无毒).
**Pungent nature enters the heart**, benefits the liver (辛归心，宜肝).
**May be consumed long-term**, stabilizing the five *zàng* organs, and dispels stomach heat (可久食，安五脏，除胃中热).
**Harmful to the sick**; those with chronic cold in the chest or abdomen will worsen if consumed (不利病人，其心腹有痼冷者，食之必加剧).
**Its seeds:** Treat nocturnal seminal emission and cloudy urine (其子：主梦泄精，尿色白).
**Roots:** Boil the juice to nourish hair (根：煮汁以养发).
**The Yellow Emperor said:** Frozen leek in frost should not be eaten raw, as it agitates lingering fluids—excessive drinking afterward will cause vomiting (霜韭冻不可生食，动宿饮，饮盛，必吐水).
Do not eat leek in the **5th month (June)**, as it diminishes flavor and weakens vitality (五月勿食韭，损人滋味，令人乏气力).
In the **2nd and 3rd months (March–April)**, leek is beneficial to the heart (二月、三月宜食韭，大益人心).

**White Delicate Onion (白奠荷):** Flavor pungent (辛), slightly warm (微温), dry (濇), non-toxic (无毒).
**Treats *wù* (蛊, parasitic infestation) and malaria** (主中蛊及疟病).
Crush the juice and take three *hé* (合, ~200ml) daily, twice a day (捣汁服三合，日二).
**Fresh roots:** Treat various sores (生根：主诸疮).

**Mulberry Leaf Lettuce (慕菜):** Flavor sweet, bitter (甘、苦), intensely cold (大寒), non-toxic (无毒).
**Treats seasonal epidemic fevers** and resolves wind-heat toxins (主时行壮热，解风热恶毒).

**Perilla (紫苏):** Flavor pungent (辛), slightly warm (微温), non-toxic (无毒).
**Subdues rebellious *qi*** and dispels internal cold; its seeds are particularly effective (下气，除寒中，其子尤善).

**Chicken Perilla (鸡苏):** Flavor pungent (辛), slightly warm (微温), dry (濇), non-toxic (无毒).
**Stops bleeding** and subdues rebellious *qi* (主吐血，下气).
Also called *shuǐsū* (水苏).

**Basil (罗勒):** Flavor bitter, pungent (苦、辛), warm and neutral (温、平), dry (濇), non-toxic (无毒).
**Dissolves and stabilizes water retention**, scatters toxic *qi* (消停水，散毒气).
**Should not be consumed long-term**, as it dries the *róng* and *wèi* (荣卫, nutritive and defensive *qi*) (不可久食，濇荣卫诸气).

**Dill (芜荑):** Flavor pungent (辛), neutral (平), hot (热), slippery (滑), non-toxic (无毒).
**Treats internal pathogenic *qi*** and scatters **excessive heat** moving through the skin, joints, and bones; expels intestinal parasites, digests undigested food, eliminates *cùnbái* (寸白, threadworms), and disperses abdominal heat-induced wheezing (主五内邪气，散皮肤骨节中淫淫温行毒，去三虫，能化宿食不消，逐寸白，散腹中温温喘息).
Also called *wúgū* (无姑) and [missing character] (□□).
When stored in containers, it strongly repels leeches; its odor is foul—this is made from *shānyú* (山榆, mountain elm) seeds (盛器物中甚辟水蛭，其气甚臭，此即山榆子作之).

**Elm Leaves (榆叶):** Flavor sweet (甘), neutral (平), slippery (滑), non-toxic (无毒).
**Treats infantile epilepsy**, dysuria, summer-heat exhaustion, and oppression; boil the juice and drink cold (主小儿痫，小便不利，伤暑热困闷，煮汁冷服).
**Fresh elm bark (生榆白皮):** Flavor sweet (甘), cold (冷), non-toxic (无毒).
**Promotes urination** and breaks *shílín* (石淋, urinary calculi) (利小便，破石淋).
**Flowers:** Treat infantile scalp sores (花：主小儿头疮).

**Gourd Seeds (葫荽子):** Flavor sour (酸), neutral (平), non-toxic (无毒).
**Digest food** and restore appetite (消谷，能复食味).
**Leaves should not be eaten long-term**, as they cause forgetfulness (叶不可久食，令人多忘).
**Hua Tuo said:** Those with *húchòu* (胡臭, halitosis) or foul breath should not eat it; those with **rotten teeth** will worsen; those with internal pathogenic *qi* must avoid it—consumption will exacerbate chronic illness, especially in traumatic wounds (华佗云：葫荽菜，患胡臭人，患口气臭；□齿人食之加剧；腹内患邪气者，弥不得食，食之发宿病，金疮尤忌).

**Seaweed (海藻):** Salty (咸), cold (寒), slippery (滑), non-toxic (无毒).
**Treats goiter, neck nodules, and abdominal masses**; disperses hard lumps in the neck causing pain; treats **ascending and descending intestinal rumbling**, edema of the lower limbs, promotes urination, and arouses male *yīn* vitality (主瘿瘤结气，散颈下硬核痛者，肠内上下雷呜，下十二水肿，利小便，起男子阴气).

**Kelp (昆布):** Flavor salty (咸), cold (寒), slippery (滑), non-toxic (无毒).
**Treats lower-limb edema, goiter, fistulas, and abdominal masses**; breaks accumulations (下十二水肿，瘿瘤结气，瘘疮，破积聚).

**Chamomile (茼蒿):** Flavor pungent (辛), neutral (平), non-toxic (无毒).
**Stabilizes heart *qi*** and nourishes the spleen and stomach; resolves phlegm and dampness (安心气，养脾胃，消痰饮).

**White Mugwort (白蒿):** Flavor bitter, pungent (苦、辛), neutral (平), non-toxic (无毒).
**Nourishes the five *zàng* organs**, supplements the middle, and benefits *qi*; promotes hair growth (养五脏，补中益气，长毛发).
**Long-term consumption grants longevity**; white rabbits that eat it become immortal (久食不死，白兔食之仙).

**Chinese Hollyhock (吴葵):** Also called *shǔkuí* (蜀葵).
Flavor sweet (甘), slightly cold (微寒), slippery (滑), non-toxic (无毒).
**Flowers:** Stabilize heart *qi* (花：定心气).
**Leaves:** Dispel external heat and benefit the intestines and stomach (叶：除客热，利肠胃).
**Should not be eaten long-term**, as it dulls the mind (不可久食，钝人志性).
If eaten and then bitten by a dog, the wound will never heal (若食之，被狗啮者，疮永不瘥).

**Hogfennel (藿):** Flavor salty (咸), cold (寒), dry (濇), non-toxic (无毒).
**Benefits the kidneys** and treats frequent urination (宜肾，主大小便数).
Dispels restlessness and heat (去烦热).

**Coriander (香菜):** Flavor pungent (辛), slightly warm (微温).
**Treats cholera, abdominal pain, vomiting/diarrhea**, disperses edema, resolves restlessness, and dispels heat (主霍乱、腹痛、吐下，散水肿、烦心，去热).

**Winter Melon (甜瓠):** Flavor sweet (甘), neutral (平), slippery (滑), non-toxic (无毒).
**Treats diabetes, malignant sores**, and rotting flesh in the nose and mouth (主消渴、恶疮，鼻、口中肉烂痛).
**Leaves:** Flavor sweet (甘), neutral (平); suppress hunger (主耐饥).
**Bian Que said:** Those with *jiǎoqì* (脚气, beriberi) or edema should not eat it, as the condition will never resolve (扁鹊云：患脚气虚胀者，不得食之，患永不除).

**Morning Glory (莼):** Flavor sweet (甘), cold (寒), slippery (滑), non-toxic (无毒).
**Treats diabetes and heat-induced numbness** (主消渴热痹).
**Excessive consumption aggravates hemorrhoids** (多食动痔病).

**Jewelweed (落葵):** Flavor sour (酸), cold (寒), non-toxic (无毒).
**Slippery in nature**, disperses heat and solidification; beautifies and moistens the complexion (滑中，散热实，悦泽人面).
Also called *tiānkuí* (天葵) and *xìlù* (系露).

**Hemp Sesbania (系篓):** Flavor sour (酸), neutral (平), non-toxic (无毒).
**Treats chronic sores and unhealing hemorrhoids** (主积年恶疮、痔不愈者).
If harvested at noon on the **5th day of the 5th month (May 5th)**, it is called *zīcǎo* (滋草) or *jīchángcǎo* (鸡肠草); dry and burn into ash for use (五月五日日中采之，即名滋草，一名鸡肠草，乾之烧作焦灰用).
**Bian Que said:** For men with malignant sores, ulcerated penile shafts, and unbearable pain that never heals, mix **one part ash** with **two parts fresh earthworm feces**, add a little water, grind into a paste like congealed porridge, apply to the sores, and replace when dry. **Avoid alcohol, wheat, the five pungent spices, and hot foods** (扁鹊云：丈夫患恶疮，阴头及茎作疮脓烂，疼痛不可堪忍，久不瘥者，以灰一分，蚯蚓新出屎泥二分，以少水和研，缓如煎饼面，以泥疮上，乾则易之。禁酒、面、五辛并热食等).
**The Yellow Emperor said:** Consuming *fánluó* (蘩蒌, a type of gourd) with *zǔ* (组, possibly *Zizania* or a similar plant) raw will induce diabetes and cause forgetfulness (黄帝云：蘩蒌合组鲜食之，发消渴病，令人多忘).
There is another variety growing in warm, damp areas near waterways in winter, resembling gourd leaves, also called *jīchángcǎo* (鸡肠菜), which can treat hemorrhoids (别有一种，近水渠中温湿处冬生，其状类葫荽，亦名鸡肠菜，可以疗痔病，一名天葫荽).

「**Jie (蕺):** Bitter and pungent in flavor, slightly warm in nature, with minor toxicity. Treats scabies and urinary sores.

Excessive consumption causes **breathing difficulties (气喘)** and harms the feet, leading to foot pain.

**Hu (葫):** Pungent in flavor, warm in nature, and toxic. Its pungency enters the five *zàng* organs (五脏), disperses abscesses and carbuncles, treats fresh sores, dispels wind *xie* (邪), kills **worm toxicity (蛊毒)** and **noxious *qi* (毒气)**, and is particularly effective for those with only one child.

The Yellow Emperor said: Consuming raw **hu (葫)** with **green fish sauce (青鱼鲊)**, induces internal abdominal sores, intestinal swelling, and **hernia (疝瘕)**. Excessive consumption of raw **hu** during sexual activity damages the liver *qi*, causing pallor in the face.

Avoid eating **hu** in the **fourth and eighth months (四月、八月)**, as it harms the spirit, weakens the gallbladder *qi*, causes **breathing difficulties and palpitations (喘悸)**, sharp pain in the sides and ribs (**胁肋气急**), and excessive thirst (**口味多爽**).

**Small Garlic (小蒜):** Pungent in flavor, warm in nature, and non-toxic. Its pungency enters the **spleen and kidneys (脾、肾)**. Treats **dysentery (霍乱)**, abdominal discomfort, **loss of appetite (消谷)**, regulates stomach *qi*, warms the **midsection (温中)**, dispels **pathogenic *bi* (邪痹)** and **noxious *qi* (毒气)**, and should be harvested on the **fifth day of the fifth month (五月五日)** and dried in the sun.

Its leaves treat **heart-related restlessness and pain (心烦痛)**, detoxify all poisons, and **childhood measles (小儿丹)**; however, prolonged consumption weakens the heart’s vitality.

The Yellow Emperor said: Eating **small garlic (小蒜)** with raw fish causes **loss of breath (夺气)** and **pain in the scrotum (阴核疼)**, leading to a desire for death. Avoid eating **small garlic** in the **third month (三月)**, as it harms one’s **resolution and temperament (志性)**.

**Mint Leaves (茗叶):** Bitter, salty, and sour in flavor, cold in nature, and non-toxic. Can be consumed long-term, enhancing vitality, **pleasing the mind (悦志)**, and subtly invigorating the *qi*. The Yellow Emperor said: Do not eat mint with **leeks (韭)**, as it causes **body heaviness (身重)**.

**Bitter Melon (蕃荷菜):** Bitter and pungent in flavor, warm in nature, and non-toxic. Can be consumed long-term, **calming kidney *qi* (却肾气)**, and refreshing the breath. Treats **pathogenic evils (辟邪毒)** and **fatigue from overwork (除劳弊)**. Those who are **lean and exhausted (瘦疲倦)** should avoid prolonged consumption, as it may **trigger diabetes (动消渴病)**.

**Xanthium Fruit (苍耳子):** Bitter and sweet in flavor, warm in nature. Its leaves are bitter and pungent, slightly cool, and **damp (濇)**, with minor toxicity. Treats **wind-related headaches (风头寒)**, **wind-damp *bi* (风湿痹)**, and **painful muscle contractions (拘急挛痛)**; removes **malignant flesh (恶肉)**, **dead tissue (死肌)**, **knee pain (膝痛)**, and **noxious dampness (溪毒)**. Long-term consumption **benefits the *qi* (益气)**, sharpens hearing and vision, **strengthens resolve and lightens the body (强志轻身)**. Also known as **Húqì (胡葈)**, **Dìqú (地葵)**, **Shī (施)**, and **Chángsī (常思)**. In **Sìshǔ (蜀)**, it is called **Yángfùlái (羊负来)**; in **Qín (秦)**, **Cāng’ěr (苍耳)**; and in **Wèi (魏)**, **Zhǐcì (只刺)**.

The Yellow Emperor said: **Xanthium fruit with its husk (戴甲苍耳)** should not be eaten with **pork (猪肉)**, as it harms the person. Consuming **sweet congee (甜粥)** followed by **Xanthium fruit with its husk beneath (苍耳甲下之)**, causes **migratory pain (走注)** and **sharp pain in the sides (两胁)**. It should be avoided after the **beginning of autumn (立秋)**.

**Tea Olive (食茱萸):** Pungent and bitter in flavor, **greatly warm (大温)**, and non-toxic. Harvested in the **ninth month (九月)**, with older specimens being superior. Its **closed-mouthed seeds (闭口者)** are toxic and should not be used. Stops pain, **settles *qi* downward (下气)**, dispels **coughing and reverse airflow (咳逆)**, removes **cold from the five *zàng* organs (五脏中寒冷)**, warms the midsection, and resolves **all cold-related stagnations (诸冷实不消)**. Its **white-skinned variety (生白皮)** treats **abdominal evil (中恶)** and **abdominal pain (腹痛)**, stopping **toothache (齿疼)**. Its **fine-rooted variety (根细者)** eliminates **three types of worms (三虫)** and **roundworms (寸白)**.

The Yellow Emperor said: Avoid eating **tea olive (茱萸)** in the **sixth and seventh months (六月、七月)**, as it harms the spirit and causes **erratic breathing (起伏气)**.

For **obstructed throat (咽喉不通)**, **pathogenic wind invasion (贼风中人)**, or **inability to speak due to throat obstruction (口僻不能语)**, take **one *shēng* (升) of tea olive**, removing the **black seeds (黑子)** and **closed-mouthed ones (合口者)**, and **three *shēng* of fermented broad beans (好豉)**. Mix the two with **clear wine (清酒)** and boil until **four or five bubbles (四五沸)**. Strain and drink **half a *shēng* (半升) daily, three times (日三)**, until a **light sweat (小汗)** resolves the condition.

To treat **scorpion stings (虿螫)**, chew **tea olive** and apply it as a poultice to stop the pain.

**Sichuan Peppercorn (蜀椒):** Pungent in flavor, **greatly hot (大热)**, and toxic. Treats **pathogenic *qi* (邪气)**, warms the midsection and **settles *qi* downward (下气)**, retains **stagnant drinks and old food (留饮宿食)**, and can **convert pain to itching (使痛者痒)** or **itching to pain (痒者痛)**. Prolonged consumption causes **exhaustion of *qi* (乏气)** and **blindness (失明)**. Treats **coughing and reverse airflow (咳逆)**, dispels **cold from the skin (皮肤中寒冷)**, removes **dead tissue (死肌)**, **damp *bi* pain (湿痹痛)**, **cold in the heart region (心下冷气)**, and **cold in the five *zàng* organs and six *fǔ* organs (五脏六腑寒)**. Resolves **cold accumulation in the bones and joints (百骨节中积冷)**, warms **malaria (温疟)**, and **stops spontaneous sweating (大风汗自出)**. Stops **diarrhea (下利)** and dispels **wind *xie* (风邪)**. The **closed-mouthed seeds (合口者)** are harmful, and the **black seeds (黑子)** contain minor toxicity and **moisten dampness (下水)**.

**Zhòngjǐng (仲景)** said: Use it **parboiled (熬)**.

The Yellow Emperor said: Avoid eating **peppercorn (椒)** in the **tenth month (十月)**, as it harms the heart and damages the **blood vessels (血脉)**.

**Dried Ginger (乾姜):** Pungent in flavor, warm in nature, and non-toxic. Treats **fullness in the chest (胸中满)**, **coughing and reverse airflow (咳逆上气)**, warms the midsection, stops **bleeding (漏血)** and **sweating (出汗)**, dispels **wind-damp *bi* (风湿痹)**, **diarrhea from cold (肠澼下利)**, **cold-related abdominal pain (寒冷腹痛)**, **abdominal evil (中恶)**, **dysentery (霍乱)**, **distension (胀满)**, **all wind-related toxicities (风邪诸毒)**, and **stagnant *qi* between the skin layers (皮肤间结气)**. Stops **hemoptysis (止唾血)**. Fresh ginger is even more effective.

**Fresh Ginger (生姜):** Pungent in flavor, slightly warm in nature, and non-toxic. Its pungency enters the five *zàng* organs. Treats **injury from cold (伤寒)** and **headache (头痛)**, dispels **phlegm (痰)** and **settles *qi* downward (下气)**, promotes **sweating (通汗)**, removes **nasal congestion (鼻中塞)**, **coughing and reverse airflow (咳逆上气)**, stops **vomiting (呕吐)**, dispels **noxious odor in the chest and diaphragm (胸膈上臭气)**, and **clarifies the mind (通神明)**.

The Yellow Emperor said: Avoid eating **ginger (姜)** in the **eighth and ninth months (八月、九月)**, as it harms the spirit and shortens lifespan.

**Hújūshì (胡居士)** said: Ginger kills **long worms in the abdomen (腹中长虫)**; however, long-term consumption causes **diminished resolve (少志)** and **diminished intelligence (少智)**, harming the **heart’s temperament (心性)**.

**Viola (堇葵):** Bitter in flavor, **neutral (平)**, and non-toxic. Long-term consumption removes **heart-related restlessness and agitation (心烦急)**, **stirs cold phlegm (动痰冷)**, **body heaviness (身重)**, and **excessive lethargy (多懈惰)**.

**Mustard Greens (芸薹):** Pungent in flavor, cold in nature, and non-toxic. Treats **lumbar and leg *bi* (腰脚痹)**. Those with **chronic lumbar or leg pain (旧患腰脚痛)** should avoid it, as it **worsens the condition (必加剧)**. Also treats **oil-induced edema (油肿)** and **toxic rashes (丹毒)**. Enhances **body odor (益胡臭)** and **detoxifies those under taboo (解禁咒之辈)**. From *Wǔmíng Jīng* (《五明经》).

Its seeds treat **nocturnal seminal emission (梦中泄精)** and **sexual encounters with spirits (与鬼交)**.

**Hújūshì (胡居士)** said: Commonly called **cold herb (寒菜)**, it is **very spicy (甚辣)**. Those with **body odor (胡臭)** who consume it will see their condition worsen. It is widely cultivated and eaten in **Liángxī (陇西)** and **Qiāng (羌)** regions.

**Bamboo Shoots (竹笋):** Sweet in flavor, slightly cold in nature, and non-toxic. Treats **diabetes (消渴)**, **promotes urination (利水道)**, and **enhances vitality (益气力)**. Can be consumed long-term, but those with **cold conditions (患冷人)** may experience **heart pain (心痛)** upon eating.

**Wild Chervil (野苣):** Bitter in flavor, **neutral (平)**, and non-toxic.

「If consumed for a long time, it lightens the body and reduces the need for sleep. **Hújuàn** (胡蒸), the Yellow Emperor said: It should not be eaten together with honey, as it will cause piles (痔). Also, **white chervil (白苣)**: Bitter in flavor, neutral, and non-toxic. It enhances **tendon strength (筋力)**. The Yellow Emperor said: It should not be eaten with yogurt (酪), otherwise it will cause **parasitic infestations (作虫)**.

**Fennel leaf (茴香菜)**: Bitter and pungent in flavor, slightly cold in nature, astringent, and non-toxic. Treats **acute dysentery (霍乱)**, repels heat, and removes **bad breath (除口气臭)**. When cooked with meat and water, even a small amount will eliminate the foul odor. Hence it is called **fennel (茴香)**. Fermented garlic or onion dregs (酱臭末) also have its fragrance. Its seeds: Treat **chronic snakebite wounds (蛇咬疮久不瘥)**, by pounding and applying them. They also treat **nine types of fistulas (九种瘘)**.

**Shiitake mushroom (蕈菜)**: Bitter in flavor, cold in nature, and non-toxic. Treats **childhood fire rashes (小儿火丹)** and all **poisonous swellings (诸毒肿)**, and removes **fever (去暴热)**.

**Blue-green vegetables (蓝菜)**, such as **blue chervil (蓝苣)**: Sweet in flavor, neutral, and non-toxic. Long-term consumption greatly benefits the **kidneys (大益肾)**, replenishes the **marrow and brain (填髓脑)**, promotes **dharma of the five organs (利五脏)**, and harmonizes the **six bowels (调六腑)**. **Hújūshì (胡居士)** said: In **Hédōng (河东)**, **Liángxī (陇西)**, and **Qiāng (羌)** regions, as well as among the **Hú (胡)**, it is widely cultivated and eaten, whereas in **Hàn (汉)** regions, it is rare. Its leaves are long, broad, and thick, and when cooked, they are sweet and delicious. It survives winter without dying, and in spring, it bears **flowers (英)**, whose petals are yellow, growing in clusters at the joints. Its seeds: **Effectively treat excessive sleepiness (甚治人多睡)**.

**Oldenlandia leaf (萹竹叶)**: Bitter in flavor, neutral, astringent, and non-toxic. Treats **persistent skin infections (浸淫)**, **scabies (疥瘙)**, **carbuncles and hemorrhoids (疽痔)**, and kills **three types of worms (杀三虫)**. It also treats **vaginal discharge in women (女人阴蚀)**. **Biānqiú (扁鹊)** said: The juice, when cooked and served cold to children, treats **roundworms (蛔虫)**.

**Purslane (斯菜)**: Bitter and sour in flavor, cold in nature, astringent, and non-toxic. It enhances **tendon strength (筋力)** and removes **latent heat (去伏热)**. Treats **five types of jaundice (五种黄病)**. Freshly pounded and strained juice, served cold, one *shāng* (升) per dose, twice daily.

The Yellow Emperor said: On the **Fifth Day of the Fifth Month (五月五日)**, do not eat any **green vegetables (一切菜)**, as it may provoke **a hundred illnesses (发百病)**.

All **green vegetables (一切菜)**, once cooked and eaten hot, are safe. However, if one eats **all kinds of meat and garlic (一切肉并蒜)** after recovery from illness and then engages in **sexual intercourse (行房)**, the illness will surely recur and death will follow; If one eats **raw green vegetables (生青菜)** after recovery but before full health is restored, the hands and feet will become **blue and swollen (青肿)**; If one eats **raw green vegetables (青菜)** and then engages in **sexual intercourse (行房)** before fully recovering, the illness will worsen and death will surely follow.

In the **Tenth Month (十月)**, do not eat **frost-damaged vegetables (被霜菜)**, as it may cause **dull complexion (面上无光泽)**, **eye pain (目濇痛)**, and **malarial fever (疟发心痛)**. It may also cause **lumbar pain (腰疼)**, or even **heart malaria (致心疟)**, where during an attack, the hands, feet, and all ten fingers’ nails turn blue, leading to **prostration and paralysis (困痿)**.

#1 **Correction**: Originally 『**méi (枚)**』, corrected to 『**jù (菊)**』 based on the **Shadow Printed Song Edition (据影宋刻本改)**.

「#2 **Cease (上止)**—originally 『**止**』, corrected according to the Shadow Printed Song Edition (据影宋刻本改).
#3 **Fever (热)**—in the Shadow Printed Song Edition, it reads 『**满**』 (fullness).
#4 **Harmonize with the Five Phases (通和五气)**—in the Shadow Printed Song Edition, it reads 『**Harmonize with the nasal and ear qi (通鼻耳气)**』.
#5 **Blindness (盲)**—originally 『**面**』 (face), corrected according to the Shadow Printed Song Edition.
#6 **Fruit (果)**—originally 『**栗**』 (chestnut), corrected according to the Shadow Printed Song Edition.
#7 **Tea (茶)**—in the Shadow Printed Song Edition, it reads 『** 荼**』 (a variant of tea).
#8 **Primary (主)**—originally 『**上**』 (above), corrected according to the Shadow Printed Song Edition.
#9 **Contradict (逆)**—originally 『**道**』 (Dao/Way), corrected according to the Shadow Printed Song Edition.
#10 **Three portions (三合)**—in the Shadow Printed Song Edition, it reads 『**Two portions (二合)**』.
#11 **Qi nourishment (气养)**—these two characters were originally reversed, corrected according to the Shadow Printed Song Edition variant.
#12 **Vegetable (菜)**—in the Shadow Printed Song Edition, it reads 『**葇**』 (a variant of vegetable).

**Food Therapy**

**Grains and Millet (谷米) – Fourth Category**

**Coix Seed (薏苡仁):**
Tastes sweet, is warm, and is non-toxic.
**Treats:** Contracture of sinews rendering flexion and extension impossible; chronic wind-dampness paralysis lowering *qi*; prolonged use lightens the body and strengthens vitality.
**Additional Effects:** Eliminates the three lower parasites from its roots.
**Noted by Master Physicians:** Coix seed dispels pathogenic *qi* from sinews and bones, rendering them numb; promotes intestinal and gastric function; resolves edema; and enhances appetite.
**Alternative Names:** □ (unclear), *Ganmi* (感米). Often cultivated and consumed in Shu.

**Sesame (胡麻):**
Tastes sweet, is neutral, and is non-toxic.
**Treats:** Midsection injury with emaciation; nourishes the five *zang* organs; augments *qi* and strength; develops muscles; replenishes marrow and brain; strengthens sinews and bones; heals traumatic wounds; alleviates pain; and addresses injury-induced fever, malaria, and post-vomiting/diarrhea exhaustion.
**Prolonged Use:** Lightens the body, prevents aging, sharpens intellect, enhances sensory acuity, and endures cold and heat, prolonging life.
**Sesame Oil (作油):** Slightly cold; promotes large intestinal function; aids in postpartum placental retention.
**Raw Sesame:** Rubbed on carbuncles and swellings; stimulates hair regrowth; dispels scalp wind.
**Alternative Names:** *Jusheng* (巨胜), *Goushi* (狗虱), *Fangjing* (方茎), *Hongcang* (鸿藏).
**Leaves (青蘘):** Treat summer-heat injury.
**Flowers:** Promote hair regrowth. Harvested in July, dried in shade for optimal use.

**White Sesame Seed (白麻子):**
Tastes sweet, is neutral, and is non-toxic.
**Benefits:** Liver; tonifies the middle and augments *qi*; promotes youthful vigor and longevity.
**Treats:** Windstroke with sweating; expels water; facilitates urination; disperses stagnant blood, wind, toxins, and swelling; restores blood vessels; postpartum residual ailments.
**Additional Effects:** Promotes hair growth; usable in shampoo.
**Prolonged Use:** Conveys divine vitality.

**Honey (饴):**
Tastes sweet, is slightly warm, and is non-toxic.
**Treats:** Cold deficiency; augments *qi* and strength; stops intestinal rumbling, gurgling, and pain; eliminates hemoptysis; mitigates sudden coughing.

**Yellow Soybean Curd (大豆黄卷):**
Tastes sweet, is neutral, and is non-toxic.
**Treats:** Chronic wind-dampness paralysis, sinew contraction, and knee pain; dispels stagnation in the five *zang* organs and stomach; augments *qi*; stops toxicity.

**Remedies for Blemishes and Skin Clarity:**
Removes black moles and facial blotches (*mian yu*); nourishes hair and skin.

**Soybean (大豆, *Sheng* – Raw):**
Tastes sweet, is neutral, and is cold; non-toxic.
**Uses:** When freshly ground and applied with refined vinegar, treats all toxic swellings and stops pain. When its juice is boiled and consumed cold, it kills ghostly toxins, expels water retention and edema, removes stomach heat, alleviates wind paralysis, midsection injury, and urinary disorders (*lin lu*), dispels stagnant blood, dissolves cold accumulations in the five *zang* organs, and neutralizes *wu tou* (aconite) and *san jian* (three toxic substances). Counteracts poison from all medicines.
**Caution:** Prolonged use causes heaviness in the body.

**Roasted Soybean Hulls (大豆屑):**
Tastes sweet, is warm and neutral; non-toxic.
**Treats:** Stomach heat, body swelling, paralysis, indigestion, and abdominal distension.

**Harvest:** September.
**Yellow Emperor’s Warning:** Consuming soybean hulls while eating pork is forbidden.

**Caution:** Fried soybeans must not be given to children aged one to ten. If consumed, followed by pork, it will cause fatal *qi* stagnation.

---

**Red Adzuki Bean (赤小豆):**
Tastes sweet and salty, is neutral and cold; non-toxic.
**Treats:** Edema, promotes pus and blood drainage.
**Alternative Names:** *Chi Dou* (赤豆).
**Caution:** Prolonged use causes dryness.

**Green Adzuki Bean (青小豆):**
Tastes sweet and salty, is warm and neutral, and is astringent (*xian*); non-toxic.
**Treats:** Cold and heat disorders, internal heat, diabetes (*xiao ke*); stops diarrhea and dysentery, facilitates urination, removes vomiting, sudden diarrhea, and lower abdominal distension.
**Alternative Names:** *Ma Lei*, *Hu Dou*.
**Yellow Emperor’s Warning:** Consuming green adzuki beans with fermented carp (*li yu*) causes jaundice, leading to chronic illness (*gan zao*) within five years.

---

**Fermented Soybeans (大豆豉):**
Tastes bitter and sweet, is cold and astringent; non-toxic.
**Treats:** Cold-induced headache, alternating cold and heat, repels pestilential *zhang qi* and toxic pathogens, alleviates restlessness and fullness, benefits chronic fatigue with wheezing, relieves coldness and pain in the legs, and neutralizes toxins from livestock and animal fetuses.

**Mung Bean (篇豆):**
Tastes sweet, is slightly warm; non-toxic.
**Effects:** Harmonizes the midsection and lowers *qi*.

**Mung Bean Leaves:**
Neutral; treats cholera with uncontrollable vomiting and diarrhea.

**Broussonetia Paper Mulberry (乔麦):**
Tastes sour, is slightly cold; non-toxic.
**Effects:** Difficult to digest; induces intense internal heat and wind.
**Leaves (raw):** Induce pruritic wind (*ci feng*), causing itching.

**Yellow Emperor’s Warning:** Consuming its flour mixed with pork or mutton as a hot dish, if eaten more than eight or nine times, generates internal heat wind, causing eyebrows and mustaches to fall out—only to regrow sparsely. This affliction is common in regions north of *Jing Qin*.

---

**Barley (大麦):**
Tastes salty, is slightly cold and slippery; non-toxic.
**Uses:** Nourishes the heart, treats diabetes (*xiao ke*), and removes heat.
**Prolonged Consumption:** Increases strength and endurance.
**Sprouted Barley (麦芽):** Warm; aids digestion and harmonizes the midsection.
**Charred Barley (as *mi*):** Stops diarrhea and dysentery. Mix with diluted vinegar and consume three times daily, once at night.

**Wheat (小麦):**
Tastes sweet, is slightly cold; non-toxic.
**Effects:** Nourishes liver *qi*, removes pathogenic heat, stops thirst and dry throat, facilitates urination, and stops uterine bleeding and hemoptysis.
**For Women:** Ensures male offspring if consumed during pregnancy.
**As Flour (harvested in June):** Warm; non-toxic. Treats infantile epilepsy (*xian*), indigestion, expels five types of rectal worms, balances stomach *qi*, aids digestion, and stops diarrhea.
**Caution:** Overconsumption causes prolonged diarrhea and attracts pathogenic *qi*, making treatment difficult.

**Green Millet (青粱米):**
Tastes sweet, is slightly cold; non-toxic.
**Treats:** Stomach paralysis, internal heat, diabetes (*xiao ke*), stops diarrhea and dysentery, facilitates urination, augments *qi* and strength, benefits the midsection, lightens the body, and prolongs life.

**Yellow Millet (黄粱米):**
Tastes sweet, is neutral; non-toxic.
**Effects:** Augments *qi* and harmonizes the midsection; stops diarrhea and dysentery.
**Common Name:** *Zhu Gen Mi* (bamboo root rice).
**Additional Use:** Protects against exposure to wind while lying in damp, cold environments.

**White Millet (白粱米):**
Tastes sweet, is slightly cold; non-toxic.
**Effects:** Removes heat and augments *qi*.

**Millet (粟米):**
Tastes salty, is slightly cold; non-toxic.
**Effects:** Nourishes kidney *qi*, removes bone paralysis and internal heat, and augments *qi*.

**Aged Millet (陈粟米):**
Tastes bitter, is cold; non-toxic.
**Treats:** Stomach heat, diabetes (*xiao ke*), and facilitates urination.

**Job’s Tears (丹黍米):**
Tastes bitter, is slightly warm; non-toxic.
**Treats:** Cough with upward *qi* reversal, cholera, stops diarrhea and dysentery, removes heat, and alleviates thirst.

**White Job’s Tears (白黍米):**
Tastes sweet and pungent, is warm; non-toxic.
**Uses:** Nourishes the lungs, benefits the midsection, and augments *qi*.
**Caution:** Prolonged use generates excess heat and restlessness.

**Yellow Emperor’s Warning:** Consuming the five types of Job’s tears with *kui* (malva) causes chronic illness. Storing cured meats in these grains is fatal if consumed without knowledge.

**Aged Stored Rice (陈廪米):**
Tastes salty and sour, is slightly cold; non-toxic.
**Effects:** Removes restlessness and heat, lowers *qi*, harmonizes the stomach, and stops diarrhea and dysentery.
**Yellow Emperor’s Warning:** Storing cured meats in rice for three months harms those who consume it unknowingly.

**Foxtail Millet (蘖米):**
Tastes bitter, is slightly warm; non-toxic.
**Treats:** Cold in the midsection, lowers *qi*, and removes heat.

**Barbary Wheat (秫米):**
Tastes sweet, is slightly cold; non-toxic.
**Treats:** Cold and heat disorders, facilitates the large intestine, and treats lacquer poisoning (*qi chuang*).

---
**Alcohol (酒):**
Tastes bitter, sweet, and pungent; intensely hot; toxic in excess.
**Effects:** Enhances medicinal efficacy, dispels all malevolent *qi* and pathogenic influences.

**Yellow Emperor’s Warning:**
- Drinking alcohol after sudden diarrhea causes latent heat above the diaphragm.
- Consuming raw vegetables with alcohol induces abdominal distension and intestinal blockage.

**Bian Que’s Warnings:**
- Chronic alcohol consumption rots the intestines, corrodes the stomach, erodes the marrow, and weakens the sinews, damaging the spirit and shortening life.
- Drunkenness followed by exposure to wind, if fanned by hand, leads to malignant wind disorders.
- Drunkenness followed by cold water bathing causes painful paralysis (*teng bi*).
- Heavy intoxication with sweating requires dusting the body with powder to dry it naturally; otherwise, it induces wind paralysis.
- Avoid alcohol before meals to prevent lifelong nausea.
- Eating to fullness followed by excessive water or alcohol consumption causes abdominal distension and diarrhea.

**Jìmǐ (Glutinous Millet):**
Taste sweet, balanced, non-toxic.
Benefits *qi*, calms the center, supplements deficiency, and harmonizes the spleen.

**Gēngmǐ (Non-glutinous Rice):**
Taste pungent, bitter, balanced, non-toxic.
Relieves mental agitation, stops chronic diarrhea, regulates stomach *qi*, strengthens muscles, and warms the center.
*One account says:* Raw, it is cold; parched, it is hot.

**Nuòmǐ (Glutinous Rice):**
Taste bitter, warm, non-toxic.
Warms the center, increases appetite, but generates excess heat, causing constipation.

**Jiǔ (Fermented Rice Wine):**
Taste sour, warm, cloying, non-toxic.
Dissolves abscesses and swellings, disperses water *qi*, kills pathogenic toxins, and promotes blood circulation.
**Bian Que said:** Excessive consumption damages bones.
It harmonizes all medicines and dissipates toxic heat.

**Yán (Salt):**
Taste salty, warm, non-toxic.
Kills malevolent spirits, pathogenic invasions, toxic *qi*, and lower abdominal ulcers; treats alternating cold and heat in febrile diseases. It induces vomiting of phlegm from the chest, stops sudden abdominal pain, and strengthens muscles and bones.
*Do not consume excessively*—it damages the lungs, causing chronic cough, darkens the skin, and weakens sinews.
**Bian Que said:** Salt can eliminate all severe wind disorders and pain; roast and apply it as a poultice.
**Huangdi said:** After eating sweet congee, consuming salt immediately causes vomiting or dysentery.

---
**Section: Wǔshòu (Five Beasts) – Human Breast Milk:**
Taste sweet, balanced, non-toxic.
Supplements the five *zàng* organs, promoting plumpness, fair complexion, and radiance.

**Horse Milk:**
Taste pungent, warm, non-toxic.
Quenches thirst.

**Cow Milk:**
Taste sweet, slightly cold, non-toxic.
Supplements deficiency and fatigue, quenches thirst.
When combined with fresh ginger and scallions, it stops infantile vomiting of milk.
Strengthens after labor.

**Sheep Milk:**
Taste sweet, slightly warm, non-toxic.
Supplements cold, deficiency, and blood loss, but may cause internal heat.

**Donkey Milk:**
Taste sour, cold (*one account says: intensely cold*), non-toxic.
Treats severe heat and jaundice, quenches thirst.

**Sow Milk:**
Balanced, non-toxic.
Treats infantile convulsions and epilepsy; administered as a drink, it is miraculously effective.

---
**Cheese from Horse, Cow, and Sheep:**
Taste sweet, sour, slightly cold, non-toxic.
Supplements the lungs and facilitates the large intestine.
**Huangdi said:** After eating sweet cheese, consuming vinegar immediately causes blood stasis (*yuèjué*) and hematuria.
**Hua Tuo said:** If a cricket enters the ear, rinsing with this cheese will expel it.

**Sand-Cow and White Sheep Ghee:**
Taste sweet, slightly cold, non-toxic.
Eliminates stagnant *qi* in the chest, facilitates the large and small intestines, and treats oral ulcers.

**Female Ox Ghee:**
Taste sweet, balanced, non-toxic.
Dispels all wind-dampness paralysis, removes heat, promotes bowel movements, and digests stagnant food.

**Ghee (Clarified Butter):**
Taste sweet, balanced, non-toxic.
Supplements deficiency, dispels all wind paralysis; refined through repeated boiling is optimal.
It particularly treats moon-shaped ulcers.
It nourishes the marrow, supplements the center, fills the bones, and prolonged use extends life.

**Xióngròu (Bear Meat):**
Taste sweet, slightly cold and slightly warm, non-toxic.
Treats wind paralysis with numbness and sinew contractions, the five types of flaccidity.
If consumed by those with abdominal masses, alternating cold and heat, or emaciation, the illness will never be cured.
Its fat—taste sweet, slightly cold—treats disorders as the meat does.
It also eliminates headaches, white patches, and facial paralysis; excessive consumption causes vomiting.
Prolonged use strengthens willpower, suppresses hunger, lightens the body, and prolongs life.
**Huangdi said:** All meats, if undercooked or improperly preserved, cause blood stasis when consumed.

Bear and pig fat must not be used for lamps—its smoke, when inhaled, causes blindness and impaired distant vision.

**Yángjiǎo (Ram’s Horn):**
Taste sour, bitter, warm, slightly cold, non-toxic.
Treats night blindness, sharpens vision, kills scabies mites, stops cold-induced diarrhea and palpitations from fear.
It eliminates stagnant *qi* in the joints, wind injuries, pathogenic toxins, and hemoptysis; it also relieves postpartum pain in women.
Burned, it repels ghosts and demons, wards off tigers and wolves.
Prolonged use calms the mind, benefits *qi*, lightens the body.
*Avoid dampness, as it may become toxic.*

**Bone Marrow (髓):**
Taste sweet, warm, non-toxic.
Treats injuries to men and women, deficiency of yin and yang *qi*, repels wind-heat, stops toxins, benefits blood vessels, strengthens channel *qi*. Taken with wine, it may also be used long-term without harming the body.

**Ram’s Gall (青羊胆汁):**
Cold, non-toxic.
Treats all sores, generates the body’s vessels, cures night blindness, sharpens vision.

**Lungs (肺):**
Neutral. Supplements the lungs, treats coughs, stops thirst, increases urination, treats injuries to the *zhōng* (midsection), stops emptiness, supplements deficiencies, expels wind pathogens.

**Liver (肝):**
Supplements the liver, sharpens vision.

**Heart (心):**
Treats anxiety and anger, reverses rebellious *qi* in the diaphragm.

**Kidneys (肾):**
Supplements deficient kidney *qi*, benefits essence and marrow.

**Skull Bone (头骨):**
Treats infantile convulsions and epilepsy; boil and use for bathing.

**Hoof Meat (蹄肉):**
Neutral. Treats men’s five strains and seven injuries.

**Meat (肉):**
Taste bitter, sweet, greatly hot, non-toxic.
Treats warmth in the *zhōng* (midsection), stops pain, cures residual lactation disorders, and severe wind in the head and brain—inducing spontaneous sweating. For those with *xūláo* (consumptive disorders) and coldness, it supplements the *zhōng*, benefits *qi* and strength, calms the mind, stops fright, aids childbirth—but is harmful to those with seasonal ailments.

**Head Meat (头肉):**
Neutral.
Treats wind-induced dizziness, emaciation, infantile convulsions, and men’s five strains and seven injuries.

**Its Bone (其骨):**
Hot.
Treats *xūláo* (consumptive disorders), cold in the *zhōng*, and emaciation—*but those with latent heat must not consume it.*

**Sheep Fat (生脂):**
Stops dysentery with prolapse, dispels wind-toxins, and eases postpartum abdominal colic in women.

**Sheep Abdomen (肚):**
Treats gastric inversion; cures *xūyíng* (consumptive emaciation) with frequent urination and stops spontaneous sweating.

Emperor Huangdi said:
*"Sheep meat eaten with vinegar harms the heart, and it should not be eaten raw with fish or curdled milk, as it harms people."*

All sheep hooves with white pearl-like nodules within—called *yang xuánjīn* (sheep suspensory tendons)—when eaten, induce epilepsy. Black-headed white sheep: eating their brains causes intestinal abscesses.

Eating sheep abdomen with rice and drinks regularly over time causes gastric inversion and dysphagia. Eating it with sweet congee induces excessive salivation and vomiting of clear water.

**Sheep Brain, Pig Brain:**
Men who consume them damage their *jīngqì* (essence-qi) and become infertile. If eaten, they must be thoroughly mashed into powder and taken with vinegar—but it is still better not to eat them at all.

Green sheep liver eaten with small red beans dims the eyes. Eating any raw sheep liver with pepper damages the five *zàng* (solid organs), harms the heart, and is especially detrimental to children.

Avoid cooking sheep meat in water from willow or white poplar trees or in copper vessels—eating it damages *yang* in men and *yin* in women.

After violent diarrhea, eating sheep marrow or bone broth causes persistent fever and recurrent dysentery.

All six domestic animals’ organs that move on their own when placed on grass, remain unchanged in color when exposed to salt or vinegar, fall to the ground without staining, or are rejected by dogs—these are poisonous and fatal.

Avoid eating sheep meat in the sixth lunar month, as it harms the spirit-qi.

**Sand Ox Marrow (沙牛髓):**
Taste sweet, warm, non-toxic.
Calms the five *zàng*, balances stomach-qi, harmonizes the twelve meridians, regulates the three *jiāo* (burners), warms bones and marrow, supplements the *zhōng* (midsection), mends severed injuries, benefits *qi* and strength, stops diarrhea, and alleviates *xiāokě* (consumptive thirst)—all taken with warm, clear wine.

**Liver:** Brightens the eyes.
