**Gallbladder:** Can be made into pills for myriad remedies. Taste bitter, intensely cold, non-toxic. Removes heat from the heart and abdomen, stops dysentery, alleviates dry mouth, and benefits eye essence.

**Heart:** Governs *xūwàng* (consumptive forgetfulness).
**Kidneys:** Treat damp *bì* (bi-syndrome), supplement kidney-qi, and benefit essence.
**Teeth:** Treat infantile bovine epilepsy (*niúxián*).
**Meat:** Taste sweet, neutral, non-toxic. Treats *xiāokě* (consumptive thirst), stops drooling, calms the *zhōng*, benefits *qi* and strength, and nourishes spleen-stomach-qi. Should not be eaten habitually, as it exacerbates latent illnesses.

Dead animals must not be eaten.

**Throat:** Governs infantile *bèiyè* (a form of infantile convulsions).

**Yellow oxen, sand-colored oxen, and black bull urine:** Taste bitter and pungent, slightly warm, neutral, non-toxic. Treat cases of generalized edema where both abdomen and limbs are distended, and promote urination.

The Yellow Emperor said: *"If a black ox dies of its own accord with its head pointing north, eating its meat will harm a person."* Any ox that dies suddenly during a feverish state is entirely unfit for consumption—eating it will cause intestinal abscesses (*chángyōng*). Consuming the tendons from the hoofs of oxen afflicted with hoof-and-mouth disease will cause flesh-like growths (*ròucì*) in humans.

The meat of *dúgān* (one-horned) oxen is lethal—these are oxen that have eaten snakes. Oxen afflicted with scabies: eating their meat causes itching of the body. Consuming beef and pork together will inevitably produce *cùnbái chóng* (roundworms). Eating *zhí’ěr* millet, white wine, and raw beef together also produces *cùnbái chóng*—this is strictly forbidden. Those suffering from diarrhea (*xiàlì*) who eat beef from dead oxen will see their condition worsen.

The milk and curdled milk of all oxen and horses, when fed to live fish, will cause fish to develop *yǔ* (a form of fish disease).

The spleen of all livestock must never be eaten by humans in their lifetime.

Avoid eating beef in the twelfth lunar month—it harms one’s *shénqì* (spirit-vitality).

**Horse heart:** Governs *xǐwàng* (euphoric forgetfulness).

**Lungs:** Govern *hánrè jīngwěi* (cold-heat scrotal atrophy).

**Meat:** Taste pungent and bitter, neutral, cold, non-toxic. Treats *shāngzhōng* (abdominal injury), removes heat, descends *qi*, strengthens tendons, fortifies the loins and spine, builds vitality and resolve, sharpens the mind, lightens the body, and suppresses hunger. The Yellow Emperor said: *"If a white horse dies of its own accord, eating its meat will harm a person."* The brain of a white horse with a dark head (*xuántóu*) will cause epilepsy (*diān*) in those who consume it. If a white horse has a black saddle-mark extending through the flesh beneath, eating it will damage the five *zàng* (visceral) organs. Those with diarrhea who eat horse meat will see their condition worsen. The meat of a white horse with green hooves is unfit for consumption.

The sweat and hair of all horses must never be ingested—they harm humans. For those who eat horse meat and suffer restlessness and vexation, drinking fine wine will alleviate the symptoms, but white wine will worsen them.

Avoid eating horse meat in the fifth lunar month—it harms one’s *shénqì* (spirit-vitality).

**Wild horse penis:** Taste sour and salty, warm, non-toxic. Treats male *yīnwěi* (erectile dysfunction) and *suō* (retraction), and deficiency of semen.

**Meat:** Pungent, neutral, non-toxic. Treats *rénmǎxián* (human-horse epilepsy), inability of tendons and vessels to contract, *zhōubì* (circulating numbness), and *jībùrén* (muscular insensitivity). Meat from diseased animals is forbidden.

**Donkey meat:** Taste sour, neutral, non-toxic. Treats *fēngkuáng* (wind-induced madness), melancholy, and discontent—it calms the *xīnqì* (heart-vitality). Meat from diseased animals is forbidden.

The head, when burned to remove the hair and then boiled to extract its juice for fermenting wine, is highly effective in treating severe *dàfēng* (paralyzing wind) that causes trembling and inability to stand upright. The hide glue is also effective for *dàfēng*.

**Dog penis:** Taste sour, neutral, non-toxic. Treats *shāngzhōng* (abdominal injury), male *yīnwěi* (erectile dysfunction) with inability to rise.

**Brain:** Treats *tóufēngbì* (wind-induced head numbness), lower *chuāng* (ulcers) with fleshy growths within.

**Meat:** Taste sour and salty, warm, non-toxic. Nourishes the *shèn* (kidneys), calms the Five *Zàng* (solid organs), restores severe exhaustion from injury or overwork, and benefits those with prolonged illness and extreme depletion. Consumption lightens the body and enhances *qì* and strength.
The Yellow Emperor said: Eating white dogs with sea *yáo* (cusk-eel) will inevitably cause grave illness. If a white dog dies naturally without its tongue protruding, eating it harms the person. Dogs in spring often become mad—if their noses turn red, rise, and become dry, this indicates impending madness. Their meat must not be consumed. Avoid eating dog meat in the ninth lunar month—it harms one’s *shénqì* (spirit-vitality).

**Piglet testicles (*túnluǎn*):** Taste sweet, warm, non-toxic. Alleviates penile pain, *jīngxián* (epilepsy), *guǐqì* (ghostly affliction), *wùdú* (poisonous hex), and dispels cold-heat disorders, *bèntún* (abdominal distension), *wǔliàng* (five types of urinary dysfunction), and *xiégas* (malignant contractions). Also called *túndiān* (piglet’s frenzy). Dry in the shade—do not let it spoil.

**Piglet meat:** Taste pungent, neutral, with slight toxicity. Prolonged consumption causes widespread *jīnròu suìtòng* (tendon-muscle fragmentation pain) and *búqì* (qi deficiency).

**Large pig’s hind legs with suspended hooves and claws:** Non-toxic. Treats *wǔzhì* (five types of hemorrhoids), internal *fúrè* (latent heat), and *chángyōng nèishí* (intestinal abscess erosion). Soak in alcohol for half a day, then char and use.

**Four hooves:** Slightly cold, non-toxic. Treats injuries, bruises, and all festering wounds.

**Sow’s hooves:** Cold, non-toxic. Boiled juice, taken orally, induces lactation and strongly counteracts stone-drug poisoning.

**Large pig’s head meat:** Neutral, non-toxic. Restores *xū* (depletion), replenishes *qì* and strength, dispels *jīngxián* (epilepsy), *guǐdú* (ghostly poison), cold-heat disorders, and *wǔliàng* (five urinary dysfunctions).

**Brain:** Treats *fēngxuàn* (wind-induced dizziness).

**Heart:** Neutral, non-toxic. Treats *jīngxié* (epileptic seizures), *yōuyì* (melancholic rage), *xūjì* (hollow palpitations), *qìnì* (inverted *qi*), postpartum *zhòngfēng* (wind stroke) in women, and *jùxuèqì jīngkǒng* (congealed blood and *qi* causing terror).

**Kidneys:** Neutral, non-toxic. Dispels cold *lì* (diarrhea), regulates *shènqì* (kidney-*qi*), and unblocks the *pángguāng* (bladder).

**Liver:** Taste bitter, neutral, non-toxic. Benefits vision.

**Lungs:** Slightly cold, non-toxic. Treats *dòngchuāng* (frostbite ulcers) with pain and itching.

**Belly (stomach):** Slightly cold, non-toxic. Tonifies the *zhōng* (middle), benefits *qì*, stops thirst, and halts *bàolì* (violent diarrhea) in the weak.

**Intestines:** Slightly cold, non-toxic. Treats *xiāokě* (diabetes), frequent *xiǎobiàn* (urination), and restores *xiàjiāo xūjié* (lower burner depletion).

**Intermuscular fat:** Neutral, non-toxic. Used to decoct various ointments, disperses cold congealing, breaks up stagnant blood, and counteracts *bānmāo* (leopard-spotted poison) and *yuánqīngdú* (indigo poison).

**Pig’s *dòngcháng* (rectal prolapse):** Neutral, non-toxic. Treats severe bleeding in rectal prolapse.

**Wild boar meat:** Taste bitter and sour, cold, non-toxic. Treats prolonged *kuángbìng* (madness) that does not heal.

**Pig meat in general:** Taste bitter, slightly cold, nourishes the *shèn* (kidneys), with slight toxicity. Restores *shènqì* depletion, but prolonged consumption causes *shǎozǐjīng* (sperm deficiency), exacerbates latent illnesses, weakens tendons and bones, obstructs blood vessels, and weakens the muscles of the depleted. Those with *jīncāng* (golden sores/wounds) should avoid it—it worsens the condition.

**Pig blood:** Neutral, *zāi* (dry), non-toxic. Treats sudden *xiàxuè* (bleeding) that does not stop—mix with clear *měijiǔ* (fine wine) and stir-fry before consumption. Also treats *zhòngfēng juéshāng* (wind stroke with severe injury), *tóufēngxuàn* (wind-induced dizziness), *zhūlìlù* (various urinary dysfunctions), *bèntún* (abdominal distension), and *bàoqì* (sudden *qi* disorders).
The Yellow Emperor said: Consuming pig liver and lungs with *yúyáng* (crucian carp) or its intestines and roe will cause *yōngjū* (abscesses and boils). Pig liver with *lǐyú* (carp) intestines or roe harms one’s *shén* (spirit).

**Piglet brain:** Damages a man’s *yángdào* (yang channel)—when engaging in intercourse, he cannot perform.

Avoid eating pig lungs and *fěi* (malt sugar) in the eighth lunar month—consuming them together will cause boils by winter. Avoid pig meat in the tenth lunar month—it harms one’s *shénqì* (spirit-vitality).

**Deer head meat:** Neutral. Treats *xiāokě* (diabetes) and excessive *mèng* (dreaming) with hallucinations. Generates blood and treats *yōngzhǒng* (abscesses and swellings).

**Tendon:** Treats *láosǔn* (exhaustion from overwork).

**Hoof meat:** Neutral. Treats pain in the leg and knee bones, rendering one unable to step on the ground.

**Bone:** Treats internal *xū* (depletion), mends *juéshāng* (severe injuries), and strengthens bones. Can be used to make wine.

**Marrow:** Taste sweet, warm. Treats *shāngzhōng* (abdominal injury) in both men and women, *màijué* (severed pulse), *jīnjí tòng* (tendon spasms), and *kěnì* (inverted coughing). Consume with alcohol.

**Kidneys:** Neutral. Restores *shènqì* (kidney-*qi*).

**Meat:** Taste bitter, warm, non-toxic. Tonifies the *zhōng* (middle), strengthens the Five *Zàng* (solid organs), and enhances *qì* and strength. Raw meat treats *zhòngfēng* (wind stroke) with *kǒu pì bùzhèng* (crooked mouth)—grind finely and apply thinly to the affected cheek.
Hua Tuo said: Mix with fresh chili and pound into a paste. Have one person focus intently on the affected side—if it straightens, remove the paste immediately. Otherwise, it will pull the mouth back to the crooked side.

**Antlers:** Pound into powder (one *shǎng* measure), mix with five *shǎng* of white honey, and simmer gently until slightly discolored. Dry in the sun, then re-pound and sift. Take one square-inch spoonful, three times daily. This lightens the body, enhances *qì* and strength, fortifies bone marrow, and restores severe injuries.
The Yellow Emperor said: If a deer’s bile is white, eating its meat harms the person. White deer meat should not be mixed with *púbái* (silver grass) to make soup—it causes severe ulcers.

Avoid eating deer meat in the fifth lunar month—it harms one’s *shénqì* (spirit-vitality).
Master Hu Ju said: Deer are by nature fierce and easily startled, often grazing on nine specific herbs and rejecting others. They always dwell on mountains and hills, giving birth in lowlands. Those who sacrifice to the spirits use their meat because its fierce and pure nature makes it suitable.

Those taking medicinal concoctions must avoid deer meat—it weakens the efficacy of drugs. The reason is that deer habitually consume detoxifying grasses, thus able to neutralize poisons and disperse medicinal properties. The nine grasses are:
*Gēlèhuā* (knotweed flowers), *lùcōng* (leek), *lùyào* (deer medicine), *báihāo* (white mugwort), *shuǐqín* (water celery), *gāncǎo* (licorice), *qítóuhāo* (thistle), *shāncāng’ěr* (burnet saxifrage), and *jìní* (watercress).

**Roe deer bone:** Slightly warm, non-toxic. Treats *xūsǔn* (depletion) and *xièjīng* (spermatorrhea).

**Meat:** Taste sweet, warm, non-toxic.

「Nourishing the five *zàng* organs [1]. **Marrow**: Strengthens *qi* and vitality, imparts a radiant complexion.

**Roe deer** lacks gallbladder, hence its timidity and frequent startlement. The *Yellow Emperor* [2] said: *"Do not consume roe deer meat in the fifth month, as it harms the human spirit and *qi*."*

**Muntjac fat**: Taste pungent, warm, non-toxic. It treats abscesses, malignant sores, dead flesh, cold-heat disorders, and *wind-cold-damp* *bì* [3], stiffening of the limbs preventing movement, *wind-head* swelling, and opens the *cou-lì* [4], softening the skin. It must not be taken near a man’s *yīn* [5], lest it cause impotence. Also known as *gōngzhī* [6]. Harvested in the tenth month. The *Yellow Emperor* said: *"Consuming raw muntjac meat with crab juice causes heartache; consuming raw muntjac meat with pheasant meat induces chronic illness."*

**Tiger meat**: Taste sour, non-toxic. It treats nausea and vomiting, strengthens *qi* and vitality, and stops excessive salivation. It must not be eaten hot, as it spoils the teeth. **Tiger head bone**: Treats *wind* evils. **Eyes**: Treat *jìngxián* [7].

**Leopard meat**: Taste sour, warm, non-toxic. It benefits the kidneys, calms the five *zàng* organs, and treats severe injuries. It lightens the body and strengthens *qi*; long-term consumption enhances one’s faculties. **Badger meat**: Warm, non-toxic. It supplements the center, lightens the body, and strengthens *qi*; it also treats all kinds of *zhù* [8]. The *Yellow Emperor* said: *"Do not consume tiger, leopard, or badger meat in the first month, as it harms the human spirit and shortens lifespan."*

**Rabbit liver**: Treats darkened vision. **Meat**: Taste pungent, balanced, dry, non-toxic. It supplements the center and strengthens *qi*, and stops thirst. **Rabbit lacks spleen**, hence its ability to flee. This is because it belongs to the second month (*Jiànmǎo* [9], Wood phase), and Wood overcomes Earth, thus it lacks spleen. **Horses also lack spleen**, hence their ability to run.

The *Yellow Emperor* said: *"Consuming rabbit meat with otter liver will, within three days, cause the body to become a *dùnshī* [10]; consuming it with white chicken liver and heart will make the face lose color, and within a year, it will cause *lièhuáng* [11]; consuming it with ginger causes *huòluàn* [12]; consuming it with white chicken meat disrupts blood and *qi* circulation. Do not consume rabbit meat in the second month, as it harms the human spirit and *qi*."*

**Live mouse**: Slightly warm, non-toxic. It treats fractures and dislocations, mending sinews and bones. When pounded thin, its application should be renewed daily for three days.

**Otter liver**: Taste sweet, with slight toxicity. It treats *guǐlài* [13] and *guǐdú* [14], repels fish bones lodged in the throat, and stops chronic coughs. All must be burned into ash and taken with wine.

**Otter meat**: Taste sweet, warm, non-toxic. It treats seasonal epidemic *yìqì* [15] and diseases common to cattle and horses. All must be boiled to extract the juice, which is then served cold. It is also used to irrigate the six domestic animals.

**Vixen’s *yīnjīng* [16]**: Taste sweet, balanced, with slight toxicity. It treats women’s infertility, itching in the *yīn* region, *yīn*-related disorders in children, and scrotal swelling. **Meat and five *zàng* organs, along with intestines**: Taste bitter, slightly cold, toxic. It treats *guǐdú* and cold-heat disorders, chronic coldness in the five *zàng* organs, *jìngxián* in children, and adult madness with hallucinations. The *Yellow Emperor* said: *"Consuming musk deer meat with quail meat causes *zhèngjiá* [17]."*

Wild boar with green hooves and animals with red feet must not be eaten; wild animals found dead with their heads pointing north and buried in the ground must not be eaten; animals with bifurcated tails must not be eaten. Domestic animals found dead and consumed with their blood and juice will cause *jūchuāng* [18]. Do not consume anything preserved through summer in the eleventh month, as it causes *shuǐbìng* [19], vertigo, and male impotence.

On *jiǎzǐ* [20] days, do not consume any kind of animal meat—this brings great fortune. If a crow flies and perches on a person unwillingly, it means there is something in the person’s mouth. If nothing is found, pluck a hair and place it in the crow’s mouth—this brings great fortune. All birds and animals found dead without visible wounds must not be eaten.

On the third day of the third month, do not consume the five *zàng* organs of birds and animals, nor any fruits or vegetables, nor the five *xīn* [21] spices—this brings great fortune.

**Cock’s meat (male)**: Taste sweet, slightly warm, non-toxic. It treats women’s *bēngzhōng* [22] and *lòuxià* [23] (uterine bleeding), both red and white *wò* [24] (leukorrhea). It supplements depletion, warms the center, and can heal chronic injuries, as well as stubborn sores that refuse to close.

**Translating the Daoist Alchemical and Medical Text:**

---

**On the Virtues and Precautions of Poultry:**

**通神，杀恶毒.**
*[Possesses spiritual efficacy; dispels malevolent poisons.]*

**Yellow Female Chicken Meat (黄雌鸡肉):**
Taste: sour, salty. Nature: balanced (*平*), non-toxic.
**Functions:**
- Treats *shāngzhōng* [25] (midriff injury), *xiāokě* (diabetes), frequent urination without control, and *chángliè* [26] (diarrhea with undigested food).
- Nourishes and restores the five *zàng* organs after severe depletion, replenishes the five *láo* [27] (exhaustions), and strengthens *qi* and vitality.

**Chicken Egg Yolk (鸡子黄):**
Nature: slightly cool.
**Functions:**
- Alleviates heat, fire burns, ulcerated sores, and *jiǎ* [28] (skin lesions).
- May be fashioned into a *hǔpò* [29] (tiger’s spirit talisman).

**Egg White Juice (卵白汁):**
Nature: slightly cool.
**Functions:**
- Treats eye heat, redness, and pain; dispels latent heat beneath the heart; stops restlessness, fullness, coughing, and *nì* [30] (inverted breathing).
- Cures infantile diarrhea and difficult childbirth, aiding in the expulsion of the placenta—ingest raw.

**White Male Chicken Meat (白雄鸡肉):**
Taste: sour. Nature: slightly warm, non-toxic.
**Functions:**
- Subdues rebellious *qi*, dispels manic *xié* [31] (evil spirits), calms the five *zàng* organs, treats *shāngzhōng*, and alleviates *xiāokě*.

**Black Male Chicken Meat (乌雄鸡肉):**
Taste: sweet. Nature: warm, non-toxic.
**Functions:**
- Fortifies the center and stops heart pain.

**Black Female Chicken Meat (黑雌鸡肉):**
Taste: sweet. Nature: balanced, non-toxic.
**Functions:**
- Dispels wind, cold, and damp *bì* [32] (numbness), treats the five *huǎn* [33] (relaxed conditions) and six *jí* [34] (constricted conditions), and secures the fetus.

**Yellow Emperor’s Warning (黄帝云):**
Consuming chicken meat mixed with fish juice will cause *xīnhuò* [35] (cardiac nodules).

**Omen of Madness:**
Chickens with all five colors—eating their meat induces *kuáng* [36] (madness).

**Harmful Varieties:**
- Chickens with six toes and four joints (*sìjù* [37]).
- *Xuánjī* [38] (dark-feathered) with white heads.
- Domestic or wild chickens bearing *bāzì* [39] (eight-character) markings on their offspring.
- Chickens or wild crows found dead without extended claws—eating these harms the consumer.

**Taboos:**
- Egg whites consumed with garlic cause *duǎnqì* [40] (shortness of breath).
- Eggs steamed with softshell turtle meat harm the consumer.
- Chicken and otter meat eaten together cause *dùnshī* [41] (phantom corpse syndrome), untreatable by medicine.
- Eating raw eggs with green onions induces *duǎnqì*.
- Chicken and dog liver/kidney consumed together harm the consumer.
- Raw green onions with chicken or dog meat cause lifelong rectal bleeding.
- Black chicken meat with crucian carp meat generates *yōngjié* [42] (abscesses).
- Chicken, rabbit, and dog meat eaten together cause diarrhea.
- Wild pheasant meat with domestic eggs induces *dùnshī*, binding *shīguǐ* [43] (corpse ghosts) to the body, causing pain in limbs and joints.

**Restrictions:**
- Children under five who still nurse must not eat chicken.
- Eating eggs in the second month causes persistent nausea.
- On *bǐngwǔ* [44] days, consuming chicken or pheasant meat causes men to die by burning or blindness, and women to die from hemorrhage or hallucinations.
- Eating violently killed chicken in the fourth month causes internal abscesses beneath the chest/armpits, with *shǎoyáng* [45] (minor yang) symptoms in men and infertility in women, along with chronic exhaustion.
- Eating chicken in the eighth month harms one’s *shénqì* [46] (spirit-vitality).

**Pheasant Meat (雉肉):**
Taste: sour. Nature: slightly cool, non-toxic.
**Functions:**
- Fortifies the center and replenishes *qi*; stops diarrhea.
- Prolonged consumption causes emaciation.

**Beak (觜):**
- Treats *yǐnglòu* [47] (ant abscesses).

**Emperor Huang’s Saying:**
- On *jiànyǒu* [48] days of the eighth month, eating pheasant meat causes shortness of breath.
- In the eighth month, do not eat pheasant meat, as it harms one’s *shénqì* [46] (spirit-vitality).

**Goose Fat (白鹅脂):**
- Treats sudden deafness; render it into a poultice and apply it to the ear.

**Feathers (毛):**
- Treat *shègōng shuǐdú* [49] (poison from arrows or spears).

**Goose Meat (鹜肉):**
- Taste: spicy. Nature: neutral. Benefits the five *zàngfǔ* [50] (viscera and bowels).
- **Goose Grease (鹜肪):**
  - Taste: sweet. Nature: neutral. Non-toxic.
  - Treats wind-induced *lǎi* [51] (cold, heat, or stagnation), joint stiffness, and *piāngkū* [52] (hemiplegia); promotes the smooth flow of *xuèqì* [53] (blood and vitality).
- **Huang’s Saying:**
  - In the sixth month, do not eat goose meat, as it harms one’s *shénqì* [46] (spirit-vitality).

**Mandarin Duck Meat (鴛鴦肉):**
- Taste: bitter. Nature: slightly warm. Non-toxic.
- Treats abscesses and ulcers; steep in clear wine, heat until warm, and apply as a poultice to the affected area. Also, consume the heated meat.
- Additionally, it treats those plagued by *mèngsī mù* [54] (obsessive dreams or longing).

**Wild Goose Grease (雁肪):**
- Taste: sweet. Nature: neutral. Non-toxic.
- Treats wind-induced *lǎi* [51] (cold, heat, or stagnation), joint stiffness, and *piāngkū* [52] (hemiplegia); promotes the smooth flow of *xuèqì* [53] (blood and vitality).
- **Wild Goose Meat (雁肉):**
  - Taste: sweet. Nature: neutral. Non-toxic.
  - Prolonged consumption fosters luxuriant growth of hair, eyebrows, and beard; replenishes *qi* and prevents hunger, lightens the body, and enhances tolerance to heat.
- **Huang’s Saying:**
  - In the sixth month, do not eat wild goose meat, as it harms one’s *shénqì* [46] (spirit-vitality).

**Vietnamese Swallow’s Dung (越燕屎):**
- Taste: spicy. Nature: neutral. Toxic.
- Kills *gǒudú* [55] (spirit poisons or pestilential influences) and *guǐzhù* [56] (ghostly afflictions); expels malevolent *yīqì* [57] (noxious *qi*).
- Breaks *wǔyīng* [58] (five types of urinary retention); promotes urination.

「To roast with fragrant substances, treating mouth ulcers. Its meat must not be eaten, for it will be killed by *qiāolóng* [59] (water dragons) when placed in water. Huangdi says: In the eleventh month, do not eat rat meat or swallow meat, as it diminishes one’s *shénqì* [spirit-vitality].

**Rock Honey (石蜜):**
Taste: sweet. Nature: neutral, slightly cool. Non-toxic.
It treats *xīnfù xiéqì* [60] (malignant *qi* in the heart and abdomen), seizures, tetany, and calms the five *zàng* [61] (solid organs). It remedies all deficiencies, replenishes *qi* and fortifies the *zhōng* [62] (middle/spleen), stops abdominal pain, counteracts all drug toxins, dispels myriad ailments, harmonizes all medicines, nourishes *píqì* [spleen-vitality], dissipates mental agitation, aids indigestion, stops intestinal prolapse, alleviates muscle pain, treats mouth ulcers, and sharpens the senses. Prolonged consumption strengthens resolve, lightens the body, prevents hunger, resists aging, extends life, and grants Daoist transcendence. Also called *shífěi* [63] (rock candy); the finest is white like tallow—this is the honey found today in mountain cliffs. **Greenish-red honey (青赤蜜):**
Taste: sour. If consumed, it agitates the mind. Its bees are black like horseflies. Huangdi says: In the seventh month, do not eat raw honey, as it causes sudden diarrhea and dysentery.

**Beeswax (蜜蜡):**
Taste: sweet. Slightly warm. Non-toxic.
It treats purulent bloody diarrhea, fortifies the *zhōng* [middle/spleen], mends severed injuries, clears *jīnshāng* [64] (metallic wounds), enhances *qi* and strength, prevents hunger, and resists aging. **White wax:**
Treats chronic diarrhea and prolapse, recurrent bleeding after recovery, severed injuries, and benefits infants. Prolonged consumption lightens the body and prevents hunger. It grows in honeycombs or on wood/stone; it detests *kuánhuā* [65] (datura) and *bǎihé* [66] (lily). This is the wax used today.

**Locust-Snake Meat (蝗蛇肉):**
Nature: neutral. Toxic.
Fermented into wine, it dispels leprosy, all nine types of fistulas, abdominal pain, stagnant *qi*, and spirit poisons. Its belly, which contains a rat: nature neutral, slightly toxic. Treats rat-bite fistulas.

**Silkworm Moth (雄蛾):**
Taste: salty. Warm. Slightly toxic.
It augments *jīngqì* [67] (essence-vitality), strengthens the male *yángdào* [68] (yang channel), and ensures unflagging virility. Do not use paired specimens.

**Mud Carp (鮧鱼):**
Taste: sweet. Non-toxic.
Remedies all ailments.

**Eel (鳗鲡鱼):**
Taste: sweet. Greatly warm. Toxic.
Treats five types of hemorrhoids and fistulas; kills all parasites.

**Monocled Cobra Meat (鳝鱼肉):**
Taste: sweet. Greatly warm. Black specimens are non-toxic.
It fortifies the *zhōng* [middle/spleen] and nourishes blood, treating *chénchún* [69] (drooping lips). Harvested on the fifth day of the fifth month. **Its skull:**
Nature: neutral. Non-toxic.
Burned and ingested, it stops chronic diarrhea.

**Cobra’s "Tongue" (鳝鱼鳝徒河切):**
Nature: neutral. Non-toxic.
Treats *shǎoqì* [70] (weak *qi*) with labored breathing and inability to stand.

Huangdi says: In the fourth month, do not eat snake or eel meat, as it harms the spirit and *qi*.

**Cuttlefish Bone (乌贼鱼骨):**
Taste: salty. Slightly warm. Non-toxic.
For women: treats *lòuxià* [71] (menstrual disorders with red/white discharge), *bì* [72] (blocked menses), *yīnshí* [73] (vaginal ulcers), cold/heat disorders, *zhèngjiá* [74] (abdominal masses), and infertility. For men: treats *jīngqì* [75] (vital essence) entering the abdomen, causing periumbilical pain, and testicular swelling/pain, ensuring fertility. **Its meat:**
Taste: sour. Nature: neutral. Non-toxic.
Replenishes *qi* and strengthens resolve.»

**Carp Meat (鲤鱼肉):**
Taste: sweet. Nature: neutral. Non-toxic.
Treats coughing with upward *qi* reversal, *huánghuàn* [76] (jaundiced sallow complexion), and thirst. **Huangdi says:** When one consumes cassia to its full extent, eating carp meat will harm the person; those with lingering abdominal illnesses should avoid eating carp meat, as it will harm them.

**Dace (鲫鱼):**
Taste: sweet. Nature: neutral. Non-toxic.
Treats all sores. Burn into ash and mix with vinegar sauce to apply daily, twice. **Also removes intestinal abscesses.** **Huangdi says:** Fish with white eyes should not be eaten; fish with horns, if eaten, will cause palpitations and harm the person; fish without intestines or bile, if eaten for three years, will cause erectile dysfunction in men and infertility in women; fish with black spots on their bodies should not be eaten; fish with red eyes, if eaten raw (*zá* [77]), will cause *zhèngjiá* [74] (abdominal masses); if eaten salted (*yǔ* [78]), it will harm the person. All fish eaten together with vegetables will cause *huángchóng* [79] (roundworms) and *huáichóng* [80] (pinworms); all fish tails, if eaten, are not beneficial to the person and often contain hooks, which may lodge in the throat and harm them; fish with horns or white backs should not be eaten. Fish with red scales should not be eaten; fish without cheeks should not be eaten; fish lacking a single complete cheek, if eaten, will cause abscesses. **Mackerel (鲆/鲮)** is not beneficial to the person; its tail contains poison, which treats toothache. **Gizzard shad (鲳/鮧)** is poisonous and should not be eaten.

In the second month, on *gēngyín* [81] days (regarded as inauspicious), do not eat fish—it is greatly harmful. On the fifth day of the fifth month, do not eat carp roe together with pork liver, or it will not digest properly and cause illness. Those with chronic diarrhea who eat **any** fish will worsen their condition, making it difficult to treat.

Eating spoiled rice, **stale meat (鮾)**, or rotten fish together will harm the person.

In the third month, do not eat **Grass carp (鲛)** or any fish meat, as it will cause indigestion, exacerbate chronic illnesses, injure the spirit and *qi*, lead to *qi* depletion, and cause dizziness.

**Turtle Meat (鳖肉):**
Taste: sweet. Nature: neutral. Non-toxic.
Treats *zhōngshāng* [82] (midline injuries) by nourishing *qi*, supplements deficiencies, and cures *jiǎoqì* [83] (leg *qi* disorders). **Huangdi says:** On the fifth day of the fifth month, eating turtle roe together with abalone roe will cause *huánghuàn* [76]; turtles with a "王" (*wáng*) mark beneath their shells should not be eaten; turtle meat eaten together with rabbit meat and mustard seed sauce will harm the person; turtles with three feet, if eaten, will harm the person; turtle meat eaten together with *xiàncài* [84] (purslane) or *juémài* [85] (bracken) will cause *bìè* [86] (turtle-like abdominal masses). **Crab Shell (蟹壳):**
Taste: sour. Nature: cold. Toxic.
Treats chest *xié* [87] (pathogenic heat), chronic masses with pain, *yōupì* [88] (facial paralysis), and scattered *qì* [89] (poisonous eruptions). Burned, it induces *shǔ* [90] (rat *qi*).

**Its yellow substance (蟹之黄):**
Dissolves masses and disperses blood, heals *qì* [89] sores, nourishes sinews, and strengthens *qi*.

**Huangdi says:** Crabs with eyes facing inward and banded legs should not be eaten, as it will harm the person. In the twelfth month, do not eat crab or turtle, as it will harm the spirit and *qi*.

**Further says:** Turtle or tortoise meat eaten together with pork will harm the person; autumn fruits and vegetables eaten together with turtle meat will cause shortness of breath; drinking alcohol with turtle meat and *gūbái* [91] (water caltrop) will cause cold/heat disorders. On *liùjiǎ* [92] days (auspicious days), do not eat turtle or tortoise, as it harms the heart and spirit.

Eating snails or clams together with vegetables will cause heart pain, recurring every three days.

Eating raw crab (*xiāzá* [93]) with pork will cause frequent nausea and excessive salivation, harming the vitality and complexion. Shrimp without whiskers, with a dark, unbroken stripe beneath their bodies, if eaten, will harm the person—**greatly forbidden**, do not consume lightly. In the eleventh and twelfth months, do not eat shrimp or clams with their shells intact. **—Excerpted from *Bìjí Qiān Jīn Yào Fāng* [94] (The Essential Prescriptions Worth a Thousand Gold for Emergency Relief), Volume Eighty, by **Sun Simian** [95].** *(Note: Original text had "易" [95], corrected to "男" [96] per Sun Simian’s edition of *Qián Jīn Fāng*.)*

「#2 Female: Shadow Song carving edition reads *„Harm“* (corrected). #3 Omit: Likely a redundant character. #4 Follow: Original reads *„At/in“* (位), corrected to Shadow Song carving edition. #5 Lie: Shadow Song carving edition reads *„Rest“* (息). #6 One: Original lacks this character, supplemented from Shadow Song carving edition. #7 Long: Original reads *„Winter“* (冬), corrected to Shadow Song carving edition. #8 Cold: Original reads *„Command/order“* (令), corrected to Shadow Song carving edition and later verified by Shadow Song frozen edition. #9 Together: Shadow Song carving edition reads *„Together with blood“* (并血).

**Qián Jīn Yào Fāng (Essential Prescriptions Worth a Thousand Gold for Emergency Relief)**, Volume Eighty-One, verified and corrected by **Lín Yì** [97] and others—*Official Attendant and Keeper of the Imperial Larder, Minor Prefect of the Bureau of Music, and Secret Cabinet Scholar*—in the **Song Dynasty**.

**Chapter on *Yǎng Xìng* (Nurturing the Nature/Qi)**

**Preface to *Nurturing the Nature/Qi***

**Biān Qiāo** [98] said: The **Yellow Emperor** taught that the **water clock** [99] drips water day and night, marking one hundred *kè* [100]. For every *kè*, a person breathes one hundred thirty-five times; ten *kè* make thirteen hundred fifty breaths; one hundred *kè* make thirteen thousand five hundred breaths.

The **breaths of humanity** [101] are but a fleeting measure in this world.
Truly profound! Ah!»
---
*(Annotations for reference only, not included in the translation.)*

In days of old, men lamented the passage of time—how could one not cultivate virtue to compensate for its fleeting nature? I often reflect that in one day and night, there are twelve *shí* [102], ten days and nights make one hundred twenty *shí*, a hundred days and nights make one thousand two hundred *shí*, a thousand days and nights make twelve thousand *shí*, and ten thousand days and nights make one hundred twenty thousand *shí*—this spans thirty years. If one lives to ninety years, they attain but three hundred sixty thousand *shí*. Within a hundred years, these moments pass like the blink of an eye, fleeting as the *cháo-jūn* and *máo-gǔ* [103]. How could one not cultivate oneself, yet indulge the Six Emotions, striving ceaselessly for fame and gain, resorting to deceit and cunning to seek hollow praise, never sated until death?

Thus, those who nurture their nature understand this: toward fame and gain, they regard them as transient; toward what is neither fame nor gain, they also regard it as transient—so they may pass through life unharmed. I lament the many perverse ways of the age, where men abandon themselves to ruin. On idle days, I roughly compose this *Yǎng Xìng* [Nurturing the Nature/Qi] essay, to encourage the Way of humanity, for those virtuous gentlemen who share my aspirations.

To nurture one’s nature is to habituate the self until virtue becomes innate—nature itself becomes good, and without cultivation, nothing is unbeneficial. Once nature is inherently good, all internal and external ailments naturally do not arise, and calamities and misfortunes find no cause to manifest. This is the great principle of nurturing the nature.

Those who excel in nurturing their nature treat diseases before they manifest—this is its essence. Thus, nurturing the nature is not merely about ingesting elixirs or feasting on the *xiá* [104], but lies in encompassing all virtues. When all virtues are complete, even without elixirs, one may attain longevity. If virtue is lacking, though one consumes *yù-yè jīn-dān* [105], it cannot extend life.

Hence, *Lǎozǐ* [106] said: *"The adept at preserving life walks on land without encountering tigers or wild oxen"*—this is the teaching of Dao and virtue. How could one rely on elixirs to pray for longevity?

The sages formulated elixirs to rescue those whose conduct was already flawed. Thus, the foolish cling to illness for years without amending a single deed, dying in suffering without remorse—this is why *Qí Hé* [107] and *Péng Zhú* [108] departed too soon. *Jī Kāng* [109] said: There are five difficulties in nurturing life: not relinquishing fame and gain is the first; not mastering joy and anger is the second; not abstaining from sound and color is the third; not ceasing from indulging flavors is the fourth; and not preserving the spirit and essence is the fifth. If these five persist, though one aspires to longevity with the heart and recites profound teachings, chewing on their essence and breathing in the *Tàiyáng* [110], one cannot avoid misconduct or shorten their years. If these five are absent from the mind, then sincerity and harmony ascend daily, and Dao and virtue are perfected—blessings come without seeking, and longevity follows naturally. This is the fundamental principle of nurturing life.

Yet some may embrace benevolence and righteousness without the burden of excessive indulgence—perhaps they are but a step below!

The Yellow Emperor asked *Qíbó* [111]: *"I have heard that in the ancient times, men lived to a hundred years without their vitality declining. Now, men reach fifty and already decline—is this due to the changing times, or is it because humanity has lost the Way?"*

*Qíbó* replied: *"In the ancient times, those who understood the Dao regulated themselves according to yin and yang, harmonized with techniques and calculations, ate with moderation, and maintained regularity in their rising and resting. They did not indulge in reckless labor, and their form and spirit were in harmony, thus fulfilling their natural lifespan of a hundred years before departing. But today’s men are not so. They drink wine as their daily staple, indulge in licentiousness as their norm, enter chambers inebriated, exhaust their essence through desire, dissipate their true *qi*, and do not know how to preserve fullness. They do not govern their spirit in season, seeking only to gratify their hearts, indulging in pleasures contrary to life’s harmony, and lacking regularity in their conduct—thus they decline by fifty. The teachings of the ancient sages were universally followed. Even malevolent winds and evil influences were avoided in their proper seasons."*

「The Master Qi Bó said: In the age of antiquity, those who understood the *Dao*, aligned with the principles of yin and yang, harmonized with the arts of *shù*—the methods of nurturing life—maintained regularity in their meals, and disciplined their daily rising and resting. They did not exhaust themselves with reckless labor, and their physical form and vital *qi* remained in balance, allowing them to fulfill their natural lifespan of a hundred years before departing. But today’s men are not so. They drink wine as their daily nourishment, indulge in licentiousness as their norm, enter chambers inebriated, drain their essence through desire, dissipate their true *qi* without restraint, and do not know how to preserve fullness. They do not govern their spirit in accordance with the seasons, seeking only to gratify their hearts, indulging in pleasures contrary to life’s harmony, and lacking regularity in their conduct—thus they decline by fifty. The teachings of the ancient sages were universally followed. Even malevolent winds and evil influences were avoided in their proper seasons.

Those who cultivate stillness and embrace emptiness allow their true *qi* to flow naturally. Their spirit remains steadfast within, so how could illness find them? Thus, their will is serene and their desires few, their mind at peace and without fear, their body labored yet not weary, their *qi* following its natural course, and their pursuits aligned with their inclinations—all finding fulfillment. Therefore, they savor their food and adorn their attire—*Suǒwèn* states: *savor their food, adorn their attire*—and take joy in their customs, neither aspiring to what is above nor envying what is below, so their people remain simple and unadorned throughout their days. Hence, their senses are not strained by excessive cravings, their hearts not bewildered by licentiousness, and neither the foolish nor the wise, the virtuous nor the depraved, fear the world. They harmonize with the *Dao* and its methods, and thus all may attain a hundred years while their vitality remains unwaning—such is the completeness of their *virtue/power* and its safety.

Therefore, a man’s longevity or early demise depends on moderation. If he attunes to the ebb and flow of nature, he may achieve long life and immortality; if he indulges his emotions and desires, his fate shall be like morning dew. The Master Qi Bó said: At forty, yin *qi* begins to wane, and one’s vitality declines with rising and resting. At fifty, the body grows heavy, and the senses of hearing and sight grow dull. At sixty, yin *qi* weakens, strength and vigor greatly decline, and the nine orifices fail—with the upper body filled and the lower empty, tears and mucus flowing together. Hence, it is said: "Know it, and you shall not age; ignore it, and you shall grow old."

Though their names differ, all things arise from the same source. The wise discern the unity, the foolish see only the distinctions. The foolish lack what is essential, while the wise possess what is abundant. Abundance brings clarity to the ears and eyes, lightness to the body and strength to its frame—so that even in old age, one may regain vigor, and the strong may refine their essence further. Thus, the sage practices the art of *wu wéi*—non-action—takes delight in the flavors of simplicity and stillness, and though he indulges his desires and gratifies his will, he attains the preservation of emptiness. Therefore, his lifespan is boundless, enduring alongside heaven and earth. This is how the sage nurtures his body.

The first three months of spring—this is called *fā chén* (unfolding and renewing). Heaven and earth both give birth, and all things flourish. Sleep early and rise with the dawn, stroll widely in the courtyard, let your hair hang loose, and relax your form—thus invigorating your will. Let life unfold without suppression, give without taking, reward without punishment. This is the response to spring *qi*, the path of nurturing life. To act against it brings harm to the liver; in summer, it manifests as cold and disorder, so that those who honor the growth of spring shall live fewer years. The next three months of summer—this is called *fán xiù* (abundance and fruition). Heaven and earth exchange their *qi*, and all things bear fruit. Sleep early and rise with the dawn, never weary of the sun. Let your will remain without anger, let the blossoms and fruits reach maturity, and let your *qi* find release—if your affections lie outward, this is the response to summer *qi*, the path of fostering growth. To act against it brings harm to the heart; in autumn, it manifests as *chì yù* (chronic ailments and shivering), so that those who honor the harvest of summer shall live fewer years, and by winter, they shall suffer grave illness.

The next three months of autumn—this is called *róng píng* (containing and balancing). The *qi* of heaven grows urgent, while the *qi* of earth grows clear. Sleep early and rise with the dawn, awaken alongside the rooster. Let your will remain tranquil, and temper the severity of autumn’s *qi*. Gather and preserve your spirit and *qi*, so that autumn’s *qi* may be balanced. Do not let your will stray outward, and let the *qi* of the lungs remain pure—this is the response to autumn *qi*, the path of fostering containment. To act against it brings harm to the lungs; in winter, it manifests as *cān xiè* (excessive sweating and leakage), so that those who honor the storage of autumn shall live fewer years.

The next three months of winter—this is called *bì cáng* (sealing and storing). Water freezes and the earth cracks; do not disturb the yang. Sleep early and rise late, waiting for the sunlight. Let your will be as if hidden or concealed, as if you had private intentions or already attained fulfillment. Seek warmth and avoid cold, do not expose your skin, and do not let your *qi* be violently drained—this is the response to winter *qi*, the path of fostering storage. To act against it brings harm to the kidneys; in spring, it manifests as *wěi jué* (withering and fainting), so that those who honor the birth of winter shall live fewer years.

Heaven has four seasons and five elements, giving birth, growth, containment, and storage, and manifesting as cold, heat, dryness, dampness, and wind. Man has five *zàng* (viscera), transforming into five *qi* (vital energies), which give rise to joy, anger, sorrow, worry, and fear. Therefore, joy and anger harm the *qi*, while cold and heat harm the form; violent anger depletes yin, and excessive joy depletes yang. Hence, if joy and anger are not moderated, and cold and heat are not attuned to, life’s foundation shall not be secure. If a man can align himself with the seasons and adjust accordingly, he may avoid early decline and untimely death.

Zhòng Cháng Tǒng said: In the palaces of kings and nobles, there are a thousand beautiful women; in the homes of officials and warriors, there are hundreds of attendants. By day, they steep their bones and marrow in pure wine; by night, they drain their blood and *qi* through the chambers. Their ears listen to lewd sounds, their eyes delight in forbidden colors, and they neither emerge from feasting within nor return from their revels without. "The king and nobles receive this from above, while the warriors and the bold indulge in it below. When childbirth is untimely, when weaning comes too soon, when children are prematurely exposed to the *qi* of adults, or when illness drains their essence and desire, their *qi* grows weak and their blood insufficient. Even before they leave the womb, their nurturing is without method, and then they are further enfeebled by the steaming of silk and the overindulgence in the five flavors. Injured in the womb, sickly as infants, they remain frail and never attain true strength. If they then indulge their emotions and desires, these weaknesses multiply and diseases breed from diseases. The realm lacks skilled physicians, and those who practice medicine do not discern its true arts—fraudulent assistants abound, and errors are common. When a sickness strikes, none can escape it. Today, few live to a hundred years, is it not because their habits are not pure and correct?

Bào Pǔ Zǐ said: Someone asked, "What you call *injury* refers only to licentious desires?" I replied: Why limit it to that alone? Indeed, the key to long life lies in the practice within the chambers. The superior man understands this, and may thereby extend his years and ward off illness; the lesser does not harm himself through it. If one is in the prime of youth and knows how to employ the *Huán yīn Dān* (method of returning yin) to nourish the kidneys, and to take the seven *bǎi* (herbs) for longevity—though some texts say "seven *gǔ* (grains),"—without resorting to medicines, he shall not fall short of a hundred or two hundred years, though he may not attain immortality. Those who fail to grasp the art shall be compared to using a metal cup to hold soup or a feathered pouch to store fire—both futile and harmful. Furthermore, straining the mind beyond one’s capacity causes injury, exerting the body beyond its strength causes injury, deep sorrow and heavy resentment cause injury, grief and melancholy cause injury, excessive joy and mirth cause injury, obsessive pursuit of desires causes injury, constant dread of misfortune causes injury, prolonged talking and laughter cause injury, irregular sleep and rest cause injury, drawing the bow or tauting the crossbow causes injury, deep intoxication and vomiting cause injury, lying down immediately after a heavy meal causes injury, leaping about and panting for breath causes injury, loud shouting and weeping causes injury, and the failure to unite yin and yang causes injury.»

The accumulation of injuries to their utmost, when exhausted, leads to early death—this is not the Dao. Therefore, those who cultivate their nature do not spit too far, walk too swiftly, listen too intently, gaze too keenly, sit for too long, stand to the point of exhaustion, or lie down until drowsiness sets in.

They clothe themselves before feeling cold and remove their garments before feeling hot; they do not eat when excessively hungry, nor eat to the point of overfullness; they do not drink when excessively thirsty, nor drink to excess. Overindulgence in food leads to stagnation and accumulation, while excessive drinking produces phlegm and dampness.

They avoid excessive labor, excessive idleness, excessive sweating, excessive spitting, reckless running or riding, straining the eyes with distant gazes, consuming too many raw or cold foods, drinking wine in the wind, frequent bathing, harboring grand ambitions or distant aspirations, or contriving artificial marvels.

In winter, they do not seek extreme warmth; in summer, they do not pursue extreme coolness. They avoid sleeping exposed to the stars and moon, nor do they use fans while sleeping. They do not expose themselves to great cold, great heat, great winds, or thick fogs.

The five flavors should not be consumed in excess: too much sour harms the spleen, too much bitter harms the lungs, too much pungent harms the liver, too much salty harms the heart, and too much sweet harms the kidneys. These are the five flavors counteracting the five viscera, the natural principles of the Five Phases.

As for what is said to cause injury, its harm is not immediately apparent—only prolonged exposure diminishes one’s lifespan. Thus, those skilled in preserving life regulate their rising and resting according to the seasons’ early and late hours, maintain harmonious routines in their daily activities; they adjust and nourish their sinews and bones through reclining and stretching; they dispel ailments and manage duties through breathwork techniques; they apply harmonizing methods of supplementation and reduction; they balance labor and rest through principles of moderation.

They suppress anger to preserve yin, restrain excessive joy to nourish yang, and first take herbal remedies to rectify deficiencies before resorting to elixirs to achieve immortality. The principles of cultivating one’s nature are exhausted here.

As for those who seek to indulge their desires, act on impulse, and claim to comprehend fate and destiny—unbound by heterodox teachings, indulging their nature and exerting themselves without restraint—when they hear these words, even if they pass like the wind or flash like lightning before their eyes, they cannot comprehend them. Though their bodies wither in their attachments and their *qi* fades in their luxuries, they delight in it. How could one then instruct them in the ways of nurturing life? Not only do they refuse to accept it, but they dismiss it as superstition.

To expect them to believe is like offering a mirror to the blind or playing music for the deaf. When Wei Wu [Cao Cao] commanded Royal Secretary Huangfu Long, saying, *“I hear you have surpassed a hundred years, yet your vitality remains unwaning, your ears and eyes sharp, your complexion serene and joyful—this is a marvelous feat. May I inquire about your diet, practices, and guided movements? If there are teachings worth passing down, I would hope you might confide them in secrecy within the imperial precincts.”*

Huangfu Long replied in a memorial:

*"Your servant has heard that among the natures of Heaven and Earth, none is more noble than humanity; and among human concerns, none is more precious than life. The chaos of Tang [the ancient mythical age] had no beginning, and the cycles of the *eon* [劫, *kalpa*] are boundless. Human life unfolds within this expanse, fleeting as lightning’s flash. Each time I ponder this, my heart grows hot with urgency. Life comes but once and cannot be recalled—why not restrain one’s passions and nurture one’s nature to preserve oneself?

Now that the Four Seas are nearly pacified and the era is one of Great Peace, one must further unfold one’s talents and cultivate virtue to attain longevity—*a span of ten thousand years*. A span of ten thousand years is boundless, and this depends on cultivating the Dao. The Dao is easy to know, yet few can practice it.

Your servant has often heard of Daoists in Jing who have lived to 178 years yet remain vigorous. They say that if one daily consumes *yuquan* [玉泉, ‘jade spring’] and practices *zhuochi* [琢齿, ‘polishing the teeth’], one will remain youthful with a radiant complexion, expel the three worms [三虫, intestinal parasites], and strengthen one’s teeth. *Yuquan* refers to the saliva in one’s mouth. Before dawn, one should gargle with saliva until the mouth is full, then swallow it; *zhuochi* involves brushing the teeth seventy-two times. Only thus does one refine the essence.

Jie Kang said: ‘In years of abundance, there are many illnesses; in years of famine, there are few diseases.’ Truly, this is not empty!"*

「Thus, the people of the Central Plains are frugal by nature, their kitchens offering only pickled vegetables and fermented sauces. Their lives are marked by few illnesses and long years. In the southern regions beyond the Ling Mountains, however, there is abundance in all things—fish and meats from land and sea are plentiful—yet the people suffer many diseases and die young. The scholars of the northern lands, when they travel and reside there, encounter such opulence and believe it to be the blessing of fortune.

Therefore, regardless of status or age, they indulge their appetites without restraint. Long nights of drunkenness and gluttony leave their bodies hot and congested; they sleep naked and exposed, their undigested food festering within. Within less than a month, both young and old fall ill. Some suffer from cholera [霍乱], beriberi [脚气], or distension [胀满], others from alternating cold and heat, malaria, or dysentery [疟痢], foul growths and swellings [恶核丁肿], abscesses [痈疽], hemorrhoids [痔漏], or paralytic stroke [偏风猥退]. Unable to discern proper care, they perish. Such cases are endless; all they say is that they are unaccustomed to the local climate, yet none know the true source of their afflictions. Reflecting upon this, one cannot help but sigh deeply.

Students of the Dao must first recognize this truth and take it as a warning to be cautious. *Bao Pu Zi* [抱朴子, ‘Embracing Simplicity’] says: “The body of one person is a microcosm of a state. The chest and abdomen are like palaces and halls; the limbs are like the outlying districts; the bones and joints are like the officials. The spirit is like the ruler, blood like the ministers, and *qi* like the people. To govern one’s body is to govern a state.

He who loves his people ensures the stability of his state; he who cherishes his *qi* preserves his body. If the people scatter, the state falls; if the *qi* is exhausted, the body dies. The dead cannot be revived, nor can the fallen be restored. Therefore, the perfected ones [至人] prevent ailments before they arise and cure sicknesses before they take hold, treating them in the absence of symptoms rather than waiting until they have passed.

For man is hard to nourish and easily endangered; *qi* is hard to purify and easily turbid. Thus, one who understands how to safeguard the state with virtue and power [威德] and fortify the body by restraining desires can attain the *Zhen Yi* [真一, ‘True Unity’], preserve the *San Yi* [三一, ‘Three Unities’], repel all diseases, and extend his years.

**Chapter Two: Nurturing Nature by Dao Lin** [道林, ‘Daoist Forest’]
The perfected ones [真人] say: “Even if one constantly consumes elixirs [服饵] yet does not practice the cultivation of nature, it is still difficult to achieve longevity.

The Dao of nurturing nature is to always seek moderation, avoiding neither excessive fatigue nor straining beyond one’s limits. Moreover, stagnant water does not rot, and door hinges do not decay, for they are in constant motion. Thus, in nurturing nature, one must avoid prolonged standing, sitting, walking, or reclining, as well as excessive looking or listening. For prolonged looking harms the blood, prolonged reclining harms the *qi*, prolonged standing harms the bones, prolonged sitting harms the flesh, and prolonged walking harms the sinews.

One must also avoid overindulging in food, excessive drinking, heavy lifting, deep sorrow, violent anger, extreme grief, great fear, reckless leaping, excessive speech, or boisterous laughter. Do not be overly eager for what you desire, nor harbor grudges and resentment. All these excesses shorten life. If one can refrain from them, then longevity is attainable.

Therefore, those skilled in preserving life [摄生] always cultivate little thought, little contemplation, little desire, little busyness, little speech, little laughter, little sorrow, little joy, little pleasure, little anger, little fondness, and little aversion. Practicing these twelve moderations is the fundamental principle of nurturing nature. Excessive thought weakens the spirit, excessive contemplation scatters the will, excessive desire dulls the mind, excessive busyness strains the body, excessive speech depletes the *qi*, excessive laughter harms the organs, excessive sorrow paralyzes the heart, excessive joy exhausts the mind, excessive pleasure leads to forgetfulness and confusion, excessive anger disrupts the hundred vessels [百脉], excessive fondness causes obsession and distraction, and excessive aversion brings emaciation and despondency. If these twelve excesses are not eliminated, the *honorific* and *defensive* energies [荣卫] will lose their measure, blood and *qi* will act erratically, and the root of death will be sown. Only he who neither indulges in excess nor falls into deficiency approaches the Dao.

Thus, it is known that avoiding external influences [外缘] is the first method of the perfected ones in their Daoist practice. If one can do this, he may dwell even in pestilential regions without fear or doubt.

Having set aside external influences, one must then guard the Five Spirits [五神]—liver, heart, spleen, lungs, and kidneys—and adhere to the Four Rectitudes [四正] in speech, conduct, sitting, and standing. Speech must never indulge in idle thoughts or false contemplations; if the mind is filled with desires or evil, great harm will arise. Hence, Confucius said: *“The mind must not be filled with wickedness”* [思无邪]. One should always practice the Yellow Emperor’s method of inward gazing [内视], storing and pondering thoughts, so that the Five Organs [五脏] appear like suspended bells, their colors distinct and clear. This practice must never cease.

Furthermore, each morning upon rising, one should face south, extend both hands upon the knees, and with the heart’s eye [心眼] observe the *qi*, letting it ascend to the crown [顶] and descend to the *Yongquan* [涌泉, ‘gushing spring’]. This daily practice is called *Yingqi* [迎气, ‘receiving *qi*’].

One should always inhale through the nose and exhale through the mouth, doing so gently without opening wide. The exhalation should be brief, while the inhalation should be deep. Each time one eats, one should direct the *qi* into the abdomen, letting the *qi* serve as the host. Whenever the mind has any fondness, one should not indulge it deeply; whenever it has any hatred, one should not indulge it deeply either. Both extremes harm nature and spirit.

One should also avoid excessive praise or excessive condemnation. The mind must always be balanced and equal toward all things; if one detects a tilt, one should immediately correct it. In poverty, do not believe it will always be so; in wealth, do not believe it will always endure. Dwelling in the midst of poverty and riches, one must always uphold the Dao, not letting wealth or poverty alter one’s resolve or nature. Understanding the principles of the Dao, one may seem unable to speak of them, yet this has great merit. Do not boast of fine medicine, nor of virtuous speech, nor let disordered thoughts enter the mind.

One must always use profound sincerity and reverence toward all things, being careful not to feign goodness to please others. Throughout one’s life, if one does good yet is despised, one must not harbor resentment. In serving one’s lord, if one is accused of flattery, one should balance the mind with the Dao. Where the Dao resides, its virtue will not be alone. Do not say that doing good brings no good fortune, and thus blame oneself.»

「One must dwell in contentment, ensuring the heart never feels deficient. If deficiency arises, one should restrain it within oneself, lest it grow. When a person knows to stop wanting, Heaven grants them their natural blessings.

In every place one goes, one must not seek excessively, for excessive seeking will weary the heart and burden the spirit. Indeed, the reason why people often fall ill is because they fail to nourish their true nature.

The days of peace and ease are said to be everlasting, yet if one indulges in unrestrained desires and seeks whatever the heart craves—without restraint, deceiving both the seen and unseen—one will do no wrong. Yet they claim to suit their nature, unaware that each indulgence is the root of future ailments.

When the hands find nothing to grasp and cold sweat flows, they invoke the *Huángtiān* (皇天) in vain, finding no relief. All such misfortunes stem from a lifetime of careless conduct, failing to self-examine. If one reflects inwardly during youth, they will realize that every action and thought fears the onset of disease, and that the four hundred and forty-four afflictions are self-made, not decreed by Heaven.

Once sickness strikes, gentle remedies will not suffice. Then they scorn medicine and *shénxiān* (神仙) as ineffective and powerless. Therefore, the wise who cherish life must ponder deeply, cultivate shame, and discipline themselves, always striving for goodness.

As for dwelling, one must avoid luxurious and ornate adornments that breed insatiable greed, for such excess is the source of harm. Instead, let the dwelling be simple and clean, free from wind, rain, heat, or dampness.

Utensils and garments should not be of precious jade, gold, or gems, lest they deepen the roots of affliction and stir the mind’s troubles. Meals should not overflow with salted or dried meats; frugality is best.

Then one should walk with the *éwángbù* (鹅王步) gait, speak in a *hánzhōngshēng* (含锺声) tone, and sleep as a lion reclining on its right flank, feet resting on the ground. Each day, one should recite:
*"Fine food must be chewed thoroughly,
Raw food should not be swallowed hastily.
Ask of my dwelling place,
It is the grand estate of the Forest Village.
Guard the prenatal breath within the five viscera,
Let the qi reach the bones to attain immortality.*
Another verse:
*"Three daily poisons must be consumed,
But chew them well lest they linger.
The five flavors are the five viscera’s bait,
Yet wear the coarse robes of the humble."*

Having steadied the mind, one must also be cautious with speech. When speaking or reciting, always imagine the voice resonating from the *qìhǎi* (气海) below the navel.

At the first hour after sunset, one should refrain from speaking or reciting; instead, wait until dawn. Upon rising, one should focus first on virtuous matters, not on calculating wealth.

While eating, one must not speak, for speaking while eating often causes chest and back pain.

Nor should one indulge in excessive talking or laughter in bed, for sleep should not be disturbed by speech. The five viscera are like bells and chimes; if they are not suspended, they cannot sound. Walking should not be accompanied by speech, for speaking while moving will cause one to lose their *qi*. On the winter solstice, one may speak but should not utter words recklessly.

When someone asks, one must not refuse to answer, but one should avoid speaking without necessity. It is best to avoid loud speech in cold air.

Having disciplined speech, one must also regulate eating and drinking. Thus, those who nourish their nature wisely eat only when hungry and drink only when thirsty; they prefer small, frequent meals over large, sudden ones, for the latter is hard to digest.

One should always maintain a balance between hunger and satiety—neither too full nor too empty. For overeating harms the lungs, hunger weakens the *qi*, excessive salt injures the sinews, and sourness damages the bones.

Therefore, one should practice eating bland foods, chewing thoroughly to ensure the essence of grains enters the stomach, not letting the grease of alcohol settle in the intestines. When eating, one must avoid sudden anger or excessive haste, for these stir the spirit and cause restless dreams and nighttime agitation.

Heavy meats should never be consumed, as they breed countless diseases. Instead, one should eat little meat, much rice, and a few pickled vegetables, while avoiding raw greens, raw rice, small beans, stale or foul-smelling foods. One must not drink turbid wine or eat coarse grains, lest they clog the *qi* pathways. Nor should one eat raw meat, which harms the stomach; all meats must be thoroughly cooked and eaten cold.

After eating, one should rinse the mouth several times to preserve strong teeth and fresh breath. If one rinses with cold, fermented water after hot meals or salty foods, their breath will always reek, and they risk *kuāngchǐbìng* (□齿病).

Moreover, after consuming hot foods or salty dishes, one must not drink cold vinegar or fermented water, for this often causes the voice to fail and the throat to seize as if dead.

When eating hot foods and sweating, one must not face the wind, lest it trigger *jìngtóu* (痉头) and headaches, making the eyes dull and inducing drowsiness.

After meals, one should massage the face and abdomen to encourage the free flow of *jīnyè* (津液). Upon finishing, one should walk slowly, covering several *lǐ* (里) in distance. Afterward, another should rub the abdomen with powder hundreds of times, aiding digestion and greatly benefiting the body. This practice ensures one can eat freely without a hundred diseases, and then true cultivation may begin.

Eating to fullness and then lying down breeds countless diseases, as the food does not digest and forms stagnation. Lying on one’s back after overeating leads to *qìbǐ* (气痞) and *tóufēng* (头风).

Those who eat hot foods while still feeling cold will suffer from *cìfēng* (刺风). One must not eat at night.

It is also said: Do not overindulge in drink or food at night, nor engage in intense mental labor, for such exertions harm the body.

*Yūxū* (虚损) weakens a person; one should finish eating by the *wèishí* (巳时) hour each day, then avoid alcohol entirely, and one will never suffer from dry heaves for life.

Do not eat meats belonging to one’s parents’ *běnmìng* (本命) element, for this shortens one’s lifespan. Nor should one eat meats belonging to their own *běnmìng* (本命) element, lest their *húnpò* (魂魄) scatter wildly.

One must avoid all brain meats, for they greatly harm the body.

If rainwater leaks into preserved meats stored in a thatched house, eating them causes *hùyuē* (瘕约). Meats preserved in brine that are not properly dried are also harmful to the body.

Meats that move on their own without cause, if eaten, will harm the body. If bees swarm over food, eating it will surely bring poison and harm.»

If one has lingering illnesses within the belly, one must not eat *lín* (鲮) or carp meat, for it harms the body.

Moist foods and alcoholic beverages should be inspected before consumption—if no human or animal shadows are seen upon them, do not eat, lest one suffer from *zúzhù* (卒注). If one has already eaten and their belly is distended, quickly administer medicine to purge it.

One should eat *kuí* (葵) once every ten days. *Kuí* is slippery, thus facilitating the circulation of *qi* through the five *zàng* (脏), and is the sovereign among vegetables—it should not be consumed with conflicting emotions.

Moreover, one should not drink alcohol excessively; if intoxication occurs, vomiting should be induced promptly to avoid drunkenness, for otherwise, one will never be free of a hundred ailments. Prolonged alcohol consumption rots the intestines and stomach, erodes the marrow, and steams the sinews, damaging the spirit and shortening life.

When drunk, one must not face the wind, nor bask in the sun, for this drives one mad. One must also avoid lying in the wind, nor should others fan them to cool them—both actions invite illness. When drunk, one must not sleep exposed or in piles of husked grain, for this causes *lài* (癞) sores. Drunkenness followed by forced eating may lead to *yōngjū* (痈疽), *yīn* (喑), or sores. When drunk and sated, one must not ride in carriages or leap about. Drunkenness followed by sexual intercourse—whether sober or not—may cause minor ailments like *miǎn* (面) or coughing, or severe damage to the *zàngmài* (脏脉), risking death.

When hungry, one should sit to urinate; when full, one should stand. Be cautious to avoid illness.

Retaining urine when inconvenient causes cold knees and *bì* (痹). Retaining feces when unable to expel them leads to *qìzhì* (气痔). Do not strain while urinating, lest the legs and knees grow cold. When defecating, avoid forcing with breath or straining, for this causes waist pain and blurred vision—it is best to relax naturally.

Wherever springs emerge in mountain valleys or basins, one must not dwell there long, as it invites *yǐng* (瘿) disease. Cold water from deep, shaded places must not be drunk, for it will surely cause *qí* (痎) or *nüè* (疟).

Diet should be regulated, and clothing adjusted according to the seasons. When dressing in the morning, reverse the garment before putting it on—this is auspicious. Clothing that has been exposed to light should be shaken three times before the door, saying, *"Disaster departs."* This is auspicious.

Damp or sweaty clothing must not be worn for long, for it causes sores and *fēngsào* (风瘙); frequent changing is ideal. If not changed, it must be washed immediately, otherwise, it will obstruct urination.

After sweating profusely, one must not speak while changing clothes, lest one invite *pòfēng* (偏风) and hemiplegia.

In spring, one must not wear thin clothing, for it invites *shānghán* (伤寒), *huòluàn* (霍乱), indigestion, and headaches.

After changing clothes, one must adjust their sleeping quarters. In spring and summer, one should sleep facing east; in autumn and winter, facing west. The head must not face north when sleeping, nor should the bed be placed against a north-facing wall.

Before sleeping, one must not sing or recite—this invites misfortune. When ascending the bed, one should remove the left foot first.

One must not sleep beneath the spine of the bed, nor leave lamps burning after retiring, lest the *húnpò* (魂魄) and the six *shén* (神) become restless, fostering endless grievances.

Fireplaces must not be placed near the head; prolonged exposure draws *huǒqì* (火气), causing heaviness in the head, reddened eyes, and dryness in the pupils and nose.

At night, one must ensure no openings exist near the ears where wind can blow, for this causes deafness.

In summer, one must not sleep with the face exposed, for this thickens the skin, invites *xiàn* (癣), or *miànfēng* (面风). In winter, one must not cover the head when sleeping, for this ensures longevity.

When sleeping, one must not dangle their feet from high places, for this damages the kidneys, weakens the *fáng* (房), and causes cold feet.

One must not lie directly beneath a straight wall within ten steps, for the *fēnglì* (风利) will blow and cause *diān* (癫) or heaviness in the body.

One must not sit with feet suspended while sweating, for this leads to *xuèbì* (血痹), heaviness in the legs, and waist pain.

Moreover, one must not nap during the day, for this causes *shīqì* (失气).

When sleeping, one must not speak loudly, for this depletes one’s *qìlì* (气力).

At dusk, one should habitually practice closing the mouth while sleeping; if the mouth is left open, one’s *qìlì* (气力) will be lost, and moreover, malevolent *qi* (邪恶) may enter through the mouth, leading over time to *xiāohè* (消渴) and pallor from blood depletion.

Bending the knees and sleeping on one’s side nourishes one’s *qìlì* (气力), surpassing the upright prone position. As Confucius did not sleep in a corpse-like posture, it is said: *"To sleep, one should not tire of bending the knees; to wake, one should not tire of stretching them."*

When one sleeps in a relaxed state, *guǐtòng* (鬼痛) and *móxié* (魔邪) may afflict them. Before sleeping, one must first settle the mind, then the eyes.

A single night’s sleep should be divided into five stages of rest, turning with each watch of the night.

If one is plagued by nightmares, do not light a lamp to awaken them; if you do, they will surely die. Call them softly in the dark instead.

If one has a night of evil dreams, do not speak of them upon waking; rather, wash the face with water and recite the following incantation: *"Evil dreams cling to grasses and trees; good dreams become precious jade."* Thus, no harm will come.

Moreover, whether dreams are good or evil, one should not speak of them as auspicious.

In all matters of clothing, food, and rest, one must align with the season’s *qì* (气). Only those who harmonize with the seasonal *qi* can fully embody the *Dao* (道) of nurturing life.

Thus, those skilled in preserving life avoid transgressing the taboos of the sun and moon, and do not disrupt the balance of the seasons. One must know:
- The daily taboo: do not eat to fullness at noon;
- The monthly taboo: do not drink heavily on the last day of the month;
- The yearly taboo: do not travel far at dusk;
- The lifelong taboo: do not walk about at dusk after lighting candles to engage in *fáng* (房).

This is how one should always guard their *qi* (气).

The *qi* of winter arises at *yǒngquán* (涌泉, the bubbling spring—soles of the feet) on the Winter Solstice, reaches the knees by the eleventh month, the thighs by the twelfth, the waist by the first month, and this is called *sāngchángchéng* (三肠成, the completion of the three intestines). By the second month, it reaches the arms, by the third the neck, and by the fourth the crown of the head. At this time, *chúnyáng* (纯阳, pure yang) prevails, and the yin follows suit accordingly.

Thus, during the fourth and tenth months, one must avoid *fáng* (房), lest they disrupt the months when yin and yang are in full harmony.

On the Winter Solstice, one should sleep with thick layers of grass spread beneath them on the northern wall, for this is said to receive the *yuángǔ* (元气, primordial *qi*).

From the first day of the eighth month onward, one should warm their feet with gentle fire, ensuring the lower body does not grow cold and lifeless. One must always strive to keep *qi* in the lower body, never allowing it to dissipate upward.

In spring, before the frost has fully melted, clothing should be thick at the bottom and thin at the top, to nourish the *cháng* (肠, intestines), preserve *yīn* (阴, yin), and extend one’s lifespan. To nourish yin and preserve it with a single misstep is to invite disaster that may annihilate one’s entire lineage.

Thus it is said: *"In winter, the *qi* of heaven and earth is closed, and blood and *qi* are stored away. One must not engage in labor that causes sweating, lest yang *qi* be released and harm the body."*

It is also said: *"In winter, the brain freezes; in spring and autumn, both the brain and feet freeze."* This is the constant method of the sages.

In spring, one should sleep late and rise early; in summer and autumn, one should sleep and rise just before midnight. In winter, one should rise early and sleep late. All these practices benefit the body.

Though it is said to rise early, do not do so before the rooster crows; though it is said to sleep late, do not delay until after sunrise.

If winter months suddenly grow hot or summer months suddenly grow cold, one must not expose themselves to such extremes.

Those who fall ill from the *qi* of the seasons are all due to violating these principles. One must regulate their breathing to balance cold and heat, and thus avoid illness.

On the *làrì* (腊日, the final day of the lunar year), one must not sing or dance; violators will surely meet misfortune.

It is beneficial to burn white hair on the *yínrì* (寅日, Tiger Day) of the first month. One should also trim fingernails on *yínrì* (寅日, Tiger Day) and toenails on *wǔrì* (午日, Horse Day), and burning white hair is auspicious.

**Section Three: Dwelling Practices**
When constructing or inhabiting a residence, the walls must be sealed tightly, with no gaps or cracks, lest *fēngqì* (风气, pathogenic wind-*qi*) enter.

When even a slight breeze arises, do not force yourself to endure prolonged sitting—you must quickly avoid it. Prolonged residence without awareness invites *zhòngfēng* (中风, windstroke). Throughout history, those who suddenly suffer from *piānfēng* (偏风, hemiplegia)—where limbs do not obey, or the body arches like a reversed bow, or speech is lost—all stem from neglecting this warning.

Once *zhòngfēng* (中风) takes hold, all maladies converge; pathogenic *xiéqì* (邪气) seizes the opportunity, and nine out of ten such cases meet a swift end. Thus, one must be utterly vigilant, never treating this lightly. **Caution! Caution!**

In one’s dwelling, do not seal up wells or water stains, lest they cause deafness and blindness.

When at home or traveling, if suddenly caught in violent winds, torrential rain, thunderstorms, darkness, or thick fog—all signs of *lóngguǐshén* (龙鬼神, dragons, spirits, and malevolent deities) in motion—one must retreat indoors, close the doors, burn incense, and sit in quiet meditation, directing the mind to evade them. Only after their passage should one emerge; otherwise, harm will follow. Even if no immediate suffering occurs, future misfortune is inevitable.

Similarly, avoid long journeys in misty conditions.

Within the home, if sacred scriptures or images are present, one must first bow before them upon entering, then bow to elders, and always sit upright upon arrival.

At home, frequent bathing is undesirable. If bathing is necessary, it must be done in a sealed chamber, avoiding extreme heat or cold—both generate myriad ailments.

In winter, bathing need not induce profuse sweating. After bathing, avoid exposure to wind or cold. Once hair is freshly washed, do not face the wind, let dampness cling to the hair bun, or sleep with a damp head—these practices invite *tóufēng* (头风, head wind), dizziness, hair loss, darkened complexion, toothache, deafness, and scaly scalp.

Bathing on an empty stomach is forbidden; bathing after a full meal is also prohibited. After bathing, consume a modest amount of food or drink before emerging.

Bathing hair at night, followed by sleep without eating, weakens the heart, induces excessive sweating, and provokes vivid dreams.

Moreover, spouses should never bathe on the same day. Bathing is auspicious only on *huìrì* (晦日, the final day of the lunar month) or *shuòrì* (朔日, the first day of the lunar month).

Using leftover broth to wash the body causes *xuǎn* (癣, tinea); washing the face dulls its luster; washing the feet induces pain and *zèngqí* (甑畦, a condition resembling blisters or ulcers). Washing hair with hot water followed by cold rinses provokes *tóufēng* (头风). Drinking water before bathing hair also triggers seasonal *tóufēng*.

After sweating from illness, avoid cold-water baths—this damages the *xīnbāo* (心包, Heart Envelope) and may prove fatal.

At home, always admonish and harmonize the conduct of elders and juniors. If any discomfort arises, it must be expressed promptly; suppression leads to prolonged suffering, which may escalate into incurable illness.

At the first sign of unease or *ānqì* (安气, stagnant *qi*), apply massage and kneading to restore mobility to all joints and disperse pathogenic influences.

Regardless of occupation, one must daily stretch the neck, back, and limbs, and vigorously massage the head and nape to fortify against seasonal *fēngqì* (风气). This is a paramount principle, too profound to exhaust here.
