When at home or traveling, always carry with you one *shèng* (升) of dried *ài* (艾, mugwort), along with emergency pills (*bìguǐ* 避鬼丸, *shēngjī* 生肌药, *gānhuā* 甘湿药, *dīngzhǒng* 丁肿药), *shuǐyín* (水银, mercury), *dàyuán* (大黄, rhubarb), *mángxiāo* (芒硝, mirabilite), *gāncǎo* (甘草, licorice), *gānjiāng* (乾姜, dried ginger), *guìxīn* (桂心, cassia bark), and *shǔjiāo* (蜀椒, Sichuan pepper). No additional medicines need be stored—these essentials must never be lacking. Also carry a scroll of the *Bǎiyī Bèijí Yàofāng* (百一备急药方, *One Hundred and One Emergency Remedies*), including antidotes for venomous snakes, bees, and scorpions.

When one has recovered for ten days or more, apply *jiǔ* (灸, moxibustion) to several key acupoints to disperse *fēngqì* (风气). Daily, regulate *qi* through supplementation and drainage, and practice massage and *dǎoyǐn* (导引, guided movement). Do not assume health as permanent—always anticipate danger and preempt illness.

Moxibustion must be performed in seclusion, avoiding the presence of deities or spirits. The prohibitions regarding *rénshén* (人神, human-divine interactions) are detailed in Volume Twenty-Nine.

For those engaged in manual labor, administer *zhuǎnxiè* (转泻, purgative) remedies in spring and autumn to prevent *zhòng tiānxíng shíqì* (中天行时气, seasonal pathogenic influences).

**孙真人《备急千金要方》卷之八十二** *(Sun Simiao’s *Essential Prescriptions Worth a Thousand Gold* – Volume Eighty-Two)*
*校正 by 宋朝奉郎守太常少卿充秘阁校理 林亿等* *(Revised by Lin Yi et al., Title Holder of the Secretariat, Minor Minister of the Imperial Sacrifices, during the Song Dynasty)*

**Nurturing the Nature: Massage Methods (Fourth Section)**

**Indian Massage (Brahmin Method)**
Two hands grasp and twist as in hand-washing.
Two hands lightly cross, then flip and press toward the chest.
Two hands grasp and press the *yīn* (腋下, armpit), left and right.
With hands as if drawing a five-stone bow, left and right.
Two hands overlap and press the *yīn*, slowly twisting the body, left and right.
Fists strike forward, left and right.
Fists strike backward—this opens the chest, left and right.
As in stone-splitting, left and right.
Hands strike the back in reverse, left and right.
Hands brace the ground, body curls upward in three lifts.
Hands encircle the head, twisting upward—this draws the ribs.
Seated, lean sideways like a mountain being pushed, left and right.
Seated, legs extended, then one foot pulls forward in an empty sweep, left and right.
Hands push the ground while turning to look back—this is the *Tiger’s Gaze*, left and right.
Standing, twist the body backward in three lifts.
Hands cross sharply; feet stomp on them, left and right.
Standing, feet stamp forward and backward in empty steps, left and right.
Seated, legs extended, use the opposing hand to hook the extended foot at the knee, pressing down, left and right.

These eighteen postures—if practiced daily by the elderly in three sets—will, after a month, dispel a hundred ailments, enable swift movement like galloping horses, restore vitality, prolong life, sharpen appetite, brighten vision, lighten the body, and prevent exhaustion.

**Laozi’s Massage Method**
Two hands press the *yīn*, twisting the body left and right, seven times each.
Two hands pinch and twist the shoulders, left and right, seven times each.
Two hands encircle the head, twisting the waist left and right, seven times each.
Head is pulled left and right, seven times each.
Two hands support the head, lifted three times.
One hand holds the head, the other supports the knee, bent three times, left and right.
One hand supports the head, the other the knee, drawn upward three times, left and right.
Two hands grasp the head downward, stomping three times.
Two hands cross over the head, left and right, three times.
Two hands cross before the heart, pushing and pulling three times.
Two hands cross over the heart, three times.
Wrists bend to draw the ribs, elbows pulled, left and right, three times.
Left and right hands pull forward and backward, three times each.
Arms stretch to draw the neck, left and right, three times.
Hands press the knees backward, elbows pulled, palms covering the knees, left and right, three times.
Hands rub the shoulders from top to bottom, left and right.
Two hands in empty fists strike three times.
Two hands cross, then reverse and twist, seven times each.
Shake the hands outward three times, inward three times, palms reversed three times.
Rub and twist the fingers three times.
Two hands shake backward three times.
Two hands cross in reverse, twisting elbows up and down endlessly—use ten breaths.
Two hands lift upward three times.
Two hands press downward three times.
Two hands cross over the head, left and right, stretching the ribs ten times.
Two fists strike the back, digging along the spine up and down, three times.
*Digging* means scraping.
Two hands grasp in reverse, straightening the spine up and down, three times.
Palms cover the wrists, vibrating inward and outward, three times.
Palms cover, lifting forward, three times.
Palms cover, two hands cross horizontally, three times.
Palms cross horizontally and vertically, then lift, three times.
If hands are cold, strike from top to bottom until warmth returns.
Left foot extended, right hand supports it; left hand presses the foot, lifting from bottom to top, straightening three times.
Right hand presses the foot likewise.
Twist the feet forward and backward, three times each.
Left foot twisted, right foot twisted, three times each.
Twist the feet backward and forward, three times.
Straighten the feet three times.
Twist the *yīn* three times.
Vibrate the feet inward and outward, three times.
If feet are cold, strike until warmth returns.
Twist the *yīn* as desired, stomping the feet three times.
Straighten the feet backward three times.
*Tiger’s Crouch*: Twist the shoulders left and right, three times.
*Push Heaven, Support Earth*: Left and right, three times.
Left and right *Mountain Push, Mountain Carry, Tree Uproot*, three times each.
Arms stretch forward, pressing and extending three times.
Two hands and two knees stretch, three times each.
Feet stretch backward, pressing and extending three times.
Twist the inner and outer spine, three times each.

**Harmonizing Qi Method (Fifth Section)**

**Pengzu said:**
*The Dao lies not in excess.* If one does not dwell on food and clothing, on sounds and colors, on victory or defeat, on right or wrong, on gain or loss, on honor or disgrace—
when the mind is unburdened and the body not overstrained, and this is combined with *dǎoyǐn* and unceasing *xíngqì* (行气, qi-circulation), then longevity may be attained, even immortality of a thousand years.
Though humans cannot be without thought, they must gradually dispel it.

**Pengzu said:**
To harmonize the spirit, guide the *qi*, and nurture the *Dao*, one must seek a secluded chamber, close the door, and rest on a warm bed with a pillow raised two and a half inches.
Lie straight, eyes closed, and retain the breath in the chest and diaphragm. Place a feather on the nose and keep it unmoved for three hundred breaths. Then, hear nothing, see nothing, think of nothing.
Thus, cold and heat cannot invade, wasps and scorpions cannot poison, and life may reach three hundred and sixty years—this is near the *Zhēnrén* (真人, True Person).

**Morning and Evening (旦夕)**
*Danxi* (旦夕) are the times of yin-yang transformation.
At dawn, the first watch, warm *qi* arrives—frequently close the eyes, for the *shàngshēngqì* (上生气, ascending life-qi) has come, called *yángxī* (阳息, yang’s pause) while *yīn* (阴) wanes.
At dusk, after the sun sets, cold *qi* arrives—chilly and sharp, the time to rise from bed and sit or lie down, for the *xiàshēngqì* (下生气, descending life-qi) has come, called *yángxiāo yīnxī* (阳消阴息, yang’s decline and yin’s pause).
The warm *qi* of dawn and the cold *qi* of dusk constantly circulate through heaven and earth, the sun and moon, mountains and rivers, seas and all things—human and beast, grass and wood—endlessly exchanging and transforming without rest.

「Advancing and retreating like the alternating succession of day and night, or the ebb and flow of the sea’s tides at dusk—this is the Dao/Way of heaven and earth’s *xiāoxì* (消息, ebb and flow of *qi*).

Facing south toward noon, extend both hands over the knees, gently pressing and releasing the limbs. Exhale foul *qi* through the mouth, inhale pure *qi* through the nose. For all exhalations, expel the old *qi*—also called *sǐqì* (死气, death-qi); for all inhalations, take in the fresh *qi*—also called *shēngqì* (生气, life-qi). Thus the *Lǎozǐ Jīng* (《老子经》) says: *"The gate of the mysterious female, the root of heaven and earth, soft and enduring as silk—it is the Dao/Way that never grows weary."* It speaks of how the mouth and nose, the gate of heaven and earth, can expel and receive the *qi* of yin-yang, death and life.

After some time, gradually use the hands in left-to-right, upper-to-lower, and front-to-back movements, glaring eyes and gaping mouth, striking teeth and rubbing eyes, pressing the head and tugging the ears, pulling the hair and loosening the waist—all to provoke coughing, exhaling, and vigorous shaking. Repeat each motion twice or once, reverse hands, then raise the legs and shake them upright, counting to eighty-nine or ninety before stopping.

Slowly settle the mind while lying down, practicing *chán guān* (禅观, meditative observation): close the eyes and focus the mind, envisioning the primordial *yuánqì* (元气) of *Tàihé* (太和, Supreme Harmony) in the void, like a canopy of purple clouds, five colors distinct, descending into the pores and gradually ascending to the crown, as if rain clears after a shower and clouds drift into the mountains. It penetrates skin into flesh, reaches bone and marrow, then descends into the abdomen. All four limbs and five viscera receive its nourishment, like water seeping into the earth—if it fully permeates, one hears a *mìmì* (汨汨) sound in the abdomen. With concentrated intent and steadfast thought, unperturbed by external distractions, soon one feels the *yuánqì* reach the *qìhǎi* (气海, Sea of *Qi*), then swiftly the *yǒngquán* (涌泉, Gushing Spring), causing the body to tremble, the feet to curl inward, and even the bed to creak with a *lālā* (拉拉) sound—this is called *yī tōng* (一通, one circulation).

With *yī tōng* (一通), *èr tōng* (二通), up to three or five circulations per day, the body grows joyful, the complexion radiant, the hair moistened, and the senses sharp. One’s appetite improves, *qi* and strength are robust, and all ailments vanish. For five years or a decade, one remains youthful and forgets aging. Achieving a thousand or ten thousand circulations, one is near to attaining immortality.

The human body is empty and void—only *yóuqì* (游气, wandering *qi*) exists within it. When the *qi* is harmonized, no disease arises. If its ebb and flow become disordered, then all illnesses surge forth. Those skilled in cultivation must know how to regulate *qi* first. Regulating *qi* cures all great afflictions—even growing new eyebrows and beard in a hundred days, let alone lesser ailments.

The method of regulating *qi*: between midnight and noon, when *qi* is ascending, one can harmonize it; between noon and midnight, when *qi* is descending, one cannot. When regulating *qi*, lie supine on the bed, with thick, soft bedding and a high pillow so the body is level. Stretch out the hands and feet, grasp the base of the thumbs with both hands, four to five inches from the body, and place the feet four to five inches apart. Repeatedly strike the teeth, drink *yùjīng* (玉浆, Jade Nectar), and draw *qi* from the nose into the abdomen—if it lingers, stop; if it has power, take more. If the *qi* stagnates in the abdomen, exhale it slowly through the mouth, then draw it in gently through the nose. Exhalation follows the earlier method.

Close the mouth and count internally, ensuring the ears hear nothing, lest there be error or confusion. Combine this with the downward pressing of the hands—if one can reach a thousand circulations, immortality is near.

If the sky is overcast with mist, the wind fierce, or the cold intense, do not draw in *qi*—only hold it closed. For those suffering from cold-heat disorders, or about to contract *yōngjū* (痈疽, festering sores), regardless of the time of day, regulate *qi* during the illness’s onset—within one meal’s interval—before symptoms appear. If the ailment does not improve, repeat the method the next day.

For *xīn lěng bìng* (心冷病, cold-heart disease), exhale the *qi* forcefully; for heat disease, blow it out. If the lungs are diseased, exhale with a *xū* (嘘) breath; if the liver, with a *hē* (呵) breath; if the spleen, with a *xī* (唏) breath; if the kidneys, with a *yè* (呬) breath.

At midnight, eighty-one breaths; at the crowing of the rooster, seventy-two; at dawn, sixty-three; at sunrise, fifty-four; at the *chén* hour (7–9 AM), forty-five; at the *wèi* hour (9 AM–11 AM), thirty-six. Before practicing this method, first perform *dǎoyǐn* (导引, guiding and drawing) exercises three hundred and sixty times on both sides.

There are four types of disease: *lěngbì* (冷痹, cold stagnation), *qìjí* (气疾, *qi* disorders), *yěfēng* (邪风, perverse winds), and *rèdú* (热毒, heat-toxins). For any afflicted, regulate *qi* with a tranquil mind—this method will never fail to heal.

All diseases originate from the five viscera. Each viscera has eighty-one kinds of ailments, and cold, heat, wind, and *qi* disorders combine to form four hundred and forty-four diseases. Study their similarities and differences, and master their distinctions.

Diseases of the heart: the body feels cold or hot.
Signs: The heart’s color is red; the afflicted dream of people in red clothing, wielding red blades and torches, coming to frighten them.
Treatment: Use *hū* (呼, exhalation) and *chuī* (吹, blowing) *qi*—exhalation for cold, blowing for heat.

Diseases of the lungs: the chest and back feel full and distended; the limbs are restless and weary.
Signs: The lungs’ color is white; the afflicted delight in dreaming of beautiful men and women, feigning affection and clinging to others, embracing them like kin—parents, siblings, spouses.
Treatment: Exhale with a *xū* (嘘) breath.

Diseases of the liver: melancholy, discontent, sorrowful thoughts, and headache or eye pain.
Signs: The liver’s color is green; the afflicted dream of people in green clothing, holding green blades, or lions, tigers, and wolves coming to terrify them.
Treatment: Exhale with a *hē* (呵) breath.

Diseases of the spleen: the body feels restless with *yóufēng* (游风, wandering wind); pain spreads across the limbs; weariness and agitation ensue.
Signs: The spleen’s color is yellow—akin to earth’s hue; the afflicted dream of children striking them with perverse, twisted stances, or of swirling winds forming into clusters.
Treatment: Exhale with a *xī* (唏) breath.

Diseases of the kidneys: the body feels cold, *yīn* (阴) energy declines, and the face and limbs wither.
Signs: The kidneys’ color is black; the afflicted dream of black-clad figures or beasts, holding blades and torches, coming to frighten them.
Treatment: Exhale with a *yè* (呬) breath.

For cold diseases, use forceful exhalation thirty times, then gentle exhalation ten times.»

**Breathing Methods:**
Inhale through the nose, exhale through the mouth, letting sound follow breath—pronouncing the syllable as you exhale.

For heat diseases, use forceful blowing (*chuī* 吹) fifty times, then gentle blowing ten times.
Blowing should resemble the sound of blowing on an object, making the syllable’s sound and breath align.

For lung diseases, use forceful sighing (*xū* 嘘) thirty times, then gentle sighing ten times.
For liver diseases, use forceful *hē* (呵) thirty times, then gentle *hē* ten times.
For spleen diseases, use forceful *xī* (唏) thirty times, then gentle *xī* ten times.
For kidney diseases, use forceful *yàn* (咽) fifty times, then gentle *yè* (呬) thirty times.

These twelve methods of regulating *qi* must be practiced with reverence and care if one is ill—no ailment shall fail to heal.
All must first be accompanied by three hundred sixty repetitions of *daoyin* (导引) before application.

**Section on Nourishment and Dietary Therapy (Sixth Treatise):**
The text states:
In spring, one should take *Xiǎo Xùmìng Tang* (小续命汤) for five doses, along with various supplementary powders, each for one dose.
In summer’s intense heat, take *Shèn Lì Tang* (肾沥汤) for three doses.
In autumn, take *Huángqí* (黄耆) pills for one or two doses.
In winter, take medicinal wine for two or three doses. Cease upon the start of spring.

If this regimen is followed lifelong, all diseases shall never arise.

The common folk see only the lethal *gōuwěi* (钩吻) but do not trust *huángjīng* (黄精) in prolonging life.
They know only the five grains to sate hunger but do not recognize how a hundred herbs may save life.
They understand only laxatives for conception but cannot grasp how to preserve and nourish through restraint.

Thus, there are methods for nourishing with medicines.

**Idiom of Caution:**
When taking medicines, one must align with one’s innate nature and discern what suits cold or warmth.
Do not merely take what others use because it is potent.
Begin with herbal and plant medicines, then proceed to minerals—this is the broad principle of preparatory medicine.
This is the method of gradual refinement, from coarse to pure.

From youth to age, the body grows accustomed to the five grains; one cannot suddenly abandon them entirely.
Though medicines take time to show benefit, they do not immediately fill hunger. Yet, over years, they gradually solidify the bones and marrow, and the five grains may then be naturally reduced.
Nowadays, people seek immediate results, expecting swift responses. Before the organs are fortified, they abandon grains entirely, and though grain’s influence fades, the medicine has yet to take effect.
Again, they indulge in licentiousness, their form and spirit no different from the vulgar—thus, they bring ruin upon themselves. How strange!

The principles of nourishment with medicines must follow a strict order. Those who do not know this art not only harm their *yáng* (交) but also fail to harness its power.
Thus, the great method of nourishment requires first eliminating the three worms.

Once the three worms are gone, proceed to herbal medicines, then to wooden (bark/resin) medicines, and finally to mineral medicines.
Following this order allows the medicine’s nature to unfold fully, ensuring stability and longevity.

**Formula to Eliminate the Three Worms:**
Take three *dòu* (斗) of fresh *Rehmannia glutinosa* (生地黄) juice, simmered over east-facing stove reeds until three boilings occur. Add two *shāng* (升) of raw lacquer, stirring with a刑匕 (*xíngbì*) spoon, moving one *chǐ* (尺) daily.
Add three *liǎng* (两) of true cinnabar (*zhēndān* 真丹), then move another *chǐ*.
Add three *shāng* of pumpkin seed powder (*guāzǐ* 瓜子), then move another *chǐ*.
Add three *liǎng* of rhubarb powder (*dàhuáng* 大黄), simmering gently without burning. When formable, make pills the size of *wúzǐ* (梧子). Take one pill before meals, three times daily.
The turbid blood will discharge from the nose; in thirty days, all worms will expel. In fifty days, all diseases will heal, and the complexion will glow.

**Alternative Formula:**
Two *shāng* of lacquer,
Six *liǎng* of rhubarb, powdered,
One and a half *shāng* of wine,
Three *shāng* of *wújīngzi* (芜菁子, *isatis tinctoria* seeds), powdered.
Combine and simmer gently until pillable, forming *wúzǐ*-sized pills. Take three before meals.
In ten days, turbid blood will discharge from the nose; in thirty days, the worms will rot and expel. In fifty days, the body will glow, and mobility will rival a galloping horse, with stable *xiāoxī* (消息, ebb-and-flow) in the limbs—only then may one proceed to herbal medicines.
Other methods are detailed in the *Three Worms Treatise*, found in Volume Eighteen.

**Formula for *Tiānmén Dōng* (天门冬):**
Dry *Asparagus cochinchinensis* (*Tiānmén Dōng*) in the sun, pulverize, and sift.
Take one *fāngcùn* (方寸) spoonful after meals, three times daily.
Up to ten doses may be taken; especially beneficial for children. Mixing with pine resin (*sōngzhī* 松脂) or honey improves efficacy. The more, the better.

**Alternative Formula:**
Extract the juice, simmer gently to yield five *dòu*, then add one *dòu* of white honey and two *shāng* of toasted sesame powder (*húmá* 胡麻). Stir continuously without pause until pillable, then extinguish the fire. Mix with *dàdòu huáng* (大豆黄, soybean residue) to form a cake three *cùn* (寸) in diameter, half a *cùn* thick.
Take one cake daily, three times. Benefits appear after one hundred days.
This is the supreme method, encompassing all others.

**Another Method: Fermented Wine**
(Note: Original text references a formula in Volume Fourteen, omitted here.)

**Master Jiè’s Method (近二百岁而少):**
Royal Purple (*Huángfù Lóng* 皇甫隆) once recounted that Master Jiè, nearing two hundred yet youthful, took only *Tiānmén Dōng*—peeled, sliced, and dried—mixed with wine, one *fāngcùn* spoonful daily, three times. This prevents aging and strengthens the middle *qi*, curing all ailments.

*Tiānmén Dōng* grows in high mountain valleys. On Mount Tai, it is called *Yín Yáng Shí* (淫羊藿); on Mount Hē (中岳), *Tiānmén Dōng*; on Mount Háng (西岳), *Guǎn Sōng* (管松); on Mount Hú (南岳), *Bǎibù* (百部); on Mount Hǔ (北岳), *Wúbù Qù* (无不愈); in plains and hills, *Diān Jí* (颠棘).
Though named differently by region, they are one in essence.
The finest grows in northern shaded earth.

**Method of Finely Cut and Sun-Dried *Dìhuáng* (地黄):**
When finely chopped and dried under fierce sunlight, prolonged consumption grants longevity and multiplies vitality a hundredfold. It treats:
- *Xūláo* (虚劳, vacuity exhaustion) and severe injuries,
- Age-related decline, emaciation, and *piāngǔ* (偏枯, hemiplegia),
- *Fēngshī* (风湿, wind-dampness) numbness, *lěngbì* (冷痹, cold paralysis),
- Abdominal masses, malignant sores, carbuncles, and *làijí* (癞疾, leprosy),
- Severe cases where pus consumes the flesh, nasal collapse, and ulceration—
  consumption reveals *pítuō chóngchū* (皮脱虫出, parasitic exit through skin), restoring plump, radiant complexion.

It cures all ailments, including *yīnwěi* (阴痿, impotence), deafness, and dim vision.
Prolonged use darkens gray hair, regrows fallen teeth, extends life, and renders one waterproof.
After 200 days, tranquility replaces ailments; stiffness relaxes, weakness strengthens.
After 300 days, the body lightens; in three years, one outpaces galloping horses.
After six years, chronic abdominal diseases vanish.

**Method of *Dìhuáng* Pill (地黄方):**
Take 50 *jīn* of fresh *Dìhuáng*, pound and strain the juice, clarify, and simmer until halved. Add 5 *shāng* of white honey and 1 *shāng* of date pitch (*zǎozhī*), kneading until cohesive. Form pills as needed.
Daily dose: one pill (size of a chicken egg), three times. Restores luster and plumpness.

**Alternative Method:**
Take 10 *jīn* of finely chopped *Dìhuáng*, steep in 2 *dòu* of refined wine for three nights. Dry in sunlight, re-steep until wine is exhausted.
Combine with 1 *jīn* each of *Gāncǎo* (甘草), *Bājìtiān* (巴戟天), *Hòupò* (厚朴), *Qiánlù* (乾漆), and *Fùpénzǐ* (覆盆子), pulverize and sift. Post-meal, take with wine (1 *fāngcùn* spoon), three times daily. Increase to two spoons for rejuvenation, strength, and longevity.

**Method for Prepared *Dìhuáng* (熟地黄法):**
Harvest *Dìhuáng*, removing fibrous roots, leaves, and fine roots. Pound and strain the juice, soaking fatty soil in it. Steam in a sealed pot (covered with soil/millet to prevent leakage) for one hour, dry, and re-steep. Repeat until juice is exhausted, then dry.
Alternatively, slice and steam for half a day, periodically dousing with wine until saturated. Dry and form honey pills.

---
**Cultivation of *Dìhuáng* (种地黄法):**
Select fertile, loose, yellow-red soil. Plow deeply, especially in winter (reverse-plowing frozen earth is ideal).
Cut large, healthy *Dìhuáng* roots into 4–12 *fēn* segments (1 *hú* yields 1 *mǔ*). Plant in ridges spaced 1 *chǐ* apart in early spring. Weed and mound soil as it grows.
Harvest in September–October when leaves wilt. One *mǔ* yields ~20 *hú*.
Select thick roots, wash in cold water, trim fine roots, and dry thoroughly. Slice into 1-*cùn* pieces, steam in white grass-lined baskets (or sealed bags with soil) from dawn to dusk until pitch-black. If incomplete, repeat.
For pre-chopped roots, strain juice in copper pots into a thick syrup. Mix with *Dìhuáng* juice, dry, and repeat until juice is exhausted. Yield: ~1–2 *jīn* per 100 *jīn* fresh.
Harvest in August–September (avoid overripe roots). Steam with wine-sprayed layers for optimal juice extraction.

---
**Yellow Precocious (*Huángjīng*) Paste (黄精膏方):**
Take 1 *dàn* of *Huángjīng*, remove fibrous husks, wash clean, and chop. Steam until tender, press for juice, and boil off impurities to yield 1 *dòu*.
Add 3 *liǎng* of powdered *Gānjiāng* (乾姜) and 1 *liǎng* of *Guìxīn* (桂心), simmering until golden-brown. Cool, store in a dry vessel, and mix with 5 *hé* of wine. Take 2 *hé* pre-meal, twice daily.
Restores aged skin, brightens complexion, and renews hair color.
For prolonged use, mix with *Dàdòu* (大豆) powder and abstain from grains—no hunger or thirst, achieving immortality.

---
**Method of *Wūmá* (乌麻) Consumption:**
Take black-skinned *Wūmá* (真檀色), dampen with water (not soaking), steam until permeated, then dry. Repeat nine steams and poundings, removing outer skin. Pre-meal, take with water or wine (2 *fāngcùn* spoons), three times daily.
Gradually eliminates hunger; abstinence from grains prevents all diseases, extending life indefinitely.

---
**Method of *Bǎizǐ* (柏子) Consumption:**
Take 2 *shāng* of *Bǎizǐ* (柏子仁), pulverize, and steep in 4 *shāng* of refined wine until paste-like. Add 2 *shāng* of white honey and 3 *shāng* of date pitch, kneading into pills. Incorporate 1 *shāng* each of powdered *Qián Dìhuáng* (乾地黄) and *Báizhú* (白朮). Form pills the size of *wútóng* seeds (梧子). Take 30 pills, twice daily.
All ailments vanish in twenty days.

---
**Method of *Sōngzǐ* (松子) Consumption:**
Harvest on the 7th day of the 7th month (later yields fall). Take 1 *fāngcùn* spoon, three to four times daily (or 3 *hé* per dose).
After 100 days, the body lightens; after 200 days, one walks 500 *lǐ* daily. Abstain from grains to ascend as an immortal.
Quench thirst with water or mix with fat for consumption.
If pill-form, size of *wútóng* seeds; take 10 pills.

---
**Method of *Sōngzhī* (松脂) Consumption:**
Refine *Sōngzhī* (松脂) nine times, sift, and mix with honey in a sealed container (prevent wind exposure). Take one piece (size of a *bóqí* checker, 2 *cùn* long, 1 *cùn* wide), three times daily. Gradually increase to 1 *jīn* monthly.
Eliminates hunger and extends life.
Alternatively, mix with refined wine and honey into a syrup; take 1–2 *liǎng* to half a *jīn* daily.

**On the Selection and Consumption of *Sōngzhī* (松脂):**
The finest *Sōngzhī* (松脂) is taken from the resinous clusters beneath the bark of aged pine trees. Where the roots are injured or broken, hidden from the sun and moon, the collected resin is called *yīnzhī* (阴脂, "shade resin"), which is even superior.

In the East of Hēngshān (衡山), five hundred *lǐ* away, there stands a great pine, its girth thirty to forty *fēn* (围), abundant in resin. Another method: In the fifth month, carve the sunlit side of the pine (twenty-four trees) so that the resin flows downward, yielding half a *shēng* (升) per tree. Alternatively, boil the resin from the old, gnarled roots, which can also be used.

*The *Xiān Jīng* (仙经, "Immortal Scriptures") states:* If one habitually enters Hēngshān’s shade in the third month, collects the resin from pines unseen by the sun and moon, refines it, and consumes it, the immortals will come without being summoned. After one hundred days of consumption, one endures cold and heat; after two hundred days, the five *zàng* (五脏, "visceral organs") are nourished. After five years, one will see the Queen Mother of the West (*Xī Wángmǔ*, 西王母).

*The *Xiān Jīng* (仙经) further states:* Among the three hundred sixty-five mountains where stones bear fruit, only the resin from the shade of the pine in the *Mǎngǔ Yīn Huái* (满谷阴怀, "Resinous Valley of Concealment") is edible. This valley lies four hundred eighty *lǐ* east of Hēngshān’s ridge, then turns southward; after crossing its southern border and entering the valley fifty *lǐ*, one finds a stone city where white cranes dwell. To the east is a great rock forty *zhàng* (丈) high, resembling a white pine. Beneath it, two *zhàng* down, is a small cave; further east in the mountain is cinnabar (*dānshā*, 丹砂), which can be eaten. To the south, in the shaded depths, stands a massive pine, thirty *fēn* (围) in girth, with thirty trees hidden from the sun and moon—all suitable for collection and consumption.

**Method of Collecting *Sōngzhī* (松脂):**
At sunset, break the shaded side to extract its *gāo* (膏, "resinous sap"), and the sunlit side to extract its *zhī* (脂, "resin"). Divide the sap and resin equally; consuming them harmonizes one’s *shénlíng* (神灵, "spiritual essence").

Carve holes into the shaded and sunlit sides, each five *cùn* (寸) square and five *cùn* deep. Cover the holes with bark to prevent wind entry—for if wind enters, the resin becomes unusable. Collect the resin in spring and summer, then seal the holes tightly; coat them with mud to preserve their *qì* (气, "vital energy").

In the *Dānshā* (丹砂) Cave to the northeast, there is a shaded spring whose water can be drunk. This is where the *Hóngnóng Chē Jūn* (弘农车君) of the *Yuánfēng* (元封) era entered the mountain to consume *Sōngzhī*. After sixteen years, he descended to dwell in the eastern market of Cháng’ān (长安), often traveling to the *Qín Lǐng* (秦岭) via the *Shànggǔ Niútóu* (上谷牛头) Valley. Even in old age, he remained as vigorous as a man of thirty.

**Method of Refining *Sōngzhī* (松脂):**
Take seven *jīn* (斤) of pine resin and one *dàn* (石) of mulberry ash liquid. Boil the resin three times, then immerse it in cold water to congeal. Repeat the boiling process ten times in total; when the resin turns white, it is ready for consumption.

The valley now lies within the boundary of *Yōu Xiàn* (攸县), southeast of *Hēngzhōu* (衡州). This pine resin differs from that of the rest of the world.

**Method of Consuming *Fúlíng* (茯苓) with *Jià* (饵, "as tonic"):**
Take ten *jīn* of *fúlíng* (茯苓, "Poria"), remove its skin, steep in wine, seal tightly in a container, and store for eleven days. Remove, then consume in pieces the size of a *bóqí* checker, three times daily. Alternatively, take as powdered *fāngcùn* spoonfuls. Before consuming *fúlíng*, boil it four or five times in water, or steep it in water for six or seven days.

**Method of *Fúlíng* (茯苓) *Sū* (酥, "congealed resin"):**
Take five *jīn* of *fúlíng* (茯苓), boil in ash liquid once, then in *jiāngshuǐ* (浆水, "mucilaginous water") ten times, and in clear water ten times.
Take five *jīn* of pine resin (*Sōngzhī*), boil as above, but forty times per batch.
Take three *jīn* of white honey (*báimì*, 白蜜), simmer until all foam is gone.
Take five *jīn* of fresh *Tiānmén Dōng* (天门冬, "Asparagus root"), remove its heart and skin, dry in the sun, and pulverize.
Take three *jīn* each of beeswax (*là*, 蜡) and cow fat (*niú sū*, 牛酥), refined three times.

Combine these six ingredients, grind and sift each, then place them in a copper vessel over boiling water (*chóngtāng*, 重汤). First add the cow fat, then the beeswax, then the honey. When the mixture dissolves, stir continuously without pause, ensuring thorough blending. Transfer to a ceramic container, seal tightly, and prevent any leakage of *qì* (气).

The day before consumption, abstain from food. If fasting, first eat sumptuous, filling meals until satiated, then fast. Begin with two *liǎng* (两), then after twenty days, increase to four *liǎng*; after another twenty days, eight *liǎng*. Make the pills fine, and swallow them until they reach the lower throat. In the second phase, start with four *liǎng*, then after twenty days, eight *liǎng*; after another twenty days, two *liǎng*. In the third phase, begin with eight *liǎng*, then after twenty days, two *liǎng*; after another twenty days, four *liǎng*. Complete the process in one hundred eighty days. Afterward, take three pills daily for nourishment—whether or not one continues the regimen. Always dissolve the pills in cow fat and honey, and consume them with a *shēng* (升) of fine wine for optimal effect.

The mixture must be prepared on days corresponding to the *Sìshí Wángxiàng* (四时王相, "Four Seasons' Celestial Harmonies"), strictly avoiding days of *xíngshā* (刑杀, "punishment and slaughter"), *yàn* (厌, "taboo"), or the *Sìjī* (四激, "Four Forbidden")—these are days of great misfortune. This is the method of *Péngzǔ* (彭祖).

**Method of *Fúlíng* (茯苓) *Gāo* (膏, "congealed resin paste")** (*as recorded in the *Qiān Jīn Yì* (千金翼, "Wing of the Thousand Gold")*):
Remove the skin of *fúlíng* (茯苓) while cold.
Take twenty-four *jīn* of pine resin (*Sōngzhī*).
Take twelve *jīn* each of pine nut kernels (*Sōngzǐ Rén*, 松子仁) and cypress nut kernels (*Bǎizǐ Rén*, 柏子仁).

Refine all four ingredients as per their respective methods—pine and cypress kernels require no refining. Grind and sift them. Add twenty-four *shēng* (升) of white honey (*báimì*) to a copper vessel, and place it over boiling water (*chóngtāng*). Simmer gently with low fire for one day and one night. Add the ingredients in sequence, stirring until fully integrated. Continue simmering over low fire for seven days and seven nights, then form into pills the size of small dates. Take seven pills per dose, three times daily.

If one wishes to abstain from grains (*jué gǔ*), consume a full dose at once, and one will achieve a lightened body, clear vision, and eternal youth. This method is later found in some editions with additional *Fúlíng Sū* (茯苓酥), *Yǎo Rén Sū* (杳仁酥), and *Dìhuáng Sū* (地黄酥) recipes, though these are absent from the original texts. The *Qiān Jīn Yì* already contains them, so they are omitted here.

**Method of Consuming *Gǒuqǐ* (枸杞) Root:**
For cultivating *Virtue/Power* (*yǎngxìng*, 养性) and extending longevity (*xiálíng*, 遐龄).
Cut one *dàn* (石) of *gǒuqǐ* root, boil in twelve *dòu* (斗) of water (total one *dàn* of water). Reduce to six *dòu*, clarify, and simmer until three *shēng* (升) remain. Take one *dòu* of clean, dry small wheat (*xiǎomài*), steep in the juice overnight, dry in the sun twice, and repeat until the juice is fully absorbed. Dry completely, pulverize, and consume with wine in *fāngcùn* spoonfuls, twice daily. Prepare two doses in the second and eighth months annually, and one will never age throughout life.

**Method of *Gǒuqǐ* (枸杞) Wine:**
Take one hundred twenty *jīn* of *gǒuqǐ* root, cut, and boil in four *dàn* (石) of water from the *Dōngliú* (东流) River for one day and one night. Extract one *dàn* of clear juice, then steep it in *qū* (曲, "fermented grains") as in the household method of brewing wine.

「Take the clarified liquid and store it in a dry, non-leaking vessel. Add two *cāng* (斤) and a half of prepared *Rehmannia glutinosa* (*dìhuáng*), powdered *Cinnamomum cassia* bark (*guìxīn*), dried ginger (*gānjiāng*), *Alisma orientalis* (*zéxiè*), and *Sichuan peppercorn* (*shùjiāo*), each one *shēng* (升), and two *shēng* of powdered *Pachyrhizus erosus* (*shānglù*). Place these in a silk pouch, immerse it in the wine, seal tightly, and bury it three *chǐ* (尺) underground, covering the top securely.

After three *qī* (七) days, bathe, dress formally, and bow twice. At dawn on a *jiǎyín* (甲寅) day when the sun rises in the east, open the vessel. The wine will be red as gold.

Take half a *shēng* on an empty stomach in the morning. Within ten days, all ailments will be cured; within thirty days, scars will vanish.

For severe illnesses, mix one *shēng* of water with half a *shēng* of wine, and divide into five doses.

From *Thousand Gold Prescriptions* (*Qiān Jīn Yì*): If one wishes to consume stone, take two *shēng* of green-white river stones the size of dates or apricots, boil in three *shēng* of water until it reaches a single boil, then add half a *gē* (合) of this wine. The stone will soften in moments and can be eaten.

**Recipe for *Mica* (*Yúnmǔ*) Water to Cure All Illnesses:**

Take twenty *jīn* of high-grade white mica (*shàngbái yúnmǔ*), slice thinly, and wash it twice with eight *dòu* of dew water, dividing the process equally. Then, take two *dòu* of water to make a decoction, add ten *jīn* of *miáoliú* (芒硝, *mirabilite*), and steep the mica in wooden vessels for twenty days.

Place the mica in a silk pouch, hang it indoors where it is sheltered from wind and sun, and let it dry. Use water-soaked deerhide as a pouch, knead and press it until noon. Then, sift through fine silk to remove impurities, knead and press again until five *dòu* of fine powder are obtained. Discard the remainder.

Take one *dòu* of the powder, mix in two *jīn* of raw honey (*yáimì*), and stir until it resembles porridge. Place this mixture in a hollow bamboo tube, thinly coat the inside, seal the mouth with lacquer, and bury it six *chǐ* underground beneath the southern slope of a northern wall. In spring and summer, leave it buried for forty days; in autumn and winter, for thirty days. If the mixture remains unabsorbed, rebury it for another thirty days before retrieving it.

First, take one *gē* of water, mix in one *gē* of the medicine, and stir thoroughly before consuming, three times daily. Adjust the water temperature as needed. After ten days, the urine will turn yellow—this initially treats *láoqì* (labored *qi*), wind rashes (*fēngzhěn*), and similar ailments. By twenty days, internal cold and dampness will dissipate; by thirty days, decayed teeth will fall out, and new ones will grow.

After forty days, one will fear neither wind nor cold;
by fifty days, all ailments will be cured, complexion will brighten daily, and one attains longevity as an immortal sage.
This I have witnessed with my own eyes, hence I record it.

**Method for Refining Bell’s Milk Powder:**
Take one *jīn* of Bell’s milk (*zhōngrǔ*), regardless of thickness—only use the purest, whitest, and most luminous. If it does not meet these standards, it is unusable.
First, prepare an iron pot capable of holding four or five *dòu* of water as a furnace. Fill it with water, leaving three *cùn* of space at the top. Place the milk in a gold, silver, or glazed ceramic container—any vessel that can withstand use—then lower it into the pot so that the water submerges the container by over one *cùn*. Ensure it remains submerged; do not let it rise above the water.
Apply gentle heat continuously, day and night, without interruption. When the water nears depletion, replenish it with warm water. Every *zhōu* (two-hour period), remove the pot and wash both it and the milk. After seven days and seven nights, retrieve the milk, strain and dry it thoroughly, then place it in a ceramic mortar. Secure it with a jade pestle and grind it with a minimal amount of water for one day and night. Stir vigorously until the mixture becomes highly turbid, then let it settle and extract the turbid liquid. The coarser particles of milk will naturally sink to the bottom; the finer powder will remain suspended in the water. Strain out the coarse sediment, then regrind it according to the previous method. Repeat this process for five days and five nights until the milk is finely powdered. After decanting and drying the refined powder, grind it again in a silver mortar for one day. The ideal result is when it no longer dissolves in meat broth upon washing.

**Bell’s Milk Powder Decoction:**
For treating *xūlěi* (deficiency and emaciation), weakness in those over sixty, or general debility where one cannot eat—**Universal Remedy for a Hundred Ailments**—
*Shàngdàng* ginseng (3 *fèn*)
*Shíhé* (3 *fèn*)
Dried ginger (3 *fèn*)
Refined Bell’s milk powder (3 *liǎng*)

Combine the first three ingredients, grind them into a powder, and sift. Mix them evenly with the milk powder, dividing the total into nine doses. Take one dose in warm, diluted wine on an empty stomach in the morning, one at noon, and one in the evening.

After three days, continue this regimen. In total, for the duration of this medicine, limit intake to one and a half *shēng* of rice and one *shēng* of meat per three days. The meat and rice must be thoroughly cooked; avoid raw onions or fermented soybeans (*pǐ*).

**Question:** Why must one eat sparingly for three days and avoid overeating?
**Answer:** For three nights, the milk nourishes and supplements the viscera. If one overeats, the medicine will be expelled from the stomach, hence the restriction on full meals.

**Question:** Why must one not eat raw foods?
**Answer:** Consuming raw foods diminishes the medicine’s efficacy. Once the medicine’s power is weakened, the body’s fat and vitality are also impaired, hence the prohibition on raw foods.

**Question:** Why must one avoid onions and fermented soybeans?
**Answer:** Onions and fermented soybeans counteract the medicine, hence their exclusion.

After exhausting the three-day course of medicine, take three days to recover with broth-based meals as desired, but still avoid onions, fermented soybeans, and hard-to-digest foods. Once recovery is complete, resume the medicine as before until the entire *jīn* of milk is consumed. The resulting *qi* and vitality will become evident—though I cannot fully describe their effects.

Once mastered, this method can be scaled: ten *jīn*, twenty *jīn*, or as much as one wishes, with adjustments as needed.

**West Peak Sage’s *Língfēi* Powder:**
*Yúnmù* powder (1 *jīn*)
*Púfú* (8 *liǎng*)
Refined Bell’s milk powder
*Bózi* (cyperus seed) (7 *liǎng*)
Ginseng (*from Thousand-Gold Wings*) (7 *liǎng*)
*Xùduàn* (7 *liǎng*)
*Guìxīn* (7 *liǎng*)
Chrysanthemum (15 *liǎng*)
Dried *Dìhuáng* (12 *liǎng*)

Grind the nine ingredients into a powder. Take nineteen *jīn* of fresh *Tiānménwū* (asparagus tuber), extract its juice, and steep the powder in it. Place the mixture in a copper vessel and steam it with one *shí* and two *dòu* of glutinous rice. Once the rice is cooked, dry and grind it into a powder. Take one square *chǐ* dose daily with warm water.

After three days, strength doubles;
after five days, blood and vessels are fully replenished.

On the seventh day, the body feels light;
on the tenth day, the complexion glows with radiance;
by the fifteenth day, one can run as swiftly as galloping horses;
by the thirtieth day, night vision shines with light;
by the seventieth day, all white hair falls out, and the old teeth are shed.

Further, take twenty-one *chǐ* of white honey, pound it together with the powder in two hundred *zhú* (mortar strokes), and form pills the size of *tóngzi* (Chinese catalpa seeds)—eighty-one in total. Dry them in the sun, and the pills will gleam translucent as *shuǐjīng zhū* (crystal beads).

For those wishing to restore their hair and teeth, swallow seven pills daily, three times a day. Once taken, if the hair has not yet turned white and the teeth have not yet fallen out, simply consume the remaining **#14** (seventy-four pills), and after **#15** (three hundred) years, they will turn white as described. For those already white-haired, taking the medicine for seven hundred years will cause the teeth to fall out.

When entering the mountains, swallow seven pills daily and abstain from grains without feeling hunger.

Since obtaining this formula, I have nearly surpassed three *jì* (decades). Recently, my complexion has grown ever more beautiful and radiant, though I hesitated, doubting its efficacy. Over the years, I inquired extensively and found many renowned figures who, after taking this, experienced its power. Thus, I followed the method as prescribed.

But if one persists in practicing it without ceasing, the benefits will not be in vain.

—Recorded by the Sage Sun in *The Essential Prescriptions Worth a Thousand Gold for Emergency Use*, Volume Eighty-Two.

The **Sage Sun’s** *Essential Prescriptions Worth a Thousand Gold for Emergency Use*, Volume Eighty-Three:

**#1□** (originally 『胫』, *jìng*—*tibia*): **#2** (originally 『之』, *zhī*—*it/them*) **#3** (originally 『开』, *kāi*—*open*): **#4** (originally 『用』, *yòng*—*employ*) **#5** (originally 『间』, *jiān*—*interval*) **#6** (originally 『口』, *kǒu*—*mouth*) **#7** (originally 『上』, *shàng*—*above*) **#8** (originally 『二』, *èr*—*two*) **#9** (originally omitted, restored as 『治法』, *zhìfǎ*—*method of treatment*): **#10** (originally 『以』, *yǐ*—*with*) **#11** (originally 『之』, *zhī*—*it/them*) **#12** (originally 『上』, *shàng*—*above*) **#13** (originally 『清』, *qīng*—*clear/clean*) **#14** (originally 『散』, *sǎn*—*scatter*) **#15** (originally 『五』, *wǔ*—*five*) **#16** (originally 『顷者但』, *qǐngzhědàn*—*recently only*)

Recorded by **Sage Sun**, verified by **Lín Yì** and others of the **Secret Hall** (校理, *jiàolǐ*), holding the titles **Minister of Ceremonies** (守太常少卿, *Shǒu Tàicháng Shàoqīng*) and **Chief of the Imperial Library** (充秘阁校理, *Chōng Mìgé Jiàolǐ*), under the **Song Dynasty**.

**Nurturing the Nature (养性)**
The **Yellow Emperor’s Miscellaneous Prohibitions** (黄帝杂忌法), **Section Seven (第七)**

Upon waking, do not open your eyes or wash your face—this causes **dullness of vision (目涩)**, loss of sight (**失明**), and excessive tears (**饶泪**).
At dawn, speak only of virtuous deeds (**善事**), avoiding wicked words (**恶言**). If you hear of wickedness, spit three times in the direction from which it came—this brings **auspiciousness (吉)**.
Do not harbor anger (**嗔怒**), nor shout or bellow (**叱咤咄呼**), nor sigh or lament (**嗟叹**), nor sing or wail (**唱**). To do so invites **disaster (请祸)**.

Do not stand with knees crossed, nor sit with arms crossed over your knees, nor let your hair cover your face—all these are **inauspicious (不祥)**.
Do not raise your foot toward fire, nor curse **Jìn (晋)** while facing the stove.

In all your movements—walking, standing, or sitting—do not turn your back to the sun (**日**), for this is **auspicious (吉)**.
Do not sit facing north (**北**) and ponder deeply—this leads to **inauspicious consequences (不祥起)**.

Whenever you set out, keep the **Arca Major (魁纲)** above your head—all directions will be **auspicious (吉)**.
If you intend to wage battle, hold the **handle of the Big Dipper (斗柄)** before you and point it at the enemy—this brings **auspiciousness (吉)**.
Do not wear your **headgear (冠带)** while facing north—this is **ominous (凶)**.
Do not spit toward the **west-north (西北)**, for this offends the **Arca Major (魁纲)**—**ominous (凶)**.
Do not cough or spit forcefully—spittle should not be cast far, lest it cause **lung disease (肺病)**, heaviness in the limbs (**手足重**), back pain (**背痛**), or coughing (**咳嗽**).
Nor should you urinate or defecate toward the **west-north (西北)**.

Do not kill **turtles or snakes (龟蛇)**.
Do not gaze angrily at the sun or moon (**日月**)—this may cause those who see it to lose their sight (**失明**).
When traveling or riding a horse, do not look back—this allows your **spirit (神)** to depart, leaving you vulnerable to **ghostly afflictions (鬼行踖粟)**.

When passing by a **sacred temple (神庙)**, be cautious not to enter hastily. If you enter, do so with **reverence (恭敬)**, without gazing about freely (**举目恣意顾瞻**). Treat it as you would a **stern sovereign (严君)**, for only then will you receive its blessings (**福**). Otherwise, you will swiftly invite its calamities (**祸**).
Nor should you turn your head to look back at the temple (**返首顾视神庙**).

If you suddenly see a **dragon or snake (龙蛇)**, do not let it arouse fear or curiosity (**兴心惊怪**). Do not stare intently (**注意瞻视**).
If you encounter **ghostly apparitions or strange transformations (鬼怪变异之物)**, suppress your reaction and do not be alarmed—recite the charm:
*"Seeing the strange without fear, the strange itself will decay (见怪不怪，其怪自坏)."*

If you encounter a **remarkably beautiful woman (殊妙美女)** while traveling or in a crowd, beware not to gaze upon her with **longing (熟视而爱之)**. Such beings are **arcs or spirits (魑魅)**, causing deep attachment (**深爱**). Whether in **remote mountains or open fields (空山旷野)** or among **dense crowds in broad places (稠人广众)**, they act the same.

Wherever there are **sandy gnats (沙虱)** in mountains or waters, do not bathe there—it harms the person (**害人**).
If you wish to cross a river, follow behind a **donkey or horse (驴马)** and cross swiftly—this avoids harm (**不伤人**).
Where **water arrows (水弩)** lurk, shooting a person’s shadow results in death (**射人影即死**). If you wish to cross such waters, strike the surface with an object—this causes the **water arrows to scatter (其弩即散)**—and cross quickly to avoid harm (**急渡不伤**).

In all **mountains with caves or holes (孔穴)**, those who enter to gather treasures (**采宝**) must do so only in the **third or ninth month (三月九月)**. In other months, the **mountains close, and conflicting *qi* (气交犯)** leads to death (**死**).

When **hungry or empty-stomached (空腹)**, do not look upon a corpse (**尸**). If **foul *qi* (臭气)** enters your nose, a **white coating (白)** will appear on your tongue, and your breath will always be foul (**口常臭**). If you must see a corpse, first drink alcohol (**饮酒**) to ward off **poisonous and malevolent influences (毒凶#1)**.

If you touch **heat (热)**, or if you encounter a river along the way, do not wash your face—this causes **wild hair (乌野)**.

**Chamber Arts: Supplementary Methods (房中补益), Section Eight (第八)**.

「The Treatise states: Those under the age of forty often indulge in excess; once past forty, one suddenly perceives that the **Dao/Way** and **qi** have weakened. Once this decline sets in, myriad ailments arise. If left untreated for long, they become incurable. Hence, the Master Pengzu said: *"To cure a man with a man is to attain the true essence of truth."* Therefore, upon reaching forty, one must understand the **Chamber Arts (房中)****.

The **Chamber Arts (房中)** are a **Dao/Way** close at hand, yet few can practice it. Its method—consummating with ten women in a single night, sealing and preserving with utmost care—exhausts the **Chamber Arts (房中)****. Combined with medicinal tonics, if one never ceases in all four seasons, the **Dao/Way** and **qi** will be multiplied a hundredfold, and wisdom will renew itself daily. Yet, this technique is not devised to gratify lustful desires or seek fleeting pleasure, nor to indulge in **female charms (女色)** for emotional release. Its intent is to **nourish life (补益)** and dispel illness. This is the subtle essence of the **Chamber Arts (房中)****.

Thus, those under forty who take **Chamber Arts (房中)** tonics do so to hasten their misfortune—be cautious, be cautious! Therefore, one should not discuss the **Chamber Arts (房中)** with those not yet forty. If their **desire (欲心)** persists and they take both tonics and supplements, their **qi** and vitality will be depleted twice as fast, and within half a year, their **essence (精)** and **marrow (髓)** will be exhausted, bringing them near to death. Youth must be especially vigilant.

Once past forty, if one constantly **preserves the essence (固精)** and **nourishes the qi (养气)**, without depletion, they may avoid aging. Moreover, consuming **cloud mother (云母)** can cure ailments and prolong life. Those past forty must not take **purgative medicines (泻药)****, but should instead consistently consume **tonics (补药)**—this is most excellent.

In antiquity, the Yellow Emperor consummated with twelve hundred women and ascended to the **Dao/Way (仙)****, yet common folk perish from a single union. How vast is the difference between those who know and those who do not! For those who grasp the **Dao/Way (道)****, the number of unions is not excessive. Any woman, regardless of beauty, suffices if they are young, unchilded, have ample flesh, and are vigorous.

If one possesses sufficient wealth, they should select women with fine, black-and-white distinct hair, clear eyes, supple bodies, soft bones, smooth and delicate skin, harmonious voices, and limbs where the flesh is plentiful yet the bones are not too large. Their armpits and bodies should have no coarse hair; if present, it must be soft and fine. Avoid those with:
- **Disheveled hair and filthy faces (蓬头蝇面)**,
- **Thick necks and swollen throats (槌项结喉)***,
- **Deep voices and gaping mouths (雄声大口)***,
- **Prominent noses and uneven teeth (高鼻麦齿)***,
- **Clouded eyes (目精浑浊)***,
- **Coarse hair in the mouth or chin (口颔有毫)***,
- **Tall bones and joints (骨节高大)***,
- **Yellow hair and scant flesh (发黄少肉)***,
- **Rough, dense, and strong hair (隐毫多而且强)***,
- **Or hair growing in reverse (逆毫)***.

These traits are detrimental to life and longevity.

The **Dao/Way (道)** of consummating with women requires that one does not act when their **qi** is unaroused and weak. Instead, one must first **gradually attune and harmonize (徐徐调和)****, ensuring the **spirit (神)** and **intent (意)** are fully engaged. After a prolonged union, one may then draw in **yin qi (阴气)****, which, once received, will naturally strengthen within moments. This is the principle of *"weakly inviting within, forcefully expelling without"*—advancing and retreating must be **spaced and measured (疏迟)****, and one must cease when passion surges. Do not **hurl oneself recklessly (高自投掷)****, lest the five **viscera (脏)** be disordered, the **essence-vessels (精脉)** be severed, and a hundred **ailments (病)** be incurred. Yet, if one engages repeatedly with **diligent restraint (慎密)****, all diseases will be cured, life prolonged, and the **Dao/Way (仙)** near at hand—not necessarily adhering to the numbers nine, one, three, or five. One who can consummate with a hundred women without **depleting the essence (施泻)**** will achieve longevity.

If one consummates with many women, they may **harvest *qi* (采气)****. The **Dao/Way (道)** of **harvesting *qi* (采气)**** is to deeply penetrate without movement, allowing the **qi** to gather and heat above. When the warmth reaches the mouth, one should **align and draw (相当)****, inhaling the woman’s **yin qi (阴气)****. This can be done with **measured advances and retreats (疏疏进退)****, stopping when passion stirs. One should then **breathe softly, close their eyes, and rest (缓息眠目)****, lying down to **guide the *qi* internally (道引)****. Their body will grow stronger, enabling them to consummate with another woman. By frequently changing partners, one gains greater benefit. If one remains with a single woman, their **yin qi (阴气)** weakens, and the benefit is diminished.

The **yang Dao/Way (阳道)** follows the principle of **fire (法火)****, while the **yin realm (阴家)** follows the principle of **water (法水)****. Water can subdue fire, yet if **yin qi (阴气)** persistently consumes **yang qi (阳气)****, the latter will eventually weaken. The loss will outweigh the gain. If one can consummate with twelve women without **depleting the essence (施泻)****, they will never age and retain beauty. If they consummate with ninety-three women while **preserving the essence (固精)****, they will live a hundred thousand years.

When **essence (精)** is scarce, illness follows; when it is exhausted, death ensues. This must be pondered, this must be guarded against. If one engages repeatedly yet **depletes the essence (一泻)****, their **essence and *qi* (精气)** will grow, though slowly—this cannot prevent **vital exhaustion (虚)****. If one does not engage often but **depletes the essence (即泻)**** upon consummation, they gain no benefit. The **essence and *qi* (精气)** will naturally regenerate, but their growth is sluggish compared to the swiftness of **frequent consummation without depletion (数交接不泻)****.

When one practices **consummation (交合)****, they should **inhale deeply through the nose (鼻多内气)**** and **exhale subtly through the mouth (口微吐气)****. This alone brings benefit. After the union, if one **steams the body with heat (蒸热)****, this confirms the **harvesting of *qi* (得气)****. Using **three parts (三分)** of **glory grass powder (昌蒲末)**** and **one part (一分)** of **white rice powder (白粱粉)****, applied to the body and allowed to dry, will enhance vigor and prevent **moist sores (湿疮)****.

For those who must **deplete the essence (施泻)****, they should **close their mouth and open their eyes (闭口张目)****, **seal their *qi* (闭气)****, and **clench both fists (握固两手)****. Drawing in **qi** through **nose-contraction (缩鼻)****—upward, downward, left, and right—while also **contracting the lower body (缩下部)**** and **inhaling the abdomen (吸腹)****, they should **slightly arch their back (小偃脊膂)****. With their left hand’s middle two fingers, they must **press the Screened Aperture Acupoint (屏翳穴)****. Then, they should **prolonged exhale (长吐气)**** and **grind their teeth a thousand times (琢齿千遍)****, causing the **essence to ascend and nourish the brain (精上补脑)****, thus achieving longevity. If **essence** is **recklessly expelled (精妄出)****, it will **diminish the spirit (损神)****.

The *Scripture of the Dao/Way (仙经)* states: *"To achieve longevity without aging, first play with a woman, then drink **jade nectar (玉浆)***. **Jade nectar (玉浆)*** is the **oral fluid (口中津)***. One should **stimulate mutual arousal (感动)****, using the left hand to grasp, and **meditate on the elixir field (丹田)****, where **red *qi* (赤气)** resides internally—**yellow outside, white within (内黄外白)****, transforming into the **sun and moon (日月)****, revolving within the **elixir field (丹田)****. Both should enter the **muddy wall (泥垣)****, merging into a single **cause (因)****. One must **seal their *qi* deeply (闭气深内)****, allowing no **inhalation or exhalation (出入)****. Instead, they should **swallow *qi* gradually (徐徐咽气)****, rising and falling. When passion stirs and **essence** is about to be expelled, one must **quickly withdraw (急退之)***.»

This is not the practice of the highest sages or the wise—only they can accomplish it.

The **elixir field (丹田)** lies three *cùn* below the navel; the **muddy wall (泥垣)** is within the head, directly inward from between the eyes. Visualize the **sun and moon (日月)** merging into a sphere three *cùn* in diameter, their two halves blending into one—this is the union of the **sun and moon (日月)**. Even as they move in and out, one must persist in contemplating their form without ceasing—this is ideal.

It is further said: The **Dao/Way (道)** of mutual transcendence for men and women lies in deeply restraining **essence (精)**, meditating on the **red *qi* (赤色)** in the navel, as large as a chicken’s egg. Then, one should gradually inhale and exhale, withdrawing when passion stirs. A daily practice of dozens of repetitions will extend one’s lifespan.

Both partners should calm their minds and focus together, concentrating fiercely. In the method of **copulation (御女)**, if one can release twice in a month, or twenty-four times a year, they will attain two hundred years of life, with youthful vigor and no illness. If **elixir arts (药)** are added, then **longevity (长生)** is possible.

For those aged twenty, release every four days; at thirty, every eight days; at forty, every sixteen days; at fifty, every twenty days; at sixty, **restrain essence (闭精)** and refrain from release. If vitality remains strong, one may release once a month. Though some may naturally possess **qi** and strength beyond others, they must not suppress release for too long, lest **boils and abscesses (痈疽)** arise.

If one is past sixty and has not engaged in intercourse for several *xún*, yet feels no disturbance in mind, they may naturally **seal and restrain (闭固)**.

In the past, during the reign of **Zhèngguān (正观)**, an old villager over seventy years old came to me and said: *"For several days now, my **yang *qi* (阳气)** has grown stronger. I thought my **qi** and blood had already declined—how can this vigor persist? I do not know if this is a blessing or a curse in my old age."* I replied: *"This is an omen of grave misfortune."*

You have not heard of the **wax candle**? When the wax candle is about to burn out, it must first grow dim and then flare up brightly—once the light fades, it is extinguished. Now, your age has reached the **twilight years of life (桑榆)**; you ought to have long since **sealed essence (闭精)** and restrained desire. Yet suddenly, your **spring passion (春情)** surges violently—is this not contrary to nature? I secretly fear for you; take heed! After four *xún*, you fell ill and died. This is the consequence of negligence.

Such cases are not singular. I recount this to warn those who follow.

Those who practice **proper life-nurturing (善摄生)** must, whenever they feel **yang vitality (阳事)** surge, restrain it with caution—never indulge recklessly and exhaust oneself. If you can master it once, then once the **fire is quenched (火灭)**, once more the **oil is replenished (增油)**. But if you cannot restrain yourself, indulging in dissipation, then the **wax candle is nearing its end (膏火将灭)**, and the oil is being consumed—how can you not guard against this with utmost care?

The tragedy is that people in their youth do not know this, and even if they do, they do not believe or act upon it. By the time they grow old and understand, it is too late—the disease is hard to cure. Even if one preserves oneself in old age, one may still prolong life and vitality. But if one practices the **Dao (行道)** in youth and vigor, **immortality (神仙)** comes swiftly.

Someone may ask: *"Before sixty, can one not **seal essence and maintain unity (闭精守一)**?"*

No. A man cannot do without a woman, nor a woman without a man. Without a woman, desire stirs—desire stirred exhausts the **spirit (神)**; the **spirit** exhausted shortens life. If one can truly think of nothingness, that would be ideal—**eternal life (长生)**. Yet this is almost impossible. Forcing suppression and restraint is difficult to maintain and easy to fail, leading to **seminal leakage (漏精)** and **cloudy urine (尿浊)**, even inviting **ghostly intercourse (鬼交)**, harming one’s vitality a hundredfold.

As for **dietary and medicinal regimens (服食药物)**, refer to the separate volumes.

**Methods for consorting with a woman (御女之法)**:
One must avoid **homogeneous days (丙丁日)**, as well as the **new and full moons (弦望)**, **eclipses (晦朔)**, and times of **great wind, great rain, great fog, extreme cold, extreme heat, thunder, lightning, or celestial obscurity (天地晦冥)**. If one consorts during **solar or lunar eclipses (日月薄蚀)**, or under **rainbows (虹霓)**, during **earthquakes (地动)**, or in the presence of **firelight, celestial bodies, temples, or near wells, kitchens, latrines, tombs, or corpses (井灶圊厕、冢墓尸柩)**, it harms the **spirit (神)**, bringing misfortune. It harms the man a hundredfold, causes the woman to fall ill, and if she bears children, they will be **epileptic, deaf, blind, lame, or born with deformities (癫痴顽愚、喑痘聋聩、孪跛盲眇)**, short-lived, and unfilial.

If one consorts **according to the Dao (如法)**, there will be **blessings and virtue (福德)**. Wise and benevolent beings will descend into the womb, refining the parents’ **nature and conduct (性行)**, making their actions harmonious and their household prosperous, with **auspicious omens (祥瑞)** abounding. But if done improperly, there will be **scant blessings, folly, and malevolent spirits** descending into the womb, corrupting the parents’ **nature and conduct**, causing their deeds to fail, their household to decline, and misfortunes to strike repeatedly. Even if they live and grow, their **lineage and nation will perish**.

The responses of **calamity and fortune (祸福)** are as certain as **echoes (影响)**. This is an inevitable truth—how can it be reconsidered?

If one seeks to **beget children (求子)**, then...

But wait—after the woman’s menstruation has ceased, one must choose the first, third, or fifth day thereafter, selecting days that are **Royal and Auspicious Days (王相日)** and when the **lunar mansion (月宿)** aligns with a **Noble Abode (贵宿)**, then performing the **release of vital essence (施泻)** after midnight. If done thus, the child born will be male, long-lived, and endowed with wisdom and high rank.

If the **release of vital essence (施泻)** is performed on the second, fourth, or sixth day after menstruation ceases, the child born will be female.

After the sixth day, one must not perform the **release of vital essence (施泻)**—if done so, not only will no child be conceived, but even if born, the child will not thrive.

Spring: **Jia (甲)** and **Yi (乙)**
Summer: **Bing (丙)** and **Ding (丁)**

—and these coincide with the above **Lunar Mansion Days (月宿日)**, the effect is even more beneficial.

The **Yellow Emperor’s Miscellaneous Prohibitions (黄帝杂禁忌法)** state:
If one is enraged and **vital essence and blood (血气)** remain unsettled, then engaging in intercourse will cause **boils and abscesses (痈疽)**.

One must not engage in intercourse while suppressing the urge to urinate, as this will cause **dysuria (淋)**, pain in the penis, and **pallor of the face (面失血色)**. Additionally, if one enters the chamber after long travel and exhaustion, this is **five types of labor and depletion (五劳虚损)**, leading to few children.

Moreover, if intercourse occurs before a woman’s menstruation has fully ceased, it will cause illness and result in **leukoderma (白驳)**.

One must not bring **mercury (水银)** near the **yin (阴)**, as it will cause **consumption and atrophy (消缩)**.

The fats of **deer and swine (鹿、猪二脂)** must not be brought near the **yin (阴)**, as this will cause **erectile dysfunction (阴痿)**.
