**The *Píngmài* [平脉, "Level/Even Pulse"] Method**

**Section 1: The Great Principle of Even Pulse**
The text states: *"The pulse is the foundation of the medical profession. If one does not deeply investigate its Dao/Way, how can one truly be a physician? Thus, the wise physicians of antiquity, in waking and in sleep, in reverence and in casualness, never acted like ordinary people. Even in haste, they were mindful of medicine; even in adversity, they were mindful of medicine. Therefore, they could resonate with spirits and deities, harmonize with Heaven and Earth, save the masses, and serve as dependable guides. If they were to mix with common folk and lose their focus, all matters would collapse—how could the myriad beings then look up to them?"*

From this, it is clear that students must abandon mundane emotions, concentrate their minds here, and thus the *Hé-Què* [和鹊, "Harmonious Crow"] efficacy will be achieved.

The *Classics* say: *"The method of pulse diagnosis should always be performed at the prime of dawn (平旦, *píngdàn*), when the yin-qi has not yet stirred, the yang-qi has not yet dispersed, no food or drink has been taken, the Jingmai [经脉, "Channel Pulses"] are not yet full, the Luomai [络脉, "Collateral Pulses"] are balanced, and the vital energies (气) and blood are not yet disordered. Only then can one diagnose pulses that deviate from the norm."* The *Pulse Classic* (《脉经》) states: *"Any deviation from this is incorrect."* When diagnosing, one should press the pulse gently (切脉动), then quietly observe its clarity (静而视精明), examine the five colors (察五色), and assess the excess or deficiency of the five Zàng [五脏, "solid organs"] and the strength or weakness of the six Fǔ [六腑, "hollow organs"], as well as the flourishing or decline of the body’s form. These observations should be cross-referenced (参互), determining the fate of life and death.

It further states: *"For diagnosing even pulses (平脉者), all should be done at dawn (平旦). Do not eat or speak; harmonize and adjust the body’s vital energies (消息体气). If any action must be taken, it should be as brief as the time it takes to eat. The physician should follow this rule as well. After establishing the rhythm, first diagnose the Cùnkǒu [寸口, "Wrist Pulse"]. Initially, press firmly with the fingers to reach the bone (初重指切骨), and once the rhythm is set, gradually lift the fingers (便渐举指), ensuring they neither press too thickly nor too lightly (令指不厚不薄), aligning with the skin and fur (与皮毛相得), like the weight of three *sù* beans [三菽]. Between light and firm pressure, adjust according to the patient’s strength, weakness, fatness, or thinness (随人强弱肥瘦), using one’s intent to modulate the pressure (以意消息进退). The pressing and lifting should be appropriate (举按之宜), matching the pulse’s floating or sinking (称其浮沉诸类) and corresponding to the four seasons and five phases (应於四时五行), aligning with the patient’s five Zàng [五脏]. If not, the pulse’s lightness or heaviness will be misjudged (以其轻重相薄), and one may incorrectly diagnose cold or heat, gain or loss (寻状论寒暑得失)."*

The vital energies (气) and pulse (脉) of all people follow the rhythm of day and night, adapting to the four seasons. Yet, even as the pulse’s rise and fall (呼吸) correspond to the five *zhì* [至, "arrivals"] within the regulated breath (定息), there is no deficiency or excess. This is like the sundial’s (晷) varying strokes (刻) across the four seasons, yet the annual tally of days remains complete.

If a person is weak or robust, their breathing may be constrained or forceful, but the degree of their daytime and nighttime breaths will still follow the *lòukè* [漏刻, "water clock strokes"]. This is called *"the pulse’s breathing follows day and night, adapting to the four seasons."* When diagnosing the pulse, one must first use intent to harmonize and adjust (消息), suppress the patient’s breathing to match one’s own (压取病人呼吸以自同), and then observe the pulse’s rhythm (察其脉数), counting it within the regulated breath (计於定息之限). Five *zhì* [至] indicate an even pulse (平人). If there is any contraction or expansion, one should investigate the pulse’s characteristics to determine the appropriate source of the illness (寻状论病源之所宜).

**Question:** What is meant by the *"three divisions of the pulse"* (三部脉)?

**Answer:** The Cùn [寸], Guān [关], and Chǐ [尺].

Since people’s arms vary in length, their forms differ. There is a method to divide the pulse into three parts: from the horizontal crease at the elbow (肘腕中横文) to the web of the hand (掌鱼际后文), measure ten *fēn* [分], then enter six *fēn* inward—this is the Chǐ [尺]. From the web of the hand (鱼际后文), measure ten *fēn* inward—this is the Cùn [寸]. From the ten *fēn* inward, measure six *fēn* inward—this is the Cùnkǒu [寸口]. The bone here is naturally elevated, so it is said that yin-qi reaches one *cùn* inside the Chǐ [尺], and yang-qi reaches nine *fēn* inside the Cùn [寸]. From the Cùnkǒu [寸口], measure six *fēn* inward to reach the Guān [关], and from the Guān [关], measure six *fēn* inward to reach the Chǐ [尺].

It is also said: *"From the web of the hand to the high bone, measure one *cùn* inward—this is the Cùnkǒu [寸口]. From the Cùnkǒu [寸口] to the Chǐ [尺] is named Chǐzé [尺泽], hence the term 'Cùn-Chǐ [尺寸].' The region between the Cùn [寸] and Chǐ [尺] is called the Guān [关], where yang-qi emerges and yin-qi enters, marking the boundary like the three realms of Heaven-Earth-Human (天地人为三界). The Cùn [寸] governs the upper *Jiāo* [焦, "burner"], the head, and the skin and fur, extending to the upper arm (竟手上部); the Guān [关] governs the middle *Jiāo* [焦], the abdomen, and the waist (腹及腰中部); the Chǐ [尺] governs the lower *Jiāo* [焦], from the lower abdomen to the feet (小腹至足下部). This is the method of the three divisions, mirroring the three *Cái* [才, "talents"] of Heaven-Earth-Human, with the head, abdomen, and feet as the three *Yuán* [元, "origins"]."*

**Section 2: Diagnosing the Light and Heavy Pulses of the Five Zàng [Solid Organs]**
The *Classics* state: *"When first holding the pulse, with the pressure like that of three *sù* beans [三菽] and aligning with the skin and fur (与皮毛相得), this corresponds to the Lung (肺部). Metal (金), autumn’s third month, the qi of *Gēng-Xīn* [庚辛]. With the pressure like that of six *sù* beans [六菽] and aligning with the blood vessels (与血脉相得), this corresponds to the Heart (心部). Fire (火), summer’s third month, the qi of *Bǐng-Dīng* [丙丁]. With the pressure like that of nine *sù* beans [九菽] and aligning with the muscles (与肌肉相得), this corresponds to the Spleen (脾部)."*

**Diagnosing the Light and Heavy Pulses of the Five Zàng [Solid Organs] (continued)**

Earth (土), the *Wáng* [王, "sovereign"] of the four seasons, the season of late summer (季夏, *sixth month*), the *qi* of *Wù-Jǐ* [戊己]. With the pressure like that of twelve *sù* beans (十二菽之重) and aligning with the sinews (與筋平), this corresponds to the Liver (肝部).

Wood (木), spring’s third month, the *qi* of *Jiǎ-Yǐ* [甲乙]. When pressed to the bone (按之至骨) and lifted swiftly (舉之來疾), this corresponds to the Kidney (腎部). Water (水), winter’s third month, the *qi* of *Rén-Guǐ* [壬癸].

How does one distinguish when the Heart (心) and Lung (肺) pulses are both floating?
Thus it is taught: When floating and widely dispersed (浮而大散), it is the Heart (心); resembling the *qi* of Fire (火) in its floating and dispersing. When floating and short or rough (浮而短涩), it is the Lung (肺); adhering to the law of Metal (金) in its stinginess and roughness.

How does one distinguish when the Kidney (腎) and Liver (肝) pulses are both sinking?
Thus it is taught: When firm and long (牢而長), it is the Liver (肝); like a sprout emerging and thrusting forth its grain. When pressed softly (按之軟) and lifted to reveal a solid pulse beneath (舉指來實), it is the Kidney (腎). Moist yet weak like water (濡弱如水), but when lifted, it overcomes the weight of a boat (舉重勝船).

The Spleen (脾) is the central state, so its pulse lies in the middle—this is the pulse of *yin* and *yang*.

The *Thousand Gold Pieces Canon* (*千金翼*) states: *"When slow, slack, and long (迟缓而長), it is the Spleen (脾)."*

**Pulse Forms by Finger Pressure (指下形状)**

Floating pulse (浮脉): When lifted, it remains; when pressed, it vanishes. It floats beneath the fingers.

Sinking pulse (沉脉): When lifted, it vanishes; when pressed, it remains. It requires firm pressure to detect.

Rough pulse (涩脉): Fine and slow (細而迟), difficult to traverse, and dispersed. Sometimes it stops and returns again. Also called: *"floating yet short"* (浮而短), *"short yet stopping"* (短而止), or *"dispersed"* (散).

Slippery pulse (滑脉): When traversing, it moves forward and backward swiftly, flowing smoothly and turning with ease, resembling the rapidity of counting. Also called: *"floating with a bead-like sensation beneath the fingers"* (浮中如有丸), *"scattered as if about to slip away"* (洒洒如欲脱).

Bounding pulse (洪脉): Extremely large beneath the fingers. Also called: *"floating yet large"* (浮而大).

Fine pulse (细脉): Small in scale, yet consistently present—only fine in texture.

Faint pulse (微脉): Extremely fine and soft, sometimes almost vanishing, as if present yet absent. Also called: *"small"* (小), *"swift beneath the hand"* (手下快), *"thin"* (薄), or *"when pressed, it seems about to exhaust"* (按之如欲尽).

Taut pulse (弦脉): When lifted, it vanishes; when pressed, it feels like a drawn bowstring. Also called: *"like a drawn bowstring, unyielding when pressed"* (如张弓弦，按之不移), *"floating yet tense as a bowstring"* (浮紧弓为弦).

Tense pulse (紧脉): Rapid like cutting through silk. Also called: *"like a turning rope, irregular in motion"* (如转索之无常).

Slow pulse (迟脉): When three breaths are taken, it arrives and departs extremely slowly. Also called: *"when lifted, it vanishes; when pressed, it feels firm and solid"* (举之不足，按之尽牢), *"when pressed, it feels firm and solid; when lifted, it vanishes"* (按之尽牢，举之无有).

Numerous pulse (数脉): When it arrives and departs in haste. Also called: *"six or seven beats per breath"* (意六七至), *"numerous pulse is named rapid"* (数者进之名).

Slack pulse (缓脉): When it arrives and departs slowly, yet slightly faster than a slow pulse (小鴂於迟). Also called: *"floating, large, and soft, with yin and yang pulses appearing together"* (浮大而软，阴与阳同着).

Weak pulse (弱脉): Extremely soft and sinking, fine in texture. When pressed, it nearly vanishes beneath the fingers. Also called: *"only detected when pressed firmly; when lifted, it disappears"* (按之乃得，举之即无).

Moving pulse (动脉): Appears above the *guān* [关, "barrier"], without distinct head or tail, large as a bean, trembling and shaking.

Hidden pulse (伏脉): Extremely deep, only detected when the fingers press against the bone. Also called: *"sinking above the guān without emerging"* (关上沉不出), *"firm beneath the hand"* (手下裁动), *"when pressed, it vanishes; when lifted, it disappears"* (按之不足，举之无有).

Knotted pulse (芤脉): Floating, large, and soft. When pressed, the center is hollow, while the sides feel solid. Also called: *"no pulse beneath the fingers, yet pulses appear on both sides"* (指下无，两傍有).

Soft pulse (软脉): Extremely soft and floating, fine in texture. Also called: *"when pressed, it vanishes; when lifted, it remains"* (按之无有，举之有余), *"fine and soft"* (細小如软). The *Thousand Gold Pieces Canon* (*千金翼*) renders this as *"moist"* (濡).

Empty pulse (虚脉): Slow, large, and soft. When pressed, it vanishes, and beneath the fingers, it feels hollow and gaping.

Full pulse (实脉): Large and long, slightly strong. When pressed, it feels solid and firm beneath the fingers. Also called: *"both sinking and floating pulses are detected"* (沉浮皆得).

Forced pulse (促脉): Rapid in arrival and departure, sometimes stopping for a moment.

Knotty pulse (结脉): Slow in arrival and departure, sometimes stopping and returning again. When the pulse knots, life is generated.

Alternating pulse (代脉): Arrives in haste, then stops midway, unable to return on its own, and thus moves again. When the pulse alternates, death is near.

Scattered pulse (散脉): Large and dispersed. When scattered, *qi* is excessive and blood is deficient—there is exteriority without containment.

Leathery pulse (革脉): Resembling sinking, hidden, and full pulses, yet large and long, with a slight tautness. The *Thousand Gold Pieces Canon* (*千金翼*) calls this *"firm"* (牢).

Tautness and tension are similar. Softness and weakness are similar. Floating and knotted pulses are similar. Also, floating and bounding pulses are similar. Faintness and roughness are similar. Sinking and hidden pulses are similar. Slackness and slowness are similar. Also, softness and slowness are similar. Leathery and full pulses are similar. The *Wing* (*翼*) calls firmness and fullness similar. Slipperiness and rapidity are similar.

**The Five Zàng [Solid Organs] and Six Fǔ [Hollow Organs] Pulse Locations (第五)**

Heart pulse (心部): Located at the *cùnkǒu* [寸口, "inch opening"] on the left hand, before the *guān* [关, "barrier"]. Also named *Rényíng* [人迎, "meeting of humanity"].

Liver pulse (肝部): Located above the *guān* on the left hand.

Kidney pulse (腎部): Located behind the *guān* at the *chězhōng* [尺中, "middle of the cubit"] on the left hand.

Lung pulse (肺部): Located at the *cùnkǒu* on the right hand, before the *guān*. Also named *Qìkǒu* [气口, "mouth of breath"].

Spleen pulse (脾部): Located above the *guān* on the right hand.

Kidney pulse (腎部): Located behind the *guān* at the *chězhōng* on the right hand.

The *Pulse Canon* (*Mài Fǎ Zàn*) states:
*"Liver and Heart pulses emerge from the left,
Spleen and Lung pulses emerge from the right.
Kidney and the Gate of Life (命门) both emerge from the cubit.
Soul, spirit, and vital essence (魂魄谷神) all appear at the inch opening.
The left governs the officials (官),
The right governs the ministries (府).
The left aligns with the male principle,
The right aligns with the female principle.
One division before the guān is the master of human life.
The left is Rényíng,
The right is Qìkǒu—
The Gate of the Spirit (神门) makes the judgment,
Both located behind the guān.
Humans lack a second pulse—
When disease strikes, it does not heal,
And all the channels are diminished,
Each following its own domain.
The Three Yin and Three Yang pulses—
One may also say: 'When pressed, they reveal yin and yang.'
Who comes first, who comes after?
Yin diseases are treated within the officials (官藏),
Yang diseases are treated within the ministries (府).
Where do strange pathogens (奇邪) dwell?
Examine them carefully—
When the needle enters, the disease is cured.
The pulse has three domains,
Where yin and yang intermingle,
And the *hóngwèi* [荣卫, "nourishing and defensive"] *qi* and blood traverse the body.
With breath’s ebb and flow,
They move upward and downward within,
Following the rhythm of inhalation and exhalation,
And fluids circulate.
According to the seasons, their movements shift,
And their forms mirror their correspondences—
Spring is taut, autumn is floating,
Winter is sinking, summer is bounding."*

Examine the complexion and observe the pulse—
Great and small, they differ.
Within a single moment, their changes are without constancy.
The *cùn* and *zhǐ* vary in length,
Now short, now long,
Above and below, they diverge—
Now present, now absent.
Diseases alter swiftly,
Advancing or retreating, rising or falling.
The mind is bewildered, the will confused,
Actions stray from their proper order.
I wish to elucidate this thread by thread,
So that distinctions may be made clear.

The Master said:
"What you inquire about is the root of the Dao.
The pulse has three domains—*cùn*, *guān*, and *zhǐ*—
Where the nourishing and defensive *qi* flow,
Never deviating from their balance.
The kidneys’ pulse is deep, the heart’s bounding,
The lungs’ floating, the liver’s taut—
These are the constant patterns,
Never straying by a hair’s breadth.
Rising and falling, entering and exiting,
Like the revolving of water clocks.
When water descends two *kè*,
The pulse completes one full circuit of the body,
Then returns to the *cùn-kǒu*,
Where emptiness and fullness reveal themselves.

Changes and transformations intermingle,
Yin and yang interrelate—
Wind makes it float and empty,
Cold makes it taut and taut-as-a-string,
Deep and submerged like water’s dwelling,
*zhīyǐn* [支饮] and urgent tautness—
Movement and tautness bring pain,
Rapid and bounding bring heat and agitation.
If there are anomalies,
One knows the cause of the change.

The three domains differ,
Each disease takes its own form.
Excess is strange,
Deficiency is no less so;
Pathogens do not appear in vain,
They must harbor some deceit.
Examine the exterior and interior,
Distinguish the Three Burners,
Know where the pathogen resides,
And diagnose through its ebb and flow.
Assess the *fǔ* and *zàng*,
Perceive with divine clarity.

**Differentiating Disease Forms (Section Five):**
Pulses that are numerous belong to the *fǔ*,
Slow pulses belong to the *zàng*.
When the pulse is long and taut,
The disease lies in the liver.
*The Pulse Classic* states: "It originates from the liver."
When the pulse is small and blood is scarce,
The disease lies in the heart.
Bian Que said: "A large, bounding pulse originates from the heart."
When the pulse is firm below and empty above,
The disease lies in the spleen and stomach.
When the pulse is smooth—*or* rough—and slightly floating,
The disease lies in the lungs.
When the pulse is large and firm,
The disease lies in the kidneys.
Bian Que said: "Small and taut."
A smooth pulse indicates abundant blood and scarce *qi*.
A rough pulse indicates scarce blood and abundant *qi*.
A large pulse indicates both blood and *qi* are abundant.
It is also said: "When the pulse arrives large and firm,
Both blood and *qi* are replete."
A small pulse indicates both blood and *qi* are scarce.
It is also said: "When the pulse arrives fine and faint,
Both blood and *qi* are depleted."
Deep, fine, and smooth yet rapid indicates heat.
Slow and taut indicates cold.
*The Pulse Classic* says: "Bounding, rapid, and smooth indicates heat;
Rough, slow, deep, and fine indicates cold."
When the pulse is vigorous, smooth, and taut,
The disease is external—heat.
When the pulse is small, firm, and taut,
The disease is internal—cold.
A small, weak, and rough pulse is called a chronic illness;
A smooth, floating, and rapid pulse is called a new illness.
A floating and smooth pulse—
The person has external heat, wind striking like needles,
Retention of fluids—difficult to treat.
A deep and taut pulse—
Upper Burner has heat, lower Burner has cold;
When cold is applied, diarrhea follows immediately.
A deep and fine pulse—
Lower Burner has cold, frequent urination,
Often with cramping pain, severe diarrhea.
A floating, taut, and smooth pulse—
External heat, internal cold, unable to pass stool or urine.
A bounding, large, and urgent pulse—
The disease progresses swiftly externally,
With headache, fever, and abscesses.
A fine, small, and urgent pulse—
The disease progresses swiftly internally,
Cold forming *jūyīn* [瘕痕], accumulations, and abdominal stabbing pain.
A deep, heavy pulse that abruptly ceases at the *cùn-kǒu*—
The disease is blood in the intestines.
A deep, heavy pulse that scatters midway—
Due to cold and improper diet, forming a condition.
A pulse that advances straight but scatters and ceases midway—
The disease is *xiāokě* [消渴, diabetes]—
*Or* it is called *jìnyànchuāng* [浸淫疮, ulcerative sores].
A deep, heavy pulse that does not reach the *cùn-kǒu*,
Wandering and ceasing—
The disease lies in the muscles, *duànshī* [遁尸, cadaverous transformation].
A pulse that turns left and is deep and heavy—
*Qi* is weak, yang is in the chest.
A pulse that turns right and does not reach the *cùn-kǒu*—
There is a flesh condition within.
A pulse like beads strung together, not reaching—
Wind and cold in the large intestine, lingering and unresolved.
A pulse like beads strung together, not reaching, with soft *cùn-kǒu*—
Retained heat in the small intestine’s membrane, lingering and unresolved.
A pulse that advances straight and rebounds left and right—
The disease is in the blood vessels—*pēixuè* [胚血, blood stasis].
A pulse that recedes and rebounds left and right—
The disease is in the sinews and bones.
When the pulse is large in front and small behind,
It indicates headache and dizziness.
When the pulse is small in front and large behind,
It indicates chest fullness and shortness of breath.
When the upper has pulse but the lower lacks it,
The person will vomit—if not, they die.
When the upper lacks pulse but the lower has it,
Though exhausted, they suffer no distress.

The pulse is the repository of blood.
When long, *qi* is harmonized;
When short, *qi* is diseased.
When rapid, the mind is agitated;
When large, the disease advances.
When the upper is vigorous, *qi* is high;
When the lower is vigorous, *qi* is distended.
When it is *dài* [代, intermittent], *qi* is declining.
When fine—*or* smooth—*qi* is scarce;
When rough, the heart aches.
When it surges like a gushing spring,
The disease advances and becomes perilous.
When it is faint and slack, like a snapped string,
Death is near.
When short and urgent, the disease is above;
When long and relaxed, the disease is below.
When deep, taut, and urgent, the disease is internal;
When floating, bounding, and large, the disease is external.
A firm pulse indicates internal disease;
A hollow pulse indicates external disease.
Above is the exterior, below is the interior;
Floating is the exterior, deep is the interior.
Smooth indicates fullness and the lower body,
*Or* declining yang *qi*.
Rapid indicates emptiness and heat;
Floating indicates wind and emptiness;
Movement indicates pain and fright;
Deep indicates water and fullness,
*Or* *guǐyāo* [鬼疰, spectral affliction].
Weak indicates emptiness and palpitations.
Slow indicates cold;
Rough indicates scarce blood;
Relaxed indicates emptiness;
Bounding indicates *qi*—*or* heat.
Taut indicates cold;
Taut and rapid indicates malaria.
Malaria pulses are taut by nature;
Taut and rapid often indicate heat,
Taut and slow often indicate cold.
Faint indicates emptiness;
*Dài* [代] and scattered indicate death.
Taut indicates painful *bì* [痹, numbness]—*or* floating indicates wind conditions.
One-sided tautness indicates retention of fluids;
Bilateral tautness causes lateral rigidity and pain,
The person feels rough and dislikes cold.
A large pulse indicates heat and cold in the middle.
When latent, it becomes *huòluàn* [霍乱, acute dysentery].

---

**Pulse Diagnosis in Rest and Disease Manifestations**

If the pulse is strong while reclining,
It is called *tuōxuè* [脱血, blood depletion].

In general, when sweating is lost,
The lungs are cold within;
Drinking cold water,
Coughing, sneezing, and diarrhea,
Or stomach emptiness and cold—
These cases all present a **taut pulse**.

If it is **floating and large**,
It is wind;
If **floating and large**,
It is apoplexy—
Head feels heavy, nose is congested.

If it is **floating and relaxed**,
The skin lacks sensation—
Wind and cold have penetrated the muscles.

If it is **slippery and floating-scattered**,
It is a lingering, relaxed wind.

If it is **rough and taut**,
It is *bì* [痹, numbness] disease.

If it is **floating, bounding, large, and long**,
It is wind-induced vertigo, epilepsy, or convulsions.

If it is **large and firm with urgency**,
It is epilepsy.

If it is **taut and hooked**,
The sides feel as if cut by a knife—
The body appears like a *fēishī* [飞尸, "flying corpse"], yet death does not come.

If it is **taut and rapid**,
It is *duànshī* [遁尸, "escaping corpse"]—
A condition of sudden, severe exhaustion.

If it is **bounding and large**,
It is injury by cold or heat diseases.

If it is **floating, bounding, and large**,
It is injury by cold—
A condition that worsens in autumn and improves in spring.

If it is **floating and slippery**,
It is undigested food.

If it is **floating, slippery, and urgent**,
It is indigestion—
The spleen fails to process food.

If it is **short, urgent, and slippery**,
It is alcohol-related illness.

If it is **floating and fine-slippery**,
It is injury by cold fluids.

If it is **slow and rough**,
Cold is present within—
There is a pathogenic *zhèngjié* [症结, "conglomerate knot"].

If it is **taut and rapid**,
It is accumulation and masses—
There is striking pain.

If it is **taut and urgent**,
It is hernia or *hù* [瘕, "blockage"]—
Lower abdomen aches, or it is *pì* [癖, "strange disease"].
*Or* it is *bì* [痹, numbness] disease.

If it is **slow and slippery**,
It is distension.

If it is **strong and taut**,
It is called distension.

If it is **taut and small**,
It is cold *dǎo* [澼, "leakage"]—
A lingering, difficult-to-treat condition.

If it is **sinking and taut**,
It is suspended fluids causing internal pain.

If it is **taut and rapid**,
There is cold fluid—
Difficult to treat in both winter and summer.

If it is **taut and slippery**,
It is vomiting and reverse peristalsis.

If it is **small, weak, and rough**,
It is stomach reversal.

If it is **slow and relaxed**,
Cold is present.

If it is **faint and taut**,
Cold is present with weak *qi*.

If it is **sinking and slow**,
The abdomen contains cold diseases.

If it is **faint and weak**,
Cold is present with deficient *qi*.

If it is **firm and taut**,
Cold is in the stomach—
The person suffers pain and cannot eat,
Or frequent diarrhea—**difficult to treat**.
*Or* frequent vomiting—**difficult to treat**.

If it is **slippery and rapid**,
There is intense heat beneath the heart.

If it is **slippery and urgent**,
Heat is in the stomach.

If it is **relaxed and slippery**,
It is called *rèzhòng* [热中, "heat in the middle"].

If it is **sinking and urgent**,
The disease is summer-heat injury—
Sudden onset with intense, empty heat.

If it is **floating and intermittent**,
It is *guǐ* [鬼, spectral] conditions.

If it is **large, slippery, and undulating**,
It is *guǐ* [鬼, spectral] conditions.

If it is **sinking, deep, and heavy**,
The limbs lack sensation and feel heavy—
It is earthly *guǐ* [鬼, spectral] conditions.

If the pulse aligns with the muscles,
And persists for a long time,
It can be treated by purgation.

If it is **taut, small, and urgent**,
It can be treated by purgation.

If it is **taut and rapid**,
Cold and heat both erupt—
Purgation must be applied for recovery.

If it is **taut and slow**,
Warming herbs are appropriate.

If it is **taut and rapid**,
Sweating should be induced.

---
**The Three Passes and Their Corresponding Treatments (Section VI)**

For **floating pulses** and **taut pulses**,
For **sinking pulses** and **taut pulses**,
For **rough pulses** and **slippery pulses**—
If found at the *cùnkǒu* [寸口, radial wrist position],
Diseases are above the diaphragm—**affecting the head**.

If found at the *guānshàng* [关上, "upper pass"],
Diseases are below the stomach—**affecting the abdomen**.

If found at the *chǐzhōng* [尺中, "middle cubit"],
Diseases are below the kidneys—**affecting the waist and legs**.

---
**Pulse Diagnosis at the *Cùnkǒu* [寸口, Radial Wrist Position] (Section VII)**

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **slippery and slow**,
Neither sinking nor floating,
Neither long nor short,
It indicates **no disease**—
The left and right pulses follow the same law.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **excessive or deficient**—
When the pulse at the *cùnkǒu* is short in the middle hand,
It is **headache**;
When long in the middle hand,
It is **foot joint pain**;
When hurried and striking upward,
It is **shoulder and back pain**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **sinking and firm**,
It is **disease in the middle**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **floating and bounding**,
It is **disease on the outside**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **sinking and weak**,
It is **cold and heat or hernia and *hù* [瘕, "blockage"]**—
Lower abdomen aches.
*Or* **heat**—*or* **cold**—*or* **internal disease**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **sinking and weak**,
The disease will **inevitably worsen**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **sinking and taut**,
Cold is beneath the heart—
Frequent pain, with lingering pathogenic *yí* [邪, "evil" or "harmful agents"].

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **sinking and slippery**,
There is **fluid in the chest**—
Face and eyes are swollen, with slight heat—
It is **wind-water**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **sinking, large, and slippery**,
Sinking indicates **blood excess**,
Slippery indicates **excessive *qi***—
When blood and *qi* clash,
Entry into the **zàng* [脏, "solid organs"] means death,
Entry into the **fǔ* [腑, "hollow organs"] means recovery.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **sinking**,
There is **shortness of breath in the chest**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **sinking and wheezing**,
It is cold and heat.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **floating and slippery**,
There is **pain in the head**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **floating and large**,
And pressing it reverses to **roughness**,
While the *chǐzhōng* [尺中, "middle cubit"] pulse is also faint and rough,
It is known there is **stagnant *qi* and undigested food**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **taut and urgent**,
Taut means **blocked *wèiqì* [卫气, "defensive *qi*"]**—
When *wèiqì* is blocked, **fear of cold** arises,
And **fluids flow through the intestines**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **taut or floating**,
Cold is above the diaphragm,
And **fluids accumulate beneath the lungs**.

If the pulse is **taut at the *cùnkǒu* [寸口] position**,
It is **apoplexy**—
Or **wind-induced headache**, as in the case of *shàngfēng* [上风, "wind attack"].
The *Yì* [翼, "Wing"] text also states it is **headache from injury by cold**.

If the pulse is **taut at the *cùnkǒu* [寸口] position**,
It is **undigested food**;
If it **descends**,
It is **headache**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **taut and large**,
In women, it causes **leukorrhea for half their lives**;
In men, it causes **blood loss and impotence**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **faint and weak**,
Faint means **fear of cold**,
Weak means **fever**—
When fever should appear but does not,
The bones ache with discomfort;
When discomfort should appear but does not,
**Extreme sweating** occurs.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **faint and weak**,
Both *qi* and blood are deficient—
In men, it causes **vomiting of blood**,
In women, it causes **menorrhagia**,
And **bile-like fluids** are vomited.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **dynamic and weak**,
Dynamic means **startled fright**,
Weak means **palpitations**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **slack and slow**,
Slack means **emptiness**,
Slow means **cold**—
When emptiness and cold *qi* clash,
One craves **warm nourishment**;
If cold food is eaten, **throat pain** ensues.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **slow and slack**,
Slow means **cold**,
Slack means **stagnant *qi***—
When cold and stagnant *qi* clash,
**Twisting pain** occurs.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **slow and choppy**,
Slow means **cold**,
Choppy means **scarce blood**.

If the pulse **reaches past the *cùnkǒu* into the *yújì* [鱼际] position**,
**Enuresis** occurs;
If the pulse **exits the *yújì* position**,
**Reverse *qi* and dyspnea** arise.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **solely firm**,
It indicates **heart overstrain**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **rolling like thick porridge**,
**Yang *qi* is diminished**;
If it **beats in rapid succession like spider silk**,
**Yin *qi* is declining**.

If the **forearm pulses are both absent in yang**,
One suffers **heart cold with venomous heat**,
While the **mouth feels hot**.
If one forearm pulse is **absent in yang**,
That arm **lacks mobility**;
If **both forearm pulses are absent in yang**,
The case is **untreatable**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse **alternates between large and small**,
It is the **yin network**—
One suffers **yin wind paralysis**,
Which **spontaneously erupts**,
And the body **feels washed by cold**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse **alternates between small and large**,
It is the **yang network**—
One suffers **cutaneous disorders**,
With **sweating and aversion to cold**,
And **numbness in the lower limbs**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **floating**,
It is **windstroke with fever and headache**—
Serve **Guìzhī [桂枝] Decoction** or **Gěgēn [葛根] Decoction**,
Needle **Fēngchí [风池]** and **Fēngfǔ [风府]**,
Expose to **fire and heat**,
Apply **Wind-Relieving Plaster**,
And **induce sweating**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **taut**,
It is **headache from injury by cold**—
Serve **Máhuáng [麻黄] Decoction to induce sweating**,
Needle **Méichōng [眉冲]**, **Sìliè [颞颥]**,
And apply **Cold-Injury Plaster**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **faint**,
It is **cold causing epistaxis**—
Serve **Wǔwèizi [五味子] Decoction** or **Máhuáng Zhūyú [麻黄茱萸] Plaster**,
And **induce sweating**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **rapid**,
It is **vomiting**—
For **heat lingers in the stomach meridian**,
Ascending to **chest stagnation**—
Serve **emetic medicines**,
Needle the **stomach meridian**,
And serve **Heat-Clearing Decoction**.

If **injury by cold lasts seven to eight days, or up to ten days**,
With **heat in the middle burner**,
**Restlessness, fullness, and thirst**—
Serve **Zhīmǔ [知母] Decoction**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **surging and large**,
**Chest and flank fullness**—
Serve **Shēngjiāng [生姜] Decoction** or **Báiwěi [白薇] Pill**,
Or **Zǐwǎn [紫菀] Decoction** to **promote bowel movements**,
And needle **Shàngguǎn [上管]**, **Qīmén [期门]**, **Zhāngmén [章门]**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **slack**,
**Cutaneous numbness**—
**Wind-cold lingers in the muscles**—
Serve **Fángfēng [防风] Decoction**,
And **apply thin herbal compresses** is best;
Moxibustion at **Wind-Relieving Points** is also advised.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **slippery**,
**Yang excess**—
**Chest oppression and fullness**,
With **vomiting and reverse *qi***—
Serve **Qiánhú [前胡] Decoction**,
And needle **Tàiyáng [太阳]** and **Jùquē [巨阙] to drain**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **taut**,
**Heart feels constricted**,
With **mild headache**—
**Water *qi* lingers in the chest**—
Serve **Gānsuì [甘遂] Pill**,
And needle **Qīmén [期门] to drain**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **weak**,
**Yang *qi* is deficient**,
With **spontaneous sweating**—
Serve **Fúlíng [茯苓] Decoction** or **Nèibǔ [内补] Powder**,
And **moderate diet and activity**,
Avoiding **excessive labor**;
Needle the **stomach meridian to reinforce**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **choppy**,
It is **stomach *qi* deficiency**—
Serve **Chán Dìhuáng [乾地黄] Decoction**,
**Nourish oneself**,
And **harmonize diet**;
Needle the **stomach meridian** (or **Sānlǐ [三里]**) to reinforce.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **knotted**,
It is **vomiting of blood**;
If **slightly pricking** occurs, it is **epistaxis**—
**Hollow and empty**,
A result of **blood loss**—
Serve **Zhú Pí [竹皮] Decoction** or **Huángtǔ [黄土] Decoction**,
And **moxibustion at the *jiǎo* [脍] point**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **suppressed**,
**Reverse *qi* in the chest**,
With **dysphagia and obstruction**—
**All *qi* ascends to the chest**—
Serve **Qiánhú [前胡] Decoction** or **Dà Sān Jiàn [大三建] Pill**,
And needle **Jùquē [巨阙] to drain**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **deep**,
**Chest pain radiating to the flanks**—
**Water *qi* lingers in the chest**—
Serve **Zéqī [泽漆] Decoction**,
And needle **Jùquē [巨阙] to drain**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **soft and weak**,
With **spontaneous sweating**—
It is **a wasting disorder**—
Serve **Chán Dìhuáng [乾地黄] Decoction**, **Shǔyù [薯蓣] Pill**, **Nèibǔ [内补] Powder**, or **Mǔlì [牡蛎] Powder** (with powdered **Yùyǔ [玉屑]**),
And needle **Tàichōng [太冲] to reinforce**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **slow**,
**Cold lingers in the upper burner**—
**Heart pain, throat acidity**,
With **vomiting of acidic fluids**—
Serve **Fùzi [附子] Decoction**, **Shēngjiāng [生姜] Decoction**, or **Zhūyú [茱萸] Pill**,
And **harmonize diet with warmth**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **firm**,
It is **heat generation**—
In the **spleen and lungs**, causing **vomiting and reverse *qi***;
If **deficient**, it is **cold generation**—
In the **spleen and stomach**, causing **indigestion**.
For **heat**, serve **Zhú Yè [竹叶] Decoction** or **Gěgēn [葛根] Decoction**;
For **cold**, serve **Zhūyú [茱萸] Pill** or **Shēngjiāng [生姜] Decoction**.

If the *cùnkǒu* pulse is **fine**,
With **fever and vomiting**—
Serve **Huángqín Lóngdǎn [黄苓龙胆] Decoction**;
If **vomiting persists**—
Serve **Júepí Jiégēng [橘皮桔梗] Decoction**,
And **moxibustion at Zhōngfǔ [中府]**.

---

**Píngguān [平关] pulse governs opposite therapies**:
If the pulse **above the *guān* [关] is floating and large**,
**Wind lingers in the stomach**—
**Yawning, shoulder breathing**,
**Heart feels dim and indistinct**,
And **nausea follows meals**.

If the pulse **above the *guān* is faint and floating**,
**Accumulated heat in the stomach**—
**Vomiting of roundworms**,
And **heart palpitations with forgetfulness**.

If the pulse **above the *guān* is slippery, with uneven large and small beats**,
**Vomiting will surely occur**—
It is **a sign the illness is about to strike**,
And in **one or two days**, it will **erupt and agitate**;
The patient **desires to drink frequently**,
But **drinking triggers immediate diarrhea**.

If **diarrhea occurs**,
**Cessation means survival**,
**Persistence means death**.

If the pulse **above the *guān* is taut and slippery**,
It is **roundworm movement**.

If the pulse **above the *guān* is taut and long** (*Yì* [翼] text says **large**),
With **pain as if from knife-thrusts**,
Located **above and below the navel on either side**—
*The *Màijīng* [脉经] states there is **accumulation** above and below the navel on either side.*

If the pulse **above the *guān* is choppy and firm**,
Large and **firm with force**,
And **does not diminish under pressure**—
It is **middle burner excess**—
With **suppressed cold and stagnation in the spleen and lungs**,
And **firm heat in the stomach**.

If the pulse **above the *guān* is rolling and large**, while the **forearm and wrist pulses are fine**—
The patient **suffers heart and abdominal cold accumulation**,
With **congealed masses and clumps**,
And **craves warm food and drink**.

If the pulse **above the *guān* appears and disappears intermittently**,
Alternates between **large and small**,
And between **uneven and rapid beats**—
It is **stomach cold and heat**,
With **weakened constitution**,
**Loss of appetite**,
And **episodic symptoms like malaria**.

If the pulse **above the *guān* is floating**,
With **abdominal fullness and loss of appetite**—
Floating means **hollow fullness**—
Serve **Píngwèi [平胃] Pill**, **Fúlíng [茯苓] Decoction**, or **Shēngjiāng Qiánhú [生姜前胡] Decoction**,
And needle the **stomach meridian**—
**Drain first, then reinforce**.

The pulse above the *guān* is **tight**—
With **distressing fullness and pain beneath the heart**,
For a tight pulse signifies **fullness**—
Serve **Cinnamon-Tangkuei Decoction**, or better yet, **add two liang of Rhubarb**.
*The Pulse Classic* says:
*"Rhubarb Decoction is also excellent for treatment."*
Needle **Jùquè [巨阙]** and **Lower Stomach Channel**, draining them.

The pulse above the *guān* is **feeble**—
With **stomach cold** and **constriction beneath the heart**—
Serve **Aconite Decoction**, **Fresh Ginger Decoction**, or **Aconite Pill**,
And needle **Jùquè [巨阙]** to reinforce.

The pulse above the *guān* is **rapid**—
With **guest heat in the stomach**—
Serve **Anemarrhena Decoction** (or **Pill**), or **Heat-Eliminating Decoction**,
And needle **Jùquè [巨阙]** and **Upper Stomach Channel**, draining them.

The pulse above the *guān* is **slow**—
With **loss of appetite**—
This is **spleen-stomach qi deficiency**—
Serve **Píngwèi [平胃] Pill** or **Spleen-Reinforcing Decoction**,
And also needle **Zhāngmén [章门]** to reinforce.

The pulse above the *guān* is **slippery**—
With **heat in the stomach**,
For slippery signifies **heat-fullness with stagnant qi**—
Thus **loss of appetite**, and **vomiting after eating**—
Serve **Magnolia-Phellodendron-Ephedra Decoction** or **Píngwèi [平胃] Pill**,
Or serve **Aster Decoction** and **Ginseng-Great-Píngwèi Pill**,
And needle the **Stomach Channel**, draining it.

The pulse above the *guān* is **string-taut**—
With **cold in the stomach** and **heart-region reversal**—
For a string-taut pulse indicates **stomach qi vacuity**—
Serve **Cinnamon-Tangkuei Decoction**,
And **warm the diet**,
Needling the **Stomach Channel** to reinforce.

The pulse above the *guān* is **weak**—
With **stomach vacuity** and **guest heat**,
For a weak pulse signifies **vacuity-heat illness**.
Though it says there is heat, **do not attack it heavily**—
For when heat departs, cold will arise.
Serve **Bamboo-Leaf Decoction** instead,
And needle the **Stomach Channel** to reinforce.

The pulse above the *guān* is **fine**—
**Vacuity**, with **abdominal fullness**—
Serve **Fresh Ginger Decoction**, **Cinnamon-Chuanpepper Decoction**, or **White Powder Pill**,
And needle-moxa the **Three Channels**.

The pulse above the *guān* is **rough**—
With **blood-qi reversal and cold**,
For a rough pulse signifies **blood vacuity**—
Serve **Rehmannia Decoction** or **Four-Supplement Powder**,
And needle **Foot-Tàichōng [太冲]** above to reinforce.

The pulse above the *guān* is **floral**—
With **blood in the stool**—
Serve **Fresh Rehmannia-and-Bamboo-Skin Decoction**,
And moxa **Géshū [膈输]**.
If **excessive bleeding occurs**, needle **Guānyuán [关元]**, or in severe cases, serve **Dragon Bone Pill**.
*Note: Guānyuán [关元] is also called Jùquè [巨阙].*

The pulse above the *guān* is **hidden**—
With **water-qi causing loose stools**—
Serve **Mercury Pill**,
Needle **Guānyuán [关元]**, and **facilitate urination** to stop the loose stools.
Once stopped, **discontinue**.

The pulse above the *guān* is **surging**—
With **stomach heat**, causing **distress and fullness**—
Serve **Píngwèi [平胃] Pill**,
And needle the **Stomach Channel**, **draining first, then reinforcing**.

The pulse above the *guān* is **deep**—
With **cold beneath the heart**, causing **fullness and acid regurgitation**—
Serve **White Honeysuckle Pill**, **Poria Pill**, or **Aconite Decoction**,
And needle the **Stomach Channel** to reinforce.

The pulse above the *guān* is **soft**—
With **vacuity-cold**, **spleen weakness**, and **prolonged illness**—
Serve **Red Stone Powder Decoction** or **Female Sterility Pill**,
And needle **Guānyuán [关元]** to reinforce.

The pulse above the *guān* is **slow**—
With **stomach cold**—
Serve **Cinnamon-Bark Pill** or **Cinnamon Decoction**,
And needle the **Stomach Channel** to reinforce.

The pulse above the *guān* is **full**—
With **stomach pain**—
Serve **Gardenia Decoction** or **Cinnamon-Aconite Pill**,
And needle the **Stomach Channel**.

The pulse above the *guān* is **firm**—
With **spleen-stomach stagnation** and **flourishing heat**—
Causing **persistent abdominal fullness**—
Serve **Aster Pill** or **Spleen-Draining Pill**,
And needle-moxa the **Stomach Channel**, draining it.

**Parallel Rules for *Chǐ* [尺] and *Guān* [关] Pulses:**

The *chǐ* pulse is **floating**—
**Guest yang** is in the **lower burner**.
The *chǐ* pulse is **weak**—
With **lower burner cold**, lacking yang,
And **upper burner heat surging to the head and face**.

The *chǐ* pulse is **weak at the *cùn* but strong**—
The **stomach collateral** is injured.

The *chǐ* pulse is **unilaterally slippery and rapid**—
With **flushed face as if drunk**, indicating **external heat illness**.

The *chǐ* pulse is **fine and faint**—
Causing **loose stools and cold diarrhea**.
*The Plain Questions* says:
*"A cold chǐ pulse is fine—this predicts posterior diarrhea."*

The *chǐ* pulse is **vacuous and small**—
With **foot meridian cold**, causing **flaccid paralysis and leg pain**.

The *chǐ* pulse is **rough**—
With **lower bleeding**, **difficult urination**, and **excessive sweating**.
*The Plain Questions* says:
*"A rough chǐ pulse, though slippery, predicts excessive sweating."*

The *chǐ* pulse is **deep yet slippery**—
This indicates **white worms in the *cùn* position**.

The *chǐ* pulse is **fine yet urgent**—
Causing **tendon contraction and inability to walk**.

The *chǐ* pulse is **large**—
With **heat in the abdomen**, causing **painful, bloody urination**.

The *chǐ* pulse is **coarse**, with **constant heat**—
Called **"heat in the center"**, causing **lumbar and hip pain** and **hot, bloody urination**.

The *chǐ* pulse, when pressed, **does not cease**—
In women, this indicates **blood stagnation**, corresponding with the *guān* pulse.

A **slippery** pulse—
In men, it signifies **vigorous blood and qi**,
In women, it indicates **pregnancy**.

The *chǐ* pulse **arrives yet abruptly ceases**—
In men, there is **stagnant gas in the lower abdomen**,
In women, **menstrual obstruction**.

The *chǐ* pulse is **jointly soft and weak**—
With **internal heat distress**, causing **inverted cold in hands and feet** and **sweating**.

The *chǐ* pulse is **jointly deep**, with **none above the *guān***—
Causing **heart-region dyspnea**.

The *chǐ* pulse is **jointly deep**, but **some remains above the *guān***—
Causing **cold pain beneath the heart**, **genital coldness**, and **leg paralysis**.

The *chǐ* pulse is **jointly feeble**—
With **weak vitality**, **disinclination to speak**, and **blood-qi deficiency**,
Causing **weak legs and shortness of breath**.

The *chǐ* pulse is **jointly rapid**—
With **heat in hands, feet, head, and face**;
If **jointly slow**, there is **cold**, with **chilly winds in hands, feet, head, and face**.

The *chǐ* pulse is **floating**—
With **lower burner heat-wind**, causing **difficult urination**—
Serve **Dioscorea-Hyalos Decoction** or **Slippery Stone Powder**,
And needle **Hénggǔ [横骨]** and **Guānyuán [关元]**, draining them.

The *chǐ* pulse is **tight**—
With **umbilical pain**—
Serve **Tangkuei Decoction**,
Moxa **Tiānhú [天枢]**, and needle **Guānyuán [关元]** to reinforce.

The *chǐ* pulse is **feeble**—
With **reversal**, **lower abdominal constriction**, and **cold qi**—
Serve **Minor Build-Middle Decoction**,
And needle **Qìhǎi [气海]**.

The *chǐ* pulse is **rapid**—
With **aversion to cold**, **umbilical heat-pain**, and **yellowish urination**—
Serve **Chicken-Egg Decoction** or **White Fish Powder**,
And needle **Hénggǔ [横骨]**, draining it.

The *chǐ* pulse is **slow**—
With **weak legs**, **lower limb edema**, and **difficult urination**, leaving **dribbling**—
Serve **Slippery Stone Decoction** or **Dioscorea Powder**,
And needle **Hénggǔ [横骨]**, draining it.

The *chǐ* pulse is **slippery**—
With **vigorous blood-qi** and **obstructed meridians**—
Serve **Magnolia-Phellodendron Decoction** or **Rhubarb Decoction** to **expel menstrual blood**,
And needle **Guānyuán [关元]**, draining it.

The *chǐ* pulse is **string-taut**—
With **lower abdominal pain** and **constriction in the lower abdomen and legs**—
Serve **Build-Middle Decoction** or **Tangkuei Decoction**,
And needle **Qìhǎi [气海]**, draining it.

The *chǐ* pulse is **weak**—
With **scant qi**, **fever**, and **bone weariness**,
Serve **Front-Host Decoction** or **Dried Rehmannia-Poria Decoction**,
And needle **Guānyuán [关元]**, reinforcing it.

The *chǐ* pulse is **rough**—
With **coldness in the leg meridians** and **hematuria**,
Serve **Aconite Four-Reversal Decoction**,
And needle **Foot Tai Chong [足太冲]**, reinforcing it.

The *chǐ* pulse is **knotted**—
With **lower burner vacuity** and **hematuria**,
Serve **Bamboo Skin-Dried Rehmannia Decoction**,
And **moxa** **Dan Tian [丹田]** and **Guānyuán [关元]**.

The *chǐ* pulse is **hidden**—
With **lower abdominal pain** and **hernia**,
And **undigested food**—
Serve **Major Stomach-Regulating Pill** or **Citrus-Ginger Pill**,
And needle **Guānyuán [关元]**, reinforcing it.

The *chǐ* pulse is **deep**—
With **lumbar and back pain**,
Serve **Kidney Qi Pill**,
And needle **Jīngmén [京门]**, reinforcing it.

The *chǐ* pulse is **soft**—
With **unable to lift legs**, **wind numbness**—
And **difficult urination**—
Serve **Dioscorea Decoction** or **White Fish Powder**,
And needle **Guānyuán [关元]**, draining it.

The *chǐ* pulse is **firm**—
With **abdominal distension** and **urgency in the genitals**,
Serve **Glehnia-Schisandra Pill**,
And needle **Dan Tian [丹田]**, **Guānyuán [关元]**, and **Zhōngjí [中极]**.

The *chǐ* pulse is **slow**—
With **cold in the lower burner**,
Serve **Cinnamon Branch Pill**,
And needle **Qìhǎi [气海]** and **Guānyuán [关元]**, draining it.

The *chǐ* pulse is **full**—
With **lower abdominal pain** and **incontinence**,
Serve **Tangkuei-Angelica Decoction with added two liang of Rhubarb** to **facilitate bowel movements**,
And needle **Guānyuán [关元]**, reinforcing it.

*From the **Sun Simian’s [孙真人] Emergency Thousand-Gold Prescriptions, Volume 84** [平脉方]*
*(Note: Original text had “养性” [Nurturing Nature] before “平脉方” [Leveling the Pulse], deleted per Song-dynasty shadow-printed edition.)*

---
*From the **Sun Simian’s Emergency Thousand-Gold Prescriptions, Volume 85**
*[Revised by Song-dynasty officials Lin Yi 等, including Court Attendant Lin Yi, Minister of Rites, and Secretariat Editor]*
**[Leveling the Pulse]**
**[Five Viscera Accumulations, Seventh Section]**

**Diseases of Accumulation, Concretion, and Stagnant *Qi***

Humans suffer from *accumulations*, *concretions*, and *stagnant grain-qi*. *[Note: "谷" (grain) here is also written as "系" (bind).]*

Accumulations are diseases of the *zàng* [viscera], which never shift.
Concretions are diseases of the *fǔ* [bowels], which flare at set times, their pain migrating and transforming—thus they are treatable.
Stagnant *grain-qi* manifests as lateral abdominal traction pain; pressing it eases it, but it recurs—this is *stagnant grain-qi*. When a disease has already resolved but then relapses, it is *stagnant grain-qi*.

**The Great Laws of Accumulations:**
When the pulse arrives *fine, soft, and clinging to bone*, it is an accumulation. *[#1]*
If the *cùn* [inch] pulse is *knotted*, the accumulation is in the chest.
If it *barely emerges at the cùn*, the accumulation is in the throat.
If the *guān* [bar] pulse is knotted, the accumulation is beside the navel.
If it *slightly descends past the guān*, the accumulation is in the lower abdomen.
If the *chǐ* [foot] pulse is knotted, the accumulation is at *Qìchōng* [气冲].
If it is knotted *above the guān*, the accumulation is beneath the heart.

If the pulse appears on the left, the accumulation is on the left;
If it appears on the right, the accumulation is on the right.
If the pulse appears on both sides, the accumulation is central—each corresponds to its region.

If the *cùn* pulse is *sunken and horizontal*, there is a *horizontal accumulation* in the lateral abdomen and abdomen, and the pulse is *tight*.
If there is *sudden abdominal pain* with *lumbar-back pain radiating*, there is a *cold cèng* [症] or *jǐ* [瘕] accumulation in the abdomen.
If the pulse is *tight, tense, and fine*, it is a *cèng* [症].

Cold *bì* [痹], *cèng*, *jǐ*, and *accumulations* all present with *tight, tense pulses*.
If the tightness is at the *cùn*, the accumulation is beneath the heart;
If at the *guān*, it is in the stomach’s conduit;
If at the *chǐ*, it is below the navel.
Another saying: If the *guān* pulse is *long and tight*, there is an accumulation above, below, left, or right of the navel.

**Further Pulse-Symptom Laws:**
If the left-hand pulse is horizontal, the *cèng* is on the left;
If the right-hand pulse is horizontal, the *cèng* is on the right.
If the pulse *head is large above* and *small below*, the *cèng* is above;
If the head is small above and large below, the *cèng* is below.
Another method: If the horizontal pulse appears on the left, the accumulation is on the right;
If it appears on the right, the accumulation is on the left.
If the pulse is *one-sided, surging, solid, and slippery*, it is an accumulation;
If it is *tight*, it is an accumulation, *cold bì*, or *cèng* pain.
If there is an internal accumulation but no corresponding pulse, it is difficult to treat;
If one pulse corresponds, it is easy to treat;
If none correspond, treatment is impossible.

If the left-hand pulse is large and the right small,
Upper disease is in the left lateral abdomen, lower disease in the left foot.
If the right-hand pulse is large and the left small,
Upper disease is in the right lateral abdomen, lower disease in the right foot.

If the pulse is *tight and submerged*, there is an unmovable *cèng* in the abdomen—*certain death, untreatable*.
If the pulse arrives *fine and sunken, sometimes straight*, there is a *yōng* [痈] or *zhǒng* [肿] in the body, or a *hidden beam* in the abdomen.
If the pulse arrives *sunken and empty*, it is *diarrhea*.
If it arrives *small, sunken, and solid*, there is an accumulation in the stomach—*do not purge; eating causes vomiting*.

---
**Yin-Yang, Exterior-Interior, and Empty-Full [Section 8]**
*Tight* is *Shǎoyáng* [少阳],
*Slack* is *Yángmíng* [阳明],
*Surging* is *Tàiyáng* [太阳]—the *three yang*.
*Fine* is *Shǎoyīn* [少阴],
*Slow* is *Juéyīn* [厥阴],
*Sunken* is *Tàiyīn* [太阴]—the *three yin*.

The pulse may be *one yin and one yang*,
*one yin and two yang*,
*one yin and three yang*;
Or *one yang and one yin*,
*one yang and two yin*,
*one yang and three yin*.

Thus, when the *cùn* pulse exhibits six qualities—are they all moving at once?
No: The *Classic* speaks thus not of six simultaneous pulses, but of *floating, sunken, long, short, slippery, and rough*.

Generally, *floating, slippery, and long* pulses are *yang*;
*Sunken, rough, and short* are *yin*.

When it says *one yin and one yang*, it means the pulse arrives *sunken yet slippery*.
*One yin and two yang*: the pulse arrives *sunken, slippery, and long*.
*One yin and three yang*: the pulse arrives *floating, slippery, and long*, occasionally sunken.

When it says *one yang and one yin*, it means the pulse arrives *floating yet rough*.
*One yang and two yin*: the pulse arrives *long yet sunken and rough*.
*One yang and three yin*: the pulse arrives *sunken, rough, and short*, occasionally floating.

Each corresponds to its channel’s location, indicating the *order or disorder* of the disease.

**When the pulse shows *yang excess and yin deficiency*, or *yin excess and yang deficiency*—what does this mean?**
If the *floating* pulse is *small* while the *sunken* pulse is *full*, it is *yin excess and yang deficiency*;
If the *sunken* pulse is *small* while the *floating* pulse is *full*, it is *yang excess and yin deficiency*.
This is the meaning of *yin-yang empty-full*.

Generally, *floating, large, rapid, dynamic, long, and slippery* pulses are *yang*;
*Sunken, rough, weak, tight, short, and fine* are *yin*.

If a *yang* disease presents with *yin* pulses, it is *contrary*—*death ensues*;
If a *yin* disease presents with *yang* pulses, it is *harmonious*—*life ensues*.

Before the *guān* is *yang*; after the *guān* is *yin*.
If *yang* pulses are *rapid*, vomiting occurs;
If *yin* pulses are *fine*, diarrhea occurs.
If *yang* pulses are *tight*, headache ensues;
If *yin* pulses are *tight*, abdominal pain ensues—*diagnose by yin-yang*.

The *chǐ* pulse is *yin*; *yin* pulses are always *sunken and slow*.
The *cùn* and *guān* are *yang*; *yang* pulses are always *floating and rapid*.

If there is *exterior* without *interior*, the *evil* lingers, causing *ghost disease*.
What is *exterior-interior*?
The *cùn* and *chǐ* are *exterior*; the *guān* is *interior*.
If both ends have pulses but the *guān* is *absent*, it is *yin exhaustion* if the *chǐ* pulse fails to reach the *guān*, or *yang exhaustion* if the *cùn* pulse fails to reach the *guān*.
*Yin exhaustion* with *yang faintness*—*death, untreatable*.

*Inhalation* is *exterior*, belonging to the *fǔ* [bowels];
*Exhalation* is *interior*, belonging to the *zàng* [viscera].
If *yang* is faint, inhalation fails;
If *yin* is faint, exhalation fails.
Insufficient breathing causes *shortness of breath in the chest*.

*Weakness* reverses at the *guān*;
*Dampness* reverses at the *pericranium*;
*Faintness* appears above;
*Roughness* reverses below.
*Faintness* means *insufficient yang*—*sticky heat, sweating*;
*Roughness* means *blood deficiency*—*convulsions and cold*.

The pulses of the *fǔ* [bowels] are *yang*, governing *heat*;
The pulses of the *zàng* [viscera] are *yin*, governing *cold*.
If *yang* is faint, *sweating* occurs;
If *yin* is floating, *diarrhea* occurs. *[Note: Some texts say "yin faint."]*
If *yang* pulses are *rapid*, *mouth ulcers* form;
If *yin* pulses are *fine*, *cold aversion* and *restlessness* ensue, with *insomnia*.
If *yang* is *constricted*, *vomiting of blood* occurs. *[Note: Some texts say "yang rapid."]*
If *yin* is *rough*, *bleeding* occurs. *[Note: Some texts say "yin rough."]*

There is no *yang*, then there is *convulsion*;
There is no *yin*, then there is *vomiting*.

When the pulse at the *cùnkǒu* [wrist] is **floating, large, and rapid**, it is called **"yang within yang"**.
The ailment brings **restlessness, fullness, fever, headache, and abdominal heat**.

When the pulse at the *cùnkǒu* is **deep and fine**, it is called **"yang within yin"**.
The ailment brings **melancholy, displeasure, aversion to voices, shortness of breath, occasional sweating, and stagnant *yin qi***—[some texts say *"stagnant and combined"*]—**and inability to lift the arms**. *[The *Cháoyuán* [Perch Spring] text reads: "arms cannot be lifted on one side."]*

When the pulse at the *chǐ* [forearm] is **deep and fine**, it is called **"yin within yin"**.
The ailment brings **aching in both sides [of the body], inability to stand long, weakened *yin qi*, lingering urine, and itching in the *yin* region**.

When the pulse at the *chǐ* is **slippery and floating-large**, it is called **"yin within yang"**.
The ailment brings **pain and fullness in the lower abdomen, inability to urinate**; when urination occurs, **pain arises in the *yin* region**, and the same applies to defecation.

When the pulse at the *chǐ* is **taut and long**, with **no presence at the *guān* [barrier]**, this is **"yin drying yang"**.
The person suffers **heaviness in both sides [of the body] and lower abdominal pain radiating to the waist**.

When the pulse at the *cùnkǒu* is **robust and large**, with **no presence in the *chǐ***, this is **"yang drying yin"**.
The person suffers **waist and back pain, *yin* injury, and cold in the leg channels**.

Now, what are the **three vacuities and three repletions**?
It is said: **There is the vacuity and repletion of the pulse, the vacuity and repletion of the disease, and the vacuity and repletion of diagnosis**.

The **vacuity and repletion of the pulse**: a pulse that comes **soft and weak** is **vacuity**; one that is **taut** is **repletion**.

The **vacuity and repletion of the disease**:
**Excretion** is **vacuity**; **retention** is **repletion**.
**Speech** is **vacuity**; **silence** is **repletion**.
**Sluggishness** is **vacuity**; **urgency** is **repletion**.

The **vacuity and repletion of diagnosis**:
**Itching** is **vacuity**; **pain** is **repletion**.
**External pain with internal ease** is **external repletion and internal vacuity**.
**Internal pain with external ease** is **internal repletion and external vacuity**.
Thus, it is called **vacuity and repletion**.

**Question:** What is meant by **vacuity and repletion**?
**Answer:** When **pathogenic *qi*** is **flourishing**, it is **repletion**; when **vital essence and *qi*** are **depleted**, it is **vacuity**.

What is **severe repletion**?
**Severe repletion** refers to **fierce heat diseases**, where **the *qi* is hot and the pulse is full**—this is called **severe repletion**.

**Pulse is strong, skin is hot, abdomen is distended, and there is no passage of urine or feces**—these are the **Five Repletions**.
**Pulse is fine, skin is cold, *qi* is scant, there is diarrhea or dysentery with incontinence, and refusal of food and drink**—these are the **Five Vacuities**.

**Chapter Nine: Determining the Timing of Illness**

How does one know if a person will fall ill from **sleeping exposed**?
It is because **there is *yin* within *yang***.

How does one know if a person will fall ill in **summer**?
It is because **all *yang* has entered *yin***.

How does one know if a person will fall ill in **spring**?
It is because **there is no liver pulse**.
If there is no **heart pulse**, illness will come in **summer**.
If there is no **lung pulse**, illness will come in **autumn**.
If there is no **kidney pulse**, illness will come in **winter**.
If there is no **spleen pulse**, illness will come in **any season**.

**Chapter Ten: Examinations of Voice and Complexion by Bian Que and Hua Tuo**

When a patient’s **five *zàng* [viscera] are already depleted**, with **spirit and awareness unguarded**, and their **voice is hoarse**, they will **die**.

When a patient **traces along the seams of their clothing** and **speaks incoherently**, they **cannot be treated**.

When a patient’s **both *yin* and *yang* are exhausted**, they **clutch at their clothing in emptiness** and **speak wildly**, they will **die**.

When a patient **speaks erratically, is confused, or cannot speak at all**, they **cannot be treated**.
However, **heat diseases** may still **be treated**.

When a patient’s **both *yin* and *yang* are exhausted**, and they **lose their voice and cannot speak**, they will **die within three and a half days**.

When a patient’s **inner canthi turn yellow**, their illness **is nearing recovery**.

If a patient’s **face is yellow and eyes are green**, they will **not die**; but if the green is **like grass withering**, they will **die**.

If a patient’s **face is yellow and eyes are red**, they will **not die**; but if the red is **like bloodied cloth**, they will **die**.

If a patient’s **face is yellow and eyes are white**, they will **not die**; but if the white is **like withered bone**, they will **die**.

If a patient’s **face is yellow and eyes are black**, they will **not die**; but if the black is **like the onset of death**, they will **die**.

If a patient’s **face and eyes are uniformly colored**, they will **not die**.

If a patient’s **face is black and eyes are green**, they will **not die**.

If a patient’s **face is green and eyes are white**, they will **die**.

If a patient’s **face is red and eyes are green**, they will **die within six days**.

If a patient’s **face is yellow and eyes are green**, they will **die within nine days**—this is called **"disordered *jing* [channels]."**
**Drinking alcohol in the wind** allows **pathogenic *qi* to enter the stomach channel**; **bile *qi* leaks wildly**, and the eyes **turn green**.
Even if **divine intervention** occurs, **life cannot be restored**.

If a patient’s **face is red and eyes are white**, they will **die within ten days**.
**Grief, anger, overthinking, and worry** cause **heart *qi* to retreat inward**; though the **complexion may appear fair**, **urgently seek a coffin**.

If a patient’s **face is white and eyes are black**, they will **die**.
This is because **the *róng* [nourishing] and *huá* [flourishing] essence has departed**, and the **blood vessels are empty**.

If a patient’s **face is black and eyes are white**, they will **die within eight days**.
This is due to **internal injury of kidney *qi*, with lingering illness**.

If a patient’s **face is green and eyes are yellow**, they will **die within five days**.

If a patient **lies on a bed with heart pain and shortness of breath**, it is **spleen exhaustion and internal injury**.
Though **a hundred ailments may recover**, they can **rise and wander**; yet if they **sit on the ground** and **stand leaning on the bed**, the one who can **treat this** may be called **"divinely skilled."**

If a patient’s **face lacks luster, resembling soil in color**, and they **refuse food and drink**, they will **die within four days**.

If a patient’s **eyes lack luster**, or if their **teeth turn black**, they **cannot be treated**.

If a patient’s **ears, eyes, nose, or mouth develop black patches**, and these **enter the mouth**, they will **certainly die**.

If a patient’s **ears, eyes, cheeks, or temples turn red**, they will **die within five days**.

If a patient’s **black patches appear on the forehead at the hairline**, extending down the **nose and both cheeks**, they will also **die within five days**.

If **black or white patches** appear on a patient **or a healthy person**, and these **enter the eyes or nose/mouth**, they will **die within three days**.

If a patient’s **or a healthy person’s face suddenly turns the color of horse liver**, appearing **green from afar and black up close**, they will **die**.

If a patient’s **face is black**, their **eyes stare straight ahead**, and they **dread the wind**, they will **die**.

If a patient’s **face is black and lips are green**, they will **die**.

If a patient’s **face is green and lips are black**, they will **die**.

If a patient’s **face is black and both flanks are distended**, rendering them **unable to turn or roll over**, they will **die**.

If a patient’s **eyes roll back and forth, staring fixedly**, with **shoulder breathing**, they will **die within one day**.

If a patient’s **yin is stagnant and yang is exhausted**, their **eye essence is depleted**, and they appear **dazed**, they will **die**.

If a patient’s **both *yin* and *yang* are exhausted**, and their **eye sockets are sunken**, they will **die**.

「If a patient’s **eyebrows are knitted and drooping**, they will **die within seven days**.

If a patient’s **mouth opens like a fish’s**, unable to close again, and their **qi escapes profusely without returning**, they will **die**.

If a patient’s **mouth remains open**, they will **die within three days**.

If a patient’s **lips turn green** and their **philtrum inverts**, they will **die within three days**.

If a patient’s **lips invert** and their **philtrum swells**, they will **die**.

If a patient’s **lips and mouth suddenly become parched**, they are **incurable**.

If a patient’s **lips swell and teeth scorch**, they will **die**.

If a patient’s **teeth suddenly turn black**, they will **die within thirteen days**.

If a patient’s **tongue curls and shrinks like a coiled egg**, they will **certainly die**.

If a patient’s **sweat does not flow** and their **tongue curls and turns black**, they will **die**.

If a patient’s **hair stands erect**, they will **die within fifteen days**.

If a patient’s **hair bristles like dry hemp**, and they are **prone to anger**, they will **die**.

If a patient’s **hair and eyebrows rise together**, they will **die**.

If a patient’s **fingernails turn green**, they will **die**.

If a patient’s **fingernails turn white**, they are **incurable**.

If a patient’s **flesh beneath the fingernails turns black**, they will **die within eight days**.

If a patient’s **nourishing (*Yíng*) and defensive (*Wèi*) *qi* are exhausted**, and their **face becomes bloated**, they will **die**.

If a patient **suddenly swells**, and their **face becomes ashen and black**, they will **die**.

If a patient’s **palms become bloated and lose their natural texture**, they will **die**.

If a patient’s **umbilicus swells and protrudes**, they will **die**.

If a patient’s **scrotum and penis both swell**, they will **die**.

If a patient’s **pulse ceases**, their **mouth remains open**, and their **feet become swollen**, they will **die within five days**.

If a patient’s **top of the foot swells**, they **vomit repeatedly** and feel **head-heavy**, they will **die**.

If a patient’s **top of the foot swells above**, and their **knees become as large as a bowl**, they will **die within ten days**.

If a patient **lies down** and **unconsciously defecates**, they will **die**.

If a patient **emits a corpse-like stench**, they are **untreatable**.

For **liver illnesses**, if the **skin turns white**, it is the **day of the lungs (*Fèi*)**, on **Reginal days (Gēngxīn)**, they will **die**.

For **heart illnesses**, if the **eyes turn black**, it is the **day of the kidneys (*Shèn*)**, on **Yin days (Rénwèi)**, they will **die**.

For **spleen illnesses**, if the **lips turn green**, it is the **day of the liver (*Gān*)**, on **Jia-Yi days (Jiǎyǐ)**, they will **die**.

For **lung illnesses**, if the **cheeks turn red and eyes swell**, it is the **day of the heart (*Xīn*)**, on **Bing-Xu days (Bǐngxū)**, they will **die**.

For **kidney illnesses**, if the **face swells and lips turn yellow**, it is the **day of the spleen (*Pí*)**, on **Wu-Ji days (Wùjǐ)**, they will **die**.

**Green** should resemble the **sheen of a black jade**, not **indigo**.

**Red** should resemble the **inner texture of silk and vermilion**, not **ochre**.

**White** should resemble **goose down**, not **washing water**.
**Black** should resemble **thick lacquer**, not **charcoal**.
**Yellow** should resemble **silk-wrapped realgar**, not **yellow soil**.

**Chapter Eleven: Diagnosing the Critical Signs of Five Zang and Six Fu Organs**

If the **liver (Gān)** is failing, death occurs in **eight days**.
*How do we know?* The face turns **green**, the patient only wishes to lie down, gazes without seeing others, and **sweats (or weeps) profusely like water without stopping**.
*Alternative:* Death in **one or two days**.

If the **gallbladder (Dǎn)** is failing, death occurs in **seven days**.
*How do we know?* The **eyebrows slant inward**.

If the **tendons (Jīn)** are failing, death occurs in **nine days**.
*How do we know?* The **fingernails and toenails turn green**, and the patient **shouts and curses incessantly**.
*Alternative:* Death in **eight days**.

If the **heart (Xīn)** is failing, death occurs **on the first day**.
*How do we know?* The patient **gasps for breath and turns their head back**—**instant death**.
*Alternative:* If the **eyes appear fixed and staring**, death occurs in **two days**.

If the **intestines (Cháng)** are failing, death occurs in **six days**.
*How do we know?* The **hair stands erect like dry hemp**, unable to bend or stretch, and **cold sweat does not cease**.

If the **spleen (Pí)** is failing, death occurs in **twelve days**.
*How do we know?* The **mouth feels cold**, the **feet swell**, the **abdomen is hot and distended**, **diarrhea is uncontrollable**, and **urine passes without restraint**.

If the **stomach (Wèi)** is failing, death occurs in **five days**.
*How do we know?* The **back aches**, the **lumbar region feels heavy**, and the patient **cannot turn over**.
*Alternative:* If the **calf muscles flatten**, death occurs in **nine days**.

If the **flesh (Ròu)** is failing, death occurs in **six days**.
*How do we know?* The **ears dry out**, the **tongue swells entirely**, **blood appears in the urine**, and **stool is bloody and watery**.
*Alternative:* If the **feet swell**, death occurs in **nine days**.

If the **lungs (Fèi)** are failing, death occurs **on the first day of the month (Gōngyè)**.
*How do we know?* The **mouth gapes open**, and **breath escapes but does not return**.
*Alternative:* If the **nose and mouth are hollow and breathing is shallow**, death occurs **on the first day of the month**.

If the **large intestine (Dàcháng)** is failing, it is **untreatable**.
*How do we know?* **Diarrhea is uncontrollable**; when the **diarrhea ceases**, death follows.

If the **kidneys (Shèn)** are failing, death occurs in **four days**.
*How do we know?* The **teeth wither suddenly**, the **face turns pitch-black**, **yellow appears in the eyes**, the **lumbar region feels as if it will snap**, and **cold sweat pours like flowing water**.
*Alternative:* If the **philtrum flattens**, death occurs in **seven days**.

If the **bones (Gǔ)** are failing, the **teeth turn yellow and fall out**, and death occurs in **ten days**.

All **floating pulses without roots** are fatal.
*The above are the roots of the five Zang and six Fu organs.*

**Chapter Twelve: Diagnosing Contrary Seasonal Pulses**

In **spring (wood season)**, when the **liver pulse** should arrive first, followed by the **heart**, then **lungs**, then **kidneys**, this is the **proper sequential pulse of the sovereign and minister**.
By **sixth month (earth season)**, when the **spleen pulse** should arrive first but instead **does not**, and the **kidney pulse** appears instead, this is called **"kidney contrary to spleen"**—death occurs in **seventy days**.
*What is meant by "kidney contrary to spleen"?*
In **summer (fire season)**, when the **heart pulse** should arrive first, followed by the **lungs**, but instead the **kidney pulse** appears—this is also **"kidney contrary to spleen"**.
*Critical period:* **fifth and sixth months**; **avoid days Jia-Ding (丙丁)**.

If the **spleen pulse** should arrive first in spring but instead **does not**, and the **liver pulse** arrives first, this is called **"spleen contrary to liver"**—death occurs in **thirty days**.
*Critical period:* **first and second months**; **avoid days Jia-Yi (甲乙)**.

If the **liver pulse** should arrive first in spring but instead **does not**, and the **kidney pulse** arrives first, this is called **"kidney contrary to liver"**—death occurs in **three years**.
*Critical period:* **seventh and eighth months**; **avoid days Geng-Xin (庚辛)**.

If the **heart pulse** should arrive first in summer but instead **does not**, and the **kidney pulse** arrives first, this is called **"kidney contrary to heart"**—death occurs in **two years**.
*Critical period:* **sixth month**; **avoid days Wu-Ji (戊己)**.

*The discussion of lung metal’s pulse here is omitted—this is an oversight in the *Southern Pointer*. Further clarification awaits the *Separate Records on Five Phases*.*

In treating illness, observe the **patient’s appearance, spirit, and complexion**, the **strength or decline of the pulse**, and whether the **disease is new or chronic**—only then may treatment proceed.
If **appearance and spirit align**, the **complexion is lustrous**, and the **pulse follows the seasons**, the case is **easy to treat**.
If **appearance and spirit contradict**, the **complexion is dull and lifeless**, the **pulse is firm and excessive**, and the **pulse defies the seasons**, the case is **difficult to treat**.

*Pulses that defy the seasons*:
- In **spring**, encountering a **lung pulse**,
- In **summer**, encountering a **kidney pulse**,
- In **autumn**, encountering a **heart pulse**,
- In **winter**, encountering a **spleen pulse**—
If these pulses arrive as **suspended, exhausted, or choppy**, they are called **"contrary to the seasons"**.
- In **spring and summer**, if the pulse is **deep and choppy**,
- In **autumn and winter**, if the pulse is **floating and large**,
- If the disease is **hot** but the pulse is **calm**,
- If there is **diarrhea** but the pulse is **large**,
- If there is **bleeding** but the pulse is **full**,
- If the disease is **internal** but the pulse is **firm and full**,
- If the disease is **external** but the pulse is **not full**—
These are all **contrary to the seasons** and **difficult to cure**.

The pulses of the **four seasons** all take **stomach qi (Wèi qì)** as their foundation. Even if the **sequential pulses of the sovereign and minister** appear, without **stomach qi**, recovery is difficult.
*What is the stomach pulse?*
It arrives **weak yet slippery**—this is called **easy to treat**.
