**Acupuncture Prescriptions**
**General Principles of Needling (第五, *General Principles of Needling*)**

The practitioner of needling must first understand the acupuncture points, reinforcing the deficient and reducing the excessive, directing the firm to the soft and the soft to the firm, applying urgency where needed and slowness where appropriate, ensuring the smooth flow of *honor* (荣) and *wei* (卫) qi—never deviating from principle.

The needle must never stray from the practitioner’s intent. The mouth should hold the thread as if grasping a bowstring, the eyes fixed inward, regulating *qi* and blood without erratic movement.

When the needle enters **one fen**, one perceives the *qi* of Heaven and Earth;
When it enters **two fen**, one discerns the *qi* of inhalation and exhalation—the rising and descending of Water and Fire;
When it enters **three fen**, one grasps the *qi* of the Four Seasons and Five Phases, the顺逆 *qi* of the Five Zang Organs and Six Fu Organs.

Needling the **skin and hair, pores and interstices** must not harm the muscles;
Needling the **muscles** must not harm the tendons and vessels;
Needling the **tendons and vessels** must not harm the bone marrow;
Needling the **bone marrow** must not harm the collateral vessels.

The **East (甲乙, Wood)** governs the Liver, Gallbladder, tendons, and *hun* (魂, ethereal soul).
The **South (丙丁, Fire)** governs the Heart, Small Intestine, blood vessels, and *shen* (神, spirit).
The **West (庚辛, Metal)** governs the Lung, Large Intestine, skin and hair, and *po* (魄, corporeal soul).
The **North (壬癸, Water)** governs the Kidney, Bladder, bone marrow, and *zhi* (志, will).
The **Center (戊己, Earth)** governs the Spleen, Stomach, muscles, and *yi* (意, intent).

If needling harms the **tendons**, the patient will stare blankly, losing their *hun* (魂).
If it harms the **blood vessels**, the patient will grow agitated, losing their *shen* (神).
If it harms the **skin and hair**, the patient will pant, losing their *po* (魄).
If it harms the **bone marrow**, the patient will groan, losing their *zhi* (志).
If it harms the **muscles**, the patient’s limbs will fail to contract, losing their *yi* (意).

These are the **Five Disruptions**—disturbances arising from improper needling.
If the practitioner further exceeds measure, death may follow.

Needling can kill the living but cannot revive the dead—
for the foolish who needle recklessly will die,
yet cannot restore life to the living.

Moreover, one must discern:
If a patient’s condition resembles death, do not treat them;
If a ruler’s governance resembles ruin, do not advise them.
Even the wisest sage cannot revive the dead or restore a fallen state.

Thus it is said:
*"Enter not a perilous state, dwell not in chaos."*

The foolish, greedy for gain, unaware of preservation or ruin,
risk their own lives and lineage—both perish together.
The collapse of states and families is also the way of medicine.

**Methods of Needling**
First, determine reinforcement or reduction.
The breath should align with the *Jiang* and *Han* rivers—
reinforcement and reduction must be measured like *sheng* (升) and *dou* (斗) vessels,
adhering to the prescribed methods of the classics,
ensuring *yin* and *yang* do not conflict.

*Zhen* (震, Thunder) marks the beginning of *yang* *qi*, Fire rules at *yín* (寅).
*Dui* (兑, Joy) marks the end of *yin* *qi*; *wu* (戊) is the Earth’s grave.

*Kàn* (坎, Water) is the *Tai Xuan Hua* (太玄华)—
at Winter Solstice, the night’s midpoint births the first *yang* line.
*Li* (离, Fire) is the *Tai Yang Jing* (太阳精),
symbolizing the central maiden.

To **reinforce**, needle from *mǎo* (卯, Southeast) to *nán* (南, South),
filling deficiencies—from *dìhù* (地户) to *xùn* (巽, Southeast) as *dìxū* (地虚, Earth’s emptiness).
To **reduce**, needle from *yǒu* (酉, Northwest).

*The Tianmen* (天门) lies in *qián* (乾, Heaven).
Needles are inserted by daylight, facing *yín* (寅) to *wǔ* (午).
They are removed by moonlight, from *shēn* (申) toward *wǔ* (午)—
*wǔ* being the position of the sun and moon’s light.

Thus, contemplating the Five Phases,
adjusting *honor* and *wei* *qi* to harmonize the body—
this is called the *Random Body Treasure* (随身宝).

**Methods of Using the *Fēngzhēn* (锋针, Sharp Needle)**
For swift disease removal:
First, reinforce with five breaths, then insert five *fen* and retain for ten breaths;
insert one *cùn* and retain for twenty breaths—
adjusting as the master directs.

For **urgent needling**, insert deeply and retain longer;
for **slow needling**, insert shallowly and remove swiftly;
for **large lesions**, allow slight bleeding;
for **slippery points**, remove quickly, insert shallowly, and retain longer;
for **tight points**, locate the vessel precisely, retain according to its *shùn* or *nì*, then remove swiftly—
press the point but do not bleed.

For the **weak and small**, avoid large needles.
If *qi* is deficient, supplement with herbs.

The **three other needles**—
the *zhèngzhōng* (正中), *pòyōng* (破痈), *jiānliú* (坚瘤), and *rùròu* (息肉)—
also treat diseases.

The **fire needle** also uses a sharp needle,
burned with oil flame to achieve fierce heat—
if insufficient, it harms the patient.

Apply every other day; after three sessions,
abundant pus and fluid indicate success.

*The Jiùquè* (巨阙), *Tàicāng* (太仓), and *Shàngxiàguǎn* (上下管)—
these six points in this row **forbid** fire needling.

For **large, hardened masses**, pause and rotate the needle briefly—
this is optimal.

Before each needling, examine the pulse:
if strong, proceed; if weak, do not needle hastily.

If fever and chills arise the night after needling,
this signifies the disease is struck—do not be alarmed.

**Moxibustion Principles (第六, *Moxibustion Principles*)**

All acupuncture points on the body are where the Zang-Fu Organs’ *honor* and *wei* *qi*, blood, and vessels circulate—
each with its designated pathways for urgent treatment.
Patients vary in age, stature, fatness, and leanness—
each requires careful consideration, measured proportionately;
do not apply uniformly, lest errors arise.

The **inch measurement** follows the ancient standard of eight *cùn* per *chǐ*,
taking the first joint of the middle finger (left for men, right for women) as one *cùn*.
If the hand’s length is indeterminate,
use the width of the thumb’s first joint as one *cùn*.

Skill lies in perception—
*"One *fú* (夫)"* refers to the span of four fingers.
Also, identify by muscle texture, creases, depressions, or the patient’s sensation of relief upon pressure—
only the meticulous will succeed.

Where the classics speak of *"three intervals"* (横三间),
this means three moxa cones between two intervals—
one *cùn* contains three moxa applications,
each moxa cone being three *fen*—
three *zhuàng* (壮) constitute one *cùn*.

The Yellow Emperor said:
*"Moxibustion without three *fen* is mere cruelty."*

The moxa cone must be large—
small or weak cones yield poor results.
Adjust according to intent.

**Methods of Moxibustion**
The patient must lie level; never tilt.
If the point is misaligned during moxibustion,
it benefits nothing—only damaging healthy flesh.

If the point is seated, then apply **moxibustion while seated**; if the point is prone, then apply **external moxibustion**; if the point is upright, then apply **moxibustion while standing**—to do otherwise risks missing the target.

When speaking of *zhuàng* (壮) counts,
if a robust adult encounters a deep-rooted illness,
one may **double the usual number**.
For the elderly, weak, or infirm,
one may **reduce it by half**.
According to Bian Que’s method,
some cases require up to **five hundred *zhuàng*** or **a thousand *zhuàng***—
each case must be adjusted as needed;
do not rigidly adhere to fixed rules.

The *Míngtáng* (明堂) classics often state:
*"Needle insertion to six *fēn* (分),
moxibustion to three *zhuàng*."*
No further instruction is given.

Cao’s method includes **a hundred *zhuàng*** or **fifty *zhuàng***,
and the *Xiǎopǐn* (小品) prescriptions also follow this.
Adjustments must be made based on the severity of the illness—
**do not blindly follow tradition**.

For infants over **seven days old** and up to **one year old**,
moxibustion should not exceed **seven *zhuàng***,
with cones no larger than **a sparrow’s droppings**.

In general, **moxibustion proceeds from yang to yin**—
begin at the **head, moving leftward downward**,
then proceed from the **head, moving rightward downward**.
Always **start from the upper body and move downward**,
and perform moxibustion **only after noon**,
when **yin-qi has not yet ascended**.
Needling or moxibustion before dawn,
when **the stomach-qi is weak and the body prone to dizziness**,
is forbidden—**beware**.

Such are the **primary principles**,
but **sudden acute cases** must not be treated by these fixed rules.

**Moxibustion techniques for raw or cooked effects**:
The **waist and above** constitute the **upper region**,
the **waist and below** the **lower region**.
The **external** is **yang**, nourishing the **honors** (荣),
the **internal** is **yin**, safeguarding the **defenses** (卫).
Thus, the **zàng-fǔ** (脏腑) and their **circulatory pathways** (经络)
are named so.

Hence, **men aged forty and above** have their **qi in the waist**,
while **women aged forty and above** have their **qi in the breasts**.
Thus, **men decline from below first**,
and **women decline from above first**.
When applying **raw or cooked moxibustion**,
one must **moderate and adjust accordingly**—
the method should **follow the shifting nature of the disease**.
The **general rule** is:
**External moxibustion should prioritize raw effects**,
**internal moxibustion should prioritize cooked effects**;
the rest may be adjusted as needed.

The **head** is the **source of the body**,
where **the spirit and *Dao* (神之所法) reside**.
Its **orifices** (气口) are sharp and clear,
and **the three hundred and sixty-five pathways** (络)
all converge upward at the head.
Thus, the **head is the gathering point of all yang**—
**head diseases must be carefully examined**,
and **moxibustion of its points must not be reckless**.
Overuse risks **injuring the spirit**,
or **exhausting yang-essence** (阳精),
causing **yin-spirit** (阴魄) to **rebel in turn**—
hence, **moxibustion of the head should not exceed a hundred *zhuàng***.

The **back and spine** serve as the **body’s transverse beam**,
where **the five *zàng* (脏) are struck or settled**,
and the **Taiyang meridian** (太阳) converges.
Here, **yin and yang disturbances** manifest,
and **cold or heat** become ailments.
**Excessive cooked moxibustion** harms the patient greatly.

The **arms and legs, hands and feet** are the **body’s branches**,
where **the spirit strikes into the five *zàng* and six *fǔ* (腑)**.
They **draw nourishment from blood and vessels** (脉),
**adapt to distant or near needs**,
**venture into deep or shallow terrain**,
and **sustain the meridians**.
Their **positions are narrow and shallow**—
thus, **moxibustion should be minimal**.
**Overuse** prevents **internal spirit** (内神) from entering,
**clogging the spirit’s flow**,
leading to **numbness and paralysis**—
**the arm may fail to lift**.
Hence, **moxibustion of the limbs should not be overcooked**.

Yet, **the internal organs** (腹脏) are of **essential nature**—
**indulging in the five flavors** (五味) without restraint
can **fester into chronic wind-cold**,
**impairing digestion** (水谷不消).
Thus, **cooked moxibustion is appropriate**.

For **Dàzhù (大杼), Jǐngzhōng (脊中), Shènshū (肾输), and Pángguāng (膀胱)**—
**eight critical points**—
up to **two hundred *zhuàng*** may be applied.

For **Xīnzhǔ (心主)** and **hand-foot *Tàiyīn* (太阴)**,
up to **sixty or seventy *zhuàng*** may be applied.

For **Sānlǐ (三里), Tàixī (太溪), Tàichōng (太冲)**,
and **the two *Yīnyáng Língquán* (阴阳陵泉)**,
and **the upper and lower *Lián* (廉)**,
up to **a hundred *zhuàng*** may be applied—
**three sessions** (三报) are required for full recovery.

For **Fùshàng (腹上), Xiàguǎn (下管), Zhōngguǎn (中管), Tàicāng (太仓), and Guānyuán (关元)**,
up to **a hundred *zhuàng*** may be applied—
**three sessions** are required for full recovery.

If the illness is severe,
**three sessions** are essential for healing.

For **deep-rooted cold and stagnant diseases**,
**cooked moxibustion is most effective**.

If treating **wind disorders of yin and yang** (阴阳风),
where the **body is hot and pulses are large**,
use **a sharp needle** (锋针) to **pierce the point**,
and **reinforce every other day**—
**one session** (一报) as before.

If treating **evil wind or spectral possession** (邪风鬼注),
where **pain is acute and *qi* is weak**,
use **a fine needle** (毫针) to **dispel the affliction**,
adjusting based on the **severity of the disease**.

**Superficial needling and internal medicine** must be applied as needed,
**adjusting and guiding the *qi***,
**harmonizing with the heavens** (与天同心).
With such care, **a hundred years of lasting peace** (永安)
and **no sudden illnesses** (横病) will follow.
This is the **essential summary**—
**do not pass it on unless wise**; keep it secret.

**For faint or subtle pulses** (微数之脉),
**moxibustion is strictly forbidden**—
it risks **injuring blood and vessels**,
and **scorching sinews and bones**.

**After sweating, do not apply moxibustion**—
this is **a grave violation**.

If the **pulse is floating and heat is intense**,
**moxibustion is forbidden**.

For **head, face, eyes, and throat**,
**raw moxibustion with minimal effect** is preferred;
for **arms and legs**,
**slightly cooked moxibustion** is advised—
**never apply excessively**.

For **chest, back, and abdomen**,
**strongly cooked moxibustion** is most suitable;
for the **waist and spine**,
**raw moxibustion with minimal effect** is preferred.

In all cases, **adjust according to intent**,
**modify as circumstances demand**,
**respond flexibly to a thousand changes and ten thousand variations**—
**no single rule can encompass all possibilities**.

For **warm diseases** (温病),
apply moxibustion **where the symptoms manifest**—
up to **a hundred *zhuàng* or more**,
or as few as **ninety *zhuàng***.

For **Dàzhù (大杼) and the stomach’s *guǎn* (胃管)**,
up to **fifty *zhuàng*** may be applied.

For **Xīnzhǔ (心主) and hand-foot *Tàiyáng* (太阳)**,
up to **fifty *zhuàng*** may be applied.

For **Sānlǐ (三里), Qūchí (曲池), and Tàichōng (太冲)**,
up to **a hundred *zhuàng*** may be applied—
**three sessions** are required for full recovery.

If **five *láo* (劳) ailments** (五劳) are **deep-seated and widespread**,
or if **poisonous *qi* (毒气) is the cause**,
**no more than fifty *zhuàng*** should be applied—
**three sessions** are required for full recovery.

If **attacking the *zàng-fǔ* (脏腑) causes abdominal pain**,
up to **a hundred *zhuàng*** may be applied.

For **sudden violent illnesses** (卒暴病),
or **spectral possession**,
**moxibustion of the head, face, and limbs should be frequent**,
while **abdomen and back should be minimal**—
**never exceed fifty *zhuàng***,
and **never reduce below three, five, seven, or nine *zhuàng***.

For **yin-yang damp-wind disorders** (阴阳濡风),
or **obstructed speech** (口啁僻),
**no more than thirty *zhuàng*** should be applied,
with **one session every three days**—
**three sessions** for mild cases,
**nine sessions** for severe cases.
This is because **damp-wind *qi* is subtle and penetrates deeply**—
**gentle heat and gradual *qi* guidance** are needed to **expel it slowly**.

If **urgent treatment is forced**,
the **damp-wind *qi* will spread and penetrate deeply**,
**becoming a chronic illness**—
**incurable**.

「Hence, one should use **gentle heat** (缓火).

For **all vacuity-related illnesses** (虚疾), where **phlegm and dampness** (水谷) congeal and stagnate, causing **wandering pain** (流离), **moxibustion of the abdomen and back** (灸腹背) should be applied **frequently** (宜多), but **never exceed one hundred *zhuàng*** (不过百壮).

In general, when a person **suddenly contracts wind** (卒暴得风) or is **struck by seasonal *qi*** (中时气), and suffers from **any affliction** (凡百所苦), **urgent moxibustion or acupuncture treatment** (急灸疗) must be administered—**never endure it and allow stagnation** (慎勿忍之停滞).

If it is a **minor official** (王相), he may recover without further issue (可得无他); otherwise, if delayed, **all such cases become difficult to cure** (皆难愈).

This principle **must be deeply understood** (深宜知此一条).

For those who **travel or reside in the Sichuan or Yunnan regions** (昊蜀地游宦), **moxibustion should be applied to three or four locations on the body** (体上常须三两处灸之), ensuring **the sores do not heal prematurely** (勿令疮暂瘥). Then, **malarial miasma** (瘴疠), **warm malaria** (温疟), and **toxic *qi*** (毒气) will **not afflict the person** (不能着人).

Thus, **moxibustion is widely practiced in Sichuan and Yunnan** (故昊蜀多行灸法).

There is the **Ahshi method** (阿是法): When a person has **disease or pain** (病痛), one should **press and knead the affected area** (即令捏其上). If **a moxa roll is wrapped directly over the spot** (若裹当其处), regardless of whether it aligns with **acupuncture points** (孔穴), the pain will **immediately ease** (即得便快). The site where the pain **is resolved** (成痛处) is called the **Ahshi point** (阿是). Both **moxibustion and acupuncture** (灸刺) prove effective here, hence the term **Ahshi point** (阿是穴).

The **Seventh Chapter on the Precautions of Medical Acupuncture and Moxibustion** (太医针灸宜忌第七) states:

*"Before performing acupuncture or moxibustion, one must first determine the **auspicious and inauspicious years** (行年宜忌) and the **location of the patient’s spirit** (人神所在). If the treatment does not correspond with these **precautions** (禁忌), it may proceed—though the full guidelines follow below."*

**Auspicious years for treatment (天医):**
**Wood-element years** (木命人行年) – **inauspicious for acupuncture or ingesting green medicines** (则不宜针及服青药).
**Fire-element years** (火命人行年) – **inauspicious for inducing sweating or ingesting red medicines** (则不宜汗及服赤药).
**Earth-element years** (土命人行年) – **inauspicious for inducing vomiting or ingesting yellow medicines** (则不宜吐及服黄药).
**Metal-element years** (金命人行年) – **inauspicious for moxibustion or ingesting white medicines** (则不宜灸及服白药).
**Water-element years** (水命人行年) – **inauspicious for purgation or ingesting black medicines** (则不宜下及服黑药).

If a physician **does not know these principles** (不知此法), his treatment will **become obstructed** (下手即困); if he encounters a patient whose **year, month, or day aligns with deep inauspiciousness** (年命厄会深), his treatment may **prove fatal** (下手即死).

**Correspondences between Heavenly Doctors (天医), Blood Taboos (血忌), and Month/Year/Time Taboos (月忌, 行年医法):**

**Monthly Auspicious Times (月傍通) and Heavenly Doctors (天医):**
卯　寅　丑　子　亥　戌　酉　申　未　巳　午　辰 – **auspicious for calling a master to treat illness** (呼师治病吉)
**Blood Taboos (血忌):**
丑　未　寅　申　卯　酉　辰　戌　巳　亥　午　子 – **inauspicious for acupuncture or moxibustion** (忌针灸)
**Monthly Inauspicious Times (月厌):**
戌　酉　申　未　午　巳　辰　卯　寅　丑　子　亥 – **inauspicious for acupuncture or moxibustion** (忌针灸)
**Four Excitations (四激):**
戌　戌　戌　丑　丑　丑　辰　辰　辰　未　未　未 – **inauspicious for acupuncture or moxibustion** (忌针灸)
**Monthly Killing Times (月杀):**
戌　巳　午　未　寅　卯　辰　亥　子　丑　申　酉 – **all actions are ominous; nothing may be undertaken** (不可举，百事凶).
According to *The Thousand Gold Prescriptions* (《千金翼》) and *The External Canon* (《外台》), these are the **Monthly Killing Times** (月杀): 丑　戌　未　辰 (repeated three times).
**Monthly Punishments (月刑):**
巳　子　辰　申　午　丑　寅　酉　未　亥　卯　戌 – **inauspicious for treating disease** (不疗病)
**Six Harmful Times (六害):**
巳　辰　卯　寅　丑　子　亥　戌　酉　申　未　午 – **inauspicious for treating disease** (不疗病)

If the **auspicious monthly times** (天医) are applied, **calling a master to treat illness is fortunate** (呼师避病吉); if the **punitive or harmful times** (刑害) are applied, **the treatment is ominous** (上凶).

**Determining Auspicious Years (行年医法):**
**Heavenly Doctors (天医) for the Year:**
脐　心　肘　咽　口　头　脊　膝　足
一　二　三　四　五　六　七　八　九
十　十一　十二　十三　十四　十五　十六　十七　十八

**Heavenly Doctors (天医) for the Year (by stem-branch):**
卯　戌　子　未　酉　亥　辰　寅　巳　午　丑　申

**Method to Seek the Heavenly Doctor of the Year:**
*"Normally, add the **transmitting year** (传送) to the **Grand Duke Year** (太岁), and the **Grand Duke Year’s position** (太乙下) is the Heavenly Doctor."*

**Method to Seek the Heavenly Doctor of the Month:**
*"For **yang months** (阳月), add **Great Auspiciousness** (大吉); for **yin months** (阴月), add **Small Auspiciousness** (小吉) to the **monthly stem-branch** (月建). The **Functionary’s position** (功曹下) is the **Ghostly Path** (鬼道), and the **transmitting year’s position** (传送下) is the Heavenly Doctor."*

**Method to Avoid Illness (避病法):**
*"Add **Small Auspiciousness** (小吉) to the **monthly stem-branch** (月建). The **Heavenly Doctor’s position** (登明下) is the Heavenly Doctor—**this is where one may avoid illness** (可於此避病)."*

**Method to Treat Illness (治病法):**
*"Add the **monthly stem-branch** (月将) to the **hourly stem-branch** (时), and the **Heavenly Doctor’s position** (天医) to the **patient’s year** (加病人年)—**this is where one may treat malaria** (治之疟)."*

**Method to Call a Master (唤师法):**
*"In the hours of **未、卯、巳、亥、酉**, the **spirit resides elsewhere** (鬼所在)—**calling a master here is inauspicious** (唤师凶)."*

**Right Twelve Divisions of the Body Where the Spirit Resides**
*(All are forbidden from acupuncture, moxibustion, or injury; be cautious.)*

**Daytime Taboos (by Heavenly Stems and Earthly Branches):**
- **1st Day (Jīa, 甲):** **Head**
- **2nd Day (Yǐ, 乙):** **Neck**
- **3rd Day (Bǐng, 丙):** **Shoulders and Arms**
- **4th Day (Dīng, 丁):** **Chest and Ribs**
- **5th Day (Wù, 戊):** **Abdomen**
- **6th Day (Jǐ, 己):** **Back**

**Verified and corrected by the Song Dynasty officials: Ling Yì (林亿) and others, appointed as Palace Secretariat (Mìgé, 秘阁) and Minister of the Imperial Sacrifices (Shǒuliáng Shǒu Tàicháng Shǎoqiè, 奉郎守太常少卿).**

**Needle and Moxibustion Acupuncture Points Treatise**
**The Principle of Corresponding Acupuncture Points**
**The Treatise states:** *(Whenever it is said that an acupuncture point corresponds to a disease, the point’s name is listed above, and the symptoms below. Sometimes a single ailment involves dozens of points, or several ailments share one point—all must be considered and applied flexibly as needed in practice. If a point requires needling, then needle it to reinforce or reduce; if needling is contraindicated, simply apply moxibustion. However, the fundamental method of moxibustion is this: as long as the acupuncture point and the needle pose no restrictions, once the needling—whether with a white needle or a warm needle—is complete, then apply moxibustion. This is the mark of a skilled physician. For the disease of leg qi (脚氣), needling is particularly effective. If one needles but does not moxibustion, or moxibustions but does not needle, this is not the practice of a skilled physician. If one uses needle and moxibustion without medicine, or medicine without needle and moxibustion, this is even more far from the practice of a skilled physician. It is only lamentable that in the lower strata of society, those who know needling are few. Therefore, students must deeply understand the proper application of needle therapy, mastering both warm needling (燔针) and white needling (白针). To know needling and medicine alike is indeed the way of a skilled physician.)*

**Volume 90 of *Essential Prescriptions for Emergency Use* (千金要方)**

**Head Disorders:**

- **Tóuwéi (头维), Dàlíng (大陵):** govern headache as if the head were broken, eye pain as if the eyes were being torn out.

- **Nǎohù (脑户), Tōngtiān (通天), Nǎokōng (脑空):** govern heavy, painful headaches.

- **Also stated:** Shūmài governs wind-induced pain behind the ears.

- **Also stated:** Shàngxīng governs wind-induced pain radiating from the head to the jaw.
- **Xìnhuì (囟会):** governs wind-induced dizziness of the head and headache, with a pale complexion.
- **Tiānyǒng (天牖), Fēngmén (风门), Kūnlún (昆仑), Guānyuán (关元), Guānchōng (关冲):** govern wind-induced dizziness and headache.

- **The *Jiǎ-Yǐ* (甲乙) Treatise states:** dizziness, eye pain, half-sided cold-induced headache.
- **Tiānzhù (天柱), Táodào (陶道), Dàzhù (大杼, also called Běnshén 本神), Kǒngzuì (孔最), Hòuxī (后溪):** govern headache.
- **Mùchuāng (目窗), Zhōngzhǔ (中渚), Wángǔ (完骨), Mìngmén (命门), Fēnglóng (丰隆), Tàibái (太白), Wàiqiū (外丘), Tōnggǔ (通谷), Jīnggǔ (京骨), Línqì (临泣), Xiǎohǎi (小海), Chéngjīn (承筋), Yánglín (阳谷), Yánglíngquán (阳陵泉):** govern headache, cold and heat, sweating, without aversion to cold.

- **Xiāolián (消滦), Běnshén (本神), Tōngtiān (通天), Qiángjiān (强间), Fēngfǔ (风府), Yīnmén#1 (喑门):** govern neck pain as if pulled taut, so severe that turning the head left or right is impossible.

「Yángbái (阳白), Shàngxīng (上星), Běnshén (本神), Dàdū (大都), Qǔquán (曲泉), Xiáxī (侠溪), Sānjiān (三间), Qiángǔ (前谷), Cuánzhú (攒竹), Yùzhěn (玉枕), govern sudden eye strain and upward fixation of the eyes.

Shùgǔ (束骨), governs ulceration and redness of the canthus.

Yèmén (掖门), governs sudden eye discomfort.

Shāngyáng (商阳), Jùwò (巨窌), Shàngguān (上关), Chéngguāng (承光), Tóngzǐwò (瞳子窌), Luòquè (络却), govern total blindness with no perception of light.

Qīmén (期门), governs greenish eyes with vomiting.

Fēngchí (风池), Nǎohù (脑户), Yùzhěn (玉枕), Fēngfǔ (风府), Shàngxīng (上星), govern eye pain with impaired vision. Treat first with **Zhěnxī (譩嘻)**, then with **Tiānyǒu (天牖)** and **Fēngchí (风池)**.

Tàiyuán (太泉), governs greenish opacity in the pupil.

**Nasal Disorders:**

Shéntíng (神庭), Cuánzhú (攒竹), Yíngxiāng (迎香), Fēngmén (风门), Héngǔ (合谷), Zhìyīn (至阴), Tōnggǔ (通谷), govern nasal congestion with clear mucus discharge.

Qǔchā (曲差), Shàngxīng (上星), Yíngxiāng (迎香), Sùmìng (素命), Shuǐwò (水窌), Yìnjiāo (龈交), Tōngtiān (通天), Héwò (禾窌), Fēngfǔ (风府), govern nasal obstruction, labored breathing, nasal congestion with excessive mucus, epistaxis with ulcers.

Shuǐgōu (水沟), Tiānyǒu (天牖), govern inability to retain mucus, loss of smell.

*The Jia-Yi [甲乙] states:* Nasal congestion with inability to breathe, and uncontrolled epistaxis.

Yìnjiāo (龈交), governs nasal polyps, pain in the nasal bridge and forehead, and nasal ulcers.

Chénglíng (承灵), Fēngchí (风池), Fēngmén (风门), Zhěnxī (譩嘻), Hòuxī (后溪), govern nasal bleeding, obstruction, and labored breathing.

Nǎokōng (脑空), Jiǎoyīn (窍阴), govern nasal carbuncles, progressing to malignant nasal ulcers.

Fēngmén (风门), Wǔchù (五处), govern frequent, incessant sneezing.

**General Treatment for Throat Stricture (喉痹):**
For sudden rib-side inversion in cases of throat stricture, first puncture **Chōngmài (沖脉)**, then puncture Sānlǐ (三里) and Yúnmén (雲門), draining each.

Additionally, pricking the tip of the little finger and inducing bleeding immediately resolves the condition.

All cases are treated with reinforcing-needling of **Shǒu Tàiyīn (手太阴)** to induce sweating.

**General Treatment for Sudden Heart Pain with Sweating (卒心痛汗出):**
Prick **Dàdūn (大敦)**, inducing bleeding immediately resolves the condition.

For cases of **heart fullness (心实)**, sudden heart pain occurs.
For cases of **heart emptiness (心虚)**, heart restlessness occurs, with a fearful sensation preventing movement and loss of intelligence.

**Fùjié (腹结)** governs *pain encircling the umbilicus, radiating to the heart* **(绕脐痛抢心).**

**Chōngmén (冲门)** governs *cold accumulating in the abdomen, causing distension and pain with erratic discharge* **(寒气满腹中积，痛疼淫滦).**

**Jiānmèi (间使)** governs *cold invasion with shortness of breath* **(寒中少气).**

**Yǐnbái (隐白)** governs *abdominal cold with cold distension and dyspnea* **(腹中寒，冷气胀喘).**

**Jiūwěi (鸠尾)** governs *abdominal skin pain and itching* **(腹皮痛，搔痒).**

**Zhōngjí (中极)** governs *abdominal heat pain* **(腹中热痛).**

**Shuǐfèn (水分), Shímén (石门)** govern *lower abdominal constriction and pain* **(小腹中拘急痛).**

**Jùquè (巨阙), Shàngguǎn (上管), Shímén (石门), Yīnjiāo (阴跷)** govern *abdominal fullness with sudden pain and sweating* **(腹中满，暴痛汗出).**

**Xíngjiān (行间)** governs *abdominal heat pain radiating upward to the heart, with epigastric fullness* **(腹痛而热，上柱心，心下满).**

**Tàixī (太溪)** governs *abdominal pain radiating inward* **(腹中相引痛).**

**Yǒngquán (涌泉)** governs *wind entering the abdomen, causing lower abdominal pain* **(风入腹中，小腹痛).**

**Fēnglóng (丰隆)** governs *chest pain as if pierced, with abdominal pain as if cut by a knife* **(胸痛如刺，腹若刀切痛).**

---
**Distension and Fullness Diseases:**

**Zhōngjí (中极)** governs *lower abdominal masses as hard as stone, with abdominal fullness* **(小腹积聚坚如石，小腹满).**
It is also said that **Zhōngjí (中极)** governs *abdominal distension from cold invasion* **(寒中腹胀).**

**Tōnggǔ (通谷)** governs *congealed masses and retained fluids, chest fullness, and indigestion* **(结积留饮癖囊，胸满，饮食不消).**

**Pángguāngshū (膀胱输)** governs *firm masses and accumulations* **(坚结积聚).**

**Shàngguǎn (上管)** governs *epigastric rigidity, cold accumulations, and distension* **(心下坚，积聚冷胀).**

**Wèiguǎn (胃管), Sānjiāoshū (三焦输)** govern *lower abdominal masses as large as a tray, gastric distension, and indigestion* **(小腹积聚，坚大如盘，胃胀，食饮不消).**

**Sānlǐ (三里), Zhāngmén (章门), Jīngmén (京门), Lìduì (厉兑), Nèitíng (内庭), Yīngǔ (阴谷), Luòquè (络却), Kūnlún (昆仑), Shāngqiū (商丘), Yīngǔ (阴谷), Qǔquán (曲泉), Yīnlíngquán (阴陵泉)** govern *abdominal distension and fullness preventing rest* **(腹胀满不得息).**
It is also said that **Yīnlíngquán (阴陵泉)** governs *abdominal distension with loss of appetite, flank fullness, abdominal fluid accumulation, and inability to lie down* **(腹中胀，不嗜食，胁下满，腹中盛水，胀逆不得卧).**
It is also said that **Shāngqiū (商丘)** governs *abdominal fullness with persistent discomfort and epigastric cold pain* **(腹中满，向向然不便，心下有寒痛).**

**Yǐnbái (隐白)** governs *abdominal distension with inverted breathing* **(腹胀逆息).**
It is also said that **Yǐnbái (隐白)** governs *abdominal fullness with vomiting* **(腹满喜呕).**

**Chǐzé (尺泽)** governs *abdominal distension with dyspnea and shivering* **(腹胀喘振栗).**

**Jiěxī (解溪)** governs *severe lower abdominal heaviness* **(腹大下重).**
It is also said that **Jiěxī (解溪)** governs *rebellious cold rising to the chest, with abdominal distension* **(厥气上柱，腹大).**

**Dàzhōng (大钟)** governs *abdominal fullness with difficult defecation* **(腹满便难).**

**Gāngshū (肝输), Bāohuì (包肓)** govern *lower abdominal fullness* **(小腹满).**

**Shuǐdào (水道)** governs *lower abdominal distension and fullness, with pain radiating to the perineum* **(小腹胀满，痛引阴中).**

**Rìyuè (日月), Dàhéng (大横)** govern *lower abdominal heat with a desire to sigh excessively* **(小腹热，欲走太息).**

**Wěizhōng (委中)** governs *lower abdominal rigidity and swelling* **(小腹坚肿).**

**Guānyuán (关元)** governs *cold entering the abdomen* **(寒气入腹).**

**Xuángǔ (悬枢)** governs *abdominal masses moving upward and downward* **(腹中积上下行).**

**Xuánzhōng (悬钟)** governs *abdominal fullness* **(腹满).**

**Píshū (脾输), Dàchángshū (大肠输)** govern *abdominal distension radiating to the spine, with excessive eating and drinking leading to emaciation—known as "food stagnation"* **(腹中气胀引脊痛，食饮多而身赢瘦，名曰食晦).**
First take **Pítú (脾俞)**, then **Jìlèi (季肋).**

**Yīnshì (阴市)** governs *abdominal fullness, flaccidity, and shortness of breath* **(腹中满，痿厥少气).**

**Qiūxū (丘墟)** governs *large hernias with abdominal rigidity* **(大疝腹坚).**

**Jīngmén (京门)** governs *abdominal distension from alternating cold and heat* **(寒热腹#¹胀).**

**Gāoqū (高曲)** governs *abdominal masses* **(腹中积聚).**

**Huángshū (肓输)** governs *large abdominal cold hernias* **(大腹寒疝).**
*The Jia-Yi [Classical]* states: *cold invasion of the large abdomen* **(界一大腹寒中).**

**Tiāngōng (天枢)** governs *abdominal distension with intestinal rumbling and upward-rising gas* **(腹胀肠鸣，气上冲胸).**

**Qìchōng (气冲)** governs *severe abdominal heat with unrest, abdominal gas accumulation, sudden distension, urinary retention, and erratic discharge* **(腹中大热不安，腹有大气，暴胀满，癃，淫滦).**

**Tàichōng (太冲)** governs *emaciation, fear, insufficient breath, and abdominal stagnation* **(赢瘦恐惧，气不足，腹中悒悒).**

**Qímén (期门)** governs *severe abdominal rigidity preventing rest, distension, numbness, and particularly large lower abdomen* **(腹大坚，不得息，胀痹满，小腹尤大).**

**Tàiyīn Xì (太阴郄)** governs *abdominal fullness and masses* **(腹满积聚).**

**Tàixī (太溪)** governs *abdominal distension and swelling* **(腹中胀肿).**

**Héngmén (衡门)** governs *abdominal fullness from cold, with abdominal masses and pain* **(寒气腹满，腹中积聚疼痛).**

**Jùquè (巨阙), Shàngguǎn (上管)** govern *abdominal distension, visceral distension, and epigastric fullness* **(腹胀、五脏胀、心腹满).**

**Zhōngguǎn (中管)** governs *abdominal distension with obstruction, dysentery, constipation, mental distress impairing the body, gas accumulation causing severe abdominal pain, abscess formation, and alternating upward/downward movement* **(腹胀不通，疰，大便坚，忧思损伤，气积聚，腹中甚痛，作脓肿，往来上下).**

**Yīnjiāo (阴交)** governs *wandering visceral breath* **(五脏游气).**

**Sānlǐ (三里), Xíngjiān (行间), Qǔquán (曲泉)** govern *abdominal anger and fullness* **(腹瞋满).**

**Xiàngǔ (陷谷)** governs *severe abdominal fullness with frequent belching* **(腹大满，喜噫).**

**Chōngyáng (冲阳)** governs *severe abdominal fullness with loss of appetite* **(腹大不嗜食).**

**Wǔlǐ (五里)** governs *epigastric distension and pain with upward-rising breath* **(心下胀满而痛，上气).**

**Tàibái (太白), Gōngsūn (公孙)** govern *abdominal distension with indigestion, tympanites, and abdominal gas accumulation* **(腹胀，食不化，鼓胀，腹中气大满).**

**Lòugǔ (漏谷)** governs *intestinal rumbling, forced yawning, sadness, breath reversal, and abdominal tension* **(肠鸣、强欠、心悲、气逆，腹缜满急).**

**Lìgōu (蠡沟)** governs *frequent belching, fear, palpitations, insufficient breath, and abdominal stagnation* **(数噫恐悸，气不足，腹中悒悒).**

**In cases of abdominal heat with thirst and excessive saliva—this is the roundworm.**
Gather the abdomen with the hand and press firmly without allowing it to move, then pierce **Zhōngguǎn (中管)** with a large needle, holding it firmly in place before withdrawing.

**For abdominal fullness and pain preventing rest:**
Lie supine with one knee bent and one leg extended, then insert a needle into **Qìchōng (气冲)** three inches deep. When *qi* arrives, bleed it.

**Yīndū (阴都)** governs *epigastric fullness, breath reversal, and intestinal rumbling* **(心满、气逆、肠鸣).**

**Xiàngǔ (陷谷), Wēnliú (温留), Lòugǔ (漏谷), Fùliú (复留), Yánggāng (阳纲)** govern *intestinal rumbling with pain* **(肠鸣而痛).**

**Shànglián (上廉)** governs *intestinal rumbling chasing one another* **(肠鸣相追逐).**

**Wèishū (胃输)** governs *abdominal fullness with rumbling* **(腹满而鸣).**

「Zhāngmén (章门), governs *intestinal rumbling with a full, resonant sound* **(肠呜盈盈然).**

**Yīngchuāng (膺窗), governs *intestinal rumbling with a gushing, overflowing sensation* **(肠鸣泄注).**

**Tàibái (太白), Gōngsūn (公孙), govern *intestinal rumbling* **(肠鸣).**

**Qímén (脐中), governs *constant intestinal rumbling, with qi surging upward to the heart* **(肠中常鸣，上冲心).**

**Yīnjiāo (阴交), governs *intestinal rumbling with a cascading sound, as if water is flowing* **(肠鸣濯濯，如有水声).**

**Diseases of urination and defecation:**
**Fēnglóng (丰隆), governs *difficulty in urination and defecation, with straining* **(大小便涩难).**
**Yíngchōng (营冲) four acupoints, govern *impaired urination and defecation* **(大小便不利).**
**Chángqiáng (长强), Xiǎochángshū (小肠输), govern *difficulty in urination and defecation, with dribbling and retention* **(大小便难，淋癃).**
**Shuǐdào (水道), governs *constriction of the Triple Burner (三焦), with obstructed urination and defecation* **(大小便不通).**
**Zhìbiān (秩边), Bāohuì (包肓), govern *urinary retention (癃闭), heaviness in the lower abdomen (下重), and difficulty in defecation* **(大小便难).**
**Huìyīn (会阴), governs *all diseases of the genital region (阴中诸病), with pain radiating between front and back (前后相引痛), preventing urination and defecation* **(不得大小便).**
**It is also said to govern *difficulty in urination, with heat in the urethral orifice (窍中热)* **(小便难).**

**Dàchángshū (大肠输), Bāmìng (八命), govern *smooth urination and defecation* **(大小便利).**
**Yánggāng (阳纲), governs *uncontrolled bowel movements (大便不节), with yellowish-red urine (小便赤黄), and intestinal rumbling with gushing diarrhea* **(肠呜泄注).**
**Qūgǔduān (屈骨端), governs *impaired urination* **(小便不利).**
**For frequent loose stools (大便泄数), cauterize Tiānshū (天枢).**

**Láogōng (劳宫), governs *persistent rectal bleeding (大便血不止), with red urine* **(尿赤).**
**Tàixī (太溪), governs *yellow urine (尿黄), with difficulty in defecation* **(大便难).**
**Zhōnglì (中窌), Shímén (石门), Chéngshān (承山), Tàichōng (太冲), Zhōngguǎn (中管), Dàzhōng (大锺), Tàixī (太溪), Chéngjīn (承筋), govern *difficulty in defecation* **(大便难).**
**It is also said that Tàichōng (太冲) governs *urinary retention, with pain in the upper genital region* **(阴上痛).**
**It is also said that Zhōngguǎn (中管) governs *heat in the small intestine (小肠有热), with yellow urine* **(尿黄).**
**Dàzhōng (大锺) governs *difficulty in defecation* **(大便难).**
**Kūnlún (昆仑), governs *obstructed defecation* **(不得大便).**
**Yùshū (育输), governs *dry stools (大便乾), with severe abdominal pain* **(腹中切痛).**
**Shígùan (石关), governs *constipation (大便闭), with cold qi causing blockage (寒气结), and a firm, full sensation in the heart/epigastrium* **(心坚满).**
**Zhōngzhù (中注), Fúbù (浮部), govern *heat in the lower abdomen (小腹热), with firm stools* **(大便坚).**
**Shànglián (上廉), Xiàlián (下廉), govern *difficulty in urination, with yellow urine* **(小便难，黄).**
**Shǎofǔ (少府), Sānlǐ (三里), govern *impaired urination (小便不利), with urinary retention* **(癃).**
**Shènshū (肾输), governs *difficulty in urination (小便难), with turbid red urine (赤浊), and alternating cold and heat in the bones (骨寒热).**
**Hénggǔ (横骨), Dàjù (大巨), Qīmén (期门), govern *fullness in the lower abdomen (小腹满), with difficulty in urination (小便难), and genital region heaviness* **(阴下纵).**
**Dàdūn (大敦), Jīmén (箕门), Wěizhōng (委中), Wěiyáng (委阳), govern *genital spasms and urinary incontinence (阴跳遗尿); difficulty in urination* **(小便难).**
**Zhōngjí (中极), Lígōu (蠡沟), Lòugǔ (漏谷), Chéngfú (承扶), Zhìyīn (至阴), govern *impaired urination (小便不利), with seminal emission* **(失精).**
**It is also said that Chéngfú (承扶) governs *scrotal swelling (民中肿), with stools passing straight out (大便直出), cold in the scrotum (阴胞有寒), and difficulty in urination* **(小便不利).**
**Yīnlíngquán (阴陵泉), governs *fullness below the heart (心下满), with cold in the middle (寒中), and difficulty in urination* **(小便不利).**
**Guānyuán (关元), governs *obstructed urinary bladder (胞闭塞), with obstructed urination (小便不通), and urinary retention due to exhaustion, heat, or stones* **(劳热石淋).**
**It is also said to govern *stone-related urinary retention (石淋), with thirty-six ailments below the navel (脐下三十六疾), preventing urination (不得小便), and cauterization of the foot’s Tàiyáng (太阳) channel* **(并灸足太阳).**
**It is also said to govern *injury to the middle causing urinary bleeding* **(伤中尿血).**
**Lièquē (列缺), governs *urinary heat and pain* **(小便热痛).**
**Jīngmén (京门), Zhàohǎi (照海), govern *yellow urine (尿黄), with obstructed waterways* **(水道不通).**
**It is also said that Jīngmén (京门) governs *overflowing drink (溢饮), with obstructed waterways (水道不通), and yellow urine* **(溺黄).**
**Yīnjiāo (阴交), Shímén (石门), Wěiyáng (委阳), govern *firm lower abdominal pain radiating to the genital region (小腹坚痛引阴中), with obstructed urination* **(不得小便).**
**Dàlíng (大陵), governs *red eyes (目赤), with urine resembling blood* **(小便如血).**
**Chéngjiān (承浆), governs *yellowish-red urine (小便赤黄), or occasional urinary incontinence* **(或时不禁).**
**Wángǔ (完骨), Xiǎochángshū (小肠输), Báihuánshū (白环输), Pángguāngshū (膀胱输), govern *yellowish-red urine* **(小便赤黄).**
**Qiángǔ (前谷), Wěizhōng (委中), govern *difficulty in urination with red urine* **(尿赤难).**
**Yīngǔ (阴谷), governs *difficulty in urination (尿难), with genital flaccidity and dysfunction* **(阴痿不用).**
**Zhōngfēng (中封), Xíngjiān (行间), govern *shivering with white urine (振寒溲白), difficulty and pain in urination* **(尿难、痛).**
**It is also said that Xíngjiān (行间) governs *urinary retention (癃闭), with pain in the penis* **(茎中痛).**

**For urine of varying colors—green, yellow, red, white, or black—**
**Green urine is treated by taking *井 (well) points*,
Yellow urine by taking *输 (output) points*,
Red urine by taking *荣 (nutrient) points*,
White urine by taking *经 (channel) points*,
Black urine by taking *合 (confluence) points* **(井、输、荣、经、合).**

**Guānyuán (关元), Yǒngquán (涌泉), govern *urinary retention due to bladder obstruction (胞转气淋), and also frequent urination* **(小便数).**
**Yīnlíngquán (阴陵泉), Guānyuán (关元), govern *irregular cold and heat, with kidney disease (肾病), preventing bending forward or backward (不可以俯仰), and urinary retention with yellow urine* **(气癃尿黄).**
**Qìchōng (气冲), governs *abdominal fullness and heat (腹中满热), with urinary retention and obstruction* **(淋闭不得尿).**
**Qǔquán (曲泉), governs *urinary retention with genital flaccidity* **(癃闭阴痿).**
**Jiāoxìn (交信), governs *urinary retention due to stagnant qi* **(气淋).**
**Rángǔ (然谷), governs *urinary retention with hernia* **(癃疝).**
**Fùliú (复留), governs *urinary retention* **(淋).**
**It is also said to govern *blood in the urine* **(血淋).**
**Xuánzhōng (悬钟), governs *the five types of urinary retention* **(五淋).**
**Dàdūn (大敦), Qìmén (气门), govern *the five types of urinary retention, preventing urination* **(五淋不得尿).**
**Tōnglǐ (通里), governs *urinary incontinence* **(遗溺).**
**Qǔgǔ (曲骨), governs *lower abdominal distension (小腹胀), with blood in the urine and urinary retention (血癃), and difficulty in urination* **(小便难).**
**Guānyuán (关元), Zhōngfǔ (中府), Shénmén (神门), govern *urinary incontinence* **(遗尿).**
**In the *Jia-Yi* (甲乙) text, Zhōngfǔ (中府) is written as Wěizhōng (委中).**
**Yīnlíngquán (阴陵泉), Yánglíngquán (阳陵泉), govern *unaware urinary incontinence* **(失禁遗尿不自知).**

**Diarrhea and dysentery diseases:**
**Jīngmén (京门), Rángǔ (然谷), Yīnlíngquán (阴陵泉), govern *chronic diarrhea that fails to resolve* **(洞泄不化).**
**Jiāoxìn (交信), governs *diarrhea with red and white mucus (泄痢赤白), with blood leakage* **(漏血).**
**Dāntián (丹田), governs *uncontrollable diarrhea (泄痢不禁), with lower abdominal colic* **(小腹绞痛).**
**Fùliú (复留), governs *intestinal prolapse with purulent bloody stools (肠澼便脓血), with heaviness after diarrhea (泄痢后重), and abdominal pain resembling tetanic spasms* **(腹痛如痉状).**
**Píshū (脾输), governs *diarrhea with inability to eat (泄痢不食), and food failing to nourish the skin and muscles* **(食不生肌肤).**
**Xiǎochángshū (小肠输), governs *diarrhea with purulent bloody stools of five colors (泄痢脓血五色), with lower abdominal heaviness and pain* **(重下肿痛).**
**Guānyuán (关元), Tàixī (太溪), govern *unresolving diarrhea* **(泄痢不止).**
**Jīngmén (京门), Kūnlún (昆仑), govern *chronic diarrhea with whole-body pain* **(洞泄体痛).**
**Tiānshū (天枢), governs *winter diarrhea due to excessive cold exposure (冬月重感于寒则泄), with navel pain (当脐痛), and sharp lower abdominal pain between the intestines and stomach caused by wandering qi* **(肠胃间游气切痛).**
**Fùāi (腹哀), governs *purulent bloody stools (便脓血), with cold in the middle (寒中), and undigested food (食不化), causing lower abdominal pain* **(腹中痛).**
**Chǐzé (尺泽), governs *vomiting and diarrhea with both upper and lower discharges (呕泄上下出), with pain under both ribs* **(两胁下痛).**
**Shùgǔ (束骨), governs *intestinal prolapse with diarrhea* **(肠澼泄).**
**Chángqiáng (长强), governs *head heaviness with chronic diarrhea* **(头重洞泄).**
**Tàibái (太白), governs *abdominal distension (腹胀), with undigested food (食不化), tendency to vomit (喜呕), and diarrhea containing purulent blood* **(泄有脓血).**
**Dìjī (地机), governs *chronic diarrhea with mucus (溏痕), with lower abdominal pain (腹中痛), and visceral numbness (脏痹).**
**Yīnlíngquán (阴陵泉), Yǐnbái (隐白), govern *heat in the chest (胸中热), with sudden diarrhea* **(暴泄).**
**Tàichōng (太冲), Qǔquán (曲泉), govern *prolapse with diarrhea, and dysentery with blood discharge* **(搪泄，痢注下血).**

**Kidney Shu (腎輸), Zhāngmén (章門):**
Govern *cold in the abdomen (寒中), chronic diarrhea with undigested food (洞泄不化).*

**Huìyáng (會陽):**
Govern *cold in the abdomen (腹中有寒), diarrhea with prolapse (泄注), and intestinal prolapse with blood discharge (肠澼便血).*

**Sānjiāo Shu (三焦輸), Xiǎocháng Shu (小腸輸), Xiàxiàn (下窌), Yìshě (意舍), Zhāngmén:**
Govern *intestinal rumbling (肠鸣), abdominal distension (胪胀), and tendency toward diarrhea with prolapse (欲泄注).*

**Zhōngxiàn (中窌):**
Govern *abdominal distension (腹胀) and chronic diarrhea (飧泄).*

**Dàcháng Shu (大腸輸):**
Govern *intestinal rumbling (肠鸣), abdominal rigidity and swelling (腹瞋肿), and sudden diarrhea (暴泄).*

---
**Diabetes (消渴病):**
**Chéngjiān (承浆), Yìshě (意舍), Guānchōng (关冲), Rángǔ (然谷):**
Govern *excessive thirst and drinking (消渴嗜饮).*
It is also said:
**Yìshě (意舍):**
Govern *excessive thirst with body heat (消渴身热), and jaundiced complexion (面目黄).*

**Láogōng (劳宫):**
Govern *severe thirst with inability to eat (苦渴食不下).*

**Qǔchí (曲池):**
Govern *alternating cold and heat with thirst (寒热渴).*

**Yǐnbái (隐白):**
Govern *thirst (饮渴).*

**Xíngjiān (行间), Tàichōng (太冲):**
Govern *hoarseness and excessive thirst (哑乾善渴).*

**Shāngqiū (商丘):**
Govern *internal agitation with thirst (烦中渴).*

---
**Edema (水肿病):**
**Gōngsūn (公孙):**
Govern *head and facial swelling (头面肿).*

**Shuǐgōu (水沟):**
Govern *edema (水肿) and fullness in the philtrum (人中满).*

**Wèicāng (胃仓):**
Govern *edema with abdominal distension (水肿胪胀), inability to eat or drink (食饮不下), and aversion to cold (恶寒).*

**Zhāngmén (章門):**
Govern *general body moistness (身润), stone-like edema (石水), and body swelling (身肿).*

**Wūyì (屋翳):**
Govern *body swelling with painful skin (身肿皮痛), making clothing unbearable (不可近衣).*

**Zhōngfǔ (中府), Jiànshǐ (间使), Hégǔ (合谷):**
Govern *facial and abdominal swelling (面腹肿).*

**Yīnjiāo (阴交), Shímén (石门):**
Govern *watery edema (水胀), with water-qi circulating in the skin (水气行皮中), causing the lower abdomen to feel taut (小腹皮敦敦然), dark urine (小便黄), and fullness of breath (气满).*

**Guānyuán (关元):**
Govern *fullness in the lower abdomen (小腹满) and stone-like edema (石水).*

**Sìmǎn (四满), Rángǔ (然谷):**
Govern *abdominal distension with stone-like edema (大腹石水).*

**Guānmén (关门):**
Govern *body swelling with heaviness (身肿身重).*

**Tiānhú (天枢), Fēnglóng (丰隆), Lìduì (厉兑), Xiàngǔ (陷谷), Chōngyáng (冲阳):**
Govern *facial floating edema (面浮肿).*
It is also said:
**Fēnglóng (丰隆):**
Govern *swelling of the limbs (四肢肿) and body dampness (身湿).*

**Tiānfǔ (天府):**
Govern *body distension with reversed breathing (身胀逆息), inability to lie down (不得卧), wind-induced sweating with body swelling (风汗身肿), and frequent spitting with wheezing (喘息多唾).*

**Qìchōng (气冲):**
Govern *severe watery edema (大气石水).*

**Jiěxī (解溪):**
Govern *wind-induced edema with swelling of the face and elbows (风水面肘肿), and darkened complexion (颜黑).*

**Shànglián (上廉):**
Govern *wind-induced edema with knee swelling (风水膝肿).*

**Sānlǐ (三里):**
Govern *abdominal distension with skin swelling (水腹胀，皮肿).*

**Xiàngǔ (陷谷), Lièquè (列缺):**
Govern *facial and ocular abscesses with swelling (面目痈肿).*
It is also said:
**Lièquè (列缺):**
Govern *profuse sweating with limb swelling (汗出，四肢肿).*

**Líndì (临泣):**
Govern *armpit swelling (腋下肿) and fullness in the chest (胸中满).*

**Dàdūn (大敦):**
Govern *severe abdominal distension (大腹肿胀) and a dull, heavy sensation in the umbilical region (脐腹悒悒).*

**Tiānyòu (天牖):**
Govern *breast swelling (乳肿) and swelling in the supraclavicular fossa (缺盆中肿).*

**Kūnlún (昆仑):**
Govern *lumbar and buttock swelling (腰尻肿), and heel swelling (端跟肿).*

**Qiūxū (丘墟), Yángkuì (阳蹻):**
Govern *armpit swelling (腋下肿), alternating cold and heat (寒热), and neck swelling (颈肿).*

**Qǔquán (曲泉):**
Govern *abdominal swelling (腹肿).*

**Fùliú (复留), Fēnglóng (丰隆):**
Govern *wind reversal with limb swelling (风逆，四肢肿).*

**Yīngǔ (阴谷):**
Govern *alternating cold and heat with unilateral abdominal swelling (寒热，腹偏肿).*

**Wángǔ (完骨), Jùmìng (巨命):**
Govern *head, facial, and elbow swelling (头面气肘肿).*

**Yánglíngquán (阳陵泉):**
Govern *head and facial swelling (头面肿).*

For **head and eye abscesses with swelling (头目痈肿), retained fluids (留饮), and lateral costal fullness (胸胁支满)**, acupuncture at **Xiàngǔ (陷谷)** to induce bleeding resolves it immediately.

---
**Inability to Eat (不能食病):**
**Fēnglóng (丰隆):**
Govern *inability to eat (不能食).*

**Shímén (石门):**
Govern *loss of appetite (不欲食) and undigested food upon ingestion (谷入不化).*

**Tiānhú (天枢), Lìduì (厉兑), Nèitíng (内庭):**
Govern *undigested food (食不化), loss of appetite (不嗜食), and periumbilical tightness (侠脐急).*

**Wéidào (维道):**
Govern *water-qi in the Triple Burner (三焦有水气) and inability to eat (不能食).*

**Zhōngfēng (中封):**
Govern *jaundiced body with mild heat (身黄有微热) and loss of appetite (不嗜食).*

**Rángǔ (然谷), Nèitíng (内庭), Píshu (脾輸):**
Govern *loss of appetite (不嗜食).*

**Wèishu (胃輸), Shènshu (腎輸):**
Govern *cold distension in the stomach (胃中寒胀), with excessive eating leading to emaciation (食多身赢瘦).*
It is also said:
**Wèishu (胃輸):**
Govern *vomiting of tendons (呕吐筋孪), inability to eat (食不下), and inability to eat (不能食).*

**Dàcháng Shu (大腸輸), Zhōuróng (周荣):**
Govern *inability to eat (食不下) and excessive drinking (喜饮).*

**Yánggāng (阳纲), Qīmén (期门), Shàoshāng (少商), Láogōng (劳宫):**
Govern *inability to eat or drink (饮食不下).*

**Zhāngmén (章門):**
Govern *undigested food and drink (食饮不化), regurgitation after ingestion (入腹还出), internal heat (热中), loss of appetite (不嗜食), dysphagia (苦吞), aversion to the smell of food (闻食臭伤饱), jaundiced body with sour pain (身黄酸疼), and emaciation (赢瘦).*

**Zhōngtíng (中庭), Zhōngfǔ (中府):**
Govern *diaphragmatic cold (膈寒), inability to eat (食不下), and vomiting with regurgitation (呕吐还出).*

**Shídòu (食窦):**
Govern *diaphragmatic rumbling like thunder (膈中雷鸣) and constant gurgling sounds (察察隐隐常有水声).*

**Jùquè (巨阙):**
Govern *diaphragmatic obstruction (膈中不利).*

**Zhōngjí (中极):**
Govern *hunger without ability to eat (饥不能食).*

**Shàngguǎn (上管), Zhōngguǎn (中管):**
Govern *cold-induced inability to eat (寒中伤饱) and undigested food and drink (食饮不化).*

For **undigested food and drink with regurgitation (食饮不化，入腹还出)**, first acupuncture **Xiàguǎn (下管)**, then **Sānlǐ (三里)** for drainage.

For **loss of appetite (不嗜食)**, acupuncture **Rángǔ (然谷)** to induce bleeding makes one immediately hungry.

**Vomiting (呕吐病):**
**Shāngqiū (商丘), Yōumén (幽门), Tōnggǔ (通谷):**
Govern *tendency to vomit (喜呕).*
It is also said:
**Shāngqiū (商丘):**
Govern *spleen deficiency (脾虚), causing cold-induced illness (病寒不乐), excessive sighing (好太息), alternating cold and heat (多寒热), and tendency to vomit (喜呕).*

**Shùfǔ (俞府), Língxū (灵墟), Shéncáng (神藏), Jùquè (巨阙):**
Govern *vomiting with chest fullness (呕吐胸满).*

**Shuàigǔ (率谷):**
Govern *agitation with vomiting (烦满呕吐).*

**Tiānróng (天容):**
Govern *coughing with vomiting of saliva (咳逆呕沫).*

**Wèishu (胃輸), Shènshu (腎輸):**
Govern *vomiting (呕吐).*

**Qǔzé (曲泽):**
Govern *reverse breath with vomiting of saliva (逆气呕涎).*

**Zhōngtíng (中庭), Zhōngfǔ (中府):**
Govern *reverse vomiting with regurgitation (呕逆吐，食下还出).*

**Shímén (石门):**
Govern *vomiting (呕吐).*

**Yánglíngquán (阳陵泉):**
Govern *vomiting of old fluids (呕宿汁) and a dull sensation beneath the heart (心下澹澹).*

**Wéidào (维道):**
Govern *persistent vomiting (呕逆不止).*

**Shàoshāng (少商), Láogōng (劳宫):**
Govern *vomiting (呕吐).*

**Juégǔ (绝骨):**
Govern *vomiting due to heat (病热欲呕).*

**Dàzhōng (大钟), Tàixī (太溪):**
Govern *agitation with heart fullness and vomiting (烦心满，呕).*

**Húnmén (魂门), Yángguān (阳关):**
Govern *persistent vomiting with excessive saliva (呕吐不住，多涎).*

**Yǐnbái (隐白):**
Govern *diaphragmatic vomiting (膈中呕吐) and loss of appetite (不欲食).*

**Gègè Shu (膈輸):**
Govern *vomiting of food (吐食).*
Also, **moxibustion at Zhāngmén (章门) and Wèiguǎn (胃管).*

**Jùquè (巨阙), Xiōngtáng (胸堂):**
Govern *vomiting of food (吐食).*

**Dàdūn (大敦):**
Govern *hiccoughs (哕噫).*
Also, **moxibustion at Jùguān (巨关).*

**Nèitíng (内庭):**
Govern *frequent yawning with aversion to human sounds (喜频伸数欠，恶闻人音).*

**Hemoptysis (吐血病):**
**Shàngguǎn (上管), Bùróng (不容), Dàlíng (大陵):**
Govern *vomiting of blood (呕血).*

**Xiōngtáng (胸堂), Píshu (脾輸), Shǒuxīnzhǔ (手心主), Jiànshǐ (间使), Wèiguǎn (胃管), Tiānhú (天枢), Gānshu (肝輸), Yújì (鱼际), Láogōng (劳宫), Jiāngshu (肩輸), Tàixī (太溪):**
Govern *spitting and vomiting of blood (唾血吐血).*

**Hemoptysis (吐血病) and Related Disorders:**

**Jùnmén (郡门):**
Govern *epistaxis with vomiting of blood (衄血吐血).*

**Wěizhōng (委中), Yǐnbái (隐白):**
Govern *severe, uncontrolled epistaxis (衄血剧不止).*

**Dàquán (大泉), Shéndōng (神门):**
Govern *spitting of blood with shivering (唾血振寒) and vomiting of blood with upward-rising breath (呕血上气).*

**Shǒu Shàoyīn Jì (手少阴郄):**
Govern *vomiting of blood (吐血).*

**Xíngjiān (行间):**
Govern *shortness of breath with vomiting of blood (短气呕血), chest and back pain.*
Also, **moxibustion is strictly forbidden here.**

**Tàichōng (太冲):**
Govern *pale complexion and lips (面唇色白), frequent vomiting of blood (时时呕血), and menorrhagia (女子漏血).*

**Yǒngquán (涌泉):**
Govern *uncontrolled epistaxis (衄血不止).*

**Rángǔ (然谷):**
Govern *coughing with blood in sputum (咳唾有血).*

**Dì Wǔ Huì (地五会):**
Govern *internal depletion with insufficient sputum (内损唾血不足) and external lack of moisture (外无膏泽).*
**Needling depth: three *cùn* (分).**

**Coughing with upward-rising breath and reverse breathing (咳逆上气):**
**Tiānróng (天容), Liánquán (廉泉), Pòhù (魄户), Qìshè (气舍), Chīxī (譩嘻), Fútū (扶突):**
Govern *coughing with upward-rising breath (咳逆上气), dyspnea with spitting of frothy saliva (喘息呕沫), and clenched teeth (齿噤).*
As recorded in *Jiǎ Yǐ (甲乙)*:
- For *severe upward-rising breath (阳气大逆)*, where breath accumulates in the chest, causing distress and shoulder-shaking breath, with violent upward-rising breath, dyspnea, and inability to lie down, use **Tiānróng (天容)**.
- For *upward-rising breath with chest pain (上气胸痛)*, use **Liánquán (廉泉)**.
- For *coughing with upward-rising breath (咳逆上气)*, use **Pòhù (魄户)** and **Qìshè (气舍), Chīxī (譩嘻)**.
- For *hoarseness, throat sounds, dyspnea (咽喉鸣喝喘息)*, use **Fútū (扶突)**.
- For *spitting of frothy saliva (唾沫)*, use **Tiānróng (天容)**.

**Tóuwéi (头维):**
Govern *dyspnea with distress and fullness (喘逆烦满), spitting of frothy saliva (呕沫), and sweating (流汗).*

**Quēpén (缺盆), Xīnshū (心输), Gānshū (肝输), Jùquè (巨阙), Jiūwěi (鸠尾):**
Govern *coughing with blood in sputum (咳唾血).*
Also, **Jiūwěi (鸠尾)** governs *hiccoughs with dyspnea (噫喘), chest fullness with coughing and vomiting (胸满咳呕).*

**Tánzhōng (膻中), Jùquè (巨阙):**
Govern *coughing (咳嗽).*

**Qīmén (期门):**
Govern *coughing with upward-rising breath (咳逆上气).*
As recorded: **Qīmén (期门)** governs *dyspnea (喘逆), inability to lie down comfortably (卧不安席), coughing, and masses beneath the ribs (胁下积聚).*

**Tiānfǔ (天府):**
Govern *upward-rising breath (上气) and dyspnea (喘不得息).*

**Rángǔ (然谷), Tiānquán (天泉), Xiàngǔ (陷谷), Xiōngtáng (胸堂), Zhāngmén (章门), Qǔquán (曲泉), Tiāntū (天突), Yúnmén (云门), Fèishū (肺输), Línqì (临泣), Jiānjǐng (肩井), Fēngmén (风门), Xíngjiān (行间):**
Govern *coughing with upward-rising breath (咳逆).*

**Wéidào (维道):**
Govern *persistent coughing with upward-rising breath (咳逆不止).*

**Fútū (扶突):**
Govern *coughing with upward-rising breath (咳逆上气) and throat sounds (咽中鸣喘).*

**Pòhù (魄户), Zhōngfǔ (中府):**
Govern *lung cold and heat (肺寒热), inability to lie down with labored breathing (呼吸不得卧), coughing with upward-rising breath (咳逆上气), spitting of frothy saliva with dyspnea (呕沫喘气相追逐).*

**Dàbāo (大包):**
Govern *severe dyspnea (大气不得息).*

**Fèishū (肺输), Shènshū (肾输):**
Govern *dyspnea with shortness of breath and myriad diseases (喘咳少气百病).*

**Huòzhōng (或中), Shímén (石门):**
Govern *coughing with upward-rising breath (咳逆上气) and excessive saliva (涎出多唾).*

**Tiānchí (天池):**
Govern *upward-rising breath (上气) and throat sounds (喉呜).*

**Tiāntū (天突), Huágài (华盖):**
Govern *coughing with upward-rising breath (咳逆上气) and sudden dyspnea (喘暴).*

**Zǐgōng (紫宫), Yùtáng (玉堂), Tàixī (太溪):**
Govern *coughing with upward-rising breath (咳逆上气) and heart distress (心烦).*

**Tánzhōng (膻中), Huágài (华盖):**
Govern *shortness of breath with inability to lie down (短气不得息) and speechlessness (不能言).*

**Shūfǔ (输府), Shéncáng (神藏):**
Govern *coughing with upward-rising breath (咳逆上气) and dyspnea (喘不得息).*

**Huòzhōng (或中), Yúnmén (云门):**
Govern *coughing with upward-rising breath (咳逆上气), spitting of excessive frothy saliva (漾出多唾), labored breathing with palpitations (呼吸喘悸), and inability to lie down comfortably (坐不安席).*

**Bùláng (步郎), Āndū (安都):**
Govern *blockage above the diaphragm (膈上不通), shortness of breath with labored breathing (呼吸少气喘息).*

**Qìhù (气户), Yúnmén (云门), Tiānfǔ (天府), Shéndōng (神门):**
Govern *dyspnea (喘逆上气), labored breathing with shoulder-shaking breath (呼吸肩息), and loss of taste for food (不知食味).*

**Xiábái (侠白):**
Govern *coughing (咳), dry heaves with distress and fullness (乾呕烦满).*

**Kùfáng (库房), Zhōngfǔ (中府), Zhōuróng (周荣), Chǐzé (尺泽):**
Govern *coughing with upward-rising breath (咳逆上气), labored breathing with sputum (呼吸多唾浊沫脓血).*
As recorded: **Zhōngfǔ (中府)** governs *lung system urgency (肺系急), where coughing immediately causes chest pain (咳辄胸痛).*

**Shǎohǎi (少海):**
Govern *upward-rising breath with labored breathing (气逆呼吸), hiccoughs (噫哕), and vomiting (呕).*

**Jīngqú (经渠), Xíngjiān (行间):**
Govern *frequent coughing (喜咳).*
As recorded: **Jīngqú (经渠)** governs *coughing with upward-rising breath (咳逆上气), dyspnea (喘), and warmth in the palm (掌中热).*

**Dàlíng (大陵), Shǎoshāng (少商):**
Govern *coughing with upward-rising breath (咳逆) and dyspnea (喘).*
As recorded: **Dàlíng (大陵)** governs *coughing with upward-rising breath (咳逆), cold and heat symptoms (寒热发).*

**Láogōng (劳宫):**
Govern *upward-rising breath with persistent hiccoughs (气逆，噫不止).*

**Dàquán (大泉):**
Govern *coughing with upward-rising breath (咳逆), chest fullness (胸满), and dyspnea (喘不得息).*

**Sānlǐ (三里):**
Govern *coughing with excessive sputum (咳嗽多唾).*

**Zhīgōu (支沟):**
Govern *coughing (咳), facial flushing with heat (面赤而热).*

**Jiāngshū (肩输):**
Govern *upward-rising breath (上气).*

**Qiángǔ (前谷):**
Govern *coughing with chest fullness (咳而胸满).*

**Qǔzé (曲泽):**
Govern *bleeding resolves sudden coughing with upward-rising breath (卒咳逆，逆气).*

**Coughing with sputum (咳唾):**
For *persistent coughing (噫善咳)* where breath has no outlet, first use **Sānlǐ (三里)**, then **Tàibái (太白), Zhāngmén (章门).**

**Pīntuán Qì (贲豚气):**
**Zhāngmén (章门), Shímén (石门), Yīnjiāo (阴交):**
Govern *abdominal distension with upward-rising breath (贲豚上气).*
As recorded in *Jiǎ Yǐ (甲乙)*:
- For *abdominal distension with gasping (贲豚腹肿)*, use **Zhāngmén (章门)**.
- For *upward-rising breath with abdominal distension (贲豚气上)*, causing *abdominal tension and pain (腹腆坚), pain radiating to the genital region (痛引阴中), inability to urinate (不得小便), and testicular discomfort (两丸骞)*, where symptoms first draw toward the waist and then the lower abdomen, with *firm pain in the waist and lower abdomen (腰臗小腹坚痛)*, use **Shímén (石门)**.
- For *upward-rising breath with abdominal distension (贲豚气上)*, causing *abdominal tension and pain (腹腆坚), pain radiating to the genital region (痛引阴中), inability to urinate (不得小便), and testicular discomfort (两丸骞)*, use **Yīnjiāo (阴交)**.

**Guānyuán (关元):**
Govern *abdominal distension with cold breath entering the lower abdomen (贲豚，寒气入小腹).*

**Qīmén (期门):**
Govern *abdominal distension with symptoms both above and below (贲豚上下).*

**Guīlái (归来):**
Govern *abdominal distension where symptoms draw upward from the scrotum (贲豚，卵上入，引茎痛).*

**Zhōngjí (中极):**
Govern *abdominal distension with upward-rising breath causing heart distress (贲豚上抢心), severe cases leading to inability to lie down (甚则不得息).*

**Tiānhú (天枢):**
Govern *abdominal distension with hernias (贲豚胀疝).*
As recorded in *Jiǎ Yǐ (甲乙)*: For *gasping with hiccoughs and vomiting (气疝哕呕), facial swelling (面肿), and abdominal distension (贲豚).*

**Hand Diseases:**

**Yìmén (掖门):**
Govern *pain in the arm (手臂痛).*

**Jùquè (巨阙):**
Govern *palm coldness (手清).*

**Jiānzhēn (肩贞):**
Govern *inability to raise the shoulder (手髍小不举).*

**Yīnjiāo (阴交):**
Govern *hand and foot stiffness (手脚拘挛).*

**Shàoshāng (少商):**
Govern *numbness in the hand (手不仁).*

**Lièquē (列缺):**
Govern *heat in the arm and body (手臂身热).*

**Dàlíng (大陵):**
Govern *hand contraction preventing extension (手挛不伸).*
Also governs: *hand spasms with slight deviation (手掣小偏).*

**Nèiguān (内关):**
Govern *hand wind-heat (手中风热).*

**Jiānshǐ (间使):**
Govern *arm pain (手痛).*

**Qūzé (曲泽):**
Govern *hand’s reverse *qi* (手青逆气).*

**Zhōngchōng (中冲), Láogōng (劳宫), Shàochōng (少冲), Dàquán (大泉), Jīngqú (经渠), Lièquē (列缺):**
Govern *palm heat and elbow pain (手掌热，肘中痛).*

**Qiángè (前腋):**
Govern *arm wrapping contraction (臂裹挛急), inability to raise the hand (手不上举).*

**Chǐzé (尺泽):**
Govern *spasmodic pain preventing hand extension (掣痛，手不可伸).*

**Shénmén (神门), Shàohǎi (少海):**
Govern *arm contraction (手臂挛).*

**Yǎnglǎo (养老):**
Govern *inability to move the hand up and down (手不得上下).*

**Nèitíng (内庭):**
Govern *the four *jüés* (四厥), hand and foot numbness (手足闷).*

**Wànǔgǔ (腕骨), Zhōngzhǔ (中渚):**
Govern *spasms in the five fingers preventing flexion and extension (五指掣，不可屈伸).*

**Qūchí (曲池):**
Govern *inability to lift heavy objects with the hand (手不可举重), wrist stiffness (腕急), elbow pain (肘中痛), difficulty in flexion and extension (难屈伸).*
Also governs: *inability to raise the hand (手不举).*

**Yángxī (阳溪):**

Govern *tendon tension, hands drawing together (筋急，手相引).*

Govern *armpit contraction (腋挛).*

**Tiānjǐng (天井), Wàiguān (外关), Qūchí (曲池):**
Govern *arm paralysis and numbness (臂痿不仁).*

Govern *pain along the inner side of the arm (臂内廉痛).*

Govern *arm pain (臂痛).*

**Dìwǔhuì (地五会), Yángfú (阳辅), Shēnmài (申脉), Wěiyáng (委阳), Tiānchí (天池), Línqì (临泣):**
Govern *armpit swelling (腋下肿).*

Govern *shoulder and back pain (肩背痛).*

**Gěshū (膈输), Lùnxī (论嘻), Jīngmén (京门), Chǐzé (尺泽):**
Govern *coldness and stiffness in the shoulder and back (肩背寒痓), pain along the inner side of the shoulder blade (肩胛内廉痛).*

**Lièquē (列缺):**

In cases of excess: *shoulder and back heat, sweating, sudden limb swelling (四肢暴肿);*
In cases of deficiency: *shoulder coldness with shivering, insufficient breath for respiration (气不足以息).*

**Shéndào (神道), Gǔzhōng (谷中), Yāoshū (腰输), Chángqiáng (长强), Dàzhù (大杼), Gègūan (膈关), Shuǐfēn (水分), Píshū (脾输), Xiǎochángshū (小肠输), Pángguāngshū (膀胱输):**
Govern *lumbar and spinal rigidity (腰脊急强).*

**Yāoshū (腰输), Pángguāngshū (膀胱输), Chángqiáng (长强), Qìchōng (气冲), Shàngxiāo (上窌), Xiàxiāo (下窌), Jūliáo (居髎):**
Govern *lumbar pain (腰痛).*

**Zhìshì (志室), Jīngmén (京门):**
Govern *lumbar pain and spinal rigidity (腰痛脊急).*

Govern *lumbar and spinal hernia pain (腰脊疝痛).*

**Cìxiāo (次窌), Bāohuāng (胞肓), Chéngjīn (承筋):**

**Sānlǐ (三里), Yīnshì (阴市), Yángfú (阳辅), Lìgōu (蠡沟):**
Govern *lumbar pain preventing turning of the head (腰痛不可以顾).*
Also: **Yángfú (阳辅)** governs *lumbar pain as if struck by a hammer (腰痛如锤居中), swelling and pain preventing coughing (肿痛，不可以咳), coughing causing tendon contraction and joint pain (咳则筋缩急，诸节痛), pain shifting unpredictably (上下无常), with cold and heat.*

**Shùgǔ (束骨), Fēiyáng (飞扬), Chéngjīn (承筋):**
Govern *lumbar pain as if broken (腰痛如折).*

**Shēnmài (申脉), Tàichōng (太冲), Yángkuī (阳蹻):**
Govern *lumbar pain preventing elevation (腰痛不能举).*

**Kūnlún (昆仑):**
Govern *spinal rigidity, heaviness in the lower back and buttocks (脊强，背尻骨重).*

**Héyáng (合阳):**
Govern *lumbar and spinal pain radiating to the abdomen (腰脊痛引腹).*

**Wěizhōng (委中):**
Govern *lumbar pain with a sensation of impending collapse along the spine to the head (侠脊至头几几然), for cases of heavy lumbar and leg pain—acupuncture and bleeding here resolves chronic and stubborn conditions (凡腰脚重痛，於此刺出血，久痼宿疹亦皆立已).*

**Dàzhōng (大钟):**
Govern *lumbar and spinal pain.*

**Wěiyáng (委阳), Yīnmén (殷门):**
*[From *Jiǎ-Yǐ*]*—Govern *lumbar pain allowing bending but preventing standing upright (腰痛得俯不得仰).*

**Tàibái (太白), Yīnlíngquán (阴陵泉), Xíngjiān (行间):**
Govern *lumbar pain preventing bending or standing upright (腰痛不可俯仰).*

**Fúchéng (扶承):**
Govern *lumbar, spinal, sacral, and buttock pain with cold and numbness (腰脊尻臀股阴寒痛).*

**Yǒngquán (涌泉):**
Govern *lumbar and spinal pain radiating as if loosening (腰脊相引如解).*
*[From *Jiǎ-Yǐ*]*—Govern *lumbar pain with difficult defecation (腰痛大便难).*

**Yīngǔ (阴谷):**
Govern *pain along the inner spine (脊内廉痛).*

**Fùfèn (附分):**
Govern *back pain radiating to the head (背痛引头).*

**Gègūan (膈关), Zhìbiān (秩边), Jīnggǔ (京骨):**
Govern *back aversion to cold, pain, and spinal rigidity, with difficulty bending or standing upright (背恶寒痛脊强，难以俯仰).*

**Jīngmén (京门):**
*[From *Jiǎ-Yǐ*]*—Govern *lumbar pain preventing prolonged standing (腰痛不可以久立).*
**Shígūan (石关):**
Govern *spinal spasm with inverted curvature (脊痉反折).*

**Tàixī (太溪), Cìwò (次窌), Liángguāngshū (脸胱输):**
Govern *foot numbness and cold (足清不仁).*
*[Also stated:]*
**Tàixī (太溪):**
Govern *hands and feet cold to the joints (手足寒至节).*

**Dìcāng (地仓), Dàquán (大泉):**
Govern *foot atrophy and inability to walk (足痿璧不能行).*

**Guāngmíng (光明):**

**Huánjiào (环跳), Shùgǔ (束骨), Jiāoxìn (交信), Yīnjiāo (阴交), Yīnshè (阴舍):**

**Shēnmài (申脉), Yǐnbái (隐白), Xíngjiān (行间):**
Govern *pelvic cold and heat (腔中寒热).*

**Tàichōng (太冲), Yǒngquán (涌泉):**
Govern *meridian sourness (经酸).*

**Fùyáng (付阳):**

**Zhìyīn (至阴):**

Govern *meridian pain with heavy limbs, shortness of breath, and difficulty speaking (经疼四肢重，少气难言).*

**Yǒngquán (涌泉), Rángǔ (然谷):**

*For hip-joint pain preventing elevation, use a fine needle with cold retention, applying the waxing-waning moon’s life-death cycle as the breath count—immediate resolution follows.*

**Dúbí (犊鼻):**
Govern *knee pain and numbness (膝中痛不仁).*

Govern *knee numbness and difficulty kneeling (主膝不仁，难跪).*

**Zhōngfēng (中封):**
Govern *shortness of breath, body heaviness due to dampness, knee swelling, and anterior inner ankle pain (少气身重湿，膝肿，内踝前痛).*

**Jiěxī (解溪), Tiáokǒu (条口), Qiūxū (丘墟), Tàibái (太白):**

**Xīgūan (膝关):**

*For swelling at *Dúbí (犊鼻)*, moxibustion is permissible but acupuncture is forbidden. If the area above hardens, do not treat aggressively—aggression may be fatal.*

Govern *severe wind-induced mania (狂易大风).*

**Línqì (临泣):**

*[From *Jiǎ-Yǐ*]*—Govern *pain in the outer canthus of the eye (目外眦痛).*

Govern *flaccid paralysis (痿厥)* and *wind-induced occipital heaviness (风头重痛).*

*[From *Jiǎ-Yǐ*]*—Govern *Zhàohǎi (照海),* which governs *severe wind-induced seizures (大风),* with *silent, unlocalized pain (默默不知所痛),* and *visual disturbances resembling stars (视如见星).*

**Nèiguān (内关):**
Govern *wind-induced heat in the hands (手中风热).*

**Jiànshǐ (间使):**
Govern *wind-induced heat in the head and body (头身风热).*

**Shāngyáng (商阳):**
Govern *wind-induced disorders in the ears (耳中风生).*

**Guānjīng (关冲):**
Govern *facial blackness and thirst due to wind (面黑渴风).*

**Tiānjǐng (天井), Shéndào (神道), Xīnshū (心输):**
Govern *sorrow and melancholy with mental confusion (悲愁恍惚),* and *unrelenting grief (悲伤不乐).*
*[From *Jiǎ-Yǐ*]*—Govern *Tiānjǐng (天井),* which governs *severe wind-induced seizures (大风),* with *silent, unlocalized pain (默默不知所痛),* and *unrelenting grief (悲伤不乐).*

Govern *epileptic seizures with abdominal retraction (瘈疭裹急),* and *lumbar and abdominal pain (腰腹相引).*

Govern *wind-induced body coldness (风身寒).*

**Yěmén (掖门):**
Govern *wind-induced cold and heat (风寒热).*

**Shàngguān (上关):**

**Píshū (脾输), Pángguāngshū (膀胱输):**

**Qǔchí (曲池), Lièquē (列缺):**

**Diānjí (癫疾):**

*[From *Jiǎ-Yǐ*]*—Govern *Tiānjǐng (天井),* which governs *sudden epileptic seizures with dizziness (卒暴痫眩).*

**Rushing Yang (冲阳), Abundant隆 (丰隆):**

**Sudden Corpse Coma (卒尸厥):**
**Hidden White (隐白), Great Thrust (大敦):**
Govern *sudden corpse coma where the patient is unaware of their surroundings (卒尸厥不知人),* yet *their pulse remains active as before (脉动如故).*

**Middle Extremity (中极), Falling Parameter (仆参):**
Govern *disorientation and corpse coma with distress and pain (恍惚尸厥烦痛).*

Govern *four types of coma (四厥):*
- For *numbness in the hands and feet that persists (手足闷者久持之),*
- For *coma with heat, headache, and abdominal distension (厥热脑痛, 腹胀皮痛者),*
*(Note: "皮痛" refers to pain in the skin or superficial tissues, often indicating heat or inflammation.)*

**Armpit Gate (掖门), Retention Gate (注市):**
*(Located beneath the armpit, four ribs down, level with the nipple, two inches behind the nipple in a depression; colloquially called "Retention Market" (注市). When taking, raise the armpit; puncture five divisions deep, moxibustion fifty cones.)*
Govern *sudden coma (卒中恶), sudden corpse coma (飞尸遁注), and fullness in the chest and sides (胸胁满).*

**Nine Twists Convergence (九曲中府):**
*(Located three inches below Retention Market (注市); puncture five divisions deep, moxibustion thirty cones.)*
Govern *sudden coma due to evil wind and pathogenic qi (恶风邪气遁尸),* and *internal stagnation of blood (内有瘀血).*

**Acupuncture and Moxibustion Points for Heat Diseases (第五 热病)**

**Fish Intersection (鱼际), Yang Valley (阳谷):**
Treats heat diseases—shivering, neck rigidity, abdominal fullness, impotence, and unchanged complexion.

**Channel Gorge (经渠), Yang Pool (阳池), Union Valley (合谷), Branch Gully (支沟), Front Valley (前谷), Inner Courtyard (内庭), Rear Ravine (后溪), Wrist Bone (腕骨), Yang Valley (阳谷), Severe Junction (厉兑), Rush Yang (冲阳), Dissolving Ravine (解溪):**
Treats heat diseases where sweating does not occur.

**Kongzui (孔最):**
Treats arm heat and pain with no sweating; all may be treated with moxibustion or acupuncture to induce sweating.

**Listening Gap (列缺), Crooked Pool (曲池):**
Treats heat diseases with restlessness, chest oppression, initial heat in arms and body, *zhi* (瘈) and *di* (疭), lip and mouth twitching, flared nostrils, and sweating from under the eyes like pearls.
*The *Jia-Yi* (甲乙) text states:* Below the nipples, two inches inward, with fullness and palpitations in the flanks.

**Central Convergence (中冲), Labor Palace (劳宫), Great Mound (大陵), Interval Messenger (间使), Pass Rush (关冲), Lesser Rush (少冲), Yang Ravine (阳溪), Heaven’s Cavern (天窌):**
Treats heat diseases with restlessness, chest oppression, and no sweating; palm heat, heart pain, body heat like fire, pervasive fullness, and root-of-tongue pain.
*Additionally:* Interval Messenger (间使) treats heat diseases with restlessness, hiccups, chest heaviness, and preference for movement and heat.
*Labor Palace (劳宫)* treats heat diseases where sweating fails to appear after three days, with dread and anxiety.
*The *Jia-Yi* text states:* Treats heat diseases with fullness and vomiting, where sweating fails after three days, causing dread, inability to turn sides, coughing, fullness, dysuria, bloody urine, incessant urination, vomiting, blood inversion, hiccups, chest pain, inability to eat, and tongue ulceration; palm heat and vomiting.
*Three Intervals (三间):*
Treats body heat with dyspnea and feverishness.
*The *Jia-Yi* text states:* Alternating chills and fever, dry mouth, body heat, dyspnea, eye pain, and susceptibility to fright.

**Crooked Marsh (曲泽):**
Treats febrile and warm diseases with body heat, restlessness, dry mouth.
*The *Jia-Yi* text states:* A dull, frightened heart, body heat, restlessness, dry mouth, clear hands, inverted *qi* causing vomiting and spitting, elbow *zhi* (瘈) with shaking, clear forehead, sweating not reaching the eyebrows; governs injury by cold and *yùn* (愠) diseases.

**Crooked Pool (曲池):**
Treats residual heat from injury by cold.

**Armpit Gate (掖门), Middle Ford (中渚), Through Logic (通理):**
Treats heat diseases with initial discontent, headache, facial heat, and no sweating.
*Additionally:* Through Logic (通理) treats heat diseases with prolonged initial discontent.

**Receiving Saliva (承浆):**
Treats sweating with incessant epistaxis.

**Warm Retention (温留):**
Treats injury by cold with alternating chills and fever, headache, hiccups, and inability to raise shoulders.

**Upper Canal (上管), Crooked Difference (曲差), Upper Star (上星), Potter’s Path (陶道), Heavenly Pillar (天柱), Upper Command (上命), Suspended Lime (悬厘), Wind Pool (风池), Life Gate (命门), Bladder Convergence (膀胱输):**
Treat fullness and inability to sweat.

**Flying Yang (飞扬):**
Treats lower body chills and fever, inability to sweat, and body heaviness.

**Five Treatments (五处), Gathered Bamboo (攒竹), Correcting Camp (正营), Upper Canal (上管), Hollow Basin (缺盆), Middle Palace (中府):**
Treat sweating with alternating chills and fever.

**Great Gap (巨阙):**
Treats restlessness and vomiting.
*The *Jia-Yi* text states:* Abdominal distension and belching; restlessness, vomiting, and obstruction in the diaphragm.

**Hundred Meetings (百会):**
Treats sweating with vomiting and *zhuò* (痓).

**Commerce Hill (商丘):**
Treats alternating chills and fever with a tendency to vomit.

**Suspended Skull (悬颅):**
Treats heat diseases with headache and body heat.

**Lesser Translation (少译):**
Treats shivering, inability to use the little finger, and headache.

**Jade Pillow (玉枕), Great Pivot (大杼), Liver Convergence (肝输), Heart Convergence (心输), Diaphragm Convergence (膈输), Potter’s Path (陶道):**
Treat inability to sweat, shivering, and aversion to cold.

**Great Spine (大椎):**
Treats intense heat in injury by cold with restlessness and vomiting.

**Suspended Dong (悬董), Crow’s Tail (鸠尾):**
Treat heat diseases with unilateral headache radiating to the outer canthus.

**Diaphragm Convergence (膈输), Middle Palace (中府):**
Treat alternating chills and fever with skin, flesh, and bone pain, shortness of breath preventing sleep, and flank fullness.
*Additionally:* Diaphragm Convergence (膈输) treats excessive sleepiness, reluctance to move, body dampness, and inability to eat.

**Listening Gap (列缺):**
Treats alternating chills and fever with palm heat.

**Spirit Path (神道), Close Gate (关元):**
Treat body heat, headache, and inability to move forward or backward.

**Crooked Spring (曲泉):**
Treats body heat, headache, and inability to sweat.

**Triple Burner Convergence (三焦输):**
Treats headache and inability to eat.

**Fish Intersection (鱼际):**
Treats mild headache with sweating.

**Heavenly Well (天井):**
Treats shivering and neck pain.

**Kidney Convergence (肾输):**
Treats body and head heat with redness, shivering, lumbar and limb dampness, and vomiting.

**Shoulder Well (肩井), Pass Rush (关冲):**
Treat alternating chills and fever with shivering, *qi* ascending and preventing sleep.

**Elbow Marsh (尺泽):**
Treats inverted *qi* with vomiting, neck rigidity, and inability to sweat; restlessness and body pain.

**Shoulder Sincerity (肩贞):**
Treats alternating chills and fever with neck stiffness.
*The *Jia-Yi* text states:* Tinnitus with hearing loss, radiating heat and pain from the hollow basin to the shoulder, numbness, and inability to lift.

**Commission Middle (委中):**
Treats heat diseases with lumbar pain.

**Rush Yang (冲阳):**
Treats shivering with yawning.

**Great Metropolis (大都):**
Treats heat diseases with sweating and *jue* (厥), cold feet.
*The *Wai Kui* (外奎) text states:* Inability to sweat with cold hands and feet.

**Great White (太白):**
Treats heat diseases with initial head heaviness, facial pain, restlessness, body heat, and lumbar pain from *qi* conflict, preventing bending or stretching.
*Additionally:* Heat diseases with fullness, inability to sleep, body heaviness, and bone pain without relief.

**Support Correct (支正), Lesser Sea (少海):**
Treat heat diseases with initial lumbar sourness, thirst, frequent eating and drinking, body heat, neck stiffness, and strength; alternating chills and fever.
*The *Jia-Yi* text states:* Treats alternating chills and fever, neck swelling; if excess, elbow contracture and headache; if deficient, warts or small scabs.

**Rear Ravine (后溪):**
Treats body heat with aversion to cold.

**Brightness (光明):**
Treats cold feet and inability to sweat.

**Reversed Retention (复留):**
Treats alternating chills and fever with no comfort, incessant sweating, wind inversion, and limb swelling.

**General Treatments for Heat Diseases:**
For heat diseases with restlessness, cold feet, and excessive sweating, first take *Ran Valley* (然谷), then *Great Creek* (太溪), and the pulsating artery between the big toes—all should first be reinforced.

---

**Heat Diseases (热病):**
First, lumbar and tibial sourness [腰胫酸], thirst [喜渴], and frequent drinking [数饮]. The body feels cool [身清]; if cool, the neck is stiff [项痛], cold and sour [而寒且酸], with hot feet [足热] that refuse to speak [不欲言], and a headache that makes one toss about [颠颠然]. First take *Gushing Spring* (涌泉) and *Great Yang Well* (太阳井), *Rong* (荣). For heat diseases with little *qi* and sudden chills [热中少气厥寒], moxibustion [灸] will drive away the heat [热去]; moxibustion of *Gushing Spring* (涌泉) three times [三壮].

Restlessness [烦心] and lack of appetite [不嗜食], moxibustion of *Gushing Spring* (涌泉).

If the heat departs but *Four Reversals* (四逆) remain—wheezing [喘气], *Pian Feng* (偏风), with sweating [汗出] and coolness [而清]—all take *Spartan Creek* (侠溪).

For heat diseases with body stiffness [身痹] and aversion to washing [洗淅], alternating chills [振寒], and fullness in the *Jì Xié* ribs [季胁支满痛].

For *Wen* diseases (温病), if the body heat persists for five days or more without sweating [汗不出], then prick *Great Spring* (太泉) and leave the needle for one *shi* (时), then remove it. If not yet five days, do not prick.

For those who sigh excessively [好太息], lack appetite [不嗜食], and often experience alternating chills and fever with sweating [多寒热汗出], vomiting when sick [病至则喜呕], and exhaustion after vomiting [呕已乃衰], then take *Gong Sun* (公孙) and *Well* (井), *Output* (输).

If in excess: cutting pain in the intestines [肠中切痛], sudden chills [厥], swelling of the head and face [头面肿起], restlessness [烦心], mania [狂], excessive drinking [多饮], aversion to lying down [不嗜卧];
If deficient: abdominal distension [鼓胀], great fullness in the belly [腹中气大满], heat and pain with no appetite [热痛不嗜食], *Huo Luan* (霍乱), *Gong Sun* (公孙) treats this.
