**Method for Selecting the Point (取穴法):**
Have the patient sit upright, bend their spine, and extend both hands, placing the arms on the knees. Ensure the back is straight, and the large toe of the hand aligns with the kneecap. Use an object to support the elbow, preventing the arm from shaking. From the upper angle of the scapula, feel along until reaching the lower head of the scapula. Between them lies the space of four ribs and three intervals. Moxibustion should be applied to the midpoint, following the hollow between the ribs and the scapular border. Press the lateral side of the ribs, near the scapula, until the patient feels a drawing sensation toward the **chōng** (胸) **hù** (户). Moxibustion should be applied to both scapulae, each for one point, up to six hundred sessions, or even a thousand. The patient should feel **qì** descending with a rumbling sensation like flowing water; something should also be expelled. If there is no lingering **tán** (痰) or old illness, then nothing will be expelled [灸两胛中各一处，至六百壮，多至千壮，当觉气下砻砻然如流水状，亦当有所下出，若无停痰宿疾，则无所下也].

「If the patient is already too weak to sit upright, they should be made to lie on their side, with the upper arm pulled forward to locate and moxibustion the point. To find the point, use the right hand to press from the right shoulder, extending outward until the fingertips reach what the shoulder cannot; the same applies to the left hand. Then, apply moxibustion as before.

If the patient cannot maintain a prolonged upright sitting position with arms extended, they may instead lie face down with a cloth covering the upper back, arms extended forward. Have someone pull apart the scapulae to expose the point, for if not done so, the overlapping scapular point cannot be accessed. The covering cloth must be consistently adjusted to the proper size, otherwise the point will be lost.

Once this moxibustion is completed, the patient’s **yáng qì** (陽氣) should flourish. They should then regulate their breathing and practice self-nourishment, restoring their body to balance. The point is located near the fifth vertebra, viewed from above.

The text states: In ancient times, Qin Huan failed to cure Jin Hou’s illness because the affliction lay above the **gāo** (膏) and below the **huāng** (肓), beyond the reach of acupuncture and medicine—this is precisely the point in question. At that time, people lacked the skill to locate it, which is why chronic illnesses were difficult to dispel. If one applies diligence and finds this point to perform moxibustion, no illness will fail to heal.

**Sān Lǐ** (三里), also known as **Zhōngwǎn** (中腕), governs abdominal cold, distension, intestinal rumbling, abdominal pain, stagnant blood in the chest and abdomen, lower abdominal distension, skin swelling, insufficient **yīn qì** (陰氣), hardness of the lower abdomen, feverish illness with inability to sweat, frequent vomiting, bitter taste, intense heat, body inversion, clenched jaw with bulging neck, lumbar pain preventing turning of the head, dizziness upon turning, alternating joy and sorrow, and its location is sought above and below. It also treats:

- **kǒu pì** (口僻) and **rǔ zhǒng** (乳痈), throat obstruction rendering speech impossible, insufficient stomach **qì**, chronic diarrhea, inability to digest food, **zhuì xià zhù mǎn** (胁下柱满) preventing prolonged standing, knee weakness with alternating cold and heat, aversion to food with intense hunger, abdominal heat causing restlessness and wild speech, **rǔ zhǒng** (乳痈), frequent sighing, distaste for food odors, manic singing and laughter, sudden anger with loud cursing, cholera with urinary incontinence, loss of **qì** leading to **yáng jué** (陽厥), chills with vertigo, difficult urination, and frequent hiccups.

All these ailments are treated by moxibustion or needling, with sessions ranging from as few as two or three hundred to as many as five hundred.

**Yǒng Quán** (涌泉) governs frequent shortness of breath, throat obstruction, body heat and pain, lumbar and lateral discomfort, sudden dizziness with forgetfulness, **yīn zhì** (陰痹) with abdominal distension, lumbar pain, difficult defecation, shoulder, back, neck, and occipital pain, intermittent vertigo, men resembling **wù** (蛊) toxicity in males, and **zǔ** (阻) in females, body stiffness like being bound, loss of appetite, reverse breathing, coldness extending from the feet to the knees, throat pain preventing ingestion, hoarseness with inability to speak, difficult urination, lower abdominal pain, wind entering the intestines, **diān zhì** (癫疾), sudden umbilical pain, **xié xià zhù mǎn** (胁下柱满) with chest and lateral discomfort, incessant nosebleeds, **wǔ shàn** (五疝), pain throughout the fingertips, and inability to step on the ground.

All these afflictions are treated by this point. For women, it governs the eighth illness.»

Lower abdominal rigidity and pain, obstructed menses—acupuncture **Dài Mài** (帶脈) six *cùn* deep, moxibustion five *zhàng*; located at the end of the eighth rib, one *cùn* and eight *fèn* inward. *"End"* is alternatively *"below."*

For uterine bleeding or blood stagnation with obstruction, reverse *qi* distension—acupuncture **Xuě Hǎi** (血海) five *cùn* deep, moxibustion five *zhàng*; located two *cùn* above the inner medial knee, at the junction of white flesh and bone.

For uterine bleeding with lower abdominal distension like obstruction, alternating chills and fever, generalized abdominal swelling—acupuncture **Yīn Gǔ** (陰谷) four *cùn* deep, moxibustion three *zhàng*; located behind the inner knee’s collateral bone, above the large tendon, below the small tendon—found only when the knee is flexed. The *Jiǎ-Yǐ* states: For uterine bleeding with yellow urine, **Yīn Gǔ** governs it.

For female **shàn-jū** (疝瘕), pressing yields a sensation as if hot water were poured between the thighs, lower abdominal swelling, protruding and painful vulva, menstrual discharge, vaginal itching or swelling, or dysmenorrhea with greenish vaginal discharge like pumpkin porridge, blood stagnation with infertility, loss of appetite—acupuncture **Qū Quán** (曲泉) six *cùn* deep, moxibustion three *zhàng*; located below the inner knee’s collateral bone, in the depression between the large and small tendons—found only when the knee is flexed.

For **shàn-jū** where pressing feels like hot water splashed onto the inner thigh down to the knee, chronic diarrhea, vaginal pain, lower abdominal rigidity, severe urgency with dampness, loss of appetite—acupuncture **Yīn Líng Quán** (陰陵泉) two *cùn* deep, moxibustion three *zhàng*; located in the depression below the inner knee’s collateral bone, found only when the foot is extended.

For menstrual inversion, excessive limb *lù* (淫滦), sudden vulvar spasms, **shàn** (疝), lower abdominal lateral pain—acupuncture **Yīn Lì** (陰蹻) three *cùn* deep, moxibustion three *zhàng*; located below the inner malleolus, within the space of a fingernail. This is also the **Zhào Hǎi** (照海) point.

For enlarged lower abdomen, difficulty in urination, dry throat with thirst, lateral umbilical **shàn**—acupuncture **Zhōng Fēng** (中封) four *cùn* deep, moxibustion three *zhàng*; located one *cùn* and a half anterior to the inner malleolus, taken with the foot extended.

For female infertility, sudden vulvar protrusion, uterine bleeding—acupuncture **Rán Gǔ** (然谷) three *cùn* deep, moxibustion three *zhàng*; located in the depression below the medial malleolus, at the base of the large bone.

For infertility, if the placenta does not expel, or if wind leaks from head to foot—acupuncture **Kūn Lún** (昆仑) five *cùn* deep, moxibustion three *zhàng*; located above the heel bone, behind the outer malleolus.

For irregular menses, seeing red and white discharge while pregnant, leading to miscarriage, uterine cold—acupuncture **Xíng Jiān** (行間) six *cùn* deep, moxibustion three *zhàng*; located in the webbing between the big toe and second toe, where pulsation is felt.

For menstrual obstruction with dysuria, rigid spine, mutual pulling and inversion, anhidrosis—acupuncture **Yāo Shū** (腰俞) two *cùn* deep, retain needle for seven breaths, moxibustion three *zhàng*; located below the twenty-first vertebra.

For infertility, intermittent fever, uncontrollable vulvar protrusion, white *lì* (沥), **jué** (痓), spinal inversion—acupuncture **Shàng Liào** (上窌) three *cùn* deep, retain needle for seven breaths, moxibustion three *zhàng*; located one *cùn* below the first lumbar vertebra’s spinous process, lateral to the spine.

For alternating red and white *lì*, subxiphoid accumulation, lumbar pain preventing flexion/extension—acupuncture **Cì Liào** (次窌) three *cùn* deep, retain needle for seven breaths, moxibustion three *zhàng*; located in the depression of the second lumbar vertebra, lateral to the spine.

For red *lì* with intermittent white *lì*, *qi* stagnation, scanty menses—acupuncture **Zhōng Mìng** (中命) two *cùn* deep, retain needle for seven breaths, moxibustion three *zhàng*; located in the depression of the third lumbar vertebra, lateral to the spine.

For uncontrollable greenish vaginal discharge, red *lì*, vaginal itching and pain radiating to the lower abdomen, inability to bend—acupuncture the **Yāo Yàn Jiāo Zhě** (腰尻交者), two *cùn* above the sacrum, with needle retention based on lunar phases; immediate relief upon insertion. Alternatively, **Xià Mìng** (下命).

For intestinal rumbling and diarrhea—acupuncture **Xià Liào** (下窌) two *cùn* deep, retain needle for seven breaths, moxibustion three *zhàng*; located in the depression of the fourth lumbar vertebra, lateral to the spine.

For urgent red and white *lì*, **dān-dì** (癲疭)—acupuncture **Wǔ Shū** (五枢) one *cùn* deep, moxibustion five *zhàng*; located three *cùn* below **Dài Mài**.

For spasticity, abdominal distension, **shàn**, obstructed menses, postpartum disorders, infertility with vaginal itching, **bēn-tún** (奔豚) surging upward, lower abdominal rigidity, radiating pain to the vulva, inability to urinate—acupuncture **Yīn Jiāo** (陰交) eight *fèn* deep, moxibustion five *zhàng*; located one *cùn* below the umbilicus.

For abdominal distension with **shàn-jū**, postpartum disorders, infertility with vaginal itching, **bēn-tún** surging upward, lower abdominal rigidity, radiating pain to the vulva, inability to urinate—acupuncture **Shí Mén** (石門) five *cùn* deep; located two *cùn* below the umbilicus. *Caution*: Moxibustion contraindicated for pregnancy.

For infertility, retained blood not expelled, inverted uterus preventing urination, lower abdominal fullness, kidney stone pain—acupuncture **Guān Yuán** (關元) two *cùn* deep, moxibustion seven *zhàng*; located three *cùn* below the umbilicus. Also treats rib distension, headache, back heat, **bēn-tún**, cold, frequent urination, uncontrollable diarrhea.

For misaligned **zǐ mén** (子門), lower abdominal cold, vaginal itching and pain, **bēn-tún** assaulting the heart, inability to eat when hungry, abdominal distension, menstrual obstruction, dysuria, postpartum disorders, infertility, internal deficiency—acupuncture **Zhōng Jí** (中極) two *cùn* deep, retain needle for ten breaths, moxibustion three *zhàng*; located four *cùn* below the umbilicus.

For red and white *lì*, vaginal dryness and pain, aversion to intercourse, lower abdominal rigidity, urinary obstruction—acupuncture **Qū Gǔ** (屈骨) one *cùn* and a half deep, moxibustion three *zhàng*; located one *cùn* below **Zhōng Jí**.

For obstructed menses, **bēn-xiè** (奔泄) *qi*, radiating lumbar and spinal pain—acupuncture **Qì Xué** (氣穴) one *cùn* deep, moxibustion five *zhàng*; located one *cùn* below **Sì Mǎn** (四满).

For uterine pain, retained blood, irregular menses, abdominal distension with intestinal rumbling, *qi* surging to the chest—acupuncture **Tiān Shū** (天枢) five *cùn* deep, moxibustion three *zhàng*; located one *cùn* and a half lateral to **Huáng Shū** (肓俞).

For lower abdominal distension with radiating vulvar pain, lumbar and spinal pain during menses, uterine **jū**, empty **zǐ mén**, obstructed urination and defecation—acupuncture **Shuǐ Dào** (水道) two *cùn* and a half deep, moxibustion five *zhàng*; located three *cùn* below **Dà Jū** (大巨).

For irregular or violently obstructed menses, abdominal distension with urinary retention, excessive limb *lù*, fever, difficult lactation, **zǐ** (子) surging to the heart, retained placenta, chaotic *qi*, abdominal twisting pain, inability to lie supine or prone, one knee flexed while the other extends, with *qi* surging upward—insert needle three *cùn* deep and bleed upon *qi* arrival.

Located one *cùn* below **Guī Lái** (歸來), the pulse moves with the touch.

For postpartum illnesses, inability to ingest food or drink, **èi-tān** (贲豚) rising and falling, and food stagnation causing abdominal distension—acupuncture **Qī Mén** (期門) four *fèn* deep, moxibustion five *zhàng*. Located at the end of the second rib.

For breast abscesses, tetany, and shock, heavy menses, inability to flex the foot, heel pain—acupuncture **Xià Lián** (下廉) three *fèn* deep, moxibustion three *zhàng*. Located three *cùn* below **Shàng Lián** (上廉).

For irregular menses, pregnancy upon seeing blood, and breast swelling—acupuncture **Lín Qì** (臨泣) two *fèn* deep, moxibustion three *zhàng*. Located between the second and third toes of the foot, one *cùn* and a half from **Xiá Xī** (侠溪).

For female **shàn** (疝), lower abdominal swelling, loose stools, urinary retention, enuresis, vulvar pain, darkened complexion, pain below the eyes, and metrorrhagia—acupuncture **Tài Chōng** (太沖) three *fèn* deep, moxibustion three *zhàng*. Located two *cùn* behind the base joint of the big toe, where the pulse moves.

For female **shàn** (疝), excessive leukorrhea or bloody discharge, intermittent or violent abdominal pain—acupuncture **Lí Gōu** (蠡沟) three *fèn* deep, moxibustion three *zhàng*. Located five *cùn* above the inner ankle.

For childlessness and shortness of breath upon coughing—acupuncture **Yǒng Quán** (涌泉) three *fèn* deep, moxibustion three *zhàng*. Located in the center of the foot’s depression.

For difficult lactation, surging *qi* to the heart, and vulvar **shàn** (疝)—acupuncture **Chōng Mén** (沖門) seven *fèn* deep, moxibustion five *zhàng*. Located below **Fǔ Shě** (府舍), five *cùn* above **Dà Héng** (大横).

For amenorrhea, tetany, excessive sadness, a sensation of falling, and inability to sweat—acupuncture **Zhào Hǎi** (照海) four *fèn* deep, moxibustion two *zhàng*. Located four *fèn* below the inner ankle. Also treats female **lín** (淋), vulvar protrusion, excessive limb *lù* (淫滦), and stagnant blood.

For stagnant blood in the **zǐ zàng** (子脏), internal inversion causing distension and pain—acupuncture **Shí Guān** (石關) one *cùn* deep, moxibustion five *zhàng*. Located one *cùn* below **Yīn Dū** (阴都).

**Huáng Mén** (肓门) treats residual postpartum illnesses.
**Sān Lǐ** (三里) treats breast abscesses with heat.
**Shén Fēng** (神封) and **Yīng Chuāng** (膺窗) treat breast abscesses with alternating cold and heat, shortness of breath, and inability to lie still.
**Rǔ Gēn** (乳根) treats chest swelling and breast abscesses with cold, heat, and unbearable pain upon pressure.

**Dà Xī** (大溪) and **Xiá Xī** (侠溪) treat breast swelling and abscesses.
It is also said: **Xiá Xī** treats lower abdominal rigidity and pain, and obstructed menses.
**Tài Quán** (太泉) treats jealous milk (妬乳) and chest pain.
**Dà Hé** (大赫) treats female **wò** (沃, excessive vaginal discharge).
**Sì Mǎn** (四满) treats stagnant blood in the **zǐ zàng** (子脏), internal inversion causing distension and pain, and **shàn** (疝).
It is also said: treats blood in the **bāo** (胞, uterus).

**Zhōng Jí** (中极) treats constricted **lián** (拘孪), lower abdominal **shàn** (疝), amenorrhea, residual postpartum illnesses, and vulvar itching leading to infertility.
**Qì Chōng** (气冲) treats infertility and lower abdominal pain.
**Zhī Gōu** (支沟) treats female spinal stiffness and red eyes.

**Zhù Bīn** (筑宾) treats severe **shàn** (疝) and infertility.
**Yīn Lián** (阴廉) treats postpartum conditions or those resembling never having given birth.
**Yǒng Quán** (涌泉) and **Yīn Gǔ** (阴谷) treat male symptoms resembling **wù** (蛊, toxic disorder) and female symptoms resembling obstruction, with a sensation of loosening in the waist and spine, and loss of appetite.
**Shuǐ Yuán** (水原) and **Zhào Hǎi** (照海) treat infertility, vulvar protrusion, urinary disorders, amenorrhea with excessive suppression, and substernal pain.
It is also said: **Zhào Hǎi** treats vulvar protrusion with bleeding, vulvar swelling or itching, and discharge resembling cucumber or chrysanthemum juice.

**For pediatric illnesses:**
**Běn Shén** (本神), **Qián Dǐng** (前顶), **Rèn Huì** (囟会), and **Tiān Zhù** (天柱) treat infantile convulsions and tetany.
**Lín Qì** (臨泣) treats infantile convulsions with reversed gaze.
**Lú Xī** (颅息) treats infantile seizures with dyspnea.
**Rán Gǔ** (然谷) treats infantile umbilical wind, inability to open the mouth, and excessive startling.
**Chì Mài** (瘈脉) and **Cháng Qiáng** (长强) treat infantile convulsions, tetany, vomiting, diarrhea, fear-induced loss of essence, blurred vision, and eye discharge.
**Xuán Zhōng** (悬钟) treats infantile abdominal distension with inability to eat or drink.
**Xiào Xī** (譩嘻) treats infantile headache from eating spoiled food.

*(End of Chapter 93 from Sun Simiao’s Essential Prescriptions Worth a Thousand Gold for Emergencies)*
